1:1:1/In the beginning, God created the heavens and the earth.
1:1:2/The earth was formless and empty; darkness covered the deep waters. And the Spirit of God was hovering over the surface of the waters.
1:1:3/Then God said, "Let there be light," and there was light.
1:1:4/God saw that the light was good, and He separated the light from the darkness.
1:1:5/God named the light "Day" and the darkness "Night." The evening passed and the morning came, marking the first day.
1:1:6/Then God said, "Let there be a space between the waters, to separate the waters of the heavens from the waters of the earth."
1:1:7/So God made the space and separated the water under the space from the water above it. And it happened just like that.
1:1:8/God called the space "Sky." The evening passed and the morning came, marking the second day.
1:1:9/Then God said, "Let the waters beneath the sky flow together into one place, so dry ground may appear." And that is what happened.
1:1:10/God called the dry ground "Land" and the gathered waters "Seas." And God saw that it was good.
1:1:11/Then God said, "Let the land sprout with vegetation—every sort of seed-bearing plant, and trees that grow seed-bearing fruit. These seeds will then produce the kinds of plants and trees from which they came." And that is what happened.
1:1:12/The land produced vegetation: plants bearing seeds according to their kinds and trees bearing fruit with seed in it according to their kinds. And God saw that it was good.
1:1:13/The evening passed and the morning came, marking the third day.
1:1:14/Then God said, "Let lights appear in the sky to separate the day from the night. Let them be signs to mark the seasons, days, and years.
1:1:15/Let these lights in the sky shine down on the earth." And that is what happened.
1:1:16/God made two great lights—the larger one to govern the day, and the smaller one to govern the night. He also made the stars.
1:1:17/God set these lights in the sky to light the earth,
1:1:18/to govern the day and night, and to separate the light from the darkness. And God saw that it was good.
1:1:19/The evening passed and the morning came, marking the fourth day.
1:1:20/Then God said, "Let the waters swarm with fish and other life. Let the skies be filled with birds of every kind."
1:1:21/So God created great sea creatures and every living thing that scurries and swarms in the water, and every sort of bird—each producing offspring of the same kind. And God saw that it was good.
1:1:22/Then God blessed them, saying, "Be fruitful and multiply. Let the fish fill the seas, and let the birds multiply on the earth."
1:1:23/The evening passed and the morning came, marking the fifth day.
1:1:24/Then God said, "Let the earth produce every sort of animal, each producing offspring of the same kind—livestock, small animals that scurry along the ground, and wild animals." And that is what happened.
1:1:25/God made all sorts of wild animals, livestock, and small animals, each able to produce offspring of the same kind. And God saw that it was good.
1:1:26/Then God said, "Let us make human beings in our image, to be like us. They will reign over the fish in the sea, the birds in the sky, the livestock, all the wild animals on the earth, and the small animals that scurry along the ground."
1:1:27/So God created human beings in his own image. In the image of God he created them; male and female he created them.
1:1:28/Then God blessed them and said, "Be fruitful and multiply. Fill the earth and govern it. Reign over the fish in the sea, the birds in the sky, and all the animals that scurry along the ground."
1:1:29/Then God said, "Look! I have given you every seed-bearing plant throughout the earth and all the fruit trees for your food.
1:1:30/And to all the animals of the earth, all the birds in the sky, and all the creatures that crawl on the earth—everything that has the breath of life in it—I give every green plant for food." And that is what happened.
1:1:31/Then God looked over all he had made, and he saw that it was very good. The evening passed and the morning came, marking the sixth day.
1:2:1/So the heavens and the earth were completed, along with everything in them.
1:2:2/By the seventh day, God had finished the work he had been doing; so on the seventh day, he rested from all his work.
1:2:3/God blessed the seventh day and made it holy, because on it he rested from all the work of creating that he had done.
1:2:4/These are the origins of the heavens and the earth when they were created, at the time when the LORD God made the earth and heavens,
1:2:5/Before any plant of the field was in the earth and before any herb of the field had grown. For the LORD God had not sent rain on the earth, and there was no one to work the soil.
1:2:6/But streams came up from the earth and watered the whole surface of the ground.
1:2:7/Then the LORD God formed a man from the dust of the ground and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life, and the man became a living being.
1:2:8/The LORD God planted a garden in the east, in Eden; and there he put the man he had formed.
1:2:9/And the LORD God made all kinds of trees grow out of the ground—trees that were pleasing to the eye and good for food. In the middle of the garden were the tree of life and the tree of the knowledge of good and evil.
1:2:10/A river watering the garden flowed from Eden; from there it was separated into four headwaters.
1:2:11/The name of the first is Pishon; it winds through the entire land of Havilah, where there is gold.
1:2:12/And the gold of that land is good; aromatic resin and onyx are also there.
1:2:13/The name of the second river is Gihon; it winds through the entire land of Cush.
1:2:14/The name of the third river is Tigris; it runs along the east side of Ashur. And the fourth river is the Euphrates.
1:2:15/The LORD God took the man and put him in the Garden of Eden to work it and take care of it.
1:2:16/And the LORD God commanded the man, "You are free to eat from any tree in the garden;
1:2:17/but you must not eat from the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, for when you eat from it, you will certainly die."
1:2:18/Then the LORD God said, "It is not good for the man to be alone. I will make a helper suitable for him."
1:2:19/Now the LORD God had formed out of the ground all the wild animals and all the birds in the sky. He brought them to the man to see what he would name them; and whatever the man called each living creature, that was its name.
1:2:20/So the man gave names to all the livestock, the birds in the sky and all the wild animals. But for Adam no suitable helper was found.
1:2:21/So the LORD God caused the man to fall into a deep sleep; and while he was sleeping, he took one of the man’s ribs and then closed up the place with flesh.
1:2:22/Then the LORD God made a woman from the rib he had taken out of the man, and he brought her to the man.
1:2:23/The man said, "This is now bone of my bones and flesh of my flesh; she shall be called 'woman,' for she was taken out of man."
1:2:24/That is why a man leaves his father and mother and is united to his wife, and they become one flesh.
1:2:25/Adam and his wife were both naked, and they felt no shame.
1:3:1/Now the serpent was more cunning than any animal of the field that the LORD God had made. He said to the woman, "Did God really say you can't eat from any tree in the garden?"
1:3:2/And the woman said to the serpent, "We can eat the fruit from the trees in the garden:
1:3:3/But about the fruit of the tree in the middle of the garden, God said, 'You must not eat it or even touch it, or you will die.'"
1:3:4/And the serpent said to the woman, "You will not actually die:
1:3:5/For God knows that when you eat from it, your eyes will be opened, and you will be like gods, knowing good and evil."
1:3:6/When the woman saw that the tree was good for food, pleasing to the eye, and desirable for gaining wisdom, she took some of its fruit and ate it. She also gave some to her husband who was with her, and he ate it.
1:3:7/Then both of their eyes were opened, and they realized they were naked; so they sewed fig leaves together and made coverings for themselves.
1:3:8/And they heard the sound of the LORD God walking in the garden in the cool of the day, and Adam and his wife hid from the LORD God among the trees of the garden.
1:3:9/And the LORD God called to Adam and said to him, "Where are you?"
1:3:10/He said, "I heard Your voice in the garden, and I was afraid because I was naked; so I hid."
1:3:11/And He said, "Who told you that you were naked? Have you eaten from the tree that I commanded you not to eat from?"
1:3:12/The man said, "The woman You put here with me—she gave me some fruit from the tree, and I ate it."
1:3:13/Then the LORD God said to the woman, "What is this you have done?" The woman said, "The serpent deceived me, and I ate."
1:3:14/And the LORD God said to the serpent, "Because you have done this, you are cursed more than all livestock and all wild animals; you will crawl on your belly and eat dust all the days of your life.
1:3:15/And I will cause hostility between you and the woman, and between your offspring and hers; he will crush your head, and you will strike his heel."
1:3:16/To the woman He said, "I will greatly increase your pain in childbearing; with pain you will give birth to children. Your desire will be for your husband, and he will rule over you."
1:3:17/To Adam He said, "Because you listened to your wife and ate from the tree about which I commanded you, 'You must not eat from it,' cursed is the ground because of you; through painful toil you will eat food from it all the days of your life.
1:3:18/It will produce thorns and thistles for you, and you will eat the plants of the field.
1:3:19/By the sweat of your brow you will eat your food until you return to the ground, since from it you were taken; for dust you are and to dust you will return."
1:3:20/Adam named his wife Eve, because she would become the mother of all the living.
1:3:21/The LORD God made garments of skin for Adam and his wife and clothed them.
1:3:22/Then the LORD God said, "Look, the human has become like one of us, knowing good and evil. Now, he must not be allowed to reach out his hand and take also from the tree of life and eat, and live forever."
1:3:23/So the LORD God banished him from the Garden of Eden to work the ground from which he had been taken.
1:3:24/Thus He expelled the man; and He placed at the east of the Garden of Eden Cherubim and a flaming sword that turned every way, to guard the way to the tree of life.
1:4:1/Adam was intimate with Eve, his wife; she became pregnant and gave birth to Cain, saying, "I have produced a man with the help of the LORD."
1:4:2/Then she gave birth to his brother Abel. Abel took care of sheep, while Cain worked the soil.
1:4:3/As time went on, Cain brought some of the fruits of the soil as an offering to the LORD.
1:4:4/Abel also brought an offering—the best portions of the firstborn of his flock. The LORD looked with favor on Abel and his offering,
1:4:5/But on Cain and his offering, he did not look with favor. Cain was very angry, and his face was downcast.
1:4:6/The LORD asked Cain, "Why are you angry? Why is your face downcast?
1:4:7/If you do what is right, won't you be accepted? But if you do not do what is right, sin is crouching at your door; it desires to have you, but you must rule over it."
1:4:8/Cain spoke to Abel, his brother. And when they were in the field, Cain attacked Abel, his brother, and killed him.
1:4:9/Then the LORD asked Cain, "Where is Abel, your brother?" He replied, "I don't know. Am I my brother's guardian?"
1:4:10/And He said, "What have you done? The voice of your brother's blood is crying out to me from the ground.
1:4:11/Now you are cursed and cut off from the ground, which has opened its mouth to receive your brother's blood from your hand.
1:4:12/When you work the ground, it will no longer yield its crops for you. You will be a restless wanderer on the earth."
1:4:13/Cain said to the LORD, "My punishment is more than I can bear.
1:4:14/Today you are driving me from the land, and I will be hidden from your presence; I will be a restless wanderer on the earth, and whoever finds me will kill me."
1:4:15/But the LORD said to him, "Not so; anyone who kills Cain will suffer vengeance seven times over." And the LORD put a mark on Cain so that no one who found him would kill him.
1:4:16/So Cain left the LORD's presence and lived in the land of Nod, east of Eden.
1:4:17/Cain was intimate with his wife, and she became pregnant and gave birth to Enoch. Cain then built a city and named it after his son, Enoch.
1:4:18/To Enoch was born Irad, and Irad fathered Mehujael, and Mehujael fathered Methushael, and Methushael fathered Lamech.
1:4:19/Lamech married two women, one named Adah and the other Zillah.
1:4:20/Adah gave birth to Jabal; he was the ancestor of those who live in tents and raise livestock.
1:4:21/His brother's name was Jubal; he was the ancestor of all who play the harp and flute.
1:4:22/And Zillah, she also bore Tubal-Cain, who forged all kinds of tools out of bronze and iron. Tubal-Cain's sister was Naamah.
1:4:23/Lamech said to his wives, "Adah and Zillah, listen to me; wives of Lamech, hear my words. I have killed a man for wounding me, a young man for injuring me.
1:4:24/If Cain is avenged seven times, then Lamech seventy-seven times."
1:4:25/Adam was intimate with his wife again, and she gave birth to a son and named him Seth, saying, "God has granted me another child in place of Abel, since Cain killed him."
1:4:26/To Seth also a son was born, and he named him Enosh. At that time people began to call on the name of the LORD.
1:5:1/This is the record of Adam's descendants. On the day God created humans, He made them to resemble Himself.
1:5:2/He created them male and female, blessed them, and named them "Human" on the day they were created.
1:5:3/Adam lived 130 years and had a son who looked like him, whom he named Seth.
1:5:4/After Seth was born, Adam lived 800 more years and had other sons and daughters.
1:5:5/Adam lived a total of 930 years, and then he died.
1:5:6/Seth lived 105 years and then had Enos.
1:5:7/After Enos was born, Seth lived 807 more years and had other sons and daughters.
1:5:8/Seth lived a total of 912 years, and then he died.
1:5:9/Enos lived 90 years and then had Cainan.
1:5:10/After Cainan was born, Enos lived 815 more years and had other sons and daughters.
1:5:11/Enos lived a total of 905 years, and then he died.
1:5:12/Cainan lived 70 years and then had Mahalaleel.
1:5:13/After Mahalaleel was born, Cainan lived 840 more years and had other sons and daughters.
1:5:14/Cainan lived a total of 910 years, and then he died.
1:5:15/Mahalaleel lived 65 years and then had Jared.
1:5:16/After Jared was born, Mahalaleel lived 830 more years and had other sons and daughters.
1:5:17/Mahalaleel lived a total of 895 years, and then he died.
1:5:18/Jared lived 162 years and then had Enoch.
1:5:19/After Enoch was born, Jared lived 800 more years and had other sons and daughters.
1:5:20/Jared lived a total of 962 years, and then he died.
1:5:21/Enoch lived 65 years and then had Methuselah.
1:5:22/After Methuselah was born, Enoch walked faithfully with God for 300 years and had other sons and daughters.
1:5:23/Enoch lived a total of 365 years.
1:5:24/Enoch walked faithfully with God, and then he disappeared because God took him away.
1:5:25/Methuselah lived 187 years and then had Lamech.
1:5:26/After Lamech was born, Methuselah lived 782 more years and had other sons and daughters.
1:5:27/Methuselah lived a total of 969 years, and then he died.
1:5:28/Lamech lived 182 years and then had a son.
1:5:29/He named him Noah, saying, "He will bring us relief from our work and the painful labor of farming the land cursed by the Lord."
1:5:30/After Noah was born, Lamech lived 595 more years and had other sons and daughters.
1:5:31/Lamech lived a total of 777 years, and then he died.
1:5:32/When Noah was 500 years old, he became the father of Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
1:6:1/When people began to increase in number on the earth and daughters were born to them,
1:6:2/the sons of God noticed that the daughters of humans were beautiful, and they married any of them they chose.
1:6:3/Then the LORD said, "My Spirit will not contend with humans forever, for they are mortal; their days will be a hundred and twenty years."
1:6:4/In those days, and also afterward, when the sons of God went to the daughters of humans and had children by them, they were the heroes of old, men of renown.
1:6:5/And God saw that the wickedness of humans was great on the earth, and that every inclination of the thoughts of their hearts was only evil all the time.
1:6:6/The LORD regretted that he had made human beings on the earth, and his heart was deeply troubled.
1:6:7/So the LORD said, "I will wipe from the face of the earth the human race I have created—and with them the animals, the birds and the creatures that move along the ground—for I regret that I have made them."
1:6:8/But Noah found favor in the eyes of the LORD.
1:6:9/These are the records of Noah: Noah was a righteous man, blameless among the people of his time, and he walked faithfully with God.
1:6:10/Noah had three sons: Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
1:6:11/Now the earth was corrupt in God’s sight and was full of violence.
1:6:12/God saw how corrupt the earth had become, for all the people on earth had corrupted their ways.
1:6:13/So God said to Noah, "I am going to put an end to all people, for the earth is filled with violence because of them. I am surely going to destroy both them and the earth.
1:6:14/Make yourself an ark of cypress wood; make rooms in it and coat it with pitch inside and out.
1:6:15/This is how you are to build it: The ark is to be three hundred cubits long, fifty cubits wide, and thirty cubits high.
1:6:16/Make a roof for it, leaving below the roof an opening one cubit high all around. Put a door in the side of the ark and make lower, second and third decks.
1:6:17/I am going to bring floodwaters on the earth to destroy all life under the heavens, every creature that has the breath of life in it. Everything on earth will perish.
1:6:18/But I will establish my covenant with you, and you will enter the ark—you and your sons and your wife and your sons’ wives with you.
1:6:19/You are to bring into the ark two of all living creatures, male and female, to keep them alive with you.
1:6:20/Two of every kind of bird, of every kind of animal and of every kind of creature that moves along the ground will come to you to be kept alive.
1:6:21/You are to take every kind of food that is to be eaten and store it away as food for you and for them."
1:6:22/Noah did everything just as God commanded him.
1:7:1/And the LORD said to Noah, "Come into the ark, you and your entire family, because I have seen that you are righteous in this generation."
1:7:2/"You shall take seven pairs of every clean animal, a male and its female, and two of every animal that is not clean, a male and its female."
1:7:3/"Also, take seven pairs of birds of the air, male and female, to keep their species alive on the face of the earth."
1:7:4/"In seven days, I will send rain on the earth for forty days and forty nights, and I will wipe from the face of the earth every living creature I have made."
1:7:5/And Noah did everything that the LORD commanded him.
1:7:6/Noah was six hundred years old when the floodwaters came on the earth.
1:7:7/Noah, his sons, his wife, and his sons' wives entered the ark to escape the waters of the flood.
1:7:8/Of clean animals, animals that are not clean, birds, and everything that crawls on the ground,
1:7:9/they went into the ark with Noah, two by two, male and female, as God had commanded Noah.
1:7:10/After seven days, the floodwaters came on the earth.
1:7:11/In the six hundredth year of Noah's life, in the second month, on the seventeenth day of the month, on that day all the springs of the great deep burst forth, and the floodgates of the heavens were opened.
1:7:12/And it rained on the earth for forty days and forty nights.
1:7:13/On that very day, Noah, and Shem, Ham, and Japheth, the sons of Noah, Noah's wife, and the three wives of his sons entered the ark with them.
1:7:14/They, and every kind of wild animal, all the livestock, every creature that crawls on the earth, and every bird, everything with wings.
1:7:15/They went into the ark with Noah, two by two, of all flesh in which there was the breath of life.
1:7:16/Those that entered, male and female of all flesh, entered as God had commanded him; and the LORD closed it behind him.
1:7:17/The flood continued forty days on the earth, and the waters increased and lifted the ark high above the earth.
1:7:18/The waters rose and increased greatly on the earth, and the ark floated on the surface of the water.
1:7:19/The waters rose greatly on the earth, covering all the high mountains under the entire heavens.
1:7:20/The waters rose fifteen cubits above the mountains, covering them.
1:7:21/Every living thing that moved on the earth perished—birds, livestock, wild animals, all the creatures that swarm over the earth, and all mankind.
1:7:22/Everything on dry land that had the breath of life in its nostrils died.
1:7:23/Every living thing on the face of the earth was wiped out; people and animals and the creatures that move along the ground and the birds were wiped from the earth. Only Noah was left, and those with him in the ark.
1:7:24/And the waters flooded the earth for a hundred and fifty days.
1:8:1/And God remembered Noah, and every living thing, and all the animals that were with him in the ark: and God caused a wind to blow across the earth, and the waters began to go down;
1:8:2/The sources of water from deep within the earth and the floodgates of the skies were closed, and the rain from the skies was stopped;
1:8:3/And the waters receded from the earth steadily: and after 150 days, the waters had decreased.
1:8:4/And the ark came to rest in the seventh month, on the seventeenth day of the month, on the mountains of Ararat.
1:8:5/And the waters continued to decrease until the tenth month: on the first day of the tenth month, the tops of the mountains became visible.
1:8:6/After forty days, Noah opened the window he had made in the ark:
1:8:7/And he sent out a raven, which kept flying back and forth until the waters had dried up from the earth.
1:8:8/He also sent out a dove to see if the waters had receded from the surface of the ground;
1:8:9/But the dove found no place to rest her foot, and she returned to him in the ark, because water covered the surface of the whole earth. He reached out his hand, took her, and brought her back into the ark.
1:8:10/And he waited another seven days; and again he sent out the dove from the ark;
1:8:11/And the dove came back to him in the evening, and there in her beak was a freshly plucked olive leaf. So Noah knew that the waters had receded from the earth.
1:8:12/And he waited yet another seven days; and sent out the dove, which did not return to him anymore.
1:8:13/In the six hundred and first year, in the first month, the first day of the month, the waters had dried up from the earth. Noah then removed the covering of the ark, looked out, and saw that the surface of the ground was dry.
1:8:14/By the second month, on the twenty-seventh day of the month, the earth was completely dry.
1:8:15/And God spoke to Noah, saying,
1:8:16/Leave the ark, you and your wife, and your sons, and your sons' wives with you.
1:8:17/Bring out with you every living thing that is with you, of all flesh, including birds, livestock, and every creature that moves on the ground; so they can breed abundantly on the earth, be fruitful, and multiply on the earth.
1:8:18/So Noah came out, along with his sons, his wife, and his sons' wives.
1:8:19/Every animal, every creature that crawls, and every bird, everything that moves on the earth, according to their kinds, came out of the ark.
1:8:20/And Noah built an altar to the LORD; and took of every clean animal, and of every clean bird, and offered burnt offerings on the altar.
1:8:21/And the LORD smelled the pleasing aroma; and the LORD said in his heart, I will never again curse the ground because of humans, even though every inclination of the human heart is evil from childhood. And I will never again destroy all living creatures, as I have done.
1:8:22/As long as the earth endures, planting and harvesting, cold and heat, summer and winter, day and night will never cease.
1:9:1/And God blessed Noah and his sons, saying to them, "Be fruitful, multiply, and fill the earth."
1:9:2/Every creature on earth, every bird in the sky, everything that moves on the ground, and all the fish in the sea will fear and dread you. They are all given into your hands.
1:9:3/You can eat every moving thing that lives, just as I have given you the green plants.
1:9:4/However, you must not eat meat that still has its lifeblood in it.
1:9:5/I will certainly demand an accounting for the lifeblood of your lives. I will require it from every animal and from every human being; from everyone, I will require the life of another human.
1:9:6/Whoever sheds human blood, by humans shall their blood be shed; for God made humans in his own image.
1:9:7/And as for you, be fruitful and multiply; increase greatly on the earth and multiply in it."
1:9:8/Then God spoke to Noah and to his sons with him, saying,
1:9:9/"Now, I am establishing my covenant with you and with your descendants after you,
1:9:10/and with every living creature that is with you—the birds, the livestock, and all the wild animals with you, all that came out of the ark with you—every living creature on earth.
1:9:11/I establish my covenant with you: Never again will all life be destroyed by the waters of a flood; never again will there be a flood to destroy the earth."
1:9:12/And God said, "This is the sign of the covenant I am making between me and you and every living creature with you, a covenant for all generations to come:
1:9:13/I have set my rainbow in the clouds, and it will be the sign of the covenant between me and the earth.
1:9:14/Whenever I bring clouds over the earth and the rainbow appears in the clouds,
1:9:15/I will remember my covenant between me and you and all living creatures of every kind. Never again will the waters become a flood to destroy all life.
1:9:16/When the rainbow is in the clouds, I will see it and remember the everlasting covenant between God and all living creatures of every kind on the earth."
1:9:17/Then God said to Noah, "This is the sign of the covenant I have established between me and all life on the earth."
1:9:18/The sons of Noah who came out of the ark were Shem, Ham, and Japheth. Ham was the father of Canaan.
1:9:19/These were the three sons of Noah, and from them came the people who were scattered over the whole earth.
1:9:20/Noah became a farmer and planted a vineyard.
1:9:21/He drank some of the wine, became drunk, and lay uncovered inside his tent.
1:9:22/Ham, the father of Canaan, saw his father naked and told his two brothers outside.
1:9:23/But Shem and Japheth took a garment, laid it across their shoulders, walked backward and covered their father's nakedness. Their faces were turned the other way so they would not see their father's nakedness.
1:9:24/When Noah awoke from his wine and found out what his youngest son had done to him,
1:9:25/he said, "Cursed be Canaan! He will be the lowest of slaves to his brothers."
1:9:26/He also said, "Praised be the Lord, the God of Shem! May Canaan be the slave of Shem.
1:9:27/May God extend Japheth's territory; may Japheth live in the tents of Shem, and may Canaan be their slave."
1:9:28/And Noah lived 350 years after the flood.
1:9:29/Noah lived a total of 950 years, and then he died.
1:10:1/Here are the family lines of Noah's sons: Shem, Ham, and Japheth. Sons were born to them after the flood.
1:10:2/Japheth's sons were Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras.
1:10:3/Gomer's sons were Ashkenaz, Riphath, and Togarmah.
1:10:4/Javan's sons were Elishah, Tarshish, Kittim, and Dodanim.
1:10:5/From these, the coastal nations spread out into their territories, each with its own language, by their clans, within their nations.
1:10:6/Ham's sons were Cush, Mizraim, Phut, and Canaan.
1:10:7/Cush's sons were Seba, Havilah, Sabtah, Raamah, and Sabtechah. Raamah's sons were Sheba and Dedan.
1:10:8/Cush was the father of Nimrod, who became a powerful figure on the earth.
1:10:9/He was a mighty hunter in the Lord's sight, which is why people say, "Like Nimrod, a mighty hunter before the Lord."
1:10:10/The first centers of his kingdom were Babel, Erech, Accad, and Calneh, in the land of Shinar.
1:10:11/From that land, Asshur went out and built Nineveh, Rehoboth Ir, Calah,
1:10:12/and Resen, which is between Nineveh and Calah; that is the great city.
1:10:13/Mizraim was the father of the Ludim, Anamim, Lehabim, Naphtuhim,
1:10:14/Pathrusim, Casluhim (from whom the Philistines came), and Caphtorim.
1:10:15/Canaan was the father of Sidon, his firstborn, and Heth,
1:10:16/and the Jebusite, Amorite, Girgasite,
1:10:17/Hivite, Arkite, Sinite,
1:10:18/Arvadite, Zemarite, and Hamathite. Later, the Canaanite clans scattered.
1:10:19/The Canaanite territory stretched from Sidon toward Gerar as far as Gaza, and then toward Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, and Zeboiim, as far as Lasha.
1:10:20/These are Ham's sons, by their clans and languages, in their territories and nations.
1:10:21/Also, to Shem, the ancestor of all the children of Eber and the older brother of Japheth, children were born.
1:10:22/Shem's sons were Elam, Asshur, Arphaxad, Lud, and Aram.
1:10:23/Aram's sons were Uz, Hul, Gether, and Mash.
1:10:24/Arphaxad was the father of Salah, and Salah was the father of Eber.
1:10:25/To Eber were born two sons: the name of one was Peleg, because in his time the earth was divided; his brother's name was Joktan.
1:10:26/Joktan was the father of Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, and Jerah,
1:10:27/Hadoram, Uzal, Diklah,
1:10:28/Obal, Abimael, and Sheba,
1:10:29/Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab. All these were Joktan's sons.
1:10:30/Their settlements stretched from Mesha toward Sephar, in the eastern hill country.
1:10:31/These are Shem's sons, by their clans and languages, in their territories and nations.
1:10:32/These are the family lines of Noah's sons, according to their generations, within their nations. From these, the nations spread out over the earth after the flood.
1:11:1/The entire earth shared the same language and way of speaking.
1:11:2/As they moved from the east, they discovered a plain in the land of Shinar and settled there.
1:11:3/They said to each other, "Let's make bricks and bake them thoroughly." They used bricks instead of stone and tar for mortar.
1:11:4/Then they said, "Let's build ourselves a city and a tower that reaches the sky, to make a name for ourselves and prevent us from being scattered all over the world."
1:11:5/The LORD came down to see the city and the tower that the humans were building.
1:11:6/And the LORD said, "Look, the people are united, and they all speak the same language. This is just the beginning of what they will do. Now, nothing they plan to do will be impossible for them.
1:11:7/"Come, let's go down and confuse their language so they won't understand each other."
1:11:8/So the LORD scattered them from there over the face of the entire earth, and they stopped building the city.
1:11:9/That's why it was called Babel, because there the LORD confused the language of the whole world, and from there the LORD scattered them over the face of the whole earth.
1:11:10/These are the descendants of Shem: Shem was a hundred years old when he became the father of Arphaxad, two years after the flood.
1:11:11/And Shem lived five hundred years after he became the father of Arphaxad, and he had other sons and daughters.
1:11:12/Arphaxad lived thirty-five years and then became the father of Salah.
1:11:13/After he became the father of Salah, Arphaxad lived four hundred and three years and had other sons and daughters.
1:11:14/Salah lived thirty years and then became the father of Eber.
1:11:15/After he became the father of Eber, Salah lived four hundred and three years and had other sons and daughters.
1:11:16/Eber lived thirty-four years and then became the father of Peleg.
1:11:17/After he became the father of Peleg, Eber lived four hundred and thirty years and had other sons and daughters.
1:11:18/Peleg lived thirty years and then became the father of Reu.
1:11:19/After he became the father of Reu, Peleg lived two hundred and nine years and had other sons and daughters.
1:11:20/Reu lived thirty-two years and then became the father of Serug.
1:11:21/After he became the father of Serug, Reu lived two hundred and seven years and had other sons and daughters.
1:11:22/Serug lived thirty years and then became the father of Nahor.
1:11:23/After he became the father of Nahor, Serug lived two hundred years and had other sons and daughters.
1:11:24/Nahor lived twenty-nine years and then became the father of Terah.
1:11:25/After he became the father of Terah, Nahor lived a hundred and nineteen years and had other sons and daughters.
1:11:26/Terah lived seventy years and then became the father of Abram, Nahor, and Haran.
1:11:27/These are the descendants of Terah: Terah became the father of Abram, Nahor, and Haran; and Haran became the father of Lot.
1:11:28/Haran died before his father Terah in his homeland, in Ur of the Chaldeans.
1:11:29/Abram and Nahor both married: Abram's wife was named Sarai, and Nahor's wife was Milcah, the daughter of Haran, who was the father of both Milcah and Iscah.
1:11:30/But Sarai was unable to have children; she did not have any offspring.
1:11:31/Terah took his son Abram, his grandson Lot (Haran's son), and his daughter-in-law Sarai (Abram's wife), and they set out together from Ur of the Chaldeans to go to the land of Canaan. But when they came to Haran, they settled there.
1:11:32/Terah lived two hundred and five years, and he died in Haran.
1:12:1/The LORD told Abram, "Leave your country, your relatives, and your father's house, and go to a land I will show you.
1:12:2/I will make you into a great nation, I will bless you, I will make your name famous, and you will be a blessing.
1:12:3/I will bless those who bless you and curse those who curse you; and through you, all families on earth will be blessed."
1:12:4/So Abram left, as the LORD had instructed him; and Lot went with him. Abram was seventy-five years old when he left Haran.
1:12:5/Abram took his wife Sarai, his nephew Lot, all their possessions, and the people they had acquired in Haran, and they set out for the land of Canaan, where they eventually arrived.
1:12:6/Abram traveled through the land to the site of Shechem, to the oak of Moreh. At that time, the Canaanites were in the land.
1:12:7/The LORD appeared to Abram and said, "To your offspring, I will give this land." So there Abram built an altar to the LORD, who had appeared to him.
1:12:8/He moved from there to a mountain east of Bethel and pitched his tent, with Bethel to the west and Ai to the east. There he built another altar to the LORD and called on the name of the LORD.
1:12:9/Then Abram continued traveling, heading south.
1:12:10/But there was a severe famine in the land, so Abram went down to Egypt to live there temporarily because the famine was severe.
1:12:11/As he was about to enter Egypt, he said to his wife Sarai, "I know you are a beautiful woman,
1:12:12/and when the Egyptians see you, they will say, 'This is his wife.' Then they will kill me but will let you live.
1:12:13/Please say you are my sister, so it will go well for me because of you, and my life will be spared thanks to you."
1:12:14/When Abram arrived in Egypt, the Egyptians noticed that Sarai was very beautiful.
1:12:15/The princes of Pharaoh also saw her and praised her to Pharaoh, and she was taken into Pharaoh's palace.
1:12:16/Pharaoh treated Abram well for her sake, and Abram acquired sheep, cattle, male and female donkeys, male and female servants, and camels.
1:12:17/But the LORD inflicted serious diseases on Pharaoh and his household because of Sarai, Abram's wife.
1:12:18/So Pharaoh summoned Abram and asked, "What have you done to me? Why didn't you tell me she was your wife?
1:12:19/Why did you say, 'She is my sister,' so I took her to be my wife? Now then, here is your wife. Take her and go!"
1:12:20/Then Pharaoh gave orders about Abram to his men, and they sent him away, along with his wife and everything he had.
1:13:1/Abram left Egypt with his wife, all his possessions, and Lot, heading south.
1:13:2/Abram was extremely wealthy, with lots of livestock, silver, and gold.
1:13:3/He traveled from the south to Bethel, to the spot where his tent had been at first, between Bethel and Hai.
1:13:4/He returned to the altar he had built there and called on the LORD's name.
1:13:5/Lot, who was traveling with Abram, also had sheep, cattle, and tents.
1:13:6/The land couldn't support them living together because their possessions were so vast.
1:13:7/There was conflict between Abram's herdsmen and Lot's herdsmen, and the Canaanites and Perizzites were living in the land at that time.
1:13:8/Abram said to Lot, "Please let's not have any conflict between us or our herdsmen. We're family.
1:13:9/Look around you. The whole land is available. Please, let's separate. If you go left, I'll go right; if you go right, I'll go left."
1:13:10/Lot looked around and saw that the whole Jordan Valley was well-watered everywhere, like the LORD's garden or the land of Egypt, before the LORD destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah.
1:13:11/So Lot chose the whole Jordan Valley for himself and traveled east, and they separated from each other.
1:13:12/Abram lived in the land of Canaan, while Lot lived among the cities of the plain, setting up his tent near Sodom.
1:13:13/But the people of Sodom were extremely wicked and sinful against the LORD.
1:13:14/After Lot had gone, the LORD said to Abram, "Look around from where you are, to the north, south, east, and west.
1:13:15/All the land you see, I will give to you and your descendants forever.
1:13:16/And I will make your descendants as numerous as the dust of the earth; so that if someone could count the dust, then your descendants could be counted.
1:13:17/Get up and walk through the land, its length and breadth, for I am giving it to you."
1:13:18/Then Abram moved his tent and settled in the oaks of Mamre at Hebron, where he built an altar to the LORD.
1:14:1/In the time of Amraphel king of Shinar, Arioch king of Ellasar, Chedorlaomer king of Elam, and Tidal king of nations;
1:14:2/These kings waged war against Bera king of Sodom, Birsha king of Gomorrah, Shinab king of Admah, Shemeber king of Zeboiim, and the king of Bela, now known as Zoar.
1:14:3/All of them joined forces in the valley of Siddim, which is now the Dead Sea.
1:14:4/For twelve years they were under Chedorlaomer's rule, but in the thirteenth year, they rebelled.
1:14:5/And in the fourteenth year, Chedorlaomer and the kings allied with him came and defeated the Rephaims in Ashteroth Karnaim, the Zuzims in Ham, and the Emims in Shaveh Kiriathaim,
1:14:6/And the Horites in their mountain of Seir, as far as Elparan, which is by the desert.
1:14:7/Then they turned back and went to Enmishpat, now Kadesh, and conquered all the territory of the Amalekites, as well as the Amorites living in Hazezontamar.
1:14:8/The king of Sodom, the king of Gomorrah, the king of Admah, the king of Zeboiim, and the king of Bela (also known as Zoar) went out and lined up for battle against them in the Valley of Siddim;
1:14:9/Against Chedorlaomer king of Elam, Tidal king of nations, Amraphel king of Shinar, and Arioch king of Ellasar—four kings against five.
1:14:10/The Valley of Siddim was full of tar pits; and as the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah fled, some fell into them, while the rest escaped to the hills.
1:14:11/The victors took all the possessions and food from Sodom and Gomorrah and went on their way.
1:14:12/They also captured Lot, Abram's nephew who lived in Sodom, along with his possessions, and left.
1:14:13/A survivor came and informed Abram the Hebrew, who was living near the great trees of Mamre the Amorite, a brother of Eshcol and Aner, all of whom were allies of Abram.
1:14:14/When Abram learned that his relative had been taken captive, he called out his trained men, born in his household—318 of them—and chased the captors as far as Dan.
1:14:15/He and his servants attacked them at night, defeated them, and pursued them to Hobah, north of Damascus.
1:14:16/He recovered all the goods and brought back his relative Lot and his possessions, along with the women and other people.
1:14:17/The king of Sodom went out to meet Abram after his victory over Chedorlaomer and the kings allied with him, at the Valley of Shaveh (that is, the King's Valley).
1:14:18/Melchizedek king of Salem brought out bread and wine; he was the priest of God Most High.
1:14:19/He blessed Abram, saying, "Blessed be Abram by God Most High, Creator of heaven and earth.
1:14:20/And praise be to God Most High, who has handed over your enemies to you." And Abram gave him a tenth of everything.
1:14:21/The king of Sodom said to Abram, "Give me the people and keep the goods for yourself."
1:14:22/But Abram said to the king of Sodom, "I have sworn an oath to the LORD, God Most High, Creator of heaven and earth,
1:14:23/That I will accept nothing belonging to you, not even a thread or the strap of a sandal, so that you will never be able to say, 'I made Abram rich.'
1:14:24/I will accept nothing but what my men have eaten and the share that belongs to the men who went with me—Aner, Eshcol, and Mamre. Let them have their share."
1:15:1/After these events, the word of the LORD came to Abram in a vision, saying, "Do not be afraid, Abram: I am your protector, and your very great reward."
1:15:2/And Abram said, "LORD God, what will you give me, since I am childless, and the manager of my household is this Eliezer of Damascus?"
1:15:3/And Abram said, "Look, you have given me no offspring: and, see, someone born in my house will inherit everything."
1:15:4/Then, the word of the LORD came to him, saying, "This person will not be your heir; but someone who is your own biological child will be your heir."
1:15:5/He took him outside and said, "Look up at the sky and count the stars, if you can: and he said to him, "Your descendants will be just as numerous."
1:15:6/And he trusted in the LORD; and it was credited to him as righteousness.
1:15:7/And He said to him, "I am the LORD who brought you out of Ur of the Chaldeans, to give you this land to possess it."
1:15:8/And he said, "LORD God, how will I know that I will possess it?"
1:15:9/And He said to him, "Bring me a three-year-old heifer, a three-year-old female goat, a three-year-old ram, a turtledove, and a young pigeon."
1:15:10/He brought all these to Him, cut them in half, and placed each half opposite the other; but he did not cut the birds in half.
1:15:11/And when birds of prey came down on the carcasses, Abram drove them away.
1:15:12/As the sun was setting, Abram fell into a deep sleep, and a thick and dreadful darkness came over him.
1:15:13/And He said to Abram, "Be certain that your descendants will be strangers in a land that is not theirs, and will be enslaved and mistreated there for four hundred years.
1:15:14/But I will judge the nation they serve, and afterward, they will come out with great possessions.
1:15:15/And you will go to your ancestors in peace and be buried at a ripe old age.
1:15:16/But in the fourth generation, they will return here, for the wrongdoing of the Amorites has not yet reached its full measure."
1:15:17/When the sun had set and it was dark, a smoking firepot with a blazing torch appeared and passed between the pieces.
1:15:18/On that day, the LORD made a covenant with Abram, saying, "To your descendants I have given this land, from the river of Egypt to the great river, the Euphrates:
1:15:19/The Kenites, the Kenizzites, and the Kadmonites,
1:15:20/And the Hittites, the Perizzites, and the Rephaim,
1:15:21/And the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Girgashites, and the Jebusites.
1:16:1/Now Sarai, Abram's wife, had not been able to have children for him. She had an Egyptian servant named Hagar.
1:16:2/And Sarai said to Abram, "Look, the LORD has prevented me from having children. Please sleep with my servant; maybe I can have children through her." Abram listened to what Sarai said.
1:16:3/So after Abram had been living in Canaan for ten years, Sarai, Abram's wife, took Hagar the Egyptian, her servant, and gave her to her husband Abram as a wife.
1:16:4/Abram slept with Hagar, and she became pregnant. When she realized she was pregnant, she began to look down on her mistress.
1:16:5/Then Sarai said to Abram, "This is your fault! I put my servant in your arms, and now that she knows she's pregnant, she despises me. May the LORD judge between you and me."
1:16:6/But Abram said to Sarai, "Look, your servant is in your hands; do with her whatever you think best." Then Sarai mistreated Hagar, so she ran away.
1:16:7/The angel of the LORD found her by a spring of water in the desert, by the spring on the way to Shur.
1:16:8/And he said, "Hagar, servant of Sarai, where have you come from, and where are you going?" She said, "I'm running away from my mistress Sarai."
1:16:9/The angel of the LORD told her, "Go back to your mistress and submit to her."
1:16:10/The angel of the LORD also said to her, "I will increase your descendants so much that they will be too numerous to count."
1:16:11/And the angel of the LORD said to her, "You are pregnant and will give birth to a son. You shall name him Ishmael, for the LORD has heard of your misery.
1:16:12/He will be a wild donkey of a man; his hand will be against everyone and everyone's hand against him, and he will live in hostility toward all his brothers."
1:16:13/She gave this name to the LORD who spoke to her: "You are the God who sees me," for she said, "I have now seen the One who sees me."
1:16:14/That is why the well was called Beer Lahai Roi; it is still there, between Kadesh and Bered.
1:16:15/And Hagar bore Abram a son, and Abram named his son, whom Hagar bore, Ishmael.
1:16:16/Abram was eighty-six years old when Hagar bore Ishmael to him.
1:17:1/When Abram was ninety-nine years old, the LORD appeared to Abram and said to him, "I am the Almighty God; walk before me and be blameless.
1:17:2/I will establish my covenant between me and you, and will greatly increase your numbers."
1:17:3/Abram fell facedown, and God spoke to him, saying,
1:17:4/"As for me, this is my covenant with you: You will be the father of many nations.
1:17:5/Your name will no longer be Abram, but your name will be Abraham, for I have made you a father of many nations.
1:17:6/I will make you extremely fruitful; I will make nations of you, and kings will descend from you.
1:17:7/I will establish my covenant between me and you and your descendants after you for generations to come, to be your God and the God of your descendants after you.
1:17:8/And to you and your descendants after you, I will give the land where you are now an alien, all the land of Canaan, as an everlasting possession; and I will be their God."
1:17:9/Then God said to Abraham, "You must keep my covenant, you and your descendants after you for the generations to come.
1:17:10/This is my covenant with you and your descendants after you, the covenant you are to keep: Every male among you shall be circumcised.
1:17:11/You are to undergo circumcision, and it will be the sign of the covenant between me and you.
1:17:12/For the generations to come, every male among you who is eight days old must be circumcised, including those born in your household or bought with money from a foreigner—those who are not your offspring.
1:17:13/Whether born in your household or bought with your money, they must be circumcised. My covenant in your flesh is to be an everlasting covenant.
1:17:14/Any uncircumcised male, who has not been circumcised in the flesh, will be cut off from his people; he has broken my covenant."
1:17:15/And God said to Abraham, "As for Sarai your wife, you are no longer to call her Sarai; her name will be Sarah.
1:17:16/I will bless her and will surely give you a son by her. I will bless her so that she will be the mother of nations; kings of peoples will come from her."
1:17:17/Then Abraham fell facedown; he laughed and said to himself, "Will a son be born to a man a hundred years old? Will Sarah bear a child at the age of ninety?"
1:17:18/And Abraham said to God, "If only Ishmael might live under your blessing!"
1:17:19/Then God said, "Yes, but your wife Sarah will bear you a son, and you will call him Isaac. I will establish my covenant with him as an everlasting covenant for his descendants after him.
1:17:20/As for Ishmael, I have heard you: I will surely bless him; I will make him fruitful and will greatly increase his numbers. He will be the father of twelve rulers, and I will make him into a great nation.
1:17:21/But my covenant I will establish with Isaac, whom Sarah will bear to you by this time next year."
1:17:22/After finishing speaking with him, God went up from Abraham.
1:17:23/Abraham took his son Ishmael and all those born in his household or bought with his money, every male in his household, and circumcised them, as God had told him.
1:17:24/Abraham was ninety-nine years old when he was circumcised,
1:17:25/and his son Ishmael was thirteen years old when he was circumcised.
1:17:26/On that very day Abraham and his son Ishmael were circumcised.
1:17:27/And all the men of his household, whether born in the household or bought from a foreigner, were circumcised with him.
1:18:1/The LORD appeared to him by the oaks of Mamre as he sat at the entrance of his tent during the hottest part of the day.
1:18:2/He looked up and saw three men standing near him. When he saw them, he ran from the tent entrance to meet them and bowed down to the ground.
1:18:3/He said, "My Lord, if I have found favor in your eyes, please do not pass by your servant.
1:18:4/Please let a little water be brought, and wash your feet, and rest yourselves under the tree.
1:18:5/I'll get some bread so you can refresh yourselves before you go on, since you've come to your servant." And they said, "Do as you have said."
1:18:6/Abraham hurried into the tent to Sarah and said, "Quickly prepare three measures of fine flour, knead it, and make cakes."
1:18:7/Abraham ran to the herd, selected a tender and good calf, and gave it to a servant, who hurried to prepare it.
1:18:8/He then took curds, milk, and the calf that had been prepared, and set these before them. He stood by them under the tree while they ate.
1:18:9/They asked him, "Where is Sarah your wife?" He replied, "There, in the tent."
1:18:10/One of them said, "I will surely return to you about this time next year, and Sarah your wife will have a son." Sarah heard this from the entrance of the tent, which was behind him.
1:18:11/Now Abraham and Sarah were old, advanced in age; it had ceased to be with Sarah after the manner of women.
1:18:12/So Sarah laughed to herself, thinking, "After I have grown old, and my husband is old, shall I have pleasure?"
1:18:13/The LORD said to Abraham, "Why did Sarah laugh and say, 'Will I really have a child, now that I am old?'
1:18:14/Is anything too difficult for the LORD? At the appointed time, I will return to you, about this time next year, and Sarah will have a son."
1:18:15/But Sarah denied it, saying, "I did not laugh," because she was afraid. He said, "No, but you did laugh."
1:18:16/The men set out from there and looked down toward Sodom, with Abraham walking with them to see them on their way.
1:18:17/Then the LORD said, "Should I hide from Abraham what I am about to do,
1:18:18/considering that Abraham will surely become a great and powerful nation, and all the nations of the earth will be blessed through him?
1:18:19/For I have chosen him, so that he will direct his children and his household after him to keep the way of the LORD by doing what is right and just, so that the LORD will bring about for Abraham what he has promised him."
1:18:20/Then the LORD said, "The outcry against Sodom and Gomorrah is so great, and their sin so grievous,
1:18:21/that I will go down and see if what they have done is as bad as the outcry that has reached me. If not, I will know."
1:18:22/The men turned away and went toward Sodom, but Abraham remained standing before the LORD.
1:18:23/Abraham approached and said, "Will you sweep away the righteous with the wicked?
1:18:24/What if there are fifty righteous people in the city? Will you really sweep it away and not spare the place for the sake of the fifty righteous people in it?
1:18:25/Far be it from you to do such a thing—to kill the righteous with the wicked, treating the righteous and the wicked alike. Far be it from you! Will not the Judge of all the earth do right?"
1:18:26/The LORD said, "If I find fifty righteous people in the city of Sodom, I will spare the whole place for their sake."
1:18:27/Abraham spoke up again: "Now that I have been so bold as to speak to the Lord, though I am nothing but dust and ashes,
1:18:28/what if the number of the righteous is five less than fifty? Will you destroy the whole city for lack of five?" And he said, "If I find forty-five there, I will not destroy it."
1:18:29/Once again he spoke to him, "What if only forty are found there?" He said, "For the sake of forty, I will not do it."
1:18:30/Then he said, "May the Lord not be angry, but let me speak. What if only thirty can be found there?" He answered, "I will not do it if I find thirty there."
1:18:31/Abraham said, "Now that I have been so bold as to speak to the Lord, what if only twenty can be found there?" He said, "For the sake of twenty, I will not destroy it."
1:18:32/Then he said, "May the Lord not be angry, but let me speak just once more. What if only ten can be found there?" He answered, "For the sake of ten, I will not destroy it."
1:18:33/The LORD went on his way as soon as he had finished speaking with Abraham, and Abraham returned to his place.
1:19:1/Two angels arrived in Sodom in the evening; Lot was sitting at the city gate. When Lot saw them, he got up to greet them and bowed down with his face to the ground.
1:19:2/He said, "Please, my lords, come to my house to spend the night. You can wash your feet, then get up early and continue on your journey." But they answered, "No, we'll stay in the square."
1:19:3/However, Lot insisted so strongly that they did go with him and entered his house. He prepared a meal for them, baked unleavened bread, and they ate.
1:19:4/But before they went to bed, all the men from every part of the city of Sodom surrounded the house, both young and old.
1:19:5/They called out to Lot, "Where are the men who came to you tonight? Bring them out to us so we can have sex with them."
1:19:6/Lot went outside to meet them and shut the door behind him.
1:19:7/He said, "Please, my friends, don't do such a wicked thing.
1:19:8/Look, I have two daughters who have never slept with a man. Let me bring them out to you, and you can do what you like with them. But don't do anything to these men, for they have come under the protection of my roof."
1:19:9/They replied, "Stand back!" And they said, "This man came here as a foreigner, and now he wants to play the judge! We'll treat you worse than them." They kept pressing in on Lot and moved forward to break down the door.
1:19:10/But the men inside reached out and pulled Lot back into the house and shut the door.
1:19:11/Then they struck the men who were at the door of the house, young and old, with blindness so that they couldn't find the door.
1:19:12/The men said to Lot, "Do you have anyone else here? Sons-in-law, sons, daughters, or anyone else in the city? Get them out of here,
1:19:13/because we are going to destroy this place. The outcry against its people has become so great before the LORD, and the LORD has sent us to destroy it."
1:19:14/So Lot went out and spoke to his sons-in-law, who were pledged to marry his daughters. He said, "Hurry and get out of this place, because the LORD is about to destroy the city!" But his sons-in-law thought he was joking.
1:19:15/With the dawn breaking, the angels urged Lot, saying, "Get up, take your wife and your two daughters who are here, or you will be swept away when the city is punished."
1:19:16/When he hesitated, the men grasped his hand and the hands of his wife and two daughters and led them safely out of the city, for the LORD was merciful to them.
1:19:17/As soon as they had brought them out, one of them said, "Run for your life! Don't look back, and don't stop anywhere in the plain! Run to the mountains or you will be swept away!"
1:19:18/But Lot said to them, "No, my lords, please!
1:19:19/Your servant has found favor in your eyes, and you have shown great kindness to me in sparing my life. But I can't run to the mountains; this disaster will overtake me, and I'll die.
1:19:20/Look, here is a town near enough to run to, and it's small. Let me flee to it—it's very small, isn't it? Then my life will be spared."
1:19:21/He said to him, "Very well, I will grant this request too; I will not overthrow the town you speak of.
1:19:22/Hurry, escape there, because I can't do anything until you reach it." That is why the town was called Zoar.
1:19:23/The sun had risen over the land when Lot entered Zoar.
1:19:24/Then the LORD rained down burning sulfur on Sodom and Gomorrah—from the LORD out of the heavens.
1:19:25/He overthrew those cities and the entire plain, destroying all those living in the cities—and also the vegetation in the land.
1:19:26/But Lot's wife looked back, and she became a pillar of salt.
1:19:27/Abraham got up early in the morning to the place where he had stood before the LORD.
1:19:28/He looked down toward Sodom and Gomorrah, toward all the land of the plain, and he saw dense smoke rising from the land, like smoke from a furnace.
1:19:29/When God destroyed the cities of the plain, he remembered Abraham, and he brought Lot out of the catastrophe that overthrew the cities where Lot had lived.
1:19:30/Lot and his two daughters left Zoar and settled in the mountains, for he was afraid to stay in Zoar. He and his two daughters lived in a cave.
1:19:31/The older daughter said to the younger, "Our father is old, and there is no man around here to give us children—as is the custom all over the earth.
1:19:32/Let's get our father to drink wine, and then we can sleep with him and preserve our family line through our father."
1:19:33/That night they got their father to drink wine, and the older daughter went in and slept with her father. He was not aware of it when she lay down or when she got up.
1:19:34/The next day, the older daughter said to the younger, "Last night I slept with my father. Let's get him to drink wine again tonight, and you go in and sleep with him so we can preserve our family line through our father."
1:19:35/So they got their father to drink wine that night also, and the younger daughter went in and slept with him. Again, he was not aware of it when she lay down or when she got up.
1:19:36/In this way, both of Lot's daughters became pregnant by their father.
1:19:37/The older daughter had a son, and she named him Moab; he is the father of the Moabites of today.
1:19:38/And the younger daughter also had a son, and she named him Ben-Ammi; he is the father of the Ammonites of today.
1:20:1/And Abraham traveled from there toward the southern lands, and lived between Kadesh and Shur, and stayed temporarily in Gerar.
1:20:2/And Abraham said of Sarah his wife, "She is my sister." So Abimelech, king of Gerar, sent for and took Sarah.
1:20:3/But God came to Abimelech in a dream at night, and said, "You are as good as dead because of the woman you have taken; she is another man's wife."
1:20:4/But Abimelech had not been intimate with her, and he said, "Lord, would you destroy an innocent nation too?
1:20:5/Didn't he tell me, 'She is my sister'? And she herself said, 'He is my brother.' With a clear conscience and clean hands, I did this."
1:20:6/And God said to him in a dream, "Yes, I know you did this with a clear conscience, and I have also prevented you from sinning against me. That's why I did not let you touch her.
1:20:7/Now then, return the man's wife, for he is a prophet, and he will pray for you, and you will live. But if you do not return her, know that you will surely die, you and all who belong to you."
1:20:8/So Abimelech got up early in the morning, called all his servants, and told them all these things, and the men were terrified.
1:20:9/Then Abimelech summoned Abraham and said to him, "What have you done to us? How have I wronged you that you have brought such a great guilt upon me and my kingdom? You have done things to me that should never be done."
1:20:10/And Abimelech said to Abraham, "What did you see that made you do this?"
1:20:11/And Abraham said, "I thought, 'There is surely no fear of God in this place, and they will kill me because of my wife.'
1:20:12/And indeed, she really is my sister, the daughter of my father though not of my mother; and she became my wife.
1:20:13/And when God made me wander from my father's house, I told her, 'This is the kindness you must do me: at every place we go, say of me, "He is my brother."'
1:20:14/And Abimelech took sheep, oxen, male servants, and female servants, and gave them to Abraham, and returned Sarah his wife to him.
1:20:15/And Abimelech said, "Look, my land is before you; live wherever you like."
1:20:16/And to Sarah he said, "Look, I have given your brother a thousand pieces of silver. It is a sign of your innocence in the eyes of all who are with you; you are completely vindicated."
1:20:17/So Abraham prayed to God, and God healed Abimelech, his wife, and his female slaves so they could have children again.
1:20:18/For the LORD had caused all the women in Abimelech's household to be infertile because of Sarah, Abraham's wife.
1:21:1/The LORD visited Sarah as he had promised, and did for Sarah what he had said.
1:21:2/Sarah became pregnant and gave birth to a son for Abraham in his old age, exactly at the time God had promised.
1:21:3/Abraham named his son, who was born to him and whom Sarah bore, Isaac.
1:21:4/Abraham circumcised his son Isaac when he was eight days old, following God's command.
1:21:5/Abraham was one hundred years old when his son Isaac was born to him.
1:21:6/Sarah said, "God has brought me laughter, and everyone who hears about this will laugh with me."
1:21:7/She also said, "Who would have told Abraham that Sarah would nurse children? Yet, I have given birth to a son in his old age."
1:21:8/The child grew and was weaned, and Abraham threw a big feast on the day Isaac was weaned.
1:21:9/Sarah saw that the son Hagar the Egyptian had borne to Abraham was mocking.
1:21:10/So she said to Abraham, "Get rid of this slave woman and her son, for the slave woman's son will never share in the inheritance with my son Isaac."
1:21:11/This matter distressed Abraham greatly because it concerned his son.
1:21:12/But God said to Abraham, "Do not be distressed about the boy and your slave woman. Listen to whatever Sarah tells you, because it is through Isaac that your offspring will be reckoned.
1:21:13/I will make the son of the slave woman into a nation also, because he is your offspring."
1:21:14/Early the next morning, Abraham took some food and a skin of water and gave them to Hagar. He set them on her shoulders and then sent her off with the boy. She went on her way and wandered in the Desert of Beersheba.
1:21:15/When the water in the skin was gone, she put the boy under one of the bushes.
1:21:16/Then she went off and sat down about a bowshot away, for she thought, "I cannot watch the boy die." And as she sat there, she began to sob.
1:21:17/God heard the boy crying, and the angel of God called to Hagar from heaven and said to her, "What's the matter, Hagar? Do not be afraid; God has heard the boy crying as he lies there.
1:21:18/Get up, lift the boy up and take him by the hand, for I will make him into a great nation."
1:21:19/Then God opened her eyes and she saw a well of water. She went and filled the skin with water and gave the boy a drink.
1:21:20/God was with the boy as he grew up. He lived in the desert and became an archer.
1:21:21/He lived in the Desert of Paran, and his mother got him a wife from Egypt.
1:21:22/At that time, Abimelech and Phichol, the commander of his forces, said to Abraham, "God is with you in everything you do.
1:21:23/Now swear to me here before God that you will not deal falsely with me or my children or my descendants. Show to me and the country where you now reside as a foreigner the same kindness I have shown to you."
1:21:24/Abraham said, "I swear it."
1:21:25/Then Abraham complained to Abimelech about a well of water that Abimelech's servants had seized.
1:21:26/Abimelech said, "I don't know who has done this. You did not tell me, and I only heard about it today."
1:21:27/Abraham brought sheep and cattle and gave them to Abimelech, and the two men made a treaty.
1:21:28/Abraham set apart seven ewe lambs from the flock.
1:21:29/Abimelech asked Abraham, "What is the meaning of these seven ewe lambs you have set apart by themselves?"
1:21:30/Abraham replied, "Accept these seven lambs from my hand as a witness that I dug this well."
1:21:31/So that place was called Beersheba, because the two men swore an oath there.
1:21:32/After the treaty had been made at Beersheba, Abimelech and Phichol, the commander of his forces, returned to the land of the Philistines.
1:21:33/Abraham planted a tamarisk tree in Beersheba, and there he called on the name of the LORD, the Eternal God.
1:21:34/And Abraham stayed in the land of the Philistines for a long time.
1:22:1/After these events, God tested Abraham. He called to him, "Abraham!" and Abraham responded, "Here I am."
1:22:2/God said, "Take your son, your only son Isaac, whom you love, and go to the region of Moriah. Sacrifice him there as a burnt offering on a mountain I will show you."
1:22:3/Early the next morning, Abraham got up, saddled his donkey, took two of his servants and his son Isaac, cut the wood for the burnt offering, and set out for the place God had told him about.
1:22:4/On the third day, Abraham looked up and saw the place in the distance.
1:22:5/Abraham told his servants, "Stay here with the donkey; the boy and I will go over there to worship and then we'll come back to you."
1:22:6/Abraham placed the wood for the burnt offering on Isaac's shoulders, while he himself carried the fire and the knife. As the two of them went on together,
1:22:7/Isaac spoke up and said to his father Abraham, "Father?" "Yes, my son?" Abraham replied. "The fire and wood are here," Isaac said, "but where is the lamb for the burnt offering?"
1:22:8/Abraham answered, "God himself will provide the lamb for the burnt offering, my son." And the two of them continued on together.
1:22:9/When they arrived at the place God had directed him to, Abraham built an altar there and arranged the wood on it. He bound his son Isaac and laid him on the altar, on top of the wood.
1:22:10/Then Abraham reached out his hand and took the knife to kill his son.
1:22:11/But the angel of the LORD called out to him from heaven, "Abraham! Abraham!" "Here I am," he replied.
1:22:12/"Do not lay a hand on the boy," he said. "Do not do anything to him. Now I know that you fear God, because you have not withheld from me your son, your only son."
1:22:13/Abraham looked up and there in a thicket he saw a ram caught by its horns. He went over and took the ram and sacrificed it as a burnt offering instead of his son.
1:22:14/Abraham named that place The LORD Will Provide. And to this day it is said, "On the mountain of the LORD it will be provided."
1:22:15/And the angel of the LORD called to Abraham from heaven a second time,
1:22:16/"Because you have done this and have not withheld your son, your only son, I swear by myself," declares the LORD,
1:22:17/"that I will surely bless you and make your descendants as numerous as the stars in the sky and as the sand on the seashore. Your descendants will take possession of the cities of their enemies,
1:22:18/and through your offspring all nations on earth will be blessed, because you have obeyed me."
1:22:19/Then Abraham returned to his servants, and they set off together for Beersheba. And Abraham stayed in Beersheba.
1:22:20/Some time later, Abraham was told, "Milcah is also a mother; she has given birth to sons for your brother Nahor:
1:22:21/Uz the firstborn, Buz his brother, Kemuel (the father of Aram),
1:22:22/Chesed, Hazo, Pildash, Jidlaph, and Bethuel."
1:22:23/Bethuel became the father of Rebekah. Milcah bore these eight to Nahor, Abraham's brother.
1:22:24/His concubine, whose name was Reumah, also had sons: Tebah, Gaham, Tahash, and Maacah.
1:23:1/Sarah lived to be one hundred and twenty-seven years old; these were the years of Sarah's life.
1:23:2/Sarah passed away in Kirjatharba, which is also known as Hebron in the land of Canaan, and Abraham came to mourn for Sarah and to cry over her loss.
1:23:3/Abraham stood up from beside his deceased wife and spoke to the Hethites, saying,
1:23:4/"I am a foreigner and a temporary resident among you. Please allow me to buy a burial site from you so that I can bury my deceased wife out of my sight."
1:23:5/The Hethites responded to Abraham, telling him,
1:23:6/"Listen to us, sir. You are a respected prince among us. Choose the best of our tombs to bury your dead. None of us will refuse you his tomb for burying your dead."
1:23:7/Abraham got up and bowed to the local people, the Hethites.
1:23:8/He negotiated with them, saying, "If you agree that I should bury my dead away from my sight, please plead with Ephron son of Zohar on my behalf,
1:23:9/So that he may sell me the cave of Machpelah, which he owns at the edge of his field. Let him sell it to me at its full price for a burial site among you."
1:23:10/Ephron was sitting among the Hethites, and Ephron the Hittite answered Abraham in the hearing of the Hethites, everyone who entered the city gate, saying,
1:23:11/"No, my lord, listen to me. I give you the field, and the cave that is in it, I give it to you. In the presence of my people, I give it to you. Bury your dead."
1:23:12/Abraham bowed down before the local people.
1:23:13/He said to Ephron in the hearing of the people of the land, "But if you will, please listen to me. I will pay the price of the field. Accept it from me so that I may bury my dead there."
1:23:14/Ephron responded to Abraham, saying to him,
1:23:15/"My lord, listen to me. The land is worth four hundred shekels of silver, but what is that between friends? Go ahead and bury your dead."
1:23:16/Abraham agreed with Ephron and paid Ephron the silver he had mentioned in the hearing of the Hethites: four hundred shekels of silver, accepted as currency by merchants.
1:23:17/The field of Ephron in Machpelah, near Mamre—the field, the cave in it, and all the trees within the boundaries of the field—was legally transferred
1:23:18/To Abraham as his property in the presence of the Hethites, before all who entered the city gate.
1:23:19/Afterward, Abraham buried his wife Sarah in the cave of the field of Machpelah near Mamre, which is Hebron, in the land of Canaan.
1:23:20/The field and the cave in it were legally secured to Abraham by the Hethites as a burial site.
1:24:1/Abraham was old and advanced in years, and the LORD had blessed Abraham in every way.
1:24:2/Abraham said to his senior servant, who managed all he owned, "Please place your hand under my thigh:
1:24:3/And swear by the LORD, the God of heaven and earth, that you will not get a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites among whom I live:
1:24:4/Instead, you must go to my homeland and my relatives to find a wife for my son Isaac."
1:24:5/The servant asked him, "What if the woman is unwilling to come back with me to this land? Should I then take your son back to the country you came from?"
1:24:6/Abraham replied, "Make sure you do not take my son back there.
1:24:7/The LORD, the God of heaven, who took me from my father’s household and my native land, who spoke to me and promised me on oath, saying, 'To your offspring I will give this land'—He will send His angel ahead of you, and you will get a wife for my son from there.
1:24:8/If the woman is unwilling to come back with you, then you will be released from this oath of mine. Just do not take my son back there."
1:24:9/So the servant placed his hand under the thigh of his master Abraham and swore an oath to him concerning this matter.
1:24:10/The servant took ten of his master’s camels and left, taking with him all kinds of good things from his master. He set out for Aram Naharaim and made his way to the town of Nahor.
1:24:11/He had the camels kneel down near the well outside the town; it was toward evening, the time women go out to draw water.
1:24:12/He prayed, "LORD, God of my master Abraham, please grant me success today and show kindness to my master Abraham.
1:24:13/Here I am, standing beside this spring, and the daughters of the townspeople are coming out to draw water.
1:24:14/May it be that when I say to a young woman, 'Please let down your jar that I may have a drink,' and she says, 'Drink, and I’ll water your camels too'—let her be the one you have chosen for your servant Isaac. By this I will know that you have shown kindness to my master."
1:24:15/Before he had finished praying, Rebekah came out with her jar on her shoulder. She was the daughter of Bethuel son of Milcah, who was the wife of Abraham’s brother Nahor.
1:24:16/The woman was very beautiful, a virgin; no man had ever slept with her. She went down to the spring, filled her jar and came up again.
1:24:17/The servant hurried to meet her and said, "Please give me a little water from your jar."
1:24:18/"Drink, my lord," she said, and quickly lowered the jar to her hands and gave him a drink.
1:24:19/After she had given him a drink, she said, "I’ll draw water for your camels too, until they have had enough to drink."
1:24:20/So she quickly emptied her jar into the trough, ran back to the well to draw more water, and drew enough for all his camels.
1:24:21/Without saying a word, the man watched her closely to learn whether or not the LORD had made his journey successful.
1:24:22/When the camels had finished drinking, the man took out a gold nose ring weighing a beka and two gold bracelets weighing ten shekels.
1:24:23/Then he asked, "Whose daughter are you? Please tell me, is there room in your father’s house for us to spend the night?"
1:24:24/She answered him, "I am the daughter of Bethuel, the son that Milcah bore to Nahor."
1:24:25/And she added, "We have plenty of straw and fodder, as well as room for you to spend the night."
1:24:26/Then the man bowed down and worshiped the LORD,
1:24:27/saying, "Praise be to the LORD, the God of my master Abraham, who has not abandoned his kindness and faithfulness to my master. As for me, the LORD has led me on the journey to the house of my master’s relatives."
1:24:28/The young woman ran and told her mother’s household about these things.
1:24:29/Now Rebekah had a brother named Laban, and he hurried out to the man at the spring.
1:24:30/As soon as he had seen the nose ring, and the bracelets on his sister’s arms, and had heard Rebekah tell what the man said to her, he went out to the man and found him standing by the camels near the spring.
1:24:31/"Come, you who are blessed by the LORD," he said. "Why are you standing out here? I have prepared the house and a place for the camels."
1:24:32/So the man went to the house, and the camels were unloaded. Straw and fodder were provided for the camels, and water to wash his feet and the feet of the men who were with him.
1:24:33/A meal was set before him, but he said, "I will not eat until I have told you what I have to say." "Then tell us," they said.
1:24:34/He said, "I am Abraham’s servant.
1:24:35/The LORD has blessed my master abundantly, and he has become wealthy. He has given him sheep and cattle, silver and gold, male and female servants, and camels and donkeys.
1:24:36/My master’s wife Sarah has borne him a son in her old age, and he has given him everything he owns.
1:24:37/My master made me swear an oath and said, 'You must not get a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, in whose land I live,
1:24:38/but go to my father’s family and to my own clan, and get a wife for my son.'
1:24:39/Then I asked my master, 'What if the woman will not come back with me?'
1:24:40/He replied, 'The LORD, before whom I have walked faithfully, will send his angel with you and make your journey a success, so that you can get a wife for my son from my own clan and from my father’s family.
1:24:41/You will be released from my oath if, when you go to my clan, they refuse to give her to you—then you will be released from my oath.'
1:24:42/"When I came to the spring today, I said, 'LORD, God of my master Abraham, if you will, please grant success to the journey on which I have come.
1:24:43/See, I am standing beside this spring. If a young woman comes out to draw water and I say to her, 'Please let me drink a little water from your jar,'
1:24:44/and she says to me, 'Drink, and I’ll draw water for your camels too,' let her be the one the LORD has chosen for my master’s son.'
1:24:45/"Before I finished praying in my heart, Rebekah came out, with her jar on her shoulder. She went down to the spring and drew water, and I said to her, 'Please give me a drink.'
1:24:46/She quickly lowered her jar from her shoulder and said, 'Drink, and I’ll water your camels too.' So I drank, and she watered the camels also.
1:24:47/I asked her, 'Whose daughter are you?' She said, 'The daughter of Bethuel, Nahor’s son, whom Milcah bore to him.' Then I put the ring on her nose and the bracelets on her arms.
1:24:48/And I bowed down and worshiped the LORD. I praised the LORD, the God of my master Abraham, who had led me on the right path to get the daughter of my master’s brother for his son.
1:24:49/Now if you will show kindness and faithfulness to my master, tell me; and if not, tell me, so I may know which way to turn."
1:24:50/Laban and Bethuel answered, "This is from the LORD; we can say nothing to you one way or the other.
1:24:51/Here is Rebekah, right before you; take her and go, and let her become the wife of your master’s son, as the LORD has directed."
1:24:52/When Abraham’s servant heard their words, he bowed down to the ground before the LORD.
1:24:53/Then the servant brought out gold and silver jewelry and articles of clothing and gave them to Rebekah. He also gave costly gifts to her brother and to her mother.
1:24:54/Afterward, they ate and drank, he and the men who were with him, and spent the night there. When they got up the next morning, he said, "Send me on my way to my master."
1:24:55/But her brother and her mother replied, "Let the young woman remain with us ten days or so; then you may go."
1:24:56/But he said to them, "Do not delay me, since the LORD has made my journey successful; send me on my way so I may go to my master."
1:24:57/Then they said, "Let’s call the young woman and ask her about it."
