1:24:58/So they called Rebekah and asked her, "Will you go with this man?" "I will go," she said.
1:24:59/So they sent their sister Rebekah on her way, along with her nurse and Abraham’s servant and his men.
1:24:60/And they blessed Rebekah and said to her, "Our sister, may you increase to thousands upon thousands; may your offspring possess the cities of their enemies."
1:24:61/Then Rebekah and her attendants got ready and mounted the camels and went back with the man. So the servant took Rebekah and left.
1:24:62/Now Isaac had come from Beer Lahai Roi, for he was living in the Negev.
1:24:63/He went out to the field one evening to meditate, and as he looked up, he saw camels approaching.
1:24:64/Rebekah also looked up and saw Isaac. She got down from her camel
1:24:65/and asked the servant, "Who is that man in the field coming to meet us?" "He is my master," the servant answered. So she took her veil and covered herself.
1:24:66/Then the servant told Isaac all he had done.
1:24:67/Isaac brought her into the tent of his mother Sarah, married Rebekah, and loved her. So Isaac was comforted after his mother’s death.
1:25:1/Then again Abraham married another woman, named Keturah.
1:25:2/And she gave birth to Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah for him.
1:25:3/Jokshan fathered Sheba and Dedan. And Dedan's sons were Asshurim, Letushim, and Leummim.
1:25:4/Midian's sons were Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abidah, and Eldaah. All these were Keturah's children.
1:25:5/Abraham left everything he owned to Isaac.
1:25:6/But to the sons of his concubines, Abraham gave gifts and sent them away from his son Isaac, while he was still alive, to the eastern lands.
1:25:7/Abraham lived for 175 years.
1:25:8/Then Abraham passed away, dying at a ripe old age, satisfied with life; and he joined his ancestors in death.
1:25:9/Isaac and Ishmael, his sons, buried him in the cave of Machpelah, in the field of Ephron son of Zohar the Hittite, near Mamre; 
1:25:10/This is the field Abraham bought from the Hittites. There Abraham was buried with Sarah, his wife.
1:25:11/After Abraham's death, God blessed his son Isaac, who lived near the well Lahairoi.
1:25:12/Here are the descendants of Ishmael, Abraham's son, whom Hagar the Egyptian, Sarah's servant, bore to Abraham:
1:25:13/These are the names of Ishmael's sons, listed in the order of their birth: Nebajoth, the firstborn, then Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,
1:25:14/Mishma, Dumah, Massa,
1:25:15/Hadar, Tema, Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah.
1:25:16/These are Ishmael's sons, and these are their names, by their settlements and encampments: twelve tribal leaders according to their groups.
1:25:17/Ishmael lived 137 years. He breathed his last and died, and was gathered to his people.
1:25:18/They settled from Havilah to Shur, which is opposite Egypt in the direction of Assyria. He died in the presence of all his relatives.
1:25:19/These are the descendants of Isaac, Abraham's son: Abraham fathered Isaac.
1:25:20/Isaac was 40 years old when he married Rebekah, daughter of Bethuel the Aramean from Paddan Aram and sister of Laban the Aramean.
1:25:21/Isaac prayed to the LORD on behalf of his wife because she was childless. The LORD answered his prayer, and Rebekah his wife became pregnant.
1:25:22/The babies jostled each other within her, and she said, "Why is this happening to me?" So she went to inquire of the LORD.
1:25:23/And the LORD told her, "Two nations are in your womb, and two peoples from within you will be separated; one people will be stronger than the other, and the older will serve the younger."
1:25:24/When the time came for her to give birth, there were twin boys in her womb.
1:25:25/The first to come out was red, and his whole body was like a hairy garment; so they named him Esau.
1:25:26/Afterward, his brother came out, with his hand grasping Esau's heel; so he was named Jacob. Isaac was 60 years old when Rebekah gave birth to them.
1:25:27/As the boys grew up, Esau became a skilled hunter, a man of the open country, while Jacob was content to stay at home among the tents.
1:25:28/Isaac, who had a taste for wild game, loved Esau, but Rebekah loved Jacob.
1:25:29/One day when Jacob was cooking some stew, Esau came in from the open country, famished.
1:25:30/He said to Jacob, "Quick, let me have some of that red stew! I'm exhausted!" That is why he was also called Edom.
1:25:31/Jacob replied, "First sell me your birthright."
1:25:32/Esau said, "Look, I'm about to die. What good is the birthright to me?"
1:25:33/But Jacob said, "Swear to me first." So he swore an oath to him, selling his birthright to Jacob.
1:25:34/Then Jacob gave Esau some bread and lentil stew. He ate and drank, and then got up and left. So Esau despised his birthright.
1:26:1/There was a famine in the land, in addition to the first famine that occurred during Abraham's time. Isaac went to Abimelech, the king of the Philistines, in Gerar.
1:26:2/The LORD appeared to him and said, "Do not go down to Egypt; stay in the land I will tell you about:
1:26:3/Stay in this land, and I will be with you and bless you. I will give all these countries to you and your descendants, fulfilling the promise I made to your father Abraham.
1:26:4/I will increase your descendants to be as numerous as the stars in the sky and will give these lands to your descendants. Through your offspring, all nations on earth will be blessed.
1:26:5/Because Abraham listened to me and followed my requirements, my commands, my decrees, and my laws."
1:26:6/Isaac settled in Gerar.
1:26:7/When the local men asked about his wife, he said, "She is my sister," because he was afraid to say, "She is my wife," thinking, "The men of this place might kill me on account of Rebekah, for she is very beautiful."
1:26:8/After he had been there a long time, Abimelech, king of the Philistines, looked out of a window and saw Isaac caressing Rebekah, his wife.
1:26:9/Abimelech summoned Isaac and said, "She is obviously your wife! Why did you say, 'She is my sister'?" Isaac answered him, "Because I thought I might lose my life on account of her."
1:26:10/Abimelech said, "What have you done to us? One of the people could easily have slept with your wife, and you would have brought guilt upon us."
1:26:11/Abimelech warned all his people, saying, "Anyone who harms this man or his wife shall surely be put to death."
1:26:12/Then Isaac planted crops in that land and reaped a hundredfold that same year. The LORD blessed him.
1:26:13/The man became rich, and his wealth continued to grow until he became very wealthy.
1:26:14/He had so many flocks and herds and servants that the Philistines envied him.
1:26:15/All the wells that his father's servants had dug in the time of his father Abraham, the Philistines stopped up, filling them with earth.
1:26:16/Abimelech told Isaac, "Move away from us; you have become too powerful for us."
1:26:17/So Isaac moved away from there and encamped in the Valley of Gerar, where he settled.
1:26:18/Isaac reopened the wells that had been dug in the time of his father Abraham, which the Philistines had stopped up after Abraham died, and he gave them the same names his father had given them.
1:26:19/Isaac's servants dug in the valley and discovered a well of fresh water there.
1:26:20/But the herdsmen of Gerar argued with Isaac's herdsmen, saying, "The water is ours!" So he named the well Esek, because they disputed with him.
1:26:21/Then they dug another well, but they quarreled over that one also; so he named it Sitnah.
1:26:22/He moved on from there and dug another well, and no one quarreled over it. He named it Rehoboth, saying, "Now the LORD has given us room and we will flourish in the land."
1:26:23/From there he went up to Beersheba.
1:26:24/That night the LORD appeared to him and said, "I am the God of your father Abraham. Do not be afraid, for I am with you; I will bless you and will increase the number of your descendants for the sake of my servant Abraham."
1:26:25/He built an altar there and called on the name of the LORD. There he pitched his tent, and there Isaac's servants dug a well.
1:26:26/Then Abimelech went to him from Gerar, with Ahuzzath, his adviser, and Phichol, the commander of his forces.
1:26:27/Isaac asked them, "Why have you come to me, since you were hostile to me and sent me away?"
1:26:28/They answered, "We saw clearly that the LORD was with you; so we said, 'There ought to be a sworn agreement between us'—between us and you. Let us make a treaty with you
1:26:29/that you will do us no harm, just as we did not harm you but always treated you well and sent you away peacefully. You are now the blessed of the LORD.'"
1:26:30/He made them a feast, and they ate and drank.
1:26:31/Early the next morning, they swore an oath to each other. Then Isaac sent them on their way, and they left him in peace.
1:26:32/That day Isaac's servants came and told him about the well they had dug. They said, "We've found water!"
1:26:33/He named it Shibah, and to this day the name of the city is Beersheba.
1:26:34/When Esau was forty years old, he married Judith daughter of Beeri the Hittite, and Basemath daughter of Elon the Hittite.
1:26:35/They were a source of grief to Isaac and Rebekah.
1:27:1/When Isaac was old and his eyesight had faded so he couldn't see, he called Esau, his eldest son, and said, "My son." And he answered, "Here I am."
1:27:2/He said, "Look, I am old and don't know when I will die.
1:27:3/So please, take your weapons, your quiver and bow, and go out to the field to hunt some venison for me.
1:27:4/Then prepare a delicious meal, just the way I like it, and bring it to me to eat, so that I can give you my blessing before I pass away."
1:27:5/Rebekah overheard Isaac speaking to Esau. So Esau went out to the field to hunt for venison to bring back.
1:27:6/Rebekah then said to Jacob, her son, "Listen, I heard your father talking to your brother Esau, saying,
1:27:7/'Bring me some venison and prepare a delicious meal for me to eat, so I can bless you in the presence of the LORD before I die.'
1:27:8/Now, my son, listen carefully and do exactly as I tell you.
1:27:9/Go to the flock and bring me two choice young goats, so I can prepare them into a delicious meal for your father, just the way he likes it.
1:27:10/Then take it to your father to eat, so that he may bless you before his death."
1:27:11/Jacob said to Rebekah, his mother, "But Esau is hairy, and I'm smooth-skinned.
1:27:12/If my father touches me, he'll know I'm deceiving him and I'll bring a curse on myself instead of a blessing."
1:27:13/His mother said to him, "Let the curse fall on me, my son. Just do as I say and go get them for me."
1:27:14/So he went and got them and brought them to his mother, and she prepared a delicious meal, just how his father liked it.
1:27:15/Rebekah took the best clothes of her elder son Esau, which she had in the house, and put them on her younger son Jacob.
1:27:16/She also covered his hands and the smooth part of his neck with the goat skins.
1:27:17/Then she handed to her son Jacob the delicious meal and bread she had made.
1:27:18/He went to his father and said, "My father." And he said, "Here I am. Who are you, my son?"
1:27:19/Jacob said to his father, "I am Esau, your firstborn. I've done as you told me. Please sit up and eat some of my game, so you can bless me."
1:27:20/Isaac asked his son, "How did you find it so quickly, my son?" He answered, "Because the LORD your God granted me success."
1:27:21/Then Isaac said to Jacob, "Come closer so I can touch you, my son, to know whether you really are my son Esau or not."
1:27:22/Jacob went close to Isaac his father, who touched him and said, "The voice is Jacob's voice, but the hands are the hands of Esau."
1:27:23/He did not recognize him, because his hands were hairy like those of his brother Esau; so he proceeded to bless him.
1:27:24/He asked, "Are you really my son Esau?" And he replied, "I am."
1:27:25/Then he said, "Serve me, and let me eat some of my son's game, so that I may give you my blessing." Jacob brought it to him and he ate; he also brought him wine, and he drank.
1:27:26/Then his father Isaac said to him, "Come here and kiss me, my son."
1:27:27/So he went to him and kissed him. When Isaac smelled the clothes, he blessed him and said, "Ah, the smell of my son is like the smell of a field that the LORD has blessed.
1:27:28/May God give you heaven's dew and earth's richness—an abundance of grain and new wine.
1:27:29/May nations serve you and peoples bow down to you. Be lord over your brothers, and may the sons of your mother bow down to you. Cursed be everyone who curses you, and blessed be everyone who blesses you!"
1:27:30/As soon as Isaac had finished blessing Jacob, and Jacob had scarcely left his father's presence, his brother Esau came in from hunting.
1:27:31/He too prepared some delicious food and brought it to his father. He said to his father, "Let my father get up and eat some of his son's game, so that you may bless me."
1:27:32/His father Isaac asked him, "Who are you?" He answered, "I am your son, your firstborn, Esau."
1:27:33/Isaac trembled violently and said, "Who was it, then, that hunted game and brought it to me? I ate it just before you came and I blessed him—and indeed he will be blessed!"
1:27:34/When Esau heard his father's words, he let out a loud and bitter cry and said to his father, "Bless me—me too, my father!"
1:27:35/But he said, "Your brother came deceitfully and took your blessing."
1:27:36/Esau said, "Isn't he rightly named Jacob? This is the second time he has taken advantage of me: he took my birthright, and now he's taken my blessing!" Then he asked, "Haven't you reserved any blessing for me?"
1:27:37/Isaac answered Esau, "I have made him your lord and have given all his relatives to him as servants, and I have sustained him with grain and new wine. So what can I possibly do for you, my son?"
1:27:38/Esau said to his father, "Do you have only one blessing, my father? Bless me too, my father!" Then Esau wept aloud.
1:27:39/His father Isaac answered him, "Your dwelling will be away from the earth's richness, away from the dew of heaven above.
1:27:40/You will live by the sword and you will serve your brother. But when you grow restless, you will throw his yoke from off your neck."
1:27:41/Esau held a grudge against Jacob because of the blessing his father had given him. Esau said to himself, "The days of mourning for my father are near; then I will kill my brother Jacob."
1:27:42/When Rebekah was told what her older son Esau had said, she sent for her younger son Jacob and said to him, "Your brother Esau is consoling himself with the thought of killing you.
1:27:43/Now then, my son, do what I say: Flee at once to my brother Laban in Haran.
1:27:44/Stay with him for a while until your brother's fury subsides.
1:27:45/When your brother's anger against you fades and he forgets what you did to him, I'll send word for you to come back from there. Why should I lose both of you in one day?"
1:27:46/And Rebekah said to Isaac, "I'm sick of living because of these Hittite women. If Jacob takes a wife from among the women of this land, from Hittite women like these, my life will not be worth living."
1:28:1/Isaac called Jacob, blessed him, and instructed him, saying, "You must not marry any of the Canaanite women.
1:28:2/Get up, go to Padanaram, to your mother's father Bethuel's house; and choose a wife for yourself from there, from the daughters of Laban, your mother's brother.
1:28:3/May God Almighty bless you, make you fruitful, and increase your numbers so that you become a community of peoples.
1:28:4/And may He grant you the blessing of Abraham, to you and your descendants with you, so that you may take possession of the land where you now live as a foreigner, which God gave to Abraham.
1:28:5/So Isaac sent Jacob on his way, and he went to Padanaram, to Laban, son of Bethuel the Aramean, the brother of Rebekah, who was the mother of Jacob and Esau.
1:28:6/When Esau saw that Isaac had blessed Jacob and sent him to Padanaram to find a wife, and that as he blessed him he commanded him, saying, "You must not marry a Canaanite woman,"
1:28:7/And that Jacob had listened to his father and mother and had gone to Padanaram,
1:28:8/And Esau realized that his father Isaac did not approve of the Canaanite women,
1:28:9/Esau then went to Ishmael and married Mahalath, the daughter of Abraham's son Ishmael and sister of Nebajoth, in addition to the wives he already had.
1:28:10/Jacob left Beersheba and set out for Haran.
1:28:11/He came to a certain place and stayed there for the night because the sun had set. Taking one of the stones there, he used it as his pillow and lay down to sleep.
1:28:12/He had a dream in which he saw a stairway resting on the earth, with its top reaching to heaven, and the angels of God were ascending and descending on it.
1:28:13/And there above it stood the LORD, who said, "I am the LORD, the God of your father Abraham and the God of Isaac. I will give you and your descendants the land on which you are lying.
1:28:14/Your descendants will be like the dust of the earth, and you will spread out to the west and to the east, to the north and to the south. All peoples on earth will be blessed through you and your offspring.
1:28:15/I am with you and will watch over you wherever you go, and I will bring you back to this land. I will not leave you until I have done what I have promised you."
1:28:16/When Jacob awoke from his sleep, he thought, "Surely the LORD is in this place, and I was not aware of it."
1:28:17/He was filled with awe and said, "How awesome is this place! This is none other than the house of God; this is the gate of heaven."
1:28:18/Early in the morning, Jacob took the stone he had placed under his head, set it up as a pillar, and poured oil on top of it.
1:28:19/He named that place Bethel, though the city used to be called Luz.
1:28:20/Then Jacob made a vow, saying, "If God will be with me and will watch over me on this journey I am taking and will give me food to eat and clothes to wear
1:28:21/So that I return safely to my father's household, then the LORD will be my God.
1:28:22/And this stone that I have set up as a pillar will be God's house, and of all that you give me I will give you a tenth."
1:29:1/Then Jacob continued his journey and arrived in the land of the eastern peoples.
1:29:2/He saw a well in the field with three flocks of sheep resting near it; this well was used to water the flocks, and it was covered by a large stone.
1:29:3/All the flocks would gather there, and the shepherds would roll the stone away to water the sheep, then put the stone back over the well.
1:29:4/Jacob asked them, "My friends, where are you from?" They replied, "We're from Haran."
1:29:5/Then he asked, "Do you know Laban, Nahor's son?" They answered, "Yes, we know him."
1:29:6/He inquired, "Is he doing well?" They said, "He's fine, and look, here comes his daughter Rachel with the sheep."
1:29:7/He said, "Look, it's still broad daylight, not time to gather the animals. Water the sheep and take them to graze."
1:29:8/But they replied, "We can't until all the flocks are gathered and the stone is rolled away from the well; then we water the sheep."
1:29:9/While he was still talking with them, Rachel arrived with her father's sheep, for she was a shepherdess.
1:29:10/When Jacob saw Rachel, the daughter of Laban, his mother's brother, and the sheep of Laban, he went over, rolled the stone away from the well, and watered his uncle's sheep.
1:29:11/Jacob kissed Rachel, then broke down and cried.
1:29:12/He told Rachel he was her father's relative, Rebekah's son, and she ran to tell her father.
1:29:13/When Laban heard about Jacob, his sister's son, he ran to meet him, embraced him, kissed him, and brought him to his home. Jacob told Laban all that had happened.
1:29:14/Laban said to him, "You are truly my own flesh and blood." And Jacob stayed with him for a month.
1:29:15/Then Laban said to Jacob, "Just because you're my relative doesn't mean you should work for me for nothing. Tell me, what should your wages be?"
1:29:16/Laban had two daughters: the older was Leah, and the younger was Rachel.
1:29:17/Leah had soft eyes, but Rachel was stunning and beautiful.
1:29:18/Jacob was in love with Rachel and said, "I'll work for you for seven years in return for your younger daughter Rachel."
1:29:19/Laban replied, "It's better I give her to you than to someone else. Stay with me."
1:29:20/So Jacob worked seven years to get Rachel, but they felt like only a few days to him because of his love for her.
1:29:21/Then Jacob said to Laban, "My time is up; give me my wife so I can be with her."
1:29:22/Laban gathered all the men of the place and held a feast.
1:29:23/But in the evening, he took Leah, his daughter, to Jacob, and Jacob slept with her.
1:29:24/Laban gave his daughter Leah a servant, Zilpah, as a maid.
1:29:25/When morning came, there was Leah! Jacob said to Laban, "What have you done to me? I worked for Rachel. Why have you deceived me?"
1:29:26/Laban replied, "It's not our custom here to marry off the younger before the older.
1:29:27/Complete this bridal week with Leah, and we will also give you Rachel in return for another seven years of work."
1:29:28/Jacob agreed and completed the week with Leah. Then Laban gave him his daughter Rachel as a wife.
1:29:29/Laban gave his daughter Rachel a servant, Bilhah, as her maid.
1:29:30/Jacob also slept with Rachel, and he loved Rachel more than Leah. He worked for Laban for another seven years.
1:29:31/When the LORD saw that Leah was unloved, he enabled her to conceive, but Rachel remained childless.
1:29:32/Leah became pregnant and gave birth to a son. She named him Reuben, for she said, "The LORD has seen my misery; surely now my husband will love me."
1:29:33/She conceived again and gave birth to a son and said, "Because the LORD heard that I am unloved, he has given me this son also." So she named him Simeon.
1:29:34/Again she conceived and gave birth to a son and said, "Now at last my husband will become attached to me because I have borne him three sons." Therefore he was named Levi.
1:29:35/Once more she conceived and gave birth to a son. She said, "This time I will praise the LORD." Therefore she named him Judah. Then she stopped having children.
1:30:1/When Rachel saw that she couldn't have children for Jacob, she became jealous of her sister and told Jacob, "Give me children, or I'll die."
1:30:2/Jacob became angry with Rachel and said, "Am I in the place of God, who has kept you from having children?"
1:30:3/She then said, "Here's my servant Bilhah; sleep with her so she can have children on my behalf and I too can have a family through her."
1:30:4/So she gave him her servant Bilhah as a wife, and Jacob slept with her.
1:30:5/Bilhah became pregnant and gave Jacob a son.
1:30:6/Rachel said, "God has vindicated me; He has listened to my plea and given me a son." Therefore, she named him Dan.
1:30:7/Then Bilhah, Rachel's servant, became pregnant again and gave Jacob a second son.
1:30:8/Rachel said, "I have struggled greatly with my sister, and I have won." So she named him Naphtali.
1:30:9/When Leah saw that she had stopped having children, she took her servant Zilpah and gave her to Jacob as a wife.
1:30:10/And Zilpah, Leah's servant, gave Jacob a son.
1:30:11/Leah said, "A troop is coming!" So she named him Gad.
1:30:12/Then Zilpah, Leah's servant, gave Jacob a second son.
1:30:13/Leah said, "How happy I am! The women will call me happy." So she named him Asher.
1:30:14/Reuben went out during the wheat harvest and found some mandrakes in the field, which he brought to his mother Leah. Rachel asked Leah, "Please give me some of your son's mandrakes."
1:30:15/But she said to her, "Isn't it enough that you took away my husband? Will you take my son's mandrakes too?" Rachel said, "He can sleep with you tonight in exchange for your son's mandrakes."
1:30:16/When Jacob came in from the fields that evening, Leah went out to meet him and said, "You must sleep with me tonight because I have hired you with my son's mandrakes." So he slept with her that night.
1:30:17/God listened to Leah, and she became pregnant and bore Jacob a fifth son.
1:30:18/Leah said, "God has rewarded me for giving my servant to my husband." So she named him Issachar.
1:30:19/And Leah became pregnant again and gave Jacob a sixth son.
1:30:20/Leah said, "God has presented me with a precious gift. Now my husband will treat me with honor, because I have borne him six sons." So she named him Zebulun.
1:30:21/Later, she had a daughter and named her Dinah.
1:30:22/Then God remembered Rachel; He listened to her and enabled her to conceive.
1:30:23/She became pregnant and gave birth to a son and said, "God has taken away my disgrace."
1:30:24/She named him Joseph, saying, "May the Lord add another son to me."
1:30:25/After Rachel gave birth to Joseph, Jacob said to Laban, "Send me on my way so I can go back to my own homeland.
1:30:26/Give me my wives and children, for whom I have served you, and let me go. You know how much work I’ve done for you."
1:30:27/But Laban said to him, "If I have found favor in your eyes, please stay. I have learned by divination that the Lord has blessed me because of you."
1:30:28/He added, "Name your wages, and I will pay them."
1:30:29/Jacob said to him, "You know how I have worked for you and how your livestock has fared under my care.
1:30:30/The little you had before I came has increased greatly, and the Lord has blessed you wherever I turned. Now when may I do something for my own household?"
1:30:31/"What shall I give you?" Laban asked. Jacob replied, "Don’t give me anything. But if you will do this one thing for me, I will go on tending your flocks and watching over them:
1:30:32/Let me go through all your flocks today and remove from them every speckled or spotted sheep, every dark-colored lamb, and the spotted or speckled goats. They will be my wages.
1:30:33/And my honesty will testify for me in the future, whenever you check on the wages you have paid me. Any goat in my possession that is not speckled or spotted, or any lamb that is not dark-colored, will be considered stolen."
1:30:34/Laban said, "Agreed. Let it be as you have said."
1:30:35/That same day he removed all the male goats that were streaked or spotted, and all the speckled or spotted female goats (all that had white on them), and all the dark-colored lambs, and he placed them in the care of his sons.
1:30:36/Then he put a three-day journey between himself and Jacob, while Jacob continued to tend the rest of Laban's flocks.
1:30:37/Jacob, however, took fresh-cut branches from poplar, almond, and plane trees and made white stripes on them by peeling the bark and exposing the white inner wood of the branches.
1:30:38/Then he placed the peeled branches in all the watering troughs, so they would be directly in front of the flocks when they came to drink. When the flocks were in heat and came to drink,
1:30:39/they mated in front of the branches. And they bore young that were streaked, speckled, and spotted.
1:30:40/Jacob separated the lambs and set the faces of the flocks toward the streaked and all the dark-colored animals in Laban’s herd. He put his own herds by themselves and did not put them with Laban’s animals.
1:30:41/Whenever the stronger females were in heat, Jacob would place the branches in the troughs in front of the animals so they would mate near the branches,
1:30:42/but if the animals were weak, he would not put them there. So the weaker animals went to Laban and the stronger ones to Jacob.
1:30:43/As a result, the man grew exceedingly prosperous and came to own large flocks, and female and male servants, and camels and donkeys.
1:31:1/He overheard Laban's sons saying, "Jacob has taken everything that belonged to our father; he's gained all this wealth from what was once our father's."
1:31:2/And Jacob noticed that Laban's attitude towards him had changed; it was not as friendly as before.
1:31:3/Then the LORD told Jacob, "Go back to the land of your ancestors and to your family, and I will be with you."
1:31:4/Jacob sent for Rachel and Leah to come out to the fields where his flocks were.
1:31:5/He told them, "I've noticed that your father doesn't look at me the same way he used to; however, the God of my father has been with me.
1:31:6/You both know how hard I've worked for your father.
1:31:7/Yet your father has cheated me and changed my wages ten times; but God didn't allow him to harm me.
1:31:8/If he said, 'Your wages will be the speckled animals,' then all the animals gave birth to speckled young. And if he said, 'Your wages will be the striped animals,' then all the animals gave birth to striped young.
1:31:9/In this way, God has taken your father's livestock and given them to me.
1:31:10/It happened that during the breeding season, I had a dream where I saw that the male goats mating with the females were striped, speckled, and mottled.
1:31:11/And in the dream, God's angel called out to me, 'Jacob!' and I answered, 'Here I am.'
1:31:12/He said, 'Look up and see that all the male goats mating with the flock are striped, speckled, and mottled, for I have seen everything Laban has been doing to you.
1:31:13/I am the God of Bethel, where you anointed a pillar and made a vow to me. Now, get up, leave this land, and return to your homeland.'
1:31:14/Rachel and Leah responded, "Do we still have any share in our father's inheritance?
1:31:15/Aren't we considered foreigners by him? He sold us and has used up all the money that should have been ours.
1:31:16/All the wealth that God has taken from our father belongs to us and our children. So do whatever God has told you."
1:31:17/Then Jacob got ready, put his children and wives on camels,
1:31:18/and took all his livestock and all the possessions he had acquired in Paddan-aram to go to his father Isaac in the land of Canaan.
1:31:19/While Laban was away shearing his sheep, Rachel stole her father's household gods.
1:31:20/Jacob deceived Laban the Aramean by not telling him he was fleeing.
1:31:21/So he fled with all he had, crossed the Euphrates River, and headed for the hill country of Gilead.
1:31:22/Three days later, Laban was told that Jacob had fled.
1:31:23/So he took his relatives with him, pursued Jacob for seven days, and caught up with him in the hill country of Gilead.
1:31:24/But God came to Laban the Aramean in a dream at night and said to him, "Be careful not to say anything to Jacob, either good or bad."
1:31:25/When Laban caught up with Jacob, Jacob had pitched his tent in the hills, and Laban and his relatives camped in the hill country of Gilead.
1:31:26/Laban said to Jacob, "What have you done? You've deceived me and carried off my daughters like captives in war.
1:31:27/Why did you run off secretly and deceive me? Why didn't you tell me, so I could send you off with joy and singing to the music of timbrels and harps?
1:31:28/You didn't even let me kiss my grandchildren and my daughters goodbye. You have done a foolish thing.
1:31:29/I have the power to harm you; but last night the God of your father warned me, 'Be careful not to say anything to Jacob, either good or bad.'
1:31:30/Now you have gone because you longed to return to your father's household. But why did you steal my gods?"
1:31:31/Jacob answered Laban, "I was afraid, because I thought you would take your daughters away from me by force.
1:31:32/But if you find anyone who has your gods, that person shall not live. In the presence of our relatives, see for yourself whether there is anything of yours here with me; and if so, take it." Now Jacob did not know that Rachel had stolen the gods.
1:31:33/So Laban went into Jacob's tent, into Leah's tent, and into the tents of the two female servants, but he found nothing. After he came out of Leah's tent, he entered Rachel's tent.
1:31:34/Now Rachel had taken the household gods and put them inside her camel's saddle and was sitting on them. Laban searched through everything in the tent but found nothing.
1:31:35/Rachel said to her father, "Don't be angry, my lord, that I cannot stand up in your presence; I'm having my period." So he searched but could not find the household gods.
1:31:36/Jacob became angry and argued with Laban. Jacob said to him, "What is my crime? What sin have I committed that you hunt me down?
1:31:37/Now that you have searched through all my goods, what have you found that belongs to your household? Put it here in front of your relatives and mine, and let them judge between us.
1:31:38/I've been with you for twenty years now. Your sheep and goats have not miscarried, nor have I eaten rams from your flocks.
1:31:39/I did not bring you animals torn by wild beasts; I bore the loss myself. And you demanded payment from me for whatever was stolen by day or night.
1:31:40/This was my situation: The heat consumed me in the daytime and the cold at night, and sleep fled from my eyes.
1:31:41/It was like this for the twenty years I was in your household. I worked for you fourteen years for your two daughters and six years for your flock, and you changed my wages ten times.
1:31:42/If the God of my father, the God of Abraham and the Fear of Isaac, had not been with me, you would surely have sent me away empty-handed. But God has seen my hardship and the toil of my hands, and last night he rebuked you."
1:31:43/Laban answered Jacob, "The women are my daughters, the children are my children, and the flocks are my flocks. Everything you see is mine. Yet what can I do today about these daughters of mine, or about the children they have borne?
1:31:44/Come now, let's make a covenant, you and I, and let it serve as a witness between us."
1:31:45/So Jacob took a stone and set it up as a pillar.
1:31:46/Then Jacob said to his relatives, "Gather some stones." So they took stones and made a heap, and they ate there by the heap.
1:31:47/Laban called it Jegar-sahadutha, but Jacob called it Galeed.
1:31:48/Laban said, "This heap is a witness between you and me today." That is why it was called Galeed,
1:31:49/And also Mizpah, because he said, "May the LORD keep watch between you and me when we are away from each other.
1:31:50/If you mistreat my daughters or if you take any wives besides my daughters, even though no one is with us, remember that God is a witness between you and me."
1:31:51/Then Laban said to Jacob, "Here is this heap, and here is this pillar I have set up between you and me.
1:31:52/This heap is a witness, and this pillar is a witness, that I will not go past this heap to your side to harm you and that you will not go past this heap and pillar to my side to harm me.
1:31:53/May the God of Abraham and the God of Nahor, the God of their father, judge between us." So Jacob took an oath in the name of the Fear of his father Isaac.
1:31:54/Then Jacob offered a sacrifice on the mountain and invited his relatives to eat a meal. After they had eaten, they spent the night on the mountain.
1:31:55/Early the next morning, Laban kissed his grandchildren and his daughters and blessed them. Then Laban left and returned home.
1:32:1/And Jacob continued on his journey, and he encountered angels of God.
1:32:2/When Jacob saw them, he said, "This is God's army," and he named that place Mahanaim.
1:32:3/Jacob sent messengers ahead to his brother Esau in the land of Seir, the region of Edom.
1:32:4/He instructed them, "This is what you should say to my lord Esau: 'Your servant Jacob says, I have been staying with Laban and have remained there until now:
1:32:5/I have acquired cattle, donkeys, sheep, male servants, and female servants, and I am sending this message to my lord in hopes of gaining your favor.'"
1:32:6/The messengers returned to Jacob, saying, "We went to your brother Esau, and he is coming to meet you, with four hundred men accompanying him."
1:32:7/Then Jacob was very afraid and distressed, so he divided the people with him, as well as the flocks, herds, and camels, into two groups;
1:32:8/Thinking, "If Esau attacks one group, the other group that is left may escape."
1:32:9/And Jacob prayed, "O God of my father Abraham and God of my father Isaac, LORD, who told me, 'Go back to your country and your relatives, and I will make things go well for you':
1:32:10/I am unworthy of all the kindness and faithfulness you have shown your servant; I had only my staff when I crossed this Jordan, and now I have become two groups.
1:32:11/Please save me from the hand of my brother, from the hand of Esau, for I am afraid he might come and attack me, and the mothers with their children.
1:32:12/And you have said, 'I will surely treat you well and make your descendants as numerous as the sand of the sea, which is too great to count.'"
1:32:13/He spent that night there and selected a gift for his brother Esau from what he had:
1:32:14/Two hundred female goats and twenty male goats, two hundred ewes and twenty rams,
1:32:15/Thirty nursing camels with their young, forty cows and ten bulls, twenty female donkeys and ten male donkeys.
1:32:16/He handed them over to his servants, each herd by itself, and said to his servants, "Go ahead of me and keep some space between the herds."
1:32:17/He instructed the one in the lead, "When my brother Esau meets you and asks, 'Who do you belong to? Where are you going? And who owns all these animals in front of you?'
1:32:18/Then you are to say, 'They belong to your servant Jacob. They are a gift sent to my lord Esau, and he is coming behind us.'"
1:32:19/He also gave the same instructions to the second, the third, and all the others who followed the herds, "This is what you are to say to Esau when you meet him.
1:32:20/And be sure to say, 'Look, your servant Jacob is right behind us.'" Jacob thought, "I will pacify him with these gifts going ahead of me, and later, when I see him, perhaps he will receive me."
1:32:21/So the gifts went on ahead of him, while he himself spent that night in the camp.
1:32:22/That night he got up and took his two wives, his two female servants, and his eleven sons and crossed the ford of the Jabbok.
1:32:23/After he had sent them across the stream, he sent over all his possessions.
1:32:24/So Jacob was left alone, and a man wrestled with him till daybreak.
1:32:25/When the man saw that he could not overpower him, he touched the socket of Jacob's hip so that his hip was wrenched as he wrestled with the man.
1:32:26/Then the man said, "Let me go, for it is daybreak." But Jacob replied, "I will not let you go unless you bless me."
1:32:27/The man asked him, "What is your name?" "Jacob," he answered.
1:32:28/Then the man said, "Your name will no longer be Jacob, but Israel, because you have struggled with God and with humans and have overcome."
1:32:29/Jacob said, "Please tell me your name." But he replied, "Why do you ask my name?" And there he blessed Jacob.
1:32:30/So Jacob called the place Peniel, saying, "It is because I saw God face to face, and yet my life was spared."
1:32:31/As he crossed over Penuel, the sun rose on him and he was limping because of his hip.
1:32:32/That is why to this day the Israelites do not eat the tendon attached to the socket of the hip, because the man touched the socket of Jacob's hip in the tendon that shrank.
1:33:1/Jacob looked up and saw Esau coming with four hundred men. He then divided his children among Leah, Rachel, and the two maidservants.
1:33:2/He placed the maidservants and their children in front, Leah and her children next, and finally Rachel and Joseph at the back.
1:33:3/He went ahead of them, bowing to the ground seven times as he approached his brother.
1:33:4/Esau ran to meet him, hugged him, put his arms around his neck, and kissed him. They both cried.
1:33:5/When he saw the women and children, he asked, "Who are these with you?" Jacob answered, "These are the children God has graciously given to me, your servant."
1:33:6/Then the maidservants and their children approached and bowed down.
1:33:7/Next, Leah and her children came forward and bowed down, and after them, Joseph and Rachel also bowed down.
1:33:8/Esau asked, "What's the meaning of all the herds I met?" Jacob replied, "To gain favor in your eyes, my lord."
1:33:9/Esau said, "I have plenty, my brother; keep what you have for yourself."
1:33:10/But Jacob said, "Please, if I have found favor with you, accept my gift. Seeing your face is like seeing the face of God, especially since you have accepted me."
1:33:11/"Please accept my gift that has been brought to you, because God has been gracious to me and I have all I need." And because Jacob insisted, Esau accepted it.
1:33:12/Esau suggested, "Let's get going and I'll lead the way."
1:33:13/But Jacob said, "My lord knows that the children are delicate, and I have to care for the nursing flocks and herds. If they are driven hard for even one day, all the animals could die.
1:33:14/Please go ahead of your servant. I'll move at a slow pace, in step with the livestock and the children, until I reach my lord in Seir."
1:33:15/Esau offered, "Then let me leave some of my men with you." But Jacob asked, "Why do that? Just let me find favor in the eyes of my lord."
1:33:16/So Esau set off that day back to Seir.
1:33:17/Jacob traveled to Succoth, built a house, and made shelters for his livestock. That's why the place is called Succoth.
1:33:18/Jacob arrived safely at the city of Shechem in Canaan, coming from Paddan Aram, and camped in front of the city.
1:33:19/He bought a piece of land where he pitched his tent from the sons of Hamor, Shechem's father, for a hundred pieces of silver.
1:33:20/He set up an altar there and named it El-Elohe-Israel.
1:34:1/Dinah, the daughter of Leah and Jacob, went out to see the local women.
1:34:2/When Shechem, the son of Hamor the Hivite and prince of the region, saw her, he took her, forced himself on her, and violated her.
1:34:3/He became deeply attached to Dinah, Jacob's daughter, fell in love with her, and spoke tenderly to her.
1:34:4/Shechem asked his father Hamor, "Please get me this girl as my wife."
1:34:5/Jacob found out that Shechem had violated his daughter Dinah. His sons were out in the fields with his livestock, so he didn't say anything until they returned.
1:34:6/Hamor, Shechem's father, went to talk to Jacob about the matter.
1:34:7/When Jacob's sons heard about it, they came in from the fields. They were deeply upset and furious because Shechem had done something outrageous in Israel by sleeping with Jacob's daughter—a thing that should never be done.
1:34:8/Hamor tried to negotiate with them, saying, "My son Shechem longs for your daughter. Please let him marry her."
1:34:9/"Let's make marriages between us. Give us your daughters, and take our daughters for yourselves.
1:34:10/You can live among us; the land is open to you. Live here, trade, and acquire property in it."
1:34:11/Shechem also said to her father and brothers, "Let me win your favor, and I'll give you whatever you ask.
1:34:12/Demand any bride-price or gift, and I'll pay it. Just let me marry the girl."
1:34:13/Jacob's sons responded deceitfully to Shechem and his father Hamor because of what he had done to their sister Dinah.
1:34:14/They said, "We can't do this; we can't give our sister to a man who is not circumcised. That would be a disgrace to us.
1:34:15/But we will agree to it on one condition: if every male among you gets circumcised as we are.
1:34:16/Then we'll give you our daughters, take your daughters for ourselves, live among you, and become one community.
1:34:17/But if you don't agree to be circumcised, we'll take our sister and leave."
1:34:18/Hamor and his son Shechem were pleased with this proposal.
1:34:19/Shechem didn't hesitate to do what was asked because he was smitten with Jacob's daughter. He was more respected than anyone else in his father's household.
1:34:20/Hamor and Shechem went to their city's gate and spoke to the men of their city, saying,
1:34:21/"These men are friendly toward us. Let them live in the land and trade in it. The land has plenty of room for them. We can marry their daughters and give them ours.
1:34:22/But there's one condition for them to agree to live with us and become one community: every male among us must be circumcised as they are.
1:34:23/Then won't their livestock, property, and all their animals become ours? Just agree to their condition, and they will settle among us."
1:34:24/Everyone who went out of the city gate listened to Hamor and his son Shechem, and every male was circumcised, all who went out of the gate of his city.
1:34:25/On the third day, when they were in pain, two of Jacob's sons, Simeon and Levi, Dinah's brothers, took their swords, boldly attacked the city, and killed all the males.
1:34:26/They killed Hamor and his son Shechem with the sword, took Dinah from Shechem's house, and left.
1:34:27/Jacob's sons came upon the dead and looted the city because their sister had been defiled.
1:34:28/They seized their flocks, herds, donkeys, everything in the city, and in the fields,
1:34:29/took all their wealth, their children, and their wives, and plundered everything in the houses.
1:34:30/Jacob said to Simeon and Levi, "You've brought trouble on me, making me odious to the inhabitants of the land, the Canaanites and the Perizzites. Since I have few men, they'll band together against me, attack me, and I and my household will be destroyed."
1:34:31/But they said, "Should he treat our sister like a prostitute?"
1:35:1/And God told Jacob, "Get up, go to Bethel, and live there. Make an altar there to God, who appeared to you when you were running away from your brother Esau."
1:35:2/Then Jacob told his family and everyone with him, "Get rid of the foreign gods you have, purify yourselves, and change your clothes.
1:35:3/Let's get up and go to Bethel. There, I will build an altar to God, who listened to me in my time of trouble and has been with me wherever I have gone."
1:35:4/So they gave Jacob all the foreign gods they had and the earrings they were wearing. Jacob buried them under the oak near Shechem.
1:35:5/As they traveled, a great fear from God fell upon the surrounding cities, so they did not chase after Jacob's group.
1:35:6/So Jacob arrived at Luz, which is in the land of Canaan, also known as Bethel, along with all the people with him.
1:35:7/There he built an altar and named the place Elbethel, because God had appeared to him there when he was fleeing from his brother.
1:35:8/But Deborah, Rebekah’s nurse, died, and she was buried under an oak below Bethel, so it was named Allonbachuth.
1:35:9/And God appeared to Jacob again after he returned from Paddan-aram and blessed him.
1:35:10/And God told him, "Your name is Jacob, but you will no longer be called Jacob; your name will be Israel." So he named him Israel.
1:35:11/And God said to him, "I am God Almighty: be fruitful and increase in number; a nation and a community of nations will come from you, and kings will be among your descendants.
1:35:12/And the land I gave to Abraham and Isaac, I will give to you, and I will give this land to your descendants after you."
1:35:13/Then God left him at the place where he had spoken with him.
1:35:14/And Jacob set up a stone pillar at the place where God had talked with him, and he poured out a drink offering on it, and also poured oil on it.
1:35:15/And Jacob named the place where God had spoken with him, Bethel.
1:35:16/They left Bethel, and when they were still some distance from Ephrath, Rachel began to give birth and had a difficult labor.
1:35:17/When she was in severe labor, the midwife said to her, "Don't be afraid; you're going to have another son."
1:35:18/As she was dying, she named her son Ben-Oni, but his father named him Benjamin.
1:35:19/And Rachel died and was buried on the way to Ephrath, which is Bethlehem.
1:35:20/And Jacob set up a pillar over her grave; it is the pillar of Rachel's grave to this day.
1:35:21/Then Israel moved on and pitched his tent beyond Migdal Eder.
1:35:22/While Israel was living in that region, Reuben went and slept with Bilhah, his father's concubine, and Israel heard about it. Jacob had twelve sons:
1:35:23/The sons of Leah: Reuben, Jacob’s firstborn, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, and Zebulun.
1:35:24/The sons of Rachel: Joseph and Benjamin.
1:35:25/And the sons of Bilhah, Rachel’s servant: Dan and Naphtali.
1:35:26/And the sons of Zilpah, Leah’s servant: Gad and Asher. These were Jacob's sons, born to him in Paddan-aram.
1:35:27/And Jacob came to his father Isaac at Mamre, or Kiriath Arba (that is, Hebron), where Abraham and Isaac had stayed.
1:35:28/Isaac lived 180 years.
1:35:29/Then Isaac breathed his last and died, and was gathered to his people, old and full of years. His sons Esau and Jacob buried him.
1:36:1/Here are the descendants of Esau, also known as Edom.
1:36:2/Esau married women from Canaan: Adah, daughter of Elon the Hittite, and Aholibamah, daughter of Anah and granddaughter of Zibeon the Hivite;
1:36:3/And Bashemath, daughter of Ishmael and sister of Nebajoth.
1:36:4/Adah gave birth to Eliphaz for Esau; Bashemath gave birth to Reuel;
1:36:5/And Aholibamah gave birth to Jeush, Jaalam, and Korah. These are Esau's sons, born to him in Canaan.
1:36:6/Esau took his wives, sons, daughters, all household members, his livestock, all his animals, and all his possessions he had acquired in Canaan, and moved to a region away from his brother Jacob.
1:36:7/Their wealth was so great that they couldn't live together; the land where they were staying couldn't support them because of their livestock.
1:36:8/So Esau settled in the hill country of Seir. Esau is Edom.
1:36:9/These are the descendants of Esau, the ancestor of the Edomites, in the hill country of Seir:
1:36:10/These are the names of Esau's sons: Eliphaz, son of Esau's wife Adah, and Reuel, son of Esau's wife Bashemath.
1:36:11/The sons of Eliphaz were Teman, Omar, Zepho, Gatam, and Kenaz.
1:36:12/Timna, a concubine of Eliphaz, Esau's son, bore Amalek to Eliphaz. These were the sons of Esau's wife Adah.
1:36:13/These are the sons of Reuel: Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah. These were the sons of Esau's wife Bashemath.
1:36:14/These were the sons of Aholibamah, daughter of Anah and granddaughter of Zibeon, Esau's wife. She bore to Esau Jeush, Jaalam, and Korah.
1:36:15/These were the chiefs among Esau's sons: the sons of Eliphaz, Esau's firstborn, chief Teman, chief Omar, chief Zepho, chief Kenaz,
1:36:16/Chief Korah, chief Gatam, and chief Amalek. These are the chiefs from Eliphaz in Edom; these were the sons of Adah.
1:36:17/And these are the sons of Reuel, Esau's son; chief Nahath, chief Zerah, chief Shammah, chief Mizzah. These are the chiefs from Reuel in Edom; these are the sons of Esau's wife Bashemath.
1:36:18/And these are the sons of Aholibamah, Esau's wife; chief Jeush, chief Jaalam, chief Korah. These were the chiefs from Aholibamah, daughter of Anah, Esau's wife.
1:36:19/These are the sons of Esau (who is Edom), and these are their chiefs.
1:36:20/These are the sons of Seir the Horite, who lived in the land: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, and Anah,
1:36:21/And Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan. These are the chiefs of the Horites, the descendants of Seir in Edom.
1:36:22/And the children of Lotan were Hori and Hemam; Lotan's sister was Timna.
1:36:23/And the children of Shobal were Alvan, Manahath, Ebal, Shepho, and Onam.
1:36:24/And these are the children of Zibeon: both Ajah and Anah. This was the Anah who discovered the hot springs in the wilderness while pasturing the donkeys of his father Zibeon.
1:36:25/And the children of Anah were Dishon and Aholibamah, the daughter of Anah.
1:36:26/And these are the children of Dishon: Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran, and Cheran.
1:36:27/The children of Ezer are these: Bilhan, Zaavan, and Akan.
1:36:28/The children of Dishan are these: Uz and Aran.
1:36:29/These are the chiefs who came from the Horites: chief Lotan, chief Shobal, chief Zibeon, chief Anah,
1:36:30/Chief Dishon, chief Ezer, chief Dishan. These are the chiefs who came from Hori, among their chiefs in the land of Seir.
1:36:31/These are the kings who ruled in Edom before any Israelite king reigned.
1:36:32/Bela, son of Beor, ruled in Edom, and the name of his city was Dinhabah.
1:36:33/When Bela died, Jobab, son of Zerah from Bozrah, succeeded him.
1:36:34/After Jobab died, Husham from the land of the Temanites ruled in his place.
1:36:35/When Husham died, Hadad, son of Bedad, who defeated Midian in the field of Moab, ruled in his place. His city was named Avith.
1:36:36/After Hadad died, Samlah from Masrekah ruled in his place.
1:36:37/When Samlah died, Saul from Rehoboth on the river succeeded him.
1:36:38/After Saul died, Baal-hanan, son of Achbor, ruled in his place.
1:36:39/When Baal-hanan, son of Achbor, died, Hadar ruled in his place. His city was named Pau, and his wife's name was Mehetabel, daughter of Matred, daughter of Mezahab.
1:36:40/These are the names of the chiefs descended from Esau, by their families, locations, and by their names: chief Timnah, chief Alvah, chief Jetheth,
1:36:41/Chief Aholibamah, chief Elah, chief Pinon,
1:36:42/Chief Kenaz, chief Teman, chief Mibzar,
1:36:43/Chief Magdiel, chief Iram. These are the chiefs of Edom, according to their settlements in the land they owned. This is Esau, the father of the Edomites.
1:37:1/Jacob lived in the land where his father had been a foreigner, in the land of Canaan.
1:37:2/These are the descendants of Jacob. Joseph, at seventeen years old, was tending the flock with his brothers; and the young man was with the sons of Bilhah and Zilpah, his father's wives. Joseph reported their bad behavior to their father.
1:37:3/Israel loved Joseph more than all his other children because he was born in his old age, and he made him a colorful coat.
1:37:4/When his brothers saw that their father loved him more than any of them, they hated him and couldn't speak to him kindly.
1:37:5/Joseph had a dream and when he told his brothers about it, they hated him even more.
1:37:6/He said to them, "Please listen to this dream I had:
1:37:7/We were tying up bundles of grain in the field when suddenly my bundle stood up and your bundles gathered around mine and bowed down to it."
1:37:8/His brothers asked him, "Do you really think you will reign over us or have authority over us?" And they disliked him even more because of his dreams and what he said.
1:37:9/Then he had another dream and told it to his brothers, saying, "Look, I had another dream, and this time the sun, moon, and eleven stars were bowing down to me."
1:37:10/When he told his father and brothers, his father scolded him and said, "What kind of dream is this? Will your mother, your brothers, and I actually come to bow down to the ground before you?"
1:37:11/His brothers were jealous of him, but his father kept the matter in mind.
1:37:12/His brothers went to graze their father's flock near Shechem.
1:37:13/Israel said to Joseph, "Aren't your brothers grazing the flock in Shechem? Come, I'll send you to them." And he replied, "Here I am."
1:37:14/He told him, "Go and see if everything is alright with your brothers and the flock, and bring me back a report." So he sent him off from the Valley of Hebron, and Joseph went to Shechem.
1:37:15/A man found him wandering in the fields and asked him, "What are you looking for?"
1:37:16/He replied, "I'm looking for my brothers. Please tell me where they are grazing their flocks."
1:37:17/The man said, "They have moved on from here; I heard them say, 'Let's go to Dothan.'" So Joseph went after his brothers and found them in Dothan.
1:37:18/But they saw him in the distance, and before he reached them, they plotted to kill him.
1:37:19/They said to each other, "Here comes that dreamer.
1:37:20/Let's kill him and throw him into one of these cisterns. We can say a vicious animal ate him. Then we'll see what comes of his dreams."
1:37:21/When Reuben heard this, he tried to rescue him from their hands. "Let's not take his life," he said.
1:37:22/Reuben said to them, "Don't shed any blood. Throw him into this cistern here in the wilderness, but don't lay a hand on him." He said this to rescue him from them and take him back to his father.
1:37:23/So when Joseph arrived, his brothers stripped him of his colorful coat, the one he was wearing.
1:37:24/Then they took him and threw him into the cistern. The cistern was empty; there was no water in it.
1:37:25/As they sat down to eat, they looked up and saw a caravan of Ishmaelites coming from Gilead. Their camels were loaded with spices, balm, and myrrh, on their way to take them down to Egypt.
1:37:26/Judah said to his brothers, "What do we gain if we kill our brother and cover up his blood?
1:37:27/Come, let's sell him to the Ishmaelites and not lay our hands on him; after all, he is our brother, our own flesh." His brothers agreed.
1:37:28/Then some Midianite traders passed by. They pulled Joseph up out of the cistern and sold him to the Ishmaelites for twenty pieces of silver. And they took Joseph to Egypt.
1:37:29/When Reuben returned to the cistern and saw that Joseph was not there, he tore his clothes.
1:37:30/He went back to his brothers and said, "The boy is gone! What am I going to do?"
1:37:31/Then they took Joseph's coat, slaughtered a goat, and dipped the coat in the blood.
1:37:32/They took the colorful coat back to their father and said, "We found this. Please examine it to see if it is your son's coat or not."
1:37:33/He recognized it and said, "It is my son's coat. A wild animal must have eaten him. Joseph has surely been torn to pieces."

1:38:1/At that time, Judah left his brothers and stayed with a man from Adullam named Hirah.
1:38:2/There, Judah met the daughter of a Canaanite man named Shuah. He married her and slept with her.
1:38:3/She became pregnant and gave birth to a son, whom she named Er.
1:38:4/She got pregnant again and gave birth to another son, naming him Onan.
1:38:5/Once more, she became pregnant and had a son, whom she named Shelah. She was in Chezib when she gave birth to him.
1:38:6/Judah arranged for Er, his firstborn, to marry a woman named Tamar.
1:38:7/But Er, Judah's firstborn, was evil in the Lord's sight, so the Lord took his life.
1:38:8/Then Judah told Onan, "Marry your brother's widow. Fulfill your duty as a brother-in-law and provide offspring for your brother."
1:38:9/But Onan knew that the child would not be considered his. So whenever he slept with his brother's wife, he wasted his semen on the ground to avoid providing offspring for his brother.
1:38:10/What he did was displeasing in the Lord's sight, so He also took Onan's life.

1:38:14/she took off her widow's clothes, covered herself with a veil to disguise herself, and sat down at the entrance to Enaim, which is on the road to Timnath. She saw that Shelah had grown up, but she had not been given to him as his wife.
1:38:15/When Judah saw her, he thought she was a prostitute because she had covered her face.
1:38:16/He turned to her by the roadside and said, "Come, let me sleep with you." He did not realize she was his daughter-in-law. She asked, "What will you give me to sleep with you?"
1:38:17/He replied, "I'll send you a young goat from my flock." She asked, "Will you give me something as a pledge until you send it?"
1:38:18/He asked, "What pledge should I give you?" She replied, "Your seal, its cord, and the staff in your hand." So he gave them to her, slept with her, and she became pregnant by him.
1:38:19/She got up, left, removed her veil, and put on her widow's clothes again.
1:38:20/Judah sent the young goat by his friend the Adullamite to get his pledge back from the woman, but he did not find her.
1:38:21/He asked the men of the area, "Where is the shrine prostitute who was beside the road at Enaim?" They said, "There hasn't been any shrine prostitute here."
1:38:22/He went back to Judah and said, "I didn't find her. Also, the men of the area said there hasn't been any shrine prostitute here."
1:38:23/Judah said, "Let her keep the items, or we'll become a laughingstock. After all, I did send this young goat, but you didn't find her."

1:38:26/Judah recognized them and said, "She is more righteous than I, since I didn't give her to my son Shelah." And he did not sleep with her again.

1:39:1/Joseph was taken to Egypt; Potiphar, an officer of Pharaoh and captain of the guard, an Egyptian, bought him from the Ishmaelites who had brought him there.
1:39:2/The LORD was with Joseph, making him a successful man; he lived in the house of his Egyptian master.
1:39:3/His master noticed that the LORD was with him and that the LORD made everything he did successful.
1:39:4/Joseph gained his favor and served him; he appointed him overseer of his house, entrusting him with everything he owned.
1:39:5/From the time he appointed him overseer in his house and over all he owned, the LORD blessed the Egyptian's house because of Joseph; the LORD's blessing was on everything he had, both in the house and in the field.
1:39:6/He left everything he had in Joseph's care; he did not concern himself with anything except the food he ate. Joseph was handsome and well-built.
1:39:7/After these events, his master's wife took notice of Joseph and said, "Sleep with me."
1:39:8/But he refused and told his master's wife, "Look, my master doesn't worry about anything in the house with me here, and he has entrusted everything he owns to my care.
1:39:9/No one is greater in this house than I am; my master has withheld nothing from me except you, because you are his wife. How could I do such a wicked thing and sin against God?"
1:39:10/Even though she spoke to Joseph day after day, he refused to go to bed with her or even be with her.
1:39:11/One day, when Joseph went into the house to attend to his duties, and none of the household servants were inside,
1:39:12/she caught him by his cloak and said, "Sleep with me." But he left his cloak in her hand, ran out of the house, and escaped.
1:39:13/When she saw that he had left his cloak in her hand and had run out of the house,
1:39:14/she called her household servants. "Look," she said to them, "this Hebrew has been brought to us to make a fool of us! He came in here to sleep with me, but I screamed.
1:39:15/When he heard me scream for help, he left his cloak beside me and ran out of the house."
1:39:16/She kept his cloak beside her until his master came home.
1:39:17/Then she told him the same story, saying, "The Hebrew servant you brought us came to me to make a fool of me.
1:39:18/But as soon as I screamed for help, he left his cloak beside me and ran out of the house."
1:39:19/When his master heard the story his wife told him, saying, "This is how your servant treated me," he burned with anger.
1:39:20/Joseph's master took him and put him in prison, the place where the king's prisoners were confined. And there he was, in the prison.
1:39:21/But the LORD was with Joseph and extended kindness to him, granting him favor in the eyes of the prison warden.
1:39:22/The warden put all the prisoners in the prison under Joseph's care; he was responsible for all that was done there.
1:39:23/The warden paid no attention to anything under Joseph's care, because the LORD was with him and made whatever he did successful.
1:40:1/After these events, the king of Egypt's cupbearer and baker offended their master, the king of Egypt.
1:40:2/Pharaoh became angry with two of his officials, the head cupbearer and the head baker.
1:40:3/He imprisoned them in the house of the captain of the guard, in the same prison where Joseph was confined.
1:40:4/The captain of the guard assigned Joseph to attend to them, and they spent some time in custody.
1:40:5/Both of them had a dream on the same night, each dream with its own meaning, the cupbearer and the baker of the king of Egypt, who were imprisoned.
1:40:6/When Joseph came to them in the morning, he saw that they were troubled.
1:40:7/He asked Pharaoh's officials who were in custody with him, "Why do you look so downcast today?"
1:40:8/They replied, "We have had dreams, but there is no one to interpret them." Joseph said to them, "Aren't interpretations God's business? Please tell me your dreams."
1:40:9/The chief cupbearer described his dream to Joseph, saying, "In my dream, I saw a vine in front of me;
1:40:10/And on the vine were three branches. It seemed as though it budded, its blossoms bloomed, and its clusters ripened into grapes.
1:40:11/I had Pharaoh's cup in my hand, and I took the grapes, squeezed them into Pharaoh's cup, and placed the cup in his hand."
1:40:12/Joseph told him, "This is what it means: The three branches represent three days.
1:40:13/Within three days, Pharaoh will restore your position, and you will place Pharaoh's cup in his hand, just as you used to do when you were his cupbearer.
1:40:14/But when things go well with you, please remember me and show me kindness; mention me to Pharaoh and get me out of this prison.
1:40:15/For I was kidnapped from the land of the Hebrews, and here I have done nothing to deserve being put in a dungeon."
1:40:16/When the chief baker saw that the interpretation was favorable, he said to Joseph, "I also had a dream, and in my dream, there were three white baskets on my head;
1:40:17/In the top basket were all kinds of baked goods for Pharaoh, but the birds were eating them out of the basket on my head."
1:40:18/Joseph responded, "This is its interpretation: The three baskets are three days.
1:40:19/Within three days, Pharaoh will remove your head from you and hang you on a tree, and the birds will eat your flesh."
1:40:20/On the third day, which was Pharaoh's birthday, he held a feast for all his servants. He lifted up the heads of the chief cupbearer and the chief baker among his servants.
1:40:21/He restored the chief cupbearer to his position, so that he once again placed the cup in Pharaoh's hand,
1:40:22/But he hanged the chief baker, just as Joseph had interpreted to them.
1:40:23/However, the chief cupbearer did not remember Joseph; he forgot him.
1:41:1/After two full years had passed, Pharaoh had a dream: he was standing by the river.
1:41:2/Suddenly, seven healthy and well-fed cows came up out of the river and grazed in the meadow.
1:41:3/Then, seven other cows, sickly and thin, came up after them from the river and stood beside the healthy cows on the riverbank.
1:41:4/The sickly and thin cows ate up the seven healthy and well-fed cows. Then Pharaoh woke up.
1:41:5/He fell asleep again and dreamed a second time: seven ears of grain, healthy and good, grew on a single stalk.
1:41:6/After them, seven other ears of grain sprouted—thin and scorched by the east wind.
1:41:7/The seven thin ears swallowed up the seven healthy, full ears. Pharaoh woke up and realized it was a dream.
1:41:8/In the morning, he was troubled, so he summoned all of Egypt's magicians and wise men. Pharaoh told them his dreams, but no one could interpret them for him.
1:41:9/Then the chief cupbearer spoke to Pharaoh, saying, "Today I remember my mistakes:
1:41:10/Pharaoh was angry with his servants, and imprisoned me and the chief baker in the house of the captain of the guard.
1:41:11/We both had dreams on the same night, each dream with its own meaning.
1:41:12/A young Hebrew man was there with us, a servant of the captain of the guard. We told him our dreams, and he interpreted them for us, giving each man the interpretation of his dream.
1:41:13/And things turned out exactly as he interpreted for us: I was restored to my position, and the baker was hanged."
1:41:14/Pharaoh immediately sent for Joseph, and he was quickly brought out of the dungeon. He shaved, changed his clothes, and came before Pharaoh.
1:41:15/Pharaoh said to Joseph, "I had a dream, and no one can interpret it. But I've heard it said about you that when you hear a dream, you can interpret it."
1:41:16/Joseph replied to Pharaoh, "I cannot do it myself, but God will give Pharaoh the answer he desires."
1:41:17/Pharaoh said to Joseph, "In my dream, I was standing on the bank of the river:
1:41:18/And I saw seven cows, fat and healthy, come up out of the river and graze in the reed grass.
1:41:19/Then, seven other cows came up after them, miserable and very thin, such as I had never seen in all the land of Egypt for badness.
1:41:20/And the thin and sickly cows ate up the first seven fat cows.
1:41:21/But after they had eaten them, no one could tell that they had done so; they looked just as miserable as before. Then I woke up.
1:41:22/In my dream, I also saw seven ears of grain, full and good, growing on a single stalk.
1:41:23/After them, seven other ears sprouted—withered, thin, and scorched by the east wind.
1:41:24/And the thin ears swallowed up the seven good ears. I told this to the magicians, but no one could explain it to me."
1:41:25/Joseph said to Pharaoh, "Pharaoh's dreams are one and the same: God has revealed to Pharaoh what he is about to do.
1:41:26/The seven good cows are seven years, and the seven good ears are seven years; it's one and the same dream.
1:41:27/The seven thin and sickly cows that came up after them are seven years, and the seven empty ears scorched by the east wind will be seven years of famine.
1:41:28/This is what I have told Pharaoh: God has shown Pharaoh what he is about to do.
1:41:29/Seven years of great abundance are coming throughout the land of Egypt,
1:41:30/But seven years of famine will follow them. Then all the abundance in Egypt will be forgotten, and the famine will ravage the land.
1:41:31/The abundance in the land will not be remembered, because the famine that follows will be so severe.
1:41:32/The reason the dream was given to Pharaoh in two forms is that the matter has been firmly decided by God, and God will do it soon.
1:41:33/Now let Pharaoh look for a discerning and wise man and put him in charge of the land of Egypt.
1:41:34/Let Pharaoh take action to appoint overseers over the land and take a fifth of the harvest of Egypt during the seven years of abundance.
1:41:35/They should collect all the food of these good years that are coming and store up the grain under Pharaoh's authority, to be kept in the cities for food.
1:41:36/This food will be a reserve for the country against the seven years of famine that will occur in the land of Egypt, so that the land may not perish through the famine."
1:41:37/This proposal pleased Pharaoh and all his servants.
1:41:38/Pharaoh said to his servants, "Can we find anyone like this man, one in whom is the spirit of God?"
1:41:39/Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, "Since God has made all this known to you, there is no one so discerning and wise as you.
1:41:40/You shall be in charge of my palace, and all my people are to submit to your orders. Only with respect to the throne will I be greater than you."
1:41:41/Pharaoh said to Joseph, "See, I have set you over all the land of Egypt."
1:41:42/Pharaoh took his signet ring from his finger and put it on Joseph’s finger. He dressed him in robes of fine linen and put a gold chain around his neck.
1:41:43/He had him ride in his second chariot, and people shouted before him, "Make way!" Thus he put him in charge of all the land of Egypt.
1:41:44/Pharaoh said to Joseph, "I am Pharaoh, but without your word, no one will lift hand or foot in all Egypt."

1:41:47/During the seven years of abundance, the land produced plentifully.

1:41:49/Joseph stored up huge quantities of grain, like the sand of the sea, until he stopped keeping records because it was beyond measure.

1:44:12/He searched, starting with the oldest and ending with the youngest, and the cup was found in Benjamin's sack.
1:44:13/Then they tore their clothes, loaded their donkeys, and returned to the city.
1:44:14/Judah and his brothers arrived at Joseph's house, where he was still present, and they fell to the ground before him.
1:44:15/Joseph asked them, "What have you done? Don't you realize that a man like me can certainly find things out through divination?"
1:44:16/Judah replied, "What can we say to my lord? How can we explain ourselves? How can we prove our innocence? God has uncovered your servants' guilt. Here we are, my lord's slaves—both we and the one who was found with the cup."
1:44:17/But he said, "Far be it from me to do such a thing! Only the man who was found with the cup will become my slave. The rest of you, go back to your father in peace."
1:44:18/Then Judah approached him and said, "Please, my lord, let your servant speak a word in my lord's ears, and don't be angry with your servant, for you are like Pharaoh himself.
1:44:19/My lord asked his servants, 'Do you have a father or a brother?'
1:44:20/And we answered my lord, 'We have an elderly father, and a young brother, the child of his old age. His brother is dead, and he is the only one left of his mother's children, and his father loves him.'
1:44:21/Then you told your servants, 'Bring him down to me so I can see him for myself.'
1:44:22/We said to my lord, 'The boy cannot leave his father; if he leaves him, his father will die.'
1:44:23/But you told your servants, 'Unless your youngest brother comes down with you, you will not see my face again.'
1:44:24/When we went back to your servant, my father, we told him what my lord had said.
1:44:25/Our father told us, 'Go back and buy a little more food.'
1:44:26/But we said, 'We cannot go down. If our youngest brother is with us, then we will go down, for we cannot see the man's face unless our youngest brother is with us.'
1:44:27/Your servant, my father, said to us, 'You know that my wife bore me two sons.
1:44:28/One of them went away from me, and I said, "He must have been torn to pieces," and I haven't seen him since.
1:44:29/If you take this one from me too and harm comes to him, you will bring my gray hair down to the grave in sorrow.'
1:44:30/Now, if I go back to your servant, my father, and the boy is not with us—since his life is closely bound up with the boy's life—
1:44:31/it will happen that when he sees the boy is not with us, he will die. Your servants will bring the gray hair of your servant, our father, down to the grave in sorrow.
1:44:32/For your servant guaranteed the boy's safety to my father, saying, 'If I do not bring him back to you, I will bear the blame before my father for all my life.'
1:44:33/Now, please let your servant stay here as my lord's slave in place of the boy, and let the boy return with his brothers.
1:44:34/For how can I go back to my father if the boy is not with me? I cannot bear to see the distress that would come upon my father."
1:45:1/Then Joseph couldn't hold back in front of everyone who was there; he shouted, "Make everyone leave me." And no one stayed with him while Joseph revealed his identity to his brothers.
1:45:2/And he cried loudly: and the Egyptians and Pharaoh's household heard it.
1:45:3/And Joseph said to his brothers, "I am Joseph; is my father still alive?" But his brothers couldn't respond because they were shocked to see him.
1:45:4/Then Joseph told his brothers, "Please come closer to me." When they did, he said, "I am Joseph, your brother, the one you sold into Egypt."
1:45:5/So now, don't be upset or angry with yourselves for selling me here, because God sent me ahead of you to save lives.
1:45:6/For the past two years, there has been famine in the land, and for the next five years, there will be no plowing or harvesting.
1:45:7/But God sent me ahead of you to ensure you have descendants on the earth, and to save your lives in an extraordinary way.
1:45:8/So, it wasn't you who sent me here, but God. He has made me like a father to Pharaoh, the lord of his entire household, and ruler over all of Egypt.
1:45:9/Quickly go to my father and tell him, 'Your son Joseph says, God has made me lord of all Egypt. Come down to me without delay.'
1:45:10/You will live in the land of Goshen, and you'll be close to me—you, your children, your grandchildren, your flocks, your herds, and everything you own.
1:45:11/And I will provide for you there, because five more years of famine are coming, otherwise you, your household, and all that you have might come to poverty.
1:45:12/And now, you see with your own eyes, and so does my brother Benjamin, that it is really me speaking to you.
1:45:13/Tell my father about all the honor I've received in Egypt and everything you've seen. Hurry and bring my father down here.
1:45:14/Then he embraced his brother Benjamin and cried, and Benjamin cried on his shoulder.
1:45:15/He also kissed all his brothers and wept over them. Afterward, his brothers talked with him.
1:45:16/When the news reached Pharaoh's palace that Joseph's brothers had come, Pharaoh and his officials were pleased.
1:45:17/Pharaoh said to Joseph, "Tell your brothers, 'Do this: Load your animals and return to the land of Canaan;
1:45:18/And bring your father and your families back to me. I will give you the best of the land of Egypt, and you will eat from the richness of the land.'
1:45:19/Now you are ordered to do this: Take carts from Egypt for your children and wives, and bring your father and come.
1:45:20/Don't worry about your belongings, because the best of all Egypt will be yours."
1:45:21/And the children of Israel did so: Joseph gave them carts, as Pharaoh had commanded, and provided them with supplies for their journey.
1:45:22/To each of them he gave new clothing, but to Benjamin, he gave three hundred pieces of silver and five sets of clothes.
1:45:23/And to his father, he sent as follows: ten donkeys loaded with the best things of Egypt, and ten female donkeys loaded with grain, bread, and food for his father on the journey.
1:45:24/So he sent his brothers off, and as they were leaving, he told them, "Don't argue on the way."
1:45:25/And they left Egypt and returned to the land of Canaan to their father Jacob,
1:45:26/And told him, "Joseph is still alive, and he is the ruler over all the land of Egypt." Jacob's heart nearly stopped because he didn't believe them.
1:45:27/But when they recounted all that Joseph had said to them, and when he saw the carts Joseph had sent to transport him, the spirit of their father Jacob was revived.
1:45:28/And Israel said, "Enough; my son Joseph is still alive. I will go and see him before I die."
1:46:1/Israel set out with all he had, reached Beersheba, and offered sacrifices to the God of his father Isaac.
1:46:2/That night, God spoke to Israel in a dream, saying, "Jacob, Jacob." And he replied, "Here I am."
1:46:3/He said, "I am God, the God of your father. Do not be afraid to go down to Egypt, for there I will make you into a great nation.
1:46:4/I will go down to Egypt with you, and I will surely bring you back again. And Joseph will close your eyes when you pass away."
1:46:5/Jacob left Beersheba, and his sons carried him, their little ones, and their wives in the wagons Pharaoh had sent.
1:46:6/They brought their livestock and possessions they had acquired in Canaan and went to Egypt, Jacob and all his descendants with him.
1:46:7/His sons, grandsons, daughters, and granddaughters—all his descendants—he brought with him to Egypt.

1:46:14/Zebulun's sons were Sered, Elon, and Jahleel.

1:46:17/Asher's sons were Imnah, Ishvah, Ishvi, Beriah, and their sister Serah. Beriah's sons were Heber and Malchiel.
1:46:18/These were the sons of Zilpah, whom Laban gave to his daughter Leah. She bore these to Jacob—sixteen people in total.
