1:46:20/In Egypt, Joseph had two sons, Manasseh and Ephraim, born to him by Asenath, daughter of Potiphera, priest of On.
1:46:21/Benjamin's sons were Belah, Becher, Ashbel, Gera, Naaman, Ehi, Rosh, Muppim, Huppim, and Ard.
1:46:22/These were the sons of Rachel who were born to Jacob—fourteen people in total.
1:46:23/Dan's son was Hushim.
1:46:24/Naphtali's sons were Jahzeel, Guni, Jezer, and Shillem.
1:46:25/These were the sons of Bilhah, whom Laban gave to his daughter Rachel. She bore these to Jacob—seven people in total.
1:46:26/All the people who came with Jacob to Egypt, who were his direct descendants, not including his sons' wives, numbered sixty-six.
1:46:27/And Joseph had two sons born in Egypt, making the total number of people in Jacob's family who came to Egypt seventy.
1:46:28/Jacob sent Judah ahead to Joseph to get directions to Goshen, and when they arrived in Goshen,
1:46:29/Joseph prepared his chariot and went to meet his father Israel in Goshen. He presented himself to him, hugged his neck, and wept for a long time.
1:46:30/Israel said to Joseph, "Now I can die in peace, since I have seen your face and know you are still alive."
1:46:31/Joseph told his brothers and his father's household, "I'll go up and inform Pharaoh, telling him, 'My brothers and my father's household, who were in Canaan, have come to me.
1:46:32/The men are shepherds; they've always taken care of livestock. They've brought their flocks, herds, and everything they own.'
1:46:33/When Pharaoh calls for you and asks about your occupation,
1:46:34/you should say, 'Your servants have been livestock keepers from our youth till now, both we and our ancestors.' This way, you can live in the region of Goshen, since all shepherds are looked down upon by the Egyptians."
1:47:1/Then Joseph went to Pharaoh and said, "My father, my brothers, their livestock, and everything they own have come from the land of Canaan. Now, they are in the region of Goshen."
1:47:2/He brought five of his brothers and introduced them to Pharaoh.
1:47:3/Pharaoh asked his brothers, "What do you do for a living?" They answered Pharaoh, "Your servants are shepherds, just like our ancestors."
1:47:4/They also said to Pharaoh, "We've come to live here temporarily because there's no pasture for our flocks in Canaan due to the severe famine. So, please let us stay in Goshen."
1:47:5/Pharaoh told Joseph, "Your father and your brothers have come to you."
1:47:6/"The land of Egypt is at your disposal; settle your father and brothers in the best part of the land. Let them live in Goshen. And if you know any capable men among them, put them in charge of my livestock."
1:47:7/Joseph introduced his father Jacob to Pharaoh, and Jacob gave Pharaoh his blessing.
1:47:8/Pharaoh asked Jacob, "How old are you?"
1:47:9/Jacob told Pharaoh, "I've been on this journey for 130 years. My life has been short and difficult, and I haven't lived as long as my ancestors did during their journeys."
1:47:10/After blessing Pharaoh again, Jacob left his presence.
1:47:11/Joseph settled his father and brothers in Egypt and gave them property in the best part of the land, in the region of Rameses, as Pharaoh had instructed.
1:47:12/Joseph provided for his father, his brothers, and all his father's household with food according to the number of their dependents.
1:47:13/The famine was so severe that there was no food in all the land; both Egypt and Canaan were exhausted by the famine.
1:47:14/Joseph collected all the money found in Egypt and Canaan in exchange for the grain they were buying, and he brought it to Pharaoh's palace.
1:47:15/When the money in Egypt and Canaan ran out, all the Egyptians came to Joseph and said, "Give us food. Why should we die in front of you? The money is gone."
1:47:16/Joseph said, "Bring your livestock, and I will give you food in exchange for your livestock if you're out of money."
1:47:17/So they brought their livestock to Joseph, and he gave them food in exchange for their horses, sheep, cattle, and donkeys. He supplied them with food in exchange for all their livestock that year.
1:47:18/When that year ended, they came to him the next year and said, "We won't hide from you that our money is spent; you have our livestock, and there's nothing left for my lord except our bodies and our land.
1:47:19/Why should we die before your eyes, both we and our land? Buy us and our land in exchange for food, and we with our land will become servants to Pharaoh. Give us seed so we can live and not die, and the land won't become desolate."
1:47:20/So Joseph bought all the land in Egypt for Pharaoh. Every Egyptian sold their field because the famine was too severe for them. Thus, the land became Pharaoh's.
1:47:21/He moved the people to cities from one end of Egypt's borders to the other.
1:47:22/But he did not buy the land of the priests because they received a regular allotment from Pharaoh and had enough food from the allotment Pharaoh gave them. Therefore, they didn't sell their land.
1:47:23/Then Joseph said to the people, "Look, I have bought you and your land today for Pharaoh. Here is seed for you to sow the land.
1:47:24/When the crops come in, give one-fifth to Pharaoh. The other four parts will be yours as seed for the fields and as food for yourselves, your households, and your children."
1:47:25/They said, "You have saved our lives. May we find favor in the eyes of my lord, and we will be Pharaoh's servants."
1:47:26/Joseph established it as a law across the land of Egypt to this day that Pharaoh should have one-fifth, except for the land of the priests, which did not become Pharaoh's.
1:47:27/And Israel lived in the land of Egypt, in the region of Goshen. They acquired property there, became fruitful, and multiplied greatly.
1:47:28/Jacob lived in the land of Egypt for seventeen years, so he lived a total of 147 years.
1:47:29/When the time approached for Israel to die, he called for his son Joseph and said to him, "If I have found favor in your eyes, please place your hand under my thigh and promise to deal kindly and faithfully with me. Do not bury me in Egypt.
1:47:30/But let me lie with my fathers. Carry me out of Egypt and bury me in their burial place." Joseph replied, "I will do as you have said."
1:47:31/He said, "Swear to me." And Joseph swore to him. Then Israel bowed in gratitude at the head of his bed.
1:48:1/After these events, someone informed Joseph, "Look, your father is ill." So he took his two sons, Manasseh and Ephraim, with him.
1:48:2/Someone informed Jacob, saying, "Look, your son Joseph is coming to you." Israel gathered his strength and sat up in bed.
1:48:3/Jacob said to Joseph, "God Almighty appeared to me at Luz in Canaan and blessed me,
1:48:4/And told me, 'I will make you fruitful and increase your numbers. I will turn you into a community of peoples and will give this land to your descendants as a permanent inheritance.'
1:48:5/Now, your two sons, Ephraim and Manasseh, who were born to you in Egypt before I arrived here, will be considered as my own, just like Reuben and Simeon.
1:48:6/Any children you have after them will be yours and will inherit their land under the names of their brothers.
1:48:7/When I was returning from Paddan, Rachel died in Canaan, not far from Ephrath, so I buried her there on the way to Ephrath, which is Bethlehem."
1:48:8/Israel saw Joseph's sons and asked, "Who are these?"
1:48:9/Joseph told his father, "They are my sons, whom God has given me here." He said, "Please bring them to me so I can bless them."
1:48:10/Israel's eyes were weak from age and he couldn't see well. He brought them close, kissed them, and embraced them.
1:48:11/Israel said to Joseph, "I never expected to see your face again, but now God has let me see your children too."
1:48:12/Joseph moved them away from his knees and bowed down with his face to the ground.

1:48:14/Israel extended his right hand and placed it on Ephraim's head, who was the younger, and his left hand on Manasseh's head, crossing his hands intentionally; for Manasseh was the firstborn.
1:48:15/He blessed Joseph and said, "God, whom my fathers Abraham and Isaac walked before, the God who has been my shepherd all my life to this day,
1:48:16/The Angel who has delivered me from all harm, bless these boys. May they carry on my name and the names of my fathers Abraham and Isaac, and may they grow into a multitude on the earth."
1:48:17/When Joseph saw that his father placed his right hand on Ephraim's head, he was displeased; he took his father's hand to move it from Ephraim's head to Manasseh's head.
1:48:18/Joseph said to his father, "Not so, my father, this one is the firstborn; put your right hand on his head."
1:48:19/But his father refused and said, "I know, my son, I know. He too will become a people, and he too will be great. Nevertheless, his younger brother will be greater than he, and his descendants will become a group of nations."
1:48:20/He blessed them that day, saying, "By you, Israel will pronounce blessings, saying, 'May God make you like Ephraim and Manasseh.'" He put Ephraim ahead of Manasseh.
1:48:21/Then Israel said to Joseph, "I am about to die, but God will be with you and take you back to the land of your ancestors."
1:48:22/Furthermore, I have given you one more portion than your brothers, which I took from the Amorites with my sword and bow.
1:49:1/Jacob called his sons together and said, "Come together so I can tell you what will happen to you in the future."
1:49:2/"Gather around, and listen, sons of Jacob; pay attention to Israel, your father."
1:49:3/Reuben, you are my firstborn, my strength, and the first sign of my virility, the most distinguished in dignity and power.
1:49:4/But you are as unstable as water and will not excel because you slept in your father's bed, thus defiling it—he went up to my bed.
1:49:5/Simeon and Levi are brothers; they use violence as their tool.
1:49:6/I want nothing to do with their schemes; don't let me be associated with their gatherings. For in their anger, they killed a man, and on a whim, they crippled oxen.
1:49:7/May their anger be cursed, for it was fierce; and their fury, for it was ruthless. I will scatter them in Jacob and disperse them in Israel.
1:49:8/Judah, your brothers will praise you; you will grasp your enemies by the neck; your father's sons will bow down to you.
1:49:9/Judah is like a young lion: from the kill, my son, you have ascended. He crouches and lies down like a lion, like a mighty lion—who dares to rouse him?
1:49:10/The scepter will not leave Judah, nor the ruler's staff from between his feet, until Shiloh comes; and to him will the obedience of the peoples be.
1:49:11/He ties his foal to the vine, his donkey's colt to the best vine. He washes his garments in wine, his robes in the blood of grapes.
1:49:12/His eyes will be darker than wine, and his teeth whiter than milk.
1:49:13/Zebulun will live by the seashore and become a haven for ships; his border will extend toward Sidon.
1:49:14/Issachar is a strong donkey, lying down between the sheepfolds.
1:49:15/He saw that rest was good and the land was pleasant; so he bent his shoulder to bear the burden and became a laborer.
1:49:16/Dan will judge his people as one of the tribes of Israel.
1:49:17/Dan will be a snake on the road, a viper along the path, that bites the horse's heels so its rider falls backward.
1:49:18/I look forward to your salvation, O LORD.
1:49:19/Gad will be attacked by a band of raiders, but he will attack them at their heels.
1:49:20/Asher's food will be rich; he will provide delicacies fit for a king.
1:49:21/Naphtali is a doe set free that bears beautiful fawns.
1:49:22/Joseph is a fruitful vine, a fruitful vine near a spring, whose branches climb over the wall.
1:49:23/Archers attacked him with hostility; they shot at him and held a grudge.
1:49:24/Yet his bow remained steady, his strong arms stayed limber, because of the hand of the Mighty One of Jacob, because of the Shepherd, the Rock of Israel.
1:49:25/Because of the God of your father who will help you, because of the Almighty who will bless you with blessings from the heavens above, blessings from the deep that lies below, blessings of the breasts and womb.
1:49:26/The blessings of your father surpass the blessings of my ancestors, reaching to the heights of the eternal hills. They will be on the head of Joseph, on the brow of the prince among his brothers.
1:49:27/Benjamin is a ravenous wolf; in the morning he devours the prey, and in the evening he divides the plunder.
1:49:28/These are the twelve tribes of Israel, and this is what their father said to them when he blessed them, giving each the blessing appropriate to him.
1:49:29/Then he instructed them, saying, "I am about to be gathered to my people. Bury me with my fathers in the cave in the field of Ephron the Hittite,
1:49:30/in the cave in the field of Machpelah, near Mamre in Canaan, which Abraham bought along with the field as a burial place from Ephron the Hittite.
1:49:31/There they buried Abraham and Sarah his wife; there they buried Isaac and Rebekah his wife, and there I buried Leah.
1:49:32/The field and the cave in it were bought from the Hittites."
1:49:33/When Jacob had finished giving instructions to his sons, he pulled his feet up into the bed, breathed his last, and was gathered to his people.
1:50:1/Joseph threw himself on his father's face, cried over him, and kissed him.
1:50:2/Joseph ordered his servants, the doctors, to preserve his father's body, and the doctors did so to Israel.
1:50:3/It took forty days to complete the process, as this is the standard time for embalming. The Egyptians grieved for him for seventy days.
1:50:4/After the mourning period ended, Joseph approached Pharaoh's household and said, "If I have found favor with you, please tell Pharaoh that 
1:50:5/my father made me promise, saying, 'When I die, bury me in my own tomb that I have prepared in the land of Canaan.' So please let me go and bury my father, and I will return."
1:50:6/Pharaoh responded, "Go and bury your father, as he made you promise."
1:50:7/So Joseph went to bury his father, accompanied by all of Pharaoh's servants, the senior members of his household, and all the senior figures of Egypt,
1:50:8/along with all of Joseph's family, his brothers, and his father's family. They left only their young children, their flocks, and their herds in Goshen.
1:50:9/A large procession including chariots and horsemen accompanied him, forming a very grand entourage.
1:50:10/When they reached the threshing floor of Atad, which is beyond the Jordan, they held a very large and solemn funeral ceremony for seven days.
1:50:11/Seeing the mourning at the threshing floor of Atad, the local Canaanites remarked, "This is a deep mourning by the Egyptians." Therefore, the place was named Abel Mizraim, which is beyond the Jordan.
1:50:12/His sons did exactly as he had instructed them:
1:50:13/They carried him to the land of Canaan and buried him in the cave in the field of Machpelah, which Abraham had bought along with the field as a burial site from Ephron the Hittite, near Mamre.
1:50:14/After burying his father, Joseph returned to Egypt with his brothers and everyone who had gone with him to the burial.
1:50:15/When Joseph's brothers realized their father was dead, they said, "Joseph might still be holding a grudge against us and could decide to pay us back for all the wrong we did to him."
1:50:16/So they sent a message to Joseph, saying, "Before he died, your father left instructions, saying,
1:50:17/'Please forgive your brothers for their wrongdoing and sin, for they did treat you badly.' Now, we ask you to forgive the sins of the servants of your father's God." Joseph cried when they spoke to him.
1:50:18/Then his brothers also came, fell down before him, and said, "We are your slaves."
1:50:19/But Joseph said to them, "Don't be afraid. Am I in the place of God?
1:50:20/You intended to harm me, but God intended it for good, to accomplish what is now being done, the saving of many lives.
1:50:21/So now, don't be afraid. I will provide for you and your children." And he reassured them, speaking kindly to them.
1:50:22/Joseph stayed in Egypt, along with his father's family, and lived to be a hundred and ten years old.
1:50:23/Joseph saw the third generation of Ephraim's children, and also the children of Machir, the son of Manasseh, were born on Joseph's knees.
1:50:24/And Joseph said to his brothers, "I am about to die, but God will surely take care of you and lead you out of this land to the land he promised on oath to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob."
1:50:25/Then Joseph made the sons of Israel swear an oath, saying, "God will surely take care of you, and you must carry my bones up from this place."
1:50:26/So Joseph died at the age of a hundred and ten. After they embalmed him, he was placed in a coffin in Egypt.
2:1:1/Here are the names of the Israelites who moved to Egypt; each one, along with his family, followed Jacob.
2:1:2/Reuben, Simeon, Levi, and Judah,
2:1:3/Issachar, Zebulun, and Benjamin,
2:1:4/Dan, and Naphtali, Gad, and Asher.
2:1:5/In total, seventy descendants of Jacob moved to Egypt, since Joseph was already there.
2:1:6/And Joseph passed away, along with all his brothers and that entire generation.
2:1:7/The Israelites were very fruitful, increased rapidly, multiplied, and became extremely powerful; the land was filled with them.
2:1:8/A new king came to power in Egypt who did not know about Joseph.
2:1:9/He said to his people, "Look, the Israelite population is larger and stronger than we are.
2:1:10/Let's be smart about this; otherwise, they'll multiply even more, and if war breaks out, they might join our enemies, fight against us, and leave the country."
2:1:11/So they put slave masters over them to oppress them with forced labor. They built Pithom and Raamses as storage cities for Pharaoh.
2:1:12/But the more they were oppressed, the more they multiplied and spread; so the Egyptians came to dread the Israelites.
2:1:13/The Egyptians forced the Israelites to work under harsh conditions.
2:1:14/They made their lives miserable with hard labor, making mortar and bricks, and doing all kinds of work in the fields. Every task they were forced to do was harsh.
2:1:15/The king of Egypt spoke to the Hebrew midwives, one named Shiphrah and the other Puah.
2:1:16/He said, "When you help the Hebrew women during childbirth, look at the sex of the baby. If it's a boy, kill him; if it's a girl, let her live."
2:1:17/But the midwives feared God and did not do what the king of Egypt had told them; they let the boys live.
2:1:18/The king of Egypt summoned the midwives and asked them, "Why have you done this? Why have you let the boys live?"
2:1:19/The midwives answered Pharaoh, "Hebrew women are not like Egyptian women; they are vigorous and give birth before the midwives arrive."
2:1:20/So God was good to the midwives, and the people continued to multiply and became very strong.
2:1:21/And because the midwives feared God, he gave them families of their own.
2:1:22/Then Pharaoh gave this order to all his people: "Every Hebrew boy that is born you must throw into the Nile, but let every girl live."
2:2:1/A man from the Levi family married a Levi woman.
2:2:2/The woman became pregnant and gave birth to a son. Seeing that he was a beautiful child, she hid him for three months.
2:2:3/When she could no longer hide him, she made a basket from papyrus, sealed it with tar and pitch, placed the child inside, and set it among the reeds along the riverbank.
2:2:4/His sister stood at a distance to see what would happen to him.
2:2:5/Pharaoh's daughter went down to bathe in the river, while her attendants walked along the riverbank. Spotting the basket among the reeds, she sent her servant to get it.
2:2:6/Upon opening it, she saw the baby crying and felt sorry for him, realizing, "This is one of the Hebrew babies."
2:2:7/Then his sister asked Pharaoh's daughter, "Should I go and find a Hebrew woman to nurse the baby for you?"
2:2:8/Pharaoh's daughter told her, "Go." So the girl went and called the baby's mother.
2:2:9/Pharaoh's daughter instructed her, "Take this baby and nurse him for me, and I'll pay you." So the woman took the baby and nursed him.
2:2:10/When the child grew older, she brought him to Pharaoh's daughter, and he became her son. She named him Moses, saying, "I drew him out of the water."
2:2:11/As Moses grew up, he went out to his people and observed their hard labor. He saw an Egyptian beating a Hebrew, one of his own people.
2:2:12/Looking around and seeing no one, he killed the Egyptian and hid him in the sand.
2:2:13/The next day, he saw two Hebrews fighting and asked the aggressor, "Why are you hitting your fellow Hebrew?"
2:2:14/The man retorted, "Who appointed you ruler and judge over us? Do you plan to kill me as you killed the Egyptian?" Moses was afraid, thinking, "What I did must have become known."
2:2:15/When Pharaoh heard about this, he tried to kill Moses. But Moses fled from Pharaoh and settled in the land of Midian, where he sat down by a well.
2:2:16/The priest of Midian had seven daughters who came to draw water and fill the troughs to water their father's flock.
2:2:17/Some shepherds came and drove them away, but Moses got up, helped the women, and watered their flock.
2:2:18/When they returned to Reuel, their father, he asked, "How did you come back so quickly today?"
2:2:19/They answered, "An Egyptian rescued us from the shepherds, even drawing enough water for us and watering the flock."
2:2:20/He asked his daughters, "Where is he? Why did you leave the man? Invite him to have something to eat."
2:2:21/Moses agreed to stay with the man, who gave his daughter Zipporah to Moses in marriage.
2:2:22/She gave birth to a son, and Moses named him Gershom, saying, "I have become a foreigner in a foreign land."
2:2:23/Over time, the king of Egypt died. The Israelites groaned under their slavery and cried out, and their cry for help because of their slavery went up to God.
2:2:24/God heard their moaning and remembered his covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
2:2:25/God looked on the Israelites and was concerned about them.
2:3:1/Moses was taking care of the flock of Jethro, his father-in-law, the priest of Midian. He led the flock to the far side of the desert and came to Horeb, the mountain of God.
2:3:2/An angel of the LORD appeared to him in a flame of fire from within a bush. He saw that the bush was on fire, but it didn't burn up.
2:3:3/Moses thought, "I'll go over and see this amazing sight—why the bush doesn't burn up."
2:3:4/When the LORD saw that he had gone over to look, God called to him from within the bush, "Moses, Moses!" And Moses replied, "Here I am."
2:3:5/Then God said, "Don't come any closer. Take off your sandals, for the place where you are standing is holy ground."
2:3:6/He continued, "I am the God of your father, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob." Moses hid his face, afraid to look at God.
2:3:7/Then the LORD said, "I have definitely seen the suffering of my people in Egypt. I've heard their cries against their slave drivers. I am aware of their pain.
2:3:8/So I have come down to rescue them from the Egyptians and to bring them up out of that land into a good and spacious land, a land flowing with milk and honey—the home of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites.
2:3:9/Now, the cry of the Israelites has reached me, and I have seen how the Egyptians are oppressing them.
2:3:10/So now, go. I am sending you to Pharaoh to bring my people, the Israelites, out of Egypt."
2:3:11/But Moses said to God, "Who am I that I should go to Pharaoh and bring the Israelites out of Egypt?"
2:3:12/And God said, "I will be with you. And this will be the sign to you that it is I who have sent you: When you have brought the people out of Egypt, you will worship God on this mountain."
2:3:13/Moses said to God, "Suppose I go to the Israelites and say to them, 'The God of your fathers has sent me to you,' and they ask me, 'What is his name?' Then what shall I tell them?"
2:3:14/God said to Moses, "I AM WHO I AM. This is what you are to say to the Israelites: 'I AM has sent me to you.'"
2:3:15/God also said to Moses, "Say to the Israelites, 'The LORD, the God of your fathers—the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob—has sent me to you.' This is my name forever, the name you shall call me from generation to generation.
2:3:16/Go, gather the elders of Israel together and say to them, 'The LORD, the God of your fathers—the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob—appeared to me and said: I have watched over you and have seen what has been done to you in Egypt.
2:3:17/And I have promised to bring you up out of your misery in Egypt into the land of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites—a land flowing with milk and honey.'
2:3:18/They will listen to your voice, and you and the elders of Israel will go to the king of Egypt and say to him, 'The LORD, the God of the Hebrews, has met with us. Let us take a three-day journey into the wilderness to offer sacrifices to the LORD our God.'
2:3:19/But I know that the king of Egypt will not let you go unless compelled by a mighty hand.
2:3:20/So I will stretch out my hand and strike Egypt with all the wonders that I will perform among them. After that, he will let you go.
2:3:21/And I will make the Egyptians favorably disposed toward this people, so that when you leave you will not leave empty-handed.
2:3:22/Every woman is to ask her neighbor and any woman living in her house for articles of silver and gold and for clothing, which you will put on your sons and daughters. And so you will plunder the Egyptians.
2:4:1/Moses responded, "But what if they don't believe me or listen to me? They might say, 'The LORD hasn't appeared to you.'"
2:4:2/And the LORD asked him, "What's that in your hand?" He replied, "A staff."
2:4:3/He said, "Throw it on the ground." So he threw it on the ground, and it turned into a snake; and Moses ran from it.
2:4:4/Then the LORD told Moses, "Reach out your hand and grab it by the tail." So he reached out his hand, caught it, and it turned back into a staff in his hand.
2:4:5/This is so they will believe that the LORD, the God of their ancestors, the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, has appeared to you.
2:4:6/Then the LORD said to him, "Put your hand inside your cloak." He put his hand into his cloak, and when he took it out, his hand was leprous, white as snow.
2:4:7/He said, "Put your hand back into your cloak." So he put his hand back into his cloak, and when he took it out, it was restored, just like the rest of his flesh.
2:4:8/If they don't believe you or pay attention to the first sign, they might believe the second sign.
2:4:9/But if they don't believe these two signs or listen to you, take some water from the Nile and pour it on the dry ground. The water you take from the river will turn into blood on the ground.
2:4:10/Moses said to the LORD, "Please, Lord, I've never been eloquent, neither in the past nor since you've spoken to your servant. I'm slow of speech and tongue."
2:4:11/And the LORD said to him, "Who gave humans their mouths? Who makes them deaf or mute? Who gives them sight or makes them blind? Is it not I, the LORD?
2:4:12/Now go, and I will help you speak and will teach you what to say."
2:4:13/But Moses said, "Please, Lord, send someone else."
2:4:14/Then the LORD's anger burned against Moses, and he said, "Isn't Aaron, the Levite, your brother? I know he can speak well. Look, he is on his way to meet you, and he will be happy to see you.
2:4:15/You shall speak to him and put the words in his mouth; I will help both of you speak and will teach you what to do.
2:4:16/He will speak to the people for you, and it will be as if he were your mouth and as if you were God to him.
2:4:17/And take this staff in your hand, with which you'll perform the signs."
2:4:18/Moses went back to Jethro his father-in-law and said to him, "Please let me go back to my brothers in Egypt to see if they are still alive." And Jethro said to Moses, "Go in peace."
2:4:19/And the LORD said to Moses in Midian, "Go back to Egypt, for all the men who wanted to kill you are dead."
2:4:20/So Moses took his wife and sons, put them on a donkey, and started back to Egypt. Moses also took the staff of God in his hand.
2:4:21/And the LORD said to Moses, "When you return to Egypt, see that you perform before Pharaoh all the wonders I have given you the power to do. But I will harden his heart so he will not let the people go.
2:4:22/Then you shall say to Pharaoh, 'This is what the LORD says: Israel is my firstborn son,
2:4:23/and I told you, "Let my son go, so he may worship me." But you refused to let him go; so I will kill your firstborn son.'"
2:4:24/On the journey, at a lodging place, the LORD met Moses and was about to kill him.
2:4:25/But Zipporah took a flint knife, cut off her son's foreskin, and touched Moses' feet with it, saying, "Surely you are a bridegroom of blood to me!"
2:4:26/So the LORD let him alone. At that time she said, "A bridegroom of blood," referring to the circumcision.
2:4:27/And the LORD said to Aaron, "Go into the wilderness to meet Moses." So he went and met him at the mountain of God and kissed him.
2:4:28/Moses told Aaron all the words of the LORD who had sent him, and all the signs he had commanded him to perform.
2:4:29/Moses and Aaron gathered all the elders of the Israelites,
2:4:30/and Aaron told them everything the LORD had said to Moses. He also performed the signs before the people,
2:4:31/and the people believed. When they heard that the LORD had visited the Israelites and seen their misery, they bowed down and worshiped.
2:5:1/Then Moses and Aaron went in and told Pharaoh, "This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: 'Let my people go, so they can celebrate a festival to me in the wilderness.'"
2:5:2/Pharaoh responded, "Who is the LORD that I should listen to His command to let Israel go? I do not recognize the LORD, and I will not let Israel go."
2:5:3/They replied, "The God of the Hebrews has met with us. Please, let us take a three-day journey into the desert to offer sacrifices to the LORD our God, to avoid being struck with plagues or the sword."
2:5:4/But the king of Egypt said to them, "Moses and Aaron, why are you distracting the people from their work? Get back to your labor."
2:5:5/Pharaoh also said, "Look, the people of the land are now numerous, and you want them to stop their work."
2:5:6/That same day, Pharaoh gave this order to the slave drivers and overseers in charge of the people:
2:5:7/"Do not supply any more straw for the people to make bricks as before. Let them go and gather their own straw.
2:5:8/But require them to make the same number of bricks as before; don't reduce the quota. They are lazy; that's why they are crying out, 'Let us go and sacrifice to our God.'
2:5:9/Make the work harder for the men so that they keep working and pay no attention to lies."
2:5:10/So the slave drivers and overseers went out and said to the people, "This is what Pharaoh says: 'I will not provide you with straw.
2:5:11/Go and get your own straw wherever you can find it, but your work will not be reduced at all.'"
2:5:12/So the people scattered all over Egypt to gather stubble to use for straw.
2:5:13/The slave drivers kept pressing them, saying, "Complete the work required of you for each day, just as when you had straw."
2:5:14/And the Israelite overseers, whom Pharaoh's slave drivers had set over them, were beaten and asked, "Why haven't you met your quota of bricks yesterday or today, as before?"
2:5:15/Then the Israelite overseers went and appealed to Pharaoh, "Why are you treating your servants this way?
2:5:16/No straw is given to your servants, yet they tell us, 'Make bricks!' See, your servants are being beaten, but the fault is with your own people."
2:5:17/But he said, "You are lazy, lazy! That's why you say, 'Let us go and sacrifice to the LORD.'
2:5:18/Now get to work. You will not be given any straw, yet you must produce your full quota of bricks."
2:5:19/The Israelite overseers realized they were in a bad situation when they were told, "You must not reduce the number of bricks required of you for each day."
2:5:20/When they left Pharaoh, they found Moses and Aaron waiting to meet them,
2:5:21/and they said to them, "May the LORD look on you and judge! You have made us obnoxious to Pharaoh and his officials and have put a sword in their hand to kill us."
2:5:22/Moses went back to the LORD and asked, "LORD, why have you brought trouble on this people? Why did you send me?
2:5:23/Ever since I went to Pharaoh to speak in your name, he has brought trouble on this people, and you have not rescued your people at all."
2:6:1/Then the LORD said to Moses, "Now you will see what I will do to Pharaoh: for with a strong hand he will let them go, and with a strong hand he will drive them out of his land."
2:6:2/And God spoke to Moses, saying, "I am the LORD."
2:6:3/And I revealed myself to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob as God Almighty, but by my name JEHOVAH, I was not known to them.
2:6:4/And I have also established my covenant with them, to give them the land of Canaan, the land where they were foreigners.
2:6:5/And I have also heard the groaning of the children of Israel, whom the Egyptians keep in slavery; and I have remembered my covenant.
2:6:6/Therefore, tell the children of Israel, 'I am the LORD, and I will bring you out from under the burdens of the Egyptians, and I will free you from their slavery, and I will redeem you with an outstretched arm and with great judgments.'
2:6:7/And I will take you as my people, and I will be your God: and you shall know that I am the LORD your God, who brings you out from under the burdens of the Egyptians.
2:6:8/And I will bring you into the land, which I swore to give to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob; and I will give it to you as a heritage: I am the LORD."
2:6:9/And Moses relayed this to the children of Israel: but they did not listen to Moses because of their broken spirit and harsh slavery.
2:6:10/And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
2:6:11/Go in, speak to Pharaoh king of Egypt, that he let the children of Israel go out of his land.
2:6:12/And Moses spoke before the LORD, saying, "Look, the children of Israel have not listened to me; how then will Pharaoh listen to me, when I am not eloquent?"
2:6:13/And the LORD spoke to Moses and to Aaron, and gave them a command for the children of Israel and for Pharaoh king of Egypt, to bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt.
2:6:14/These are the heads of their fathers' houses: The sons of Reuben the firstborn of Israel; Hanoch, and Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi: these are the families of Reuben.
2:6:15/And the sons of Simeon; Jemuel, and Jamin, and Ohad, and Jachin, and Zohar, and Shaul the son of a Canaanite woman: these are the families of Simeon.
2:6:16/And these are the names of the sons of Levi according to their generations; Gershon, and Kohath, and Merari: and the lifespan of Levi was one hundred thirty-seven years.
2:6:17/The sons of Gershon; Libni, and Shimi, according to their families.
2:6:18/And the sons of Kohath; Amram, and Izhar, and Hebron, and Uzziel: and the lifespan of Kohath was one hundred thirty-three years.
2:6:19/And the sons of Merari; Mahali and Mushi: these are the families of Levi according to their generations.
2:6:20/And Amram married Jochebed, his father's sister, and she bore him Aaron and Moses: and the lifespan of Amram was one hundred and thirty-seven years.
2:6:21/And the sons of Izhar; Korah, and Nepheg, and Zichri.
2:6:22/And the sons of Uzziel; Mishael, and Elzaphan, and Zithri.
2:6:23/And Aaron married Elisheba, daughter of Amminadab, sister of Naashon, and she bore him Nadab, and Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
2:6:24/And the sons of Korah; Assir, and Elkanah, and Abiasaph: these are the families of the Korhites.
2:6:25/And Eleazar, Aaron's son, married one of the daughters of Putiel, and she bore him Phinehas: these are the heads of the fathers of the Levites according to their families.
2:6:26/These are that Aaron and Moses, to whom the LORD said, "Bring out the children of Israel from the land of Egypt according to their armies."
2:6:27/These are they who spoke to Pharaoh king of Egypt, to bring out the children of Israel from Egypt: these are that Moses and Aaron.
2:6:28/And it happened on the day when the LORD spoke to Moses in the land of Egypt,
2:6:29/That the LORD spoke to Moses, saying, "I am the LORD: speak to Pharaoh king of Egypt all that I say to you."
2:6:30/And Moses said before the LORD, "Look, I am not eloquent, how will Pharaoh listen to me?"
2:7:1/The LORD said to Moses, "Look, I have made you like a god to Pharaoh, and your brother Aaron will be your prophet.
2:7:2/You must say everything I command you, and your brother Aaron will tell Pharaoh to let the Israelites leave his land.
2:7:3/I will make Pharaoh's heart stubborn and will perform many miracles and wonders in Egypt.
2:7:4/But Pharaoh will not listen to you, so I can demonstrate my power in Egypt and lead my people, the Israelites, out of Egypt through mighty acts of judgment.
2:7:5/And the Egyptians will realize that I am the LORD when I show my power in Egypt and free the Israelites from among them.
2:7:6/Moses and Aaron did exactly as the LORD commanded them.
2:7:7/Moses was eighty years old and Aaron eighty-three when they spoke to Pharaoh.
2:7:8/The LORD spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying,
2:7:9/When Pharaoh demands a miracle, tell Aaron to throw his staff down in front of Pharaoh, and it will become a snake.
2:7:10/Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and did as the LORD had instructed; Aaron threw his staff down in front of Pharaoh and his officials, and it became a snake.
2:7:11/Then Pharaoh called for his wise men and sorcerers, and the Egyptian magicians also did the same with their magic.
2:7:12/They each threw down their staffs, which also became snakes, but Aaron's staff swallowed up their staffs.
2:7:13/Yet Pharaoh's heart was hardened, and he did not listen to them, just as the LORD had said.
2:7:14/The LORD said to Moses, "Pharaoh's heart is unyielding; he refuses to let the people go.
2:7:15/Go to Pharaoh in the morning as he goes out to the water, wait by the riverbank to meet him, and take the staff that turned into a snake in your hand.
2:7:16/Tell him, 'The LORD, the God of the Hebrews, has sent me to say to you: Let my people go, so they may worship me in the wilderness. But until now, you have not listened.
2:7:17/This is what the LORD says: By this you will know that I am the LORD. I will strike the water of the river with the staff in my hand, and it will turn to blood.
2:7:18/The fish in the river will die, the river will stink, and the Egyptians will be unable to drink its water.
2:7:19/The LORD said to Moses, "Tell Aaron to take his staff and stretch out his hand over the waters of Egypt—over their rivers, their canals, their ponds, and all their pools of water—so they may turn to blood. There will be blood throughout the whole land of Egypt, even in containers of wood and stone."
2:7:20/Moses and Aaron did as the LORD commanded; Aaron raised the staff and struck the water of the river in the presence of Pharaoh and his officials, and all the water in the river turned to blood.
2:7:21/The fish in the river died, the river smelled bad, and the Egyptians couldn't drink its water. There was blood throughout the land of Egypt.
2:7:22/But the Egyptian magicians did the same with their magic, and Pharaoh's heart remained hardened. He did not listen to them, as the LORD had said.
2:7:23/Pharaoh turned and went back to his palace, not taking even this to heart.
2:7:24/And all the Egyptians dug around the river for water to drink because they couldn't drink the water from the river.
2:7:25/Seven days passed after the LORD struck the river.
2:8:1/And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying, "Go to Pharaoh and tell him, 'This is what the LORD says: Let my people go, so they can worship me.'"
2:8:2/But if you refuse to release them, watch out, because I will fill your entire territory with frogs.
2:8:3/The river will swarm with frogs. They will enter your house, your bedroom, onto your bed, into the homes of your servants and your people, into your ovens, and your dough bowls.
2:8:4/The frogs will be all over you, your people, and all your servants.
2:8:5/Then the LORD said to Moses, "Tell Aaron to stretch out his hand with his staff over the rivers, canals, and ponds, and bring up frogs over the land of Egypt."
2:8:6/So Aaron stretched out his hand over the waters of Egypt, and the frogs came up and covered the land of Egypt.
2:8:7/But the magicians used their magic to do the same thing and brought frogs over the land of Egypt.
2:8:8/Then Pharaoh urgently called for Moses and Aaron and said, "Pray to the LORD to take the frogs away from me and my people, and I will let the people go to offer sacrifices to the LORD."
2:8:9/Moses said to Pharaoh, "You have the honor of telling me when I should pray for you, your officials, and your people, to get rid of the frogs from your houses and leave them only in the river."
2:8:10/Pharaoh said, "Tomorrow." Moses replied, "It will be as you say, so you may know that there is no one like the LORD our God.
2:8:11/The frogs will leave you, your houses, your officials, and your people; they will remain only in the river."
2:8:12/Then Moses and Aaron left Pharaoh, and Moses cried out to the LORD about the frogs He had brought on Pharaoh.
2:8:13/And the LORD did what Moses asked; the frogs died in the houses, courtyards, and fields.
2:8:14/They were piled into heaps, and the land reeked of them.
2:8:15/But when Pharaoh saw that there was relief, he hardened his heart and did not listen to them, just as the LORD had predicted.
2:8:16/Then the LORD told Moses, "Tell Aaron to stretch out his staff and strike the dust of the ground, and throughout Egypt the dust will become lice."
2:8:17/They did so. Aaron stretched out his hand with his staff, struck the dust of the earth, and it turned into lice on people and animals. All the dust throughout the land of Egypt became lice.
2:8:18/But when the magicians tried to produce lice by their secret arts, they could not. So there were lice on people and animals.
2:8:19/Then the magicians said to Pharaoh, "This is the finger of God." But Pharaoh's heart was stubborn, and he did not listen to them, just as the LORD had said.
2:8:20/And the LORD said to Moses, "Get up early in the morning, confront Pharaoh as he goes to the water and say to him, 'This is what the LORD says: Let my people go, so they can worship me.'"
2:8:21/Otherwise, if you do not let my people go, I will send swarms of flies on you, your officials, your people, and into your houses. The houses of the Egyptians will be full of flies, and even the ground will be covered with them.
2:8:22/But on that day, I will set apart the land of Goshen, where my people live, so no swarms of flies will be there. This way you will know that I, the LORD, am in this land.
2:8:23/I will make a distinction between my people and your people. This miraculous sign will happen tomorrow.'"
2:8:24/And the LORD did so. Dense swarms of flies poured into Pharaoh's palace and into the houses of his officials. Throughout Egypt, the land was ruined by the swarms of flies.
2:8:25/Then Pharaoh summoned Moses and Aaron and said, "Go, offer sacrifices to your God here in the land."
2:8:26/But Moses said, "It wouldn't be right to do that, for we would be offering the Egyptians' detestable things to the LORD our God. If we do, won't the Egyptians stone us?"
2:8:27/"We must take a three-day journey into the wilderness to offer sacrifices to the LORD our God, as he commands us."
2:8:28/Pharaoh said, "I will let you go to offer sacrifices to the LORD your God in the wilderness, but don't go too far. Pray for me."
2:8:29/Moses said, "As soon as I leave you, I will pray to the LORD, and tomorrow the swarms of flies will leave Pharaoh, his officials, and his people. But let Pharaoh not act deceitfully again by not letting the people go to offer sacrifices to the LORD."
2:8:30/Then Moses left Pharaoh and prayed to the LORD.
2:8:31/And the LORD did as Moses asked; He removed the swarms of flies from Pharaoh, his officials, and his people. Not one fly remained.
2:8:32/But this time also Pharaoh hardened his heart and did not let the people go.
2:9:1/Then the LORD said to Moses, "Go to Pharaoh and tell him, 'This is what the LORD, the God of the Hebrews, says: Let my people go so they can worship me.'
2:9:2/If you refuse to let them go and continue to hold them,
2:9:3/Be aware that the LORD's hand will strike your livestock in the fields—the horses, donkeys, camels, cattle, and sheep—with a devastating plague.
2:9:4/But the LORD will make a distinction between the livestock of Israel and that of Egypt, so that none of Israel's animals will die."
2:9:5/And the LORD set a specific time, saying, "Tomorrow the LORD will do this in the land."
2:9:6/And the next day, the LORD did as He had said, causing all the livestock of Egypt to die, but not one of the livestock of the Israelites died.
2:9:7/Pharaoh investigated and found that not even one of the livestock of the Israelites had died. Yet Pharaoh's heart remained unyielding, and he did not let the people go.
2:9:8/Then the LORD told Moses and Aaron, "Take handfuls of soot from a furnace, and have Moses toss it into the air in front of Pharaoh.
2:9:9/It will become fine dust over the whole land of Egypt and cause festering boils to break out on people and animals throughout the land."
2:9:10/So they took soot from a furnace and stood before Pharaoh; Moses tossed it into the air, and it caused festering boils to break out on people and animals.
2:9:11/The magicians could not stand before Moses because of the boils, for the boils affected the magicians and all the Egyptians.
2:9:12/But the LORD hardened Pharaoh's heart, and he did not listen to them, just as the LORD had told Moses.
2:9:13/Then the LORD said to Moses, "Get up early in the morning, confront Pharaoh, and say to him, 'This is what the LORD, the God of the Hebrews, says: Let my people go, so they can worship me.
2:9:14/For this time I will send all my plagues to your very heart, and on your officials and your people, so you may know that there is no one like me in all the earth.
2:9:15/By now I could have stretched out my hand and struck you and your people with a plague that would have wiped you off the earth.
2:9:16/But I have raised you up for this very purpose, to show you my power and to have my name proclaimed in all the earth.
2:9:17/Are you still exalting yourself against my people by not letting them go?
2:9:18/Tomorrow at this time I will send a very heavy hail, such as has not been seen in Egypt from the day it was founded till now.
2:9:19/Therefore, send now and gather your livestock and everything you have in the field. For upon every person and animal found in the field and not brought home, the hail will fall, and they will die.'"
2:9:20/Those among Pharaoh's officials who feared the word of the LORD hurried to bring their servants and livestock inside to safety.
2:9:21/But those who did not take the word of the LORD seriously left their servants and livestock in the field.
2:9:22/Then the LORD said to Moses, "Stretch out your hand toward the sky so that hail will fall all over Egypt—on people, animals, and all the plants of the field throughout the land of Egypt."
2:9:23/Moses stretched out his staff toward the sky, and the LORD sent thunder and hail, and lightning flashed down to the ground. So the LORD rained hail on the land of Egypt.
2:9:24/There was hail, and lightning flashing within the hail, very severe, such as had never been in all the land of Egypt since it became a nation.
2:9:25/The hail struck everything in the fields, both people and animals; it beat down everything growing in the fields and shattered every tree.
2:9:26/Only in the land of Goshen, where the Israelites were, was there no hail.
2:9:27/Pharaoh sent for Moses and Aaron and said to them, "This time I have sinned; the LORD is in the right, and I and my people are in the wrong.
2:9:28/Plead with the LORD, for we have had enough thunder and hail. I will let you go; you don't have to stay any longer."
2:9:29/Moses replied, "As soon as I leave the city, I will spread out my hands in prayer to the LORD. The thunder will stop, and there will be no more hail, so you may know that the earth belongs to the LORD.
2:9:30/But I know that you and your officials still do not fear the LORD God."
2:9:31/The flax and barley were destroyed, because the barley had headed and the flax was in bloom.
2:9:32/But the wheat and spelt were not destroyed, for they ripen later.
2:9:33/Moses left Pharaoh and the city, spread out his hands to the LORD; the thunder and hail stopped, and the rain no longer poured down on the land.
2:9:34/When Pharaoh saw that the rain, hail, and thunder had ceased, he sinned again: he and his officials hardened their hearts.
2:9:35/Pharaoh's heart was unyielding, and he did not let the Israelites go, just as the LORD had said through Moses.
2:10:1/And the LORD said to Moses, "Go to Pharaoh, for I have made his heart and the hearts of his officials stubborn so I can display my signs to them.
2:10:2/So you can tell your children and grandchildren about what I have done in Egypt and the signs I performed among them; and you will know that I am the LORD."
2:10:3/Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and said, "This is what the LORD, the God of the Hebrews, says: 'How long will you refuse to humble yourself before me? Let my people go, so they can worship me.
2:10:4/If you refuse to let my people go, tomorrow I will bring locusts into your territory.
2:10:5/They will cover the surface of the ground so that it cannot be seen. They will eat what little you have left after the hail, including every tree that is growing in your fields.
2:10:6/They will fill your houses and those of all your officials and all the Egyptians—something neither your parents nor your ancestors have ever seen from the day they settled in this land till now.'" Then Moses turned and left Pharaoh.
2:10:7/Pharaoh's officials said to him, "How long will this man be a trap for us? Let the people go, so they can worship the LORD their God. Don't you realize yet that Egypt is ruined?"
2:10:8/Then Moses and Aaron were brought back to Pharaoh. He said to them, "Go, worship the LORD your God. But exactly who will be going?"
2:10:9/Moses answered, "We will go with our young and our old, with our sons and our daughters, and with our flocks and herds, because we are to celebrate a festival to the LORD."
2:10:10/Pharaoh said, "The LORD be with you—if I let you go, along with your women and children! Clearly, you are bent on evil.
2:10:11/No! Have only the men go and worship the LORD, since that's what you have been asking for." And they were driven out of Pharaoh's presence.
2:10:12/And the LORD said to Moses, "Stretch out your hand over Egypt so that locusts swarm over the land and devour everything growing in the fields, everything left by the hail."
2:10:13/So Moses stretched out his staff over Egypt, and the LORD brought an east wind across the land all that day and all that night. By morning, the east wind had brought the locusts.
2:10:14/The locusts invaded all Egypt and settled down in every area of the country. It was unprecedented; never before had there been such a plague of locusts, nor will there ever be again.
2:10:15/They covered all the ground until it was black. They devoured all that was left after the hail—every plant in the fields and all the fruit on the trees. Nothing green remained on tree or plant in all the land of Egypt.
2:10:16/Pharaoh quickly summoned Moses and Aaron and said, "I have sinned against the LORD your God and against you.
2:10:17/Now forgive my sin once more and pray to the LORD your God to take this deadly plague away from me."
2:10:18/Moses then left Pharaoh and prayed to the LORD.
2:10:19/And the LORD changed the wind to a very strong west wind, which caught up the locusts and carried them into the Red Sea. Not a single locust was left anywhere in Egypt.
2:10:20/But the LORD made Pharaoh's heart stubborn, and he did not let the Israelites go.
2:10:21/Then the LORD said to Moses, "Stretch out your hand toward the sky so that darkness spreads over Egypt—darkness that can be felt."
2:10:22/So Moses stretched out his hand toward the sky, and total darkness covered all Egypt for three days.
2:10:23/No one could see anyone else or move about for three days. Yet all the Israelites had light in the places where they lived.
2:10:24/Then Pharaoh summoned Moses and said, "Go, worship the LORD. Even your women and children may go with you; only leave your flocks and herds behind."
2:10:25/But Moses said, "You must allow us to have sacrifices and burnt offerings to present to the LORD our God.
2:10:26/Our livestock too must go with us; not a hoof is to be left behind. We have to use some of them in worshiping the LORD our God, and until we get there we won't know what we are to use to worship the LORD."
2:10:27/But the LORD hardened Pharaoh's heart, and he was not willing to let them go.
2:10:28/Pharaoh said to Moses, "Get out of my sight! Make sure you do not appear before me again! The day you see my face you will die."
2:10:29/Moses replied, "You have spoken well. I will never see your face again."
2:11:1/And the LORD said to Moses, "I will bring one more plague upon Pharaoh and Egypt; after that, he will let you leave. When he does, he will urgently send you all away.
2:11:2/Tell the people to ask their Egyptian neighbors for silver and gold jewelry.
2:11:3/And the LORD made the Egyptians view the Israelites favorably. Also, Moses was highly respected in Egypt, by Pharaoh's officials and the people.
2:11:4/And Moses declared, "This is what the LORD says: At midnight, I will move through Egypt.
2:11:5/Every firstborn in Egypt will die, from Pharaoh's firstborn, who sits on the throne, to the firstborn of the servant girl at the mill, and even the firstborn of all livestock.
2:11:6/There will be a loud wailing across Egypt, unlike anything before or ever again.
2:11:7/But among the Israelites, not even a dog will bark at any person or animal. This will show you that the LORD makes a distinction between Egypt and Israel.
2:11:8/Then all your officials will come to me, bowing down and saying, 'Leave, you and all the people who follow you!' After that, I will leave." And he left Pharaoh's presence, furious.
2:11:9/And the LORD said to Moses, "Pharaoh will not listen to you, so that my miracles may be multiplied in Egypt."
2:11:10/Moses and Aaron performed all these miracles before Pharaoh, but the LORD made Pharaoh's heart stubborn, so he wouldn't let the Israelites leave his country.
2:12:1/And the LORD spoke to Moses and Aaron in Egypt, saying,
2:12:2/This month is to be the start of months for you; it will be the first month of the year for you.
2:12:3/Tell the whole community of Israel that on the tenth day of this month each man must get a lamb for his family, one lamb per household.
2:12:4/If a household is too small for a whole lamb, they must share one with their nearest neighbor, based on the number of people; you are to determine the amount of lamb needed in proportion to what each person will eat.
2:12:5/Your lamb must be perfect, a year-old male, chosen from the sheep or the goats.
2:12:6/You must care for it until the fourteenth day of the month, when the entire assembly of the community of Israel will slaughter the lambs at twilight.
2:12:7/Then they must take some of the blood and put it on the sides and tops of the doorframes of the houses where they eat the lambs.
2:12:8/That same night they are to eat the meat roasted over the fire, along with unleavened bread and bitter herbs.
2:12:9/Do not eat the meat raw or boiled in water, but roast it over a fire—with the head, legs, and internal organs.
2:12:10/Do not leave any of it till morning; if some is left till morning, you must burn it.
2:12:11/This is how you are to eat it: with your cloak tucked into your belt, your sandals on your feet, and your staff in your hand. Eat it in haste; it is the LORD's Passover.
2:12:12/For I will pass through Egypt tonight and strike down every firstborn of both people and animals, and I will bring judgment on all the gods of Egypt. I am the LORD.
2:12:13/The blood will be a sign for you on the houses where you are; when I see the blood, I will pass over you. No destructive plague will touch you when I strike Egypt.
2:12:14/This day will be a memorial for you, and you must celebrate it as a festival to the LORD; throughout your generations you are to celebrate it as a permanent ordinance.
2:12:15/For seven days you must eat unleavened bread. On the first day, remove the yeast from your houses. Anyone who eats anything with yeast in it from the first day through the seventh day must be cut off from Israel.
2:12:16/On the first day hold a sacred assembly, and another one on the seventh day. Do no work at all on these days, except to prepare food for everyone to eat; that is all you may do.
2:12:17/Celebrate the Festival of Unleavened Bread, because it was on this very day that I brought your divisions out of Egypt. Celebrate this day as a lasting ordinance for the generations to come.
2:12:18/In the first month, from the evening of the fourteenth day until the evening of the twenty-first day, you must eat unleavened bread.
2:12:19/For seven days no yeast is to be found in your houses. And anyone, whether foreigner or native-born, who eats anything with yeast in it must be cut off from the community of Israel.
2:12:20/Do not eat anything with yeast; wherever you live, you must eat unleavened bread.
2:12:21/Then Moses summoned all the elders of Israel and said to them, "Go at once and select the animals for your families and slaughter the Passover lamb.
2:12:22/Take a bunch of hyssop, dip it into the blood in the basin and put some of the blood on the top and on both sides of the doorframe. None of you shall go out of the door of your house until morning.
2:12:23/For the LORD will pass through to strike the Egyptians; when he sees the blood on the top and sides of the doorframe, the LORD will pass over that doorway, and he will not permit the destroyer to enter your houses and strike you down.
2:12:24/Keep this ceremony as a permanent ordinance for you and your descendants.
2:12:25/When you enter the land the LORD will give you as he promised, observe this ceremony.
2:12:26/And when your children ask you, 'What does this ceremony mean to you?'
2:12:27/then tell them, 'It is the Passover sacrifice to the LORD, who passed over the houses of the Israelites in Egypt and spared our homes when he struck down the Egyptians.'" Then the people bowed down and worshiped.
2:12:28/The Israelites went and did just as the LORD had commanded Moses and Aaron.
2:12:29/At midnight the LORD struck down all the firstborn in Egypt, from the firstborn of Pharaoh, who sat on the throne, to the firstborn of the prisoner who was in the dungeon, and the firstborn of all the livestock as well.
2:12:30/Pharaoh and all his officials and all the Egyptians got up during the night, and there was loud wailing in Egypt, for there was not a house without someone dead.
2:12:31/He summoned Moses and Aaron during the night and said, "Get up and leave my people, you and the Israelites! Go, worship the LORD as you have requested.
2:12:32/Take your flocks and herds, as you have said, and go. And also bless me."
2:12:33/The Egyptians urged the people to hurry and leave the country. "For otherwise," they said, "we will all die!"
2:12:34/So the people took their dough before the yeast was added, and carried it on their shoulders in kneading troughs wrapped in clothing.
2:12:35/The Israelites did as Moses instructed and asked the Egyptians for articles of silver and gold and for clothing.
2:12:36/The LORD made the Egyptians favorably disposed toward the people, and they gave them what they asked for; so they plundered the Egyptians.
2:12:37/The Israelites journeyed from Rameses to Succoth. There were about six hundred thousand men on foot, besides women and children.
2:12:38/A mixed multitude also went up with them, along with large droves of livestock, both flocks and herds.
2:12:39/They baked unleavened cakes from the dough they had brought out of Egypt. It was not leavened because they had been driven out of Egypt and did not have time to prepare food for themselves.
2:12:40/The time that the Israelites lived in Egypt was four hundred and thirty years.
2:12:41/At the end of the four hundred and thirty years, to the very day, all the LORD's divisions left Egypt.
2:12:42/This is a night of vigil to honor the LORD for bringing them out of the land of Egypt. This is a night to be observed for the LORD by all the Israelites throughout their generations.
2:12:43/And the LORD said to Moses and Aaron, "This is the regulation for the Passover: No foreigner may eat it.
2:12:44/But any slave you have bought may eat it after you have circumcised him.
2:12:45/Neither a foreigner nor a hired worker may eat it.
2:12:46/It must be eaten inside one house; take none of the meat outside the house. Do not break any of the bones.
2:12:47/The whole community of Israel must celebrate it.
2:12:48/If a foreigner residing among you wants to celebrate the LORD's Passover, all his males must be circumcised, and then he may take part like one born in the land. No uncircumcised male may eat it.
2:12:49/The same law applies both to the native-born and to the foreigner residing among you.
2:12:50/All the Israelites did just as the LORD had commanded Moses and Aaron.
2:12:51/On that very day, the LORD brought the Israelites out of Egypt by their divisions.
2:13:1/And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
2:13:2/Dedicate to me every firstborn, the first to come from the womb among the Israelites, both humans and animals; they belong to me.
2:13:3/And Moses told the people, "Remember this day when you left Egypt, the place of slavery, because the LORD led you out of there with a mighty hand; no bread with yeast shall be eaten.
2:13:4/Today, you are leaving in the month of Abib.
2:13:5/When the LORD brings you into the land of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Hivites, and Jebusites, which he promised to your ancestors to give you—a land flowing with milk and honey—you must perform this ceremony in this month.
2:13:6/For seven days you must eat bread made without yeast, and on the seventh day, there will be a celebration in honor of the LORD.
2:13:7/Bread without yeast must be eaten for seven days; no bread with yeast shall be seen with you, nor shall yeast be seen anywhere within your territories.
2:13:8/And you shall explain to your son on that day, 'This is done because of what the LORD did for me when I came out of Egypt.'
2:13:9/It will serve as a sign on your hand and as a reminder between your eyes, so the LORD's law may be in your mouth; for the LORD brought you out of Egypt with a mighty hand.
2:13:10/Therefore, you must keep this decree at its appointed time year after year.
2:13:11/When the LORD brings you into the land of the Canaanites, as he swore to you and your ancestors, and gives it to you,
2:13:12/You must dedicate to the LORD every first offspring of the womb, and every firstborn male of your livestock belongs to the LORD.
2:13:13/Every firstborn donkey you must redeem with a lamb; if you do not redeem it, you must break its neck. And you must redeem every firstborn among your sons.
2:13:14/When in the future your son asks you, 'What does this mean?' you shall answer, 'With a mighty hand the LORD brought us out of Egypt, from the house of slavery.'
2:13:15/And it happened that when Pharaoh stubbornly refused to let us go, the LORD killed every firstborn in the land of Egypt, both human and animal. That is why I sacrifice to the LORD every male that opens the womb, but every firstborn of my sons I redeem.
2:13:16/It will serve as a symbol on your hand and as an emblem on your forehead that with a mighty hand the LORD brought us out of Egypt.
2:13:17/When Pharaoh let the people go, God did not lead them on the road through the land of the Philistines, although that was shorter. For God said, 'Lest the people change their minds when they see war and return to Egypt.'
2:13:18/But God led the people around by the way of the wilderness toward the Red Sea. And the Israelites went up out of the land of Egypt prepared for battle.
2:13:19/And Moses took the bones of Joseph with him, for Joseph had made the sons of Israel solemnly swear, saying, 'God will surely take notice of you, and then you must carry my bones away from here with you.'
2:13:20/They journeyed from Succoth and camped at Etham, on the edge of the wilderness.
2:13:21/And the LORD went ahead of them by day in a pillar of cloud to guide them along the way, and by night in a pillar of fire to give them light, so they could travel by day and night.
2:13:22/The pillar of cloud by day and the pillar of fire by night did not depart from before the people.
2:14:1/And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
2:14:2/Tell the Israelites to turn back and camp in front of Pihahiroth, between Migdol and the sea, opposite Baalzephon. You are to camp by the sea, right in front of it.
2:14:3/Pharaoh will think the Israelites are trapped in the wilderness, surrounded and unable to escape.
2:14:4/I will make Pharaoh's heart stubborn, so he will chase after them. I will be honored through Pharaoh and his entire army, and the Egyptians will know that I am the LORD. And they did exactly that.
2:14:5/Word reached the king of Egypt that the people had escaped. Pharaoh and his officials changed their minds about the people and wondered, "Why did we let Israel go from serving us?"
2:14:6/So he prepared his chariot and took his troops with him.
2:14:7/He took six hundred of his best chariots, along with all the other chariots of Egypt, each with its commander.
2:14:8/And the LORD made Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, stubborn, and he pursued the Israelites, who were leaving triumphantly.
2:14:9/The Egyptians—all Pharaoh's horses and chariots, his horsemen, and his army—chased after the Israelites and caught up with them as they camped by the sea near Pihahiroth, opposite Baalzephon.
2:14:10/As Pharaoh approached, the Israelites looked up, and there were the Egyptians, marching after them. They were terrified and cried out to the LORD.
2:14:11/They said to Moses, "Were there no graves in Egypt, so you brought us to the desert to die? What have you done by bringing us out of Egypt?
2:14:12/Didn't we say in Egypt, 'Leave us alone; let us serve the Egyptians'? It would have been better for us to serve the Egyptians than to die in the desert."
2:14:13/Moses told the people, "Don't be afraid. Stand firm and watch the LORD's salvation that He will show you today. The Egyptians you see today, you will never see again.
2:14:14/The LORD will fight for you; you only need to be still."
2:14:15/Then the LORD said to Moses, "Why are you crying out to me? Tell the Israelites to move forward.
2:14:16/But raise your staff and stretch out your hand over the sea to split it. Then the Israelites will go through the sea on dry ground.
2:14:17/And I will make the Egyptians' hearts stubborn so they will follow them. And I will gain glory through Pharaoh and all his army, through his chariots and his horsemen.
2:14:18/The Egyptians will know that I am the LORD when I am honored through Pharaoh, his chariots, and his horsemen."
2:14:19/The angel of God, who had been leading the camp of Israel, moved and went behind them. The pillar of cloud also moved from in front and stood behind them,
2:14:20/coming between the camps of the Egyptians and Israel. Throughout the night the cloud brought darkness to one side and light to the other, so neither went near the other all night long.
2:14:21/Moses stretched out his hand over the sea, and the LORD drove the sea back with a strong east wind all night, turning the sea into dry land. The waters were divided.
2:14:22/So the Israelites went through the sea on dry ground, with walls of water on their right and on their left.
2:14:23/The Egyptians pursued them, and all Pharaoh's horses, chariots, and horsemen followed them into the sea.
2:14:24/In the morning watch, the LORD looked down on the Egyptian army through the pillar of fire and cloud and threw the Egyptian army into confusion.
2:14:25/He jammed the wheels of their chariots so that they had difficulty driving. And the Egyptians said, "Let's get away from the Israelites! The LORD is fighting for them against Egypt."
2:14:26/Then the LORD said to Moses, "Stretch out your hand over the sea so that the waters may flow back over the Egyptians, their chariots, and their horsemen."
2:14:27/Moses stretched out his hand over the sea, and at daybreak the sea returned to its normal depth. The Egyptians were fleeing toward it, and the LORD swept them into the sea.
2:14:28/The returning waters covered the chariots and horsemen—the entire army of Pharaoh that had followed the Israelites into the sea. Not one of them survived.
2:14:29/But the Israelites walked on dry ground in the middle of the sea, with walls of water on their right and on their left.
2:14:30/So the LORD saved Israel that day from the hands of the Egyptians, and Israel saw the Egyptians dead on the seashore.
2:14:31/And when the Israelites saw the mighty hand of the LORD displayed against the Egyptians, the people feared the LORD and put their trust in Him and in Moses His servant.
2:15:1/Then Moses and the Israelites sang this song to the LORD, saying, "I will sing to the LORD, for he has triumphed magnificently: he has thrown the horse and its rider into the sea."
2:15:2/The LORD is my strength and my song, and he has become my salvation: he is my God, and I will make a home for him; my father's God, and I will praise him highly.
2:15:3/The LORD is a warrior; the LORD is his name.
2:15:4/He threw Pharaoh's chariots and his army into the sea; his elite officers were drowned in the Red Sea.
2:15:5/The depths covered them; they sank to the bottom like a stone.
2:15:6/Your right hand, O LORD, is majestic in power; your right hand, O LORD, shattered the enemy.
2:15:7/In your great majesty, you overthrew those who rose against you. You unleashed your wrath, which consumed them like chaff.
2:15:8/At the blast of your nostrils, the waters piled up, the floods stood firm like a wall, and the depths froze in the heart of the sea.
2:15:9/The enemy boasted, 'I will chase, I will overtake, I will divide the spoils; my desire will be satisfied on them. I will draw my sword, my hand will destroy them.'
2:15:10/But you blew with your wind, and the sea covered them. They sank like lead in the mighty waters.
2:15:11/Who is like you, O LORD, among the gods? Who is like you, majestic in holiness, awesome in praises, working wonders?
2:15:12/You stretched out your right hand, and the earth swallowed them.
2:15:13/In your mercy, you led the people you redeemed; you guided them in your strength to your holy dwelling.
2:15:14/The peoples will hear and tremble; anguish will grip the dwellers of Philistia.
2:15:15/Then the leaders of Edom will be terrified; the mighty men of Moab will be seized with trembling; all the inhabitants of Canaan will melt away.
2:15:16/Fear and dread will fall on them; by the power of your arm, they will be as still as a stone until your people pass by, O LORD, until the people you bought pass by.
2:15:17/You will bring them in and plant them on the mountain of your inheritance, the place, O LORD, you made for your dwelling, the sanctuary, O LORD, your hands established.
2:15:18/The LORD will reign forever and ever.
2:15:19/For Pharaoh's horse, his chariots, and his horsemen went into the sea, and the LORD brought the waters of the sea back over them; but the Israelites walked through the sea on dry ground.
2:15:20/And Miriam the prophetess, Aaron's sister, took a tambourine in her hand; and all the women followed her with tambourines and dancing.
2:15:21/And Miriam sang to them: "Sing to the LORD, for he is highly exalted. The horse and its rider he has hurled into the sea."
2:15:22/So Moses led Israel away from the Red Sea, and they went into the desert of Shur. For three days they traveled in the desert without finding water.
2:15:23/When they came to Marah, they couldn't drink its water because it was bitter. That's why the place was named Marah.
2:15:24/And the people complained against Moses, asking, "What are we going to drink?"
2:15:25/So he cried out to the LORD, and the LORD showed him a piece of wood. He threw it into the water, and the water became sweet. There he set for them a decree and a law, and there he tested them,
2:15:26/And said, "If you listen carefully to the LORD your God and do what is right in his eyes, if you pay attention to his commands and keep all his decrees, I will not bring on you any of the diseases I brought on the Egyptians, for I am the LORD, who heals you."
2:15:27/Then they came to Elim, where there were twelve springs of water and seventy palm trees, and they camped there near the water.
2:16:1/They set out from Elim, and the entire community of the Israelites arrived at the Wilderness of Sin, located between Elim and Sinai, on the fifteenth day of the second month after leaving Egypt.
2:16:2/The whole community of the Israelites complained against Moses and Aaron in the wilderness.
2:16:3/The Israelites said to them, "If only we had died by the LORD's hand in Egypt, where we sat around pots of meat and ate all the bread we wanted. Instead, you've brought us into this desert to starve this entire assembly to death."
2:16:4/Then the LORD said to Moses, "Look, I'm going to make bread rain down from heaven for you. The people will go out and collect a certain amount each day, so I can test them to see if they will follow my instructions or not."
2:16:5/It will happen that on the sixth day when they prepare what they bring in, it will be twice as much as they collect on the other days.
2:16:6/Moses and Aaron told all the Israelites, "By evening, you will realize that it was the LORD who brought you out of Egypt."
2:16:7/"And in the morning, you will see the glory of the LORD, because he has heard your complaints against him. Who are we, that you should complain against us?"
2:16:8/Moses also said, "You will know this when the LORD gives you meat to eat in the evening and all the bread you want in the morning, because he has heard the complaints you've been making against him. Who are we? Your complaints are not against us but against the LORD."
2:16:9/Moses told Aaron, "Tell the entire Israelite community to come before the LORD, for he has heard your complaints."
2:16:10/As Aaron spoke to the whole Israelite community, they looked toward the desert, and the glory of the LORD appeared in the cloud.
2:16:11/The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
2:16:12/"I have heard the complaints of the Israelites. Tell them, 'In the evening you will eat meat, and in the morning you will be filled with bread. Then you will know that I am the LORD your God.'"
2:16:13/That evening quail came and covered the camp, and in the morning there was a layer of dew around the camp.
2:16:14/When the dew was gone, thin flakes like frost appeared on the desert floor.
2:16:15/When the Israelites saw it, they asked each other, "What is it?" because they didn't know what it was. Moses told them, "This is the bread the LORD has given you to eat."
2:16:16/"This is what the LORD has commanded: 'Each one of you is to gather as much as they need, an omer per person according to the number of people in each tent.'"
2:16:17/The Israelites did as they were told; some gathered more, some less.
2:16:18/But when they measured it by the omer, the one who gathered much didn't have too much, and the one who gathered little didn't have too little. Everyone had gathered just as much as they needed.
2:16:19/Moses said, "No one is to keep any of it until morning."
2:16:20/However, some of them didn't listen to Moses and kept part of it until morning, but it was full of worms and began to smell. Moses was angry with them.
2:16:21/They gathered it every morning, each person as much as they needed, and when the sun grew hot, it melted away.
2:16:22/On the sixth day, they gathered twice as much bread, two omers for each person, and the leaders of the community came and reported this to Moses.
2:16:23/He said to them, "This is what the LORD has said: 'Tomorrow is a day of sabbath rest, a holy sabbath to the LORD. Bake what you want to bake and boil what you want to boil. Save whatever is left and keep it until morning.'"
2:16:24/So they saved it until morning, as Moses commanded, and it didn't stink or get worms in it.
2:16:25/Moses said, "Eat it today, because today is a sabbath to the LORD. You will not find it on the ground today.
2:16:26/Six days you are to gather it, but on the seventh day, the sabbath, there will not be any."
2:16:27/Nevertheless, some of the people went out on the seventh day to gather it, but they found none.
2:16:28/The LORD said to Moses, "How long will you refuse to keep my commands and my instructions?
2:16:29/See, the LORD has given you the sabbath; that is why on the sixth day he gives you bread for two days. Everyone is to stay where they are; no one is to go out on the seventh day."
2:16:30/So the people rested on the seventh day.
2:16:31/The Israelites called it manna. It was white like coriander seed and tasted like wafers made with honey.
2:16:32/Moses said, "This is what the LORD has commanded: 'Take an omer of manna and keep it for the generations to come, so they can see the bread I gave you to eat in the wilderness when I brought you out of Egypt.'"
2:16:33/Moses said to Aaron, "Take a jar and put an omer of manna in it. Then place it before the LORD to be kept for your generations."
2:16:34/As the LORD commanded Moses, Aaron placed the manna in front of the Testimony, to be kept.
2:16:35/The Israelites ate manna for forty years, until they came to a land that was settled; they ate manna until they reached the border of Canaan.
2:16:36/An omer is one-tenth of an ephah.
2:17:1/All the Israelites traveled from the wilderness of Sin, moving from place to place as the LORD commanded, and set up camp in Rephidim. But there was no water for them to drink.
2:17:2/So the people argued with Moses, saying, "Give us water to drink." Moses replied, "Why are you arguing with me? Why are you testing the LORD?"
2:17:3/The people were desperately thirsty for water there; they complained to Moses, saying, "Why did you bring us out of Egypt, to kill us, our children, and our livestock with thirst?"
2:17:4/In distress, Moses cried out to the LORD, "What should I do with these people? They are almost ready to stone me."
2:17:5/The LORD instructed Moses, "Walk ahead of the people. Take some of the elders of Israel with you; take the staff with which you struck the Nile, and go.
2:17:6/Look, I will stand there before you by the rock at Horeb. Strike the rock, and water will come out of it for the people to drink." Moses did this in the presence of the elders of Israel.
2:17:7/He named the place Massah and Meribah because the Israelites argued and tested the LORD, asking, "Is the LORD among us or not?"
2:17:8/Then Amalek came and fought against Israel at Rephidim.
