2:17:9/Moses said to Joshua, "Select some men for us, and go out to fight Amalek. Tomorrow I will stand on the top of the hill with the staff of God in my hand."
2:17:10/Joshua did as Moses told him and fought against Amalek, while Moses, Aaron, and Hur went to the top of the hill.
2:17:11/Whenever Moses held up his hand, Israel was winning, but whenever he lowered his hand, Amalek was winning.
2:17:12/But Moses' arms grew tired; so they took a stone and put it under him, and he sat on it. Aaron and Hur held his hands up—one on one side, one on the other—so that his hands remained steady till sunset.
2:17:13/Joshua overwhelmed Amalek and his forces with the sword.
2:17:14/The LORD said to Moses, "Write this as a reminder in a book and recite it to Joshua: I will completely erase the memory of Amalek from under the heavens."
2:17:15/Moses built an altar and named it The LORD Is My Banner.
2:17:16/He declared, "Because the LORD has sworn: the LORD will be at war with Amalek from generation to generation."
2:18:1/When Jethro, the priest of Midian, Moses’ father-in-law, heard about everything God had done for Moses and for Israel, his people, and how the LORD had brought Israel out of Egypt;
2:18:2/Then Jethro, Moses’ father-in-law, took Zipporah, Moses’ wife, after he had sent her back,
2:18:3/And her two sons; one was named Gershom, for he said, "I have been a foreigner in a foreign land";
2:18:4/And the other was named Eliezer, for he said, "The God of my father was my helper and saved me from Pharaoh's sword";
2:18:5/And Jethro, Moses’ father-in-law, came with his sons and his wife to Moses in the wilderness, where he was camped at the mountain of God;
2:18:6/And he said to Moses, "I, your father-in-law Jethro, have come to you, along with your wife and her two sons."
2:18:7/And Moses went out to meet his father-in-law, bowed down, and kissed him; they asked each other about their well-being and then went into the tent.
2:18:8/And Moses told his father-in-law everything the LORD had done to Pharaoh and the Egyptians for Israel's sake, all the hardships they had encountered on the way, and how the LORD had delivered them.
2:18:9/And Jethro was delighted about all the good things the LORD had done for Israel, in rescuing them from the Egyptians.
2:18:10/And Jethro said, "Praise be to the LORD, who has rescued you from the Egyptians and from Pharaoh, and who has delivered the people from the Egyptians' control.
2:18:11/Now I know that the LORD is greater than all other gods, because of the way he dealt with those who were arrogant towards them."
2:18:12/And Jethro, Moses’ father-in-law, brought a burnt offering and sacrifices to God; and Aaron came with all the elders of Israel to eat a meal with Moses’ father-in-law in the presence of God.
2:18:13/And the next day, Moses sat to judge the people, and they stood around Moses from morning until evening.
2:18:14/When Moses’ father-in-law saw all that he was doing for the people, he asked, "What is this you are doing for the people? Why do you sit alone while everyone stands around you from morning until evening?"
2:18:15/And Moses said to his father-in-law, "Because the people come to me to seek God's will.
2:18:16/When they have a dispute, it comes to me, and I decide between the parties and inform them of God's decrees and laws."
2:18:17/And Moses’ father-in-law said to him, "What you are doing is not good.
2:18:18/You and these people who come to you will only wear yourselves out. The work is too heavy for you; you cannot handle it alone.
2:18:19/Listen now to my advice, and God be with you. You should represent the people before God and bring their disputes to Him.
2:18:20/You should teach them the decrees and laws, and show them the way to live and the duties they are to perform.
2:18:21/But select capable men from all the people—men who fear God, trustworthy men who hate dishonest gain—and appoint them as officials over thousands, hundreds, fifties, and tens.
2:18:22/Have them serve as judges for the people at all times, but have them bring every major case to you. The minor cases they can decide themselves. This will make your load lighter, because they will share it with you.
2:18:23/If you do this and God so commands, you will be able to stand the strain, and all these people will go home satisfied."
2:18:24/So Moses listened to his father-in-law and did everything he said.
2:18:25/Moses chose capable men from all Israel and made them leaders of the people, officials over thousands, hundreds, fifties, and tens.
2:18:26/And they judged the people at all times; the difficult cases they brought to Moses, but the minor ones they decided themselves.
2:18:27/And Moses let his father-in-law depart, and he went back to his own country.
2:19:1/In the third month after the Israelites had left Egypt, they arrived in the wilderness of Sinai.
2:19:2/They had traveled from Rephidim, reached the desert of Sinai, and set up camp in the wilderness; there, Israel camped near the mountain.
2:19:3/Moses went up to meet with God, and the LORD called to him from the mountain, saying, "This is what you are to say to the descendants of Jacob and inform the Israelites:
2:19:4/You have seen what I did to the Egyptians, and how I carried you on eagles' wings and brought you to myself.
2:19:5/So now, if you listen carefully to my voice and keep my covenant, you will be my treasured possession out of all the nations, for the whole earth is mine.
2:19:6/And you will be to me a kingdom of priests and a holy nation.' These are the words you are to speak to the Israelites."
2:19:7/Moses then summoned the elders of the people and set before them all these commands that the LORD had given him.
2:19:8/All the people responded together, "We will do everything the LORD has said." Moses brought their answer back to the LORD.
2:19:9/The LORD said to Moses, "I am going to come to you in a dense cloud, so the people will hear me speaking with you and will always put their trust in you." Then Moses told the LORD what the people had said.
2:19:10/And the LORD told Moses, "Go to the people and consecrate them today and tomorrow. Have them wash their clothes
2:19:11/and be ready by the third day, because on that day the LORD will come down on Mount Sinai in the sight of all the people.
2:19:12/You must set limits for the people all around, saying, 'Be careful not to go up the mountain or touch its edge. Anyone who touches the mountain will surely be put to death.
2:19:13/No hand is to touch it, but they shall surely be stoned or shot with arrows; whether animal or person, they will not live.' When the trumpet sounds a long blast, they may approach the mountain."
2:19:14/Then Moses went down from the mountain to the people and consecrated them, and they washed their clothes.
2:19:15/He said to the people, "Prepare yourselves for the third day. Do not come near your wives."
2:19:16/On the morning of the third day, there were thunders and lightnings, a thick cloud on the mountain, and a very loud trumpet blast. Everyone in the camp trembled.
2:19:17/Then Moses led the people out of the camp to meet with God, and they stood at the foot of the mountain.
2:19:18/Mount Sinai was covered in smoke because the LORD descended on it in fire. The smoke billowed up like smoke from a furnace, and the whole mountain trembled violently.
2:19:19/As the sound of the trumpet grew louder and louder, Moses spoke and God answered him with a voice.
2:19:20/The LORD descended to the top of Mount Sinai and called Moses to the top of the mountain. So Moses went up.
2:19:21/The LORD warned Moses, "Go down and warn the people so they do not force their way through to see the LORD and many of them perish.
2:19:22/Even the priests, who approach the LORD, must consecrate themselves, or the LORD will break out against them."
2:19:23/Moses said to the LORD, "The people cannot come up to Mount Sinai, for you yourself warned us, 'Set limits around the mountain and consecrate it.'"
2:19:24/Then the LORD replied, "Go down and bring Aaron up with you. But the priests and the people must not force their way through to come up to the LORD, or he will break out against them."
2:19:25/So Moses went down to the people and told them.
2:20:1/And God spoke all these words, saying,
2:20:2/I am the LORD your God, who brought you out of Egypt, out of the land of slavery.
2:20:3/You shall have no other gods before me.
2:20:4/You shall not make for yourself an idol in the form of anything in heaven above or on the earth beneath or in the waters below.
2:20:5/You shall not bow down to them or worship them; for I, the LORD your God, am a jealous God, punishing the children for the sin of the parents to the third and fourth generation of those who hate me,
2:20:6/But showing love to a thousand generations of those who love me and keep my commandments.
2:20:7/You shall not misuse the name of the LORD your God, for the LORD will not hold anyone guiltless who misuses his name.
2:20:8/Remember the Sabbath day by keeping it holy.
2:20:9/Six days you shall labor and do all your work,
2:20:10/But the seventh day is a Sabbath to the LORD your God. On it you shall not do any work, neither you, nor your son or daughter, nor your male or female servant, nor your animals, nor any foreigner residing in your towns.
2:20:11/For in six days the LORD made the heavens and the earth, the sea, and all that is in them, but he rested on the seventh day. Therefore the LORD blessed the Sabbath day and made it holy.
2:20:12/Honor your father and your mother, so that you may live long in the land the LORD your God is giving you.
2:20:13/You shall not murder.
2:20:14/You shall not commit adultery.
2:20:15/You shall not steal.
2:20:16/You shall not give false testimony against your neighbor.
2:20:17/You shall not covet your neighbor's house. You shall not covet your neighbor's wife, or his male or female servant, his ox or donkey, or anything that belongs to your neighbor.
2:20:18/And all the people witnessed the thunder and lightning, the sound of the trumpet, and the mountain in smoke; and when the people saw it, they trembled and stood at a distance.
2:20:19/And they said to Moses, "Speak to us yourself and we will listen. But do not have God speak to us or we will die."
2:20:20/And Moses said to the people, "Do not be afraid. God has come to test you, so that the fear of God will be with you to keep you from sinning."
2:20:21/And the people remained at a distance, while Moses approached the thick darkness where God was.
2:20:22/And the LORD said to Moses, "This is what you are to say to the Israelites: 'You have seen that I have spoken to you from heaven.'"
2:20:23/You must not make any gods to be alongside me; do not make for yourselves gods of silver or gods of gold.
2:20:24/Make an altar of earth for me and sacrifice on it your burnt offerings and fellowship offerings, your sheep and your cattle. In every place where I cause my name to be honored, I will come to you and bless you.
2:20:25/If you make an altar of stones for me, do not build it with dressed stones, for you will defile it if you use a tool on it.
2:20:26/And do not go up to my altar on steps, lest your nakedness be exposed on it.
2:21:1/Here are the laws you must present to them.
2:21:2/If you purchase a Hebrew servant, he is to serve for six years. In the seventh year, he shall be freed without having to pay anything.
2:21:3/If he arrived alone, he shall leave alone. If he was married, then his wife shall leave with him.
2:21:4/If his master gives him a wife and she bears him sons or daughters, the wife and her children belong to her master, and he shall leave by himself.
2:21:5/But if the servant declares, 'I love my master, my wife, and my children; I do not want to go free,'
2:21:6/then his master must take him before the judges. He shall take him to the door or doorpost, and pierce his ear with an awl. After that, he will serve his master for life.
2:21:7/If a man sells his daughter as a servant, she is not to be freed in the same way male servants are.
2:21:8/If she does not please her master who has betrothed her to himself, he must allow her to be bought back. He has no right to sell her to foreigners because he has broken faith with her.
2:21:9/If he has selected her for his son, he must grant her the rights of a daughter.
2:21:10/If he marries another woman, he must not reduce her food, clothing, or marital rights.
2:21:11/If he does not provide these three things for her, she is to go free, without any payment of money.
2:21:12/Anyone who strikes a person and causes death must be put to death.
2:21:13/However, if it was not intentional but God allowed it to happen, I will designate a place where the person can flee.
2:21:14/But if someone deliberately attacks and kills another person, you must take them away from my altar and put them to death.
2:21:15/Anyone who attacks their father or mother must be put to death.
2:21:16/Anyone who kidnaps someone, whether they have sold them or still have them, must be put to death.
2:21:17/Anyone who curses their father or mother must be put to death.
2:21:18/If men argue and one strikes the other with a stone or fist and the injured person does not die but is confined to bed,
2:21:19/if the injured person recovers enough to walk around with a cane, the attacker will not be punished. However, they must compensate the injured person for their lost time and ensure they are fully healed.
2:21:20/If a man strikes his servant or maid with a rod and the servant dies as a direct result, he must be punished.
2:21:21/However, if the servant survives for a day or two, there is no punishment, for the servant is his property.
2:21:22/If men fight and injure a pregnant woman so that she gives birth prematurely but there is no serious injury, the offender must be fined whatever the woman's husband demands and the court allows.
2:21:23/But if there is serious injury, you are to take life for life,
2:21:24/eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot,
2:21:25/burn for burn, wound for wound, bruise for bruise.
2:21:26/If a man hits the eye of his servant or the eye of his maid and destroys it, he must let the servant go free to compensate for the eye.
2:21:27/And if he knocks out a tooth of his manservant or maidservant, he must let the servant go free to compensate for the tooth.
2:21:28/If an ox gores a man or a woman to death, the ox must be stoned, and its meat must not be eaten. But the owner of the ox will not be held responsible.
2:21:29/However, if the ox has had a habit of goring in the past and its owner has been warned but has not kept it confined and it kills a man or woman, the ox must be stoned and its owner also must be put to death.
2:21:30/If a payment is demanded of the owner, then he may redeem his life by paying whatever is demanded.
2:21:31/This law also applies if the ox gores a son or daughter.
2:21:32/If the ox gores a servant or maid, the owner must pay thirty shekels of silver to their master, and the ox must be stoned.
2:21:33/If anyone uncovers a pit or digs one and fails to cover it and an ox or a donkey falls into it,
2:21:34/the owner of the pit must compensate the animal's owner, but the dead animal will belong to him.
2:21:35/If one person's ox injures another's so that it dies, they must sell the live ox and divide the proceeds; they must also divide the dead animal.
2:21:36/But if it is known that the ox has been in the habit of goring and the owner has not kept it confined, the owner must pay ox for ox, and the dead animal will be his.
2:22:1/If someone steals an ox or a sheep, and either slaughters or sells it, they must compensate with five oxen for an ox, and four sheep for a sheep.
2:22:2/If a thief is caught breaking in and is fatally struck, no one is held responsible for his death.
2:22:3/However, if it happens after sunrise, the person who struck the thief is guilty of bloodshed; the thief must fully compensate. If unable to pay, he must be sold to cover his theft.
2:22:4/If the stolen animal is found alive in the thief's possession, whether it's an ox, donkey, or sheep, he must pay back double.
2:22:5/If someone lets their livestock graze in someone else's field or vineyard, they must compensate with the best of their own field or vineyard.
2:22:6/If a fire is started and spreads to thorns, consuming stacks of grain, standing grain, or a field, the one who started the fire must make full restitution.
2:22:7/If someone entrusts their neighbor with money or goods and they are stolen from the neighbor's house, the thief, if caught, must pay back double.
2:22:8/If the thief is not caught, the homeowner must appear before the judges to determine if they have stolen their neighbor's property.
2:22:9/In any case of wrongdoing involving an ox, donkey, sheep, clothing, or any lost item claimed by another, both parties must present their case before the judges. Whoever the judges find guilty must pay double to their neighbor.
2:22:10/If someone entrusts a neighbor with an animal and it dies, is injured, or is taken without anyone seeing,
2:22:11/then an oath before the LORD shall be made between them to certify that the keeper has not stolen the property. The owner must accept this, and no restitution is required.
2:22:12/But if the animal was stolen, the keeper must compensate the owner.
2:22:13/If it was killed by a wild animal, the keeper should bring the remains as evidence and will not have to compensate for the loss.
2:22:14/If someone borrows an animal from their neighbor and it gets injured or dies in the absence of the owner, they must make full restitution.
2:22:15/However, if the owner was present, no compensation is required. If the animal was rented, the loss is covered by the rental fee.
2:22:16/If a man seduces a woman who is not engaged and sleeps with her, he must pay the bride price and marry her.
2:22:17/If her father absolutely refuses to give her to him, he must pay an amount equivalent to the bride price for virgins.
2:22:18/You must not allow a sorceress to live.
2:22:19/Anyone who has sexual relations with an animal must be put to death.
2:22:20/Anyone who sacrifices to any god other than the LORD alone shall be completely destroyed.
2:22:21/You must not mistreat or oppress a foreigner, for you were foreigners in Egypt.
2:22:22/You must not cause harm to any widow or orphan.
2:22:23/If you do harm them and they cry out to me, I will certainly hear their cry;
2:22:24/and my anger will flare up, and I will kill you with the sword; your wives will become widows and your children fatherless.
2:22:25/If you lend money to one of my people among you who is needy, do not act like a moneylender; charge no interest.
2:22:26/If you take your neighbor's cloak as a pledge, return it by sunset,
2:22:27/because it is their only covering—it is the cloak for their body. What else will they sleep in? When they cry out to me, I will hear, for I am compassionate.
2:22:28/You must not blaspheme God or curse a leader of your people.
2:22:29/Do not hold back offerings from your granaries or vats. You must give me the firstborn of your sons.
2:22:30/You must do the same with your cattle and your sheep. Let them stay with their mothers for seven days, but give them to me on the eighth day.
2:22:31/You must be holy to me. Therefore, do not eat any meat that has been torn by wild animals in the field; throw it to the dogs.
2:23:1/Do not spread false reports. Do not join forces with the wicked by being an untruthful witness.
2:23:2/Do not follow the crowd in doing wrong. When you give testimony in a lawsuit, do not pervert justice by siding with the crowd,
2:23:3/Do not show favoritism to a poor person in their lawsuit.
2:23:4/If you come across your enemy's ox or donkey wandering off, be sure to return it.
2:23:5/If you see the donkey of someone who hates you fallen down under its load, do not leave it there; be sure you help them with it.
2:23:6/Do not deny justice to your poor people in their lawsuits.
2:23:7/Stay far away from a false charge, and do not kill the innocent and righteous, for I will not acquit the guilty.
2:23:8/Do not accept a bribe, for a bribe blinds those who see and twists the words of the righteous.
2:23:9/Do not oppress a foreigner; you yourselves know how it feels to be foreigners, because you were foreigners in Egypt.
2:23:10/For six years you are to sow your fields and harvest the crops,
2:23:11/But during the seventh year, you must let it rest and lie fallow, so that the poor among your people may eat from it, and what they leave the wild animals may eat. Do the same with your vineyard and your olive grove.
2:23:12/Six days you shall do your work, but on the seventh day you must rest, so that your ox and your donkey may rest, and the slave born in your household, and the foreigner, may be refreshed.
2:23:13/Be careful to do everything I have said to you. Do not invoke the names of other gods; do not let them be heard on your lips.
2:23:14/Celebrate three festivals for me each year.
2:23:15/You must observe the Festival of Unleavened Bread; for seven days eat bread made without yeast, as I commanded you, at the appointed time in the month of Aviv, for in that month you came out of Egypt. No one is to appear before me empty-handed.
2:23:16/Celebrate the Festival of Harvest with the firstfruits of the crops you sow in your field. Celebrate the Festival of Ingathering at the end of the year, when you gather in your crops from the field.
2:23:17/Three times a year all the men are to appear before the Sovereign Lord.
2:23:18/Do not offer the blood of a sacrifice to me along with anything containing yeast. The fat of my festival offerings must not be kept until morning.
2:23:19/Bring the best of the firstfruits of your soil to the house of the Lord your God. Do not cook a young goat in its mother's milk.
2:23:20/See, I am sending an angel ahead of you to guard you along the way and to bring you to the place I have prepared.
2:23:21/Pay attention to him and listen to what he says. Do not rebel against him; he will not forgive your rebellion, since my Name is in him.
2:23:22/If you listen carefully to what he says and do all that I say, I will be an enemy to your enemies and will oppose those who oppose you.
2:23:23/My angel will go ahead of you and bring you into the land of the Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, Canaanites, Hivites, and Jebusites, and I will wipe them out.
2:23:24/Do not bow down before their gods or worship them or follow their practices. You must demolish them and break their sacred stones to pieces.
2:23:25/Worship the Lord your God, and his blessing will be on your food and water. I will take away sickness from among you,
2:23:26/No one will miscarry or be barren in your land. I will give you a full life span.
2:23:27/I will send my terror ahead of you and throw into confusion every nation you encounter. I will make all your enemies turn their backs and run.
2:23:28/I will send the hornet ahead of you to drive the Hivites, Canaanites, and Hittites out of your way.
2:23:29/But I will not drive them out in a single year, because the land would become desolate and the wild animals too numerous for you.
2:23:30/Little by little I will drive them out before you, until you have increased enough to take possession of the land.
2:23:31/I will establish your borders from the Red Sea to the Sea of the Philistines, and from the desert to the River. I will give into your hands the people who live in the land, and you will drive them out before you.
2:23:32/Do not make a covenant with them or with their gods.
2:23:33/They must not stay in your land, or they will cause you to sin against me. If you worship their gods, it will surely be a snare to you.
2:24:1/He told Moses, "Come up to the LORD, you, Aaron, Nadab, Abihu, and seventy of Israel's elders; and worship from a distance."
2:24:2/Only Moses is to come near the LORD; the others must not come close, and the people cannot come up with him.
2:24:3/Moses relayed to the people all the LORD's commands and laws. Unanimously, the people said, "We will do everything the LORD has said."
2:24:4/Moses documented all the LORD's commands, got up early in the morning, built an altar at the foot of the mountain, and set up twelve pillars for the twelve tribes of Israel.
2:24:5/He sent young Israelite men to offer burnt offerings and sacrifice oxen as fellowship offerings to the LORD.
2:24:6/Moses took half of the blood and put it in bowls; the other half he sprinkled on the altar.
2:24:7/He took the covenant book and read it to the people. They responded, "We will do everything the LORD has said and obey."
2:24:8/Moses took the blood and sprinkled it on the people, saying, "This is the blood of the covenant the LORD has made with you based on all these words."
2:24:9/Moses, Aaron, Nadab, Abihu, and the seventy elders of Israel went up.
2:24:10/They saw the God of Israel. Under his feet was something like a pavement made of sapphire, clear as the sky itself.
2:24:11/But God did not raise his hand against these leaders of the Israelites; they saw God, and they ate and drank.
2:24:12/The LORD told Moses, "Come up to me on the mountain and stay here, and I will give you the tablets of stone with the law and commands I have written for their instruction."
2:24:13/Moses got up, along with his assistant Joshua, and Moses went up the mountain of God.
2:24:14/He told the elders, "Wait here for us until we return to you. Aaron and Hur are with you; anyone with a dispute can go to them."
2:24:15/Moses went up the mountain, and the cloud covered it.
2:24:16/The LORD's glory settled on Mount Sinai, and the cloud covered it for six days. On the seventh day, he called to Moses from within the cloud.
2:24:17/The appearance of the LORD's glory to the Israelites was like a consuming fire on the mountaintop.
2:24:18/Moses entered the cloud as he went up the mountain. He stayed on the mountain for forty days and forty nights.
2:25:1/And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
2:25:2/Tell the Israelites to bring me an offering. You are to accept the offering from anyone who gives it willingly from their heart.
2:25:3/This offering should include gold, silver, and bronze,
2:25:4/As well as blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, fine linen, and goats' hair,
2:25:5/Also, rams' skins dyed red, another type of durable leather, and acacia wood,
2:25:6/Oil for the lamp, spices for the anointing oil and for the fragrant incense,
2:25:7/Onyx stones, and other gemstones for setting in the ephod and the breastplate.
2:25:8/Have them make a sanctuary for me, so I can live among them.
2:25:9/Make sure you construct it exactly according to the design I show you—the design of the tabernacle and all its furnishings.
2:25:10/They are to make an ark of acacia wood—its length should be two and a half cubits, its width a cubit and a half, and its height a cubit and a half.
2:25:11/Cover it inside and out with pure gold, and put a gold molding around it.
2:25:12/Cast four gold rings for it and attach them to its four feet, with two rings on one side and two rings on the other.
2:25:13/Make poles of acacia wood and cover them with gold.
2:25:14/Insert the poles into the rings on the sides of the ark to carry it.
2:25:15/The poles are to remain in the rings of the ark; they should not be removed.
2:25:16/Place in the ark the tablets of the covenant law, which I will give you.
2:25:17/Make a cover of pure gold—two and a half cubits long and a cubit and a half wide.
2:25:18/Make two cherubim out of hammered gold at the ends of the cover.
2:25:19/Make one cherub on one end and the second cherub on the other; make the cherubim of one piece with the cover, at the two ends.
2:25:20/The cherubim are to have their wings spread upward, overshadowing the cover with them. The cherubim are to face each other, looking toward the cover.
2:25:21/Place the cover on top of the ark and put in the ark the tablets of the covenant law that I will give you.
2:25:22/There, above the cover between the two cherubim that are over the ark of the covenant law, I will meet with you and give you all my commands for the Israelites.
2:25:23/Make a table of acacia wood—two cubits long, a cubit wide, and a cubit and a half high.
2:25:24/Cover it with pure gold and put a gold molding around it.
2:25:25/Also make around it a rim a handbreadth wide and put a gold molding on the rim.
2:25:26/Make four gold rings for the table and fasten them to the four corners, where the four legs are.
2:25:27/The rings are to be close to the rim to hold the poles used in carrying the table.
2:25:28/Make the poles of acacia wood, overlay them with gold and use them to carry the table.
2:25:29/Make its plates and dishes of pure gold, as well as its pitchers and bowls for the pouring out of offerings.
2:25:30/Place the Bread of the Presence on this table to be before me at all times.
2:25:31/Make a lampstand of pure gold. The lampstand should be made of hammered work: its base, its stem, its cups, its buds, and its flowers should be of one piece with it.
2:25:32/Six branches are to extend from the sides of the lampstand—three on one side and three on the other.
2:25:33/Three cups shaped like almond flowers with buds and petals are to be on one branch, three on the next branch, and the same for all six branches extending from the lampstand.
2:25:34/And on the lampstand itself are to be four cups shaped like almond flowers with buds and petals.
2:25:35/Include a bud under each pair of branches that extend from the lampstand, for a total of six branches.
2:25:36/The buds and branches shall all be of one piece with the lampstand, hammered out of pure gold.
2:25:37/Then make its seven lamps and set them up on it so that they light the space in front of it.
2:25:38/Its wick trimmers and trays are to be of pure gold.
2:25:39/A talent of pure gold is to be used for the lampstand and all these accessories.
2:25:40/See that you make them according to the pattern shown you on the mountain.
2:26:1/You shall also construct the tabernacle using ten curtains of fine linen, intricately woven with blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and decorated with cherubim.
2:26:2/Each curtain will be twenty-eight cubits long and four cubits wide, with all the curtains having the same dimensions.
2:26:3/Five of the curtains will be joined together, and the other five curtains will also be joined together.
2:26:4/Make loops of blue yarn along the edge of one curtain at the end in the set, and do the same on the edge of the outermost curtain in the second set.
2:26:5/Create fifty loops on one curtain and fifty loops on the edge of the last curtain in the second set, so the loops can be fastened together.
2:26:6/Then make fifty gold clasps and use them to join the curtains together, so it becomes a single tabernacle.
2:26:7/Make additional curtains of goat hair to serve as a covering over the tabernacle; you will need eleven curtains.
2:26:8/Each of these curtains will be thirty cubits long and four cubits wide, with all eleven curtains being the same size.
2:26:9/Join five of the curtains by themselves and the other six by themselves, and fold the sixth curtain double at the front of the tabernacle.
2:26:10/Make fifty loops on the edge of the last curtain in one set, and fifty loops on the edge of the curtain in the second set.
2:26:11/Then make fifty bronze clasps and insert them into the loops to join the tent together as one unit.
2:26:12/The remaining part of the curtains of the tent, the half curtain that is left over, shall hang over the back of the tabernacle.
2:26:13/And the extra length on one side and on the other side, from the length of the curtains, shall hang over the sides of the tabernacle to cover it.
2:26:14/You shall also make a covering for the tent out of ram skins dyed red and another covering on top made of fine leather.
2:26:15/Construct frames for the tabernacle using acacia wood, standing upright.
2:26:16/Each frame will be ten cubits long and a cubit and a half wide.
2:26:17/Each frame will have two pegs aligned with each other; you shall do this for all the frames of the tabernacle.
2:26:18/Make the frames for the tabernacle, twenty frames for the south side.
2:26:19/And make forty silver bases under the twenty frames; two bases under each frame for its two pegs.
2:26:20/For the second side of the tabernacle, the north side, there will also be twenty frames.
2:26:21/And their forty silver bases; two bases under each frame.
2:26:22/For the west side of the tabernacle, make six frames.
2:26:23/Make two additional frames for the corners of the tabernacle at the rear.
2:26:24/These will be connected at the bottom and also joined together at the top with a single ring; this is how it will be for both of the corner frames.
2:26:25/So there will be eight frames with their sixteen silver bases, two bases under each frame.
2:26:26/Make crossbars of acacia wood; five for the frames on one side of the tabernacle,
2:26:27/Five bars for the frames on the other side of the tabernacle, and five bars for the frames on the west side of the tabernacle.
2:26:28/The middle bar in the center of the frames will extend from end to end.
2:26:29/Overlay the frames with gold and make their rings of gold as holders for the bars, and overlay the bars with gold as well.
2:26:30/Raise up the tabernacle according to the design you were shown on the mountain.
2:26:31/Make a veil of blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and fine linen, artistically worked with cherubim.
2:26:32/Hang it on four pillars of acacia wood overlaid with gold, with hooks of gold, standing on four silver bases.
2:26:33/Hang the veil below the clasps and bring the Ark of the Covenant inside the veil, so the veil will separate the Holy Place from the Most Holy Place.
2:26:34/Place the atonement cover on the Ark of the Covenant in the Most Holy Place.
2:26:35/Set the table outside the veil, and the lampstand across from the table on the south side of the tabernacle; place the table on the north side.
2:26:36/Make a curtain for the entrance of the tent, using blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and finely twisted linen, decorated with embroidery.
2:26:37/For the curtain, make five pillars of acacia wood, overlay them with gold, and their hooks shall be of gold; and cast five bronze bases for them.
2:27:1/You shall construct an altar of acacia wood, five cubits in length and five cubits in width; the altar shall be square, and its height shall be three cubits.
2:27:2/You shall make horns for it on its four corners; the horns shall be of the same material, and you shall cover it with bronze.
2:27:3/You shall make its pans to catch its ashes, along with its shovels, basins, meat hooks, and firepans: all its utensils you shall make of bronze.
2:27:4/You shall make for it a grate of bronze mesh, and on the mesh you shall make four bronze rings at its four corners.
2:27:5/You shall place it under the ledge of the altar below, so that the net extends halfway up the altar.
2:27:6/You shall make poles for the altar, poles of acacia wood, and cover them with bronze.
2:27:7/The poles shall be inserted into the rings, so that the poles are on the two sides of the altar when it is carried.
2:27:8/You shall make it hollow with boards; as it was shown to you on the mountain, so shall it be made.
2:27:9/You shall construct the courtyard of the tabernacle: for the south side, facing south, there shall be curtains for the courtyard made of finely twisted linen, one hundred cubits long for one side.
2:27:10/And its twenty pillars and their twenty bases shall be of bronze; the hooks of the pillars and their bands shall be of silver.
2:27:11/And similarly for the north side in length, there shall be curtains one hundred cubits long, and its twenty pillars and their twenty bases of bronze; the hooks of the pillars and their bands of silver.
2:27:12/And for the width of the courtyard on the west side, there shall be curtains of fifty cubits: their pillars ten, and their bases ten.
2:27:13/And the width of the courtyard on the east side, facing east, shall be fifty cubits.
2:27:14/The curtains for one side of the gate shall be fifteen cubits: their pillars three, and their bases three.
2:27:15/And on the other side, curtains fifteen cubits: their pillars three, and their bases three.
2:27:16/And for the gate of the courtyard, there shall be a curtain twenty cubits long, made of blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and finely twisted linen, crafted with embroidery; its pillars shall be four, and their bases four.
2:27:17/All the pillars around the courtyard shall be banded with silver; their hooks shall be of silver, and their bases of bronze.
2:27:18/The length of the courtyard shall be one hundred cubits, and the width fifty cubits everywhere, and the height five cubits, made of finely twisted linen, and their bases of bronze.
2:27:19/All the utensils of the tabernacle for every use, and all its tent pegs, and all the pegs of the courtyard, shall be of bronze.
2:27:20/You shall instruct the Israelites to bring you clear olive oil, beaten for the light, so that the lamp may always burn.
2:27:21/In the Tent of Meeting, outside the curtain that shields the Ark of the Covenant, Aaron and his sons shall tend it from evening until morning before the LORD. It shall be a lasting ordinance for the generations to come from the Israelites.
2:28:1/Select Aaron your brother and his sons from among the Israelites to serve me as priests—Aaron, Nadab and Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar, Aaron's sons.
2:28:2/Create sacred garments for Aaron your brother to honor and beautify him.
2:28:3/Talk to all the skilled artisans I have endowed with wisdom, so they can make Aaron's garments to set him apart, allowing him to serve me as a priest.
2:28:4/These are the garments they are to make: a breastplate, an ephod, a robe, an embroidered tunic, a turban, and a sash. They are to make these sacred garments for your brother Aaron and his sons so they can serve me as priests.
2:28:5/They must use gold, blue, purple, scarlet yarn, and fine linen.
2:28:6/They are to craft the ephod with gold, blue, purple, scarlet yarn, and finely twisted linen, skillfully worked.
2:28:7/It will have two shoulder pieces attached to its two edges, so it can be fastened.
2:28:8/The artistically woven waistband on the ephod must be made of the same materials—gold, blue, purple, scarlet yarn, and finely twisted linen.
2:28:9/You are to take two onyx stones and engrave on them the names of the Israelites.
2:28:10/Engrave six of their names on one stone and the remaining six on the other, in the order of their birth.
2:28:11/With the skill of a gem cutter, engrave the two stones with the names of the Israelites. Set them in gold filigree settings.
2:28:12/Attach the stones to the shoulder pieces of the ephod as memorial stones for the Israelites. Aaron will carry their names on his shoulders before the LORD as a reminder.
2:28:13/Make settings of gold.
2:28:14/Create two gold chains with twisted work, and attach the twisted chains to the settings.
2:28:15/Fashion the breastpiece of decision with skilled craftsmanship, like the work of the ephod; use gold, blue, purple, scarlet yarn, and finely twisted linen.
2:28:16/It should be square and folded double, a span in length and width.
2:28:17/Set it with four rows of gemstones. The first row will have a ruby, a topaz, and a beryl.
2:28:18/The second row will have a turquoise, a sapphire, and an emerald.
2:28:19/The third row will have a jacinth, an agate, and an amethyst.
2:28:20/The fourth row will have a chrysolite, an onyx, and a jasper. They are to be mounted in gold filigree settings.
2:28:21/The stones are to correspond to the names of the Israelites, twelve according to their names. They are to be like the engravings of a seal, each with its name for the twelve tribes.
2:28:22/Make chains of pure gold, twisted like cords, for the breastpiece.
2:28:23/Make two gold rings for the breastpiece and attach them to its two corners.
2:28:24/Then attach the two gold chains to the rings at the corners of the breastpiece.
2:28:25/Attach the other ends of the two chains to the two settings, connecting them to the shoulder pieces of the ephod at the front.
2:28:26/Make two gold rings and attach them to the other two corners of the breastpiece, on the inside edge next to the ephod.
2:28:27/Make two more gold rings and attach them to the bottom of the shoulder pieces on the front of the ephod, close to the seam just above the waistband of the ephod.
2:28:28/The rings of the breastpiece are to be tied to the rings of the ephod with a blue cord, connecting it to the waistband so that the breastpiece will not swing out from the ephod.
2:28:29/Aaron will carry the names of the Israelites in the breastpiece of decision over his heart when he enters the Holy Place, as a continual memorial before the LORD.
2:28:30/Into the breastpiece of decision you are to place the Urim and Thummim, so they will be over Aaron's heart when he goes before the LORD. Thus, Aaron will always bear the means of making decisions for the Israelites over his heart before the LORD.
2:28:31/Make the robe of the ephod entirely of blue cloth.
2:28:32/It should have an opening for the head in its center. There must be a woven edge around this opening, like the collar of a body armor, so it will not tear.
2:28:33/Make pomegranates of blue, purple, and scarlet yarn around the hem of the robe, with gold bells between them.
2:28:34/The gold bells and pomegranates are to alternate around the hem of the robe.
2:28:35/Aaron must wear it when he ministers. The sound of the bells will be heard when he enters and leaves the Holy Place before the LORD, so he will not die.
2:28:36/Make a plate of pure gold and engrave on it as on a seal: HOLY TO THE LORD.
2:28:37/Fasten it on a blue cord to attach it to the turban; it is to be on the front of the turban.
2:28:38/It will be on Aaron's forehead, and Aaron will bear the guilt involved in the sacred gifts the Israelites consecrate, whatever their gifts may be. It will be always on his forehead, so that they will be accepted before the LORD.
2:28:39/Weave the tunic of fine linen, make the turban of fine linen, and also make the sash using embroidered work.
2:28:40/For Aaron's sons, make tunics, sashes, and headgear for dignity and adornment.
2:28:41/Dress your brother Aaron and his sons with these garments. Anoint them, ordain them, and consecrate them so they may serve me as priests.
2:28:42/Make linen undergarments to cover their nakedness, reaching from the waist to the thighs.
2:28:43/Aaron and his sons must wear them whenever they enter the tent of meeting or approach the altar to minister in the Holy Place, so they will not incur guilt and die. This is to be a lasting ordinance for Aaron and his descendants.
2:29:1/Here's what you need to do to make them holy, so they can serve me as priests: Take one young bull and two rams without any defects.
2:29:2/Also take unleavened bread, unleavened cakes mixed with oil, and unleavened wafers spread with oil, all made from fine wheat flour.
2:29:3/Put them all in one basket and bring them, along with the bull and the two rams.
2:29:4/Bring Aaron and his sons to the entrance of the meeting tent and wash them with water.
2:29:5/Then, dress Aaron in the tunic, the robe of the ephod, the ephod itself, the breastplate, and tie the skillfully woven band of the ephod around him.
2:29:6/Place the turban on his head and attach the sacred emblem to the turban.
2:29:7/Next, take the anointing oil, pour it on his head, and anoint him.
2:29:8/Bring his sons and dress them in tunics.
2:29:9/Tie sashes around Aaron and his sons, put headbands on them, and the priesthood will be their responsibility as a lasting ordinance. This is how you will ordain Aaron and his sons.
2:29:10/Bring the bull to the front of the meeting tent, and Aaron and his sons shall lay their hands on its head.
2:29:11/Then, slaughter the bull in the presence of the LORD at the entrance to the meeting tent.
2:29:12/Take some of the bull's blood and put it on the horns of the altar with your finger, and pour out the rest of the blood at the base of the altar.
2:29:13/Take all the fat that covers the internal organs, the lobe of the liver, and both kidneys with the fat on them, and burn them on the altar.
2:29:14/But burn the bull's flesh, its skin, and its dung outside the camp. It is a sin offering.
2:29:15/Also take one ram, and Aaron and his sons shall lay their hands on its head.
2:29:16/Then, slaughter the ram, take its blood and sprinkle it around the altar.
2:29:17/Cut the ram into pieces, wash the internal organs and the legs, and place them with the head and the other pieces.
2:29:18/Burn the entire ram on the altar. It is a burnt offering to the LORD, a pleasing aroma, an offering made by fire to the LORD.
2:29:19/Now take the other ram, and Aaron and his sons shall lay their hands on its head.
2:29:20/Then, slaughter the ram, take some of its blood and put it on the lobe of the right ear of Aaron and his sons, on the thumbs of their right hands, and on the big toes of their right feet. Sprinkle the blood around the altar.
2:29:21/Take some of the blood on the altar and some of the anointing oil and sprinkle it on Aaron and his garments, as well as on his sons and their garments. Then he and his garments will be holy, as well as his sons and their garments.
2:29:22/Also take the fat from the ram, the fat tail, the fat that covers the internal organs, the lobe of the liver, both kidneys with the fat on them, and the right thigh (since it is a ram of ordination),
2:29:23/along with one loaf of bread, one cake made with oil, and one wafer from the basket of unleavened bread that is before the LORD.
2:29:24/Put all these in the hands of Aaron and his sons and wave them as a wave offering before the LORD.
2:29:25/Then take them from their hands and burn them on the altar on top of the burnt offering, as a pleasing aroma before the LORD. It is an offering made by fire to the LORD.
2:29:26/Take the breast of the ram of Aaron's ordination and wave it as a wave offering before the LORD. It will be your portion.
2:29:27/Consecrate the breast of the wave offering and the thigh of the contribution, which were waved and raised up, from the ram of ordination, from what was for Aaron and for his sons.
2:29:28/This is to be a lasting ordinance for Aaron and his descendants from the Israelites, for it is a contribution. It will be a contribution from the Israelites from their fellowship offerings, their contribution to the LORD.
2:29:29/The sacred garments of Aaron will be passed down to his sons after him, to be anointed and ordained in them.
2:29:30/The son who succeeds him as priest and enters the tent of meeting to serve in the Holy Place must wear them for seven days.
2:29:31/Take the ram of ordination and cook its meat in a sacred place.
2:29:32/Aaron and his sons are to eat the meat of the ram and the bread in the basket at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
2:29:33/They are to eat these offerings with which atonement was made to ordain and consecrate them, but no one else may eat them because they are sacred.
2:29:34/If any of the meat of the ordination or any of the bread remains until morning, burn the leftovers. They must not be eaten because they are sacred.
2:29:35/Do this for Aaron and his sons, exactly as I have commanded you. The ordination will last seven days.
2:29:36/Each day offer a bull as a sin offering for atonement. Cleanse the altar by making atonement for it, and then anoint it to consecrate it.
2:29:37/For seven days make atonement for the altar and consecrate it. Then the altar will be most holy, and whatever touches it will be holy.
2:29:38/This is what you are to offer on the altar: two one-year-old lambs each day, continuously.
2:29:39/Offer one lamb in the morning and the other lamb at twilight.
2:29:40/With the first lamb offer a tenth of an ephah of fine flour mixed with a quarter of a hin of pressed olive oil, and a quarter of a hin of wine as a drink offering.
2:29:41/Offer the second lamb at twilight with the same grain offering and drink offering as in the morning, as a pleasing aroma, an offering made by fire to the LORD.
2:29:42/This will be a regular burnt offering throughout your generations at the entrance to the tent of meeting before the LORD, where I will meet you to speak to you there.
2:29:43/There I will meet with the Israelites, and the place will be consecrated by my glory.
2:29:44/I will consecrate the tent of meeting and the altar. I will also consecrate Aaron and his sons to serve me as priests.
2:29:45/I will dwell among the Israelites and be their God.
2:29:46/And they will know that I am the LORD their God, who brought them out of Egypt so that I might dwell among them. I am the LORD their God.
2:30:1/You must build an altar for burning incense, using acacia wood to construct it.
2:30:2/It should be one cubit long and one cubit wide, forming a square, and two cubits high with horns of the same material.
2:30:3/Cover it with pure gold, including the top, sides, and horns, and craft a gold crown around it.
2:30:4/Make two gold rings for it below the crown on opposite sides, for holding the poles used to carry it.
2:30:5/The poles themselves should be made of acacia wood and covered with gold.
2:30:6/Place it in front of the curtain that shields the Ark of the Covenant, in front of the atonement cover on the Ark where I will meet with you.
2:30:7/Aaron must burn fragrant incense on it every morning when he tends the lamps.
2:30:8/He must also burn incense in the evening when he lights the lamps, so incense will burn regularly before the LORD for generations to come.
2:30:9/Do not offer any unauthorized incense on it, or any burnt offering, grain offering, or drink offering.
2:30:10/Once a year Aaron must make atonement on its horns. This annual atonement must be made with the blood of the sin offering of atonement for generations to come. It is most holy to the LORD.
2:30:11/And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
2:30:12/When you take a census of the Israelites to count them, each one must pay the LORD a ransom for himself to avoid a plague when you count them.
2:30:13/Everyone included in the census must pay half a shekel, based on the sanctuary shekel (which is twenty gerahs). This half shekel is an offering to the LORD.
2:30:14/Everyone counted, from twenty years old and up, must give this offering to the LORD.
2:30:15/The wealthy must not give more, and the poor must not give less than half a shekel when you give the offering to the LORD to atone for your lives.
2:30:16/You must take the atonement money from the Israelites and use it for the service of the Tent of Meeting. It will serve as a reminder to the Israelites before the LORD, making atonement for your lives.
2:30:17/And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
2:30:18/You must also make a bronze basin with its bronze stand for washing. Place it between the Tent of Meeting and the altar, and put water in it.
2:30:19/Aaron and his sons will wash their hands and feet with water from it.
2:30:20/Whenever they enter the Tent of Meeting, they must wash with water so they will not die. Also, when they approach the altar to minister by presenting a food offering to the LORD,
2:30:21/they must wash their hands and feet so they will not die. This is to be a lasting ordinance for Aaron and his descendants for generations to come.
2:30:22/Moreover, the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
2:30:23/Take the finest spices: 500 shekels of liquid myrrh, half as much (250 shekels) of fragrant cinnamon, 250 shekels of fragrant calamus,
2:30:24/500 shekels of cassia—all according to the sanctuary shekel—and a hin of olive oil.
2:30:25/Make these into a sacred anointing oil, a fragrant blend, the work of a perfumer. It will be the sacred anointing oil.
2:30:26/Then use it to anoint the Tent of Meeting, the Ark of the Covenant law,
2:30:27/the table and all its articles, the lampstand and its accessories, the altar of incense,
2:30:28/the altar of burnt offering and all its utensils, and the basin with its stand.
2:30:29/You must consecrate them so they will be most holy, and whatever touches them will be holy.
2:30:30/Anoint Aaron and his sons and consecrate them so they may serve me as priests.
2:30:31/Tell the Israelites, 'This will be my sacred anointing oil for generations to come.
2:30:32/Do not pour it on anyone else's body, and do not make any oil with the same formula. It is sacred, and you are to consider it sacred.
2:30:33/Anyone who makes perfume like it and puts it on anyone other than a priest must be cut off from their people.'
2:30:34/And the LORD said to Moses, "Take fragrant spices—gum resin, onycha, and galbanum—along with pure frankincense, all in equal amounts,
2:30:35/and make a fragrant blend of incense, the work of a perfumer. It must be salted and pure and sacred.
2:30:36/Grind some of it to powder and place it in front of the Ark of the Covenant law in the Tent of Meeting, where I will meet with you. It shall be most holy to you.
2:30:37/Do not make any incense with this formula for yourselves; consider it holy to the LORD.
2:30:38/Whoever makes incense like it to enjoy its fragrance must be cut off from their people.
2:31:1/And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
2:31:2/Look, I have specifically chosen Bezaleel, the son of Uri, the son of Hur, from the tribe of Judah:
2:31:3/And I have filled him with the spirit of God, giving him wisdom, understanding, knowledge, and exceptional skills in all kinds of craftsmanship,
2:31:4/To create intricate designs, to work with gold, silver, and bronze,
2:31:5/And in cutting stones for setting, and in carving wood, to engage in all kinds of craftsmanship.
2:31:6/And I have also provided Aholiab, the son of Ahisamach, from the tribe of Dan, to work with him. And in the hearts of all who are skilled, I have placed wisdom so they can make everything I have instructed you;
2:31:7/The meeting tent, the ark of the covenant, the atonement cover on it, and all the furnishings of the tent,
2:31:8/The table and its furnishings, the pure gold lampstand with all its accessories, and the altar of incense,
2:31:9/The altar of burnt offering with all its furnishings, the basin and its stand,
2:31:10/The woven garments, the holy garments for Aaron the priest, and the garments for his sons to serve as priests,
2:31:11/The anointing oil, and fragrant incense for the sanctuary. They are to do everything just as I have commanded you.
2:31:12/And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
2:31:13/Tell the Israelites, 'You must observe my Sabbaths. This will be a sign between me and you for the generations to come, so you may know that I am the LORD, who makes you holy.
2:31:14/Therefore, you must keep the Sabbath because it is sacred for you. Anyone who desecrates it must surely be put to death; anyone who does any work on that day must be cut off from their people.
2:31:15/Six days work may be done, but the seventh day is a Sabbath of rest, sacred to the LORD. Anyone who does any work on the Sabbath day must surely be put to death.
2:31:16/So the Israelites are to observe the Sabbath, celebrating it for the generations to come as a lasting covenant.
2:31:17/It will be a sign forever between me and the Israelites, for in six days the LORD made the heavens and the earth, and on the seventh day he rested and was refreshed.
2:31:18/And when he had finished speaking with him on Mount Sinai, he gave Moses the two tablets of the covenant, tablets of stone, written by the finger of God.
2:32:1/When the people saw that Moses was taking a long time to come down from the mountain, they gathered around Aaron and said, "Get up, make us gods who will lead us. As for this Moses, the man who brought us out of Egypt, we don't know what has happened to him."
2:32:2/Aaron told them, "Take off the gold earrings that your wives, sons, and daughters are wearing, and bring them to me."
2:32:3/So all the people took off their gold earrings and brought them to Aaron.
2:32:4/He took the gold from them, shaped it with a tool, and made a golden calf. Then they said, "These are your gods, Israel, who brought you up out of Egypt."
2:32:5/When Aaron saw this, he built an altar in front of the calf and announced, "Tomorrow there will be a festival to the LORD."
2:32:6/They got up early the next day, offered burnt offerings, and presented peace offerings. The people sat down to eat and drink and then got up to indulge in revelry.
2:32:7/The LORD said to Moses, "Go down, because your people, whom you brought out of Egypt, have become corrupt."
2:32:8/They have quickly turned away from what I commanded them and have made themselves a golden calf. They have worshiped it and sacrificed to it and said, 'These are your gods, Israel, who brought you up out of Egypt.'"
2:32:9/The LORD said to Moses, "I have seen these people, and they are indeed a stiff-necked people."
2:32:10/Now leave me alone so that my anger may burn against them and that I may destroy them. Then I will make you into a great nation."
2:32:11/But Moses sought the favor of the LORD his God and said, "LORD, why should your anger burn against your people, whom you brought out of Egypt with great power and a mighty hand?"
2:32:12/Why should the Egyptians say, 'He brought them out with evil intent, to kill them in the mountains and to wipe them off the face of the earth'? Turn from your fierce anger; relent and do not bring disaster on your people."
2:32:13/Remember your servants Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, to whom you swore by your own self: 'I will make your descendants as numerous as the stars in the sky and will give your descendants all this land I promised them, and it will be their inheritance forever.'"
2:32:14/Then the LORD relented and did not bring on his people the disaster he had threatened.
2:32:15/Moses turned and went down the mountain with the two tablets of the covenant law in his hands. They were inscribed on both sides, front and back.
2:32:16/The tablets were the work of God; the writing was God's writing, engraved on the tablets.
2:32:17/When Joshua heard the noise of the people shouting, he said to Moses, "There is the sound of war in the camp."
2:32:18/Moses replied, "It is not the sound of victory, it is not the sound of defeat; it is the sound of singing that I hear."
2:32:19/As soon as Moses approached the camp and saw the calf and the dancing, his anger burned and he threw the tablets out of his hands, breaking them to pieces at the foot of the mountain.
2:32:20/He took the calf they had made and burned it in the fire; then he ground it to powder, scattered it on the water, and made the Israelites drink it.
2:32:21/Moses said to Aaron, "What did these people do to you, that you led them into such great sin?"
2:32:22/Aaron said, "Do not let your anger burn; you know the people are prone to evil."
2:32:23/They said to me, 'Make us gods who will go before us. As for this Moses, the man who brought us up out of Egypt, we don't know what has happened to him.'"
2:32:24/So I told them, 'Whoever has any gold jewelry, take it off.' Then they gave me the gold, and I threw it into the fire, and out came this calf!"
2:32:25/When Moses saw that the people were running wild and that Aaron had let them get out of control and so become a laughingstock to their enemies,
2:32:26/he stood at the entrance to the camp and said, "Whoever is for the LORD, come to me." And all the Levites rallied to him.
2:32:27/Then he said to them, "This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: 'Each man strap a sword to his side. Go back and forth through the camp from one end to the other, each killing his brother and friend and neighbor.'"
2:32:28/The Levites did as Moses commanded, and that day about three thousand of the people died.
2:32:29/Moses said, "Today you have been ordained for the service of the LORD, each man at the cost of his son and brother, so that he might bestow a blessing upon you this day."
2:32:30/The next day Moses said to the people, "You have committed a great sin. But now I will go up to the LORD; perhaps I can make atonement for your sin."
2:32:31/Moses went back to the LORD and said, "Oh, these people have committed a great sin by making themselves gods of gold."
2:32:32/Yet now, if you will forgive their sin—but if not, please blot me out of the book you have written."
2:32:33/The LORD replied to Moses, "Whoever has sinned against me, I will blot out of my book."
2:32:34/Now go, lead the people to the place I spoke of, and my angel will go before you. However, when the time comes for me to punish, I will punish them for their sin."
2:32:35/And the LORD struck the people with a plague because of what they did with the calf Aaron had made.
2:33:1/The LORD said to Moses, "Leave this place and go up with the people you brought out of Egypt to the land I promised to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, saying, 'I will give it to your descendants.'
2:33:2/I will send an angel ahead of you and drive out the Canaanites, Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites.
2:33:3/To a land flowing with milk and honey. But I will not travel among you, for you are stubborn, and I might destroy you on the way."
2:33:4/When the people heard this distressing news, they mourned and no one put on their jewelry.
2:33:5/For the LORD had told Moses, "Tell the Israelites, 'You are a stubborn people. If I were to come among you for even a moment, I might destroy you. So now, take off your jewelry so I can decide what to do with you.'"
2:33:6/So the Israelites took off their jewelry at Mount Horeb.
2:33:7/Moses took the tent and set it up outside the camp, far from the camp, and called it the Tent of Meeting. Anyone seeking the LORD would go out to the Tent of Meeting outside the camp.
2:33:8/Whenever Moses went out to the tent, all the people would rise and stand at the entrance of their tents, watching Moses until he entered the tent.
2:33:9/As Moses entered the tent, the pillar of cloud would come down and stay at the entrance of the tent, and the LORD would speak with Moses.
2:33:10/All the people saw the pillar of cloud standing at the tent entrance, and each one worshipped at the entrance of their tent.
2:33:11/The LORD would speak to Moses face to face, as one speaks to a friend. Then Moses would return to the camp, but his young aide Joshua, son of Nun, did not leave the tent.
2:33:12/Moses said to the LORD, "You have been telling me, 'Lead these people,' but you have not let me know whom you will send with me. You have said, 'I know you by name and you have found favor with me.'
2:33:13/Now if I have found favor in your sight, please show me your ways so I may know you and continue to find favor with you. Remember this nation is your people."
2:33:14/And He said, "My presence will go with you, and I will give you rest."
2:33:15/Then Moses said to Him, "If your presence does not go with us, do not send us up from here.
2:33:16/How will it be known that I and your people have found favor in your sight unless you go with us? Your going with us will distinguish us, me and your people, from all the other people on the face of the earth."
2:33:17/And the LORD said to Moses, "I will do the very thing you have asked, because I am pleased with you and I know you by name."
2:33:18/Then Moses said, "Please show me your glory."
2:33:19/And He said, "I will make all my goodness pass before you, and I will proclaim my name, the LORD, in your presence. I will have mercy on whom I will have mercy, and I will have compassion on whom I will have compassion.
2:33:20/But," He said, "you cannot see my face, for no one may see me and live."
2:33:21/And the LORD said, "Here is a place near me where you shall stand on a rock.
2:33:22/When my glory passes by, I will put you in a cleft in the rock and cover you with my hand until I have passed by.
2:33:23/Then I will remove my hand, and you will see my back; but my face must not be seen."
2:34:1/And the LORD said to Moses, "Carve two stone tablets like the first ones, and I will write on these tablets the words that were on the first tablets, which you broke."
2:34:2/"Be ready by morning, and in the morning come up to Mount Sinai and present yourself to me at the top of the mountain."
2:34:3/"No one is to come up with you, nor should anyone be seen anywhere on the mountain; nor let the flocks or herds graze in front of that mountain."
2:34:4/So he carved two stone tablets like the first ones; and Moses got up early in the morning, and went up to Mount Sinai as the LORD had instructed him, carrying the two stone tablets in his hand.
2:34:5/And the LORD descended in the cloud and stood with him there, and declared the name of the LORD.
2:34:6/And the LORD passed in front of him and declared, "The LORD, The LORD God, compassionate and gracious, slow to anger, and overflowing with kindness and truth,
2:34:7/Maintaining love for thousands, forgiving wrongdoing, rebellion, and sin, yet He will not leave the guilty unpunished; bringing the consequences of the fathers' sins upon their children and their children's children, to the third and fourth generation."
2:34:8/And Moses quickly bowed his head to the ground and worshiped.
2:34:9/And he said, "If now I have found favor in your sight, O LORD, I pray, let the LORD go among us, even though we are a stubborn people; and forgive our iniquity and our sin, and take us as your inheritance."
2:34:10/And He said, "Look, I am making a covenant: before all your people I will perform wonders never before done in any nation in all the world. The people you live among will see how awesome the work of the LORD is, the awesome deeds I will do with you."
2:34:11/"Pay attention to what I command you today: I will drive out before you the Amorites, Canaanites, Hittites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites."
2:34:12/"Be careful not to make a treaty with the inhabitants of the land where you are going, or it will be a snare among you."
2:34:13/"But you shall demolish their altars, smash their sacred stones, and cut down their Asherah poles."
2:34:14/"For you must not worship any other god, because the LORD, whose name is Jealous, is a jealous God."
2:34:15/"Be careful not to make a treaty with the inhabitants of the land, for when they prostitute themselves to their gods and sacrifice to them, they will invite you and you will eat their sacrifices."
2:34:16/"And when you choose some of their daughters as wives for your sons and those daughters prostitute themselves to their gods, they will lead your sons to do the same."
2:34:17/"Do not make any idols for yourselves."
2:34:18/"You must keep the Feast of Unleavened Bread. For seven days eat bread made without yeast, as I commanded you, at the appointed time in the month of Abib, for in that month you came out of Egypt."
2:34:19/"Everything that first opens the womb is mine, and all your male livestock, the firstborn of cow and sheep."
2:34:20/"But the firstborn of a donkey you must redeem with a lamb; if you do not redeem it, break its neck. Redeem all your firstborn sons. No one is to appear before me empty-handed."
2:34:21/"Six days you shall labor, but on the seventh day you must rest; even during the plowing season and harvest you must rest."
2:34:22/"And you shall celebrate the Feast of Weeks, with the firstfruits of the wheat harvest, and the Feast of Ingathering at the turn of the year."
2:34:23/"Three times a year all your men are to appear before the Sovereign LORD, the God of Israel."
2:34:24/"For I will drive out nations before you and enlarge your territory, and no one will covet your land when you go up three times each year to appear before the LORD your God."
2:34:25/"Do not offer the blood of a sacrifice to me along with anything containing yeast, and do not let any of the sacrifice from the Passover Festival remain until morning."
2:34:26/"Bring the best of the firstfruits of your soil to the house of the LORD your God. Do not cook a young goat in its mother's milk."
2:34:27/And the LORD said to Moses, "Write down these words, for in accordance with these words I have made a covenant with you and with Israel."
2:34:28/And he was there with the LORD forty days and forty nights; he did not eat bread or drink water. And he wrote on the tablets the words of the covenant, the Ten Commandments.
2:34:29/When Moses came down from Mount Sinai with the two tablets of the covenant in his hands, he was not aware that his face was radiant because he had spoken with the LORD.
2:34:30/When Aaron and all the Israelites saw Moses, his face was radiant, and they were afraid to come near him.
2:34:31/But Moses called to them; so Aaron and all the leaders of the community came back to him, and Moses spoke to them.
2:34:32/Afterward all the Israelites came near him, and he gave them all the commands the LORD had given him on Mount Sinai.
2:34:33/Until Moses had finished speaking with them, he put a veil over his face.
2:34:34/But whenever Moses went in before the LORD to speak with him, he removed the veil until he came out. And when he came out and told the Israelites what he had been commanded,
2:34:35/the Israelites would see Moses’ face was radiant. Then Moses would put the veil back over his face until he went in to speak with the LORD.
2:35:1/Moses gathered all the Israelites and said, "These are the commands the LORD has given for you to follow."
2:35:2/You can work for six days, but the seventh day is a sacred day of rest dedicated to the LORD. Anyone who works on this day must be put to death.
2:35:3/Do not light any fires in your homes on the Sabbath day.
2:35:4/Moses told the Israelites, "This is what the LORD has commanded:"
2:35:5/"Everyone who is willing should bring an offering to the LORD. You can bring gold, silver, and bronze,
2:35:6/as well as blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, fine linen, and goats' hair,
2:35:7/ram skins dyed red, another type of durable leather, and acacia wood,
2:35:8/olive oil for the lamps, spices for the anointing oil and for the fragrant incense,
2:35:9/onyx stones, and other gems for setting in the ephod and the breastplate.
2:35:10/Anyone skilled can come and make everything the LORD has commanded:
2:35:11/the tabernacle, its tent and cover, its clasps, frames, crossbars, posts, and bases,
2:35:12/the ark with its poles, the atonement cover, and the curtain that shields it,
2:35:13/the table with its poles and all its articles, and the bread of the Presence,
2:35:14/the lampstand that is for light with its accessories, lamps, and oil for the light,
2:35:15/the altar of incense with its poles, the anointing oil, the fragrant incense, and the curtain for the doorway at the entrance to the tabernacle,
2:35:16/the altar of burnt offering with its bronze grating, its poles, and all its utensils, the basin with its stand,
2:35:17/the curtains of the courtyard with its posts and bases, and the curtain for the entrance to the courtyard,
2:35:18/the tent pegs for the tabernacle and for the courtyard, and their ropes,
2:35:19/the woven garments for ministering in the sanctuary, both the sacred garments for Aaron the priest and the garments for his sons to serve as priests."
2:35:20/Then all the Israelites left Moses' presence.
2:35:21/Everyone whose heart was moved and whose spirit prompted them brought an offering to the LORD for the work on the Tent of Meeting, for all its service, and for the sacred garments.
2:35:22/Both men and women came, all who were willing, and brought gold jewelry of all kinds: brooches, earrings, rings, and ornaments. They all presented their gold as a wave offering to the LORD.
2:35:23/Everyone who had blue, purple, or scarlet yarn, fine linen, goats' hair, ram skins dyed red or another type of durable leather brought them.
2:35:24/Those presenting an offering of silver or bronze brought it as an offering to the LORD, and everyone who had acacia wood for any part of the work brought it.
2:35:25/Every skilled woman spun with her hands and brought what she had spun—blue, purple, or scarlet yarn or fine linen.
2:35:26/And all the women whose hearts stirred them to use their skill spun the goats' hair.
2:35:27/The leaders brought onyx stones and other gems to be set in the ephod and the breastplate.
2:35:28/They also brought spices and olive oil for the light, for the anointing oil, and for the fragrant incense.
2:35:29/The Israelites brought a freewill offering to the LORD, every man and woman whose heart made them willing to bring material for all kinds of work, which the LORD, through Moses, had commanded to be done.
2:35:30/Moses said to the Israelites, "See, the LORD has chosen Bezalel son of Uri, the son of Hur, of the tribe of Judah.
2:35:31/He has filled him with the Spirit of God, with wisdom, with understanding, with knowledge, and with all kinds of skills—
2:35:32/to make artistic designs for work in gold, silver, and bronze,
2:35:33/to cut and set stones, to work in wood, and to engage in all kinds of artistic crafts.
2:35:34/And He has given both him and Oholiab son of Ahisamach, of the tribe of Dan, the ability to teach others.
2:35:35/He has filled them with skill to do all kinds of work as engravers, designers, embroiderers in blue, purple, and scarlet yarn and fine linen, and weavers—all of them skilled workers and designers.
2:36:1/Then Bezaleel, Aholiab, and every skilled craftsman, whom the LORD endowed with wisdom and understanding, set to work on all kinds of tasks for the sanctuary service, just as the LORD had instructed.
2:36:2/And Moses summoned Bezaleel, Aholiab, and every skilled craftsman in whose heart the LORD had placed wisdom, everyone who felt compelled to come and do the work.
2:36:3/They received from Moses all the offerings the Israelites had brought for the sanctuary's service. They continued to bring him voluntary offerings every morning.
2:36:4/All the skilled workers who were doing the sanctuary work left their work to come,
2:36:5/And they told Moses, "The people are bringing more than enough for completing the work the LORD commanded us to do."
2:36:6/So Moses issued an order, which was announced throughout the camp: "No man or woman should make anything more as an offering for the sanctuary." Thus, the people were stopped from bringing more.
2:36:7/Because what they already had was more than enough to complete all the work.
2:36:8/Every skilled craftsman among them who worked on the tabernacle made ten curtains of finely twisted linen, and blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, with cherubim skillfully worked into them.
2:36:9/Each curtain was twenty-eight cubits long and four cubits wide, all the curtains were the same size.
2:36:10/He joined five of the curtains together, and did the same with the other five.
2:36:11/He made loops of blue material along the edge of the end curtain in one set, and did the same on the edge of the end curtain in the other set.
2:36:12/He made fifty loops on one curtain and fifty loops on the edge of the curtain in the other set, with the loops opposite each other.
2:36:13/Then he made fifty gold clasps and used them to fasten the curtains to each other, so that the tabernacle was a unified whole.
2:36:14/He made curtains of goat hair for a tent over the tabernacle; he made eleven of these.
2:36:15/Each curtain was thirty cubits long and four cubits wide, all eleven curtains were the same size.
2:36:16/He joined five of the curtains into one set and the other six into another set.
2:36:17/He made fifty loops along the edge of the end curtain in one set and fifty loops along the edge of the end curtain in the other set.
2:36:18/He made fifty bronze clasps to join the tent together into a single unit.
2:36:19/He made a covering for the tent out of ram skins dyed red and another covering of fine leather on top of that.
2:36:20/He made upright frames for the tabernacle out of acacia wood.
2:36:21/Each frame was ten cubits long and one and a half cubits wide.
2:36:22/Each frame had two projections, set parallel to each other; he did this for all the frames of the tabernacle.
2:36:23/He made frames for the tabernacle: twenty frames for the south side,
2:36:24/And he made forty silver bases under the twenty frames; two bases under each frame for its two projections.
2:36:25/For the other side of the tabernacle, the north side, he made twenty frames,
2:36:26/And their forty silver bases; two bases under each frame.
2:36:27/For the west end of the tabernacle, he made six frames.
2:36:28/He made two frames for the corners of the tabernacle at the rear.
2:36:29/They were coupled at the bottom and joined together at the top by a single ring; he did this for both of them at the two corners.
2:36:30/So there were eight frames and sixteen silver bases; two bases under each frame.
2:36:31/He made crossbars of acacia wood; five for the frames on one side of the tabernacle,
2:36:32/Five bars for the frames on the other side of the tabernacle, and five bars for the frames on the west end of the tabernacle.
2:36:33/He made the center bar to run through the frames from one end to the other.
2:36:34/He overlaid the frames with gold and made their rings of gold as holders for the bars, and overlaid the bars with gold.
2:36:35/He made a curtain of blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and finely twisted linen, with cherubim skillfully worked into it.
2:36:36/He made four pillars of acacia wood for it and overlaid them with gold, with their hooks of gold; and he cast four silver bases for them.
2:36:37/He made a curtain for the entrance of the tent, of blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and finely twisted linen, embroidered with needlework,
2:36:38/And five pillars for it with hooks. He overlaid their capitals and bands with gold, but their five bases were made of bronze.
2:37:1/Bezaleel constructed the ark from acacia wood: it was two and a half cubits long, a cubit and a half wide, and a cubit and a half high.
2:37:2/He covered it inside and out with pure gold and crafted a gold crown around it.
2:37:3/He created four gold rings for it, placing them at its four corners; two rings on one side and two on the other.
2:37:4/He made poles from acacia wood and covered them with gold.
2:37:5/He inserted the poles into the rings on the sides of the ark to carry it.
2:37:6/He crafted the mercy seat from pure gold: it was two and a half cubits long and one and a half cubits wide.
2:37:7/He formed two cherubim from gold, hammering them out from a single piece at the two ends of the mercy seat.
2:37:8/One cherub was placed at one end and the other cherub at the opposite end; he made the cherubim at the two ends as part of the mercy seat.
2:37:9/The cherubim spread their wings upward, covering the mercy seat with their wings, facing each other with their faces toward the mercy seat.
2:37:10/He constructed the table from acacia wood: it was two cubits long, a cubit wide, and a cubit and a half high.
2:37:11/He covered it with pure gold and added a gold crown around it.
2:37:12/He also added a border a handbreadth wide around it and placed a gold crown around the border.
2:37:13/He cast four gold rings for it and attached the rings to its four legs.
2:37:14/The rings were placed close to the border as holders for the poles to carry the table.
2:37:15/He made the poles from acacia wood and covered them with gold to carry the table.
2:37:16/He crafted the vessels that were to be placed on the table—his dishes, spoons, bowls, and covers—all out of pure gold.
2:37:17/He made the lampstand from pure gold, hammering out its base, shaft, branches, bowls, buds, and flowers as one piece.
2:37:18/Six branches extended from its sides; three branches from one side and three from the other.
