6:19:47/The territory of the Danites was too small for them, so they went up, fought against Leshem, captured it, struck it with the sword, took possession of it, settled there, and renamed Leshem as Dan, after their ancestor Dan.
6:19:48/This is the inheritance of the Danite tribe according to their families, these cities with their villages.
6:19:49/After they finished dividing the land into inheritances by their boundaries, the Israelites gave an inheritance among them to Joshua son of Nun:
6:19:50/By the LORD's command, they gave him the city he requested, Timnathserah in the hill country of Ephraim. He rebuilt the city and settled there.
6:19:51/These are the inheritances that Eleazar the priest, Joshua son of Nun, and the heads of the families of the Israelite tribes distributed as inheritances by lot in Shiloh before the LORD, at the entrance to the tent of meeting. Thus, they finished dividing the land.
6:20:1/The LORD also spoke to Joshua, saying,
6:20:2/Tell the children of Israel to set aside cities of refuge, as I instructed through Moses.
6:20:3/These cities will be a safe haven for anyone who accidentally kills another person, protecting them from the avenger of blood.
6:20:4/When someone seeking refuge reaches one of these cities, they must explain their situation to the city elders at the gate. The elders will then allow them to enter and live among them.
6:20:5/If the avenger of blood comes after them, the city must not hand over the person, because the killing was accidental and there was no prior hatred.
6:20:6/They can live in that city until they are tried by the congregation and until the high priest of that time dies. After that, they can return to their own city and home, from which they fled.
6:20:7/They designated Kedesh in Galilee in the hills of Naphtali, Shechem in the hills of Ephraim, and Kirjatharba (Hebron) in the hills of Judah.
6:20:8/Beyond the Jordan east of Jericho, they designated Bezer in the wilderness on the plateau from the tribe of Reuben, Ramoth in Gilead from the tribe of Gad, and Golan in Bashan from the tribe of Manasseh.
6:20:9/These cities were set aside for all the children of Israel and for any foreigner living among them, so that anyone who accidentally killed someone could flee there and not be killed by the avenger of blood until they had a trial before the congregation.
6:21:1/Then the leaders of the Levite families approached Eleazar the priest, Joshua son of Nun, and the leaders of the other Israelite tribes;
6:21:2/They spoke to them at Shiloh in Canaan, saying, "The LORD, through Moses, commanded us to be given cities to live in, along with their surrounding pasturelands for our livestock."
6:21:3/So, following the LORD's command, the Israelites gave the Levites these cities and their pasturelands from their own inheritance.
6:21:4/The Kohathite families received their cities by lot. The descendants of Aaron the priest, who were Levites, received thirteen cities from the tribes of Judah, Simeon, and Benjamin.
6:21:5/The other Kohathite families received ten cities by lot from the tribes of Ephraim, Dan, and the half-tribe of Manasseh.
6:21:6/The Gershonite families received thirteen cities by lot from the tribes of Issachar, Asher, Naphtali, and the half-tribe of Manasseh in Bashan.
6:21:7/The Merarite families, by their clans, received twelve cities from the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and Zebulun.
6:21:8/The Israelites allocated these cities and their pasturelands to the Levites by lot, as the LORD had instructed through Moses.
6:21:9/They designated cities from the tribes of Judah and Simeon, specifically naming them.
6:21:10/The descendants of Aaron, from the Kohathite families of the Levites, received the first allotment.
6:21:11/They were given the city of Arba, the ancestor of Anak, which is Hebron, in the hill country of Judah, along with its surrounding pasturelands.
6:21:12/However, the fields and villages around the city were given to Caleb son of Jephunneh as his possession.
6:21:13/So they gave the descendants of Aaron the priest Hebron (a city of refuge for those accused of manslaughter) and its pasturelands, Libnah and its pasturelands,
6:21:14/Jattir and its pasturelands, Eshtemoa and its pasturelands,
6:21:15/Holon and its pasturelands, Debir and its pasturelands,
6:21:16/Ain and its pasturelands, Juttah and its pasturelands, and Beth-shemesh and its pasturelands; nine cities in total from those two tribes.
6:21:17/From the tribe of Benjamin, they received Gibeon and its pasturelands, Geba and its pasturelands,
6:21:18/Anathoth and its pasturelands, and Almon and its pasturelands; four cities in total.
6:21:19/In total, the priests, the descendants of Aaron, received thirteen cities with their pasturelands.
6:21:20/The rest of the Kohathite Levite families received their cities by lot from the tribe of Ephraim.
6:21:21/They were given Shechem (a city of refuge for those accused of manslaughter) and its pasturelands in the hill country of Ephraim, Gezer and its pasturelands,
6:21:22/Kibzaim and its pasturelands, and Beth-horon and its pasturelands; four cities in total.
6:21:23/From the tribe of Dan, they received Eltekeh and its pasturelands, Gibbethon and its pasturelands,
6:21:24/Aijalon and its pasturelands, Gath-rimmon and its pasturelands; four cities in total.
6:21:25/From the half-tribe of Manasseh, they received Taanach and its pasturelands, and Gath-rimmon and its pasturelands; two cities in total.
6:21:26/Altogether, these ten cities and their pasturelands were for the remaining families of the Kohathites.
6:21:27/To the Gershonite families of the Levites, from the half-tribe of Manasseh, they gave Golan in Bashan (a city of refuge for those accused of manslaughter) and its pasturelands, and Beeshterah and its pasturelands; two cities in total.
6:21:28/From the tribe of Issachar, they received Kishion and its pasturelands, Daberath and its pasturelands,
6:21:29/Jarmuth and its pasturelands, En-gannim and its pasturelands; four cities in total.
6:21:30/From the tribe of Asher, they received Mishal and its pasturelands, Abdon and its pasturelands,
6:21:31/Helkath and its pasturelands, and Rehob and its pasturelands; four cities in total.
6:21:32/From the tribe of Naphtali, they received Kedesh in Galilee (a city of refuge for those accused of manslaughter) and its pasturelands, Hammoth-dor and its pasturelands, and Kartan and its pasturelands; three cities in total.
6:21:33/In total, the Gershonite families received thirteen cities with their pasturelands.
6:21:34/To the Merarite families, the rest of the Levites, from the tribe of Zebulun, they gave Jokneam and its pasturelands, Kartah and its pasturelands,
6:21:35/Dimnah and its pasturelands, Nahalal and its pasturelands; four cities in total.
6:21:36/From the tribe of Reuben, they received Bezer and its pasturelands, Jahazah and its pasturelands,
6:21:37/Kedemoth and its pasturelands, and Mephaath and its pasturelands; four cities in total.
6:21:38/From the tribe of Gad, they received Ramoth in Gilead (a city of refuge for those accused of manslaughter) and its pasturelands, Mahanaim and its pasturelands,
6:21:39/Heshbon and its pasturelands, Jazer and its pasturelands; four cities in total.
6:21:40/Thus, the Merarite families, the remaining Levites, received twelve cities by their lot.
6:21:41/In total, the Levites within the Israelite territory received forty-eight cities with their pasturelands.
6:21:42/Each of these cities included their surrounding pasturelands: this was the case for all these cities.
6:21:43/And the LORD gave Israel all the land he had sworn to give their ancestors; they took possession of it and settled there.
6:21:44/The LORD provided them with peace on every side, just as he had sworn to their ancestors. None of their enemies could stand against them; the LORD handed all their enemies over to them.
6:21:45/Not one of all the good promises the LORD had made to the house of Israel failed; everything was fulfilled.
6:22:1/Then Joshua called the Reubenites, and the Gadites, and the half tribe of Manasseh,
6:22:2/And said to them, "You have followed all that Moses, the servant of the LORD, commanded you, and have listened to my instructions in everything I commanded you:
6:22:3/You haven't abandoned your brothers all these days until now, but have fulfilled the command of the LORD your God.
6:22:4/And now the LORD your God has given your brothers rest, as he promised them: so now return, go to your homes, and to the land of your inheritance, which Moses, the servant of the LORD, gave you on the other side of the Jordan.
6:22:5/But be very careful to follow the commandment and the law that Moses, the servant of the LORD, gave you: to love the LORD your God, to walk in all his ways, to obey his commands, to hold fast to him, and to serve him with all your heart and with all your soul."
6:22:6/So Joshua blessed them and sent them away, and they went to their homes.
6:22:7/Now to one half of the tribe of Manasseh, Moses had given land in Bashan, but to the other half, Joshua gave land among their brothers on this side of the Jordan, to the west. And when Joshua sent them away to their homes, he blessed them,
6:22:8/And he said to them, "Return to your homes with great wealth, with a lot of livestock, with silver, gold, bronze, iron, and a lot of clothing: share the spoils of your enemies with your brothers."
6:22:9/And the children of Reuben, the children of Gad, and the half tribe of Manasseh left the children of Israel at Shiloh, which is in the land of Canaan, to go to the land of Gilead, to the land they owned, as they were instructed by the LORD through Moses.
6:22:10/When they reached the regions of the Jordan in the land of Canaan, the children of Reuben, the children of Gad, and the half tribe of Manasseh built an altar by the Jordan, a large altar in appearance.
6:22:11/And the children of Israel heard it said, "Look, the children of Reuben, the children of Gad, and the half tribe of Manasseh have built an altar facing the land of Canaan, in the regions of the Jordan, on the side belonging to the children of Israel."
6:22:12/And when the children of Israel heard this, the whole congregation of the children of Israel gathered at Shiloh to prepare for war against them.
6:22:13/And the children of Israel sent Phinehas, the son of Eleazar the priest, to the children of Reuben, the children of Gad, and the half tribe of Manasseh, in the land of Gilead,
6:22:14/Along with him ten leaders, one leader from each chief family of all the tribes of Israel; each one was a head of their family among the clans of Israel.
6:22:15/And they went to the children of Reuben, the children of Gad, and the half tribe of Manasseh, in the land of Gilead, and spoke with them, saying,
6:22:16/"This is what the entire congregation of the LORD asks: What is this act of betrayal against the God of Israel? Why have you turned away from the LORD today by building yourselves an altar, intending to rebel against the LORD today?
6:22:17/Was the sin of Peor not enough for us, from which we have not yet cleansed ourselves to this day, even though a plague struck the congregation of the LORD,
6:22:18/That you must turn away from following the LORD today? And if you rebel against the LORD today, tomorrow he will be angry with the whole congregation of Israel.
6:22:19/However, if the land of your possession is unclean, then cross over to the land of the LORD's possession, where the LORD's tabernacle stands, and share it among us. But do not rebel against the LORD, nor against us, by building an altar for yourselves besides the altar of the LORD our God.
6:22:20/Did not Achan, the son of Zerah, sin with the devoted thing, and wrath fell on the whole congregation of Israel? And he was not the only one who died for his sin."
6:22:21/Then the children of Reuben, the children of Gad, and the half tribe of Manasseh replied to the leaders of the thousands of Israel,
6:22:22/"The Almighty God, the LORD, the Almighty God, the LORD, he knows, and let Israel itself know; if it was in rebellion or in breach of faith against the LORD, do not spare us today,
6:22:23/If we have built ourselves an altar to turn away from following the LORD, or if to offer burnt offerings or grain offerings on it, or if to make sacrifices of peace offerings on it, let the LORD himself demand an account.
6:22:24/But in fact, we did it out of concern for this reason, thinking, 'In the future, your children might say to our children, "What do you have to do with the LORD, the God of Israel?
6:22:25/For the LORD has made the Jordan a boundary between us and you, you children of Reuben and children of Gad; you have no share in the LORD." So your children might make our children stop fearing the LORD.
6:22:26/Therefore, we said, 'Let us now build an altar, not for burnt offerings nor for sacrifices,
6:22:27/But as a witness between us and you, and our generations after us, that we will perform the service of the LORD in his presence with our burnt offerings, sacrifices, and peace offerings, so your children will not say to our children in the future, "You have no share in the LORD."'
6:22:28/And we thought, if they say this to us or to our generations in the future, then we will say, 'Look at the replica of the LORD's altar, which our ancestors made, not for burnt offerings nor for sacrifices, but as a witness between us and you.'
6:22:29/Absolutely not! We would never rebel against the LORD or turn away from following the LORD by building an altar for burnt offerings, grain offerings, or sacrifices, other than the altar of the LORD our God that stands before his tabernacle."
6:22:30/And when Phinehas the priest, and the leaders of the congregation, the heads of the thousands of Israel who were with him, heard the words that the children of Reuben, the children of Gad, and the children of Manasseh spoke, it was good in their eyes.
6:22:31/And Phinehas, the son of Eleazar the priest, said to the children of Reuben, the children of Gad, and the children of Manasseh, "Today we know that the LORD is among us, because you have not committed this act of treachery against the LORD. Now you have saved the children of Israel from the hand of the LORD."
6:22:32/And Phinehas, the son of Eleazar the priest, and the leaders, returned from the children of Reuben and from the children of Gad, from the land of Gilead to the land of Canaan, to the children of Israel, and brought back word to them.
6:22:33/And the report was good in the eyes of the children of Israel; and the children of Israel blessed God, and did not speak of going up against them in battle to destroy the land where the children of Reuben and Gad lived.
6:22:34/And the children of Reuben and the children of Gad named the altar Witness: "For it is a witness between us that the LORD is God."
6:23:1/After a long time, once the LORD had given Israel peace from all their surrounding enemies, Joshua became very old.
6:23:2/Joshua gathered all of Israel, including the elders, leaders, judges, and officials, and told them, "I am very old now:
6:23:3/You have witnessed everything the LORD your God has done to these nations for your sake; it was the LORD your God who fought for you.
6:23:4/Look, I have allocated these remaining nations to your tribes by lot, as your inheritance, from the Jordan to the great sea in the west, including all the nations I have defeated.
6:23:5/And the LORD your God will push them out before you and remove them from your sight; and you will take over their land, just as the LORD your God promised you.
6:23:6/So be very brave to keep and follow all that is written in the book of the law of Moses, without turning aside from it to the right or to the left;
6:23:7/Do not mingle with these nations that remain among you. Do not invoke the names of their gods or swear by them. Do not serve them or bow down to them.
6:23:8/But stick to the LORD your God, as you have until now.
6:23:9/The LORD has driven out great and powerful nations before you; and no one has been able to withstand you to this day.
6:23:10/A single one of you can make a thousand flee, because the LORD your God fights for you, just as He promised.
6:23:11/So be very careful to love the LORD your God.
6:23:12/If you turn away and cling to the remnants of these nations that remain among you, and if you intermarry with them and associate with them and they with you,
6:23:13/Know for sure that the LORD your God will no longer drive out these nations before you. Instead, they will be traps and snares to you, whips on your backs and thorns in your eyes, until you disappear from this good land the LORD your God has given you.
6:23:14/And remember, today I am following the path all the earth takes. You know with all your heart and soul that not one of the good promises the LORD your God made to you has failed. Every single one has been fulfilled; not one has failed.
6:23:15/Just as all the good things the LORD your God promised you have come to you, so the LORD will bring upon you all the bad things, until He has destroyed you from this good land He has given you.
6:23:16/If you break the covenant of the LORD your God, which He commanded you, and go and serve other gods and bow down to them, then the LORD's anger will burn against you, and you will quickly perish from the good land He has given you.
6:24:1/Joshua gathered all the tribes of Israel at Shechem, calling the elders, leaders, judges, and officials of Israel; they came before God.
6:24:2/Joshua said to all the people, "This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: 'Your ancestors lived beyond the Euphrates River in ancient times, including Terah, the father of Abraham and Nahor, and they worshiped other gods.
6:24:3/I took your ancestor Abraham from beyond the Euphrates and led him through the entire land of Canaan, increasing his descendants and giving him Isaac.
6:24:4/To Isaac, I gave Jacob and Esau. To Esau, I gave the mountains of Seir to possess, but Jacob and his children went down to Egypt.
6:24:5/I sent Moses and Aaron, and I afflicted Egypt with what I did there, and afterward, I brought you out.
6:24:6/I brought your ancestors out of Egypt, and when you reached the sea, the Egyptians chased after your ancestors with chariots and horsemen to the Red Sea.
6:24:7/When they cried out to the LORD, He put darkness between you and the Egyptians, brought the sea over them, and covered them. You saw with your own eyes what I did in Egypt. Then you lived in the wilderness for a long time.
6:24:8/I brought you to the land of the Amorites who lived east of the Jordan. They fought against you, but I gave them into your hands so that you could take possession of their land; I destroyed them before you.
6:24:9/Then Balak son of Zippor, king of Moab, prepared to fight against Israel. He sent for Balaam son of Beor to curse you,
6:24:10/but I refused to listen to Balaam. So he continued to bless you, and I delivered you from his hand.
6:24:11/You crossed the Jordan and came to Jericho. The citizens of Jericho fought against you, as did the Amorites, Perizzites, Canaanites, Hittites, Girgashites, Hivites, and Jebusites, but I gave them into your hands.
6:24:12/I sent the hornet ahead of you, which drove them out before you, not by your sword or bow.
6:24:13/I gave you land you did not toil for, and cities you did not build, and you live in them. You eat from vineyards and olive groves you did not plant.'
6:24:14/Now, fear the LORD and serve Him with all faithfulness. Throw away the gods your ancestors worshiped beyond the Euphrates River and in Egypt, and serve the LORD.
6:24:15/But if serving the LORD seems undesirable to you, then choose today whom you will serve, whether the gods your ancestors served beyond the Euphrates, or the gods of the Amorites, in whose land you are living. But as for me and my household, we will serve the LORD."
6:24:16/The people responded, "Far be it from us to forsake the LORD to serve other gods;
6:24:17/for it is the LORD our God who brought us and our ancestors up out of Egypt, from the land of slavery, and performed those great signs before our eyes. He protected us on our entire journey and among all the nations through which we traveled.
6:24:18/And the LORD drove out before us all the nations, including the Amorites who lived in the land. We too will serve the LORD, for He is our God."
6:24:19/Joshua warned the people, "You may not be able to serve the LORD. He is a holy God; He is a jealous God. He will not forgive your rebellion and your sins.
6:24:20/If you abandon the LORD and serve foreign gods, He will turn and bring disaster on you and make an end of you, after He has been good to you."
6:24:21/But the people said to Joshua, "No, we will serve the LORD."
6:24:22/Joshua said, "You are witnesses against yourselves that you have chosen to serve the LORD." "Yes, we are witnesses," they replied.
6:24:23/"Now then," said Joshua, "throw away the foreign gods that are among you and yield your hearts to the LORD, the God of Israel."
6:24:24/And the people said to Joshua, "We will serve the LORD our God and obey Him."
6:24:25/On that day, Joshua made a covenant for the people, and there at Shechem, he established a statute and ordinance for them.
6:24:26/Joshua recorded these things in the Book of the Law of God. He took a large stone and set it up there under the oak near the holy place of the LORD.
6:24:27/Joshua said to all the people, "See, this stone will be a witness against us. It has heard all the words the LORD has said to us. It will be a witness against you if you are untrue to your God."
6:24:28/Then Joshua dismissed the people, each to their inheritance.
6:24:29/After these events, Joshua son of Nun, the servant of the LORD, died at the age of 110.
6:24:30/They buried him in the land of his inheritance at Timnath Serah in the hill country of Ephraim, north of Mount Gaash.
6:24:31/Israel served the LORD throughout the lifetime of Joshua and of the elders who outlived him and who had experienced all the works of the LORD that He had done for Israel.
6:24:32/The bones of Joseph, which the Israelites had brought up from Egypt, were buried at Shechem in the tract of land that Jacob bought for a hundred pieces of silver from the sons of Hamor, the father of Shechem. This became the inheritance of Joseph's descendants.
6:24:33/Eleazar son of Aaron died and was buried at Gibeah, which had been allotted to his son Phinehas in the hill country of Ephraim.
7:1:1/After Joshua died, the Israelites asked the LORD, "Who should lead us into battle against the Canaanites first?"
7:1:2/The LORD answered, "Judah shall lead. I have given the land into their control."
7:1:3/Then Judah said to his brother Simeon, "Join me in my territory to fight the Canaanites, and I will do the same for you in yours." So Simeon joined him.
7:1:4/Judah attacked, and the LORD helped them defeat ten thousand Canaanites and Perizzites in Bezek.
7:1:5/They encountered Adonibezek in Bezek, fought him, and defeated the Canaanites and Perizzites.
7:1:6/But Adonibezek escaped; they chased him, captured him, and cut off his thumbs and big toes.
7:1:7/Adonibezek said, "Seventy kings with their thumbs and big toes cut off scavenged under my table. As I did, so God has repaid me." They brought him to Jerusalem, where he died.
7:1:8/The people of Judah attacked Jerusalem, captured it, killed its people with the sword, and set the city on fire.
7:1:9/Then the people of Judah fought against the Canaanites living in the hills, the Negev, and the western foothills.
7:1:10/Judah also fought against the Canaanites in Hebron (formerly called Kirjatharba), killing Sheshai, Ahiman, and Talmai.
7:1:11/Next, they went against the people living in Debir (previously Kirjathsepher).
7:1:12/Caleb announced, "Whoever captures Kirjathsepher will get my daughter Achsah as their wife."
7:1:13/Othniel, son of Kenaz and Caleb's younger brother, captured it, so Caleb gave him Achsah as his wife.
7:1:14/When she came to him, she persuaded him to ask her father for a field. She dismounted her donkey, and Caleb asked her, "What do you want?"
7:1:15/She replied, "Please give me a blessing. Since you've given me land in the Negev, also give me springs of water." So Caleb gave her the upper and lower springs.
7:1:16/The descendants of the Kenite, Moses' father-in-law, went up from the City of Palms with the people of Judah into the desert of Judah, located in the Negev near Arad. There, they lived among the people.
7:1:17/Judah joined with Simeon, his brother, and they defeated the Canaanites living in Zephath, completely destroying it. Therefore, it was called Hormah.
7:1:18/Judah also captured Gaza, Ashkelon, and Ekron, along with their territories.
7:1:19/The LORD was with Judah, enabling them to take over the hill country, but they couldn't drive out the people in the plains because they had iron chariots.
7:1:20/As Moses had promised, they gave Hebron to Caleb, who drove out the three sons of Anak from there.
7:1:21/But the tribe of Benjamin didn't drive out the Jebusites who lived in Jerusalem; so the Jebusites live there among the Benjaminites to this day.
7:1:22/The house of Joseph also went up against Bethel, and the LORD was with them.
7:1:23/The house of Joseph sent spies to Bethel (formerly called Luz).
7:1:24/The spies saw a man leaving the city and said to him, "Show us how to get into the city, and we will show you mercy."
7:1:25/When he showed them the way into the city, they struck the city with the sword but let the man and his family go.
7:1:26/The man went to the land of the Hittites, built a city, and named it Luz, which is its name to this day.
7:1:27/Manasseh did not drive out the people of Bethshean, Taanach, Dor, Ibleam, Megiddo, and their surrounding towns, for the Canaanites were determined to stay in that land.
7:1:28/When Israel became strong, they subjected the Canaanites to forced labor but did not completely drive them out.
7:1:29/Ephraim did not drive out the Canaanites living in Gezer; the Canaanites lived among them in Gezer.
7:1:30/Zebulun did not drive out the residents of Kitron or Nahalol; the Canaanites lived among them but were subjected to forced labor.
7:1:31/Asher did not drive out the residents of Accho, Sidon, Ahlab, Achzib, Helbah, Aphik, or Rehob.
7:1:32/So the Asherites lived among the Canaanites, the inhabitants of the land, because they did not drive them out.
7:1:33/Naphtali did not drive out the residents of Bethshemesh or Bethanath. Instead, they lived among the Canaanites, the inhabitants of the land. Nevertheless, the residents of Bethshemesh and Bethanath were forced to work for them.
7:1:34/The Amorites pushed the children of Dan into the mountains, not allowing them to come down into the valley.
7:1:35/However, the Amorites were determined to stay in Mount Heres, Aijalon, and Shaalbim. Yet, when the strength of the house of Joseph increased, they were subjected to forced labor.
7:1:36/The territory of the Amorites extended from the ascent of Akrabbim, from Sela and upward.
7:2:1/An angel of the LORD came from Gilgal to Bochim and said, "I led you out of Egypt and brought you to the land I promised your ancestors; I vowed never to break my covenant with you.
7:2:2/You must not make any agreements with the people of this land; you should destroy their altars. Yet you haven't listened to me: why have you done this?
7:2:3/So I also said, 'I won't drive them out before you; they'll be like thorns in your side, and their gods will trap you.'
7:2:4/When the angel of the LORD said these things to all the Israelites, the people cried out loud.
7:2:5/They named that place Bochim and offered sacrifices there to the LORD.
7:2:6/After Joshua sent the people away, the Israelites went to claim their inheritance and settle in the land.
7:2:7/The people served the LORD throughout Joshua's lifetime and during the lives of the elders who outlived Joshua, who had witnessed all the great deeds the LORD had done for Israel.
7:2:8/Joshua, the son of Nun, the servant of the LORD, died at the age of one hundred and ten.
7:2:9/They buried him within the boundaries of his inheritance in Timnathheres, in the hill country of Ephraim, north of Mount Gaash.
7:2:10/After that whole generation had been gathered to their ancestors, another generation grew up who neither knew the LORD nor what he had done for Israel.
7:2:11/The Israelites did what was evil in the LORD's sight and served the Baals.
7:2:12/They abandoned the LORD, the God of their ancestors, who had brought them out of Egypt. They followed and worshiped various gods of the peoples around them. They provoked the LORD to anger.
7:2:13/They abandoned the LORD and served Baal and the Ashtoreths.
7:2:14/The LORD's anger burned against Israel, and he handed them over to raiders who plundered them. He sold them into the hands of their enemies all around, whom they could no longer withstand.
7:2:15/Wherever they went, the LORD's hand was against them for harm, as the LORD had warned, and as the LORD had sworn to them. They were in great distress.
7:2:16/Yet the LORD raised up judges, who saved them from the hands of these raiders.
7:2:17/But they wouldn't listen to their judges; instead, they prostituted themselves to other gods and worshiped them. They quickly turned from the ways of their ancestors, who had obeyed the LORD's commands; they did not do so.
7:2:18/Whenever the LORD raised up a judge for them, he was with the judge and saved them out of the hands of their enemies as long as the judge lived; for the LORD relented because of their groaning under those who oppressed and afflicted them.
7:2:19/But when the judge died, the people returned to ways even more corrupt than those of their ancestors, following other gods and serving and worshiping them. They refused to give up their evil practices and stubborn ways.
7:2:20/The LORD's anger burned against Israel, and he declared, "Because this nation has violated the covenant I laid down for their ancestors and has not listened to me,
7:2:21/I will no longer drive out before them any of the nations Joshua left when he died.
7:2:22/I will use them to test Israel and see whether they will keep the way of the LORD and walk in it as their ancestors did."
7:2:23/Therefore, the LORD left those nations, not driving them out quickly; he did not give them into Joshua's hand.
7:3:1/These are the nations the LORD left to test Israel, especially those who hadn't experienced the wars in Canaan;
7:3:2/This was so future generations of Israelites could learn about warfare, especially those who had no prior knowledge of it.
7:3:3/Specifically, the five rulers of the Philistines, all the Canaanites, the Sidonians, and the Hivites living in the mountains of Lebanon, from Mount Baalhermon to the entrance of Hamath.
7:3:4/Their purpose was to test Israel, to see if they would follow the LORD's commands, which He had given their ancestors through Moses.
7:3:5/The Israelites lived among the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites.
7:3:6/They married their daughters, gave their own daughters to the sons of these people, and worshiped their gods.
7:3:7/The Israelites did wrong in the eyes of the LORD, forgot the LORD their God, and worshiped the Baals and the Asherah poles.
7:3:8/So the LORD's anger burned against Israel, and He sold them into the hands of Chushanrishathaim, king of Mesopotamia, and the Israelites served Chushanrishathaim for eight years.
7:3:9/But when the Israelites cried out to the LORD, He raised up a deliverer for them, Othniel, the son of Kenaz, Caleb's younger brother, who saved them.
7:3:10/The Spirit of the LORD came upon him, and he led Israel. He went to war, and the LORD gave Chushanrishathaim, king of Mesopotamia, into his hands, so that he overpowered Chushanrishathaim.
7:3:11/And the land had peace for forty years, until Othniel son of Kenaz died.
7:3:12/Again the Israelites did evil in the eyes of the LORD, and the LORD gave Eglon, king of Moab, power over Israel because they had done evil in the eyes of the LORD.
7:3:13/He allied with the Ammonites and Amalekites, attacked Israel, and took possession of the City of Palms.
7:3:14/So the Israelites served Eglon, king of Moab, for eighteen years.
7:3:15/But when the Israelites cried out to the LORD, He raised up for them a deliverer, Ehud, son of Gera, a left-handed Benjamite. The Israelites sent him with a tribute to Eglon, king of Moab.
7:3:16/Ehud made a double-edged sword about a foot and a half long, which he strapped to his right thigh under his clothing.
7:3:17/He presented the tribute to Eglon, king of Moab, who was a very fat man.
7:3:18/After he had presented the tribute, he sent away the people who had carried it.
7:3:19/But he himself turned back at the stone images near Gilgal and said, "I have a secret message for you, O king." The king commanded silence, and all his attendants left him.
7:3:20/Ehud then approached him while he was sitting alone in his upper room in the cool of the day. Ehud said, "I have a message from God for you," and the king rose from his seat.
7:3:21/Ehud reached with his left hand, drew the sword from his right thigh, and plunged it into the king's belly.
7:3:22/The handle sank in after the blade, and his fat closed over the blade, for he did not pull the sword out of his belly; and his bowels emptied.
7:3:23/Then Ehud went out to the porch, shut the doors of the upper room behind him, and locked them.
7:3:24/After he had gone, the servants came and found the doors of the upper room locked. They thought, "He must be relieving himself in the inner room of the cool house."
7:3:25/They waited to the point of embarrassment, but when he did not open the doors of the room, they took a key and unlocked them. There they found their lord dead on the floor.
7:3:26/Ehud escaped while they delayed, passed beyond the stone images, and escaped to Seirath.
7:3:27/Upon arrival, he sounded the trumpet in the hill country of Ephraim, and the Israelites went down with him from the hills, with him leading them.
7:3:28/He said to them, "Follow me, for the LORD has delivered your enemies, the Moabites, into your hands." So they followed him, captured the fords of the Jordan leading to Moab, and allowed no one to cross over.
7:3:29/At that time they struck down about ten thousand Moabites, all strong and able-bodied men; no one escaped.
7:3:30/That day Moab was made subject to Israel, and the land had peace for eighty years.
7:3:31/After him came Shamgar son of Anath, who struck down six hundred Philistines with an ox goad. He too saved Israel.
7:4:1/The Israelites once again did wrong in the eyes of the LORD after Ehud passed away.
7:4:2/So, the LORD allowed them to be conquered by Jabin, the king of Canaan, who ruled in Hazor. His army was led by Sisera, who lived in Harosheth of the Gentiles.
7:4:3/The Israelites cried out to the LORD because Sisera had nine hundred iron chariots and had harshly oppressed the Israelites for twenty years.
7:4:4/At that time, Deborah, a prophetess and the wife of Lapidoth, was leading Israel.
7:4:5/She lived under the palm tree of Deborah between Ramah and Bethel in the hill country of Ephraim, and the Israelites came to her for judgment.
7:4:6/She sent for Barak, the son of Abinoam, from Kedesh in Naphtali, and said to him, "Hasn't the LORD, the God of Israel, commanded you: 'Go, march to Mount Tabor, taking with you ten thousand men from the tribes of Naphtali and Zebulun?'
7:4:7/And I will lead Sisera, the commander of Jabin's army, with his chariots and troops, to the Kishon River and give him into your hands."
7:4:8/Barak said to her, "If you go with me, I will go; but if you don't go with me, I won't go."
7:4:9/She replied, "Certainly, I will go with you. However, the honor of the victory will not be yours, for the LORD will hand Sisera over to a woman." So Deborah went with Barak to Kedesh.
7:4:10/Barak summoned Zebulun and Naphtali to Kedesh, and ten thousand men followed him. Deborah also went with him.
7:4:11/Now Heber the Kenite had separated from the other Kenites, the descendants of Hobab, Moses' brother-in-law, and pitched his tent near the great tree in Zaanaim, close to Kedesh.
7:4:12/They informed Sisera that Barak, the son of Abinoam, had gone up to Mount Tabor.
7:4:13/So Sisera gathered all his nine hundred iron chariots and all the men with him, from Harosheth of the Gentiles to the Kishon River.
7:4:14/Then Deborah said to Barak, "Get ready! This is the day the LORD will give Sisera into your hands. Hasn't the LORD gone ahead of you?" So Barak went down Mount Tabor, with ten thousand men following him.
7:4:15/And the LORD threw Sisera and all his chariots and army into confusion before Barak. Sisera got down from his chariot and fled on foot.
7:4:16/But Barak chased the chariots and the army to Harosheth of the Gentiles, and all Sisera's troops fell by the sword; not a single one was left.
7:4:17/Meanwhile, Sisera fled on foot to the tent of Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite, because there was peace between King Jabin of Hazor and the family of Heber the Kenite.
7:4:18/Jael went out to meet Sisera and said to him, "Come in, my lord, come in with me. Don't be afraid." So he went into her tent, and she covered him with a blanket.
7:4:19/He said to her, "Please give me a little water to drink; I'm thirsty." She opened a container of milk, gave him a drink, and covered him again.
7:4:20/He then told her, "Stand at the entrance of the tent. If anyone comes and asks you, 'Is anyone here?' say 'No.'"
7:4:21/But Jael, Heber's wife, took a tent peg and a hammer, quietly approached him while he was fast asleep and exhausted, and drove the peg through his temple into the ground, and he died.
7:4:22/As Barak pursued Sisera, Jael came out to meet him and said, "Come, and I will show you the man you're looking for." When he went into her tent, there lay Sisera dead, with the tent peg through his temple.
7:4:23/On that day, God subdued Jabin, the Canaanite king, before the Israelites.
7:4:24/And the power of the Israelites continued to grow stronger against Jabin, the Canaanite king, until they destroyed him.
7:5:1/Then Deborah and Barak, the son of Abinoam, sang on that day, saying,
7:5:2/Celebrate the LORD for avenging Israel, when the people freely offered themselves.
7:5:3/Listen up, kings; pay attention, princes; I, yes I, will sing to the LORD; I will sing praises to the LORD, the God of Israel.
7:5:4/LORD, when you left Seir, when you marched from the region of Edom, the earth shook, and the heavens poured down rain, the clouds also released water.
7:5:5/The mountains melted before the LORD, that Sinai in front of the LORD, the God of Israel.
7:5:6/During the days of Shamgar, son of Anath, and during the days of Jael, the main roads were deserted, and travelers took winding paths.
7:5:7/The people in the villages disappeared, they vanished in Israel, until I, Deborah, rose up, until I arose as a mother in Israel.
7:5:8/They chose new gods; then war was at the gates: was a shield or spear seen among forty thousand in Israel?
7:5:9/My heart goes out to the leaders of Israel who offered themselves willingly among the people. Praise the LORD.
7:5:10/Speak, you who ride on white donkeys, you who sit in judgment, and walk by the road.
7:5:11/Those saved from the clash of archers at the watering places, there they will recount the righteous deeds of the LORD, the righteous deeds toward his villagers in Israel: then the people of the LORD will go down to the gates.
7:5:12/Wake up, wake up, Deborah: wake up, wake up, sing a song: arise, Barak, and take your captives, you son of Abinoam.
7:5:13/Then he made the survivors rule over the nobles among the people: the LORD made me rule over the mighty.
7:5:14/From Ephraim came those rooted against Amalek; after you, Benjamin, with your people; from Machir came down leaders, and from Zebulun those who wield the writer's pen.
7:5:15/And the princes of Issachar were with Deborah; as was Issachar, so was Barak: sent into the valley on foot. Among the clans of Reuben there were great deliberations.
7:5:16/Why did you stay among the sheep pens, listening to the flutes for the flocks? Among the clans of Reuben there was much indecision.
7:5:17/Gilead stayed beyond the Jordan: and why did Dan remain with the ships? Asher stayed on the seashore, settling down in his harbors.
7:5:18/Zebulun and Naphtali risked their lives to the death on the high fields.
7:5:19/The kings came and fought, then the kings of Canaan fought at Taanach by the waters of Megiddo; they took no spoils of silver.
7:5:20/They fought from heaven; the stars in their paths fought against Sisera.
7:5:21/The Kishon River swept them away, that ancient river, the Kishon River. Oh my soul, you have trampled down strength.
7:5:22/Then the horse hooves were broken by the galloping, the galloping of their mighty ones.
7:5:23/Curse Meroz, said the angel of the LORD, curse its inhabitants bitterly; because they did not come to the help of the LORD, to the help of the LORD against the mighty.
7:5:24/Blessed above women shall Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite, be, blessed above women in the tent.
7:5:25/He asked for water, and she gave him milk; she offered cream in a noble dish.
7:5:26/She reached for the tent peg, her right hand for the workman's hammer. Then she struck Sisera, she crushed his head, when she pierced and struck through his temples.
7:5:27/At her feet he sank, he fell, he lay still: at her feet he sank, he fell; where he sank, there he fell dead.
7:5:28/Sisera's mother looked out the window, and cried through the lattice, "Why is his chariot so long in coming? Why do the wheels of his chariots delay?"
7:5:29/Her wise ladies answered her, indeed, she answered herself,
7:5:30/"Have they not sped? Have they not divided the plunder; a girl or two for every man; colorful garments as plunder for Sisera, colorful embroidered garments, double-dyed garments for the necks of the plunderers?"
7:5:31/So may all your enemies perish, O LORD: but let those who love him be like the sun when it rises in its strength. And the land had peace for forty years.
7:6:1/The Israelites did wrong in the eyes of the LORD, leading the LORD to hand them over to the Midianites for seven years.
7:6:2/The Midianites overpowered Israel, forcing the Israelites to create hideouts in the mountains, caves, and strongholds due to the threat.
7:6:3/Whenever Israel planted crops, the Midianites, Amalekites, and eastern peoples would attack them.
7:6:4/They camped against the Israelites and ruined the crops all the way to Gaza, leaving no food for Israel, not even sheep, oxen, or donkeys.
7:6:5/They came with their livestock and tents, swarming like locusts in number; they and their camels were too many to count, and they invaded the land to ravage it.
7:6:6/Israel was severely weakened because of the Midianites, and the Israelites cried out to the LORD for help.
7:6:7/When the Israelites cried out to the LORD because of the Midianites,
7:6:8/The LORD sent a prophet to the Israelites, who said, "This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: I brought you up from Egypt and freed you from the land of slavery.
7:6:9/I rescued you from the Egyptians and from all who oppressed you. I drove out your enemies and gave you their land.
7:6:10/I told you, 'I am the LORD your God; do not fear the gods of the Amorites in whose land you live.' But you have not listened to me."
7:6:11/An angel of the LORD came and sat under the oak in Ophrah that belonged to Joash the Abiezrite, where his son Gideon was threshing wheat in a winepress to keep it from the Midianites.
7:6:12/The angel of the LORD appeared to Gideon and said, "The LORD is with you, mighty warrior."
7:6:13/Gideon replied, "Pardon me, my lord, but if the LORD is with us, why has all this happened to us? Where are all his wonders that our ancestors told us about, saying, 'Didn't the LORD bring us up from Egypt?' But now the LORD has abandoned us and given us into the hand of Midian."
7:6:14/The LORD turned to him and said, "Go in the strength you have and save Israel from Midian's hand. Am I not sending you?"
7:6:15/He said to him, "Pardon me, my lord, but how can I save Israel? My clan is the weakest in Manasseh, and I am the least in my family."
7:6:16/The LORD answered, "I will be with you, and you will strike down all the Midianites, leaving none alive."
7:6:17/Gideon replied, "If I have found favor in your eyes, give me a sign that it is really you talking to me.
7:6:18/Please do not leave until I come back and bring my offering and set it before you." And the LORD said, "I will wait until you return."
7:6:19/Gideon went inside, prepared a young goat, and made bread without yeast from an ephah of flour. He put the meat in a basket and the broth in a pot and brought them out under the oak to present to him.
7:6:20/The angel of God said to him, "Take the meat and the unleavened bread, place them on this rock, and pour out the broth." And Gideon did so.
7:6:21/Then the angel of the LORD reached out the tip of the staff in his hand and touched the meat and the unleavened bread. Fire flared from the rock, consuming the meat and the bread. And the angel of the LORD disappeared from his sight.
7:6:22/When Gideon realized that he was the angel of the LORD, he exclaimed, "Alas, Sovereign LORD! I have seen the angel of the LORD face to face!"
7:6:23/But the LORD said to him, "Peace! Do not be afraid. You are not going to die."
7:6:24/So Gideon built an altar to the LORD there and called it The LORD Is Peace. To this day it stands in Ophrah of the Abiezrites.
7:6:25/That same night, the LORD said to him, "Take the second bull from your father's herd, the one seven years old. Tear down your father's altar to Baal and cut down the Asherah pole beside it.
7:6:26/Then build a proper kind of altar to the LORD your God on the top of this height. Using the wood of the Asherah pole that you cut down, offer the second bull as a burnt offering."
7:6:27/So Gideon took ten of his servants and did as the LORD had told him. But because he was afraid of his family and the townspeople, he did it at night rather than in the daytime.
7:6:28/In the morning when the people of the town got up, there was Baal's altar, demolished, with the Asherah pole beside it cut down and the second bull sacrificed on the newly built altar!
7:6:29/They asked each other, "Who did this?" When they carefully investigated, they were told, "Gideon son of Joash did it."
7:6:30/The people of the town demanded of Joash, "Bring out your son. He must die because he has broken down Baal's altar and cut down the Asherah pole beside it."
7:6:31/But Joash replied to the hostile crowd around him, "Are you going to plead Baal's cause? Are you trying to save him? Whoever fights for him shall be put to death by morning! If Baal really is a god, he can defend himself when someone breaks down his altar."
7:6:32/So because Gideon broke down Baal's altar, they gave him the name Jerub-Baal that day, saying, "Let Baal contend with him."
7:6:33/All the Midianites, Amalekites and the eastern peoples joined forces and crossed over the Jordan and camped in the Valley of Jezreel.
7:6:34/Then the Spirit of the LORD came on Gideon, and he blew a trumpet, summoning the Abiezrites to follow him.
7:6:35/He sent messengers throughout all Manasseh, calling them to arms, and also into Asher, Zebulun, and Naphtali, so that they too went up to meet them.
7:6:36/Gideon said to God, "If you will save Israel by my hand as you have promised,
7:6:37/look, I will place a wool fleece on the threshing floor. If there is dew only on the fleece and all the ground is dry, then I will know that you will save Israel by my hand, as you said."
7:6:38/And that is what happened. Gideon rose early the next day; he squeezed the fleece and wrung out the dew—a bowlful of water.
7:6:39/Then Gideon said to God, "Do not be angry with me. Let me make just one more request. Allow me one more test with the fleece, but this time make the fleece dry and let the ground be covered with dew."
7:6:40/That night God did so. Only the fleece was dry; all the ground was covered with dew.
7:7:1/Then Jerubbaal, who is Gideon, and all the people with him, got up early and set up camp beside the well of Harod. The Midianite army was to the north of them, by the hill of Moreh, in the valley.
7:7:2/And the LORD said to Gideon, "You have too many people with you for me to hand the Midianites over to you. Otherwise, Israel might claim they saved themselves by their own strength.
7:7:3/So now, announce to the people, 'Anyone who is scared or afraid should leave and go back from Mount Gilead.'" And 22,000 people left, while 10,000 remained.
7:7:4/Then the LORD said to Gideon, "There are still too many people. Take them down to the water, and I will test them for you there. Whoever I tell you can go with you, will go; and whoever I tell you cannot go, will not go."
7:7:5/So Gideon took the people down to the water. And the LORD told Gideon, "Separate those who lap the water with their tongues like a dog from those who kneel down to drink."
7:7:6/Three hundred men lapped with their hands to their mouths, while the rest knelt down to drink water.
7:7:7/And the LORD said to Gideon, "With the 300 men who lapped the water, I will save you and hand the Midianites over to you. Let all the others go home."
7:7:8/So the people took provisions and their trumpets. Gideon sent all the other Israelites home but kept the 300 men. And the Midianite camp was below him in the valley.
7:7:9/That night, the LORD said to Gideon, "Get up and go down to the camp, because I have given it into your hands.
7:7:10/But if you're afraid to attack, go down to the camp with your servant Phurah
7:7:11/and listen to what they are saying. Afterwards, you will be encouraged to attack." So he and his servant Phurah went down to the outskirts of the enemy camp.
7:7:12/The Midianites, Amalekites, and all the eastern peoples had settled in the valley, thick as locusts. Their camels were as numerous as the sand on the seashore.
7:7:13/When Gideon arrived, he heard a man telling his friend about a dream. He said, "I had a dream where a barley loaf tumbled into the Midianite camp, hit a tent, and it collapsed."
7:7:14/His friend replied, "This can only be the sword of Gideon, son of Joash, the Israelite. God has given Midian and the whole camp into his hands."
7:7:15/When Gideon heard the dream and its interpretation, he bowed in worship. Then he returned to the Israelite camp and said, "Get up! The LORD has given the Midianite camp into our hands."
7:7:16/He divided the 300 men into three groups and gave each man a trumpet and a jar with a torch inside.
7:7:17/Then he said to them, "Watch me and do exactly as I do. When I reach the edge of the camp, do exactly as I do.
7:7:18/When I and all who are with me blow our trumpets, then from all around the camp, blow yours and shout, 'For the LORD and for Gideon.'"
7:7:19/Gideon and the 100 men with him reached the edge of the camp at the beginning of the middle watch, just after they had changed the guard. They blew their trumpets and broke the jars that were in their hands.
7:7:20/The three groups blew their trumpets, smashed their jars, holding the torches in their left hands and the trumpets in their right hands to blow them, and they shouted, "A sword for the LORD and for Gideon!"
7:7:21/They stood in place around the camp while the whole camp ran, shouting and fleeing.
7:7:22/When the 300 trumpets sounded, the LORD caused the men throughout the camp to turn on each other with their swords. The army fled to Beth Shittah towards Zererah, as far as the border of Abel Meholah near Tabbath.
7:7:23/Then the Israelites from Naphtali, Asher, and all Manasseh rallied and chased the Midianites.
7:7:24/Gideon sent messengers throughout all of Mount Ephraim, saying, "Come down against the Midianites and seize the waters of the Jordan ahead of them as far as Beth Barah." So all the men of Ephraim were called out, and they took control of the waters as far as Beth Barah and the Jordan.
7:7:25/They captured two Midianite leaders, Oreb and Zeeb. They killed Oreb at the Rock of Oreb and Zeeb at the Winepress of Zeeb. They pursued Midian and brought the heads of Oreb and Zeeb to Gideon across the Jordan.
7:8:1/The men of Ephraim confronted him, asking, "Why did you treat us this way by not calling us when you went to fight the Midianites?" They argued with him fiercely.
7:8:2/He responded, "What have I accomplished compared to you? Isn't the leftover grapes of Ephraim better than the main harvest of Abiezer?
7:8:3/God has given you the victory over Midian's leaders, Oreb and Zeeb. What could I have done compared to that?" Their anger subsided after he said this.
7:8:4/Gideon and his three hundred men, exhausted yet determined, crossed the Jordan River.
7:8:5/He asked the people of Succoth for bread for his followers, saying, "They are exhausted, and we are chasing Zebah and Zalmunna, the kings of Midian."
7:8:6/The leaders of Succoth questioned, "Do you already have Zebah and Zalmunna in your grasp that we should feed your army?"
7:8:7/Gideon replied, "Once the LORD has given me victory over Zebah and Zalmunna, I will punish you with thorns and briers from the wilderness."
7:8:8/He then went to Penuel and made the same request, but the people of Penuel responded just as those of Succoth had.
7:8:9/To the people of Penuel, he said, "When I return victorious, I will tear down this tower."
7:8:10/Zebah and Zalmunna were in Karkor with their army, about fifteen thousand men, all that remained of the eastern armies, since one hundred and twenty thousand swordsmen had fallen.
7:8:11/Gideon took the route of the tent dwellers east of Nobah and Jogbehah, attacking the unsuspecting army.
7:8:12/When Zebah and Zalmunna fled, he pursued them, captured the two Midianite kings, and defeated their army.
7:8:13/Gideon, son of Joash, returned from battle before dawn,
7:8:14/Captured a young man from Succoth and interrogated him. He provided the names of Succoth's leaders and elders, seventy-seven in total.
7:8:15/He confronted the men of Succoth, saying, "Here are Zebah and Zalmunna, about whom you taunted me, asking if I had captured them to justify feeding my exhausted men."
7:8:16/He took the city's elders, along with wilderness thorns and briers, and used them to teach the men of Succoth a lesson.
7:8:17/He demolished the tower of Penuel and executed the men of the city.
7:8:18/He asked Zebah and Zalmunna, "Describe the men you killed at Tabor." They answered, "They looked like you, each one resembling a prince."
7:8:19/He said, "They were my brothers, my mother's sons. If you had spared them, I would not kill you."
7:8:20/He ordered his eldest son, Jether, to kill them. But the boy hesitated, afraid because he was still young.
7:8:21/Zebah and Zalmunna said, "Do it yourself, for a man's strength is measured by his actions." Gideon then killed Zebah and Zalmunna and took the ornaments from their camels' necks.
7:8:22/The Israelites offered Gideon the rule, saying, "You, your son, and your grandson should rule us because you saved us from Midian."
7:8:23/Gideon replied, "I will not rule over you, nor will my son. The LORD will rule over you."
7:8:24/Gideon asked for a favor, "Give me the earrings from your spoils." (They had golden earrings because they were Ishmaelites.)
7:8:25/They agreed, "We will gladly give them." They spread a garment and each man threw in the earrings he had taken.
7:8:26/The gold earrings he requested weighed one thousand seven hundred shekels, not counting the other ornaments, pendants, purple garments worn by the kings of Midian, and the chains from their camels' necks.
7:8:27/Gideon made an ephod from the gold and placed it in Ophrah, his city. All Israel idolized it there, which became a trap for Gideon and his family.
7:8:28/Midian was subdued before the Israelites and did not raise its head again. The land enjoyed peace for forty years during Gideon's lifetime.
7:8:29/Jerubbaal, son of Joash, lived in his own house.
7:8:30/Gideon fathered seventy sons through his many wives.
7:8:31/His concubine in Shechem also bore him a son, whom he named Abimelech.
7:8:32/Gideon, son of Joash, died at a ripe old age and was buried in the tomb of Joash his father, in Ophrah of the Abiezrites.
7:8:33/After Gideon's death, the Israelites turned back to idolatry, worshipping the Baals and making Baal-Berith their god.
7:8:34/The Israelites forgot the LORD their God, who had saved them from all their enemies surrounding them.
7:8:35/They did not show kindness to Jerubbaal's (Gideon's) family, despite all the good he had done for Israel.
7:9:1/Abimelech, Jerubbaal's son, went to Shechem to his mother's relatives and talked with them and the entire family of his mother's father, saying,
7:9:2/"Please speak to all the men of Shechem. Which is better for you: that all seventy sons of Jerubbaal rule over you or just one? Remember, I am your own flesh and blood."
7:9:3/His mother's relatives spoke about him to all the men of Shechem, and they were inclined to follow Abimelech, saying, "He is our brother."
7:9:4/They gave him seventy pieces of silver from the temple of Baalberith, and Abimelech used it to hire reckless adventurers who followed him.
7:9:5/He went to his father's home in Ophrah and killed his seventy brothers, the sons of Jerubbaal, on one stone. However, Jotham, the youngest son of Jerubbaal, survived because he hid.
7:9:6/Then all the men of Shechem and the house of Millo gathered and made Abimelech king by the oak of the pillar in Shechem.
7:9:7/When they told Jotham, he stood on top of Mount Gerizim, raised his voice, and called out to them, "Listen to me, men of Shechem, so that God may listen to you."
7:9:8/Once, the trees decided to anoint a king over them. They said to the olive tree, 'Be our king.'
7:9:9/But the olive tree replied, 'Should I give up my oil, which honors both gods and humans, to hold sway over the trees?'
7:9:10/Then the trees said to the fig tree, 'Come and be our king.'
7:9:11/But the fig tree answered, 'Should I give up my sweetness and my delicious fruit to hold sway over the trees?'
7:9:12/Next, the trees said to the vine, 'Come and be our king.'
7:9:13/But the vine replied, 'Should I give up my wine, which cheers both gods and humans, to hold sway over the trees?'
7:9:14/Finally, all the trees said to the bramble, 'Come and be our king.'
7:9:15/And the bramble said to the trees, 'If you really want to anoint me king over you, come and take refuge in my shade. But if not, let fire come out of the bramble and consume the cedars of Lebanon.'
7:9:16/Now, if you have acted honestly and sincerely in making Abimelech king, and if you have treated Jerubbaal and his house well, and have repaid him appropriately for his actions;
7:9:17/(Because my father fought for you, risked his life, and rescued you from Midian's hand;
7:9:18/And today you have risen against my father's house, killed his seventy sons on one stone, and made Abimelech, the son of his servant girl, king over the men of Shechem because he is your brother;)
7:9:19/If you have acted with honesty and sincerity towards Jerubbaal and his house today, then rejoice in Abimelech, and let him also rejoice in you.
7:9:20/But if not, let fire come out from Abimelech and consume the men of Shechem and the house of Millo; and let fire come out from the men of Shechem and from the house of Millo, and consume Abimelech.
7:9:21/Then Jotham ran away, fled, and went to Beer, living there out of fear of Abimelech his brother.
7:9:22/When Abimelech had ruled over Israel for three years,
7:9:23/God sent a spirit of discord between Abimelech and the men of Shechem; and the men of Shechem betrayed Abimelech:
7:9:24/This happened so that the violence against the seventy sons of Jerubbaal might come back on Abimelech their brother, who killed them, and on the men of Shechem who helped him kill his brothers.
7:9:25/The men of Shechem set ambushes for him on the mountaintops and robbed everyone who passed by them. This was reported to Abimelech.
7:9:26/Gaal son of Ebed and his brothers arrived in Shechem, and the men of Shechem put their trust in him.
7:9:27/They went out into the fields, harvested their vineyards, trod the grapes, held a festival, and went into the temple of their god to eat, drink, and curse Abimelech.
7:9:28/Gaal son of Ebed said, "Who is Abimelech, and who is Shechem, that we should serve him? Isn't he Jerubbaal's son and Zebul his deputy? Serve the descendants of Hamor, Shechem's father! Why should we serve him?
7:9:29/If only this people were under my command! Then I would remove Abimelech." And he challenged Abimelech, "Increase your army and come out."
7:9:30/When Zebul, the governor of the city, heard the words of Gaal son of Ebed, he was furious.
7:9:31/He sent messengers to Abimelech secretly, saying, "Look, Gaal son of Ebed and his brothers have come to Shechem, and they are inciting the city against you.
7:9:32/Now, move by night with your forces and lie in wait in the fields.
7:9:33/In the morning at sunrise, attack the city. When Gaal and his forces come out against you, do whatever you can to them."
7:9:34/So Abimelech and all his troops set out by night and lay in wait near Shechem in four groups.
7:9:35/When Gaal son of Ebed went out and stood at the entrance of the city gate, Abimelech and his forces rose from their hiding places.
7:9:36/Seeing the people, Gaal said to Zebul, "Look, people are coming down from the mountaintops!" Zebul replied, "You're seeing the shadows of the mountains as if they were men."
7:9:37/Again Gaal spoke, "Look, there are people coming down from the center of the land, and another group is coming from the direction of the diviners' oak."
7:9:38/Then Zebul said to him, "Where is your mouth now, you who said, 'Who is Abimelech that we should serve him?' Aren't these the people you despised? Go out now and fight them."
7:9:39/So Gaal led the men of Shechem out and fought Abimelech.
7:9:40/Abimelech chased him, and Gaal fled before him. Many were wounded, even to the entrance of the gate.
7:9:41/Abimelech stayed in Arumah, and Zebul drove Gaal and his brothers out of Shechem, preventing them from living there.
7:9:42/The next day, the people went out into the fields, and this was reported to Abimelech.
7:9:43/He took his forces, divided them into three groups, and lay in wait in the fields. When he saw the people coming out of the city, he rose against them and attacked.
7:9:44/Abimelech and the group with him charged forward and stood at the entrance of the city gate, while the other two groups attacked all who were in the fields and killed them.
7:9:45/Abimelech fought against the city all day, captured it, killed the people inside, demolished the city, and scattered salt over it.
7:9:46/When all the leaders of the Tower of Shechem heard about this, they entered the stronghold of the temple of El-Berith.
7:9:47/It was reported to Abimelech that all the leaders of the Tower of Shechem were gathered together.
7:9:48/Abimelech and all his men went up Mount Zalmon. He took an axe, cut down a branch, lifted it onto his shoulder, and said to his men, "Quickly do what you have seen me do."
7:9:49/So each of his men also cut down a branch and followed Abimelech. They piled the branches against the stronghold and set it on fire over them. Thus, about a thousand men and women, all the people of the Tower of Shechem, died.
7:9:50/Then Abimelech went to Thebez, camped against it, and captured it.
7:9:51/But there was a strong tower inside the city, and all the men and women—all the people of the city—fled to it. They locked themselves in and climbed to the tower roof.
7:9:52/Abimelech approached the tower to attack it. As he approached the entrance to burn it with fire,
7:9:53/a woman dropped a millstone on Abimelech's head, cracking his skull.
7:9:54/He quickly called to his armor-bearer, "Draw your sword and kill me, so people won't say, 'A woman killed him.'" So his servant ran him through, and he died.
7:9:55/When the Israelites saw that Abimelech was dead, they all went home.
7:9:56/Thus, God repaid Abimelech for the evil he had done to his father by killing his seventy brothers.
7:9:57/And God also made the evil of the men of Shechem fall back on their heads, and the curse of Jotham son of Jerubbaal came upon them.
7:10:1/After Abimelech, Tola, the son of Puah and grandson of Dodo from Issachar, rose to defend Israel. He lived in Shamir in the hills of Ephraim.
7:10:2/He led Israel for twenty-three years, then passed away and was buried in Shamir.
7:10:3/After him, Jair, a Gileadite, took over and led Israel for twenty-two years.
7:10:4/He had thirty sons who rode on thirty young donkeys, and they owned thirty towns, known as Havothjair to this day, located in the land of Gilead.
7:10:5/Jair passed away and was buried in Camon.
7:10:6/The Israelites again did what was evil in the LORD's eyes, worshiping Baalim, Ashtaroth, the gods of Syria, Zidon, Moab, the Ammonites, and the Philistines, abandoning the LORD and not serving him.
7:10:7/The LORD's anger flared against Israel, and he handed them over to the Philistines and the Ammonites.
7:10:8/That year, they severely oppressed the Israelites for eighteen years—all those living east of the Jordan in Gilead, the land of the Amorites.
7:10:9/The Ammonites also crossed the Jordan to wage war against Judah, Benjamin, and the house of Ephraim, causing great distress in Israel.
7:10:10/The Israelites pleaded with the LORD, admitting their sin of forsaking their God and worshiping Baalim.
7:10:11/The LORD reminded the Israelites, "Haven't I rescued you from the Egyptians, Amorites, Ammonites, and Philistines?
7:10:12/The Zidonians, Amalekites, and Maonites also oppressed you, and when you cried out to me, I saved you from their power.
7:10:13/Yet you have abandoned me and worshiped other gods. Therefore, I will not save you again.
7:10:14/Go and cry out to the gods you have chosen; let them save you in your time of trouble."
7:10:15/The Israelites responded to the LORD, "We have sinned. Do whatever you think is best, but please save us today."
7:10:16/They discarded the foreign gods among them and worshiped the LORD, and he was moved by Israel's suffering.
7:10:17/The Ammonites mobilized and set up camp in Gilead. The Israelites gathered and camped at Mizpeh.
7:10:18/The leaders and people of Gilead discussed among themselves, "Who will lead the fight against the Ammonites? He will become the leader of all the people of Gilead."
7:11:1/Now Jephthah the Gileadite was a mighty warrior, and he was the son of a prostitute: and Gilead was Jephthah's father.
7:11:2/And Gilead’s wife had sons for him; and when his wife’s sons grew up, they drove Jephthah away, telling him, "You will not inherit in our father’s house; for you are the son of another woman."
7:11:3/So Jephthah fled from his brothers and lived in the land of Tob: and there, a group of adventurers gathered around Jephthah and followed him.
7:11:4/As time went on, the Ammonites waged war against Israel.
7:11:5/And indeed, when the Ammonites waged war against Israel, the elders of Gilead went to bring Jephthah back from the land of Tob:
7:11:6/And they said to Jephthah, "Come, and be our leader, so we can fight the Ammonites."
7:11:7/And Jephthah said to the elders of Gilead, "Didn’t you despise me and drive me out of my father’s house? Why do you come to me now when you're in trouble?"
7:11:8/And the elders of Gilead said to Jephthah, "That’s why we’re turning back to you now, so you can come with us, fight the Ammonites, and be our leader over all who live in Gilead."
7:11:9/And Jephthah said to the elders of Gilead, "If you bring me back to fight the Ammonites and the LORD gives them to me, will I really be your leader?"
7:11:10/And the elders of Gilead said to Jephthah, "The LORD is our witness; we will do exactly as you say."
7:11:11/Then Jephthah went with the elders of Gilead, and the people made him their leader and commander. And Jephthah repeated all his terms before the LORD in Mizpah.
7:11:12/And Jephthah sent messengers to the king of the Ammonites, saying, "What’s the issue between us that you have come to fight in my land?"
7:11:13/And the king of the Ammonites replied to Jephthah's messengers, "Because Israel took my land when they came up from Egypt, from the Arnon to the Jabbok and to the Jordan. Now give those lands back peacefully."
7:11:14/And Jephthah sent messengers again to the king of the Ammonites:
7:11:15/And said to him, "This is what Jephthah says: Israel did not take the land of Moab or the land of the Ammonites.
7:11:16/But when Israel came up from Egypt, they traveled through the wilderness to the Red Sea and came to Kadesh;
7:11:17/Then Israel sent messengers to the king of Edom, saying, 'Please let us pass through your land.' But the king of Edom wouldn’t listen. They also sent to the king of Moab, but he refused. So Israel stayed in Kadesh.
7:11:18/Then they traveled through the wilderness, skirted the lands of Edom and Moab, arrived on the east side of the land of Moab, and camped on the other side of the Arnon. They did not enter the territory of Moab, for the Arnon was its border.
7:11:19/And Israel sent messengers to Sihon king of the Amorites, king of Heshbon, and Israel said to him, 'Let us pass through your land to our own place.'
7:11:20/But Sihon did not trust Israel to pass through his territory. Instead, Sihon gathered all his people, camped in Jahaz, and fought against Israel.
7:11:21/And the LORD, the God of Israel, delivered Sihon and all his people into Israel’s hands, and they defeated them. So Israel took possession of all the land of the Amorites, who lived in that country.
7:11:22/And they took possession of all the territory of the Amorites, from the Arnon to the Jabbok and from the wilderness to the Jordan.
7:11:23/So now that the LORD, the God of Israel, has driven the Amorites out before his people Israel, should you take their land?
7:11:24/Will you not take what your god Chemosh gives you? Likewise, whatever the LORD our God has given us, we will possess.
7:11:25/Are you any better than Balak son of Zippor, king of Moab? Did he ever quarrel with Israel or fight them?
7:11:26/While Israel lived in Heshbon and its towns, and in Aroer and its towns, and in all the cities along the banks of the Arnon for three hundred years, why didn’t you recover them during that time?
7:11:27/I have not sinned against you, but you are doing me wrong by waging war against me. Let the LORD, the Judge, decide today between the Israelites and the Ammonites."
7:11:28/However, the king of the Ammonites paid no attention to the message Jephthah sent him.
7:11:29/Then the Spirit of the LORD came upon Jephthah, and he crossed Gilead and Manasseh, passed through Mizpah of Gilead, and from there he advanced against the Ammonites.
7:11:30/And Jephthah made a vow to the LORD, saying, "If you will indeed deliver the Ammonites into my hands,
7:11:31/then whatever comes out of the doors of my house to meet me when I return in triumph from the Ammonites will be the LORD’s, and I will offer it up as a burnt offering."
7:11:32/So Jephthah advanced against the Ammonites to fight them, and the LORD gave them into his hands.
7:11:33/He struck them down from Aroer to the vicinity of Minnith—twenty cities—and as far as Abel-keramim. Thus the Ammonites were subdued before the Israelites.
7:11:34/When Jephthah returned to his home in Mizpah, behold, his daughter came out to meet him with tambourines and dances. She was his only child; he had no son or daughter besides her.
7:11:35/And when he saw her, he tore his clothes and said, "Oh no, my daughter! You have brought me down, and you are among those who trouble me. For I have made a vow to the LORD, and I cannot break it."
7:11:36/She said to him, "My father, if you have made a vow to the LORD, do to me according to what has gone out of your mouth, now that the LORD has avenged you on your enemies, the Ammonites."
7:11:37/Then she said to her father, "Let this thing be done for me: Leave me alone for two months, that I may go and wander on the mountains and lament my virginity, I and my friends."
7:11:38/So he said, "Go." And he sent her away for two months. She and her friends went into the mountains and lamented her virginity.
7:11:39/And at the end of two months, she returned to her father, who did to her according to his vow which he had made. And she had never known a man. So it became a tradition in Israel,
7:11:40/That the daughters of Israel went yearly to commemorate the daughter of Jephthah the Gileadite four days in a year.
7:12:1/The men of Ephraim gathered together, headed north, and confronted Jephthah, asking, "Why did you go to fight the Ammonites without calling us to join you? We will burn down your house with you inside."
7:12:2/Jephthah replied, "My people and I were in a serious conflict with the Ammonites; and when I called for your help, you didn't rescue me from their grasp."
7:12:3/Seeing that you didn't come to my aid, I risked my life and went to fight the Ammonites myself, and the LORD gave me victory over them. So why have you come to fight me today?"
7:12:4/Then Jephthah rallied all the men of Gilead and fought against Ephraim. The Gileadites defeated the Ephraimites because they taunted them, calling them refugees from Ephraim living among the Ephraimites and Manassites.
7:12:5/The Gileadites secured the Jordan River crossings before the Ephraimites could escape. Whenever a fleeing Ephraimite asked to cross, the Gileadites would ask if he was an Ephraimite. If he said no,
7:12:6/they would tell him to say "Shibboleth." If he said "Sibboleth," unable to pronounce it correctly, they would seize him and kill him at the Jordan River crossings. At that time, 42,000 Ephraimites were killed.
7:12:7/Jephthah led Israel for six years. Then Jephthah the Gileadite died and was buried in one of the cities of Gilead.
7:12:8/After him, Ibzan of Bethlehem led Israel.
7:12:9/He had thirty sons and thirty daughters. He sent his daughters to marry outside his family and brought in thirty daughters from outside for his sons. He led Israel for seven years.
7:12:10/Then Ibzan died and was buried in Bethlehem.
7:12:11/After him, Elon, a Zebulonite, led Israel and did so for ten years.
7:12:12/Elon the Zebulonite died and was buried in Aijalon in the territory of Zebulun.
7:12:13/After him, Abdon the son of Hillel, a Pirathonite, led Israel.
7:12:14/He had forty sons and thirty grandsons, who rode on seventy donkeys. He led Israel for eight years.
7:12:15/Abdon the son of Hillel the Pirathonite died and was buried in Pirathon in the land of Ephraim, in the hill country of the Amalekites.
7:13:1/The Israelites once again did wrong in the eyes of the LORD; so the LORD handed them over to the Philistines for forty years.
7:13:2/There was a man from Zorah, of the Danite tribe, named Manoah; his wife was unable to have children.
7:13:3/An angel of the LORD appeared to the woman and told her, "You are unable to have children now, but you will become pregnant and give birth to a son.
7:13:4/So be careful, please, not to drink wine or any other alcoholic drink, or eat anything forbidden.
7:13:5/You will become pregnant and have a son whose head must not be shaved because the boy will be a Nazirite, dedicated to God from birth. He will start to save Israel from the Philistines."
7:13:6/The woman went to her husband and said, "A man of God came to me. He looked like an angel, very awe-inspiring. I didn't ask where he was from, and he didn't tell me his name.
7:13:7/But he told me, 'You will become pregnant and have a son. Now, don't drink wine or any alcoholic drink, nor eat anything forbidden, because the boy will be a Nazirite to God from birth until the day he dies.'"
7:13:8/Then Manoah prayed to the LORD, saying, "Oh Lord, please let the man of God you sent come to us again and teach us what to do for the boy who is to be born."
7:13:9/God listened to Manoah, and the angel of God came again to the woman while she was out in the field, but her husband Manoah wasn't with her.
7:13:10/The woman hurried to tell her husband, "He's here! The man who appeared to me the other day!"
7:13:11/Manoah got up and followed his wife. When he came to the man, he asked, "Are you the man who spoke to my wife?" And he said, "I am."
7:13:12/Manoah asked, "When your words come true, what is to be the boy's rule of life, and what is his work?"
7:13:13/The angel of the LORD answered Manoah, "Your wife must do everything I have told her.
7:13:14/She must not eat anything that comes from the grapevine, nor drink wine or other alcoholic drinks, nor eat anything forbidden. She must do everything I have commanded her."
7:13:15/Manoah said to the angel of the LORD, "Please stay with us, and let us prepare a young goat for you."
7:13:16/The angel of the LORD replied to Manoah, "Even if you detain me, I won't eat your food. But if you prepare a burnt offering, offer it to the LORD." (Manoah didn't realize it was an angel of the LORD.)
7:13:17/Then Manoah asked the angel of the LORD, "What is your name, so that we may honor you when your word comes true?"
7:13:18/The angel of the LORD said to him, "Why do you ask my name? It is beyond understanding."
7:13:19/So Manoah took a young goat with a grain offering and offered it on a rock to the LORD. And the angel did an amazing thing while Manoah and his wife watched.
7:13:20/As the flame blazed up from the altar toward heaven, the angel of the LORD ascended in the flame. Seeing this, Manoah and his wife fell with their faces to the ground.
7:13:21/The angel of the LORD did not appear to Manoah and his wife again. Then Manoah realized that he was an angel of the LORD.
7:13:22/Manoah said to his wife, "We are going to die because we have seen God."
7:13:23/But his wife said to him, "If the LORD had intended to kill us, he would not have accepted a burnt offering and grain offering from our hands, nor shown us all these things or now told us this."
7:13:24/The woman gave birth to a son and named him Samson. The boy grew, and the LORD blessed him.
7:13:25/And the Spirit of the LORD began to stir him at times in the camp of Dan between Zorah and Eshtaol.
7:14:1/Samson traveled to Timnath and saw a woman there among the Philistines' daughters.
7:14:2/He returned and told his father and mother, "I've seen a Philistine woman in Timnath; get her for me as my wife."
7:14:3/His parents questioned him, "Isn't there a woman among our own people or among all our kin that you have to marry a Philistine woman?" But Samson insisted, "Get her for me. She's the one I want."
7:14:4/However, his parents didn't realize this was part of the LORD's plan, seeking an opportunity against the Philistines, who were ruling over Israel at that time.
7:14:5/Samson, along with his parents, went down to Timnath. Near the vineyards of Timnath, a young lion attacked him.
7:14:6/The Spirit of the LORD empowered him, and he tore the lion apart with his bare hands as easily as one might tear a young goat. But he didn't tell his parents what he had done.
7:14:7/He continued down and spoke with the woman, and she was right in Samson's eyes.
7:14:8/Later, when he returned to marry her, he turned aside to look at the lion's carcass and found a swarm of bees and honey inside it.
