7:14:9/He scooped out the honey with his hands, eating as he went. He gave some to his parents, but didn't tell them where he had gotten it from the lion's carcass.
7:14:10/Samson's father went down to the woman, and Samson threw a feast there, as was the custom for young men.
7:14:11/When the locals saw him, they brought thirty men to accompany him.
7:14:12/Samson said to them, "Let me propose a riddle. If you can solve it during the seven days of the feast, I'll give you thirty linen garments and thirty sets of clothes."
7:14:13/But if you can't solve it, you must give me thirty linen garments and thirty sets of clothes." They agreed, "Tell us your riddle. Let's hear it."
7:14:14/He said to them, "From the eater came something to eat; from the strong came something sweet." They couldn't solve the riddle in three days.
7:14:15/On the seventh day, they pressured Samson's wife, "Coax your husband into explaining the riddle for us, or we'll burn you and your father's house. Did you invite us here to rob us?"
7:14:16/Samson's wife cried in front of him, "You must hate me! You don't really love me. You've given my people a riddle and haven't explained it to me." He replied, "I haven't even told my parents, why should I explain it to you?"
7:14:17/She cried the whole seven days of the feast. Finally, on the seventh day, he told her because she wouldn't stop nagging him. She then explained the riddle to her people.
7:14:18/Before sunset on the seventh day, the men of the town said to him, "What's sweeter than honey? What's stronger than a lion?" Samson replied, "If you hadn't plowed with my heifer, you wouldn't have solved my riddle."
7:14:19/The Spirit of the LORD came powerfully upon him. He went down to Ashkelon, killed thirty men, took their belongings, and gave their clothes to those who had solved the riddle. Furious, he returned to his father's home.
7:14:20/But Samson's wife was given to one of his companions, who had attended him at the feast.
7:15:1/But after a while, during the wheat harvest, Samson went to visit his wife, bringing a young goat. He said, "I want to go to my wife's room." But her father wouldn't let him enter.
7:15:2/Her father said, "I really thought you completely despised her, so I gave her to your friend. Isn't her younger sister more beautiful? Please, take her instead."
7:15:3/Samson replied, "This time, I'm going to be blameless when I get back at the Philistines, even if it causes them trouble."
7:15:4/Then Samson caught three hundred foxes, tied them tail to tail with torches in between, and set the torches on fire.
7:15:5/After lighting the torches, he released the foxes into the Philistines' grain fields, burning up both the sheaves and the standing grain, as well as the vineyards and olive groves.
7:15:6/When the Philistines asked, "Who did this?" they were told, "Samson, the Timnite's son-in-law, because his wife was given to his friend." So the Philistines went and burned her and her father to death.
7:15:7/Samson said to them, "Since you've done this, I won't stop until I've gotten my revenge on you."
7:15:8/He attacked them fiercely, killing many, and then went to live in a cave in the rock of Etam.
7:15:9/The Philistines then invaded Judah and spread out near Lehi.
7:15:10/The men of Judah asked, "Why have you come against us?" They replied, "We've come to capture Samson, to do to him what he did to us."
7:15:11/Three thousand men from Judah went to the cave in the rock of Etam and said to Samson, "Don't you realize the Philistines rule over us? What have you done to us?" He answered, "I only did to them what they did to me."
7:15:12/They said to him, "We've come to tie you up and hand you over to the Philistines." Samson said, "Swear to me that you won't kill me yourselves."
7:15:13/They assured him, "No, we'll only tie you up and hand you over to them. We won't kill you." So they tied him up with two new ropes and brought him up from the rock.
7:15:14/When he arrived at Lehi, the Philistines came shouting against him. Then the Spirit of the LORD came powerfully upon him, and the ropes on his arms became like charred flax, and the bindings dropped from his hands.
7:15:15/He found a fresh jawbone of a donkey, reached out, took it, and killed a thousand men with it.
7:15:16/Samson said, "With a donkey's jawbone, I've made piles upon piles. With a donkey's jawbone, I've killed a thousand men."
7:15:17/When he finished speaking, he threw away the jawbone and named that place Ramath Lehi.
7:15:18/Feeling very thirsty, he cried out to the LORD, "You've granted this great victory by the hand of your servant. Now, am I to die of thirst and fall into the hands of the uncircumcised?"
7:15:19/But God opened up a hollow place in Lehi, and water flowed out of it. When he drank, his strength returned and he revived. So he named it En Hakkore, which is in Lehi to this day.
7:15:20/And he led Israel during the time of the Philistines for twenty years.
7:16:1/Then Samson went to Gaza, saw a prostitute there, and slept with her.
7:16:2/The people of Gaza were informed, "Samson has come here." They surrounded him and lay in wait for him all night at the city gate, quietly saying, "In the morning, when it's daylight, we'll kill him."
7:16:3/Samson stayed until midnight, then he got up, took hold of the city gate's doors along with the two posts, pulled them up, bar and all, placed them on his shoulders, and carried them to the top of a hill facing Hebron.
7:16:4/Later, he fell in love with a woman in the Sorek Valley named Delilah.
7:16:5/The Philistine rulers came to her and said, "Seduce him to find out where his great strength comes from and how we can overpower him, tie him up, and subdue him. Each of us will give you eleven hundred pieces of silver."
7:16:6/Delilah said to Samson, "Please tell me where your great strength lies and how you could be tied up and subdued."
7:16:7/Samson told her, "If I'm tied up with seven fresh bowstrings that haven't been dried, I'll become weak and be just like any other man."
7:16:8/So the Philistine rulers brought her seven fresh bowstrings that hadn't been dried, and she tied him up with them.
7:16:9/Men were hiding in the room as she called out to him, "The Philistines are upon you, Samson!" But he snapped the bowstrings as easily as a piece of string snaps when it touches fire. So the secret of his strength remained unknown.
7:16:10/Then Delilah said to Samson, "You've made a fool of me and lied to me. Now, please tell me how you can be tied up."
7:16:11/He replied, "If I'm tied up tightly with new ropes that have never been used, I'll become weak and be just like any other man."
7:16:12/So Delilah took new ropes and tied him up with them, then said, "The Philistines are upon you, Samson!" while men were hiding in the room. But he snapped the ropes off his arms like thread.
7:16:13/Delilah then said to Samson, "Until now, you've made a fool of me and lied to me. Tell me how you can be tied up." He said to her, "If you weave the seven braids of my head into the fabric on the loom."
7:16:14/She wove it tightly with the pin and said to him, "The Philistines are upon you, Samson!" He woke from his sleep and pulled up the pin and the loom with the fabric.
7:16:15/She said to him, "How can you say 'I love you' when you don't confide in me? You've made a fool of me three times now and haven't told me where your great strength lies."
7:16:16/When she nagged him day after day with her words and pressed him, he was annoyed to death.
7:16:17/So he revealed everything to her and said, "No razor has ever been used on my head because I've been a Nazirite dedicated to God from my mother's womb. If my head were shaved, my strength would leave me, and I would become weak and be like any other man."
7:16:18/When Delilah realized he had told her everything, she sent for the Philistine rulers, saying, "Come back once more; he has told me everything." So the Philistine rulers returned with the money in their hands.
7:16:19/She lulled him to sleep on her lap, called for someone to shave off the seven braids of his hair, and began to subdue him. And his strength left him.
7:16:20/Then she called, "The Philistines are upon you, Samson!" He woke from his sleep and thought, "I'll go out as before and shake myself free." But he did not know that the LORD had left him.
7:16:21/But the Philistines captured him, gouged out his eyes, and took him down to Gaza. They bound him with bronze shackles, and he was forced to grind grain in the prison.
7:16:22/However, after his hair was cut, it began to grow back.
7:16:23/The Philistine rulers gathered to offer a great sacrifice to Dagon their god and to celebrate, saying, "Our god has delivered Samson, our enemy, into our hands."
7:16:24/When the people saw him, they praised their god, saying, "Our god has delivered our enemy into our hands, the one who laid waste our land and multiplied our slain."
7:16:25/When they were in high spirits, they said, "Bring out Samson to entertain us." So they called Samson out of the prison, and he entertained them. They had him stand between the pillars.
7:16:26/Samson said to the boy holding his hand, "Let me feel the pillars that support the temple, so I can lean against them."
7:16:27/The temple was full of men and women; all the Philistine rulers were there, and on the roof were about three thousand men and women watching Samson perform.
7:16:28/Then Samson prayed to the LORD, "Sovereign LORD, remember me. Please, God, strengthen me just once more, and let me with one blow get revenge on the Philistines for my two eyes."
7:16:29/He grasped the two middle pillars on which the temple stood, bracing himself against them, one with his right hand and the other with his left.
7:16:30/And Samson said, "Let me die with the Philistines." He pushed with all his might, and the temple fell on the rulers and all the people in it. Thus he killed many more when he died than while he lived.
7:16:31/Then his brothers and his father's household came down, took him, brought him back, and buried him between Zorah and Eshtaol in the tomb of Manoah his father. He had led Israel for twenty years.
7:17:1/There was a man from the region of Mount Ephraim, named Micah.
7:17:2/He told his mother, "The 1,100 pieces of silver that were stolen from you, which you cursed and also mentioned to me, I have them; I took them." His mother then blessed him, saying, "May you be blessed by the LORD, my son."
7:17:3/After he returned the 1,100 pieces of silver to his mother, she said, "I had fully dedicated this silver to the LORD on your behalf to create an engraved and a cast idol. Now, I will give it back to you."
7:17:4/Even though he gave the money back to his mother, she took 200 pieces of silver and gave them to a craftsman, who made an engraved and a cast idol out of them, and they were kept in Micah's house.
7:17:5/Micah had a shrine with gods, crafted an ephod and household idols, and appointed one of his sons to be his priest.
7:17:6/During that time, Israel had no king, and everyone did what they thought was right.
7:17:7/There was a young man from Bethlehem in Judah, of the tribe of Judah, who was a Levite and was living there.
7:17:8/This man left the city of Bethlehem in Judah to find a new place to live. He came to Mount Ephraim and to Micah's house while he was traveling.
7:17:9/Micah asked him, "Where are you from?" He replied, "I'm a Levite from Bethlehem in Judah, and I'm looking for a new place to live."
7:17:10/Micah then said to him, "Stay with me, and be a father and a priest to me. I'll pay you ten pieces of silver a year, provide you with clothes, and take care of your food." So the Levite agreed to stay.
7:17:11/The Levite agreed to live with Micah, and he became like one of Micah's own sons.
7:17:12/Micah ordained the Levite, and the young man became his priest and lived in Micah's house.
7:17:13/Then Micah said, "Now I know that the LORD will be good to me, since I have a Levite as my priest."
7:18:1/In those days, Israel had no king, and the Danite tribe was looking for a place to settle since they hadn't received their share of land among the Israelite tribes.
7:18:2/The Danites sent five brave men from their territory, from Zorah and Eshtaol, to scout and explore the land. They instructed them, "Go and explore the land." When they reached the hill country of Ephraim, they stayed at Micah's house.
7:18:3/While near Micah's house, they recognized the voice of the young Levite man and turned to him, asking, "Who brought you here? What are you doing in this place? What do you have here?"
7:18:4/He told them, "Micah has treated me this way, hired me, and I serve as his priest."
7:18:5/They said to him, "Please consult God for us to find out if our journey will be successful."
7:18:6/The priest told them, "Go in peace. The LORD is watching over your journey."
7:18:7/So the five men left and arrived at Laish, where they saw people living in safety, like the Sidonians, peaceful and secure, with no ruler to disgrace them for anything, far from the Sidonians and isolated from other people.
7:18:8/When they returned to Zorah and Eshtaol, their people asked them, "What did you find?"
7:18:9/They replied, "Get ready to attack them! We've seen the land, and it's very good. Why wait? Don't hesitate to go and take over the land.
7:18:10/When you go, you'll find a secure people and a spacious land that God has given into your hands, a place lacking nothing on earth."
7:18:11/Then six hundred men from the Danite family, armed for battle, set out from Zorah and Eshtaol.
7:18:12/They went up and camped near Kirjath Jearim in Judah, which is why the place west of Kirjath Jearim is called Mahaneh Dan to this day.
7:18:13/From there they moved on to the hill country of Ephraim and arrived at Micah's house.
7:18:14/The five men who had scouted the land of Laish told their fellow Danites, "Did you know that in one of these houses there are an ephod, household gods, a carved image, and a cast idol? Now you know what to do."
7:18:15/They turned in that direction and came to the house of the young Levite at Micah's place and greeted him.
7:18:16/The six hundred Danites, armed for battle, stood at the entrance of the gate.
7:18:17/The five scouts went in and took the carved image, the ephod, the household gods, and the cast idol while the priest and the six hundred armed men stood at the entrance of the gate.
7:18:18/When they entered Micah's house and took the carved image, the ephod, the household gods, and the cast idol, the priest asked them, "What are you doing?"
7:18:19/They told him, "Be quiet, put your hand over your mouth, and come with us. Be our father and priest. Isn't it better for you to be a priest for a whole tribe and family in Israel than for just one man's household?"
7:18:20/The priest was delighted, and he took the ephod, the household gods, the carved image, and joined the people.
7:18:21/So they turned and left, putting the children, livestock, and belongings in front of them.
7:18:22/When they were a good distance from Micah's house, the men in the houses near Micah's house gathered together and caught up with the Danites.
7:18:23/They called out to the Danites, who turned around and asked Micah, "What's the matter with you that you've mobilized such a group?"
7:18:24/He replied, "You've taken the gods I made, and the priest, and you've gone away. What do I have left? How can you ask, 'What's the matter with you?'"
7:18:25/The Danites told him, "Don't raise your voice at us, or angry men might attack you, and you and your family could lose your lives."
7:18:26/The Danites continued on their way, and Micah, seeing they were too strong for him, turned back and went home.
7:18:27/They took what Micah had made, along with his priest, and came to Laish, to a peaceful and unsuspecting people. They attacked them with the sword and burned down their city.
7:18:28/There was no one to rescue them because they lived far from Sidon and had no dealings with anyone else. The city was in a valley near Beth Rehob. They rebuilt the city and lived there.
7:18:29/They named the city Dan, after their ancestor Dan, who was born to Israel, though the city was originally called Laish.
7:18:30/The Danites set up the carved image, and Jonathan, son of Gershom, son of Manasseh, and his sons served as priests for the tribe of Dan until the land was captured.
7:18:31/They set up Micah's carved image, and it was worshiped all the time the house of God was in Shiloh.
7:19:1/In those days, when Israel had no king, a Levite living on the outskirts of Mount Ephraim took a concubine from Bethlehem in Judah.
7:19:2/His concubine was unfaithful to him, and she left him to go back to her father's house in Bethlehem in Judah, where she stayed for four months.
7:19:3/The husband then went after her to talk things over and persuade her to return, bringing his servant and two donkeys with him. She took him into her father's house, and when her father saw him, he was happy to meet him.
7:19:4/Her father, the girl's father, convinced him to stay, and he stayed with him for three days, eating, drinking, and lodging there.
7:19:5/On the fourth day, they got up early in the morning, and he prepared to leave. But the girl's father said to his son-in-law, "Strengthen yourself with some food, and then you can go."
7:19:6/So they sat down and ate and drank together. The girl's father said to the man, "Please stay the night and enjoy yourself."
7:19:7/When the man got up to leave, his father-in-law persuaded him, so he stayed another night.
7:19:8/On the fifth day, he got up early to leave, but the girl's father said, "Please refresh yourself." So they delayed until the afternoon, and they both ate.
7:19:9/When the man got up to leave with his concubine and servant, his father-in-law, the girl's father, said, "Look, the day is almost over. Spend the night here; the day is nearly done. Stay and enjoy yourself. Early tomorrow morning, you can get up and be on your way home."
7:19:10/But the man didn't want to stay another night. He got up and left, heading toward Jebus (which is Jerusalem), with his two saddled donkeys and his concubine.
7:19:11/When they were near Jebus and the day was almost gone, the servant suggested to his master, "Let's stop at this Jebusite city and spend the night."
7:19:12/But his master replied, "We won't stop in a foreign city where there are no Israelites. We'll go on to Gibeah."
7:19:13/He added, "Let's try to reach Gibeah or Ramah and spend the night in one of those places."
7:19:14/So they went on their way, and the sun set as they neared Gibeah in Benjamin.
7:19:15/They turned off there to go and spend the night in Gibeah. When he entered the city, he sat down in the open square, but no one took them into their home for the night.
7:19:16/Then an old man came in from his work in the fields at evening. He was from the hill country of Ephraim and was staying in Gibeah, but the people there were from Benjamin.
7:19:17/When he saw the traveler in the town square, the old man asked, "Where are you going? And where do you come from?"
7:19:18/The man answered, "We're traveling from Bethlehem in Judah to the remote areas of the hill country of Ephraim, which is where I'm from. I went to Bethlehem in Judah, and now I'm going to the house of the Lord. But no one has offered to take us in for the night.
7:19:19/We have straw and feed for our donkeys, and bread and wine for me, your servant, the young woman, and the young man with us. We don't need anything."
7:19:20/"You're welcome to stay with me," the old man said. "Let me take care of all your needs. Just don't spend the night in the square."
7:19:21/So he took them into his house and fed their donkeys. After they had washed their feet, they had something to eat and drink.
7:19:22/While they were enjoying themselves, some of the wicked men of the city surrounded the house. They pounded on the door and shouted to the old man who owned the house, "Bring out the man who came to your house so we can have sex with him."
7:19:23/The owner of the house went out to them and said, "No, my friends, don't be so vile. Since this man is my guest, don't do this outrageous thing.
7:19:24/Look, here is my virgin daughter and his concubine. I'll bring them out to you now, and you can use them and do to them whatever you wish. But to this man, do not do such a disgraceful thing."
7:19:25/But the men would not listen to him. So the man took his concubine and sent her outside to them, and they raped her and abused her throughout the night, and at dawn, they let her go.
7:19:26/At daybreak, the woman went back to the house where her master was staying, fell down at the door, and lay there until daylight.
7:19:27/When her master got up in the morning and opened the door of the house and stepped out to continue on his way, there lay his concubine, fallen at the door of the house, with her hands on the threshold.
7:19:28/He said to her, "Get up; let's go." But there was no answer. Then he put her on his donkey, and the man set off for home.
7:19:29/When he reached home, he took a knife, cut up his concubine, limb by limb, into twelve parts, and sent them throughout all the territory of Israel.
7:19:30/Everyone who saw it said, "Such a thing has never been seen or done, not since the Israelites came up out of Egypt. Think about it, consider it, and decide what to do."
7:20:1/Then all the Israelites came out, and the community gathered as one, from Dan to Beersheba, including the land of Gilead, to seek the LORD in Mizpeh.
7:20:2/The leaders of all the people, from all the tribes of Israel, came together in the assembly of God's people, with four hundred thousand infantrymen armed with swords.
7:20:3/(The Benjaminites heard that the Israelites had gone up to Mizpeh.) The Israelites then asked, "How did this terrible thing happen?"
7:20:4/The Levite, the husband of the murdered woman, responded, "I went to Gibeah in Benjamin with my concubine to spend the night.
7:20:5/The men of Gibeah attacked me and surrounded the house at night, intending to kill me. They raped my concubine, and she died.
7:20:6/I took my concubine, cut her into pieces, and sent her throughout the territory of Israel's inheritance because they committed a disgraceful act and folly in Israel.
7:20:7/Look, you are all Israelites; give your advice and decision here."
7:20:8/All the people stood as one, saying, "None of us will go to his tent, nor will any of us return to his house.
7:20:9/But now, this is what we'll do to Gibeah; we'll attack it by drawing lots.
7:20:10/We'll take ten men out of every hundred from all the tribes of Israel, a hundred from a thousand, and a thousand from ten thousand, to gather supplies for the people. That way, they can deal with Gibeah of Benjamin for all the disgrace they have done in Israel."
7:20:11/So all the men of Israel united against the city, bound together as one.
7:20:12/The tribes of Israel sent messengers throughout the tribe of Benjamin, saying, "What is this evil that has occurred among you?
7:20:13/Now, hand over the wicked men in Gibeah so we can execute them and purge the evil from Israel." But the Benjaminites refused to listen to their fellow Israelites.
7:20:14/The Benjaminites came together from their towns to Gibeah to go to battle against the Israelites.
7:20:15/At that time, the Benjaminites from the cities numbered twenty-six thousand swordsmen, in addition to the seven hundred elite troops from Gibeah.
7:20:16/Among all these soldiers were seven hundred select troops who were left-handed, each of whom could sling a stone at a hair and not miss.
7:20:17/The Israelites, excluding Benjamin, mustered four hundred thousand swordsmen, all experienced in battle.
7:20:18/The Israelites went up to Bethel and inquired of God. They asked, "Who of us should go first to fight against the Benjaminites?" The LORD replied, "Judah shall go first."
7:20:19/The Israelites got up in the morning and camped against Gibeah.
7:20:20/The men of Israel went out to battle against Benjamin, and they formed battle lines against them at Gibeah.
7:20:21/The Benjaminites came out of Gibeah and cut down twenty-two thousand Israelites on the battlefield that day.
7:20:22/But the Israelite troops encouraged themselves and again formed the battle line at the same place where they had lined up on the first day.
7:20:23/(The Israelites went up and wept before the LORD until evening, and they asked the LORD, "Should we again engage in battle with our brother Benjamin?" The LORD said, "Attack them.")
7:20:24/So the Israelites approached the Benjaminites on the second day.
7:20:25/Benjamin came out against them from Gibeah the second day and cut down another eighteen thousand Israelites, all armed with swords.
7:20:26/Then all the Israelites, the whole army, went up to Bethel, and they wept, sitting before the LORD. They fasted that day until evening and presented burnt offerings and peace offerings before the LORD.
7:20:27/The Israelites inquired of the LORD (the ark of the covenant of God was there in those days,
7:20:28/and Phinehas, the son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron, served before it in those days), asking, "Should we go out once more to battle against our brother Benjamin, or should we stop?" The LORD answered, "Go, for tomorrow I will give them into your hands."
7:20:29/Israel set an ambush around Gibeah.
7:20:30/The Israelites went up against the Benjaminites on the third day and formed battle lines against Gibeah as before.
7:20:31/The Benjaminites came out to meet the people and were drawn away from the city. They began to strike down some of the people as before, killing about thirty men of Israel on the roads, one of which leads to Bethel and the other to Gibeah through the open country.
7:20:32/The Benjaminites said, "They are defeated before us as in the first battle." But the Israelites said, "Let's flee and draw them away from the city to the roads."
7:20:33/All the men of Israel moved from their positions and lined up at Baal Tamar, while the Israelite ambush rushed out of its place on the west of Gibeah.
7:20:34/Then ten thousand select troops from all Israel advanced against Gibeah, and the battle was intense. But the Benjaminites did not realize that disaster was near.
7:20:35/The LORD defeated Benjamin before Israel, and the Israelites destroyed 25,100 Benjaminites that day, all armed with swords.
7:20:36/So the Benjaminites saw that they were beaten. The Israelites gave ground to the Benjaminites because they relied on the ambush they had set near Gibeah.
7:20:37/The ambush quickly rushed upon Gibeah; they advanced and struck the whole city with the edge of the sword.
7:20:38/The agreed signal between the Israelites and the ambush was to make a great cloud of smoke rise from the city.
7:20:39/When the Israelites retreated in the battle, Benjamin began to strike and kill about thirty Israelites, for they thought, "Surely they are defeated before us as in the first battle."
7:20:40/But when the column of smoke began to rise from the city, the Benjaminites looked behind them and saw the whole city going up in smoke to the sky.
7:20:41/Then the Israelites turned around, and the Benjaminites were terrified because they saw that disaster had come upon them.
7:20:42/Therefore, they turned their backs before the Israelites and fled toward the wilderness, but the battle overtook them, and those who came from the cities were destroying them in their midst.
7:20:43/Thus, they surrounded the Benjaminites, chased them, and easily trampled them down as far as the vicinity of Gibeah on the east.
7:20:44/Eighteen thousand Benjaminites fell, all of them valiant fighters.
7:20:45/They turned and fled toward the wilderness to the rock of Rimmon, and five thousand men were cut down on the highways. Then they were pursued hard to Gidom, and two thousand more were killed.
7:20:46/So that day, twenty-five thousand sword-wielding Benjaminites fell, all of them valiant fighters.
7:20:47/But six hundred men turned and fled into the wilderness to the rock of Rimmon, where they stayed for four months.
7:20:48/The Israelites turned back on the Benjaminites and struck them with the sword, including the men of every city, the animals, and everything else they found. They also set all the cities they came across on fire.
7:21:1/The men of Israel had sworn at Mizpeh, saying, "None of us will give our daughters to the Benjaminites as wives."
7:21:2/And the people went to the house of God, staying there until evening before God, crying loudly and mourning deeply.
7:21:3/They asked, "O LORD, God of Israel, why has this happened in Israel, that today we find one tribe missing from Israel?"
7:21:4/The next day, the people got up early, built an altar, and presented burnt offerings and peace offerings on it.
7:21:5/The Israelites asked, "Who among all the tribes of Israel didn't join the assembly before the LORD?" For they had made a serious oath about anyone who didn't come to the LORD at Mizpeh, saying, "They must be put to death."
7:21:6/The Israelites felt remorse for their brother Benjamin and said, "Today, one tribe has been cut off from Israel."
7:21:7/"What can we do to find wives for the remaining men, since we have sworn by the LORD not to give them our daughters as wives?"
7:21:8/They asked, "Which tribe of Israel didn't come to Mizpeh to join the LORD?" And it turned out that no one from Jabeshgilead had come to the camp for the assembly.
7:21:9/When they counted the people, they found that none of the inhabitants of Jabeshgilead were present.
7:21:10/So the assembly sent 12,000 of their bravest men with the order, "Go and strike the inhabitants of Jabeshgilead with the sword, including the women and children."
7:21:11/"This is what you must do: completely destroy every male and every woman who has slept with a man."
7:21:12/They found among the people of Jabeshgilead 400 young virgins who had not slept with a man, and they brought them to the camp at Shiloh in the land of Canaan.
7:21:13/The whole assembly sent a peaceful message to the Benjaminites at the rock of Rimmon.
7:21:14/At that time, Benjamin returned, and they were given the women of Jabeshgilead who had been spared. But there were not enough women for them.
7:21:15/The people felt sorrow for Benjamin because the LORD had made a gap in the tribes of Israel.
7:21:16/Then the elders of the assembly said, "What can we do to find wives for the remaining men, since the women of Benjamin have been wiped out?"
7:21:17/They said, "The survivors of Benjamin must have heirs so that a tribe is not wiped out from Israel."
7:21:18/However, we cannot give them our daughters as wives, for the Israelites have sworn, 'Cursed be anyone who gives a wife to Benjamin.'"
7:21:19/Then they said, "Look, there is an annual festival of the LORD in Shiloh, which is north of Bethel, east of the road that goes up from Bethel to Shechem, and south of Lebonah."
7:21:20/So they instructed the Benjaminites, "Go and hide in the vineyards.
7:21:21/Watch, and when the daughters of Shiloh come out to join the dances, rush out from the vineyards, each of you grab a wife from the daughters of Shiloh, and go to the land of Benjamin.
7:21:22/If their fathers or brothers come to argue with us, we'll plead with them for your sake, saying, 'Please be kind to them, because we didn't get wives for them during the war, and you didn't give them to them, so you're not at fault.'"
7:21:23/The Benjaminites did this and took wives according to their number from the women who danced, whom they kidnapped. Then they returned to their inheritance, rebuilt the cities, and lived in them.
7:21:24/The Israelites then left there at that time, each to his tribe and family, and they went out from there each to his own inheritance.
7:21:25/In those days, there was no king in Israel; everyone did what was right in their own eyes.
8:1:1/Now it happened during the time when judges ruled, there was a famine in the land. A man from Bethlehem in Judah went to live in Moab with his wife and two sons.
8:1:2/The man's name was Elimelech, his wife's name was Naomi, and his two sons were named Mahlon and Chilion. They were Ephrathites from Bethlehem in Judah. They went to Moab and stayed there.
8:1:3/Elimelech, Naomi's husband, died; and she was left with her two sons.
8:1:4/They married Moabite women; one was named Orpah and the other Ruth. They lived there for about ten years.
8:1:5/Then both Mahlon and Chilion also died, and Naomi was left without her two sons and her husband.
8:1:6/Naomi decided to return from Moab because she heard that the LORD had blessed his people by giving them food.
8:1:7/So she left the place where she was, along with her two daughters-in-law, and they started on the road back to the land of Judah.
8:1:8/Naomi said to her two daughters-in-law, "Go back, each of you, to your mother's home. May the LORD show you kindness, as you have shown kindness to your dead husbands and to me.
8:1:9/May the LORD help you find peace, each of you in the home of another husband." Then she kissed them, and they all cried aloud.
8:1:10/They said to her, "No, we will go back with you to your people."
8:1:11/Naomi replied, "Go back, my daughters. Why would you come with me? Can I still have sons who could become your husbands?
8:1:12/Go back, my daughters, go on your way; I am too old to have a husband. Even if I thought there was hope for me—even if I had a husband tonight and then gave birth to sons—
8:1:13/would you wait for them to grow up? Would you refrain from marrying? No, my daughters; it is much more bitter for me than for you, because the LORD's hand has turned against me."
8:1:14/They cried aloud again. Orpah kissed her mother-in-law goodbye, but Ruth clung to her.
8:1:15/Naomi said, "Look, your sister-in-law is going back to her people and her gods. Go back with her."
8:1:16/But Ruth replied, "Don't urge me to leave you or to turn back from you. Where you go, I will go; where you stay, I will stay. Your people will be my people and your God my God.
8:1:17/Where you die, I will die, and there I will be buried. May the LORD deal with me, be it ever so severely, if anything but death separates you and me."
8:1:18/When Naomi realized that Ruth was determined to go with her, she stopped urging her.
8:1:19/So the two of them continued on their journey until they arrived in Bethlehem. When they arrived, the whole town was stirred because of them, and the women exclaimed, "Can this be Naomi?"
8:1:20/She told them, "Don't call me Naomi, call me Mara, because the Almighty has made my life very bitter.
8:1:21/I went away full, but the LORD has brought me back empty. Why call me Naomi when the LORD has testified against me and the Almighty has brought misfortune upon me?"
8:1:22/So Naomi returned from Moab accompanied by Ruth the Moabite, her daughter-in-law, arriving in Bethlehem as the barley harvest was beginning.
8:2:1/Naomi had a relative on her husband's side, a very wealthy and influential man from Elimelech's family; his name was Boaz.
8:2:2/Ruth the Moabitess said to Naomi, "Let me go to the fields and pick up the leftover grain behind anyone in whose eyes I find favor." Naomi said to her, "Go ahead, my daughter."
8:2:3/So she went out, entered a field, and followed behind the harvesters. As it turned out, she was working in a field belonging to Boaz, who was from Elimelech's family.
8:2:4/Boaz arrived from Bethlehem and greeted the harvesters, "The LORD be with you!" "The LORD bless you!" they answered.
8:2:5/Boaz asked the overseer of his harvesters, "Who does that young woman belong to?"
8:2:6/The overseer replied, "She is the young Moabite woman who came back with Naomi from Moab.
8:2:7/She asked, 'Please let me glean and gather among the sheaves behind the harvesters.' She came into the field and has remained here from morning till now, except for a short rest in the shelter."
8:2:8/Then Boaz said to Ruth, "Listen, my daughter. Don't go to glean in another field and don't go away from here. Stay here with my women workers.
8:2:9/Watch the field where the men are harvesting, and follow along after the women. I have told the men not to lay a hand on you. And whenever you are thirsty, go and get a drink from the water jars the men have filled."
8:2:10/At this, she bowed down with her face to the ground. She asked him, "Why have I found such favor in your eyes that you notice me—a foreigner?"
8:2:11/Boaz replied, "I've been told all about what you have done for your mother-in-law since the death of your husband—how you left your father and mother and your homeland and came to live with a people you did not know before.
8:2:12/May the LORD repay you for what you have done. May you be richly rewarded by the LORD, the God of Israel, under whose wings you have come to take refuge."
8:2:13/Then she said, "I hope I continue to find favor in your eyes, my lord. You have reassured me and spoken kindly to your servant—though I do not have the standing of one of your servants."
8:2:14/At mealtime Boaz said to her, "Come over here. Have some bread and dip it in the wine vinegar." When she sat down with the harvesters, he offered her some roasted grain. She ate all she wanted and had some left over.
8:2:15/As she got up to glean, Boaz gave orders to his men, "Let her gather among the sheaves and don't reprimand her.
8:2:16/Also, pull out some stalks for her from the bundles and leave them for her to pick up, and don't scold her."
8:2:17/So Ruth gleaned in the field until evening. Then she threshed the barley she had gathered, and it amounted to about an ephah.
8:2:18/She carried it back to town, and her mother-in-law saw how much she had gathered. Ruth also brought out and gave her what she had left over after she had eaten enough.
8:2:19/Her mother-in-law asked her, "Where did you glean today? Where did you work? Blessed be the one who took notice of you!" Then Ruth told her mother-in-law about the one at whose place she had been working. "The name of the man I worked with today is Boaz," she said.
8:2:20/Naomi said to her daughter-in-law, "The LORD bless him! He has not stopped showing his kindness to the living and the dead." She added, "That man is our close relative; he is one of our guardian-redeemers."
8:2:21/Then Ruth the Moabitess said, "He even said to me, 'Stay with my workers until they finish harvesting all my crops.'"
8:2:22/Naomi said to Ruth her daughter-in-law, "It's good, my daughter, that you go out with his women, so that others don't bother you in another field."
8:2:23/So she stayed close to the women of Boaz to glean until the barley and wheat harvests were finished. And she lived with her mother-in-law.
8:3:1/Then Naomi, her mother-in-law, said to her, "My daughter, shouldn't I find a place of rest for you, so that things may go well for you?
8:3:2/And now, isn't Boaz, with whose young women you've been, a relative of ours? Look, he's winnowing barley tonight at the threshing floor.
8:3:3/So wash and perfume yourself, and put on your best clothes, then go down to the threshing floor. But don't let the man know you're there until he's finished eating and drinking.
8:3:4/When he lies down, note the place where he's lying. Then go and uncover his feet and lie down. He'll tell you what to do next."
8:3:5/And she replied, "I'll do everything you're telling me."
8:3:6/So she went down to the threshing floor and did everything her mother-in-law had instructed her to do.
8:3:7/After Boaz had eaten and drunk, and he was in good spirits, he went to lie down at the end of the grain pile. Then she came quietly, uncovered his feet, and lay down.
8:3:8/In the middle of the night, the man was startled and turned over, and there was a woman lying at his feet!
8:3:9/He asked, "Who are you?" And she answered, "I'm Ruth, your servant. Spread your cloak over me, since you are a close relative."
8:3:10/He said, "May you be blessed by the LORD, my daughter. You've shown more kindness now than before because you haven't chased after the younger men, whether rich or poor.
8:3:11/Now, my daughter, don't be afraid. I'll do everything you ask, for everyone in town knows you are a woman of noble character.
8:3:12/It's true that I am a close relative, but there is a relative closer than I.
8:3:13/Stay here for the night, and in the morning, if he wants to do his duty as your relative, good; let him do it. But if he doesn't want to do his duty, then as surely as the LORD lives, I will do it. Stay here until morning."
8:3:14/So she lay at his feet until morning, but got up before anyone could recognize another. And he said, "No one must know that a woman came to the threshing floor."
8:3:15/He also said, "Bring me the shawl you're wearing and hold it out." When she did so, he poured six measures of barley into it and placed it on her back. Then she went into the town.
8:3:16/When she came to her mother-in-law, Naomi asked, "How did it go, my daughter?" And she told her everything the man had done for her.
8:3:17/And she said, "He gave me these six measures of barley, saying, 'Don't go back to your mother-in-law empty-handed.'"
8:3:18/Then Naomi said, "Stay put, my daughter, until you find out how things turn out; for the man won't rest until he has settled things today."
8:4:1/Then Boaz went up to the gate and sat down there. Suddenly, the relative Boaz had mentioned came by. Boaz called out to him, "Hey, come over here and sit down." So he came over and sat down.
8:4:2/Boaz gathered ten of the city's elders and said, "Sit down here." And they sat down.
8:4:3/Boaz then said to the relative, "Naomi, who has returned from Moab, is selling a piece of land that belonged to our relative Elimelech.
8:4:4/I thought I should inform you: Buy it in the presence of these townspeople and the elders. If you will redeem it, do so. But if you will not, tell me, so I will know. For no one has the right to redeem it except you, and I am next in line." He replied, "I will redeem it."
8:4:5/Then Boaz said, "On the day you buy the land from Naomi, you also have to buy it from Ruth the Moabite, the widow of the deceased, to maintain the deceased's name on his inheritance."
8:4:6/The relative said, "I cannot redeem it for myself without jeopardizing my own inheritance. Take my right of redemption for yourself; I cannot do it."
8:4:7/In the past in Israel, this was the procedure for redeeming and exchanging property to confirm any transaction: one party would take off his sandal and give it to the other. This was the method of legalizing transactions in Israel.
8:4:8/So the relative said to Boaz, "Buy it yourself," and took off his sandal.
8:4:9/Boaz announced to the elders and all the people, "Today you are witnesses that I have bought from Naomi all that belonged to Elimelech and all that belonged to Chilion and Mahlon.
8:4:10/Also, I have acquired Ruth the Moabite, Mahlon's widow, as my wife, to maintain the deceased's name on his inheritance, so that his name will not disappear from among his family or from the town records. Today you are witnesses."
8:4:11/Then all the people at the gate and the elders said, "We are witnesses. May the LORD make the woman entering your home like Rachel and Leah, who together built up the house of Israel. May you achieve wealth in Ephrathah and become famous in Bethlehem.
8:4:12/May your house be like the house of Perez, whom Tamar bore to Judah, because of the offspring the LORD will give you by this young woman."
8:4:13/So Boaz married Ruth. She became his wife, and when he slept with her, the LORD enabled her to conceive, and she gave birth to a son.
8:4:14/The women said to Naomi, "Praise be to the LORD, who has not left you without a redeemer today. May his name become famous throughout Israel.
8:4:15/He will renew your life and sustain you in your old age. For your daughter-in-law, who loves you and is better to you than seven sons, has given him birth."
8:4:16/Naomi took the child, held him close, and cared for him.
8:4:17/The neighborhood women named him, saying, "A son has been born to Naomi." They named him Obed. He was the father of Jesse, the father of David.
8:4:18/These are the descendants of Perez: Perez fathered Hezron,
8:4:19/Hezron fathered Ram, and Ram fathered Amminadab,
8:4:20/Amminadab fathered Nahshon, and Nahshon fathered Salmon,
8:4:21/Salmon fathered Boaz, and Boaz fathered Obed,
8:4:22/Obed fathered Jesse, and Jesse fathered David.
9:1:1/There was a man from Ramathaimzophim, in the hill country of Ephraim, named Elkanah, son of Jeroham, son of Elihu, son of Tohu, son of Zuph, an Ephrathite.
9:1:2/He had two wives; Hannah was one, and Peninnah was the other. Peninnah had children, but Hannah did not.
9:1:3/This man went up from his city every year to worship and offer sacrifices to the LORD of hosts in Shiloh, where Hophni and Phinehas, the sons of Eli, were priests of the LORD.
9:1:4/When Elkanah made his offerings, he gave portions to Peninnah and all her children.
9:1:5/But he gave a special portion to Hannah because he loved her, even though the LORD had closed her womb.
9:1:6/Hannah's rival would provoke her severely to irritate her, because the LORD had closed her womb.
9:1:7/This happened year after year. Whenever Hannah went up to the house of the LORD, her rival provoked her, so she cried and wouldn't eat.
9:1:8/Then Elkanah, her husband, would say to her, "Hannah, why are you crying? Why don't you eat? Why are you so sad? Aren't I more to you than ten sons?"
9:1:9/After they had eaten and drunk in Shiloh, Hannah stood up. Eli the priest was sitting on a chair by the doorpost of the LORD's temple.
9:1:10/Deeply distressed, she prayed to the LORD and wept bitterly.
9:1:11/She made a vow, saying, "LORD of hosts, if you will look on the misery of your servant and remember me, and not forget your servant but give her a son, then I will dedicate him to the LORD for all the days of his life, and no razor shall touch his head."
9:1:12/As she continued praying before the LORD, Eli observed her mouth.
9:1:13/Hannah was praying silently; her lips moved, but her voice was not heard. Therefore, Eli thought she was drunk.
9:1:14/Eli said to her, "How long will you be drunk? Put away your wine."
9:1:15/But Hannah replied, "No, my lord, I am a woman deeply troubled. I have not drunk wine or strong drink, but I have been pouring out my soul before the LORD.
9:1:16/Do not consider your servant a worthless woman, for I have been speaking out of my great anxiety and vexation."
9:1:17/Then Eli answered, "Go in peace, and may the God of Israel grant your request that you have asked of him."
9:1:18/She said, "May your servant find favor in your eyes." Then she went her way and ate, and her face was no longer sad.
9:1:19/They rose early in the morning and worshiped before the LORD; then they went back to their home at Ramah. Elkanah knew his wife Hannah, and the LORD remembered her.
9:1:20/In due time, Hannah conceived and bore a son, and she named him Samuel, for she said, "I have asked him from the LORD."
9:1:21/Elkanah and his entire household went up to offer to the LORD the yearly sacrifice and fulfill his vow.
9:1:22/But Hannah did not go up, for she said to her husband, "I will not go until the child is weaned, and then I will bring him so he may appear before the LORD and stay there forever."
9:1:23/Elkanah her husband said to her, "Do what seems best to you; wait until you have weaned him. Only may the LORD confirm his word." So the woman stayed and nursed her son until she weaned him.
9:1:24/When she had weaned him, she took him up with her, along with three bulls, one ephah of flour, and a skin of wine, and brought him to the house of the LORD in Shiloh; the child was young.
9:1:25/They slaughtered a bull and brought the child to Eli.
9:1:26/She said, "Pardon me, my lord. As you live, my lord, I am the woman who stood here beside you, praying to the LORD.
9:1:27/For this child I prayed, and the LORD has granted me my petition that I made to him.
9:1:28/Therefore I have dedicated him to the LORD; as long as he lives, he is dedicated to the LORD." And he worshiped the LORD there.
9:2:1/Hannah prayed, saying, "My heart is full of joy in the LORD, my strength is lifted high in the LORD; my mouth boasts over my enemies because I delight in your salvation."
9:2:2/There is no one as holy as the LORD; there is no one besides you; there is no rock like our God.
9:2:3/Stop speaking so proudly; let no arrogance come from your mouth: for the LORD is a God who knows everything, and he weighs all actions.
9:2:4/The bows of the mighty are broken, but those who stumbled are now strong.
9:2:5/Those who were full now work for food; and those who were hungry are now satisfied: so that the barren has given birth to seven; and she who had many children is now weak.
9:2:6/The LORD takes life and gives it; he brings down to the grave and raises up.
9:2:7/The LORD makes poor and makes rich; he brings low and lifts high.
9:2:8/He raises the poor from the dust and lifts the needy from the ash heap; he seats them with princes and has them inherit a throne of honor: for the foundations of the earth belong to the LORD, and he has set the world upon them.
9:2:9/He will protect the feet of his faithful ones, but the wicked will be silenced in darkness; for not by strength does one prevail.
9:2:10/The enemies of the LORD will be shattered; he will thunder against them from heaven: the LORD will judge the ends of the earth; he will give strength to his king and exalt the power of his anointed.
9:2:11/And Elkanah went home to Ramah. And the child served the LORD in the presence of Eli the priest.
9:2:12/Now the sons of Eli were corrupt; they did not know the LORD.
9:2:13/And the priest's custom with the people was that, when anyone offered a sacrifice, the priest's servant would come, while the meat was boiling, with a three-pronged fork in his hand;
9:2:14/And he would thrust it into the pan, or kettle, or cauldron, or pot; whatever the fork brought up the priest would take for himself. This is how they treated all the Israelites who came there to Shiloh.
9:2:15/Also, before they burned the fat, the priest's servant would come and say to the person offering the sacrifice, "Give meat for the priest to roast; he won't accept boiled meat from you, but only raw."
9:2:16/And if the person said to him, "Let them burn the fat first, and then take as much as you want," he would reply, "No, give it now; if you don't, I'll take it by force."
9:2:17/Therefore, the sin of the young men was very great in the eyes of the LORD, for they treated the LORD's offering with contempt.
9:2:18/But Samuel served before the LORD, a boy wearing a linen ephod.
9:2:19/Moreover, his mother made him a little robe and brought it to him each year when she came up with her husband to offer the annual sacrifice.
9:2:20/And Eli would bless Elkanah and his wife, saying, "May the LORD give you children by this woman to take the place of the one she prayed for and gave to the LORD." Then they would go to their own home.
9:2:21/And the LORD was gracious to Hannah; she conceived and gave birth to three sons and two daughters. Meanwhile, the boy Samuel grew up in the presence of the LORD.
9:2:22/Now Eli was very old, and he heard about everything his sons were doing to all Israel and how they slept with the women who served at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
9:2:23/He said to them, "Why do you do such things? I hear from all the people about these wicked deeds of yours.
9:2:24/No, my sons; it is not a good report that I hear spreading among the LORD's people.
9:2:25/If one person sins against another, God may mediate for the offender; but if anyone sins against the LORD, who can intercede for them?" But they did not listen to their father, for it was the LORD's will to put them to death.
9:2:26/And the boy Samuel continued to grow in stature and in favor with the LORD and with people.
9:2:27/A man of God came to Eli and said to him, "This is what the LORD says: 'Did I not clearly reveal myself to your ancestor's family when they were in Egypt under Pharaoh's house?
9:2:28/And did I not choose him out of all the tribes of Israel to be my priest, to go up to my altar, to burn incense, and to wear an ephod in my presence? And did I not give to your ancestor's family all the food offerings presented by the Israelites?
9:2:29/Why do you scorn my sacrifice and offering that I prescribed for my dwelling? Why do you honor your sons more than me by fattening yourselves on the choicest parts of every offering made by my people Israel?'
9:2:30/Therefore the LORD, the God of Israel, declares: 'I promised that your house and your father's house would minister before me forever.' But now the LORD declares: 'Far be it from me! Those who honor me I will honor, but those who despise me will be disdained.
9:2:31/The time is coming when I will cut short your strength and the strength of your father's house, so that there will not be an old man in your family line.
9:2:32/And you will see distress in my dwelling. Despite all the good that I do for Israel, there will never be an old man in your family line.
9:2:33/Yet I will not cut off every man of yours from my altar so that your eyes will fail and your heart will grieve, and all your descendants will die in the prime of life.
9:2:34/And what happens to your two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, will be a sign to you—they will both die on the same day.
9:2:35/I will raise up for myself a faithful priest who will do according to what is in my heart and mind. I will build him a sure house, and he will walk before my anointed one always.
9:2:36/And everyone left in your family line will come and bow down before him for a piece of silver and a loaf of bread and plead, 'Appoint me to some priestly office so I can have food to eat.'"
9:3:1/And the child Samuel served the LORD in the presence of Eli. The word of the LORD was rare in those days; visions were not widespread.
9:3:2/It happened at that time, when Eli was lying down in his place, and his eyesight was beginning to fail so that he could not see;
9:3:3/And before the lamp of God went out in the temple of the LORD, where the ark of God was, and Samuel was lying down to sleep;
9:3:4/That the LORD called Samuel: and he answered, "Here I am."
9:3:5/He ran to Eli and said, "Here I am; you called me." But Eli said, "I did not call; go back to bed." So he went and lay down.
9:3:6/Again, the LORD called, "Samuel." And Samuel got up and went to Eli, and said, "Here I am; you called me." Eli answered, "I did not call, my son; go back to bed."
9:3:7/At this time, Samuel did not yet know the LORD, nor had the word of the LORD been revealed to him.
9:3:8/And the LORD called Samuel a third time. And he got up and went to Eli, and said, "Here I am; you called me." Then Eli realized that the LORD had called the boy.
9:3:9/So Eli told Samuel, "Go, lie down, and if he calls you, say, 'Speak, LORD, for your servant is listening.'" So Samuel went and lay down in his place.
9:3:10/And the LORD came, stood there, and called as before, "Samuel, Samuel." Then Samuel said, "Speak, for your servant is listening."
9:3:11/And the LORD said to Samuel, "Look, I am about to do something in Israel that will make the ears of everyone who hears about it tingle.
9:3:12/On that day I will carry out against Eli everything I have spoken regarding his family, from beginning to end.
9:3:13/For I have told him that I will judge his family forever because of the sin he knew about; his sons blasphemed God, and he did not restrain them.
9:3:14/Therefore, I have sworn to the house of Eli, the guilt of Eli’s house will never be atoned for by sacrifice or offering."
9:3:15/And Samuel lay until morning, then opened the doors of the house of the LORD. And Samuel was afraid to tell Eli the vision.
9:3:16/Then Eli called Samuel and said, "Samuel, my son." He answered, "Here I am."
9:3:17/And he said, "What was it he told you? Please do not hide it from me. May God deal with you, be it ever so severely, if you hide from me anything he told you."
9:3:18/So Samuel told him everything, hiding nothing from him. And Eli said, "It is the LORD; let him do what is good in his eyes."
9:3:19/And Samuel grew, and the LORD was with him, not letting any of his words fall to the ground.
9:3:20/And all Israel from Dan to Beersheba recognized that Samuel was attested as a prophet of the LORD.
9:3:21/And the LORD continued to appear at Shiloh, for the LORD revealed himself to Samuel at Shiloh through the word of the LORD.
9:4:1/Samuel's message reached all of Israel. Israel went to fight the Philistines, setting up camp near Ebenezer, while the Philistines camped at Aphek.
9:4:2/The Philistines prepared for battle against Israel, and when the battle began, Israel was defeated by the Philistines, who killed about four thousand soldiers on the battlefield.
9:4:3/When the people returned to camp, the elders of Israel wondered why the LORD had allowed them to be defeated by the Philistines. They decided to bring the ark of the covenant of the LORD from Shiloh, believing it would save them from their enemies.
9:4:4/So they sent to Shiloh to bring back the ark of the covenant of the LORD Almighty, who is enthroned between the cherubim. Eli's two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, were there with the ark of God's covenant.
9:4:5/When the ark of the LORD's covenant arrived in the camp, all Israel raised such a loud shout that the ground shook.
9:4:6/Hearing the uproar, the Philistines wondered what the loud celebration in the Hebrew camp meant. They soon learned that the ark of the LORD had arrived in the camp.
9:4:7/The Philistines were terrified, thinking a god had come into the Hebrew camp. They said, "Woe to us! Nothing like this has happened before.
9:4:8/"Woe to us! Who will save us from these powerful gods? These are the gods who struck the Egyptians with all sorts of plagues in the wilderness.
9:4:9/"Be strong and act like men, O Philistines, or you'll be slaves to the Hebrews as they have been to you. Be men, and fight!"
9:4:10/The Philistines fought, and Israel was defeated, with every man fleeing to his tent. It was a massive defeat; thirty thousand Israeli foot soldiers were killed.
9:4:11/The ark of God was captured, and Eli's two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, were killed.
9:4:12/A man from the tribe of Benjamin ran from the battlefield to Shiloh, arriving the same day with his clothes torn and dirt on his head as a sign of mourning.
9:4:13/When he arrived, Eli was sitting on his chair by the roadside, anxious about the ark of God. When the man entered the city and reported what had happened, the whole city was in uproar.
9:4:14/When Eli heard the outcry, he asked, "What's the meaning of this commotion?" The man hurried over to Eli to tell him.
9:4:15/Eli was ninety-eight years old and his eyesight had failed so he could not see.
9:4:16/The man told Eli, "I've just come from the battlefield; I fled from it today." Eli asked, "What happened, my son?"
9:4:17/The messenger replied, "Israel fled before the Philistines, and there has been a great slaughter among the people. Your two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, are dead, and the ark of God has been captured."
9:4:18/Upon hearing the news about the ark of God, Eli fell backward off his chair by the side of the gate, broke his neck, and died. He was old and heavy. He had led Israel for forty years.
9:4:19/Phinehas' wife, who was pregnant and close to giving birth, heard the news that the ark of God had been captured and that her father-in-law and husband were dead. She went into labor and gave birth, for her pains came upon her suddenly.
9:4:20/As she was dying, the women attending her said, "Don't be afraid; you have given birth to a son." But she did not respond or pay any attention.
9:4:21/She named the child Ichabod, saying, "The glory has departed from Israel," because the ark of God had been captured and because of her father-in-law and her husband.
9:4:22/She said, "The glory has departed from Israel, for the ark of God has been captured."
9:5:1/The Philistines captured the ark of God and took it from Ebenezer to Ashdod.
9:5:2/When the Philistines captured the ark of God, they brought it into the temple of Dagon and placed it beside Dagon.
9:5:3/When the people of Ashdod got up early the next day, they saw Dagon had fallen face down on the ground before the ark of the LORD. They picked Dagon up and put him back in his place.
9:5:4/But when they got up early the next morning, Dagon had fallen face down on the ground before the ark of the LORD again; this time, Dagon's head and both his hands were broken off, lying on the threshold, leaving only the stump of Dagon.
9:5:5/So, neither the priests of Dagon nor anyone else who enters Dagon's temple in Ashdod steps on the threshold to this day.
9:5:6/But the LORD's hand was heavy on the people of Ashdod; he devastated them and struck them with tumors, affecting Ashdod and its surrounding area.
9:5:7/Seeing this, the people of Ashdod decided that the ark of the God of Israel couldn't stay with them because his hand was harsh on them and on Dagon their god.
9:5:8/So they called together all the rulers of the Philistines and asked, "What should we do with the ark of the God of Israel?" They decided to move the ark of the God of Israel to Gath. And they moved the ark there.
9:5:9/After moving it, the LORD's hand was against the city, causing a very great destruction; he struck the men of the city, both young and old, and they developed tumors in their private parts.
9:5:10/So they sent the ark of God to Ekron. But as soon as the ark of God arrived in Ekron, the people cried out, "They've brought the ark of the God of Israel here to kill us and our people!"
9:5:11/Therefore, they gathered all the rulers of the Philistines and said, "Send the ark of the God of Israel back to its place, so it doesn't kill us and our people." For there was a deadly panic throughout the entire city; the hand of God was very heavy there.
9:5:12/Those who didn't die were afflicted with tumors, and the outcry of the city reached the heavens.
9:6:1/The ark of the LORD was in Philistine territory for seven months.
9:6:2/The Philistines called their priests and fortune-tellers, asking, "What should we do with the ark of the LORD? Tell us how we can send it back to its place."
9:6:3/They replied, "If you're sending the ark of the God of Israel away, don't send it empty-handed. Definitely send a guilt offering with it. Then you'll be healed, and it will be clear why his hand hasn't been lifted from you."
9:6:4/They asked, "What guilt offering should we send back?" The answer was, "Five gold tumors and five gold rats, matching the number of Philistine rulers, because the same plague has struck all of you and your rulers."
9:6:5/So, you should make models of your tumors and rats that are destroying the land, and honor the God of Israel. Maybe then he'll lift his hand off you, your gods, and your land.
9:6:6/Why would you harden your hearts as the Egyptians and Pharaoh did? After he performed wonders among them, didn't they let the people go, and they left?
9:6:7/Now, make a new cart and take two milk cows that have never been yoked. Hitch the cows to the cart but take their calves away from them.
9:6:8/Take the ark of the LORD and place it on the cart. Put the gold objects you're sending as a guilt offering in a box next to it, and send it off so it can go.
9:6:9/Watch and see. If it heads toward Beth Shemesh, to its own territory, then it was he who brought this great disaster upon us. But if not, then we'll know it wasn't his hand that struck us; it was just a coincidence."
9:6:10/The men did as instructed; they took two milk cows, hitched them to the cart, and locked up their calves at home.
9:6:11/They placed the ark of the LORD on the cart, along with the box containing the gold rats and the models of their tumors.
9:6:12/The cows went straight toward Beth Shemesh, staying on the road and mooing all the way, without turning right or left. The Philistine rulers followed them to the border of Beth Shemesh.
9:6:13/The people of Beth Shemesh were harvesting wheat in the valley when they looked up, saw the ark, and were overjoyed.
9:6:14/The cart reached the field of Joshua of Beth Shemesh and stopped near a large rock. They split the wood of the cart and offered the cows as a burnt offering to the LORD.
9:6:15/The Levites took down the ark of the LORD and the box with the gold objects and placed them on the large rock. On that day, the people of Beth Shemesh offered burnt offerings and made sacrifices to the LORD.
9:6:16/When the five Philistine rulers saw this, they returned to Ekron that same day.
9:6:17/These are the gold tumors the Philistines sent as a guilt offering to the LORD: one each for Ashdod, Gaza, Ashkelon, Gath, and Ekron.
9:6:18/And the gold rats matched the number of all Philistine cities under the five rulers, including fortified cities and country villages. The large rock on which they placed the ark of the LORD is still in the field of Joshua of Beth Shemesh to this day.
9:6:19/He struck down some of the men of Beth Shemesh because they looked into the ark of the LORD. He killed seventy men, and the people mourned because the LORD had struck the people with a great slaughter.
9:6:20/The men of Beth Shemesh asked, "Who can stand in the presence of this holy LORD God? And where can it go from here?"
9:6:21/So they sent messengers to the residents of Kiriath Jearim, saying, "The Philistines have returned the ark of the LORD. Come down and take it up to your place."
9:7:1/The people of Kirjathjearim came, retrieved the ark of the LORD, and placed it in Abinadab's house on the hill, dedicating Eleazar, his son, to guard the ark of the LORD.
9:7:2/While the ark stayed in Kirjathjearim, a considerable time passed—twenty years, during which all the people of Israel deeply missed the LORD.
9:7:3/Samuel addressed all the people of Israel, saying, "If you truly return to the LORD with all your hearts, then remove the foreign gods and Ashtaroth from among you, dedicate your hearts to the LORD, and serve him alone: and he will rescue you from the Philistines."
9:7:4/So the Israelites discarded Baalim and Ashtaroth, and devoted themselves to serving only the LORD.
9:7:5/Samuel said, "Bring all of Israel to Mizpeh, and I will pray to the LORD on your behalf."
9:7:6/They came together at Mizpeh, drew water, poured it out before the LORD, fasted that day, and admitted, "We have sinned against the LORD." And Samuel acted as judge for the Israelites in Mizpeh.
9:7:7/When the Philistines learned that the Israelites had assembled at Mizpeh, the Philistine rulers advanced towards Israel. Hearing this, the Israelites were terrified of the Philistines.
9:7:8/The Israelites pleaded with Samuel, "Don't stop crying out to the LORD our God for us, so that he may save us from the Philistines."
9:7:9/Samuel offered a young lamb as a complete burnt offering to the LORD; he cried out to the LORD on behalf of Israel, and the LORD answered him.
9:7:10/As Samuel was presenting the burnt offering, the Philistines approached to attack Israel. But the LORD responded with a loud thunder that day, throwing the Philistines into confusion, and they were defeated by Israel.
9:7:11/The Israelites left Mizpeh, chased the Philistines, and struck them down all the way to Bethcar.
9:7:12/Then Samuel placed a stone between Mizpeh and Shen, naming it Ebenezer, and declared, "Up to this point, the LORD has helped us."
9:7:13/Thus, the Philistines were subdued and did not invade Israel's territory again; the LORD's hand was against the Philistines throughout Samuel's lifetime.
9:7:14/The cities the Philistines had taken from Israel were returned, from Ekron to Gath; Israel reclaimed those territories from the Philistines. There was also peace between Israel and the Amorites.
9:7:15/Samuel served as Israel's judge for the rest of his life.
9:7:16/He traveled annually to Bethel, Gilgal, and Mizpeh, judging Israel in all those places.
9:7:17/He always returned to Ramah, where his home was, and there he also judged Israel and built an altar to the LORD.
9:8:1/When Samuel got old, he appointed his sons as judges over Israel.
9:8:2/His firstborn was named Joel, and his second son was Abiah; they served as judges in Beersheba.
9:8:3/But his sons didn't follow his example. Instead, they were swayed by money, accepted bribes, and twisted justice.
9:8:4/So, all the elders of Israel came together and approached Samuel in Ramah,
9:8:5/They told him, "Look, you're getting old, and your sons aren't following in your footsteps. Now appoint a king to lead us, just like all the other nations have."
9:8:6/But they wanted a king to lead them, which upset Samuel. So he prayed to the LORD about it.
9:8:7/And the LORD told Samuel, "Listen to what the people are saying to you. It's not you they've rejected, but me, from reigning over them."
9:8:8/Just as they've done since I brought them out of Egypt, abandoning me and serving other gods, they're doing the same to you.
9:8:9/So listen to them, but warn them solemnly and explain what the reign of the king who will rule over them will entail."
9:8:10/Samuel relayed all of the LORD's words to the people who were asking him for a king.
9:8:11/He said, "This is how the king who will rule over you will operate: He will take your sons for his chariots and horses, and some will run ahead of his chariots.
9:8:12/He will appoint them as commanders of thousands and commanders of fifties, to plow his ground, harvest his crops, and make his weapons of war and equipment for his chariots.
9:8:13/He will take your daughters to be pastry chefs, cooks, and bakers.
9:8:14/He will seize your fields, vineyards, and olive groves, the best ones, and give them to his officials.
9:8:15/He will take a tenth of your grain and vineyards and give it to his officers and attendants.
9:8:16/He will take your male and female servants, your finest young men, and your donkeys, and put them to his work.
9:8:17/He will take a tenth of your flocks, and you will become his servants.
9:8:18/And when that day comes, you will cry out because of the king you have chosen, but the LORD will not answer you."
9:8:19/But the people refused to listen to Samuel. "No," they said, "we want a king over us.
9:8:20/So we can be like all the other nations, with a king to lead us and to go out before us and fight our battles."
9:8:21/Samuel listened to all the people's words and repeated them to the LORD.
9:8:22/And the LORD said to Samuel, "Listen to them and give them a king." Then Samuel told the Israelites, "Everyone go back to your own town."
9:9:1/There was a man from Benjamin named Kish, the son of Abiel, the son of Zeror, the son of Bechorath, the son of Aphiah, a Benjamite, a man of great strength.
9:9:2/He had a son named Saul, an exceptional young man, and very handsome. Among the people of Israel, there was no one more handsome than he; he stood taller than anyone else from his shoulders up.
9:9:3/Kish, Saul's father, lost his donkeys. So Kish told Saul, "Take one of the servants with you, and go look for the donkeys."
9:9:4/They went through the hill country of Ephraim and the area of Shalisha, but didn't find them. Then they went through the area of Shalim, and they weren't there. They went through the land of Benjamin, but still found no trace of them.
9:9:5/When they reached the land of Zuph, Saul said to his servant with him, "Let's go back, or my father will stop worrying about the donkeys and start worrying about us."
9:9:6/The servant replied, "Look, in this city there's a man of God, highly respected; everything he says comes true. Let's go there now. Maybe he can tell us which way to go."
9:9:7/Then Saul said to his servant, "But if we go, what can we bring the man? The food in our bags is gone, and we don't have a gift to bring to the man of God. What do we have?"
9:9:8/The servant answered Saul again, "Look, I have a quarter of a shekel of silver. I can give that to the man of God to tell us our way."
9:9:9/(Before this in Israel, when someone went to inquire of God, they would say, "Let's go to the seer," because the prophet of today used to be called a seer.)
9:9:10/Then Saul said to his servant, "Good idea; let's go." So they went to the city where the man of God was.
9:9:11/As they were going up the hill to the city, they met some young women going out to draw water and asked them, "Is the seer here?"
9:9:12/They answered, "He is; he's ahead of you. Hurry now, he just came to the city today because the people have a sacrifice at the high place.
9:9:13/As soon as you enter the city, you'll find him before he goes up to the high place to eat. The people won't eat until he arrives, because he blesses the sacrifice; afterward, those who are invited will eat. Go up now; you should find him about this time."
9:9:14/They went up to the city, and as they were entering, they saw Samuel coming toward them on his way to the high place.
9:9:15/The day before Saul arrived, the LORD had revealed to Samuel,
9:9:16/"Tomorrow about this time, I will send you a man from the land of Benjamin. Anoint him leader over my people Israel; he will save my people from the Philistines. I have looked upon my people, for their cry has reached me."
9:9:17/When Samuel saw Saul, the LORD told him, "This is the man I told you about; he will govern my people."
9:9:18/Saul approached Samuel in the gateway and asked, "Please tell me where the seer's house is."
9:9:19/Samuel answered Saul, "I am the seer. Go up ahead of me to the high place, for today you will eat with me, and in the morning I will let you go and will tell you all that is in your heart.
9:9:20/As for the donkeys you lost three days ago, don't worry about them; they have been found. And to whom is all the desire of Israel turned, if not to you and your father's family?"
9:9:21/Saul replied, "Am I not a Benjamite, from the smallest tribe of Israel, and is not my clan the least of all the clans of the tribe of Benjamin? Why then do you say such a thing to me?"
9:9:22/Then Samuel took Saul and his servant, brought them into the hall, and had them sit in the place of honor among the thirty guests.
9:9:23/Samuel said to the cook, "Bring the portion I gave you, the one I told you to set aside."
9:9:24/The cook lifted up the thigh and what was on it and set it before Saul. Samuel said, "Here is what has been kept for you. Eat, because it was set aside for you for this occasion, from the time I said, 'I have invited the people.'" So Saul ate with Samuel that day.
9:9:25/After they came down from the high place into the city, Samuel talked with Saul on the roof of his house.
9:9:26/They got up early the next morning, and just before dawn, Samuel called to Saul on the roof, "Get up, so I can send you on your way." Saul got up, and both he and Samuel went outside together.
9:9:27/As they were going down to the edge of the city, Samuel said to Saul, "Tell the servant to go ahead of us" (and the servant did so), "but you stay here for a while, so I can give you a message from God."
9:10:1/Then Samuel took a vial of oil, and poured it on his head, and kissed him, and said, "Isn't it because the LORD has chosen you to be the leader over his people?"
9:10:2/When you leave me today, you'll find two men near Rachel’s tomb at the border of Benjamin in Zelzah; they will tell you, 'The donkeys you were looking for have been found. And now, your father has stopped worrying about them and is anxious about you, wondering, "What should I do about my son?"'
9:10:3/Next, you'll move on from there and reach the plain of Tabor, where you'll meet three men going up to worship God in Bethel. One will be carrying three young goats, another three loaves of bread, and another a skin of wine.
9:10:4/They will greet you and give you two loaves of bread, which you should accept from them.
9:10:5/After that, you'll arrive at the hill of God, where the Philistine outpost is. When you get to the city, you'll encounter a group of prophets coming down from the worship place with musical instruments—a lyre, a tambourine, flutes, and a harp—playing before them, and they will be prophesying.
9:10:6/Then the Spirit of the LORD will rush upon you, and you'll prophesy with them, becoming a different person.
9:10:7/When these signs happen to you, do whatever the situation requires because God is with you.
9:10:8/You must go ahead of me to Gilgal; I will come down to you to offer burnt offerings and to present peace offerings. Wait seven days until I come to you and tell you what you should do."
9:10:9/And it happened that as soon as he turned his back to leave Samuel, God changed his heart, and all those signs occurred that day.
9:10:10/When they arrived at the hill, a group of prophets met him; the Spirit of God came powerfully upon him, and he prophesied among them.
9:10:11/When everyone who had known him previously saw him prophesying with the prophets, the people asked each other, "What has happened to the son of Kish? Is Saul also among the prophets?"
9:10:12/Someone from there answered, "And who is their father?" Thus, it became a saying, "Is Saul also among the prophets?"
9:10:13/After he finished prophesying, he went to the worship place.
9:10:14/Saul’s uncle asked him and his servant, "Where have you been?" And he said, "Looking for the donkeys. When we saw they were not to be found, we went to Samuel."
9:10:15/Saul’s uncle said, "Please tell me, what did Samuel say to you?"
9:10:16/Saul replied to his uncle, "He assured us that the donkeys had been found." But he did not mention anything about the kingship that Samuel had talked about.
9:10:17/And Samuel summoned the people to the LORD at Mizpah;
9:10:18/And he said to the Israelites, "This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: 'I brought Israel up from Egypt, and I delivered you from the power of the Egyptians and from all the kingdoms that oppressed you.'"
9:10:19/"But today you have rejected your God, who saves you from all your troubles and distresses. And you have said, 'No, appoint a king over us.' Now, present yourselves before the LORD by your tribes and clans."
9:10:20/When Samuel had all Israel come forward by tribes, the tribe of Benjamin was chosen.
9:10:21/Then he brought forward the tribe of Benjamin by its clans, and the Matrite clan was chosen. Finally, Saul son of Kish was chosen. But when they looked for him, he was not to be found.
9:10:22/So they inquired further of the LORD, "Has the man come here yet?" And the LORD said, "Yes, he has hidden himself among the supplies."
9:10:23/They ran and brought him out, and as he stood among the people, he was taller than any of the others from his shoulders upward.
9:10:24/And Samuel said to all the people, "Do you see the one the LORD has chosen? There is no one like him among all the people." And all the people shouted, "Long live the king!"
9:10:25/Then Samuel explained to the people the rights and duties of kingship. He wrote them down on a scroll and placed it before the LORD. Then Samuel dismissed the people, each to their own home.
9:10:26/Saul also went to his home in Gibeah, accompanied by warriors whose hearts God had touched.
9:10:27/But some troublemakers said, "How can this man save us?" They looked down on him and did not bring him gifts. But Saul kept silent.
9:11:1/Then Nahash the Ammonite advanced and set up camp against Jabeshgilead. All the men of Jabesh spoke to Nahash, saying, "Make a treaty with us, and we will serve you."
