9:11:2/Nahash the Ammonite replied, "I'll make a treaty with you on one condition: that I gouge out all your right eyes as a disgrace to all of Israel."
9:11:3/The elders of Jabesh responded, "Give us seven days to seek help from all over Israel. If no one comes to our rescue, we will surrender to you."
9:11:4/Then the messengers arrived in Gibeah of Saul and shared the news with the people, who all began to cry loudly.
9:11:5/And when Saul returned from the fields and saw the people crying, he asked, "What's wrong with everyone?" They told him about the situation in Jabesh.
9:11:6/Upon hearing this, the Spirit of God came powerfully upon Saul, and he became very angry.
9:11:7/He took a pair of oxen, cut them into pieces, and sent the pieces throughout Israel with messengers who said, "Anyone who does not follow Saul and Samuel will have their oxen treated the same way." Fear of the LORD fell on the people, and they united as one.
9:11:8/When he counted them at Bezek, there were 300,000 from Israel and 30,000 from Judah.
9:11:9/They told the messengers to say to the men of Jabeshgilead, "By tomorrow, when the sun is hot, you will be rescued." The messengers relayed this, and the men of Jabesh were overjoyed.
9:11:10/So the men of Jabesh said, "Tomorrow we will surrender to you, and you can do to us whatever you think is best."
9:11:11/The next day, Saul divided his forces into three groups; they attacked the Ammonite camp during the early morning and fought until the day grew hot. The survivors were scattered, with no two left together.
9:11:12/Afterward, the people asked Samuel, "Who doubted that Saul should be king? Bring them out so we can kill them."
9:11:13/But Saul said, "No one will be killed today, because today the LORD has saved Israel."
9:11:14/Then Samuel said to the people, "Let's go to Gilgal and reaffirm the kingship."
9:11:15/Everyone went to Gilgal, and there they made Saul king before the LORD. They offered peace offerings to the LORD, and Saul and all the Israelites celebrated greatly.
9:12:1/And Samuel said to all Israel, "Listen, I have listened to everything you said to me and have appointed a king over you.
9:12:2/And now, here is the king leading you. I am old and gray, and my sons are here with you. I have served you from my youth until this day.
9:12:3/Here I am, testify against me before the LORD and his anointed: whose ox have I taken? Whose donkey have I taken? Whom have I cheated? Whom have I oppressed? Or from whom have I accepted a bribe to turn a blind eye? If so, I will make it right."
9:12:4/And they said, "You have not cheated us, nor oppressed us, nor taken anything from anyone's hand."
9:12:5/And he said to them, "The LORD is witness against you, and his anointed is witness today, that you have found nothing in my hand." And they said, "He is witness."
9:12:6/And Samuel said to the people, "It is the LORD who appointed Moses and Aaron and brought your ancestors up from the land of Egypt.
9:12:7/Now then, stand still so I can remind you before the LORD of all the righteous acts the LORD has done for you and your ancestors.
9:12:8/When Jacob entered Egypt and your ancestors cried out to the LORD, the LORD sent Moses and Aaron, who brought your ancestors out of Egypt and settled them in this place.
9:12:9/But when they forgot the LORD their God, he handed them over to Sisera, the commander of Hazor's army, and to the Philistines, and to the king of Moab, who fought against them.
9:12:10/Then they cried out to the LORD and said, 'We have sinned because we have abandoned the LORD and served the Baals and the Ashtoreths. But now, deliver us from the hands of our enemies, and we will serve you.'
9:12:11/And the LORD sent Jerubbaal, Bedan, Jephthah, and Samuel, and rescued you from your enemies on every side, so you lived in safety.
9:12:12/But when you saw Nahash, king of the Ammonites, coming against you, you said to me, 'No, we want a king to rule over us'—even though the LORD your God was your king.
9:12:13/Now here is the king you have chosen, the one you asked for. See, the LORD has set a king over you.
9:12:14/If you fear the LORD, serve him, listen to his voice, and do not rebel against his commands, then both you and the king who reigns over you will follow the LORD your God.
9:12:15/But if you do not listen to the LORD's voice and rebel against his commands, the LORD's hand will be against you, as it was against your ancestors.
9:12:16/Now then, stand and see this great thing the LORD is about to do before your eyes.
9:12:17/Isn't it the wheat harvest today? I will call to the LORD, and he will send thunder and rain. Then you will realize how much evil you did in the LORD's sight by asking for a king."
9:12:18/So Samuel called out to the LORD, and that day the LORD sent thunder and rain. All the people were greatly afraid of the LORD and of Samuel.
9:12:19/And all the people said to Samuel, "Pray to the LORD your God for your servants so we don't die, for we have added to all our sins the evil of asking for a king."
9:12:20/And Samuel said to the people, "Do not be afraid. You have done all this evil, yet do not turn away from following the LORD, but serve the LORD with all your heart.
9:12:21/And do not turn away after useless things that cannot benefit or save you, for they are useless.
9:12:22/For the LORD will not abandon his people, because of his great name and because it has pleased the LORD to make you his people.
9:12:23/Moreover, as for me, far be it from me to sin against the LORD by failing to pray for you. I will continue to teach you the good and right way.
9:12:24/Only fear the LORD and serve him faithfully with all your heart; for consider what great things he has done for you.
9:12:25/But if you persist in doing evil, both you and your king will be swept away."
9:13:1/Saul had been king for one year; by the time he had ruled over Israel for two years,
9:13:2/Saul selected three thousand men from Israel; two thousand stayed with Saul in Michmash and in mount Bethel, while a thousand were with Jonathan in Gibeah of Benjamin. He sent the rest of the people back to their homes.
9:13:3/Jonathan attacked the Philistine outpost in Geba, and the Philistines found out about it. Saul then sounded the trumpet throughout the land, calling the Hebrews to take notice.
9:13:4/All of Israel learned that Saul had defeated a Philistine outpost and that the Philistines now despised Israel. The people then rallied behind Saul at Gilgal.
9:13:5/The Philistines assembled to fight Israel with thirty thousand chariots, six thousand horsemen, and troops as numerous as the sand on the seashore. They advanced and set up camp in Michmash, to the east of Bethaven.
9:13:6/Seeing they were in a tight spot, the Israelites were terrified and hid in caves, thickets, rocks, high places, and pits.
9:13:7/Some Hebrews even crossed the Jordan to the lands of Gad and Gilead. Meanwhile, Saul remained in Gilgal, and all the people with him were shaking with fear.
9:13:8/He waited seven days, the time set by Samuel. But Samuel didn't come to Gilgal, and the people began to scatter from Saul.
9:13:9/Saul said, "Bring me a burnt offering and peace offerings." And he proceeded to offer the burnt offering.
9:13:10/Just as he finished making the burnt offering, Samuel arrived. Saul went out to greet him and welcome him.
9:13:11/Samuel asked, "What have you done?" Saul replied, "I saw that the people were scattering from me, you didn't arrive when expected, and the Philistines were assembling at Michmash.
9:13:12/I thought, 'The Philistines will soon attack me in Gilgal, and I haven't sought the LORD's favor.' So I felt compelled to offer the burnt offering."
9:13:13/Samuel told Saul, "You've acted foolishly. You haven't followed the command the LORD your God gave you. If you had, the LORD would have established your kingdom over Israel forever.
9:13:14/But now your kingdom won't last. The LORD has sought out a man after his own heart and appointed him leader of his people, because you haven't obeyed the LORD's command."
9:13:15/Then Samuel left Gilgal and went to Gibeah of Benjamin. Saul counted the troops who were still with him; they numbered about six hundred.
9:13:16/Saul, Jonathan his son, and the troops with them stayed in Gibeah of Benjamin, while the Philistines camped in Michmash.
9:13:17/Three raiding parties left the Philistine camp: one headed toward Ophrah in the land of Shual,
9:13:18/another toward Beth Horon, and the third toward the border overlooking the Valley of Zeboim toward the desert.
9:13:19/There were no blacksmiths found throughout all the land of Israel because the Philistines had said, "Otherwise, the Hebrews will make swords or spears."
9:13:20/So all the Israelites went down to the Philistines to have their plowshares, mattocks, axes, and sickles sharpened.
9:13:21/The price was two-thirds of a shekel for sharpening plowshares and mattocks, and a third of a shekel for sharpening forks and axes, and for repointing goads.
9:13:22/On the day of the battle, none of the troops with Saul and Jonathan had swords or spears, only Saul and Jonathan were armed.
9:13:23/The Philistine outpost moved to the pass of Michmash.
9:14:1/One day, Jonathan, Saul's son, said to his young armor-bearer, "Come, let's go to the Philistine outpost on the other side." But he didn't tell his father.
9:14:2/Saul stayed on the outskirts of Gibeah under a pomegranate tree in Migron, with about six hundred men with him.
9:14:3/Ahiah, son of Ahitub, Ichabod's brother, son of Phinehas, son of Eli, the Lord's priest in Shiloh, was wearing an ephod. The people didn't know Jonathan had left.
9:14:4/Between the paths Jonathan intended to cross to reach the Philistine outpost, there was a steep rock on one side and another on the opposite side: one was named Bozez, and the other Seneh.
9:14:5/The one facing north was opposite Michmash, and the other south, opposite Gibeah.
9:14:6/Jonathan said to his armor-bearer, "Come, let's go to the outpost of these uncircumcised men. Perhaps the Lord will act on our behalf. For nothing can hinder the Lord from saving, whether by many or by few."
9:14:7/His armor-bearer replied, "Go ahead with all that's in your heart. I'm with you all the way."
9:14:8/Then Jonathan said, "Look, we'll cross over toward those men and reveal ourselves to them."
9:14:9/If they say to us, 'Wait until we come to you,' we'll stay where we are and not go up to them.
9:14:10/But if they say, 'Come up to us,' we'll climb up, because that will be our sign that the Lord has given them into our hands."
9:14:11/So both of them showed themselves to the Philistine outpost. The Philistines said, "Look, the Hebrews are coming out of the holes they've been hiding in."
9:14:12/The men of the outpost called to Jonathan and his armor-bearer, "Come up to us, and we'll teach you a lesson." Jonathan said to his armor-bearer, "Follow me, for the Lord has given them into Israel's hand."
9:14:13/Jonathan climbed up, using his hands and feet, with his armor-bearer right behind him. The Philistines fell before Jonathan, and his armor-bearer followed and killed behind him.
9:14:14/In that first attack, Jonathan and his armor-bearer killed about twenty men in an area of about half an acre.
9:14:15/There was panic in the camp, in the field, and among all the Philistine troops. The outpost and raiding parties also panicked, and the ground shook. It was a panic sent by God.
9:14:16/Saul's lookouts at Gibeah of Benjamin saw the army melting away in all directions.
9:14:17/Then Saul said to the men with him, "Muster the troops and see who has left us." When they did, they found Jonathan and his armor-bearer were missing.
9:14:18/Saul said to Ahiah, "Bring the ark of God here." At that time, the ark of God was with the Israelites.
9:14:19/While Saul was talking to the priest, the turmoil in the Philistine camp increased. So Saul said to the priest, "Withdraw your hand."
9:14:20/Then Saul and all his men assembled and went into battle. They found the Philistines in total confusion, striking each other with their swords.
9:14:21/Those Hebrews who had previously been with the Philistines and had gone up with them to their camp went over to the Israelites who were with Saul and Jonathan.
9:14:22/When all the Israelites who had hidden in the hill country of Ephraim heard that the Philistines were fleeing, they joined the battle in hot pursuit.
9:14:23/So the Lord saved Israel that day, and the battle moved on beyond Beth Aven.
9:14:24/Now the Israelite troops were in distress that day because Saul had bound the people under an oath, saying, "Cursed be anyone who eats food before evening comes, before I have avenged myself on my enemies." So none of the troops tasted food.
9:14:25/All the troops entered the forest, and there was honey on the ground.
9:14:26/When the troops entered the forest, they saw the honey oozing out, yet no one put their hand to their mouth because they feared the oath.
9:14:27/But Jonathan had not heard his father bind the people with the oath, so he reached out the end of the staff that was in his hand, dipped it into the honeycomb, and put his hand to his mouth. His eyes brightened.
9:14:28/Then one of the soldiers told him, "Your father strictly bound the people with an oath, saying, 'Cursed be anyone who eats food today.'" That is why the troops are faint.
9:14:29/Jonathan said, "My father has made trouble for the country. See how my eyes have brightened because I tasted a little of this honey.
9:14:30/How much better it would have been if the troops had eaten freely today from the plunder they found among their enemies. Wouldn't there have been a much greater slaughter among the Philistines?"
9:14:31/They struck down the Philistines that day from Michmash to Aijalon. The troops were very tired.
9:14:32/The troops pounced on the plunder, taking sheep, cattle, and calves. They slaughtered them on the ground and ate them with the blood still in them.
9:14:33/Then someone said to Saul, "Look, the troops are sinning against the Lord by eating meat with its blood." And he said, "You have broken faith. Roll a large stone over here at once."
9:14:34/And Saul said, "Disperse yourselves among the troops and tell them, 'Bring me each his ox or sheep, and slaughter them here and eat. Do not sin against the Lord by eating meat with the blood.'" So that night all the troops brought their animals and slaughtered them there.
9:14:35/Then Saul built an altar to the Lord; it was the first altar he built to the Lord.
9:14:36/Saul said, "Let's go down after the Philistines by night and plunder them until dawn. Let's not leave a single one of them alive." "Do whatever seems best to you," they replied. But the priest said, "Let's approach God here."
9:14:37/Saul inquired of God, "Shall I go down after the Philistines? Will you give them into Israel's hand?" But God did not answer him that day.
9:14:38/Saul said, "Come here, all you leaders of the people, and find out how this sin has occurred today.
9:14:39/As surely as the Lord lives, who saves Israel, even if it is my son Jonathan, he must die." But not one of the troops said a word.
9:14:40/Then he said to all Israel, "You be on one side, and I and Jonathan my son will be on the other side." The people said to Saul, "Do what seems good to you."
9:14:41/Therefore Saul said to the Lord, the God of Israel, "Why have you not answered your servant today? If the guilt is in me or Jonathan my son, Lord, God of Israel, give Urim. But if the men of Israel are at fault, give Thummim." Jonathan and Saul were taken by lot, but the men were cleared.
9:14:42/Saul said, "Cast lots between me and Jonathan my son." And Jonathan was selected.
9:14:43/Then Saul said to Jonathan, "Tell me what you have done." Jonathan told him, "I merely tasted a little honey with the tip of the staff that was in my hand. Here I am, ready to die."
9:14:44/Saul declared, "May God deal with me, be it ever so severely, if you do not die, Jonathan."
9:14:45/But the people said to Saul, "Should Jonathan die, who has brought about this great victory in Israel? Never! As surely as the Lord lives, not one hair of his head will fall to the ground, for he has worked with God today." So the people rescued Jonathan, and he was not put to death.
9:14:46/Then Saul stopped pursuing the Philistines, and they withdrew to their own territory.
9:14:47/So Saul took control of the kingdom of Israel and fought against all his enemies on every side: Moab, the Ammonites, Edom, the kings of Zobah, and the Philistines. Wherever he turned, he inflicted punishment on them.
9:14:48/He fought valiantly and defeated the Amalekites, rescuing Israel from the hands of those who plundered them.
9:14:49/Saul's sons were Jonathan, Ishvi, and Malki-Shua. The names of his two daughters were Merab, the firstborn, and Michal, the younger.
9:14:50/Saul's wife was Ahinoam, daughter of Ahimaaz. The commander of his army was Abner, son of Ner, Saul's uncle.
9:14:51/Kish was Saul's father; Ner, the father of Abner, was the son of Abiel.
9:14:52/Throughout Saul's reign, there was bitter war with the Philistines. Whenever Saul saw a mighty or brave man, he took him into his service.
9:15:1/Samuel also said to Saul, "The LORD sent me to anoint you as king over his people, Israel. So now, listen carefully to what the LORD is saying."
9:15:2/"This is what the LORD of hosts says: I remember what Amalek did to Israel, how he ambushed them on the way when they were coming up from Egypt.
9:15:3/"Now go and strike Amalek, and completely destroy everything they have. Do not spare them; kill men and women, children and infants, cattle and sheep, camels and donkeys."
9:15:4/And Saul assembled the people, counting them in Telaim: two hundred thousand foot soldiers and ten thousand from Judah.
9:15:5/And Saul approached a city of Amalek and set up an ambush in the valley.
9:15:6/And Saul said to the Kenites, "Move away from among the Amalekites, or I will destroy you with them. You showed kindness to all the Israelites when they came up from Egypt." So the Kenites moved away from the Amalekites.
9:15:7/And Saul defeated the Amalekites from Havilah as you go to Shur, which is east of Egypt.
9:15:8/He captured Agag, the king of the Amalekites, alive, and completely destroyed all the people with the sword.
9:15:9/But Saul and the people spared Agag and the best of the sheep, oxen, fattened animals, lambs, and all that was good. They were unwilling to destroy them completely, but everything that was worthless and weak, they completely destroyed.
9:15:10/Then the word of the LORD came to Samuel, saying,
9:15:11/"I regret that I have made Saul king, for he has turned away from following me and has not carried out my commands." Samuel was distressed, and he cried out to the LORD all night.
9:15:12/When Samuel got up early to meet Saul in the morning, he was told, "Saul went to Carmel, where he set up a monument for himself, then turned and went down to Gilgal."
9:15:13/When Samuel reached Saul, Saul said, "Blessed are you by the LORD! I have carried out the LORD's command."
9:15:14/But Samuel said, "Then what is this sound of sheep in my ears, and the lowing of oxen that I hear?"
9:15:15/Saul replied, "They were brought from the Amalekites. The people spared the best of the sheep and oxen to sacrifice to the LORD your God, but we completely destroyed the rest."
9:15:16/Then Samuel said to Saul, "Stop! Let me tell you what the LORD said to me last night." Saul said to him, "Speak."
9:15:17/Samuel said, "Although you were once humble in your own eyes, were you not made the leader of the tribes of Israel? The LORD anointed you king over Israel.
9:15:18/And the LORD sent you on a mission, saying, 'Go and completely destroy those wicked people, the Amalekites; wage war against them until you have wiped them out.'
9:15:19/Why then did you not obey the LORD? Why did you pounce on the plunder and do evil in the eyes of the LORD?"
9:15:20/"But I did obey the LORD," Saul said. "I went on the mission the LORD assigned me. I brought back Agag king of Amalek and completely destroyed the Amalekites.
9:15:21/But the people took some of the plunder, sheep and oxen, the best of what was devoted to destruction, to sacrifice to the LORD your God at Gilgal."
9:15:22/Then Samuel said, "Does the LORD delight in burnt offerings and sacrifices as much as in obeying the LORD? To obey is better than sacrifice, and to heed is better than the fat of rams.
9:15:23/For rebellion is like the sin of divination, and arrogance like the evil of idolatry. Because you have rejected the word of the LORD, he has rejected you as king."
9:15:24/Then Saul said to Samuel, "I have sinned. I violated the LORD's command and your instructions. I was afraid of the people and listened to them.
9:15:25/Now, please forgive my sin and come back with me, so that I may worship the LORD."
9:15:26/But Samuel said to Saul, "I will not go back with you. You have rejected the word of the LORD, and the LORD has rejected you as king over Israel."
9:15:27/As Samuel turned to leave, Saul caught hold of the hem of his robe, and it tore.
9:15:28/Samuel said to him, "The LORD has torn the kingdom of Israel from you today and has given it to one of your neighbors—to someone better than you.
9:15:29/And he who is the Glory of Israel does not lie or change his mind; for he is not a human, that he should change his mind."
9:15:30/Then Saul said, "I have sinned. Yet please honor me now before the elders of my people and before Israel; come back with me, so that I may worship the LORD your God."
9:15:31/So Samuel went back with Saul, and Saul worshiped the LORD.
9:15:32/Then Samuel said, "Bring me Agag king of the Amalekites." Agag came to him in chains. And Agag thought, "Surely the bitterness of death is past."
9:15:33/But Samuel said, "As your sword has made women childless, so will your mother be childless among women." And Samuel cut Agag to pieces before the LORD in Gilgal.
9:15:34/Then Samuel went to Ramah, and Saul went up to his home in Gibeah of Saul.
9:15:35/And Samuel did not see Saul again until the day of his death, but Samuel grieved over Saul. And the LORD regretted that he had made Saul king over Israel.
9:16:1/And the LORD said to Samuel, "How long will you mourn for Saul, since I have rejected him from ruling over Israel? Fill your horn with oil, and go. I will send you to Jesse the Bethlehemite because I have chosen one of his sons to be king."
9:16:2/Samuel asked, "How can I go? If Saul hears about it, he will kill me." The LORD replied, "Take a heifer with you and say, 'I have come to offer a sacrifice to the LORD.'"
9:16:3/"And invite Jesse to the sacrifice, and I will show you what to do: you are to anoint for me the one I point out to you."
9:16:4/Samuel did what the LORD had told him and went to Bethlehem. The elders of the town were alarmed at his arrival and asked, "Do you come in peace?"
9:16:5/He answered, "In peace. I've come to offer a sacrifice to the LORD: consecrate yourselves and join me in the sacrifice." He also consecrated Jesse and his sons, inviting them to the sacrifice.
9:16:6/When they arrived, Samuel saw Eliab and thought, "Surely the LORD's anointed stands here before Him."
9:16:7/But the LORD said to Samuel, "Do not consider his appearance or his height, for I have rejected him. The LORD does not look at the things people look at. People look at the outward appearance, but the LORD looks at the heart."
9:16:8/Then Jesse called Abinadab and had him walk past Samuel. But Samuel said, "The LORD has not chosen this one either."
9:16:9/Next, Jesse had Shammah pass by, but Samuel said, "Nor has the LORD chosen this one."
9:16:10/Jesse had seven of his sons pass before Samuel, but Samuel told Jesse, "The LORD has not chosen these."
9:16:11/Then Samuel asked Jesse, "Are these all the sons you have?" Jesse replied, "There is still the youngest, but he is tending the sheep." Samuel said, "Send for him; we will not sit down until he arrives."
9:16:12/So he sent for him and brought him in. He was glowing with health and had a fine appearance and handsome features. Then the LORD said, "Rise and anoint him; this is the one."
9:16:13/So Samuel took the horn of oil and anointed him in the presence of his brothers, and from that day on the Spirit of the LORD came powerfully upon David. Samuel then went to Ramah.
9:16:14/But the Spirit of the LORD departed from Saul, and an evil spirit from the LORD tormented him.
9:16:15/And Saul's servants said to him, "Look, an evil spirit from God is tormenting you."
9:16:16/"Let our lord command his servants here to find someone who can play the harp well. When the evil spirit from God comes on you, he can play, and you will feel better."
9:16:17/So Saul said to his servants, "Find me someone who plays well and bring him to me."
9:16:18/One of the servants answered, "I have seen a son of Jesse the Bethlehemite who knows how to play the harp. He is also a brave man, a warrior, speaks well, and is a fine-looking man. And the LORD is with him."
9:16:19/Therefore Saul sent messengers to Jesse and said, "Send me your son David, who is with the sheep."
9:16:20/So Jesse took a donkey loaded with bread, a skin of wine, and a young goat and sent them with his son David to Saul.
9:16:21/David came to Saul and entered his service. Saul liked him very much, and David became his armor-bearer.
9:16:22/Then Saul sent word to Jesse, saying, "Please let David remain in my service, for he has found favor in my eyes."
9:16:23/Whenever the evil spirit from God came on Saul, David would take up his harp and play. Then Saul would feel better, and the evil spirit would leave him.
9:17:1/The Philistines gathered their forces for war and assembled at Shochoh in Judah, setting up camp between Shochoh and Azekah, in Ephesdammim.
9:17:2/Saul and the Israelites also gathered and camped in the Valley of Elah, preparing to face the Philistines in battle.
9:17:3/The Philistines occupied one hillside, and the Israelites another, with a valley between them.
9:17:4/A champion named Goliath, from Gath, came out of the Philistine camp. He was over nine feet tall.
9:17:5/He wore a bronze helmet and was dressed in a coat of scale armor that weighed about 125 pounds.
9:17:6/He also wore bronze shin guards and had a bronze javelin slung on his back.
9:17:7/The shaft of his spear was as thick as a weaver's rod, and its iron point weighed about 15 pounds. A shield bearer went ahead of him.
9:17:8/Goliath stood and shouted to the Israelite ranks, "Why do you come out and line up for battle? Am I not a Philistine, and are you not servants of Saul? Choose a man and have him come down to me.
9:17:9/If he can fight and kill me, we will become your subjects; but if I overcome him and kill him, you will become our subjects and serve us."
9:17:10/Then the Philistine said, "I defy the ranks of Israel today; send me a man so that we may fight each other."
9:17:11/When Saul and all Israel heard these words from the Philistine, they were dismayed and terrified.
9:17:12/David was the son of an Ephrathite named Jesse from Bethlehem in Judah, who had eight sons. Jesse was old during Saul's reign.
9:17:13/The three oldest sons of Jesse had followed Saul to the war: Eliab the firstborn, next to him Abinadab, and the third Shammah.
9:17:14/David was the youngest. The three oldest had followed Saul,
9:17:15/but David went back and forth from Saul to tend his father's sheep at Bethlehem.
9:17:16/Every morning and evening for forty days, the Philistine came forward and took his stand.
9:17:17/Jesse said to his son David, "Take this ephah of roasted grain and these ten loaves of bread for your brothers and hurry to their camp.
9:17:18/Take along these ten cheeses to the commander of their unit. See how your brothers are and bring back some assurance from them.
9:17:19/Saul and all the men of Israel were in the Valley of Elah, fighting against the Philistines.
9:17:20/Early in the morning, David left the sheep with a shepherd, took the supplies, and set out as Jesse had directed. He reached the camp as the army was going out to its battle positions, shouting the war cry.
9:17:21/Israel and the Philistines drew up their lines facing each other.
9:17:22/David left his things with the keeper of supplies, ran to the battle lines and asked his brothers how they were.
9:17:23/As he was talking with them, Goliath, the Philistine champion from Gath, stepped out from his lines and shouted his usual defiance, and David heard it.
9:17:24/When the Israelites saw the man, they all fled from him in great fear.
9:17:25/The men of Israel said, "Have you seen this man who has come up? Surely he has come up to defy Israel. The king will enrich the man who kills him with great wealth, will give him his daughter in marriage, and will exempt his family from taxes in Israel."
9:17:26/David asked the men standing near him, "What will be done for the man who kills this Philistine and removes this disgrace from Israel? Who is this uncircumcised Philistine that he should defy the armies of the living God?"
9:17:27/The people repeated to him what they had been saying and told him, "This is what will be done for the man who kills him."
9:17:28/When Eliab, David's oldest brother, heard him speaking with the men, he burned with anger at him and asked, "Why have you come down here? And with whom did you leave those few sheep in the wilderness? I know how conceited you are and how wicked your heart is; you came down just to watch the battle."
9:17:29/"What have I done now?" David said. "Can't I even speak?"
9:17:30/He then turned away to someone else and brought up the same matter, and the men answered him as before.
9:17:31/What David said was overheard and reported to Saul, who sent for him.
9:17:32/David said to Saul, "Don't let anyone lose heart because of this Philistine; your servant will go and fight him."
9:17:33/Saul replied, "You are not able to go out against this Philistine and fight him; you are only a young man, and he has been a warrior from his youth."
9:17:34/But David said to Saul, "Your servant has been keeping his father's sheep. When a lion or a bear came and took a lamb from the flock,
9:17:35/I went after it, struck it, and rescued the lamb from its mouth. When it turned on me, I seized it by its hair, struck it, and killed it.
9:17:36/Your servant has killed both the lion and the bear; this uncircumcised Philistine will be like one of them, because he has defied the armies of the living God.
9:17:37/David added, "The LORD who rescued me from the paw of the lion and the paw of the bear will rescue me from the hand of this Philistine." Saul said to David, "Go, and the LORD be with you."
9:17:38/Then Saul dressed David in his own armor. He put a bronze helmet on his head and clothed him with a coat of mail.
9:17:39/David strapped Saul's sword over the armor and tried to walk, but he wasn't used to them. "I can't go in these," he said to Saul, "because I'm not used to them." So he took them off.
9:17:40/He took his staff in his hand, selected five smooth stones from the stream, put them in the pouch of his shepherd's bag and, with his sling in his hand, approached the Philistine.
9:17:41/The Philistine moved closer to attack David, with his shield bearer in front of him.
9:17:42/When the Philistine looked David over and saw that he was only a boy, glowing with health and handsome, he despised him.
9:17:43/He said to David, "Am I a dog, that you come at me with sticks?" And the Philistine cursed David by his gods.
9:17:44/"Come here," the Philistine said, "and I'll give your flesh to the birds and the wild animals!"
9:17:45/David replied to the Philistine, "You come against me with sword, spear, and javelin, but I come against you in the name of the LORD Almighty, the God of the armies of Israel, whom you have defied.
9:17:46/Today the LORD will deliver you into my hands, and I'll strike you down and cut off your head. Today I will give the carcasses of the Philistine army to the birds and the wild animals, and the whole world will know that there is a God in Israel.
9:17:47/All those gathered here will know that it is not by sword or spear that the LORD saves; for the battle is the LORD's, and he will give all of you into our hands."
9:17:48/As the Philistine moved closer to attack him, David ran quickly toward the battle line to meet him.
9:17:49/Reaching into his bag and taking out a stone, David slung it and struck the Philistine on the forehead. The stone sank into his forehead, and he fell face down on the ground.
9:17:50/Thus David triumphed over the Philistine with a sling and a stone; without a sword in his hand he struck down the Philistine and killed him.
9:17:51/David ran and stood over the Philistine, took hold of his sword, drew it from the sheath, killed him, and cut off his head with it. When the Philistines saw that their hero was dead, they turned and ran.
9:17:52/Then the men of Israel and Judah surged forward with a shout and pursued the Philistines to the entrance of Gath and to the gates of Ekron. Their dead were strewn along the Shaaraim road to Gath and Ekron.
9:17:53/When the Israelites returned from chasing the Philistines, they plundered their camp.
9:17:54/David took the Philistine's head and brought it to Jerusalem; he put the Philistine's weapons in his own tent.
9:17:55/When Saul saw David going out to meet the Philistine, he asked Abner, the commander of the army, "Abner, whose son is this young man?" Abner replied, "As surely as you live, Your Majesty, I don't know."
9:17:56/The king said, "Find out whose son this young man is."
9:17:57/As David returned from killing the Philistine, Abner took him and brought him before Saul, with the Philistine's head still in his hand.
9:17:58/Saul asked him, "Young man, whose son are you?" David answered, "I am the son of your servant Jesse of Bethlehem."

9:18:8/Saul became furious, resenting the comparison. He thought, "They credit David with ten thousands and me with only thousands. What's left for him but the kingdom?"
9:18:9/From that day on, Saul kept a jealous eye on David.

9:18:11/Saul threw the spear, thinking, "I'll pin David to the wall." But David evaded him twice.
9:18:12/Saul feared David because the LORD was with David and had left Saul.

9:18:16/But all Israel and Judah loved David because he led them in their campaigns.

9:18:26/When Saul's servants relayed these words to David, he was pleased to become the king's son-in-law. The time had not yet expired.

9:19:3/I'll go out and stand next to my father in the field where you are hiding, and I'll talk to him about you. Whatever I find out, I'll let you know.

9:20:2/Jonathan reassured him, "Absolutely not, you won't die. Look, my father doesn't do anything, big or small, without telling me. Why would he hide this from me? It's not happening."
9:20:3/David firmly responded, "Your father knows very well that I'm in your favor, and he thinks, 'Let's not let Jonathan know this; it'll upset him.' But I swear by the living LORD and by your own life, I'm just a step away from death."

9:20:13/If my father intends to harm you, I'll let you know and send you away safely. May the LORD be with you as He has been with my father.
9:20:14/And while I'm still alive, show me the loyalty of the LORD so I don't die.
9:20:15/And don't ever withdraw your kindness from my family—not even when the LORD has eliminated all of David's enemies from the face of the earth."

9:24:4/David's men whispered to him, "This is the moment the LORD spoke of, saying, 'I will give your enemy into your hands, and you can do with him as you wish.'" Then David quietly cut off a piece of Saul's robe.
9:24:5/Afterward, David felt guilty for cutting off a piece of Saul's robe.
9:24:6/He told his men, "The LORD forbid that I should do such a thing to my master, the LORD's anointed, by attacking him, since he is the anointed of the LORD."
9:24:7/David restrained his men with these words and did not allow them to attack Saul. Saul left the cave and continued on his way.
9:24:8/Then David also got up, went out of the cave, and called out to Saul, "My lord the king!" When Saul looked behind him, David bowed down with his face to the ground in respect.
9:24:9/David asked Saul, "Why do you listen to people who say, 'David is out to harm you'?
9:24:10/Today you've seen with your own eyes how the LORD delivered you into my hands in the cave. Some urged me to kill you, but I spared you, saying, 'I won't lay a hand on my lord, for he is the LORD's anointed.'
9:24:11/See, my father, look at this piece of your robe in my hand. I cut off the corner of your robe but didn't kill you. This proves that I am not trying to harm you and that I have not sinned against you, even though you are hunting me to take my life.
9:24:12/May the LORD judge between us, and may the LORD avenge me on you, but my hand will not be against you.
9:24:13/As the old saying goes, 'From the wicked comes wickedness,' but my hand will not be against you.
9:24:14/Who has the king of Israel come out after? Who are you pursuing? A dead dog? A single flea?
9:24:15/May the LORD be our judge and decide between us. May he consider my cause and uphold it; may he vindicate me by delivering me from your hand."
9:24:16/When David finished saying this, Saul asked, "Is that your voice, my son David?" And Saul wept aloud.
9:24:17/He said to David, "You are more righteous than I, for you have repaid me with good, whereas I have repaid you with evil.
9:24:18/You have shown today that you have treated me well; the LORD delivered me into your hands, but you did not kill me.
9:24:19/When a man finds his enemy, does he let him get away unharmed? May the LORD reward you with good for what you did for me today.
9:24:20/Now I know for sure that you will indeed become king, and that the kingdom of Israel will be established in your hands.
9:24:21/Therefore, swear to me by the LORD that you will not kill off my descendants after me and that you will not wipe out my name from my father's family."
9:24:22/And David swore this to Saul. Then Saul went home, but David and his men went up to the stronghold.
9:25:1/Samuel passed away; and all the Israelites gathered, mourned for him, and buried him at his home in Ramah. Then David left and went down to the wilderness of Paran.
9:25:2/There was a man in Maon, who had property in Carmel; he was extremely wealthy, owning three thousand sheep and a thousand goats, and he was shearing his sheep in Carmel.
9:25:3/The man's name was Nabal, and his wife's name was Abigail. She was intelligent and beautiful, but Nabal was harsh and mean in his actions; he belonged to the Caleb family.
9:25:4/David found out in the wilderness that Nabal was shearing his sheep.
9:25:5/David sent ten young men, instructing them, "Go up to Carmel, visit Nabal, and greet him in my name:
9:25:6/And say to him, 'Wishing you peace, peace to your household, and peace to all that you own.
9:25:7/I've heard you have shearers. Your shepherds stayed with us, and we didn't harm them, nor did anything go missing the whole time they were in Carmel.
9:25:8/Ask your young men, and they'll confirm this. So please, let your young men be treated kindly, as we've come on a good day. Please give whatever you can to your servants and to your son David.'"
9:25:9/When David’s young men arrived, they delivered all these messages to Nabal in David's name, then waited.
9:25:10/Nabal responded to David's servants, "Who is David? And who is the son of Jesse? Nowadays, there are plenty of servants breaking away from their masters.
9:25:11/Should I take my bread, water, and meat that I've prepared for my shearers and give it to men coming from who knows where?"
9:25:12/So David's young men turned back, returned, and reported to him all these responses.
9:25:13/David told his men, "Everyone strap on your sword." So they all armed themselves, and David did as well. About four hundred men followed David, while two hundred stayed with the supplies.
9:25:14/However, one of the young men informed Abigail, Nabal’s wife, "David sent messengers from the wilderness to greet our master, but he screamed at them.
9:25:15/Yet these men were very good to us. We weren't harmed, nor did we miss anything during the time we spent with them while in the fields.
9:25:16/They were like a protective wall to us, both night and day, all the time we were with them tending the sheep.
9:25:17/Now think about what you should do, because harm is planned against our master and his entire household. He's such a wicked man that no one can talk to him."
9:25:18/Abigail quickly gathered two hundred loaves of bread, two skins of wine, five prepared sheep, five measures of roasted grain, a hundred clusters of raisins, and two hundred fig cakes, and loaded them on donkeys.
9:25:19/She told her servants, "Go ahead of me; I'll follow you." But she didn't tell her husband Nabal.
9:25:20/As she rode on the donkey, she came down a hidden part of the hill, and there were David and his men descending toward her, and she met them.
9:25:21/David had said, "It was pointless to protect all that this man has in the wilderness, so that nothing of his was missing, and yet he repays me evil for good.
9:25:22/May God deal with David's enemies, and even more, if by morning I leave alive anyone of his who can urinate against a wall."
9:25:23/When Abigail saw David, she quickly got off the donkey, bowed before David with her face to the ground,
9:25:24/And fell at his feet, saying, "Let this wrongdoing be on me, my lord. Please let your servant speak to you and listen to what I have to say.
9:25:25/Please, my lord, pay no attention to this worthless man, Nabal. He's just like his name suggests—Nabal, which means fool, and folly follows him. But I, your servant, didn't see the young men you sent.
9:25:26/Now, my lord, as surely as the LORD lives and as you live, since the LORD has prevented you from shedding blood and from taking vengeance into your own hands, let your enemies and those who intend harm for my lord be like Nabal.
9:25:27/And now, let this gift, which your servant has brought to my lord, be given to the young men who follow my lord.
9:25:28/Please forgive the trespass of your servant. For the LORD will certainly establish a lasting dynasty for my lord, because you fight the LORD's battles, and no wrongdoing has been found in you throughout your life.
9:25:29/Even though someone is pursuing you to take your life, the life of my lord will be bound securely in the bundle of the living by the LORD your God, but the lives of your enemies he will hurl away as from the pocket of a sling.
9:25:30/When the LORD has done for my lord every good thing he promised concerning you and has appointed you leader over Israel,
9:25:31/This will not cause grief or a troubled heart for my lord, either that you have shed blood without cause or that my lord has avenged himself. When the LORD has dealt well with my lord, then remember your servant."
9:25:32/David said to Abigail, "Praise be to the LORD, the God of Israel, who sent you today to meet me.
9:25:33/And blessed be your good judgment, and blessed be you, who have kept me this day from bloodshed and from avenging myself with my own hands.
9:25:34/For indeed, as the LORD, the God of Israel, lives, who has prevented me from harming you, if you had not hurried to meet me, not one male belonging to Nabal would have been left alive by morning."
9:25:35/So David accepted from her hand what she had brought him and told her, "Go up in peace to your house. See, I have listened to your voice and granted your request."
9:25:36/When Abigail returned to Nabal, he was in the middle of a banquet like that of a king in his house, and Nabal's heart was merry within him, for he was very drunk. So she told him nothing at all until the morning light.
9:25:37/But in the morning, when the effects of the wine had worn off, his wife told him these things, and his heart failed him, and he became like a stone.
9:25:38/About ten days later, the LORD struck Nabal, and he died.
9:25:39/When David heard that Nabal was dead, he said, "Praise be to the LORD, who has upheld my cause against Nabal for the insult he hurled at me. The LORD has kept his servant from doing wrong and has brought Nabal's wrongdoing down on his own head." Then David sent word to Abigail, asking her to become his wife.
9:25:40/When David's servants came to Abigail at Carmel, they said to her, "David has sent us to you to take you to him as his wife."
9:25:41/She bowed down with her face to the ground and said, "Here is your servant, ready to serve and wash the feet of my lord's servants."
9:25:42/Abigail quickly got up and rode on a donkey, accompanied by her five maids. She followed David's messengers and became his wife.
9:25:43/David also married Ahinoam of Jezreel, and both of them became his wives.
9:25:44/However, Saul had given Michal, David's wife, to Palti, son of Laish, who was from Gallim.
9:26:1/The Ziphites came to Saul in Gibeah, saying, "Isn't David hiding on the hill of Hachilah, which faces Jeshimon?"
9:26:2/So Saul got up and went down to the wilderness of Ziph with three thousand elite Israelite troops to search for David in the wilderness of Ziph.
9:26:3/Saul camped on the hill of Hachilah, which is before Jeshimon, by the road. Meanwhile, David stayed in the wilderness, and he saw that Saul was pursuing him there.
9:26:4/David therefore sent out scouts, and confirmed that Saul had indeed arrived.
9:26:5/And David went to the place where Saul had camped: and David saw where Saul and Abner, the son of Ner, the commander of his army, were sleeping. Saul was in the camp, with the troops encamped around him.
9:26:6/Then David spoke to Ahimelech the Hittite and to Abishai, son of Zeruiah, Joab's brother, asking, "Who will go down with me into Saul's camp?" And Abishai said, "I'll go down with you."
9:26:7/So David and Abishai went to the camp at night, and there they saw Saul sleeping inside the camp, his spear stuck in the ground near his head; Abner and the troops were sleeping around him.
9:26:8/Then Abishai said to David, "Today God has delivered your enemy into your hands. Now let me pin him to the ground with the spear just once, and I won't need to strike him twice."
9:26:9/But David told Abishai, "Don't kill him. Who can lay a hand on the LORD's anointed and be guilt-free?"
9:26:10/David also said, "As surely as the LORD lives, the LORD himself will strike him down; either his time will come and he will die, or he will go into battle and perish.
9:26:11/God forbid that I should lay a hand on the LORD's anointed. But please, take the spear near his head and the water jug, and let's go."
9:26:12/So David took the spear and the water jug from near Saul's head, and they left. No one saw or knew about it, nor did anyone wake up—they were all sleeping, because a deep sleep from the LORD had fallen on them.
9:26:13/Then David crossed to the other side and stood on top of a hill at a distance; there was a wide space between them.
9:26:14/And David shouted to the troops and to Abner, son of Ner, "Aren't you going to answer, Abner?" Then Abner replied, "Who are you who calls to the king?"
9:26:15/David said to Abner, "Aren't you a brave man? Who is like you in Israel? Why then didn't you protect your lord the king? Someone came into the camp to kill your lord the king.
9:26:16/What you've done is not good. As surely as the LORD lives, you deserve to die because you did not protect your master, the LORD's anointed. Look around. Where are the king's spear and the water jug that were near his head?"
9:26:17/Saul recognized David's voice and said, "Is that your voice, my son David?" And David replied, "Yes, it's my voice, my lord, O king."
9:26:18/And he said, "Why is my lord pursuing his servant? What have I done? What wrong is in my hands?
9:26:19/Now let my lord the king listen to his servant's words. If the LORD has incited you against me, then let him accept an offering. But if it's humans, may they be cursed before the LORD, for they have driven me out today so that I can't share in the LORD's inheritance, saying, 'Go, serve other gods.'
9:26:20/So now, do not let my blood fall to the ground away from the presence of the LORD. For the king of Israel has come out to search for a single flea, as one hunts a partridge in the mountains."
9:26:21/Then Saul said, "I have sinned. Come back, my son David. I will not harm you again because you valued my life today. I have acted foolishly and have made a great mistake."
9:26:22/And David responded, "Here is the king's spear! Let one of the young men come over and get it.
9:26:23/May the LORD repay everyone for their righteousness and faithfulness. The LORD delivered you into my hands today, but I would not lay a hand on the LORD's anointed.
9:26:24/Just as your life was highly valued today in my eyes, so may my life be highly valued in the eyes of the LORD, and may he rescue me from all trouble."
9:26:25/Then Saul said to David, "Blessed are you, my son David. You will do great things and surely triumph." So David went on his way, and Saul returned home.
9:27:1/David thought to himself, "I'm going to die by Saul's hand one of these days. The best thing I can do is to quickly escape to the land of the Philistines. Then Saul will give up looking for me anywhere in Israel, and I'll be out of his reach."
9:27:2/David got up and crossed over with the six hundred men who were with him to Achish, son of Maoch, the king of Gath.
9:27:3/David lived in Gath with Achish, along with his men and their families. David was there with his two wives, Ahinoam from Jezreel, and Abigail, the widow of Nabal from Carmel.
9:27:4/When Saul heard that David had fled to Gath, he stopped searching for him.
9:27:5/David said to Achish, "If you're pleased with me, let me live in one of the towns in the countryside. Why should I stay in the royal city with you?"
9:27:6/So Achish gave him Ziklag that day, which is why Ziklag belongs to the kings of Judah to this day.
9:27:7/David lived in Philistine territory for a year and four months.
9:27:8/David and his men went up and attacked the Geshurites, the Gezrites, and the Amalekites, who had lived in the area from ancient times, extending to Shur and the land of Egypt.
9:27:9/David struck the land, sparing neither man nor woman, and took the sheep, oxen, donkeys, camels, and clothes, then returned to Achish.
9:27:10/When Achish asked, "Where did you raid today?" David answered, "The southern area of Judah, the southern Jerahmeelites, and the southern Kenites."
9:27:11/David didn't leave any man or woman alive to be brought to Gath, thinking, "They might report on us, saying, 'This is what David did,' and this would be his practice all the time he lives in Philistine territory."
9:27:12/Achish trusted David, thinking, "He has made himself so odious to his people Israel that he will be my servant forever."
9:28:1/In those days, the Philistines gathered their armies for war to fight against Israel. Achish told David, "You must know for sure that you and your men will go out with me to battle."
9:28:2/David responded to Achish, "You will soon see what your servant can do." Achish then told David, "For this reason, I will make you my personal bodyguard forever."
9:28:3/Samuel had died, and all Israel mourned for him and buried him in Ramah, his hometown. Saul had expelled those with familiar spirits and the wizards from the land.
9:28:4/The Philistines assembled and set up camp in Shunem, while Saul gathered all Israel and they camped in Gilboa.
9:28:5/When Saul saw the Philistine army, he was terrified, and his heart pounded with fear.
9:28:6/When Saul sought guidance from the LORD, the LORD did not answer him, neither through dreams, nor by Urim, nor through prophets.
9:28:7/Then Saul told his servants, "Find me a woman who can summon spirits, so I can go to her and ask her advice." His servants told him, "There's a woman in Endor who can do that."
9:28:8/Saul disguised himself, wearing different clothes, and went with two men at night to the woman. He said, "Please consult a spirit for me and bring up the one I name."
9:28:9/The woman said to him, "You know what Saul has done, how he has eliminated those who summon spirits and the wizards from the land. Why are you setting a trap for my life to have me killed?"
9:28:10/Saul swore to her by the LORD, saying, "As surely as the LORD lives, you will not be punished for this."
9:28:11/The woman asked, "Whom shall I bring up for you?" He replied, "Bring up Samuel for me."
9:28:12/When the woman saw Samuel, she screamed loudly and said to Saul, "Why have you deceived me? You are Saul!"
9:28:13/The king told her, "Don't be afraid. What do you see?" The woman said to Saul, "I see spirits coming up from the ground."
9:28:14/He asked her, "What does he look like?" She answered, "An old man is coming up, wrapped in a robe." Saul realized it was Samuel, and he bowed down, face to the ground, in respect.
9:28:15/Samuel said to Saul, "Why have you disturbed me by bringing me up?" Saul replied, "I'm in great distress; the Philistines are waging war against me, and God has turned away from me. He doesn't answer me anymore, not through prophets nor dreams. That's why I've called on you, to tell me what to do."
9:28:16/Samuel said, "Why do you ask me, since the LORD has turned away from you and become your enemy?"
9:28:17/"The LORD has done exactly as he said through me: the LORD has torn the kingdom out of your hands and given it to your neighbor, David.
9:28:18/Because you did not obey the LORD's command and did not carry out his fierce anger against Amalek, the LORD has done this to you today.
9:28:19/Furthermore, the LORD will also hand over Israel along with you to the Philistines. Tomorrow, you and your sons will be with me. The LORD will also give the Israelite army into the hands of the Philistines."
9:28:20/Then Saul immediately fell full length on the ground, terrified by Samuel's words. He was completely drained of strength, for he had not eaten anything all day and night.
9:28:21/The woman came to Saul, saw that he was deeply troubled, and said to him, "Look, your servant has obeyed you. I risked my life and listened to the words you spoke to me.
9:28:22/Now please listen to your servant's advice. Let me give you some food so you can eat and have the strength to go on your way."
9:28:23/But he refused, saying, "I will not eat." However, his servants, along with the woman, persuaded him, and he listened to them. So he got up from the ground and sat on the bed.
9:28:24/The woman had a fattened calf in the house; she quickly slaughtered it. She then took flour, kneaded it, and baked unleavened bread.
9:28:25/She served it to Saul and his servants, and they ate. Then they got up and left that same night.
9:29:1/The Philistines gathered all their armies at Aphek, while the Israelites camped near a spring in Jezreel.
9:29:2/The Philistine leaders moved forward in groups of hundreds and thousands, but David and his men were at the rear with Achish.
9:29:3/The Philistine princes asked, "Why are these Hebrews here?" Achish replied to the Philistine princes, "Isn't this David, the servant of Saul, the king of Israel, who has been with me for days or years, and I've found no fault in him from the day he joined me until now?"
9:29:4/The Philistine princes were angry with him and said, "Send this man back, so he can return to the place you assigned him. He should not go with us into battle, in case he turns against us. How better to regain his master's favor than with the heads of our men?"
9:29:5/"Isn't this the David they celebrate in their dances, saying, 'Saul has slain his thousands, and David his ten thousands'?"
9:29:6/Achish called David and said, "As surely as the LORD lives, you've been trustworthy, and your actions with me in the army have been commendable. I've found nothing wrong in you from the day you arrived until now. But the lords don't approve of you.
9:29:7/So now, go back peacefully and do not upset the Philistine lords."
9:29:8/David said to Achish, "But what have I done? What have you found against me from the day I arrived until now, that I can't go and fight against the enemies of my lord the king?"
9:29:9/Achish replied to David, "I know you're as good as an angel of God in my eyes. However, the Philistine princes have decided you can't join us in battle."
9:29:10/"So get up early in the morning with your master's servants who came with you. As soon as it's light, leave."
9:29:11/So David and his men got up early to leave in the morning and return to Philistine territory. The Philistines went on to Jezreel.
9:30:1/When David and his men arrived at Ziklag on the third day, they discovered that the Amalekites had raided the south and Ziklag, attacked Ziklag, and set it on fire.
9:30:2/They had captured the women there, not killing anyone, young or old, but took them and continued on their way.
9:30:3/So when David and his men reached the city, they saw it was destroyed by fire; and their wives, sons, and daughters had been taken captive.
9:30:4/Then David and his companions cried aloud in grief until they were too exhausted to cry anymore.
9:30:5/David's two wives, Ahinoam of Jezreel and Abigail, the widow of Nabal of Carmel, had also been captured.
9:30:6/David was deeply distressed because the people talked of stoning him, as everyone was bitter over the loss of their sons and daughters. But David found strength in the LORD his God.
9:30:7/David said to Abiathar the priest, the son of Ahimelech, "Please bring me the ephod." Abiathar brought it to David.
9:30:8/And David asked the LORD, "Should I chase this raiding party? Will I catch them?" And the LORD told him, "Go after them. You will definitely catch them and succeed in the rescue."
9:30:9/So David set out with the six hundred men with him and came to the Besor Valley, where some stayed behind.
9:30:10/David continued the pursuit with four hundred men, while two hundred stayed behind, too exhausted to cross the Besor Valley.
9:30:11/They found an Egyptian in the field and brought him to David. They gave him bread to eat and water to drink,
9:30:12/and they gave him a piece of a fig cake and two clusters of raisins. After he ate, he regained his strength, for he hadn't eaten any bread or drunk any water for three days and nights.
9:30:13/David asked him, "Who do you belong to? Where are you from?" He said, "I'm a young Egyptian, the servant of an Amalekite. My master abandoned me when I became ill three days ago.
9:30:14/We raided the Negev of the Cherethites, the territory belonging to Judah, and the Negev of Caleb, and we burned Ziklag."
9:30:15/David asked him, "Can you lead me to this raiding party?" He replied, "Swear to me by God that you won't kill me or hand me over to my master, and I'll take you down to them."
9:30:16/When he led David down, there they were, scattered over the countryside, eating, drinking, and celebrating because of the great amount of plunder they had taken from the land of the Philistines and from Judah.
9:30:17/David fought them from dusk until the evening of the next day, and none of them escaped, except four hundred young men who rode off on camels.
9:30:18/David recovered everything the Amalekites had taken, including his two wives.
9:30:19/Nothing was missing: young or old, sons or daughters, plunder or anything else they had taken. David brought everything back.
9:30:20/David also took all the flocks and herds, and his men drove them ahead of the other livestock, saying, "This is David's plunder."
9:30:21/When David reached the two hundred men who were too exhausted to follow him and had been left at the Besor Valley, they came out to meet David and the people with him. As David approached, he greeted them warmly.
9:30:22/But some troublemakers among those who went with David said, "Since they didn't go with us, we won't share the plunder we recovered with them, except for each man's wife and children. They can take them and leave."
9:30:23/David replied, "No, my brothers, you must not do that with what the LORD has given us. He has protected us and handed over to us the raiders who came against us.
9:30:24/Who will listen to what you're saying? The share of the one who stayed with the supplies is to be the same as that of the one who went down to the battle. All will share alike."
9:30:25/And from that day on, David made this a rule and a right for Israel that continues to this day.
9:30:26/When David returned to Ziklag, he sent some of the plunder to the elders of Judah, his friends, saying, "Here is a gift for you from the plunder of the LORD's enemies."
9:30:27/He sent it to those in Bethel, Ramoth Negev, Jattir,
9:30:28/Aroer, Siphmoth, Eshtemoa,
9:30:29/Rachal, the towns of the Jerahmeelites, the towns of the Kenites,
9:30:30/Hormah, Bor Ashan, Athach,
9:30:31/and Hebron, and to all the places where David and his men had roamed.
9:31:1/The Philistines attacked Israel, and the Israelite soldiers fled from them, falling dead on Mount Gilboa.
9:31:2/The Philistines pursued Saul and his sons closely, killing Jonathan, Abinadab, and Melchishua, Saul's sons.
9:31:3/The battle turned against Saul, and he was severely injured by archers.
9:31:4/Saul then told his armor-bearer, "Draw your sword and run me through with it; otherwise, these uncircumcised men will come and kill me and mistreat my body." But his armor-bearer was too terrified to do it. So, Saul took his own sword and fell on it.
9:31:5/When his armor-bearer saw that Saul was dead, he also fell on his sword and died alongside him.
9:31:6/Thus, Saul, his three sons, his armor-bearer, and all his men died together that day.
9:31:7/When the Israelites on the other side of the valley and beyond the Jordan saw that the army had fled and that Saul and his sons were dead, they abandoned their cities and ran away; the Philistines then came and occupied them.
9:31:8/The next day, when the Philistines came to loot the bodies, they found Saul and his three sons dead on Mount Gilboa.
9:31:9/They cut off Saul's head, stripped his armor, and sent messengers throughout the land of the Philistines to proclaim the news in the temples of their gods and among their people.
9:31:10/They placed his armor in the temple of Ashtaroth and hung his body on the wall of Bethshan.
9:31:11/When the people of Jabeshgilead heard what the Philistines had done to Saul,
9:31:12/All the brave men set out, traveled all night, and retrieved the bodies of Saul and his sons from the wall of Bethshan. They brought them back to Jabesh and cremated them there.
9:31:13/Then they collected their bones, buried them under a tree at Jabesh, and fasted for seven days.
10:1:1/After Saul's death, when David had returned from defeating the Amalekites and had stayed two days in Ziklag;
10:1:2/On the third day, a man arrived from Saul's camp with torn clothes and dirt on his head. When he reached David, he fell to the ground in respect.
10:1:3/David asked him, "Where are you coming from?" He replied, "I've escaped from the Israelite camp."
10:1:4/David inquired, "What happened? Please tell me." He said, "The army fled from battle, many are dead, and Saul and his son Jonathan are also dead."
10:1:5/David asked the messenger, "How do you know that Saul and Jonathan are dead?"
10:1:6/The messenger answered, "I accidentally came upon Saul on Mount Gilboa, leaning on his spear, with enemy chariots and horsemen closing in on him."
10:1:7/When he saw me, he called out to me, and I responded, 'I'm here.'
10:1:8/He asked me, 'Who are you?' and I told him, 'I'm an Amalekite.'
10:1:9/Then he said, 'Please stand over me and kill me; I'm in agony but still alive.'
10:1:10/So I killed him because I was certain he wouldn't survive his fall. I then took the crown from his head and the bracelet from his arm to bring them here to you.
10:1:11/David and all the men with him then tore their clothes in grief.
10:1:12/They mourned, wept, and fasted until evening for Saul, Jonathan, the LORD's people, and the nation of Israel because they had fallen by the sword.
10:1:13/David asked the messenger, "Where are you from?" He answered, "I'm the son of a foreigner, an Amalekite."
10:1:14/David questioned him, "Weren't you afraid to lift your hand against the LORD's anointed?"
10:1:15/David then ordered one of his men, "Come here and kill him." And the man struck him down, and he died.
10:1:16/David told him, "Your blood is on your own head. Your own mouth condemned you, saying, 'I killed the LORD's anointed.'"
10:1:17/David mourned deeply for Saul and Jonathan.
10:1:18/He also ordered that the people of Judah be taught archery, as it is written in the Book of Jasher.
10:1:19/Israel's glory lies slain on your heights. How the mighty have fallen!
10:1:20/Do not announce it in Gath, do not proclaim it in the streets of Ashkelon, lest the Philistine women rejoice, lest the women of the uncircumcised celebrate.
10:1:21/May you have no dew or rain, Mount Gilboa, nor fields that yield offerings. For there the shield of the mighty was defiled, Saul's shield, as if he had not been anointed with oil.
10:1:22/Amid the blood of the slain, amid the fat of the mighty, Jonathan's bow did not turn back, nor did Saul's sword return empty.
10:1:23/Saul and Jonathan, in life they were loved and gracious, and in death they were not parted. They were swifter than eagles, stronger than lions.
10:1:24/Women of Israel, weep for Saul, who dressed you in luxurious red, who adorned your garments with gold ornaments.
10:1:25/How the mighty have fallen in battle! Jonathan, you were slain on your high places.
10:1:26/I grieve for you, my brother Jonathan; you were very dear to me. Your love for me was extraordinary, surpassing the love of women.
10:1:27/How the mighty have fallen, and the weapons of war have perished!
10:2:1/After this, David asked the LORD, "Should I go up to one of the cities of Judah?" The LORD replied, "Go up." David asked, "Where should I go?" He answered, "To Hebron."
10:2:2/So David went there, along with his two wives, Ahinoam from Jezreel and Abigail, the widow of Nabal from Carmel.
10:2:3/David also brought his men and their families, and they settled in the cities around Hebron.
10:2:4/The people of Judah came to Hebron and there they crowned David king over the tribe of Judah. They informed David, "The men of Jabesh-gilead were the ones who buried Saul."
10:2:5/David sent messengers to the men of Jabesh-gilead, telling them, "May you be blessed by the LORD for showing such loyalty to your lord Saul by burying him.
10:2:6/May the LORD now show you kindness and faithfulness, and I too will reward you for this act because you have done this.
10:2:7/So now, be strong and brave, for your master Saul is dead, and the people of Judah have anointed me as their king."
10:2:8/But Abner, son of Ner, who was the commander of Saul's army, took Ishbosheth, Saul's son, and made him cross over to Mahanaim;
10:2:9/And he declared him king over Gilead, the Ashurites, Jezreel, Ephraim, Benjamin, and all Israel.
10:2:10/Ishbosheth, Saul's son, was forty years old when he became king over Israel, and he ruled for two years. However, the tribe of Judah remained loyal to David.
10:2:11/David was king in Hebron over the tribe of Judah for seven years and six months.
10:2:12/Abner, son of Ner, and the servants of Ishbosheth, Saul's son, left Mahanaim for Gibeon.
10:2:13/Joab, son of Zeruiah, and David's servants went out and met them by the pool of Gibeon. They sat down, one group on one side of the pool and the other group on the opposite side.
10:2:14/Abner suggested to Joab, "Let the young men get up and compete in front of us." Joab agreed, "Let them get up."
10:2:15/So twelve men from Benjamin, loyal to Ishbosheth son of Saul, and twelve of David's servants got up and crossed over.
10:2:16/Each one grabbed his opponent by the head and thrust his sword into his opponent's side; so they fell down together. Therefore, that place was named Helkath Hazzurim, which is in Gibeon.
10:2:17/That day saw a fierce battle, and Abner and the men of Israel were defeated by David's servants.
10:2:18/The three sons of Zeruiah were there: Joab, Abishai, and Asahel. Asahel was as fast as a wild gazelle.
10:2:19/Asahel chased after Abner, not veering to the right or the left in his pursuit.
10:2:20/Abner looked back and asked, "Are you Asahel?" He replied, "Yes, I am."
10:2:21/Abner warned him, "Turn aside to your right or left, seize one of the young men, and take his armor." But Asahel refused to stop chasing him.
10:2:22/Again Abner warned Asahel, "Stop following me! Why should I strike you to the ground? How could I face your brother Joab?"
10:2:23/But Asahel refused to turn away, so Abner struck him in the stomach with the butt end of his spear, and the spear came out through his back. He fell there and died on the spot. Everyone who came to the place where Asahel fell and died stood still in shock.
10:2:24/Joab and Abishai continued to pursue Abner. As the sun was setting, they arrived at the hill of Ammah, near Giah on the road to the desert of Gibeon.
10:2:25/The Benjaminites rallied behind Abner, forming a single group, and took a stand on the top of a hill.
10:2:26/Then Abner called out to Joab, "Must the sword devour forever? Don't you realize this will end in bitterness? How long before you order your people to stop pursuing their brothers?"
10:2:27/Joab answered, "As God lives, if you hadn't spoken, the men would have continued the pursuit of their brothers until morning."
10:2:28/So Joab blew the trumpet, and all the troops stopped. They no longer pursued Israel, nor did they continue to fight.
10:2:29/Abner and his men traveled through the Arabah all that night, crossed the Jordan, marched through the whole morning, and arrived at Mahanaim.
10:2:30/Joab stopped pursuing Abner and gathered all his men. Besides Asahel, nineteen of David's men were missing.
10:2:31/But David's servants had struck down three hundred and sixty men from Benjamin and Abner's forces.
10:2:32/They took Asahel and buried him in his father's tomb in Bethlehem. Then Joab and his men marched through the night and reached Hebron at dawn.
10:3:1/There was a prolonged conflict between Saul's family and David's family: but David's power grew stronger, while Saul's family became weaker.
10:3:2/David had several sons born to him in Hebron: his firstborn was Amnon, with Ahinoam from Jezreel; 
10:3:3/His second son was Chileab, with Abigail, the widow of Nabal from Carmel; the third was Absalom, son of Maacah, the daughter of King Talmai of Geshur; 
10:3:4/The fourth was Adonijah, son of Haggith; the fifth, Shephatiah, son of Abital; 
10:3:5/And the sixth, Ithream, with Eglah, David’s wife. These sons were born to David in Hebron.
10:3:6/During the conflict between Saul's family and David's, Abner strengthened his position in Saul's family.
10:3:7/Saul had a concubine named Rizpah, daughter of Aiah. Ishbosheth confronted Abner, asking why he had slept with his father's concubine.
10:3:8/Abner was furious at Ishbosheth's accusation and said, "Am I a traitor to Judah? Today I show loyalty to Saul's family, your father, his brothers, and friends, and haven't handed you over to David, yet you accuse me over this woman?
10:3:9/May God deal with me, severely if I don't fulfill what the LORD has promised David by transferring the kingdom from Saul's family to establish David's rule over Israel and Judah from Dan to Beersheba."
10:3:10/To shift the kingdom from Saul's family and establish David's throne over Israel and Judah, from Dan to Beersheba.
10:3:11/Ishbosheth couldn't respond to Abner because he was afraid of him.
10:3:12/Abner sent messengers to David, proposing, "Who owns the land? Make an alliance with me, and I will help bring all Israel to you."
10:3:13/David agreed, with one condition: "You won't see me unless you bring Michal, Saul's daughter, to me when you come."
10:3:14/David demanded Ishbosheth send him Michal, whom he had married for the price of a hundred Philistine foreskins.
10:3:15/Ishbosheth complied and took her from her husband, Phaltiel son of Laish.
10:3:16/Her husband followed her, weeping, until Abner told him to go back, and he did.
10:3:17/Abner spoke with Israel's elders, reminding them of their past desire for David to be king.
10:3:18/"Now is the time," Abner said, "for the LORD has promised David will rescue Israel from the Philistines and all their enemies."
10:3:19/Abner also spoke to the tribe of Benjamin and then went to inform David in Hebron of what was acceptable to Israel and the Benjaminites.
10:3:20/Abner visited David in Hebron with twenty men. David hosted a feast for them.
10:3:21/Abner promised David, "I will gather all Israel to my lord the king, so they can make an alliance with you, and you can rule over everything you desire." David then let Abner leave in peace.
10:3:22/While David's men and Joab were away on a raid, bringing back great spoils, Abner left Hebron peacefully after meeting with David.
10:3:23/Upon their return, Joab and his troops were informed that Abner had visited the king, who had let him leave peacefully.
10:3:24/Joab confronted David, "Why did you let Abner go? Now he's escaped!
10:3:25/You know Abner came to deceive you, to find out your movements and everything you're doing."
10:3:26/After leaving David, Joab sent messengers to bring Abner back without David's knowledge.
10:3:27/When Abner returned, Joab took him aside and killed him to avenge the blood of his brother Asahel.
10:3:28/David declared, "I and my kingdom are innocent before the LORD forever of Abner's blood."
10:3:29/"May the guilt fall on Joab and his family forever. May his family never be without someone who has a discharge, or leprosy, or leans on a crutch, or dies by the sword, or lacks food."
10:3:30/Joab and his brother Abishai killed Abner because he had killed their brother Asahel in battle at Gibeon.
10:3:31/David ordered Joab and all the people with him to tear their clothes, wear sackcloth, and mourn for Abner. David himself walked behind the bier.
10:3:32/They buried Abner in Hebron. David wept loudly at Abner's grave, and all the people wept too.
10:3:33/David mourned for Abner, saying, "Should Abner have died as a criminal dies?
10:3:34/Your hands were not tied, your feet not bound. You fell as one falls before wicked men." And all the people wept for him again.
10:3:35/David refused to eat until sunset, swearing, "May God deal with me, severely if I taste bread or anything else before the sun sets."
10:3:36/The people were impressed by this, and everything the king did pleased them.
10:3:37/That day, all the people and all Israel realized that it was not the king's intention to kill Abner, son of Ner.
10:3:38/David said to his servants, "Don't you realize that a great leader and a great man has fallen in Israel today?
10:3:39/And today, even though I am the anointed king, I feel weak. These sons of Zeruiah are too much for me. May the LORD repay the evildoer according to his wickedness."
10:4:1/When Saul's son found out that Abner had died in Hebron, he became weak, and all the Israelites were distressed.
10:4:2/Saul's son had two men who were leaders of troops: one was named Baanah and the other Rechab, sons of Rimmon a Beerothite, from the tribe of Benjamin: (since Beeroth was also considered part of Benjamin.
10:4:3/The people from Beeroth fled to Gittaim and lived there as foreigners until today.)
10:4:4/Jonathan, Saul's son, had a son who was disabled in his feet. He was five years old when the news about Saul and Jonathan came from Jezreel, and his nurse picked him up and fled. In her hurry to escape, he fell and became disabled. His name was Mephibosheth.
10:4:5/Rechab and Baanah, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, went and arrived at the house of Ishbosheth during the hottest part of the day while he was taking a nap.
10:4:6/They entered the house pretending to get wheat, and they stabbed him in the stomach; then Rechab and Baanah, his brother, escaped.
10:4:7/When they entered the house, he was lying on his bed in his bedroom. They attacked him, killed him, beheaded him, took his head, and traveled through the plain all night.
10:4:8/They brought Ishbosheth's head to David in Hebron and said to the king, "Here is the head of Ishbosheth, the son of Saul, your enemy who wanted to kill you. Today, the LORD has avenged my lord the king against Saul and his descendants."
10:4:9/David responded to Rechab and Baanah, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, "As surely as the LORD lives, who has delivered me from all trouble,
10:4:10/When someone told me, 'Look, Saul is dead,' thinking they were bringing me good news, I seized him and killed him in Ziklag as a reward for his news.
10:4:11/How much more, when wicked men have murdered an innocent man in his own house on his bed, should I not now demand his blood from your hands and remove you from the earth?"
10:4:12/David ordered his men, and they killed them, cut off their hands and feet, and hung them by the pool in Hebron. But they took Ishbosheth's head and buried it in Abner's tomb in Hebron.
10:5:1/Then all the tribes of Israel came to David at Hebron and said, "Look, we are your own flesh and blood.
10:5:2/Even when Saul was king, you were the one leading Israel in and out of battle. And the LORD told you, 'You will shepherd my people Israel, and you will become their leader.'"
10:5:3/So all the elders of Israel went to the king at Hebron, and King David made a covenant with them in Hebron before the LORD. They anointed David king over Israel.
10:5:4/David was thirty years old when he started his reign, and he ruled for forty years.
10:5:5/In Hebron, he ruled over Judah for seven years and six months, and in Jerusalem, he ruled for thirty-three years over all Israel and Judah.
10:5:6/Then the king and his men went to Jerusalem to confront the Jebusites, the inhabitants of the land, who told David, "You won't get in here unless you remove the blind and the lame," thinking, "David can't possibly get in here."
10:5:7/But David captured the stronghold of Zion, which is now the City of David.
10:5:8/And David declared that day, "Anyone who strikes the Jebusites, including the lame and the blind, whom David despises, will become the leader and commander." That's why they say, "The blind and the lame shall not enter the house."
10:5:9/So David settled in the fortress and named it the City of David. He also built up the area around it, from the supporting terraces inward.
10:5:10/And David continued to grow more powerful, because the LORD God of hosts was with him.
10:5:11/King Hiram of Tyre sent envoys to David, along with cedar trees, carpenters, and stonemasons, and they built David a palace.
10:5:12/And David realized that the LORD had established him as king over Israel and had elevated his kingdom for the sake of his people Israel.
10:5:13/David took more concubines and wives from Jerusalem after he came from Hebron, and more sons and daughters were born to David.
10:5:14/These are the names of those born to him in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, and Solomon,
10:5:15/Ibhar, Elishua, Nepheg, and Japhia,
10:5:16/Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet.
10:5:17/But when the Philistines heard that David had been anointed king over Israel, they all came up to search for David. David heard about it and went down to his stronghold.
10:5:18/The Philistines also spread out in the Valley of Rephaim.
