10:5:19/And David asked the LORD, "Should I go up against the Philistines? Will you hand them over to me?" The LORD replied to David, "Go up, for I will certainly hand the Philistines over to you."
10:5:20/So David went to Baal Perazim, and there he defeated them. He said, "The LORD has broken through my enemies before me like a flood." Therefore, he named that place Baal Perazim.
10:5:21/There they abandoned their idols, and David and his men carried them away.
10:5:22/Once again, the Philistines came up and spread out in the Valley of Rephaim.
10:5:23/When David inquired of the LORD, He said, "Do not go straight up, but circle around behind them and attack them in front of the balsam trees.
10:5:24/And when you hear the sound of marching in the tops of the balsam trees, move quickly, because that will mean the LORD has gone out in front of you to strike down the Philistine army."
10:5:25/And David did as the LORD commanded him, and he struck down the Philistines from Geba all the way to Gezer.
10:6:1/Once again, David gathered all the elite men of Israel, thirty thousand in total.
10:6:2/David set out with all his followers from Baale of Judah to transport the ark of God, which is named after the LORD of hosts who resides between the cherubim.
10:6:3/They placed the ark of God on a new cart and moved it from the house of Abinadab in Gibeah, with Uzzah and Ahio, Abinadab's sons, guiding the new cart.
10:6:4/They transported it from Abinadab's house in Gibeah, with Ahio leading the way in front of the ark of God.
10:6:5/David and all of Israel celebrated before the LORD with all kinds of fir wood instruments, including harps, lyres, tambourines, trumpets, and cymbals.
10:6:6/When they reached Nachon's threshing floor, Uzzah reached out to steady the ark of God because the oxen stumbled.
10:6:7/The LORD's anger flared up against Uzzah, and God struck him down there for his mistake, and he died next to the ark of God.
10:6:8/David was upset because the LORD had struck Uzzah, and he named that place Perezuzzah, which it is still called today.
10:6:9/David became fearful of the LORD that day and wondered, "How can the ark of the LORD come to me?"
10:6:10/So David decided not to bring the ark of the LORD to the City of David but instead diverted it to the house of Obed-edom the Gittite.
10:6:11/The ark of the LORD stayed in the house of Obed-edom the Gittite for three months, and the LORD blessed Obed-edom and his entire household.
10:6:12/When King David heard that the LORD had blessed Obed-edom's household and everything he had because of the ark of God, he joyfully went and brought the ark of God from Obed-edom's house to the City of David.
10:6:13/After those carrying the ark of the LORD had walked six steps, David sacrificed oxen and fattened animals.
10:6:14/David danced with all his might before the LORD, wearing a linen ephod.
10:6:15/Thus, David and all the people of Israel brought up the ark of the LORD with shouts of joy and the sound of trumpets.
10:6:16/As the ark of the LORD entered the City of David, Michal, daughter of Saul, watched from a window. Seeing King David leaping and dancing before the LORD, she felt contempt for him in her heart.
10:6:17/They brought the ark of the LORD and set it in its place inside the tent that David had pitched for it. Then David offered burnt offerings and peace offerings before the LORD.
10:6:18/After David finished offering the burnt offerings and peace offerings, he blessed the people in the name of the LORD of hosts.
10:6:19/He distributed to everyone in Israel, both men and women, a loaf of bread, a portion of meat, and a raisin cake. Then all the people went home.
10:6:20/Then David returned home to bless his family. Michal, daughter of Saul, came out to meet David and sarcastically said, "How distinguished the king of Israel looked today, exposing himself before the servant girls like any vulgar person might do!"
10:6:21/David replied to Michal, "I was celebrating before the LORD, who chose me over your father and his entire family to rule over the LORD's people, Israel. I will celebrate before the LORD.
10:6:22/I will humble myself even more than this and will be lowly in my own eyes. But by the servant girls you mentioned, I will be held in honor."
10:6:23/Therefore, Michal, the daughter of Saul, had no children until the day of her death.
10:7:1/When the king was settled in his palace, and the LORD had given him peace from all his enemies around him,
10:7:2/the king said to Nathan the prophet, "Look, I am living in a house of cedar, but the ark of God resides in a tent."
10:7:3/Nathan replied to the king, "Go ahead and do all that is on your mind, for the LORD is with you."
10:7:4/That night, the word of the LORD came to Nathan, saying,
10:7:5/"Go and tell my servant David, 'This is what the LORD says: Are you the one to build me a house to dwell in?
10:7:6/I have not lived in a house since I brought the Israelites up from Egypt to this day. Instead, I have moved from one tent and dwelling place to another.
10:7:7/Throughout all my travels with all the Israelites, did I ever ask any of the tribes of Israel, whom I commanded to shepherd my people Israel, "Why have you not built me a house of cedar?"'
10:7:8/Now, tell my servant David, 'This is what the LORD Almighty says: I took you from the pasture, from tending the flock, to be ruler over my people Israel.
10:7:9/I have been with you wherever you have gone, and I have cut off all your enemies from before you. Now I will make your name great, like the names of the greatest men on earth.
10:7:10/And I will provide a place for my people Israel and will plant them so they can have a home of their own and no longer be disturbed. Wicked people will not oppress them anymore, as they did at the beginning
10:7:11/and have done ever since the time I appointed leaders over my people Israel. I will also give you rest from all your enemies. The LORD declares to you that the LORD himself will establish a house for you:
10:7:12/When your days are over and you rest with your ancestors, I will raise up your offspring to succeed you, your own flesh and blood, and I will establish his kingdom.
10:7:13/He is the one who will build a house for my Name, and I will establish the throne of his kingdom forever.
10:7:14/I will be his father, and he will be my son. When he does wrong, I will discipline him with a rod wielded by men, with floggings inflicted by human hands.
10:7:15/But my love will never be taken away from him, as I took it away from Saul, whom I removed from before you.
10:7:16/Your house and your kingdom will endure forever before me; your throne will be established forever.'"
10:7:17/According to all these words and this entire vision, Nathan spoke to David.
10:7:18/Then King David went in and sat before the LORD, and he said, "Who am I, Sovereign LORD, and what is my family, that you have brought me this far?
10:7:19/And as if this were not enough in your sight, Sovereign LORD, you have also spoken about the future of the house of your servant—and this decree, Sovereign LORD, is for a mere human!
10:7:20/What more can David say to you? For you know your servant, Sovereign LORD.
10:7:21/For the sake of your word and according to your will, you have done this great thing and revealed it to your servant.
10:7:22/"How great you are, Sovereign LORD! There is no one like you, and there is no God but you, as we have heard with our own ears.
10:7:23/And who is like your people Israel—the one nation on earth that God went out to redeem as a people for himself, and to make a name for himself, and to perform great and awesome wonders by driving out nations and their gods from before your people, whom you redeemed from Egypt?
10:7:24/You have established your people Israel as your very own forever, and you, LORD, have become their God.
10:7:25/And now, LORD God, keep forever the promise you have made concerning your servant and his house. Do as you have promised,
10:7:26/so that your name will be great forever. Then people will say, 'The LORD Almighty is God over Israel!' And the house of your servant David will be established in your presence.
10:7:27/You, LORD Almighty, God of Israel, have revealed this to your servant, saying, 'I will build you a house.' Therefore, your servant has found courage to pray this prayer to you.
10:7:28/Now, Sovereign LORD, you are God! Your covenant is trustworthy, and you have promised these good things to your servant.
10:7:29/Now be pleased to bless the house of your servant, that it may continue forever in your sight; for you, Sovereign LORD, have spoken, and with your blessing the house of your servant will be blessed forever.
10:8:1/After this, David defeated the Philistines and subdued them, taking Methegammah from the Philistines.
10:8:2/He also defeated Moab, measuring them with a line to decide their fate; some were put to death, and others were spared. The Moabites became David's subjects and paid tribute.
10:8:3/David also struck down Hadadezer, the son of Rehob, king of Zobah, as he tried to extend his territory to the Euphrates River.
10:8:4/David captured from him a thousand chariots, seven hundred horsemen, and twenty thousand foot soldiers. David crippled all the chariot horses but kept enough for a hundred chariots.
10:8:5/When the Syrians from Damascus came to help Hadadezer, king of Zobah, David killed twenty-two thousand of them.
10:8:6/David then placed military outposts in Syrian Damascus, and the Syrians became David's subjects, bringing tribute. The LORD protected David wherever he went.
10:8:7/David seized the gold shields carried by Hadadezer's officers and brought them to Jerusalem.
10:8:8/From Betah and Berothai, cities of Hadadezer, David took a great amount of bronze.
10:8:9/When Toi, king of Hamath, heard that David had defeated the entire army of Hadadezer,
10:8:10/Toi sent his son Joram to King David to greet him and congratulate him for defeating Hadadezer, since Hadadezer had been at war with Toi. Joram brought with him silver, gold, and bronze vessels.
10:8:11/King David dedicated these to the LORD, along with the silver and gold he had taken from all the nations he had subdued;
10:8:12/From Syria, Moab, the Ammonites, the Philistines, Amalek, and from the spoils of Hadadezer, son of Rehob, king of Zobah.
10:8:13/David became renowned after he returned from defeating the Syrians in the Valley of Salt, eighteen thousand men.
10:8:14/He placed military outposts throughout Edom, and all of Edom became subjects of David. The LORD protected David wherever he went.
10:8:15/David ruled over all Israel, administering justice and fairness to all his people.
10:8:16/Joab, the son of Zeruiah, was in charge of the army; Jehoshaphat, the son of Ahilud, was the recorder;
10:8:17/Zadok, the son of Ahitub, and Ahimelech, the son of Abiathar, were the priests; and Seraiah was the secretary;
10:8:18/Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, was in charge of the Cherethites and Pelethites; and David's sons were key advisors.
10:9:1/And David said, Is there anyone left from Saul's family, so I can show them kindness for Jonathan's sake?
10:9:2/There was a servant from Saul's household named Ziba. When they brought him to David, the king asked, "Are you Ziba?" He replied, "I am your servant."
10:9:3/The king asked, "Isn't there anyone left from Saul's family to whom I can show God's kindness?" Ziba answered the king, "Jonathan has a son who is disabled in both feet."
10:9:4/The king asked, "Where is he?" Ziba told the king, "He's in the house of Machir, son of Ammiel, in Lodebar."
10:9:5/Then King David sent for him from the house of Machir, son of Ammiel, in Lodebar.
10:9:6/When Mephibosheth, son of Jonathan and grandson of Saul, arrived before David, he bowed deeply in respect. David called out, "Mephibosheth!" He responded, "At your service!"
10:9:7/David said to him, "Don't be afraid. I will definitely show you kindness for the sake of your father Jonathan, and I will restore to you all the land of your grandfather Saul; and you will always eat at my table."
10:9:8/He bowed down and said, "Why do you pay attention to someone as insignificant as I am?"
10:9:9/Then the king summoned Ziba, Saul's servant, and said to him, "I have given your master's grandson everything that belonged to Saul and his family."
10:9:10/"You, your sons, and your servants will farm the land for him, and you will bring in the harvests to provide food for your master's grandson. But Mephibosheth, your master's grandson, will always eat at my table." Now Ziba had fifteen sons and twenty servants.
10:9:11/Ziba said to the king, "I will do everything my lord the king commands his servant." The king declared, "Mephibosheth will eat at my table like one of the king's sons."
10:9:12/And Mephibosheth had a young son named Micha. Everyone in Ziba's household became servants to Mephibosheth.
10:9:13/So Mephibosheth lived in Jerusalem, because he always ate at the king's table, even though he was disabled in both feet.
10:10:1/After this event, the king of the Ammonites passed away, and his son Hanun took over as king.
10:10:2/David said, "I will show kindness to Hanun, son of Nahash, just as his father was kind to me." So, David sent his servants to comfort him over his father's death. When David's servants arrived in the land of the Ammonites,
10:10:3/the Ammonite leaders said to Hanun, "Do you really think David is honoring your father by sending these comforters? Isn't it more likely that he's sent them to scout out the city, spy on us, and plan its destruction?"
10:10:4/So, Hanun took David's servants, shaved off half of their beards, cut their clothes up to their buttocks, and sent them away humiliated.
10:10:5/When David heard about this, he sent messengers to meet the men because they were deeply embarrassed. He told them, "Stay in Jericho until your beards have grown back, then you can return."
10:10:6/Seeing they had made themselves odious to David, the Ammonites hired 20,000 Syrian foot soldiers from Beth-rehob and Zoba, 1,000 from king Maacah, and 12,000 from Ishtob.
10:10:7/Upon hearing this, David dispatched Joab with all his mighty warriors.
10:10:8/The Ammonites positioned themselves for battle at the city gate, while the hired Syrian forces from Zoba, Rehob, Ishtob, and Maacah took a stand in the open field.
10:10:9/When Joab saw that he was facing enemies both in front and behind, he selected the best troops of Israel to face the Syrians.
10:10:10/He placed the rest of his forces under the command of his brother Abishai, positioning them against the Ammonites.
10:10:11/He said, "If the Syrians prove too strong for me, you must come to my aid; if the Ammonites are too strong for you, I'll help you."
10:10:12/"Be strong, and let's fight bravely for our people and the cities of our God. May the LORD do what is good in His sight."
10:10:13/Joab and his troops advanced to battle the Syrians, who fled before them.
10:10:14/When the Ammonites saw the Syrians fleeing, they too fled from Abishai and retreated into the city. Then Joab returned from fighting the Ammonites and went back to Jerusalem.
10:10:15/After their defeat, the Syrians regrouped.
10:10:16/Hadarezer sent for more Syrians from beyond the Euphrates River, and they came to Helam, led by Shobach, the commander of Hadarezer's army.
10:10:17/When David was informed, he gathered all Israel, crossed the Jordan River, and came to Helam. The Syrians prepared for battle against David and engaged him.
10:10:18/The Syrians fled from Israel. David killed 700 of their charioteers and 40,000 horsemen, and struck down Shobach, the commander of their army, who died there.
10:10:19/When the vassal kings of Hadarezer saw that they were defeated by Israel, they made peace with Israel and became their subjects. Thus, the Syrians were afraid to assist the Ammonites anymore.
10:11:1/After a year had passed, during the season when kings typically go to war, David sent Joab, his servants, and all Israel to destroy the Ammonites and besiege Rabbah. However, David stayed behind in Jerusalem.
10:11:2/One evening, David got up from his bed and walked around on the palace roof. From there, he saw a woman bathing, and she was very beautiful.
10:11:3/David sent someone to find out about the woman. The person reported, "Isn't this Bathsheba, the daughter of Eliam and the wife of Uriah the Hittite?"
10:11:4/David sent messengers to bring her to him. She came to him, and he slept with her. She had just purified herself from her menstrual uncleanness. Then she went back home.
10:11:5/The woman became pregnant and sent word to David, saying, "I am pregnant."
10:11:6/David then sent a message to Joab: "Send me Uriah the Hittite." So Joab sent Uriah to David.
10:11:7/When Uriah arrived, David asked him how Joab was doing, how the troops were, and how the war was progressing.
10:11:8/David told Uriah, "Go down to your house and wash your feet." Uriah left the palace, and a gift from the king was sent after him.
10:11:9/But Uriah slept at the entrance to the palace with all his master's servants and did not go down to his house.
10:11:10/When David was told, "Uriah did not go home," he asked Uriah, "Haven't you just come from a military campaign? Why didn't you go home?"
10:11:11/Uriah said to David, "The Ark and Israel and Judah are staying in tents, and my commander Joab and my lord's men are camped in the open country. How could I go to my house to eat and drink and make love to my wife? As surely as you live, I will not do such a thing!"
10:11:12/Then David said to Uriah, "Stay here today also, and tomorrow I will send you back." So Uriah stayed in Jerusalem that day and the next.
10:11:13/David invited him, and he ate and drank with him; David got him drunk. But in the evening Uriah went out to sleep on his mat among his master's servants; he did not go home.
10:11:14/In the morning, David wrote a letter to Joab and sent it with Uriah.
10:11:15/In the letter he wrote, "Put Uriah in the front line where the fighting is fiercest. Then withdraw from him so he will be struck down and die."
10:11:16/So when Joab had the city under siege, he put Uriah at a place where he knew the strongest defenders were.
10:11:17/When the men of the city came out and fought with Joab, some of the men in David's army fell; moreover, Uriah the Hittite died.
10:11:18/Then Joab sent and reported to David all the details of the battle.
10:11:19/He instructed the messenger: "When you have finished giving the king all the details of the battle,
10:11:20/if the king's anger rises and he asks you, 'Why did you get so close to the city to fight? Didn't you know they would shoot arrows from the wall?
10:11:21/Who killed Abimelech son of Jerubbesheth? Didn't a woman drop an upper millstone on him from the wall, so that he died in Thebez? Why did you get so close to the wall?' then you are to say, 'Your servant Uriah the Hittite is dead as well.'"
10:11:22/The messenger set out, and when he arrived he told David everything Joab had sent him to say.
10:11:23/The messenger said to David, "The men overpowered us and came out against us in the field, but we drove them back to the entrance of the gate.
10:11:24/Then the archers shot at your servants from the wall, and some of the king's men died. Moreover, your servant Uriah the Hittite is dead."
10:11:25/David said to the messenger, "Tell Joab, 'Don't let this upset you; the sword devours one as well as another. Press the attack against the city and destroy it.' Encourage him."
10:11:26/When Uriah's wife heard that her husband Uriah was dead, she mourned for him.
10:11:27/After the mourning was over, David sent for her and brought her to his house, and she became his wife and bore him a son. But what David had done displeased the LORD.
10:12:1/And the LORD sent Nathan to David. He came to him and said, "In a certain city, there were two men: one was very rich and the other very poor.
10:12:2/The rich man had a vast number of sheep and cattle:
10:12:3/But the poor man had nothing except one small female lamb he had bought and raised. It grew up with him and his children, sharing his food, drinking from his cup, and sleeping in his arms. It was like a daughter to him.
10:12:4/When a traveler came to the rich man, he didn't want to use one of his own animals to prepare a meal for the visitor. Instead, he took the poor man's lamb and cooked it for his guest.
10:12:5/David was furious with the man and said to Nathan, "As surely as the LORD lives, the man who did this deserves to die!
10:12:6/He must pay back the lamb four times over because he did such a thing and had no compassion."
10:12:7/Then Nathan said to David, "You are that man! This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: 'I anointed you king over Israel, and I rescued you from Saul.
10:12:8/I gave you your master's house and wives and the kingdoms of Israel and Judah. And if that had been too little, I would have given you even more.
10:12:9/Why did you despise the word of the LORD by doing what is evil in his eyes? You killed Uriah the Hittite with the sword of the Ammonites and took his wife to be your own.
10:12:10/Therefore, the sword will never leave your house, because you despised me and took the wife of Uriah the Hittite to be your own.'
10:12:11/This is what the LORD says: 'I will bring calamity on you from within your own family. I will take your wives and give them to someone close to you, and he will sleep with your wives in broad daylight.
10:12:12/You did it secretly, but I will do this in broad daylight before all Israel.'"
10:12:13/Then David said to Nathan, "I have sinned against the LORD." Nathan replied, "The LORD has taken away your sin. You are not going to die.
10:12:14/However, because by this action you have shown utter contempt for the LORD, the child born to you will die."
10:12:15/Then Nathan went back to his home. And the LORD struck the child that Uriah's wife had borne to David, and it became ill.
10:12:16/David pleaded with God for the child. He fasted and spent the nights lying in sackcloth on the ground.
10:12:17/The elders of his household stood beside him to get him up from the ground, but he refused, and he would not eat any food with them.
10:12:18/On the seventh day, the child died. David's servants were afraid to tell him that the child was dead. They thought, "While the child was still alive, we spoke to David, and he wouldn't listen to us. How can we tell him the child is dead? He may do something desperate."
10:12:19/When David noticed his servants whispering, he realized the child was dead and asked, "Is the child dead?" They replied, "He is dead."
10:12:20/Then David got up from the ground, washed, anointed himself, changed his clothes, went into the house of the LORD and worshiped. Then he went to his own house, and at his request, they served him food, and he ate.
10:12:21/His servants asked him, "Why are you acting this way? While the child was alive, you fasted and wept, but now that the child is dead, you get up and eat."
10:12:22/He answered, "While the child was still alive, I fasted and wept because I thought, 'Who knows? The LORD may be gracious to me and let the child live.'
10:12:23/But now that he is dead, why should I fast? Can I bring him back again? I will go to him, but he will not return to me."
10:12:24/Then David comforted his wife Bathsheba, went to her and lay with her. She gave birth to a son, and they named him Solomon. The LORD loved him
10:12:25/and sent word through Nathan the prophet to name him Jedidiah, because of the LORD.
10:12:26/Joab fought against Rabbah of the Ammonites and captured the royal citadel.
10:12:27/Joab sent messengers to David, saying, "I have fought against Rabbah and have captured the water supply.
10:12:28/Now muster the rest of the troops, besiege the city and capture it. Otherwise, I will take the city, and it will be named after me."
10:12:29/So David mustered all the people, went to Rabbah, fought against it, and captured it.
10:12:30/He took the crown from their king's head, and it was placed on David's own head. The crown was made of gold and set with precious stones, and it was very heavy. David took a great quantity of plunder from the city.
10:12:31/He also brought out the people who were there and put them to work with saws, iron picks, and iron axes, or made them work at the brick kilns. David did this to all the Ammonite towns. Then David and all the people returned to Jerusalem.
10:13:1/After this, Absalom, David's son, had a beautiful sister named Tamar, and Amnon, another of David's sons, fell in love with her.
10:13:2/Amnon became so obsessed that he made himself sick over his sister Tamar, because she was a virgin, and it seemed impossible for him to do anything to her.
10:13:3/But Amnon had a friend named Jonadab, the son of Shimeah, David’s brother, who was very cunning.
10:13:4/He asked him, "Why are you, the king's son, looking so haggard day after day? Won't you tell me?" Amnon said to him, "I'm in love with Tamar, my brother Absalom's sister."
10:13:5/Jonadab then said to him, "Pretend to be ill and lie down. When your father comes to see you, ask him to have Tamar come and prepare some food for you, so you can watch her make it and then eat it from her hand."
10:13:6/So Amnon lay down and pretended to be sick. When the king came to see him, Amnon asked the king, "Please let my sister Tamar come and make me a couple of cakes in my presence, so I can eat from her hand."
10:13:7/Then David sent a message to Tamar at home, saying, "Go to your brother Amnon's house and prepare some food for him."
10:13:8/So Tamar went to her brother Amnon's house, where he was lying down. She took dough, kneaded it, made cakes in his presence, and baked them.
10:13:9/She took the pan and served him the cakes, but he refused to eat. Amnon said, "Have everyone leave me." So everyone left him.
10:13:10/Then Amnon said to Tamar, "Bring the food into the bedroom, so I may eat from your hand." Tamar took the cakes she had made and brought them to Amnon, her brother, in the bedroom.
10:13:11/But when she brought them to him to eat, he grabbed her and said, "Come sleep with me, my sister."
10:13:12/She replied, "No, my brother, don't force me; such things should not be done in Israel. Don't do this disgraceful thing.
10:13:13/Where could I take my shame? And you would be like one of the scoundrels in Israel. Please, speak to the king; he won't deny me to you."
10:13:14/However, he refused to listen to her, and since he was stronger than she, he forced her and slept with her.
10:13:15/Then Amnon hated her with intense hatred. In fact, his hatred for her was greater than the love he had felt for her. Amnon said to her, "Get up and leave."
10:13:16/She said to him, "Sending me away is a greater wrong than what you've already done to me." But he refused to listen to her.
10:13:17/He called his servant and said, "Get this woman out of my sight and lock the door behind her."
10:13:18/She was wearing a richly colored garment, for this was how virgin daughters of the king were dressed. His servant put her out and locked the door behind her.
10:13:19/Tamar put ashes on her head, tore the colored garment she was wearing, placed her hand on her head, and walked away, weeping aloud as she went.
10:13:20/Her brother Absalom said to her, "Has Amnon, your brother, been with you? Be quiet for now, my sister; he is your brother. Don't take this to heart." So Tamar lived, a desolate woman, in her brother Absalom's house.
10:13:21/When King David heard about all these things, he was furious.
10:13:22/Absalom never said a word to Amnon, either good or bad, because he hated Amnon for having violated his sister Tamar.
10:13:23/Two years later, when Absalom had sheep shearers at Baal Hazor near Ephraim, he invited all the king's sons.
10:13:24/Absalom went to the king and said, "Your servant has sheep shearers; please let the king and his servants join your servant."
10:13:25/The king replied to Absalom, "No, my son, we should not all go, or we would be a burden to you." Although Absalom urged him, he still refused to go but gave him his blessing.
10:13:26/Then Absalom said, "If not, please let my brother Amnon come with us." The king asked him, "Why should he go with you?"
10:13:27/But Absalom pressed him until he let Amnon and all the king's sons go with him.
10:13:28/Absalom ordered his men, "Watch Amnon's actions. When he is cheerful with wine, and I say to you, 'Strike Amnon,' then kill him. Do not be afraid; haven't I given you this order? Be strong and brave."
10:13:29/So Absalom's servants did to Amnon as Absalom had ordered. Then all the king's sons got up, mounted their mules, and fled.
10:13:30/While they were on their way, news came to David: "Absalom has struck down all the king's sons; not one of them is left."
10:13:31/The king stood up, tore his clothes, and lay on the ground; all his servants stood by with their clothes torn.
10:13:32/Jonadab, the son of Shimeah, David's brother, said, "My lord should not think that all the young men, the king's sons, are dead; only Amnon is dead. This has been Absalom's intention since the day Amnon violated his sister Tamar.
10:13:33/So let not my lord the king take this matter to heart, thinking all his sons are dead; only Amnon is dead."
10:13:34/But Absalom fled. And the lookout raised his eyes and looked, and there were many people coming from the road behind him by the side of the mountain.
10:13:35/Jonadab said to the king, "See, the king's sons have come; as your servant said, so it has happened."
10:13:36/As soon as he finished speaking, the king's sons arrived, weeping loudly. The king and all his servants also wept very bitterly.
10:13:37/But Absalom fled and went to Talmai, son of Ammihud, king of Geshur. And David mourned for his son every day.
10:13:38/So Absalom fled and went to Geshur, and stayed there three years.
10:13:39/And King David longed to go out to Absalom, for he was consoled regarding Amnon, since he was dead.
10:14:1/Joab, the son of Zeruiah, noticed that the king's heart was inclined towards Absalom.
10:14:2/Joab sent to Tekoah, brought back a wise woman, and told her, "Please pretend to be a mourner, wear mourning clothes, don't use any perfume, and act like you've been mourning a death for a long time."
10:14:3/"Then go to the king and say these words to him." Joab gave her a script to follow.
10:14:4/When the woman from Tekoah spoke to the king, she fell to the ground in respect, and said, "Help, O king."
10:14:5/The king asked her, "What's wrong?" She replied, "I am a widow, and my husband has passed away."
10:14:6/"I had two sons who fought in the field with no one to separate them, and one killed the other."
10:14:7/"Now, the whole family is against me, demanding I hand over the son who killed his brother so they can execute him. This would leave me with neither heir nor name, erasing my husband's legacy from the earth."
10:14:8/The king told the woman, "Go home, and I will take care of this matter for you."
10:14:9/The woman from Tekoah said to the king, "My lord, O king, let the blame be on me and my family, and let the king and his throne be innocent."
10:14:10/The king said, "If anyone says anything to you, bring them to me, and they won't bother you again."
10:14:11/She said, "Please, remember the LORD your God and prevent the avengers of blood from causing further destruction, so they don't kill my son." He replied, "As surely as the LORD lives, not a hair of your son's head will fall to the ground."
10:14:12/Then the woman said, "Please allow me, your servant, to speak another word to my lord the king." He said, "Go ahead."
10:14:13/And the woman said, "Why then have you planned such a thing against God's people? For in saying this, the king implicates himself by not bringing back his own exiled son."
10:14:14/"We all must die; we are like water spilled on the ground, which cannot be collected again. Yet, God does not take away life but plans ways so that the estranged may not remain estranged from Him."
10:14:15/"I have come to speak to my lord the king because the people have made me afraid. I thought, 'Let me speak to the king; perhaps he will grant his servant's request.'"
10:14:16/"For the king listens and can save his servant from the hand of the man seeking to eliminate both me and my son from God's inheritance."
10:14:17/"Your servant thought, 'The words of my lord the king will bring comfort.' For like an angel of God, so is my lord the king in discerning good and evil. And may the LORD your God be with you."
10:14:18/Then the king responded, "Please don't hide anything from me that I'm about to ask you." The woman said, "Let my lord the king speak."
10:14:19/The king asked, "Is Joab involved in all this?" The woman answered, "As surely as you live, my lord the king, no one can deviate from anything my lord the king has said. Yes, your servant Joab directed me, and he put all these words in my mouth."
10:14:20/"To change the course of this matter, your servant Joab did this. And my lord is wise, like the wisdom of an angel of God, knowing everything that happens in the land."
10:14:21/And the king said to Joab, "Alright, I've decided: go and bring back the young man Absalom."
10:14:22/Joab fell to the ground in respect, bowed, and thanked the king. Joab said, "Today your servant knows that I have found favor in your eyes, my lord, O king, because the king has fulfilled his servant's request."
10:14:23/So Joab got up, went to Geshur, and brought Absalom back to Jerusalem.
10:14:24/The king said, "Let him return to his own house, but he must not see my face." So Absalom went to his own house and did not see the king's face.
10:14:25/But in all Israel, there was no one as praised for his beauty as Absalom; from the sole of his foot to the crown of his head, there was no flaw in him.
10:14:26/When he cut his hair (which he did at the end of every year because it became too heavy), the hair weighed two hundred shekels by the royal standard.
10:14:27/Absalom had three sons and one daughter named Tamar, who was a beautiful woman.
10:14:28/Absalom lived in Jerusalem for two full years without seeing the king's face.
10:14:29/Therefore, Absalom sent for Joab to send him to the king, but Joab refused to come. When he sent a second time, Joab still wouldn't come.
10:14:30/So he said to his servants, "Look, Joab's field is next to mine, and he has barley there; go and set it on fire." And Absalom's servants set the field on fire.
10:14:31/Then Joab got up, went to Absalom's house, and asked, "Why have your servants set my field on fire?"
10:14:32/Absalom answered Joab, "Look, I sent for you, asking you to come here so I could send you to the king to ask, 'Why have I come from Geshur? It would have been better for me to stay there. Now let me see the king's face; and if there is any guilt in me, let him execute me.'"
10:14:33/So Joab went to the king and told him this. Then he called for Absalom, who came to the king and bowed down with his face to the ground before the king. And the king kissed Absalom.
10:15:1/After this, Absalom got himself chariots and horses, and fifty men to run ahead of him.
10:15:2/Absalom would get up early and stand by the road near the gate. Whenever someone with a legal issue came to the king for a decision, Absalom would call them over and ask, "Which city are you from?" And they would answer, "Your servant is from one of the tribes of Israel."
10:15:3/Absalom would say to them, "Look, your case is valid and fair, but there's no representative from the king to hear you out."
10:15:4/Absalom also said, "I wish I were appointed judge in the land, so that anyone with a dispute or case could come to me, and I would ensure they receive justice."
10:15:5/Whenever someone approached him to bow down, he would reach out his hand, grab them, and kiss them.
10:15:6/This is how Absalom treated all the Israelites who came to the king for justice, and so he won the hearts of the people of Israel.
10:15:7/After forty years, Absalom said to the king, "Please let me go to Hebron to fulfill a vow I made to the LORD."
10:15:8/"While I was staying at Geshur in Syria, I made a vow saying, 'If the LORD brings me back to Jerusalem, I will serve the LORD.'"
10:15:9/The king said to him, "Go in peace." So he got up and went to Hebron.
10:15:10/But Absalom sent secret messengers throughout all the tribes of Israel, saying, "As soon as you hear the sound of the trumpet, then say, 'Absalom is king in Hebron.'"
10:15:11/Two hundred men from Jerusalem went with Absalom. They had been invited and went innocently, knowing nothing of the matter.
10:15:12/Absalom also sent for Ahithophel the Gilonite, David's counselor, from his city, Giloh, while he was offering sacrifices. And the conspiracy grew strong, for more and more people sided with Absalom.
10:15:13/A messenger came to David, saying, "The hearts of the people of Israel are with Absalom."
10:15:14/David said to all his officials who were with him in Jerusalem, "We must flee, or we won't escape from Absalom. Hurry, or he will quickly overtake us, bring disaster upon us, and strike the city with the edge of the sword."
10:15:15/The king's officials said to the king, "We are ready to do whatever our lord the king decides."
10:15:16/The king set out, with his entire household following him, but he left ten concubines to take care of the palace.
10:15:17/The king set out, with all the people following him, and they stopped at a place some distance away.
10:15:18/All his servants marched past him, along with all the Cherethites, Pelethites, and Gittites, six hundred men who had followed him from Gath, marching before the king.
10:15:19/Then the king said to Ittai the Gittite, "Why are you also coming with us? Go back and stay with the king, for you are a foreigner and also an exile from your home."
10:15:20/"You only arrived yesterday, so why should I make you wander around with us today, when I don't know where I'm going? Go back and take your people with you. May kindness and faithfulness be with you."
10:15:21/But Ittai replied to the king, "As surely as the LORD lives, and as my lord the king lives, wherever my lord the king may be, whether it means life or death, there your servant will be."
10:15:22/David said to Ittai, "Go ahead, cross over." So Ittai the Gittite crossed over, along with all his men and all the children who were with him.
10:15:23/The whole countryside wept aloud as all the people passed by. The king himself crossed the Kidron Valley, and all the people moved on toward the wilderness.
10:15:24/Zadok was there too, and all the Levites who were with him were carrying the ark of the covenant of God. They set down the ark of God, and Abiathar offered sacrifices until all the people had finished passing out of the city.
10:15:25/Then the king said to Zadok, "Take the ark of God back into the city. If I find favor in the LORD's eyes, he will bring me back and let me see it and his dwelling place again."
10:15:26/"But if he says, 'I am not pleased with you,' then I am ready; let him do to me whatever seems good to him."
10:15:27/The king also said to Zadok the priest, "Aren't you a seer? Go back to the city in peace, with your two sons, Ahimaaz your son, and Jonathan the son of Abiathar."
10:15:28/"I will wait at the fords in the wilderness until word comes from you to inform me."
10:15:29/So Zadok and Abiathar took the ark of God back to Jerusalem and stayed there.
10:15:30/David continued up the Mount of Olives, weeping as he went; his head was covered and he was barefoot. All the people with him covered their heads too and were weeping as they went up.
10:15:31/Someone told David, "Ahithophel is among the conspirators with Absalom." And David prayed, "O LORD, please turn Ahithophel's counsel into foolishness."
10:15:32/When David reached the summit, where people used to worship God, Hushai the Archite was there to meet him with his robe torn and dirt on his head.
10:15:33/David said to him, "If you come with me, you'll be a burden to me."
10:15:34/"But if you return to the city and say to Absalom, 'I will be your servant, O king; as I was your father's servant in the past, so I will now be your servant,' then you can help me by countering Ahithophel's advice."
10:15:35/"Aren't Zadok and Abiathar the priests with you there? So whatever you hear from the king's house, tell it to Zadok and Abiathar the priests."
10:15:36/"Look, their two sons, Ahimaaz, Zadok's son, and Jonathan, Abiathar's son, are there with them. Send me everything you hear through them."
10:15:37/So Hushai, David's friend, entered the city as Absalom was entering Jerusalem.
10:16:1/As David was just beyond the hilltop, Ziba, Mephibosheth's servant, met him with two saddled donkeys, carrying two hundred loaves of bread, a hundred clusters of raisins, a hundred summer fruits, and a bottle of wine.
10:16:2/The king asked Ziba, "What's the meaning of these?" Ziba replied, "The donkeys are for the king's household to ride; the bread and summer fruit are for the young men to eat; and the wine is for those who are exhausted in the desert to drink."
10:16:3/The king then asked, "And where is your master's son?" Ziba answered the king, "He's staying in Jerusalem, saying, 'Today, the house of Israel will return my father's kingdom to me.'"
10:16:4/Then the king told Ziba, "Everything that belonged to Mephibosheth is now yours." Ziba responded, "I deeply appreciate this, my lord, O king. May I always find favor in your eyes."
10:16:5/When King David arrived at Bahurim, a man from Saul's family lineage named Shimei, son of Gera, came out. He started cursing as he approached.
10:16:6/He threw stones at David and all of King David's servants, while all the people and warriors were on his right and left.
10:16:7/As he cursed, Shimei said, "Get out, get out, you murderer, you scoundrel!
10:16:8/"The LORD is repaying you for all the bloodshed in Saul's family, whom you replaced as king. The LORD has handed the kingdom over to your son Absalom. See, your own evil has caught up with you because you are a murderer."
10:16:9/Then Abishai, son of Zeruiah, said to the king, "Why should this dead dog curse my lord the king? Please let me go over and cut off his head."
10:16:10/But the king said, "What is this to me and you, sons of Zeruiah? If he is cursing because the LORD told him to curse David, who can ask, 'Why are you doing this?'"
10:16:11/David then said to Abishai and all his servants, "Look, my own son is trying to take my life. How much more this Benjaminite? Leave him alone; let him curse, for the LORD has told him to.
10:16:12/"Perhaps the LORD will see my distress and repay me with good for his cursing today."
10:16:13/As David and his men continued along the road, Shimei kept pace with them on the hillside opposite, cursing as he went, throwing stones and kicking up dust.
10:16:14/The king and all the people with him arrived exhausted, but they refreshed themselves there.
10:16:15/Absalom and all the men of Israel reached Jerusalem, along with Ahithophel.
10:16:16/When Hushai the Archite, David's friend, came to Absalom, Hushai said to him, "Long live the king! Long live the king!"
10:16:17/Absalom asked Hushai, "Is this your loyalty to your friend? Why didn't you go with your friend?"
10:16:18/Hushai replied to Absalom, "No; I will be loyal to the one the LORD, this people, and all the men of Israel have chosen. I will stay with him.
10:16:19/"Besides, whom should I serve? Shouldn't I serve in the presence of his son? As I have served in your father's presence, so I will be in yours."
10:16:20/Then Absalom said to Ahithophel, "Give us your advice on what we should do."
10:16:21/Ahithophel told Absalom, "Sleep with your father's concubines whom he left to take care of the palace. Then all Israel will hear that you have made yourself odious to your father, and the hands of everyone with you will be strengthened."
10:16:22/So they set up a tent for Absalom on the roof, and Absalom slept with his father's concubines in the sight of all Israel.
10:16:23/The advice Ahithophel gave in those days was as if one had inquired of the oracle of God. Such was the reputation of all Ahithophel's advice, both with David and with Absalom.
10:17:1/Moreover, Ahithophel suggested to Absalom, "Let me select twelve thousand men, and I will set out to chase David tonight.
10:17:2/I will catch him while he is tired and weak, causing him to panic. All the people with him will run away, and I will only strike down the king.
10:17:3/Then I will bring all the people back to you. The man you're after will be as good as captured, and everyone will be at peace."
10:17:4/This plan pleased Absalom and all the leaders of Israel.
10:17:5/Then Absalom said, "Call Hushai the Archite as well, and let's hear what he has to say."
10:17:6/When Hushai arrived, Absalom told him what Ahithophel had proposed and asked, "Should we follow his advice? If not, what do you suggest?"
10:17:7/Hushai told Absalom, "Ahithophel's advice isn't the best course of action right now."
10:17:8/Hushai explained, "You know your father and his men are fierce warriors, agitated and dangerous like a mother bear robbed of her cubs. Your father is a seasoned warrior; he won't be with the troops.
10:17:9/He's probably hiding in a pit or somewhere else right now. If some of his men are killed early on, anyone hearing about it will think there's a massacre among Absalom's followers.
10:17:10/Even the bravest, with the heart of a lion, will be demoralized. Everyone in Israel knows your father is a formidable man, and those with him are courageous.
10:17:11/So, I suggest gathering all of Israel to you, from Dan to Beersheba, as numerous as the sand by the sea, and lead them yourself into battle.
10:17:12/That way, we can attack him wherever he is found, and fall on him like dew covers the ground. Not one of him or his men will survive.
10:17:13/And if he retreats into a city, then all Israel will bring ropes to that city, and we'll drag it into the river until not even a pebble is left."
10:17:14/Absalom and all the men of Israel concluded that Hushai the Archite's advice was better than Ahithophel's. The LORD had determined to undermine Ahithophel's sound advice, intending to bring disaster upon Absalom.
10:17:15/Then Hushai told priests Zadok and Abiathar, "Ahithophel advised Absalom and the elders of Israel this way, but I have advised them this way.
10:17:16/Now, send a message quickly to David, warning him not to stay tonight in the wilderness plains but to cross over immediately, to prevent him and all his people from being annihilated."
10:17:17/Jonathan and Ahimaaz stayed near Enrogel, as they couldn't risk being seen entering the city. A servant girl went to inform them, and they went to tell King David.
10:17:18/However, a young boy saw them and informed Absalom. But they quickly escaped to a house in Bahurim, which had a well in its courtyard where they hid.
10:17:19/The woman of the house covered the well's mouth with a cloth and scattered grain over it, so nothing seemed amiss.
10:17:20/When Absalom's servants arrived at the house and asked, "Where are Ahimaaz and Jonathan?" The woman lied, saying, "They crossed the brook." After searching and finding no trace of them, the servants returned to Jerusalem.
10:17:21/After the servants left, the two men climbed out of the well and went to inform King David, urging him, "Hurry and cross the water, because Ahithophel has advised against you."
10:17:22/David and all his followers then crossed the Jordan River. By dawn, not one was left who hadn't crossed.
10:17:23/When Ahithophel saw that his advice was not followed, he saddled his donkey, went home to his city, set his affairs in order, and hanged himself. He died and was buried in his family's tomb.
10:17:24/David reached Mahanaim, while Absalom and all the men of Israel crossed the Jordan River with him.
10:17:25/Absalom appointed Amasa over the army instead of Joab. Amasa was the son of a man named Ithra the Israelite, who had married Abigail, the daughter of Nahash and sister to Zeruiah, Joab's mother.
10:17:26/So Israel and Absalom camped in the land of Gilead.
10:17:27/When David arrived in Mahanaim, Shobi the son of Nahash from Rabbah of the Ammonites, Machir the son of Ammiel from Lo-debar, and Barzillai the Gileadite from Rogelim,
10:17:28/brought bedding, bowls, pottery, wheat, barley, flour, roasted grain, beans, lentils, and roasted seeds,
10:17:29/along with honey, butter, sheep, and cheese from cows, for David and his people to eat. They said, "The people are hungry, tired, and thirsty in the desert."
10:18:1/David took a census of the people with him, appointing leaders of thousands and hundreds over them.
10:18:2/David divided the troops into three groups: one under Joab's command, another under Abishai, Joab’s brother, and the last under Ittai the Gittite. David assured the people, "I will definitely join you in battle."
10:18:3/But the people insisted, "You must not go! If we have to retreat, they won't care about us; even if half of us die, it won't matter to them. But you are worth ten thousand of us. It's better for you to support us from the city."
10:18:4/David agreed, "I'll do what you think is best." He stood by the gate while the troops marched out in groups of hundreds and thousands.
10:18:5/David ordered Joab, Abishai, and Ittai, "For my sake, be gentle with the young man Absalom." Everyone heard the king's orders regarding Absalom.
10:18:6/The troops went out to battle against Israel in the forest of Ephraim.
10:18:7/The Israelite forces were defeated by David's servants, resulting in a massive loss of twenty thousand men that day.
10:18:8/The battle spread across the countryside, and the forest claimed more lives that day than the sword.
10:18:9/Absalom encountered David's men while riding a mule. The mule went under the thick branches of a large oak, and Absalom's head got caught in the oak, leaving him hanging between heaven and earth, while the mule ran off.
10:18:10/When a man saw this, he reported to Joab, "I saw Absalom hanging in an oak tree."
10:18:11/Joab asked the man, "You saw him? Why didn't you strike him down right there? I would have rewarded you with ten shekels of silver and a belt."
10:18:12/The man replied to Joab, "Even if you offered me a thousand shekels of silver, I wouldn't lay a hand on the king's son. We all heard the king instruct you, Abishai, and Ittai to protect Absalom for his sake."
10:18:13/"If I had acted against his life, I would have been endangering my own, since nothing is hidden from the king. You would have opposed me."
10:18:14/Joab said, "I can't waste time with you." He grabbed three darts and thrust them into Absalom's heart while he was still alive in the oak.
10:18:15/Ten of Joab's armor-bearers surrounded Absalom, struck him, and killed him.
10:18:16/Joab sounded the trumpet, and the troops stopped pursuing Israel, as Joab restrained them.
10:18:17/They took Absalom, threw him into a large pit in the forest, and piled a huge mound of stones over him. Meanwhile, all the Israelites fled to their homes.
10:18:18/While he was alive, Absalom had erected a monument for himself in the King's Valley, saying, "I have no son to keep my name alive." He named the monument after himself, and it is known as Absalom's Monument to this day.
10:18:19/Ahimaaz, son of Zadok, said, "Let me run and bring the king the news that the LORD has vindicated him by defeating his enemies."
10:18:20/Joab told him, "You will not carry the news today. You can do so another day, but today you will not, because the king's son is dead."
10:18:21/Joab then said to Cushi, "Go, inform the king of what you have seen." Cushi bowed to Joab and ran off.
10:18:22/Ahimaaz, son of Zadok, again pleaded with Joab, "Whatever happens, please let me also run after Cushi." Joab asked, "Why do you want to run, my son, when you have no message?"
10:18:23/"Regardless," he said, "I want to run." So Joab told him, "Run." Then Ahimaaz ran by the plain and outran Cushi.
10:18:24/David was sitting between the two gates when the watchman went up to the roof of the gate and saw a man running alone.
10:18:25/The watchman shouted down to inform the king, who said, "If he is alone, he brings news." The runner approached quickly.
10:18:26/Then the watchman saw another man running and called down to the gatekeeper, "Look, another man running alone!" The king said, "He also brings news."
10:18:27/The watchman said, "The first runner runs like Ahimaaz, son of Zadok." The king remarked, "He's a good man and comes with good news."
10:18:28/Ahimaaz called out to the king, "All is well!" He bowed down before the king with his face to the ground and said, "Praise be to the LORD your God, who has delivered up those who raised their hands against my lord the king."
10:18:29/The king asked, "Is the young man Absalom safe?" Ahimaaz replied, "I saw a great commotion when Joab sent the king's servant and me, but I didn't know what it was."
10:18:30/The king told him, "Step aside and stand here." He stepped aside and waited.
10:18:31/Then Cushi arrived and said, "My lord the king, hear the good news! The LORD has avenged you today against all who rebelled against you."
10:18:32/The king asked Cushi, "Is the young man Absalom safe?" Cushi replied, "May the enemies of my lord the king and all who rise against you to harm you be like that young man."
10:18:33/Deeply moved, the king went up to the chamber over the gate and wept. As he went, he cried, "Oh my son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom! If only I had died instead of you, oh Absalom, my son, my son!"
10:19:1/Joab was informed, "Look, the king is crying and mourning for Absalom."
10:19:2/And the joy of victory that day turned into sorrow for all the people, as they heard how deeply the king was grieving for his son.
10:19:3/The people sneaked back into the city that day, like those ashamed sneak away when they flee in battle.
10:19:4/But the king covered his face and cried out loudly, "O my son Absalom, O Absalom, my son, my son!"
10:19:5/Joab entered the king's house and said, "Today, you have embarrassed all your servants who saved your life, the lives of your sons and daughters, your wives, and your concubines;
10:19:6/Because you show love to your enemies and hate towards your friends. You've made it clear today that you care neither for your leaders nor your servants. Today, I see that if Absalom had lived and all of us had died, that would have been preferable to you."
10:19:7/"Now, get up, go out, and reassure your servants. I swear by the LORD, if you don't go out, not one person will stay with you tonight. And that will be worse for you than all the troubles you've faced from your youth until now."
10:19:8/Then the king got up and sat at the city gate. And it was announced to all the people, "Look, the king is sitting at the gate." And all the people came before the king. Meanwhile, Israel had scattered, each to his own home.
10:19:9/And all the people throughout the tribes of Israel were arguing, saying, "The king saved us from our enemies and delivered us from the Philistines, but now he has fled the land because of Absalom."
10:19:10/"And Absalom, whom we anointed as our leader, is dead in battle. So why are we not saying anything about bringing the king back?"
10:19:11/King David sent messages to Zadok and Abiathar, the priests, saying, "Talk to the elders of Judah and ask them, 'Why are you the last to bring the king back to his palace, when the call to do so has reached all Israel and his household?'"
10:19:12/"You are my kin, my own flesh and blood. So why are you the last to bring back the king?"
10:19:13/"And tell Amasa, 'Aren't you my flesh and blood too? May God deal with me, severely if you are not the commander of my army from now on in place of Joab.'"
10:19:14/He won over the hearts of all the men of Judah as if they were one man; they sent word to the king, "Return, you and all your servants."
10:19:15/So the king returned and came to the Jordan River. And the people of Judah came to Gilgal to meet the king and escort him across the Jordan.
10:19:16/Shimei son of Gera, a Benjamite from Bahurim, hurried down with the men of Judah to meet King David.
10:19:17/With him were a thousand men from Benjamin, along with Ziba, the steward of Saul's household, and his fifteen sons and twenty servants. They rushed to the Jordan before the king.
10:19:18/A ferry boat went across to carry the king's household and do whatever he wished. When Shimei son of Gera crossed the Jordan, he fell before the king
10:19:19/And said to the king, "Let my lord not hold me guilty, nor remember the wrong your servant did on the day my lord the king left Jerusalem. Please, let the king put it out of his mind.
10:19:20/For I, your servant, know I have sinned. But today, I am the first of all the house of Joseph to come down to meet my lord the king."
10:19:21/But Abishai son of Zeruiah said, "Shouldn't Shimei be put to death for this, since he cursed the LORD's anointed?"
10:19:22/David replied, "What is it to me, you sons of Zeruiah, that you become a nuisance today? Should anyone be put to death in Israel today? Don't I know that today I am king over Israel?"
10:19:23/Therefore, the king said to Shimei, "You shall not die." And the king swore an oath to him.
10:19:24/Mephibosheth, Saul's grandson, came down to meet the king. He had not cared for his feet, trimmed his beard, or washed his clothes from the day the king left until the day he returned safely.
10:19:25/When he came to Jerusalem to meet the king, the king asked him, "Why didn't you come with me, Mephibosheth?"
10:19:26/He replied, "My lord, O king, my servant deceived me. I said, 'I will saddle my donkey so I can ride on it and go with the king,' because I am lame.
10:19:27/But he slandered your servant to my lord the king. However, my lord the king is like an angel of God. So do what seems best to you.
10:19:28/All my father's household deserved nothing but death from my lord the king, but you placed your servant among those who eat at your table. So what right do I have to make any more appeals to the king?"
10:19:29/The king said to him, "Why speak any more of your affairs? I have decided: you and Ziba divide the land."
10:19:30/Mephibosheth said to the king, "Let him take everything, now that my lord the king has returned safely to his own home."
10:19:31/Barzillai the Gileadite came down from Rogelim and crossed the Jordan with the king to escort him over the Jordan.
10:19:32/Now Barzillai was very old, eighty years of age. He had provided for the king during his stay at Mahanaim, for he was a very wealthy man.
10:19:33/The king said to Barzillai, "Cross over with me, and I will provide for you with me in Jerusalem."
10:19:34/But Barzillai answered the king, "How many more years will I live, that I should go up with the king to Jerusalem?
10:19:35/I am eighty years old today. Can I tell the difference between what is enjoyable and what is not? Can your servant taste what he eats and drinks? Can I still hear the voices of singing men and women? Why then should your servant be an added burden to my lord the king?
10:19:36/Your servant will cross over the Jordan with the king for a short distance, but why should the king reward me with such a favor?
10:19:37/Please let your servant return, so I may die in my own city near the graves of my father and mother. But here is your servant Chimham; let him cross over with my lord the king, and do for him what you think is best."
10:19:38/The king answered, "Chimham will cross over with me, and I will do for him what seems best to you. And anything you request of me, I will do for you."
10:19:39/So all the people crossed the Jordan, and the king crossed over. The king kissed Barzillai and blessed him, and he returned to his own home.
10:19:40/Then the king continued to Gilgal, with Chimham accompanying him. All the people of Judah and also half the people of Israel escorted the king.
10:19:41/Then all the men of Israel came to the king and asked, "Why have our brothers, the men of Judah, secretly taken you away, along with your household and all David's men, across the Jordan?"
10:19:42/The men of Judah replied to the men of Israel, "Because the king is closely related to us. Why are you angry about this? Have we eaten at the king's expense, or has he given us any gifts?"
10:19:43/But the men of Israel answered the men of Judah, "We have ten shares in the king, and we have more claim on David than you. Why then did you treat us with contempt? Weren't we the first to suggest bringing back our king?" Yet the arguments of the men of Judah were more forceful than those of the men of Israel.
10:20:1/There was a troublemaker named Sheba, son of Bichri, from the tribe of Benjamin. He blew a trumpet and declared, "We have no share in David, no part in Jesse's son! Everyone back to their tents, O Israel!"
10:20:2/So all the men of Israel abandoned David and followed Sheba, son of Bichri. But the men of Judah remained loyal to their king, from the Jordan River all the way to Jerusalem.
10:20:3/When David returned to his palace in Jerusalem, he took the ten concubines he had left to care for the palace and placed them under house arrest. He provided for them, but did not visit them. They lived in isolation until they died, as if they were widows.
10:20:4/David then ordered Amasa, "Gather the men of Judah within three days, and make sure you are here too."
10:20:5/Amasa went to summon the men of Judah, but he took longer than the time David had set for him.
10:20:6/David said to Abishai, "Now Sheba, son of Bichri, will cause us more trouble than Absalom did. Take my men and chase after him before he finds fortified cities and escapes from us."
10:20:7/So Joab's men, along with the Cherethites, the Pelethites, and all the mighty warriors, left Jerusalem to pursue Sheba, son of Bichri.
10:20:8/When they were near the large rock in Gibeon, Amasa came to meet them. Joab was wearing his military garment with a belt that had a sword in its sheath. As he stepped forward, the sword fell out.
10:20:9/Joab greeted Amasa, "How are you, my brother?" And he grabbed Amasa's beard with his right hand as if to kiss him.
10:20:10/But Amasa didn't notice the sword in Joab's hand. Joab struck him with it in the stomach, spilling his intestines on the ground, and he didn't strike him again. Amasa died. Then Joab and his brother Abishai continued the pursuit of Sheba, son of Bichri.
10:20:11/One of Joab's men stood by Amasa's body and called out, "Whoever supports Joab and David, follow Joab!"
10:20:12/Amasa lay in his blood in the middle of the road. When the man saw that everyone was stopping to look, he dragged Amasa off the road into a field and covered him with a cloth.
10:20:13/Once Amasa was moved from the road, everyone followed Joab to chase after Sheba, son of Bichri.
10:20:14/They went through all the tribes of Israel to Abel, Beth Maacah, and all the Berites. They gathered together and followed Joab.

10:20:16/Then a wise woman called from the city, "Listen, listen! Please tell Joab to come here so I can speak to him."
10:20:17/When Joab approached, the woman asked, "Are you Joab?" He replied, "I am." Then she said, "Listen to what your servant has to say." He answered, "I'm listening."
10:20:18/She said, "In the past, people would say, 'Let them ask for advice in Abel,' and that's how disputes were settled.
10:20:19/I am one of the peaceful and faithful in Israel. You are trying to destroy a city that is a mother in Israel. Why do you want to destroy the LORD's inheritance?"
10:20:20/Joab responded, "Far from it, far from it for me to swallow up or destroy!
10:20:21/That's not the case. A man from the hill country of Ephraim, named Sheba son of Bichri, has rebelled against King David. Hand him over, and I'll withdraw from the city." The woman said to Joab, "His head will be thrown to you over the wall."
10:20:22/Then the woman went to all the people with her wisdom. They cut off the head of Sheba son of Bichri and threw it out to Joab. He then blew the trumpet, and they withdrew from the city, each to his tent. Joab returned to Jerusalem to the king.
10:20:23/Joab was in command of all the army of Israel; Benaiah son of Jehoiada was over the Cherethites and Pelethites;

10:20:26/And Ira the Jairite was David's chief advisor.
10:21:1/Then there was a famine during David's reign for three consecutive years; David sought the LORD's guidance. The LORD revealed it was due to Saul and his violent actions against the Gibeonites.
10:21:2/David summoned the Gibeonites and spoke to them. The Gibeonites were not Israelites but remnants of the Amorites. Despite Israel's oath to them, Saul had tried to eliminate them in his zeal for Israel and Judah.
10:21:3/So David asked the Gibeonites, "What can I do for you? How can I make amends so you will bless the LORD's inheritance?"
10:21:4/The Gibeonites replied, "We don't want silver or gold from Saul or his family, nor do we want you to kill anyone in Israel for us." David said, "Tell me what you want me to do for you."
10:21:5/They said, "The man who tried to exterminate us and plotted to wipe us out from staying anywhere in Israel's territory,
10:21:6/let seven of his male descendants be handed over to us, and we will execute them before the LORD in Gibeah of Saul, the chosen of the LORD." David agreed, "I will give them."
10:21:7/However, David spared Mephibosheth, the son of Jonathan, son of Saul, because of the sacred promise between David and Jonathan, Saul's son.
10:21:8/But David took the two sons of Rizpah, daughter of Aiah, whom she bore to Saul, Armoni and Mephibosheth; and the five sons of Michal, daughter of Saul, whom she raised for Adriel, son of Barzillai the Meholathite:
10:21:9/And handed them over to the Gibeonites, who executed them on a hill before the LORD. All seven died together, executed during the harvest, at the start of the barley harvest.
10:21:10/Rizpah, daughter of Aiah, laid out sackcloth on a rock from the start of the harvest until rain fell from the sky on the bodies, preventing birds from touching them by day or wild animals by night.
10:21:11/When David was told what Rizpah, daughter of Aiah, Saul's concubine, had done,
10:21:12/David retrieved the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan from the men of Jabesh-gilead, who had stolen them from the streets of Bethshan, where the Philistines had hung them after defeating Saul in Gilboa.
10:21:13/He brought back the bones of Saul and Jonathan; and they collected the bones of those who had been executed.
10:21:14/The bones of Saul and Jonathan were buried in the land of Benjamin in Zelah, in the tomb of Kish, Saul's father. They carried out all that the king commanded. Afterward, God was appeased for the land.
10:21:15/Additionally, the Philistines waged war against Israel again; David and his men went down to fight the Philistines, and David became exhausted.
10:21:16/Ishbibenob, a descendant of the giants, whose spear weighed 300 shekels of bronze and who was armed with a new sword, aimed to kill David.
10:21:17/But Abishai, son of Zeruiah, came to his rescue, struck down the Philistine, and killed him. Then David's men swore to him, "You must not go to battle with us again, so you don't extinguish the light of Israel."
10:21:18/After this, there was another battle with the Philistines at Gob: Sibbechai the Hushathite killed Saph, a descendant of the giants.
10:21:19/There was another battle with the Philistines in Gob, where Elhanan, son of Jaareoregim from Bethlehem, killed the brother of Goliath the Gittite, whose spear shaft was like a weaver's rod.
10:21:20/And in another battle in Gath, there was a giant with six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot, twenty-four in total; he too was descended from the giants.
10:21:21/When he taunted Israel, Jonathan, son of Shimeah, David's brother, killed him.
10:21:22/These four were descendants of the giants in Gath, and they fell by the hand of David and his servants.
10:22:1/And David spoke to the LORD the words of this song on the day the LORD had rescued him from the grasp of all his enemies, and from the hand of Saul:
10:22:2/And he said, The LORD is my rock, my fortress, and my rescuer;
10:22:3/The God of my rock; in him I will trust: he is my shield, the source of my salvation, my stronghold, and my refuge, my savior; you save me from violence.
10:22:4/I will call on the LORD, who deserves all praise: so I will be saved from my enemies.
10:22:5/When the waves of death surrounded me, the floods of wicked men made me afraid;
10:22:6/The sorrows of hell surrounded me; the snares of death confronted me;
10:22:7/In my distress I called upon the LORD, and cried out to my God: and he heard my voice from his temple, and my cry reached his ears.
10:22:8/Then the earth shook and quaked; the foundations of heaven moved and trembled, because he was angry.
10:22:9/Smoke rose from his nostrils, and consuming fire from his mouth; coals were ignited by it.
10:22:10/He parted the heavens and came down; and darkness was under his feet.
10:22:11/And he rode upon a cherub, and flew: and he was seen upon the wings of the wind.
10:22:12/And he made darkness his covering, dark waters, and thick clouds of the skies.
10:22:13/Through the brightness before him, coals of fire were ignited.
10:22:14/The LORD thundered from heaven, and the Most High voiced his presence.
10:22:15/And he shot out arrows, and scattered them; lightning, and confused them.
10:22:16/And the depths of the sea were revealed, the foundations of the world were uncovered, at the rebuke of the LORD, at the blast of the breath of his nostrils.
10:22:17/He reached down from on high, he took me; he drew me out of deep waters;
10:22:18/He rescued me from my powerful enemy, and from those who hated me: for they were too strong for me.
10:22:19/They confronted me in the day of my disaster: but the LORD was my support.
10:22:20/He also brought me out into a spacious place: he rescued me because he delighted in me.
10:22:21/The LORD rewarded me according to my righteousness: according to the purity of my hands he has repaid me.
10:22:22/For I have followed the ways of the LORD, and have not wickedly departed from my God.
10:22:23/For all his laws were before me: and I did not turn away from his statutes.
10:22:24/I was also blameless before him, and I kept myself from my sin.
10:22:25/Therefore the LORD has repaid me according to my righteousness; according to my purity in his eyes.
10:22:26/With the merciful you show yourself merciful, with the blameless man you show yourself blameless.
10:22:27/With the pure you show yourself pure; and with the devious you show yourself shrewd.
10:22:28/And the afflicted people you will save: but your eyes are on the haughty, to bring them down.
10:22:29/For you are my lamp, O LORD: and the LORD will illuminate my darkness.
10:22:30/For by you I have charged through a troop: by my God I have leaped over a wall.
10:22:31/As for God, his way is perfect; the word of the LORD is flawless: he is a shield to all who trust in him.
10:22:32/For who is God, besides the LORD? and who is a rock, except our God?
10:22:33/God is my strength and power: and he makes my path perfect.
10:22:34/He makes my feet like the feet of a deer: and sets me on my high places.
10:22:35/He trains my hands for battle; so that my arms can bend a bow of bronze.
10:22:36/You have also given me the shield of your salvation: and your gentleness has made me great.
10:22:37/You have broadened my steps beneath me; so that my feet did not slip.
10:22:38/I pursued my enemies and destroyed them; and did not turn back until they were consumed.
10:22:39/And I have consumed them, and wounded them, so they could not rise: yes, they have fallen under my feet.
10:22:40/For you have equipped me with strength for the battle: those who rose up against me you have subdued under me.
10:22:41/You have also given me the necks of my enemies, that I might destroy those who hate me.
10:22:42/They looked, but there was no one to save; even to the LORD, but he did not answer them.
10:22:43/Then I beat them as fine as the dust of the earth, I crushed them and stamped them down like mud in the streets, and spread them out.
10:22:44/You also have delivered me from the conflicts of my people, you have kept me to be the head of nations: a people I had not known shall serve me.
10:22:45/Foreigners shall submit to me: as soon as they hear, they shall obey me.
10:22:46/Foreigners shall lose heart, and come trembling out of their fortresses.
10:22:47/The LORD lives; and blessed be my rock; and let the God of my salvation be exalted.
10:22:48/It is God who avenges me, and subdues peoples under me.
10:22:49/And who brings me out from my enemies: you also have lifted me up high above those who rose against me; you have delivered me from the violent man.
10:22:50/Therefore I will give thanks to you, O LORD, among the nations, and I will sing praises to your name.
10:22:51/He gives great victories to his king; and shows steadfast love to his anointed, to David and his descendants forever.
10:23:1/Now these are the last words of David. David, the son of Jesse, spoke, the man who was elevated, the anointed by the God of Jacob, and Israel's beloved songwriter, said,
10:23:2/The Spirit of the LORD spoke through me, and his word was on my tongue.
10:23:3/The God of Israel spoke, the Rock of Israel said to me: One who rules over people must be just, governing in the fear of God.
10:23:4/And he will be like the light of the morning when the sun rises, a morning without clouds; like the fresh grass sprouting from the earth after a clear rain.
10:23:5/Even though my family is not perfect in God's eyes; he has established an everlasting covenant with me, organized in every detail and secure. This is all my salvation and all my desire, even though he does not make it flourish.
10:23:6/But the worthless shall be completely like thorns cast away, for they cannot be picked up with the hand.
10:23:7/But anyone who touches them must be armed with iron and the shaft of a spear; they will be completely burned with fire in their place.
10:23:8/Here are the names of the mighty warriors whom David had: The Tachmonite who sat in the chief seat, among the captains; this was Adino the Eznite, who struck down eight hundred men in one encounter.
10:23:9/Next to him was Eleazar the son of Dodo the Ahohite, one of the three mighty warriors with David when they challenged the Philistines gathered there for battle, and the men of Israel had retreated.
10:23:10/He stood up and struck the Philistines until his hand grew tired and stuck to his sword. The LORD brought about a great victory that day, and the people returned after him only to collect the plunder.
10:23:11/Next to him was Shammah the son of Agee the Hararite. When the Philistines banded together at a plot of ground full of lentils, and the troops fled from the Philistines,
10:23:12/He stood in the middle of the field, defended it, and struck down the Philistines. And the LORD brought about a great victory.
10:23:13/Three of the thirty chiefs went down to David during the harvest time to the cave of Adullam, while a band of Philistines was camped in the Valley of Rephaim.
10:23:14/At that time, David was in a stronghold, and the Philistine garrison was at Bethlehem.
10:23:15/David longed and said, "Oh, that someone would get me a drink of water from the well near the gate of Bethlehem!"
10:23:16/So the three mighty warriors broke through the Philistine lines, drew water from the well near the gate of Bethlehem, and carried it back to David. But he refused to drink it; instead, he poured it out to the LORD.
10:23:17/He said, "The LORD forbid that I should do this! Isn't this the blood of the men who went at the risk of their lives?" So he would not drink it. These things were done by the three mighty warriors.
10:23:18/Abishai, the brother of Joab, the son of Zeruiah, was the leader of the three. He raised his spear against three hundred men, killed them, and became famous among the three.
10:23:19/Wasn't he the most honored of the three? Therefore, he became their commander, but he did not attain to the first three.
10:23:20/Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, the son of a valiant man from Kabzeel, who performed great deeds, he struck down two of Moab's mightiest warriors. He also went down into a pit on a snowy day and killed a lion.
10:23:21/And he killed an impressive Egyptian. The Egyptian had a spear in his hand, but Benaiah went down to him with a staff, snatched the spear from the Egyptian's hand, and killed him with his own spear.
10:23:22/These were the exploits of Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, who earned a name among the three mighty warriors.
10:23:23/He was more honored than the thirty, but he did not attain to the first three. And David put him in charge of his bodyguard.
10:23:24/Asahel the brother of Joab was one of the thirty; Elhanan the son of Dodo of Bethlehem,
10:23:25/Shammah the Harodite, Elika the Harodite,
10:23:26/Helez the Paltite, Ira the son of Ikkesh the Tekoite,
10:23:27/Abiezer the Anethothite, Mebunnai the Hushathite,
10:23:28/Zalmon the Ahohite, Maharai the Netophathite,
10:23:29/Heleb the son of Baanah, a Netophathite, Ittai the son of Ribai from Gibeah of the children of Benjamin,
10:23:30/Benaiah the Pirathonite, Hiddai from the brooks of Gaash,
10:23:31/Abialbon the Arbathite, Azmaveth the Barhumite,
10:23:32/Eliahba the Shaalbonite, of the sons of Jashen, Jonathan,
10:23:33/Shammah the Hararite, Ahiam the son of Sharar the Hararite,
10:23:34/Eliphelet the son of Ahasbai, the son of the Maachathite, Eliam the son of Ahithophel the Gilonite,
10:23:35/Hezrai the Carmelite, Paarai the Arbite,
10:23:36/Igal the son of Nathan from Zobah, Bani the Gadite,
10:23:37/Zelek the Ammonite, Nahari the Beerothite, armor-bearer to Joab the son of Zeruiah,
10:23:38/Ira an Ithrite, Gareb an Ithrite,
10:23:39/Uriah the Hittite: thirty-seven in all.
10:24:1/Once again, the LORD's anger flared up against Israel, prompting him to incite David to say, "Go, count Israel and Judah."
10:24:2/The king instructed Joab, the commander of his army, "Travel through all the tribes of Israel, from Dan to Beersheba, and take a census of the people, so I can know their number."
10:24:3/Joab responded to the king, "May the LORD your God increase the number of the people a hundred times over, and may you live to see it. But why does this please you, my lord the king?"
10:24:4/Despite this, the king's command overruled Joab and the army commanders. So Joab and the commanders left the king's presence to count the people of Israel.
10:24:5/They crossed the Jordan and camped in Aroer, to the south of the city in the middle of the Gad valley, and then moved toward Jazer.
10:24:6/Then they went through Gilead and the region of Tahtimhodshi, passed by Danjaan, and around Sidon,
10:24:7/They reached the fortress of Tyre and visited all the cities of the Hivites and Canaanites. Finally, they went to the southern part of Judah, to Beersheba.
10:24:8/After traversing the entire land, they returned to Jerusalem nine months and twenty days later.
10:24:9/Joab reported the census results to the king: there were 800,000 valiant warriors in Israel who could wield a sword, and the men of Judah numbered 500,000.
