10:24:10/Afterward, David felt remorse for having counted the people and said to the LORD, "I have greatly sinned in what I have done. Now, I beg you, O LORD, to forgive the sin of your servant, for I have acted very foolishly."
10:24:11/When David got up the next morning, the word of the LORD came to the prophet Gad, David's seer, saying,
10:24:12/"Go and tell David, 'This is what the LORD says: I am offering you three options; choose one of them for me to carry out against you.'"
10:24:13/So Gad went to David and told him, "Shall seven years of famine come to your land? Or will you flee for three months before your enemies while they pursue you? Or shall there be three days of plague in your land? Think it over and decide what answer I should give to the one who sent me."
10:24:14/David said to Gad, "I am in deep distress. Let us fall into the hands of the LORD, for his mercy is great; but do not let me fall into human hands."
10:24:15/Therefore, the LORD sent a plague on Israel from that morning until the appointed time, and seventy thousand men from Dan to Beersheba died.
10:24:16/When the angel extended his hand toward Jerusalem to destroy it, the LORD relented from the calamity and said to the angel who was striking down the people, "Enough! Withdraw your hand." The angel of the LORD was then near the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.
10:24:17/Seeing the angel who was striking the people, David said to the LORD, "I am the one who has sinned and acted wickedly. But these sheep, what have they done? Please let your hand be against me and my family, not against your people."
10:24:18/That day, Gad came to David and said to him, "Go up and build an altar to the LORD on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite."
10:24:19/David went up as the LORD had commanded through Gad.
10:24:20/When Araunah saw the king and his servants approaching, he went out and bowed down before the king with his face to the ground.
10:24:21/Araunah asked, "Why has my lord the king come to his servant?" David replied, "To buy the threshing floor from you, to build an altar to the LORD, so the plague may be halted among the people."
10:24:22/Araunah said to David, "Let my lord the king take and offer up whatever seems good to him. Here are oxen for the burnt offering, and the threshing sledges and yokes of the oxen for wood."
10:24:23/"All this, O king, Araunah gives to the king." And Araunah said to the king, "May the LORD your God accept you."
10:24:24/But the king said to Araunah, "No, I insist on buying it from you at a price. I will not offer burnt offerings to the LORD my God that cost me nothing." So David bought the threshing floor and the oxen for fifty shekels of silver.
10:24:25/And David built an altar there to the LORD and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings. Thus, the LORD was moved on behalf of the land, and the plague was stopped from afflicting Israel.
11:1:1/Now King David was old and advanced in years; despite being covered with clothes, he could not stay warm.
11:1:2/So his servants suggested, "Let's find a young virgin for my lord the king; she can take care of him and lie close to him so the king may stay warm."
11:1:3/They searched throughout all Israel for a beautiful young woman and found Abishag the Shunammite, bringing her to the king.
11:1:4/The young woman was very beautiful, took care of the king, and served him, but the king did not have sexual relations with her.
11:1:5/Then Adonijah, son of Haggith, declared himself king. He acquired chariots, horsemen, and fifty men to run ahead of him.
11:1:6/His father had never questioned his actions, asking, "Why do you behave this way?" He was also very handsome, born after Absalom.
11:1:7/He consulted with Joab, son of Zeruiah, and with Abiathar the priest, who supported Adonijah's claim.
11:1:8/But Zadok the priest, Benaiah son of Jehoiada, Nathan the prophet, Shimei, Rei, and David's elite warriors did not support Adonijah.
11:1:9/Adonijah sacrificed sheep, oxen, and fattened cattle near the stone of Zoheleth by Enrogel, inviting all his brothers, the king's sons, and all the men of Judah, the king's servants.
11:1:10/However, he did not invite Nathan the prophet, Benaiah, the elite warriors, or Solomon his brother.
11:1:11/Therefore, Nathan spoke to Bathsheba, Solomon's mother, "Have you not heard that Adonijah, son of Haggith, has become king without our lord David knowing it?
11:1:12/Now let me advise you on how to save your life and the life of your son Solomon.
11:1:13/Go and enter King David's presence, and say to him, 'My lord, O king, did you not promise your servant that Solomon your son would succeed you as king and sit on your throne? Why then has Adonijah become king?'
11:1:14/While you are still speaking with the king, I will come in and confirm your words."
11:1:15/Bathsheba went to see the king in his room, where he was very old, and Abishag the Shunammite was serving him.
11:1:16/Bathsheba bowed and paid homage to the king. The king asked, "What do you wish?"
11:1:17/She replied, "My lord, you swore by the LORD your God to your servant that Solomon your son would succeed you as king and sit on your throne.
11:1:18/But now, Adonijah has become king, and you, my lord the king, are unaware.
11:1:19/He has sacrificed oxen, fattened cattle, and sheep in abundance, and has invited all the king's sons, Abiathar the priest, and Joab the commander of the army, but he has not invited Solomon your servant.
11:1:20/Now, my lord, O king, all Israel is looking to you to announce who will sit on the throne of my lord the king after him.
11:1:21/If you do not act, when my lord the king rests with his ancestors, I and my son Solomon will be treated as criminals."
11:1:22/While she was still speaking with the king, Nathan the prophet arrived.
11:1:23/They informed the king, "Nathan the prophet is here." When he entered the king's presence, he bowed before the king with his face to the ground.
11:1:24/Nathan said, "My lord, O king, have you declared that Adonijah will succeed you as king and sit on your throne?
11:1:25/Today he has gone down and sacrificed oxen, fattened cattle, and sheep in abundance. He has invited all the king's sons, the commanders of the army, and Abiathar the priest. Right now, they are eating and drinking with him and saying, 'Long live King Adonijah!'
11:1:26/But he did not invite me, your servant, Zadok the priest, Benaiah son of Jehoiada, or your servant Solomon.
11:1:27/Is this action authorized by my lord the king without you informing your servant who should sit on the throne of my lord the king after him?"
11:1:28/Then King David responded, "Call Bathsheba to me." She came into the king's presence and stood before him.
11:1:29/The king swore, "As the LORD lives, who has delivered my soul from every trouble,
11:1:30/just as I swore to you by the LORD, the God of Israel, saying, 'Solomon your son shall succeed me as king, and he will sit on my throne in my place,' I will indeed fulfill this promise today."
11:1:31/Then Bathsheba bowed with her face to the ground, paying homage to the king, and said, "May my lord King David live forever!"
11:1:32/King David said, "Summon Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah son of Jehoiada." When they came before the king,
11:1:33/the king instructed them, "Take the servants of your lord with you, have Solomon my son ride on my own mule, and take him down to Gihon.
11:1:34/There, let Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet anoint him as king over Israel. Blow the trumpet and proclaim, 'Long live King Solomon!'
11:1:35/Then follow him up, and he will come and sit on my throne, for he will be king in my place. I have appointed him to be ruler over Israel and Judah."
11:1:36/Benaiah son of Jehoiada replied to the king, "Amen! May the LORD, the God of my lord the king, endorse this decision.
11:1:37/May the LORD be with Solomon as he has been with my lord the king, and may he make Solomon's throne even greater than the throne of my lord King David."
11:1:38/So Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, Benaiah son of Jehoiada, the Cherethites, and the Pelethites went down and had Solomon ride on King David's mule to Gihon.
11:1:39/Zadok the priest took a horn of oil from the tabernacle and anointed Solomon. They blew the trumpet, and all the people proclaimed, "Long live King Solomon!"
11:1:40/All the people followed him, playing flutes and celebrating with great joy, so that the ground shook with their noise.
11:1:41/Adonijah and all the guests with him heard it just as they finished eating. When Joab heard the sound of the trumpet, he asked, "Why does the city sound like it's in chaos?"
11:1:42/As he was speaking, Jonathan, son of Abiathar the priest, arrived. Adonijah said, "Come in, for you are a brave man and must be bringing good news."
11:1:43/Jonathan replied to Adonijah, "Actually, our lord King David has made Solomon king.
11:1:44/The king has sent with him Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, Benaiah son of Jehoiada, the Cherethites, and the Pelethites, and they have made him ride on the king's mule.
11:1:45/Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet have anointed him king at Gihon. They have come up from there celebrating, and the city is buzzing with excitement. That's the noise you heard.
11:1:46/Moreover, Solomon now sits on the royal throne.
11:1:47/Furthermore, the king's servants came to congratulate our lord King David, saying, 'May your God make Solomon's name more renowned than yours and his throne greater than your throne.' And the king bowed in worship on his bed.
11:1:48/And the king also said, 'Praise be to the LORD, the God of Israel, who has allowed someone to sit on my throne today, my own eyes seeing it.'"
11:1:49/All of Adonijah's guests panicked and dispersed in every direction.
11:1:50/Adonijah, fearing Solomon, got up and went to grasp the horns of the altar.
11:1:51/It was reported to Solomon, "Adonijah is afraid of King Solomon and has seized the horns of the altar, saying, 'Let King Solomon swear to me today that he will not kill his servant with the sword.'"
11:1:52/Solomon responded, "If he proves to be a worthy man, not a single hair of his will fall to the ground. But if evil is found in him, he will die."
11:1:53/So King Solomon sent for him, and they brought him down from the altar. He came and bowed down to King Solomon, and Solomon said to him, "Go to your home."
11:2:1/As David's time to die approached, he gave these instructions to his son Solomon,
11:2:2/"My time has come to follow the path all people must take. Be strong and show yourself to be a man.
11:2:3/Obey the LORD your God by following His ways and keeping His commands, rules, and laws as written in the Law of Moses. This will ensure you succeed in all you do and wherever you go.
11:2:4/Then the LORD will keep His promise to me: 'If your descendants are careful in their actions and live truthfully before me with all their heart and soul, you will never lack a successor on the throne of Israel.'
11:2:5/Remember what Joab son of Zeruiah did to me and what he did to the two commanders of Israel's armies—Abner son of Ner and Amasa son of Jether—killing them in peacetime as if it were war, staining his belt and sandals with their blood.
11:2:6/Act according to your wisdom, but do not let his gray head go to the grave in peace.
11:2:7/But show kindness to the sons of Barzillai the Gileadite and let them be among those who eat at your table, for they stood by me when I fled from your brother Absalom.
11:2:8/And remember Shimei son of Gera, the Benjaminite from Bahurim, who cursed me with a vicious curse on the day I went to Mahanaim. Though he came down to meet me at the Jordan River, and I swore to him by the LORD, 'I will not put you to death with the sword,'
11:2:9/now do not consider him innocent. You are a wise man; you will know what to do to him. Bring his gray head down to the grave in blood."
11:2:10/So David rested with his ancestors and was buried in the City of David.
11:2:11/David ruled over Israel for forty years: seven years in Hebron and thirty-three years in Jerusalem.
11:2:12/Then Solomon sat on the throne of his father David, and his kingdom was firmly established.
11:2:13/Adonijah, son of Haggith, went to Bathsheba, Solomon's mother. She asked, "Do you come peacefully?" He answered, "Peacefully."
11:2:14/He then said, "I have something to say to you." She replied, "Go ahead."
11:2:15/He said, "You know the kingdom was mine and all Israel looked to me as their king. However, the kingdom has turned to my brother, for it was his from the LORD.
11:2:16/Now I have one request to make of you. Do not refuse me." She said, "Go on."
11:2:17/He said, "Please ask King Solomon—he will not refuse you—to give me Abishag the Shunammite as my wife."
11:2:18/Bathsheba replied, "Very well, I will speak to the king for you."
11:2:19/So Bathsheba went to King Solomon to speak to him on behalf of Adonijah. The king stood up to meet her, bowed down to her, then sat on his throne. He had a throne brought for the king's mother, and she sat at his right hand.
11:2:20/Then she said, "I have one small request to make of you. Do not refuse me." The king replied, "Ask, my mother; I will not refuse you."
11:2:21/She said, "Let Abishag the Shunammite be given to your brother Adonijah as his wife."
11:2:22/King Solomon answered his mother, "Why do you request Abishag the Shunammite for Adonijah? You might as well request the kingdom for him, since he is my older brother, and for Abiathar the priest and Joab son of Zeruiah."
11:2:23/Then King Solomon swore by the LORD, "May God deal with me, be it ever so severely, if Adonijah has not made this request at the cost of his life.
11:2:24/Now, as the LORD lives, who has established me securely on the throne of my father David and has founded a dynasty for me as He promised, Adonijah shall be put to death today."
11:2:25/And King Solomon sent Benaiah son of Jehoiada, and he struck down Adonijah, and he died.
11:2:26/To Abiathar the priest, the king said, "Go to Anathoth, to your own fields. You deserve death, but I will not put you to death now because you carried the ark of the Sovereign LORD before my father David and because you shared in all my father's hardships."
11:2:27/So Solomon removed Abiathar from being the LORD's priest, fulfilling the word the LORD had spoken at Shiloh about the house of Eli.
11:2:28/When the news reached Joab—for Joab had sided with Adonijah though he had not sided with Absalom—he fled to the tent of the LORD and took hold of the horns of the altar.
11:2:29/It was reported to King Solomon that Joab had fled to the tent of the LORD and was beside the altar. Then Solomon ordered Benaiah son of Jehoiada, "Go, strike him down."
11:2:30/So Benaiah entered the tent of the LORD and said to Joab, "The king says, 'Come out.'" But he answered, "No, I will die here." Benaiah reported back to the king, saying, "This is what Joab said, and this is how he answered me."
11:2:31/The king commanded Benaiah, "Do as he says. Strike him down and bury him. This will remove from me and my father's house the guilt for the innocent blood Joab shed.
11:2:32/The LORD will bring his blood back on his own head because he attacked two men more righteous and better than himself and killed them with the sword without my father David knowing it: Abner son of Ner, commander of Israel's army, and Amasa son of Jether, commander of Judah's army.
11:2:33/Their blood will return upon Joab's head and on his descendants forever. But for David, his descendants, his house, and his throne, there will be peace from the LORD forever."
11:2:34/So Benaiah son of Jehoiada went up, struck down Joab, and killed him. He was buried at his home in the desert.
11:2:35/The king put Benaiah son of Jehoiada over the army in Joab's position and installed Zadok the priest in the place of Abiathar.
11:2:36/The king then summoned Shimei and told him, "Build yourself a house in Jerusalem and live there. Do not leave the city.
11:2:37/For on the day you leave and cross the Kidron Valley, know for certain you will surely die; your blood will be on your own head."
11:2:38/Shimei responded to the king, "What you say is good. As my lord the king has said, so will your servant do." And Shimei lived in Jerusalem for many days.
11:2:39/But three years later, two of Shimei's slaves ran away to Achish son of Maakah, king of Gath. They told Shimei, "Your slaves are in Gath."
11:2:40/So Shimei saddled his donkey and went to Achish at Gath to find his slaves. Shimei found them and brought them back from Gath.
11:2:41/When Solomon was told that Shimei had gone from Jerusalem to Gath and had returned,
11:2:42/the king summoned Shimei and said to him, "Did I not make you swear by the LORD and warn you, 'On the day you leave and go anywhere else, you will surely die'? And you said to me, 'The word I have heard is good.'
11:2:43/Why then have you not kept your oath to the LORD and the command I gave you?"
11:2:44/The king also said to Shimei, "You know in your heart all the wrong you did to my father David. Now the LORD will repay you for your wickedness.
11:2:45/But King Solomon will be blessed, and the throne of David will be secure before the LORD forever."
11:2:46/Then the king commanded Benaiah son of Jehoiada, who went out and struck down Shimei, and he died. The kingdom was now firmly in Solomon's control.
11:3:1/Solomon formed an alliance with Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, by marrying Pharaoh's daughter. He brought her to the city of David until he finished building his palace, the temple of the LORD, and the surrounding walls of Jerusalem.
11:3:2/However, the people still offered sacrifices at high places because there was no temple dedicated to the LORD at that time.
11:3:3/Solomon was devoted to the LORD, following the practices of his father David, except that he offered sacrifices and burned incense at the high places.
11:3:4/The king went to Gibeon to offer sacrifices because it was the most important high place. Solomon offered a thousand burnt offerings on that altar.
11:3:5/While in Gibeon, the LORD appeared to Solomon in a dream at night. God said, "Ask for whatever you want me to give you."
11:3:6/Solomon replied, "You have shown great kindness to your servant, my father David, because he was faithful to you and righteous and upright in heart. You have continued this great kindness to him and have given him a son to sit on his throne this very day."
11:3:7/Now, LORD my God, you have made your servant king in place of my father David. But I am only a young man and do not know how to carry out my duties.
11:3:8/Your servant is here among the people you have chosen, a great people, too numerous to count or number.
11:3:9/So give your servant a discerning heart to govern your people and to distinguish between right and wrong. For who is able to govern this great people of yours?"
11:3:10/The LORD was pleased that Solomon had asked for this.
11:3:11/So God said to him, "Since you have asked for this and not for long life or wealth for yourself, nor have asked for the death of your enemies but for discernment in administering justice,
11:3:12/I will do what you have asked. I will give you a wise and discerning heart, so that there will never have been anyone like you, nor will there ever be.
11:3:13/Moreover, I will give you what you have not asked for—both wealth and honor—so that in your lifetime you will have no equal among kings.
11:3:14/If you walk in obedience to me and keep my decrees and commands as David your father did, I will give you a long life."
11:3:15/Solomon awoke and realized it was a dream. He returned to Jerusalem, stood before the ark of the LORD's covenant, and offered burnt offerings and fellowship offerings. Then he gave a feast for all his court.
11:3:16/Two women who were prostitutes came to the king and stood before him.
11:3:17/One of the women said, "My lord, this woman and I live in the same house. I gave birth to a child while she was in the house.
11:3:18/Three days after my child was born, this woman also gave birth. We were alone; there was no one else with us in the house.
11:3:19/But this woman's child died during the night because she lay on it.
11:3:20/She got up in the middle of the night and took my son from my side while I, your servant, was asleep. She put him by her breast and put her dead son by my breast.
11:3:21/The next morning, I got up to nurse my son, and he was dead. But when I looked at him closely in the morning light, I saw that it wasn't the son I had borne."
11:3:22/The other woman interrupted, "No! The living one is my son; the dead one is yours." But the first one insisted, "No, the dead one is yours; the living one is mine." And so they argued before the king.
11:3:23/The king said, "This one says, 'My son is alive and your son is dead,' while that one says, 'No, your son is dead and mine is alive.'"
11:3:24/Then the king commanded, "Bring me a sword." So they brought a sword for the king.
11:3:25/He then ordered, "Cut the living child in two and give half to one and half to the other."
11:3:26/The woman whose son was alive was deeply moved out of love for her son and said to the king, "Please, my lord, give her the living baby! Don't kill him!" But the other said, "Neither I nor you shall have him. Cut him in two!"
11:3:27/Then the king gave his ruling: "Give the living baby to the first woman. Do not kill him; she is his mother."
11:3:28/When all Israel heard the verdict the king had given, they held the king in awe, because they saw that he had wisdom from God to administer justice.
11:4:1/So King Solomon ruled over all Israel.
11:4:2/His top officials were Azariah, the son of Zadok the priest,
11:4:3/Elihoreph and Ahiah, sons of Shisha, secretaries; Jehoshaphat, the son of Ahilud, the historian.
11:4:4/And Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, was in charge of the army; Zadok and Abiathar were the priests.
11:4:5/Azariah, the son of Nathan, was in charge of the district governors; Zabud, the son of Nathan, was a principal officer and the king's close advisor.
11:4:6/Ahishar was in charge of the palace; and Adoniram, the son of Abda, was in charge of forced labor.
11:4:7/Solomon had twelve district governors over all Israel, who supplied provisions for the king and his household; each one had to provide supplies for one month in the year.
11:4:8/Their names were: The son of Hur, in the hill country of Ephraim;
11:4:9/The son of Dekar, in Makaz, Shaalbim, Beth Shemesh, and Elonbethhanan;
11:4:10/The son of Hesed, in Aruboth; he also had Sochoh and the whole territory of Hepher;
11:4:11/The son of Abinadab, in all the region of Dor; he had Taphath, Solomon's daughter, as his wife.
11:4:12/Baana, the son of Ahilud, had Taanach, Megiddo, and all Beth Shean next to Zarethan below Jezreel, from Beth Shean to Abel Meholah across to Jokmeam;
11:4:13/The son of Geber, in Ramoth Gilead; he had the towns of Jair, the son of Manasseh, in Gilead, and he also controlled the region of Argob in Bashan, sixty large cities with walls and bronze gate bars;
11:4:14/Ahinadab, the son of Iddo, had Mahanaim;
11:4:15/Ahimaaz was in Naphtali; he also married Basmath, Solomon's daughter;
11:4:16/Baanah, the son of Hushai, was in Asher and Aloth;
11:4:17/Jehoshaphat, the son of Paruah, in Issachar;
11:4:18/Shimei, the son of Elah, in Benjamin;
11:4:19/Geber, the son of Uri, was in the land of Gilead, the territory of Sihon king of the Amorites and of Og king of Bashan; he was the only governor in the land.
11:4:20/Judah and Israel were numerous, like the sand by the sea in abundance, enjoying and feasting.
11:4:21/And Solomon ruled over all the kingdoms from the river to the land of the Philistines, as far as the border of Egypt; they brought tribute and served Solomon all his life.
11:4:22/Solomon's daily provisions were thirty cors of fine flour and sixty cors of meal,
11:4:23/Ten fattened oxen, twenty pasture-fed oxen, and a hundred sheep, besides deer, gazelles, roebucks, and choice poultry.
11:4:24/He had dominion over everything west of the River, from Tiphsah to Gaza, over all the kings west of the River; and he had peace on all sides around him.
11:4:25/And Judah and Israel lived in safety, each person under their own vine and fig tree, from Dan to Beersheba, all the days of Solomon.
11:4:26/Solomon had forty thousand stalls for his chariot horses and twelve thousand horsemen.
11:4:27/These district governors each in his month supplied provisions for King Solomon and all who came to King Solomon's table; they made sure nothing was lacking.
11:4:28/They also brought barley and straw for the horses and swift steeds to the place where it was required, each according to his responsibility.
11:4:29/And God gave Solomon exceptionally great wisdom and understanding, and a breadth of mind like the sand on the seashore.
11:4:30/Solomon's wisdom surpassed the wisdom of all the people of the East and all the wisdom of Egypt.
11:4:31/He was wiser than anyone else, including Ethan the Ezrahite, and Heman, Calcol, and Darda, the sons of Mahol; and his fame spread to all the surrounding nations.
11:4:32/He spoke three thousand proverbs and his songs numbered a thousand and five.
11:4:33/He spoke about plants, from the cedar of Lebanon to the hyssop that grows out of walls. He also spoke about animals, birds, reptiles, and fish.
11:4:34/People from all nations came to listen to Solomon's wisdom, sent by all the kings of the earth who had heard of his wisdom.
11:5:1/And Hiram king of Tyre sent his servants to Solomon; for he had heard that they had anointed him king in place of his father: for Hiram was always a great friend of David.
11:5:2/And Solomon sent to Hiram, saying,
11:5:3/You know how my father David couldn't build a house for the name of the LORD his God because of the wars surrounding him on all sides, until the LORD put his enemies under his feet.
11:5:4/But now the LORD my God has given me peace on all sides, with no adversaries or misfortune.
11:5:5/And, look, I plan to build a house for the name of the LORD my God, as the LORD told my father David, saying, 'Your son, whom I will place on your throne in your place, will build the house for my name.'
11:5:6/So now, please order that cedar trees be cut down for me from Lebanon; and my servants will join your servants: and I will pay you for your servants whatever you decide: for you know that there is no one among us who can cut timber like the Sidonians.
11:5:7/And when Hiram heard Solomon's message, he was very happy and said, "Praise be to the LORD today, who has given David a wise son to lead this great nation."
11:5:8/And Hiram sent to Solomon, saying, "I have considered your request and will do all you desire regarding cedar and fir timber.
11:5:9/My servants will bring them down from Lebanon to the sea; and I will transport them by sea in rafts to the place you specify, and have them unloaded there. You will then receive them, and you will fulfill my wish by providing food for my household."
11:5:10/So Hiram provided Solomon with all the cedar and fir trees he wanted.
11:5:11/And Solomon gave Hiram twenty thousand measures of wheat for his household and twenty measures of pure oil: this Solomon gave to Hiram year after year.
11:5:12/And the LORD gave Solomon wisdom, as promised: and there was peace between Hiram and Solomon; and they formed an alliance.
11:5:13/And King Solomon conscripted a labor force from all Israel; and the labor force was thirty thousand men.
11:5:14/He sent them to Lebanon, ten thousand a month in shifts: they spent one month in Lebanon and two months at home: and Adoniram was in charge of the labor force.
11:5:15/And Solomon had seventy thousand who carried loads and eighty thousand stonecutters in the hills;
11:5:16/Besides Solomon's chief officers who were over the work, three thousand three hundred, who supervised the people working on the project.
11:5:17/And the king ordered them to quarry large, expensive stones to lay the foundation of the temple.
11:5:18/And Solomon's builders and Hiram's builders cut them, and the stonecutters: so they prepared timber and stones to build the temple.
11:6:1/In the 480th year after the Israelites left Egypt, during the fourth year of Solomon's reign over Israel, in the month of Zif (the second month), Solomon began to build the LORD's temple.
11:6:2/The temple King Solomon built for the LORD was 60 cubits long, 20 cubits wide, and 30 cubits high.
11:6:3/The entrance porch in front of the temple was 20 cubits long, matching the width of the temple, and 10 cubits deep.
11:6:4/He made windows with narrow openings for the temple.
11:6:5/He built side rooms all around the walls of the temple, surrounding both the main hall and the inner sanctuary, creating a series of rooms.
11:6:6/The lowest row of rooms was five cubits wide, the middle row six cubits wide, and the top row seven cubits wide. He made offset ledges in the temple walls so that the beams wouldn't need to be inserted into the walls.
11:6:7/The temple was constructed with pre-cut stones, so there was no sound of hammers, axes, or any iron tools at the building site.
11:6:8/The entrance to the middle floor was on the south side of the temple, with winding stairs leading up to the middle level and from there to the top level.
11:6:9/He completed the temple, roofing it with beams and cedar planks.
11:6:10/He also built side rooms all around the temple, each five cubits high, which were attached to the temple with cedar timbers.
11:6:11/And the LORD spoke to Solomon, saying,
11:6:12/"Regarding this temple you are building, if you follow my decrees, carry out my regulations, and keep all my commands, I will fulfill my promise to you as I did to your father David.
11:6:13/I will dwell among the Israelites and will not abandon my people Israel."
11:6:14/So Solomon completed the temple.
11:6:15/He paneled the interior walls of the temple with cedar boards, covering the floor of the temple with pine planks.
11:6:16/He built 20 cubits of the rear part of the temple with cedar boards from floor to ceiling for the inner sanctuary, the Most Holy Place.
11:6:17/The main hall in front of this room was 40 cubits long.
11:6:18/The cedar inside the temple was carved with gourds and open flowers; all was cedar, no stone was visible.
11:6:19/He prepared the inner sanctuary inside the temple to house the Ark of the LORD's Covenant.
11:6:20/The inner sanctuary was 20 cubits long, 20 cubits wide, and 20 cubits high, and he overlaid it with pure gold. He also covered the cedar altar with gold.
11:6:21/Solomon covered the interior of the temple with pure gold, and he made gold chains to curtain off the Holy of Holies, which he also overlaid with gold.
11:6:22/He covered the entire temple with gold, completing all the temple decorations, and he also covered the altar that belonged to the Holy of Holies with gold.
11:6:23/Inside the Holy of Holies, he made two cherubim out of olive wood, each ten cubits high.
11:6:24/Each cherub had two wings, each wing five cubits long; the wingspan from one wingtip to the other was ten cubits.
11:6:25/The second cherub also measured ten cubits; both cherubim had the same size and shape.
11:6:26/The height of each cherub was ten cubits.
11:6:27/He placed the cherubim inside the innermost room of the temple, with their wings spread out. The wing of one cherub touched one wall, while the wing of the other touched the opposite wall, and their wings touched each other in the middle of the room.
11:6:28/He overlaid the cherubim with gold.
11:6:29/He carved all the walls of the temple around both the inner and outer rooms with figures of cherubim, palm trees, and open flowers.
11:6:30/He overlaid the floor of both the inner and outer rooms of the temple with gold.
11:6:31/For the entrance to the inner sanctuary, he made doors of olive wood; the doorframes were five-sided.
11:6:32/The two doors were also made of olive wood, and he carved on them carvings of cherubim, palm trees, and open flowers, and overlaid them with gold. He also spread gold over the cherubim and palm trees.
11:6:33/For the entrance to the main hall, he made doorframes of olive wood, which were four-sided.
11:6:34/The two doors were made of pine wood, each door consisting of two folding leaves.
11:6:35/He carved cherubim, palm trees, and open flowers on them and overlaid them with gold fitted smoothly over the carvings.
11:6:36/He built the inner courtyard with three rows of cut stone and a row of cedar beams.
11:6:37/The foundation of the LORD's temple was laid in the fourth year, in the month of Zif.
11:6:38/And in the eleventh year, in the month of Bul (the eighth month), the temple was completed in all its details and according to its specifications. He had spent seven years building it.
11:7:1/But Solomon spent thirteen years building his own house until it was completely finished.
11:7:2/He also constructed the House of the Forest of Lebanon; it was 100 cubits long, 50 cubits wide, and 30 cubits high, standing on four rows of cedar columns with cedar beams resting on the pillars.
11:7:3/The ceiling was covered with cedar above the beams that rested on forty-five pillars, fifteen in each row.
11:7:4/There were windows in three rows, with light facing light in three sets.
11:7:5/All the doorways and doorposts were rectangular, with windows arranged in three sets, allowing light to face light.
11:7:6/He built a columned porch that was 50 cubits long and 30 cubits wide. This porch was in front of them, with additional columns and a thick beam in front as well.
11:7:7/Then he constructed a porch for the throne where he would administer justice, called the Porch of Judgment. It was fully covered with cedar from the floor to the ceiling.
11:7:8/His own residence, where he lived, had another courtyard inside the porch, which was similar in design. Solomon also built a similar porch for Pharaoh’s daughter, whom he had married.
11:7:9/All these structures were made of expensive stones, cut to size and sawed with saws on their inner and outer surfaces, from the foundation to the eaves, and on the outside toward the great courtyard.
11:7:10/The foundation was laid with expensive, large stones, some ten cubits and some eight cubits in size.
11:7:11/Above these were high-quality stones, cut to measure, and cedar wood.
11:7:12/The great courtyard was surrounded by three rows of cut stones and a row of cedar beams, just like the inner courtyard of the LORD's house and the porch of the house.
11:7:13/King Solomon sent for Hiram from Tyre.
11:7:14/He was a widow’s son from the tribe of Naphtali, and his father was a Tyrian craftsman in bronze. Hiram was extremely skilled, knowledgeable, and experienced in all kinds of bronze work. He came to King Solomon and completed all his bronze work.
11:7:15/He cast two bronze pillars, each eighteen cubits high, with a circumference of twelve cubits around each.
11:7:16/He made two capitals of cast bronze to set on the tops of the pillars; each capital was five cubits high.
11:7:17/He created nets of checkerwork and wreaths of chainwork for the capitals on top of the pillars, seven for each capital.
11:7:18/He made the pillars, with two rows of pomegranates around each network to decorate the capitals on top, and did the same for the other capital.
11:7:19/The capitals on top of the pillars in the porch were designed with lilies, four cubits high.
11:7:20/The capitals on the two pillars also had pomegranates above, next to the rounded part next to the network, with two hundred pomegranates in rows around each capital.
11:7:21/He erected the pillars at the porch of the temple: the right pillar he named Jachin and the left pillar he named Boaz.
11:7:22/The tops of the pillars were decorated with lily designs. Thus, the work on the pillars was completed.
11:7:23/He made a large basin of cast metal, ten cubits from rim to rim, circular in shape, five cubits high, and thirty cubits in circumference.
11:7:24/Under the rim, gourds encircled it, ten to a cubit, all the way around the basin, cast in two rows when it was cast.
11:7:25/It stood on twelve oxen, three facing north, three facing west, three facing south, and three facing east; the basin rested on top of them, and their rear parts were all inward.
11:7:26/It was a handbreadth thick, and its rim was shaped like the rim of a cup, like a lily blossom. It could hold two thousand baths.
11:7:27/He made ten stands of bronze; each stand was four cubits long, four cubits wide, and three cubits high.
11:7:28/The stands had designs that included borders, and the borders were between the frames.
11:7:29/On the borders between the frames were lions, oxen, and cherubim. On the frames above and below the lions and oxen were wreaths of hammered work.
11:7:30/Each stand had four bronze wheels with bronze axles, and its four feet had supports. Under the basin were cast supports with wreaths at each side.
11:7:31/Its opening inside the crown at the top was a cubit in diameter, and the opening was round, fashioned as a pedestal, one and a half cubits in diameter. On its opening were carvings, and their borders were square, not round.
11:7:32/The four wheels were below the borders, and the axles of the wheels were attached to the stand. Each wheel was a cubit and a half in diameter.
11:7:33/The design of the wheels was like that of chariot wheels; their axles, rims, spokes, and hubs were all cast metal.
11:7:34/There were four supports at the four corners of each stand; the supports were part of the stand itself.
11:7:35/At the top of the stand there was a circular band half a cubit high; and on the top of the stand its stays and its borders were of the same piece.
11:7:36/On the plates of its stays and on its borders, he carved cherubim, lions, and palm trees, according to the space of each, with wreaths all around.
11:7:37/This is how he made the ten stands. All of them had the same casting, the same measure, and the same shape.
11:7:38/Then he made ten bronze basins, each holding forty baths and each four cubits wide, one basin on each of the ten stands.
11:7:39/He placed five stands on the right side of the house and five on the left side of the house. He set the Sea on the right side of the house, to the southeast.
11:7:40/Hiram made the basins, shovels, and bowls. So Hiram finished all the work he had undertaken for King Solomon in the LORD's house.
11:7:41/The two pillars, the two bowl-shaped capitals on top of the pillars, the two sets of network to cover the two bowl-shaped capitals on top of the pillars,
11:7:42/Four hundred pomegranates for the two sets of network (two rows of pomegranates for each network, to cover the two bowl-shaped capitals on top of the pillars),
11:7:43/The ten stands, and the ten basins on the stands,
11:7:44/The one Sea, and the twelve oxen under the Sea,
11:7:45/The pots, shovels, and bowls. All these items that Hiram made for King Solomon for the LORD's house were of polished bronze.
11:7:46/The king had them cast in the Jordan Valley in the clay ground between Succoth and Zarethan.
11:7:47/Solomon left all the items unweighed because there were so many; the weight of the bronze was not determined.
11:7:48/Solomon made all the furnishings that were in the LORD's house: the gold altar, the gold table for the bread of the Presence,
11:7:49/The pure gold lampstands, five on the right and five on the left in front of the inner sanctuary, with the flowers, lamps, and tongs of gold,
11:7:50/The cups, snuffers, basins, dishes for incense, and fire pans, all of pure gold; and the hinges for the doors of the innermost part of the house, the Most Holy Place, and for the doors of the main hall of the temple, were of gold.
11:7:51/Thus all the work King Solomon did for the house of the LORD was completed. Solomon then brought in the dedications of his father David, the silver, the gold, and the furnishings, and placed them in the treasuries of the LORD's house.
11:8:1/Then Solomon gathered the leaders of Israel, all the tribal heads, and the chiefs of the families of the children of Israel, to King Solomon in Jerusalem, so they could bring the ark of the covenant of the LORD from the city of David, which is Zion.
11:8:2/All the men of Israel came together to King Solomon during the festival in the month of Ethanim, which is the seventh month.
11:8:3/All the elders of Israel arrived, and the priests carried the ark.
11:8:4/They brought up the ark of the LORD, the meeting tent, and all the sacred items that were in the tent. The priests and the Levites carried them all.
11:8:5/King Solomon and the entire assembly of Israel that had gathered around him were before the ark, offering so many sheep and oxen that they couldn't be counted.
11:8:6/The priests placed the ark of the covenant of the LORD in its spot, inside the inner sanctuary of the temple, under the wings of the cherubim.
11:8:7/The cherubim spread their wings over the place of the ark, covering the ark and its carrying poles from above.
11:8:8/They extended the poles so that the ends could be seen from the Holy Place in front of the inner sanctuary, but they were not visible from outside. They are still there to this day.
11:8:9/Inside the ark were only the two stone tablets that Moses had placed there at Horeb, where the LORD made a covenant with the Israelites after they left Egypt.
11:8:10/When the priests exited the Holy Place, a cloud filled the LORD's temple,
11:8:11/making it impossible for the priests to stand and perform their duties because of the cloud; for the glory of the LORD filled the temple.
11:8:12/Then Solomon declared, "The LORD has said He would dwell in thick darkness.
11:8:13/I have indeed built You a magnificent house, a place for You to dwell forever."
11:8:14/The king then turned around and blessed the entire assembly of Israel while they all stood.
11:8:15/He said, "Praise be to the LORD, the God of Israel, who spoke directly to my father David and has fulfilled His promise with His own hands, saying,
11:8:16/'Since the day I brought my people Israel out of Egypt, I have not chosen a city from any of the tribes of Israel to build a temple for My Name to be there. But I have chosen David to rule over My people Israel.'
11:8:17/My father David had it in his heart to build a temple for the Name of the LORD, the God of Israel.
11:8:18/But the LORD said to my father David, 'It was good that it was in your heart to build a temple for My Name.
11:8:19/However, you will not build the temple; instead, your son, your own offspring, will build the temple for My Name.'
11:8:20/The LORD has kept the promise He made. I have succeeded David my father and now sit on the throne of Israel, just as the LORD promised, and I have built the temple for the Name of the LORD, the God of Israel.
11:8:21/And I have provided a place there for the ark, in which is the covenant of the LORD that He made with our ancestors when He brought them out of Egypt."
11:8:22/Then Solomon stood before the altar of the LORD in front of the entire assembly of Israel and spread out his hands toward heaven.
11:8:23/He said, "LORD, God of Israel, there is no God like You in heaven above or on earth below, keeping covenant and showing steadfast love to Your servants who walk before You with all their heart.
11:8:24/You have kept Your promise to Your servant David my father; You spoke with Your mouth and have fulfilled it with Your hand, as it is today.
11:8:25/Now therefore, LORD, God of Israel, keep for Your servant David my father what You have promised him, saying, 'You shall not lack a man to sit before Me on the throne of Israel, if only your children pay attention to their way, to walk before Me as you have walked before Me.'
11:8:26/Now, O God of Israel, let Your word to Your servant David my father be confirmed.
11:8:27/But will God indeed dwell on the earth? Behold, heaven and the highest heaven cannot contain You, how much less this house that I have built!
11:8:28/Yet have regard to the prayer of Your servant and to his plea, O LORD my God, listening to the cry and to the prayer that Your servant prays before You today,
11:8:29/that Your eyes may be open night and day toward this house, the place of which You have said, 'My Name shall be there,' that You may listen to the prayer that Your servant offers toward this place.
11:8:30/And listen to the plea of Your servant and of Your people Israel, when they pray toward this place. And hear in heaven Your dwelling place, and when You hear, forgive.
11:8:31/If anyone sins against their neighbor and is required to take an oath and they come and swear the oath before Your altar in this house,
11:8:32/then hear in heaven and act. Judge Your servants, condemning the guilty by bringing their conduct on their own heads, and vindicating the righteous by rewarding them according to their righteousness.
11:8:33/When Your people Israel are defeated before an enemy because they have sinned against You, and they turn back to You and confess Your name, praying and making supplication to You in this house,
11:8:34/then hear in heaven and forgive the sin of Your people Israel and bring them back to the land You gave to their ancestors.
11:8:35/When the heavens are shut up and there is no rain because they have sinned against You, and they pray toward this place and confess Your name, turning from their sin because You have afflicted them,
11:8:36/then hear in heaven and forgive the sin of Your servants, Your people Israel. Teach them the right way to live, and send rain on the land You gave Your people for an inheritance.
11:8:37/If there is famine in the land, if there is pestilence, blight, mildew, locust, or caterpillar; if their enemy besieges them in the land of their cities; whatever plague, whatever sickness there is,
11:8:38/whatever prayer, whatever plea is made by any individual or by all Your people Israel, each knowing the afflictions of their own heart, and spreading out their hands toward this house,
11:8:39/then hear in heaven Your dwelling place, forgive, act, and render to each whose heart You know, according to all their ways, for You, You only, know the hearts of all the children of mankind,
11:8:40/so that they may fear You all the days that they live in the land which You gave to our ancestors.
11:8:41/Also concerning the foreigner, who is not of Your people Israel but comes from a far country for the sake of Your name
11:8:42/(for they shall hear of Your great name and Your mighty hand and of Your outstretched arm), when they come and pray toward this house,
11:8:43/hear in heaven Your dwelling place and do according to all for which the foreigner calls to You, so that all the peoples of the earth may know Your name and fear You, as do Your people Israel, and that they may know that this house that I have built is called by Your name.
11:8:44/If Your people go out to battle against their enemy, wherever You send them, and they pray to the LORD toward the city You have chosen and the house I have built for Your name,
11:8:45/then hear in heaven their prayer and their plea, and uphold their cause.
11:8:46/If they sin against You (for there is no one who does not sin) and You are angry with them and give them to an enemy, so that they are taken captive to the land of the enemy, far off or near,
11:8:47/yet if they take it to heart in the land where they are held captive, and repent and plead with You in the land of their captors, saying, 'We have sinned and acted perversely and wickedly,'
11:8:48/if they return to You with all their heart and with all their soul in the land of their enemies who took them captive, and pray to You toward their land which You gave to their fathers, the city You have chosen, and the house I have built for Your name,
11:8:49/then hear in heaven Your dwelling place their prayer and their plea, and uphold their cause,
11:8:50/and forgive Your people who have sinned against You and all their transgressions that they have committed against You, and grant them compassion in the sight of those who took them captive, that they may have compassion on them,
11:8:51/for they are Your people and Your inheritance, whom You brought out of Egypt, out of the iron furnace.
11:8:52/Let Your eyes be open to the plea of Your servant and to the plea of Your people Israel, giving ear to them whenever they call to You.
11:8:53/For You separated them from among all the peoples of the earth to be Your inheritance, as You declared through Moses Your servant, when You brought our fathers out of Egypt, O Lord GOD.
11:8:54/And so, when Solomon finished praying all this prayer and plea to the LORD, he rose from before the altar of the LORD, where he had been kneeling with his hands spread out toward heaven.
11:8:55/He stood and blessed the whole assembly of Israel in a loud voice, saying,
11:8:56/"Praise be to the LORD, who has given rest to His people Israel according to everything He promised. Not one word has failed of all the good promises He made through His servant Moses.
11:8:57/May the LORD our God be with us, as He was with our ancestors; may He never leave us nor forsake us,
11:8:58/so that He may incline our hearts to Him, to walk in all His ways and to keep His commandments, His statutes, and His judgments, which He commanded our ancestors.
11:8:59/And may these words of mine, which I have prayed before the LORD, be near to the LORD our God day and night, that He may uphold the cause of His servant and the cause of His people Israel as each day requires,
11:8:60/so that all the peoples of the earth may know that the LORD is God and that there is no other.
11:8:61/Let your heart therefore be wholly true to the LORD our God, walking in His statutes and keeping His commandments, as at this day."
11:8:62/Then the king and all Israel with him offered sacrifices before the LORD.
11:8:63/Solomon offered as peace offerings to the LORD twenty-two thousand oxen and one hundred and twenty thousand sheep. So the king and all the Israelites dedicated the house of the LORD.
11:8:64/That same day, the king consecrated the middle of the courtyard in front of the LORD's temple. There he offered burnt offerings, grain offerings, and the fat of the peace offerings because the bronze altar before the LORD was too small to hold the burnt offerings, grain offerings, and the fat of the peace offerings.
11:8:65/At that time, Solomon held a festival, and all Israel with him, a great assembly from Lebo-hamath to the Brook of Egypt, before the LORD our God, for seven days and seven more days, fourteen days in total.
11:8:66/On the eighth day, he sent the people away. They blessed the king and went to their homes joyful and glad of heart for all the goodness that the LORD had shown to David His servant and to Israel His people.
11:9:1/When Solomon had completed the construction of the LORD's temple, the royal palace, and all that he desired to accomplish,
11:9:2/the LORD appeared to Solomon a second time, just as He had at Gibeon.
11:9:3/The LORD told him, "I have listened to your prayer and plea you presented before me. I have consecrated this temple you have built by placing my name there forever; my eyes and my heart will always be there.
11:9:4/If you live in my presence as your father David did, with a pure heart and honesty, following all my commands and keeping my decrees and laws,
11:9:5/then I will secure your royal throne over Israel forever, as I promised David your father, saying, 'You will never fail to have a successor on the throne of Israel.'
11:9:6/However, if you or your descendants turn away from me, if you do not observe my commands and decrees I have given you, and go off to serve other gods and worship them,
11:9:7/then I will cut off Israel from the land I have given them. I will reject this temple I have consecrated for my name, and Israel will become a joke and an object of ridicule among all peoples.
11:9:8/And regarding this temple, now so exalted, everyone who passes by will be shocked and will scoff, asking, 'Why has the LORD done such a thing to this land and to this temple?'
11:9:9/People will answer, 'Because they abandoned the LORD their God, who brought their ancestors out of Egypt, and embraced other gods, worshiping and serving them. That is why the LORD has brought all this disaster on them.'
11:9:10/At the end of twenty years, during which Solomon built the two buildings, the LORD's temple and the royal palace,
11:9:11/(King Hiram of Tyre had supplied Solomon with cedar and cypress logs and gold, as much as he desired), Solomon then gave Hiram twenty towns in the region of Galilee.
11:9:12/When Hiram came from Tyre to see the towns Solomon had given him, he was not pleased with them.
11:9:13/"What kind of towns are these you have given me, my brother?" he asked. And he called them the Land of Cabul, a name they have to this day.
11:9:14/Then Hiram sent the king 120 talents of gold.
11:9:15/This is the account of the forced labor King Solomon conscripted to build the LORD's temple, his own palace, the supporting terraces, the wall of Jerusalem, and the cities of Hazor, Megiddo, and Gezer.
11:9:16/Pharaoh king of Egypt had attacked and captured Gezer, burned it down, killed the Canaanites who lived there, and given it as a wedding gift to his daughter, Solomon's wife.
11:9:17/So Solomon rebuilt Gezer, Lower Beth Horon,
11:9:18/Baalath, and Tadmor in the desert, within his land,
11:9:19/as well as all his store cities, the towns for his chariots and for his horses, and whatever Solomon desired to build in Jerusalem, in Lebanon, and throughout all the territory he ruled.
11:9:20/All the people left from the Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites, who were not Israelites,
11:9:21/their descendants remaining in the land, whom the Israelites could not completely exterminate, Solomon conscripted for his slave labor force, as it is to this day.
11:9:22/But Solomon did not make slaves of the Israelites; they were his soldiers, his government officials, his officers, his captains, and commanders of his chariots and charioteers.
11:9:23/These were the chief officials in charge of Solomon's projects, 550 officials supervising the people who did the work.
11:9:24/After Pharaoh's daughter moved from the City of David to the palace Solomon had built for her, he then built the Millo.
11:9:25/Three times a year Solomon sacrificed burnt offerings and fellowship offerings on the altar he had built for the LORD, burning incense before the LORD along with them, and so completed the temple.
11:9:26/King Solomon also built a fleet of ships at Ezion Geber, which is near Eloth on the shore of the Red Sea, in the land of Edom.
11:9:27/And Hiram sent his experienced sailors to serve in the fleet with Solomon's men.
11:9:28/They sailed to Ophir and brought back 420 talents of gold, which they delivered to King Solomon.
11:10:1/When the queen of Sheba heard about Solomon's fame and his relationship with the LORD, she came to test him with difficult questions.
11:10:2/She arrived in Jerusalem with a very impressive entourage, with camels carrying spices, a lot of gold, and precious stones. Upon her arrival, she discussed everything on her mind with Solomon.
11:10:3/Solomon answered all her questions; there was nothing he didn't explain to her.
11:10:4/When the queen of Sheba witnessed Solomon's wisdom, and the palace he had built,
11:10:5/And the food on his table, the organization of his officials, the attentive service of his ministers, their attire, his cupbearers, and the stairway he used to go up to the house of the LORD, she was utterly amazed.
11:10:6/She said to the king, "The report I heard in my own country about your achievements and your wisdom is true.
11:10:7/But I didn't believe these reports until I came and saw with my own eyes. Indeed, not even half was told to me; your wisdom and prosperity surpass the fame I had heard.
11:10:8/Your men are fortunate, and your servants who stand continually before you and hear your wisdom are even more so.
11:10:9/Blessed be the LORD your God, who has delighted in you, setting you on the throne of Israel. Because the LORD loves Israel forever, he made you king to administer justice and righteousness."
11:10:10/And she gave the king 120 talents of gold, a huge quantity of spices, and precious stones. No such abundance of spices had ever been brought as those the queen of Sheba gave to King Solomon.
11:10:11/The fleet of Hiram, which brought gold from Ophir, also brought a large quantity of almug trees and precious stones.
11:10:12/The king used the almug trees to make supports for the temple of the LORD and for the royal palace, and to make harps and lyres for the musicians. No such almug trees have been seen to this day.
11:10:13/King Solomon gave the queen of Sheba all she desired and asked for, besides what he had given her out of his royal generosity. Then she returned to her own country, along with her servants.
11:10:14/The total weight of gold that came to Solomon in one year was 666 talents,
11:10:15/Besides what he received from the merchants, the profits from the traders, and all the kings of Arabia and the governors of the land.
11:10:16/King Solomon made 200 large shields of hammered gold; 600 shekels of gold went into each shield.
11:10:17/He also made 300 smaller shields of hammered gold, with three minas of gold in each shield. The king placed them in the Palace of the Forest of Lebanon.
11:10:18/Furthermore, the king made a great throne of ivory and overlaid it with refined gold.
11:10:19/The throne had six steps, and a rounded top at the back. There were armrests on both sides of the seat, and two lions stood beside the armrests.
11:10:20/Twelve lions stood on the six steps, one at either end of each step. Nothing like it had been made for any other kingdom.
11:10:21/All of King Solomon's drinking vessels were gold, and all the utensils of the Forest of Lebanon Palace were pure gold. Silver was considered of little value in Solomon's days.
11:10:22/The king had a fleet of Tarshish ships at sea along with the ships of Hiram. Every three years, the fleet of Tarshish ships brought gold, silver, ivory, apes, and peacocks.
11:10:23/Thus, King Solomon surpassed all the kings of the earth in riches and wisdom.
11:10:24/People from all over the world sought an audience with Solomon to hear the wisdom God had placed in his heart.
11:10:25/They brought him gifts—silver and gold vessels, garments, weapons, spices, horses, and mules—as tribute year after year.
11:10:26/Solomon accumulated chariots and horsemen; he had 1,400 chariots and 12,000 horsemen, which he stationed in the chariot cities and with the king in Jerusalem.
11:10:27/The king made silver as common in Jerusalem as stones, and he made cedars as plentiful as the sycamore fig trees in the lowland.
11:10:28/Solomon's horses were imported from Egypt and Kue; the royal merchants purchased them from Kue at a fixed price.
11:10:29/A chariot could be imported from Egypt for 600 shekels of silver, and a horse for 150. And in this way, they exported them to all the kings of the Hittites and the kings of Aram.
11:11:1/But King Solomon loved many foreign women, including the daughter of Pharaoh, as well as women from Moab, Ammon, Edom, Sidon, and the Hittites.
11:11:2/From the nations about which the LORD warned the Israelites, saying, "You must not engage with them, nor should they with you, for they will surely turn your heart towards their gods." Yet, Solomon was deeply attached to them in love.
11:11:3/He had seven hundred wives of royal birth and three hundred concubines, and his wives led him astray.
11:11:4/As Solomon grew old, his wives turned his heart after other gods, and his heart was not fully devoted to the LORD his God, unlike his father David's heart.
11:11:5/Solomon followed Ashtoreth the goddess of the Sidonians, and Milcom the detestable god of the Ammonites.
11:11:6/And Solomon did what was evil in the LORD's sight, failing to follow the LORD completely, as David his father had done.
11:11:7/Then Solomon built a high place for Chemosh, the detestable god of Moab, on the hill facing Jerusalem, and for Molech, the detestable god of the Ammonites.
11:11:8/And he did the same for all his foreign wives, who burned incense and offered sacrifices to their gods.
11:11:9/And the LORD became angry with Solomon because his heart had turned away from the LORD God of Israel, who had appeared to him twice.
11:11:10/And had specifically commanded him not to follow other gods, but he did not keep the LORD's command.
11:11:11/Therefore, the LORD said to Solomon, "Since this is your attitude and you have not kept my covenant and my decrees, which I commanded you, I will most certainly tear the kingdom away from you and give it to one of your subordinates.
11:11:12/However, during your lifetime, I will not do it, out of respect for your father David. I will tear it out of the hand of your son.
11:11:13/Yet I will not tear the entire kingdom away; I will give one tribe to your son for the sake of David my servant and for the sake of Jerusalem, which I have chosen."
11:11:14/And the LORD raised up an adversary against Solomon, Hadad the Edomite, from the royal line of Edom.
11:11:15/For when David was in Edom, and Joab the commander of the army went up to bury the dead, after he had killed every male in Edom;
11:11:16/(For Joab and all Israel stayed there six months, until he had eliminated every male in Edom.)
11:11:17/Hadad fled, along with some Edomite officials from his father's service, to Egypt, while Hadad was still a young boy.
11:11:18/They set out from Midian and arrived in Paran. Then, taking men from Paran with them, they went to Egypt, to Pharaoh king of Egypt, who gave Hadad a house, provided him with food, and allotted him land.
11:11:19/And Hadad gained great favor in the eyes of Pharaoh, so much so that he gave him the sister of his own wife, the sister of Queen Tahpenes, in marriage.
11:11:20/And the sister of Tahpenes bore him Genubath his son, whom Tahpenes weaned in Pharaoh's palace; and Genubath lived in Pharaoh's household among the sons of Pharaoh.
11:11:21/When Hadad heard in Egypt that David had passed away and that Joab the commander of the army was dead, Hadad said to Pharaoh, "Let me leave, so that I can return to my own country."
11:11:22/Then Pharaoh asked him, "What have you lacked with me that you are seeking to go back to your own country?" And he replied, "Nothing, but please let me go anyway."
11:11:23/And God raised up another adversary against Solomon, Rezon son of Eliadah, who had fled from his master Hadadezer king of Zobah.
11:11:24/He gathered men around him and became the leader of a marauding band after David killed those of Zobah. They went to Damascus, settled there, and took control of Damascus.
11:11:25/He was an adversary to Israel throughout Solomon's reign, adding to the trouble caused by Hadad. He detested Israel and ruled over Aram.
11:11:26/And Jeroboam son of Nebat, an Ephraimite from Zereda, Solomon's servant, whose mother's name was Zeruah, a widow, also rebelled against the king.
11:11:27/The reason he rebelled against the king was that Solomon had built the Millo and repaired the breaches in the city of David, his father.
11:11:28/Jeroboam was a strong and valiant man, and when Solomon saw that the young man was industrious, he put him in charge of all the labor force of the house of Joseph.
11:11:29/It happened at that time when Jeroboam left Jerusalem, the prophet Ahijah the Shilonite found him on the road. Ahijah had dressed himself in a new garment, and the two of them were alone in the open field.
11:11:30/Then Ahijah took hold of the new garment he was wearing and tore it into twelve pieces.
11:11:31/And he said to Jeroboam, "Take ten pieces for yourself, for this is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: 'I am about to tear the kingdom out of Solomon's hand and give you ten tribes.
11:11:32/(But he will have one tribe for the sake of my servant David and for the sake of Jerusalem, the city I have chosen from all the tribes of Israel.)
11:11:33/Because they have forsaken me and worshiped Ashtoreth the goddess of the Sidonians, Chemosh the god of Moab, and Milcom the god of the Ammonites, and have not walked in my ways, doing what is right in my eyes and keeping my statutes and judgments, as David his father did.
11:11:34/However, I will not take the entire kingdom out of his hand; I will make him ruler for all the days of his life for the sake of David my servant, whom I chose, because he kept my commands and statutes.
11:11:35/But I will take the kingdom out of his son's hand and give it to you, even ten tribes.
11:11:36/And to his son, I will give one tribe, so that David my servant may always have a lamp before me in Jerusalem, the city I have chosen to put my Name.
11:11:37/And I will take you, and you shall reign over all that your soul desires, and you shall be king over Israel.
11:11:38/And it shall be, if you listen to all that I command you, walk in my ways, and do what is right in my eyes by keeping my statutes and commands, as David my servant did, then I will be with you and build you a lasting dynasty, as I built for David, and I will give Israel to you.
11:11:39/And I will afflict David's descendants because of this, but not forever."
11:11:40/Solomon therefore sought to kill Jeroboam. But Jeroboam arose and fled to Egypt, to Shishak king of Egypt, and stayed in Egypt until Solomon's death.
11:11:41/And the rest of the acts of Solomon, all he did, and his wisdom, are they not written in the book of the acts of Solomon?
11:11:42/And the time that Solomon reigned in Jerusalem over all Israel was forty years.
11:11:43/And Solomon rested with his ancestors and was buried in the city of David his father; and Rehoboam his son succeeded him as king.
11:12:1/And Rehoboam went to Shechem: for all Israel had come to Shechem to make him king.
11:12:2/When Jeroboam, son of Nebat, who was still in Egypt, heard about it (since he had fled from King Solomon and was living in Egypt),
11:12:3/They sent for him. So Jeroboam and the entire assembly of Israel came and spoke to Rehoboam, saying,
11:12:4/Your father made our burden unbearable: now, please lighten the harsh labor and the heavy yoke he put on us, and we will serve you.
11:12:5/He told them, "Leave for three days, then come back to me." So the people left.
11:12:6/King Rehoboam consulted with the elders who had served his father Solomon while he was alive, asking, "How do you advise me to respond to these people?"
11:12:7/They replied, "If today you will be a servant to these people, serve them, respond kindly to them, and speak encouraging words to them, then they will be your servants forever."
11:12:8/But he ignored the advice the elders had given him and consulted the young men he had grown up with, who were now his advisors.
11:12:9/He asked them, "What is your advice? How should we respond to these people who have asked me to lighten the yoke my father put on them?"
11:12:10/The young men he had grown up with said to him, "Tell these people who complained about your father's heavy yoke, 'My little finger is thicker than my father's waist.
11:12:11/My father burdened you with a heavy yoke, but I will add to your yoke: my father disciplined you with whips, but I will discipline you with scorpions.'"
11:12:12/So Jeroboam and all the people returned to Rehoboam on the third day, as the king had directed, saying, "Come back to me on the third day."
11:12:13/The king answered the people harshly, rejecting the advice the elders had given him,
11:12:14/And followed the advice of the young men, saying, "My father made your yoke heavy, but I will add to it; my father disciplined you with whips, but I will discipline you with scorpions."
11:12:15/Therefore, the king did not listen to the people, for this turn of events was from the LORD, to fulfill his word, which the LORD had spoken through Ahijah the Shilonite to Jeroboam son of Nebat.
11:12:16/When all Israel realized that the king had refused to listen to them, they answered the king, "What share do we have in David? We have no inheritance in the son of Jesse. To your tents, O Israel! Look after your own house, David!" So the Israelites went home.
11:12:17/But as for the Israelites who were living in the towns of Judah, Rehoboam still ruled over them.
11:12:18/Then King Rehoboam sent out Adoram, who was in charge of forced labor, but all Israel stoned him to death. King Rehoboam managed to get into his chariot and escape to Jerusalem.
11:12:19/So Israel has been in rebellion against the house of David to this day.
11:12:20/When all Israel heard that Jeroboam had returned, they sent for him and invited him to the assembly. They made him king over all Israel. Only the tribe of Judah remained loyal to the house of David.
11:12:21/When Rehoboam arrived in Jerusalem, he mustered the entire house of Judah and the tribe of Benjamin—180,000 select troops—to fight against the house of Israel and restore the kingdom to himself.
11:12:22/But the word of God came to Shemaiah, the man of God,
11:12:23/Telling Rehoboam, son of Solomon, king of Judah, and all the house of Judah and Benjamin, and the rest of the people,
11:12:24/"This is what the LORD says: Do not go up to fight against your brothers, the Israelites. Everyone, go home, because this is my doing." They obeyed the word of the LORD and turned back, according to the word of the LORD.
11:12:25/Then Jeroboam fortified Shechem in the hill country of Ephraim and lived there. From there he went out and built up Penuel.
11:12:26/And Jeroboam thought to himself, "Now the kingdom might revert to the house of David.
11:12:27/If these people continue to offer sacrifices in the temple of the LORD at Jerusalem, their hearts will turn back to their lord, Rehoboam king of Judah. They will kill me and return to King Rehoboam of Judah."
11:12:28/After seeking advice, the king made two golden calves. He said to the people, "It's too much for you to go up to Jerusalem. Here are your gods, Israel, who brought you up out of Egypt."
11:12:29/He set one up in Bethel and the other in Dan.
11:12:30/This act became a sin; the people went to worship the one at Bethel and went as far as Dan to worship the other.
11:12:31/Jeroboam built shrines on high places and appointed priests from all sorts of people, who were not of the Levites.
11:12:32/He instituted a festival on the fifteenth day of the eighth month, like the festival held in Judah, and offered sacrifices on the altar. This he did in Bethel, sacrificing to the calves he had made. And at Bethel he also installed priests at the high places he had made.
11:12:33/On the fifteenth day of the eighth month, a month of his own choosing, he offered sacrifices on the altar he had built at Bethel. So he instituted the festival for the Israelites and went up to the altar to make offerings.
11:13:1/A man of God came from Judah to Bethel by the LORD's command, while Jeroboam was at the altar burning incense.
11:13:2/He proclaimed against the altar by the LORD's command, "O altar, altar, the LORD says: 'A child named Josiah will be born to the house of David. He will sacrifice on you the priests of the high places who burn incense on you, and human bones will be burned on you.'"
11:13:3/He gave a sign that day, saying, "This is the sign the LORD has declared: The altar will be split apart, and the ashes on it will be spilled out."
11:13:4/When King Jeroboam heard what the man of God cried out against the altar in Bethel, he stretched out his hand from the altar and said, "Seize him!" But his hand, which he had stretched out against him, dried up, so he could not pull it back.
11:13:5/The altar also split apart, and the ashes spilled out from the altar, according to the sign given by the man of God by the word of the LORD.
11:13:6/The king pleaded with the man of God, "Please ask the LORD your God to restore my hand." So the man of God prayed to the LORD, and the king's hand was restored to him, as it was before.
11:13:7/The king said to the man of God, "Come home with me for a meal, and I will give you a reward."
11:13:8/But the man of God said to the king, "Even if you gave me half your possessions, I would not go with you, nor would I eat bread or drink water here.
11:13:9/For I was commanded by the word of the LORD, 'Do not eat bread or drink water, nor return by the way you came.'"
11:13:10/So he took another road and did not return by the way he had come to Bethel.
11:13:11/An old prophet lived in Bethel; his sons came and told him all that the man of God had done that day in Bethel and the words he had spoken to the king, which they also reported to their father.
11:13:12/Their father asked them, "Which way did he go?" His sons showed him the road the man of God from Judah had taken.
11:13:13/He said to his sons, "Saddle the donkey for me." So they saddled the donkey for him, and he rode on it.
11:13:14/He went after the man of God and found him sitting under an oak. He asked, "Are you the man of God who came from Judah?" "I am," he replied.
11:13:15/Then he said to him, "Come home with me and eat."
11:13:16/But he replied, "I cannot go back with you or eat bread or drink water with you in this place.
11:13:17/I have been told by the word of the LORD, 'You must not eat bread or drink water there or return by the way you came.'"
11:13:18/The old prophet said, "I too am a prophet like you, and an angel spoke to me by the word of the LORD, saying, 'Bring him back with you to your house so that he may eat bread and drink water.'" But he was lying to him.
11:13:19/So he went back with him and ate bread in his house and drank water.
11:13:20/While they were sitting at the table, the word of the LORD came to the old prophet who had brought him back.
11:13:21/He cried out to the man of God who had come from Judah, "This is what the LORD says: 'Because you have disobeyed the LORD's command and have not kept the command the LORD your God gave you,
11:13:22/but have come back and eaten bread and drunk water in the place where he told you not to eat or drink, your body will not be buried in the tomb of your ancestors.'"
11:13:23/After the man of God had eaten and drunk, the prophet who had brought him back saddled the donkey for him.
11:13:24/As he went on his way, a lion met him on the road and killed him. His body was thrown down on the road, with both the donkey and the lion standing beside it.
11:13:25/People passing by saw the body thrown down and the lion standing beside the body, and they went and reported it in the city where the old prophet lived.
11:13:26/When the prophet who had brought him back from his journey heard about it, he said, "It is the man of God who disobeyed the word of the LORD. The LORD has delivered him to the lion, which has mauled him and killed him, according to the word of the LORD he had spoken."
11:13:27/He said to his sons, "Saddle the donkey for me." And they did.
11:13:28/He went and found the body thrown down on the road, with the donkey and the lion standing beside the body. The lion had not eaten the body or mauled the donkey.
11:13:29/The prophet picked up the body of the man of God, laid it on the donkey, and brought it back to the city to mourn and to bury him.
11:13:30/He laid the body in his own tomb, and they mourned over him, saying, "Oh, my brother!"
11:13:31/After burying him, he said to his sons, "When I die, bury me in the tomb where the man of God is buried; lay my bones beside his bones.
11:13:32/For the message he declared by the word of the LORD against the altar in Bethel and against all the shrines on the high places in the towns of Samaria will certainly come true."
11:13:33/Despite this, Jeroboam did not change his evil ways, but once again appointed priests for the high places from all sorts of people. Anyone who wanted to become a priest he consecrated for the high places.
11:13:34/This act became a sin for the house of Jeroboam, leading to its destruction and elimination from the face of the earth.
11:14:1/At that time Abijah, Jeroboam's son, became ill.
11:14:2/Jeroboam told his wife, "Please get up and disguise yourself so no one knows you're my wife. Go to Shiloh; there you'll find Ahijah the prophet who told me I'd be king over this nation.
11:14:3/Take with you ten loaves, some cakes, and a jar of honey, and go to him. He will tell you what will happen to our child."
11:14:4/Jeroboam's wife did as instructed, went to Shiloh, and arrived at Ahijah's house. Ahijah couldn't see because he was very old.
11:14:5/The LORD said to Ahijah, "Jeroboam's wife is coming to ask you about her son, for he is sick. Tell her exactly this and that. When she arrives, she will pretend to be someone else."
11:14:6/When Ahijah heard her footsteps at the door, he said, "Come in, Jeroboam's wife. Why pretend to be someone else? I have difficult news for you.
11:14:7/Tell Jeroboam, 'This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: I raised you from among the people and made you a leader over my people Israel.
11:14:8/I tore the kingdom away from David's house and gave it to you. Yet, you haven't been like my servant David, who obeyed my commands and followed me wholeheartedly, doing only what was right in my eyes.
11:14:9/Instead, you have done more evil than anyone before you. You made other gods and idols, angering me and turning your back on me.
11:14:10/So, I will bring disaster on Jeroboam's family. I will eliminate every male in Jeroboam's line, whether slave or free in Israel. I will sweep away the remnants of Jeroboam's house as one clears away dung until it's all gone.
11:14:11/Anyone from Jeroboam's family who dies in the city will be eaten by dogs, and those who die in the field will be eaten by birds. The LORD has spoken.'
11:14:12/So, go back home. As soon as you enter the city, your child will die.
11:14:13/All Israel will mourn for him and bury him. He is the only one from Jeroboam's family who will receive a proper burial because there is something good in him toward the LORD God of Israel.
11:14:14/The LORD will appoint a new king over Israel who will destroy Jeroboam's family. This is happening now.
11:14:15/The LORD will strike Israel, making it shake like a reed in the water. He will uproot Israel from this good land given to their ancestors and scatter them beyond the Euphrates River because they made Asherah poles, angering the LORD.
11:14:16/And because of Jeroboam's sins, which led Israel into sin, the LORD will give up Israel.
11:14:17/Jeroboam's wife got up, left, and went to Tirzah. As soon as she stepped over the threshold of her house, the child died.
11:14:18/They buried him, and all Israel mourned for him, as the LORD had said through his servant Ahijah the prophet.
11:14:19/The rest of Jeroboam's acts, his wars, and his reign, are recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel.
11:14:20/Jeroboam reigned for twenty-two years. Then he died, and his son Nadab succeeded him as king.
11:14:21/Rehoboam, Solomon's son, became king of Judah. He was forty-one when he began to reign and ruled for seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city chosen by the LORD from all the tribes of Israel. His mother's name was Naamah, an Ammonite.
11:14:22/Judah did what was evil in the LORD's sight, provoking him to jealousy with their sins, more than their ancestors had done.
11:14:23/They also built high places, sacred stones, and Asherah poles on every high hill and under every green tree.
11:14:24/There were even male shrine prostitutes in the land. They followed all the detestable practices of the nations the LORD had driven out before the Israelites.
