11:14:25/In the fifth year of King Rehoboam, Shishak, the king of Egypt, attacked Jerusalem.
11:14:26/He took away the treasures of the LORD's temple and the royal palace. He took everything, including all the gold shields Solomon had made.
11:14:27/King Rehoboam replaced them with bronze shields and assigned them to the commanders of the guard who watched over the entrance to the royal palace.
11:14:28/Whenever the king went to the LORD's temple, the guards carried the shields and later returned them to the guardroom.
11:14:29/The rest of Rehoboam's acts, everything he did, are recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah.
11:14:30/There was continuous war between Rehoboam and Jeroboam.
11:14:31/Rehoboam died and was buried with his ancestors in the City of David. His mother's name was Naamah, an Ammonite. His son Abijam succeeded him as king.
11:15:1/In the eighteenth year of King Jeroboam, the son of Nebat, Abijam began his reign over Judah.
11:15:2/He ruled for three years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Maachah, the daughter of Abishalom.
11:15:3/He followed all the sins his father had committed before him; his heart was not fully devoted to the LORD his God, unlike his ancestor David.
11:15:4/Yet, for David's sake, the LORD his God allowed him to maintain a presence in Jerusalem, to establish his son after him, and to secure Jerusalem.
11:15:5/Because David had done what was right in the eyes of the LORD and had not turned away from anything He commanded him throughout his life, except in the case of Uriah the Hittite.
11:15:6/There was ongoing war between Rehoboam and Jeroboam throughout their lives.
11:15:7/The rest of the deeds of Abijam, and everything he did, are they not recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah? There was also war between Abijam and Jeroboam.
11:15:8/Abijam passed away and was buried with his ancestors in the city of David; and Asa his son succeeded him as king.
11:15:9/In the twentieth year of Jeroboam king of Israel, Asa became king over Judah.
11:15:10/He ruled for forty-one years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Maachah, the daughter of Abishalom.
11:15:11/Asa did what was right in the eyes of the LORD, just as his ancestor David had done.
11:15:12/He expelled the male shrine prostitutes from the land and got rid of all the idols his ancestors had made.
11:15:13/He even removed his grandmother Maachah from her position as queen mother because she had made a repulsive idol for Asherah worship; Asa destroyed her idol and burned it in the Kidron Valley.
11:15:14/However, the high places were not removed. Nevertheless, Asa's heart remained fully committed to the LORD all his life.
11:15:15/He brought into the temple of the LORD the silver and gold and the articles that he and his father had dedicated.
11:15:16/There was constant war between Asa and Baasha king of Israel throughout their reigns.
11:15:17/Baasha king of Israel attacked Judah and fortified Ramah to prevent anyone from going to or coming from Asa king of Judah.
11:15:18/Then Asa took all the silver and gold left in the treasuries of the LORD's temple and the royal palace and sent them to Ben-Hadad king of Aram, who was ruling in Damascus, saying,
11:15:19/"Let there be a treaty between you and me, as there was between my father and your father. See, I am sending you silver and gold. Go, break your treaty with Baasha king of Israel so he will withdraw from me."
11:15:20/Ben-Hadad agreed with King Asa and sent the commanders of his armies against the towns of Israel, conquering Ijon, Dan, Abel Beth Maacah, and all Kinnereth, along with the territory of Naphtali.
11:15:21/When Baasha heard this, he stopped building Ramah and withdrew to Tirzah.
11:15:22/Then King Asa issued an order to all Judah; no one was exempted: they removed the stones and timber Baasha had used to fortify Ramah. With them, King Asa fortified Geba in Benjamin and Mizpah.
11:15:23/The rest of all the acts of Asa, all his power, everything he did, and the cities he built, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah? However, in his old age, he suffered from a disease in his feet.
11:15:24/Asa passed away and was buried with his ancestors in the city of David. His son Jehoshaphat succeeded him as king.
11:15:25/Nadab the son of Jeroboam began to reign over Israel in the second year of Asa king of Judah and ruled over Israel for two years.
11:15:26/He did evil in the eyes of the LORD, following the ways of his father and leading Israel into sin.
11:15:27/Baasha son of Ahijah, from the tribe of Issachar, plotted against him and killed him at Gibbethon, a Philistine town, while Nadab and the Israelite army were besieging it.
11:15:28/In the third year of Asa king of Judah, Baasha killed Nadab and succeeded him as king.
11:15:29/As soon as he became king, he killed all the household of Jeroboam. He did not leave any living member of Jeroboam's family, fulfilling the word of the LORD spoken by his servant Ahijah the Shilonite,
11:15:30/Because of the sins Jeroboam committed and caused Israel to commit, provoking the LORD, the God of Israel, to anger.
11:15:31/The rest of the acts of Nadab and all he did, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
11:15:32/There was constant war between Asa and Baasha king of Israel throughout their reigns.
11:15:33/In the third year of Asa king of Judah, Baasha son of Ahijah became king over all Israel in Tirzah and reigned for twenty-four years.
11:15:34/He did evil in the eyes of the LORD, following the ways of Jeroboam and leading Israel into sin.
11:16:1/Then the word of the LORD came to Jehu the son of Hanani against Baasha, saying, 
11:16:2/Since I lifted you from obscurity and made you leader over my people Israel, but you have followed Jeroboam's ways, causing my people Israel to sin and angering me with their sins;
11:16:3/Behold, I will eliminate the descendants of Baasha, and the descendants of his house; and will make your house like the house of Jeroboam the son of Nebat.
11:16:4/Anyone from Baasha's family who dies in the city will be eaten by dogs; and those who die in the fields will be eaten by the birds of the air.
11:16:5/Now the rest of the acts of Baasha, and what he did, and his might, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel? 
11:16:6/So Baasha rested with his ancestors, and was buried in Tirzah: and Elah his son reigned in his place.
11:16:7/And also through the prophet Jehu the son of Hanani, the word of the LORD came against Baasha, and against his house, for all the evil he did in the sight of the LORD, provoking him to anger with the work of his hands, by being like the house of Jeroboam; and because he killed him.
11:16:8/In the twenty-sixth year of Asa king of Judah, Elah the son of Baasha began to reign over Israel in Tirzah, for two years.
11:16:9/And his servant Zimri, captain of half his chariots, conspired against him while he was in Tirzah, getting drunk in the house of Arza, steward of his house in Tirzah.
11:16:10/And Zimri went in, struck him, and killed him, in the twenty-seventh year of Asa king of Judah, and reigned in his place.
11:16:11/And it happened, when he began to reign, as soon as he sat on his throne, he killed all the house of Baasha: he did not leave anyone who urinates against a wall, neither of his relatives nor of his friends.
11:16:12/Thus Zimri destroyed all the house of Baasha, according to the word of the LORD, which he spoke against Baasha through Jehu the prophet.
11:16:13/For all the sins of Baasha, and the sins of Elah his son, by which they sinned, and by which they made Israel to sin, provoking the LORD God of Israel to anger with their worthless idols.
11:16:14/Now the rest of the acts of Elah, and all that he did, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
11:16:15/In the twenty-seventh year of Asa king of Judah, Zimri reigned seven days in Tirzah. And the people were encamped against Gibbethon, which belonged to the Philistines.
11:16:16/And the people who were encamped heard say, Zimri has conspired, and has also slain the king: therefore, all Israel made Omri, the captain of the army, king over Israel that day in the camp.
11:16:17/And Omri went up from Gibbethon, with all Israel, and they besieged Tirzah.
11:16:18/And it happened, when Zimri saw that the city was taken, he went into the palace of the king’s house, and burned the king’s house over him with fire, and died.
11:16:19/For his sins which he sinned, doing evil in the sight of the LORD, walking in the way of Jeroboam, and in his sin which he did, making Israel to sin.
11:16:20/Now the rest of the acts of Zimri, and his treason that he committed, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel? 
11:16:21/Then the people of Israel were divided into two parts: half of the people followed Tibni the son of Ginath, to make him king; and half followed Omri.
11:16:22/But the people who followed Omri prevailed against the people who followed Tibni the son of Ginath: so Tibni died, and Omri reigned.
11:16:23/In the thirty-first year of Asa king of Judah, Omri began to reign over Israel, for twelve years: six years he reigned in Tirzah.
11:16:24/And he bought the hill Samaria from Shemer for two talents of silver, built on the hill, and named the city he built after Shemer, the owner of the hill, Samaria.
11:16:25/But Omri did evil in the eyes of the LORD, and acted worse than all those before him.
11:16:26/For he followed all the ways of Jeroboam the son of Nebat, and in his sins which made Israel to sin, provoking the LORD God of Israel to anger with their worthless idols.
11:16:27/Now the rest of the acts of Omri which he did, and his might that he showed, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel? 
11:16:28/So Omri rested with his ancestors, and was buried in Samaria: and Ahab his son reigned in his place.
11:16:29/And in the thirty-eighth year of Asa king of Judah, Ahab the son of Omri began to reign over Israel: and Ahab the son of Omri reigned over Israel in Samaria twenty-two years.
11:16:30/And Ahab the son of Omri did evil in the sight of the LORD more than all those before him.
11:16:31/And it happened, as if it had been a trivial thing for him to follow the sins of Jeroboam the son of Nebat, he married Jezebel the daughter of Ethbaal king of the Zidonians, and went and served Baal, and worshiped him.
11:16:32/And he set up an altar for Baal in the temple of Baal, which he had built in Samaria.
11:16:33/And Ahab made a sacred grove; and Ahab did more to provoke the LORD God of Israel to anger than all the kings of Israel who were before him.
11:16:34/In his days, Hiel the Bethelite rebuilt Jericho: he laid its foundation at the cost of his firstborn Abiram, and set up its gates at the cost of his youngest son Segub, according to the word of the LORD, which he spoke through Joshua the son of Nun.
11:17:1/Elijah the Tishbite, from Gilead, told Ahab, "As surely as the LORD God of Israel lives, whom I serve, there will be neither dew nor rain in the coming years except at my word."
11:17:2/And the word of the LORD came to him, saying,
11:17:3/"Leave this place, go east and hide by the Cherith Brook, east of the Jordan.
11:17:4/You will drink from the brook, and I have ordered the ravens to feed you there."
11:17:5/So he did as the LORD had told him; he went and lived by the Cherith Brook, east of the Jordan.
11:17:6/The ravens brought him bread and meat in the morning and bread and meat in the evening, and he drank from the brook.
11:17:7/Eventually, the brook dried up because there was no rain in the land.
11:17:8/And the word of the LORD came to him, saying,
11:17:9/"Go at once to Zarephath in the region of Sidon and stay there. I have directed a widow there to supply you with food."
11:17:10/So he went to Zarephath. When he arrived at the town gate, a widow was there gathering sticks. He called to her and asked, "Would you bring me a little water in a jar so I may have a drink?"
11:17:11/As she was going to get it, he called, "And bring me, please, a piece of bread."
11:17:12/"As surely as the LORD your God lives," she replied, "I don't have any bread—only a handful of flour in a jar and a little olive oil in a jug. I am gathering a few sticks to take home and make a meal for myself and my son, that we may eat it—and die."
11:17:13/Elijah said to her, "Don't be afraid. Go home and do as you have said. But first make a small loaf of bread for me from what you have and bring it to me, and then make something for yourself and your son.
11:17:14/For this is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: 'The jar of flour will not be used up and the jug of oil will not run dry until the day the LORD sends rain on the land.'"
11:17:15/She went away and did as Elijah had told her. So there was food every day for Elijah, for the woman, and for her family.
11:17:16/The jar of flour was not used up and the jug of oil did not run dry, in keeping with the word of the LORD spoken by Elijah.
11:17:17/Some time later, the son of the woman who owned the house became ill. He grew worse and worse, and finally stopped breathing.
11:17:18/She said to Elijah, "What do you have against me, man of God? Did you come to remind me of my sin and kill my son?"
11:17:19/"Give me your son," Elijah replied. He took him from her arms, carried him to the upper room where he was staying, and laid him on his bed.
11:17:20/Then he cried out to the LORD, "LORD my God, have you brought tragedy even on this widow I am staying with, by causing her son to die?"
11:17:21/Then he stretched himself out on the boy three times and cried out to the LORD, "LORD my God, let this boy's life return to him!"
11:17:22/The LORD listened to Elijah's cry, and the boy's life returned to him, and he lived.
11:17:23/Elijah picked up the child and carried him down from the room into the house. He gave him to his mother and said, "Look, your son is alive!"
11:17:24/Then the woman said to Elijah, "Now I know that you are a man of God and that the word of the LORD from your mouth is the truth."
11:18:1/After a long time, the word of the LORD came to Elijah in the third year, saying, "Go, present yourself to Ahab, and I will send rain on the land."
11:18:2/Elijah went to present himself to Ahab. Meanwhile, there was a severe famine in Samaria.
11:18:3/Ahab summoned Obadiah, who was in charge of the palace. (Obadiah was a devout believer in the LORD.
11:18:4/When Jezebel was killing off the LORD's prophets, Obadiah had taken a hundred prophets, hidden them in two caves, fifty in each, and supplied them with food and water.)
11:18:5/Ahab said to Obadiah, "Go through the land to all the springs and valleys. Maybe we can find some grass to keep the horses and mules alive so we don't lose any animals."
11:18:6/They divided the land between them to cover it: Ahab went in one direction by himself, and Obadiah went in another direction by himself.
11:18:7/As Obadiah was walking along, Elijah met him. Obadiah recognized him, bowed down to the ground, and said, "Is it really you, my lord Elijah?"
11:18:8/He replied, "Yes, it's me. Go tell your master, 'Elijah is here.'"
11:18:9/Obadiah said, "What have I done wrong that you are handing your servant over to Ahab to be killed?
11:18:10/As surely as the LORD your God lives, there isn't a nation or kingdom where my master hasn't sent someone to look for you. And whenever a nation or kingdom claimed you were not there, he made them swear they couldn't find you.
11:18:11/But now you're telling me to go to my master and say, 'Elijah is here.'
11:18:12/I'm afraid that as soon as I leave you, the Spirit of the LORD will take you somewhere I don't know. Then when I tell Ahab and he can't find you, he'll kill me. Yet I, your servant, have worshiped the LORD since my youth.
11:18:13/Haven't you heard, my lord, what I did when Jezebel was killing the prophets of the LORD? I hid a hundred of the LORD's prophets in two caves, fifty in each, and supplied them with food and water.
11:18:14/And now you're telling me to go to my master and say, 'Elijah is here'; he'll surely kill me."
11:18:15/Elijah said, "As the LORD Almighty lives, whom I serve, I will surely present myself to Ahab today."
11:18:16/So Obadiah went to meet Ahab and told him, and Ahab went to meet Elijah.
11:18:17/When Ahab saw Elijah, he said to him, "Is that you, you troubler of Israel?"
11:18:18/Elijah answered, "I haven't troubled Israel; you and your father's family have, by abandoning the LORD's commands and following the Baals.
11:18:19/Now summon the people from all over Israel to meet me on Mount Carmel. And bring the four hundred and fifty prophets of Baal and the four hundred prophets of Asherah, who eat at Jezebel's table."
11:18:20/So Ahab sent word throughout all Israel and assembled the prophets on Mount Carmel.
11:18:21/Elijah went before the people and said, "How long will you waver between two opinions? If the LORD is God, follow him; but if Baal is God, follow him." But the people said nothing.
11:18:22/Then Elijah said to them, "I am the only one of the LORD's prophets left, but Baal has four hundred and fifty prophets.
11:18:23/Let them give us two bulls. Let them choose one for themselves, cut it into pieces, and place it on the wood but not set fire to it. I will prepare the other bull and place it on the wood but not set fire to it.
11:18:24/Then you call on the name of your gods, and I will call on the name of the LORD. The god who answers by fire—he is God." Then all the people said, "What you say is good."
11:18:25/Elijah said to the prophets of Baal, "Choose one of the bulls and prepare it first, since there are so many of you. Call on the name of your god, but do not light the fire."
11:18:26/So they took the bull given them and prepared it. Then they called on the name of Baal from morning till noon, shouting, "O Baal, answer us!" But there was no response; no one answered. And they danced around the altar they had made.
11:18:27/At noon, Elijah began to taunt them. "Shout louder!" he said. "Surely he is a god! Perhaps he is deep in thought, or busy, or traveling. Maybe he is sleeping and must be awakened."
11:18:28/So they shouted louder and slashed themselves with swords and spears, as was their custom, until their blood flowed.
11:18:29/Midday passed, and they continued their frantic prophesying until the time for the evening sacrifice. But there was no response, no one answered, no one paid attention.
11:18:30/Then Elijah said to all the people, "Come here to me." They came to him, and he repaired the altar of the LORD, which had been torn down.
11:18:31/Elijah took twelve stones, one for each of the tribes descended from Jacob, to whom the word of the LORD had come, saying, "Your name shall be Israel."
11:18:32/With the stones, he built an altar in the name of the LORD, and he dug a trench around it large enough to hold two seahs of seed.
11:18:33/He arranged the wood, cut the bull into pieces, and laid it on the wood. Then he said, "Fill four large jars with water and pour it on the offering and on the wood."
11:18:34/Then he said, "Do it again," and they did it again. "Do it a third time," he ordered, and they did it the third time.
11:18:35/The water ran down around the altar and even filled the trench.
11:18:36/At the time of sacrifice, the prophet Elijah stepped forward and prayed: "LORD, God of Abraham, Isaac and Israel, let it be known today that you are God in Israel and that I am your servant and have done all these things at your command.
11:18:37/Answer me, LORD, answer me, so these people will know that you, LORD, are God, and that you are turning their hearts back again."
11:18:38/Then the fire of the LORD fell and burned up the sacrifice, the wood, the stones, and the soil, and also licked up the water in the trench.
11:18:39/When all the people saw this, they fell prostrate and cried, "The LORD—he is God! The LORD—he is God!"
11:18:40/Elijah commanded them, "Seize the prophets of Baal. Don't let anyone get away!" They seized them, and Elijah had them brought down to the Kishon Valley and slaughtered there.
11:18:41/Then Elijah said to Ahab, "Go, eat and drink, for there is the sound of a heavy rain."
11:18:42/So Ahab went off to eat and drink, but Elijah climbed to the top of Carmel, bent down to the ground and put his face between his knees.
11:18:43/He said to his servant, "Go and look toward the sea." The servant went up and looked, then said, "There is nothing." Seven times Elijah said, "Go back."
11:18:44/On the seventh time, the servant reported, "A cloud as small as a man's hand is rising from the sea." So Elijah said, "Go and tell Ahab, 'Hitch up your chariot and go down before the rain stops you.'"
11:18:45/Meanwhile, the sky grew black with clouds, the wind rose, a heavy rain started falling and Ahab rode off to Jezreel.
11:18:46/The power of the LORD came on Elijah and, tucking his cloak into his belt, he ran ahead of Ahab all the way to the entrance of Jezreel.
11:19:1/Ahab told Jezebel everything Elijah had done, including how he had killed all the prophets with the sword.
11:19:2/Then Jezebel sent a messenger to Elijah, saying, "May the gods punish me severely if I don't make your life like one of those prophets by this time tomorrow."
11:19:3/Seeing this, he got up, fled for his life, and arrived at Beersheba in Judah, where he left his servant.
11:19:4/But he himself went a day's journey into the wilderness, sat down under a juniper tree, and wished for his own death, saying, "It's enough; now, LORD, take my life, for I am no better than my ancestors."
11:19:5/While he was sleeping under the juniper tree, suddenly an angel touched him and said, "Get up and eat."
11:19:6/He looked around, and there by his head was a cake baked over hot coals and a jar of water. He ate and drank, then lay down again.
11:19:7/The angel of the LORD came back a second time, touched him, and said, "Get up and eat, for the journey ahead is too much for you."
11:19:8/So he got up, ate and drank, and traveled forty days and forty nights to Horeb, the mountain of God, strengthened by that food.
11:19:9/When he arrived there, he stayed in a cave. Then the word of the LORD came to him, asking, "What are you doing here, Elijah?"
11:19:10/He replied, "I have been very zealous for the LORD God Almighty. The Israelites have abandoned your covenant, destroyed your altars, and killed your prophets with the sword. I'm the only one left, and now they're trying to kill me too."
11:19:11/Then he was told, "Go out and stand on the mountain in the presence of the LORD, for the LORD is about to pass by." Then a great and powerful wind tore the mountains apart and shattered the rocks before the LORD, but the LORD was not in the wind. After the wind there was an earthquake, but the LORD was not in the earthquake.
11:19:12/After the earthquake came a fire, but the LORD was not in the fire. And after the fire came a gentle whisper.
11:19:13/When Elijah heard it, he covered his face with his cloak, went out, and stood at the entrance of the cave. Then a voice said to him, "What are you doing here, Elijah?"
11:19:14/He answered, "I have been very zealous for the LORD God Almighty. The Israelites have abandoned your covenant, destroyed your altars, and killed your prophets with the sword. I'm the only one left, and now they're trying to kill me too."
11:19:15/Then the LORD said to him, "Go back the way you came, and go to the Desert of Damascus. When you get there, anoint Hazael king over Aram.
11:19:16/Also, anoint Jehu son of Nimshi king over Israel, and anoint Elisha son of Shaphat from Abel Meholah to succeed you as prophet.
11:19:17/Anyone who escapes the sword of Hazael will be killed by Jehu, and anyone who escapes the sword of Jehu will be killed by Elisha.
11:19:18/Yet I reserve seven thousand in Israel—all whose knees have not bowed down to Baal and whose mouths have not kissed him."
11:19:19/So Elijah left there and found Elisha son of Shaphat plowing with twelve pairs of oxen, and he himself was driving the twelfth pair. Elijah went up to him and threw his cloak around him.
11:19:20/Elisha then left the oxen, ran after Elijah, and said, "Let me kiss my father and mother goodbye, and then I will follow you." Elijah replied, "Go back. What have I done to you?"
11:19:21/So Elisha turned back from him, took a pair of oxen, slaughtered them, and cooked the meat using the plowing equipment, and gave it to the people, and they ate. Then he set out to follow Elijah and became his attendant.
11:20:1/And Benhadad, the king of Syria, gathered all his forces together: there were thirty-two kings with him, along with horses and chariots. He advanced to besiege Samaria and waged war against it.
11:20:2/He sent messengers to Ahab, king of Israel, inside the city, saying to him, "This is what Benhadad demands: 
11:20:3/Your silver and gold are mine; your wives and your children, even the most attractive ones, belong to me."
11:20:4/The king of Israel responded, "As you say, my lord, O king, I and all I have are yours."
11:20:5/The messengers returned and said, "Benhadad insists, 'Although I demanded your silver, gold, wives, and children,
11:20:6/I will send my servants to you tomorrow around this time, and they will search your palace and the homes of your officials. Anything they find desirable, they will take."
11:20:7/Then the king of Israel summoned all the elders of the land and said, "Notice how this man is looking for trouble. He demanded my wives, children, silver, and gold, and I did not refuse him."
11:20:8/All the elders and the people advised him, "Do not listen to him or agree to his demands."
11:20:9/So he told Benhadad's messengers, "Tell my lord the king, 'I will do all you first asked of me, but this request I cannot fulfill.'" The messengers left and relayed the message.
11:20:10/Benhadad then sent this message: "May the gods deal harshly with me if there's enough dust in Samaria for all my followers to grab a handful."
11:20:11/The king of Israel replied, "Tell him, 'One should not boast as though they are putting on armor when they are taking it off.'"
11:20:12/When Benhadad received this message, he was drinking with the kings in the tents and ordered, "Prepare for battle!" So they prepared to attack the city.
11:20:13/Then a prophet approached Ahab, king of Israel, and announced, "This is what the LORD says: 'Do you see this vast army? Today, I will deliver it into your hands, and you will know that I am the LORD.'"
11:20:14/Ahab asked, "Through whom?" The prophet replied, "This is what the LORD says: 'Through the young leaders of the provinces.'" Then Ahab asked, "Who will start the battle?" He answered, "You will."
11:20:15/So he mustered the young leaders of the provinces, numbering two hundred and thirty-two. After them, he mustered all the Israelites, seven thousand in total.
11:20:16/They launched their attack at noon while Benhadad and the thirty-two kings allied with him were getting drunk in their tents.
11:20:17/The young leaders of the provinces went out first. Benhadad sent out scouts, who reported, "Men are coming out of Samaria."
11:20:18/He said, "Whether they come for peace or for war, capture them alive."
11:20:19/So the young leaders and the army following them came out of the city,
11:20:20/and each killed his opponent. The Syrians fled, and Israel pursued them. Benhadad, king of Syria, managed to escape on horseback with some horsemen.
11:20:21/The king of Israel attacked, destroying the horses and chariots, and inflicted a great defeat on the Syrians.
11:20:22/Then the prophet came to the king of Israel and advised him, "Strengthen your position and consider what you must do, because next spring the king of Syria will attack you again."
11:20:23/The officials of the king of Syria advised him, "Their gods are gods of the hills. That's why they were stronger than us. But if we fight them on the plains, we will surely be stronger than they are."
11:20:24/"Do this: Remove each king from his position and replace them with captains.
11:20:25/Recruit an army like the one you lost, horse for horse, chariot for chariot, and we will fight them on the plains. We will surely be stronger than they are." He agreed with their advice and did so.
11:20:26/At the return of the year, Benhadad mustered the Syrians and went up to Aphek to fight against Israel.
11:20:27/The Israelites were mustered and supplied, and they went to meet the Syrians. The Israelites camped before them like two small flocks of goats, while the Syrians filled the countryside.
11:20:28/Then a man of God came and told the king of Israel, "This is what the LORD says: 'Because the Syrians have said, "The LORD is a god of the hills but not a god of the valleys," I will deliver this vast army into your hands, and you will know that I am the LORD.'"
11:20:29/For seven days they camped opposite each other, and on the seventh day the battle ensued. The Israelites killed a hundred thousand Syrian foot soldiers in one day.
11:20:30/The survivors fled to Aphek, into the city, but the wall collapsed on twenty-seven thousand of the remaining men. And Benhadad fled and hid in an inner room in the city.
11:20:31/His officials said to him, "We've heard that the kings of Israel are merciful. Let's dress in sackcloth, put ropes around our heads, and go out to the king of Israel. Perhaps he will spare your life."
11:20:32/So they dressed in sackcloth, put ropes around their heads, and went to the king of Israel. They said, "Your servant Benhadad pleads, 'Please let me live.'" The king responded, "Is he still alive? He is my brother."
11:20:33/The men took this as a good sign and quickly grasped at his words. "Yes, your brother Benhadad," they said. "Go and bring him," the king said. When Benhadad came out to him, the king invited him up into his chariot.
11:20:34/Benhadad offered, "I will return the cities my father took from your father. And you may set up your own market areas in Damascus, as my father did in Samaria." Ahab replied, "On these terms, I will release you." So he made a treaty with him and let him go.
11:20:35/One of the sons of the prophets said to his companion by the word of the LORD, "Hit me, please." But the man refused to strike him.
11:20:36/He then said, "Because you have not obeyed the LORD's voice, as soon as you leave me, a lion will kill you." And as soon as he left him, a lion found him and killed him.
11:20:37/He found another man and said, "Please hit me." The man struck him, causing a wound.
11:20:38/So the prophet went and waited for the king by the road, disguising himself with ashes on his face.
11:20:39/As the king passed by, he cried out to the king: "Your servant went into the thick of the battle, and someone brought a man to me and said, 'Guard this man. If he is missing, your life will be taken for his life, or you will pay a talent of silver.'
11:20:40/While your servant was busy here and there, the man disappeared." The king of Israel said to him, "That is your verdict; you have decided it yourself."
11:20:41/He quickly removed the ashes from his face, and the king of Israel recognized him as one of the prophets.
11:20:42/He said to him, "This is what the LORD says: 'Because you have let go of a man I had determined should die, your life will be taken for his life, and your people for his people.'"
11:20:43/And the king of Israel went to his palace, sullen and angry, and arrived in Samaria.
11:21:1/After these events, Naboth the Jezreelite owned a vineyard in Jezreel, right next to the palace of Ahab, king of Samaria.
11:21:2/Ahab said to Naboth, "Let me have your vineyard to use as a herb garden, since it's so close to my house. I'll give you a better vineyard in exchange, or if you prefer, I'll pay you its value in money."
11:21:3/But Naboth told Ahab, "The LORD forbid that I should give you the inheritance of my ancestors."
11:21:4/Ahab returned to his house, upset and angry because of Naboth the Jezreelite's refusal to give him the inheritance of his ancestors. He lay on his bed, turned his face away, and refused to eat.
11:21:5/Jezebel, his wife, came to him and asked, "Why are you so upset that you're not eating?"
11:21:6/He told her, "I asked Naboth the Jezreelite to sell me his vineyard for money, or if he preferred, I would give him another vineyard in exchange. But he said, 'I will not give you my vineyard.'"
11:21:7/Jezebel, his wife, said to him, "Aren't you the ruler of Israel? Get up, eat something, and cheer up. I'll get you the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite."
11:21:8/So she wrote letters in Ahab's name, sealed them with his seal, and sent the letters to the elders and nobles who lived in Naboth's city.
11:21:9/In the letters, she wrote, "Declare a fast and place Naboth in a prominent position among the people."
11:21:10/Then appoint two scoundrels to accuse him, saying, 'You blasphemed God and the king.' Then take him out and stone him to death."
11:21:11/The elders and nobles of Naboth's city did as Jezebel had instructed in the letters she had sent them.
11:21:12/They declared a fast and placed Naboth in a prominent position among the people.
11:21:13/Two scoundrels came in and sat opposite him, and they accused Naboth in front of the people, saying, "Naboth blasphemed God and the king." So they took him outside the city and stoned him to death.
11:21:14/Then they sent word to Jezebel, saying, "Naboth has been stoned and is dead."
11:21:15/When Jezebel heard that Naboth had been stoned and was dead, she said to Ahab, "Get up and take possession of the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite, which he refused to sell to you. Naboth is no longer alive, but dead."
11:21:16/When Ahab heard that Naboth was dead, he got up to go down to the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite, to take possession of it.
11:21:17/And the word of the LORD came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying,
11:21:18/"Go down to meet Ahab king of Israel, who is in Samaria. He's at the vineyard of Naboth, where he has gone to take possession of it."
11:21:19/"Tell him, 'This is what the LORD says: Have you murdered and also taken possession? This is what the LORD says: In the place where dogs licked Naboth's blood, dogs will lick your blood, yes, yours.'"
11:21:20/Ahab said to Elijah, "Have you found me, my enemy?" Elijah answered, "I have found you, because you have sold yourself to do evil in the eyes of the LORD."
11:21:21/"I'm going to bring disaster on you. I will wipe out your descendants and cut off from Ahab every last male in Israel, both slave and free."
11:21:22/"I will make your house like that of Jeroboam son of Nebat and like that of Baasha son of Ahijah, because you have angered me and led Israel into sin."
11:21:23/And about Jezebel, the LORD also said, "Dogs will devour Jezebel by the wall of Jezreel."
11:21:24/"Anyone belonging to Ahab who dies in the city will be eaten by dogs, and anyone who dies in the field will be eaten by the birds."
11:21:25/But there was no one like Ahab, who sold himself to do what was evil in the LORD's sight, urged on by his wife Jezebel.
11:21:26/He acted most detestably in following idols, just as the Amorites had, whom the LORD drove out before the Israelites.
11:21:27/When Ahab heard these words, he tore his clothes, put on sackcloth, fasted, lay in sackcloth, and walked around meekly.
11:21:28/And the word of the LORD came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying,
11:21:29/"Do you see how Ahab has humbled himself before me? Because he has humbled himself before me, I will not bring the disaster in his time. But in his son's time, I will bring the disaster on his house."
11:22:1/And they continued three years without war between Syria and Israel.
11:22:2/In the third year, Jehoshaphat the king of Judah visited the king of Israel.
11:22:3/The king of Israel said to his servants, "Do you realize that Ramoth in Gilead belongs to us, yet we do nothing to take it back from the king of Syria?"
11:22:4/He then asked Jehoshaphat, "Will you join me in battle at Ramothgilead?" Jehoshaphat replied to the king of Israel, "I stand with you, my people as your people, my horses as your horses."
11:22:5/Jehoshaphat said to the king of Israel, "Please seek the LORD's guidance today."
11:22:6/So the king of Israel gathered about four hundred prophets and asked them, "Should I go to war against Ramothgilead, or should I hold back?" They answered, "Go ahead, for the LORD will give it into the king's hand."
11:22:7/Then Jehoshaphat asked, "Isn't there a prophet of the LORD here whom we can inquire of?"
11:22:8/The king of Israel told Jehoshaphat, "There is one more man, Micaiah son of Imlah, through whom we can inquire of the LORD, but I dislike him because he never prophesies anything good about me, only bad." Jehoshaphat said, "The king should not say such things."
11:22:9/So the king of Israel called for Micaiah son of Imlah to be brought quickly.
11:22:10/The king of Israel and Jehoshaphat king of Judah were sitting on their thrones, dressed in their royal robes, at the threshing floor by the entrance of the gate of Samaria, with all the prophets prophesying before them.
11:22:11/Zedekiah son of Chenaanah had made iron horns and declared, "This is what the LORD says: 'With these you will gore the Syrians until they are destroyed.'"
11:22:12/All the prophets were prophesying the same, saying, "Attack Ramothgilead and be victorious, for the LORD will give it into the king's hand."
11:22:13/The messenger who had gone to summon Micaiah said to him, "Look, the other prophets are unanimously predicting success for the king. Please let your word be in agreement with theirs and speak favorably."
11:22:14/But Micaiah said, "As surely as the LORD lives, I will say only what the LORD tells me to."
11:22:15/When he arrived, the king asked him, "Micaiah, should we go to war against Ramothgilead, or should we refrain?" He answered, "Go ahead, you will be successful, for the LORD will give it into the king's hand."
11:22:16/Then the king said to him, "How many times must I make you swear to tell me nothing but the truth in the name of the LORD?"
11:22:17/Micaiah replied, "I saw all Israel scattered on the hills like sheep without a shepherd, and the LORD said, 'These people have no leader. Let them go home in peace.'"
11:22:18/The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, "Didn't I tell you he never prophesies anything good about me, only bad?"
11:22:19/Micaiah continued, "Therefore, hear the word of the LORD: I saw the LORD sitting on his throne with all the armies of heaven standing around him, on his right and on his left.
11:22:20/And the LORD said, 'Who will entice Ahab to attack Ramothgilead and fall there?' One suggested this, and another that.
11:22:21/Then a spirit came forward, stood before the LORD, and said, 'I will entice him.'
11:22:22/'How?' the LORD asked. The spirit replied, 'I will go and become a lying spirit in the mouths of all his prophets.' 'You will succeed in enticing him,' said the LORD. 'Go and do it.'
11:22:23/So now, the LORD has put a lying spirit in the mouths of all these prophets of yours, and the LORD has decreed disaster for you."
11:22:24/But Zedekiah son of Chenaanah approached, struck Micaiah on the cheek, and asked, "How did the Spirit of the LORD go from me to speak to you?"
11:22:25/Micaiah replied, "You will find out on the day you go into an inner room to hide."
11:22:26/Then the king of Israel ordered, "Take Micaiah back to Amon the governor of the city and to Joash the king's son,
11:22:27/and say, 'This is what the king says: Put this man in prison and feed him only bread and water until I return safely.'"
11:22:28/Micaiah declared, "If you ever return safely, the LORD has not spoken through me. Listen, everyone, to what I have said."
11:22:29/So the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat king of Judah went up to Ramothgilead.
11:22:30/The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, "I will disguise myself and go into the battle, but you wear your royal robes." So the king of Israel disguised himself and went into the battle.
11:22:31/But the king of Syria had ordered his thirty-two chariot commanders, "Fight only with the king of Israel, not with anyone else, great or small."
11:22:32/When the chariot commanders saw Jehoshaphat, they thought, "Surely this is the king of Israel," and they turned to attack him. But Jehoshaphat cried out.
11:22:33/When the chariot commanders realized he was not the king of Israel, they stopped pursuing him.
11:22:34/But a random arrow shot by an archer struck the king of Israel between the sections of his armor. He told his chariot driver, "Turn around and get me out of the battle; I've been wounded."
11:22:35/The battle intensified that day, and the king was propped up in his chariot facing the Syrians. He died in the evening, and the blood from his wound flowed into the bottom of the chariot.
11:22:36/As the sun was setting, a cry spread through the army: "Every man to his town, every man to his land!"
11:22:37/So the king died and was brought to Samaria, and they buried him there.
11:22:38/Someone washed the chariot at the pool of Samaria, and the dogs licked up his blood, as the word of the LORD had declared.
11:22:39/The rest of the deeds of Ahab, all he did, the ivory house he built, and all the cities he constructed, are recorded in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel, aren't they?
11:22:40/Ahab rested with his ancestors, and Ahaziah his son succeeded him as king.
11:22:41/Jehoshaphat son of Asa began his reign over Judah in the fourth year of Ahab king of Israel.
11:22:42/Jehoshaphat was thirty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for twenty-five years. His mother's name was Azubah daughter of Shilhi.
11:22:43/He followed all the ways of his father Asa without turning away from them, doing what was right in the eyes of the LORD. However, the high places were not removed, and the people still offered sacrifices and burned incense there.
11:22:44/Jehoshaphat made peace with the king of Israel.
11:22:45/The rest of the acts of Jehoshaphat, his power, how he waged war, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Judah?
11:22:46/He removed from the land the rest of the male shrine prostitutes who remained from the days of his father Asa.
11:22:47/At that time there was no king in Edom; a deputy ruled.
11:22:48/Jehoshaphat built ships of Tarshish to go to Ophir for gold, but they never set sail because they were wrecked at Ezion Geber.
11:22:49/Ahaziah son of Ahab said to Jehoshaphat, "Let my men sail with yours," but Jehoshaphat refused.
11:22:50/Jehoshaphat rested with his ancestors and was buried with them in the city of David his father. And Jehoram his son succeeded him as king.
11:22:51/Ahaziah son of Ahab began to reign over Israel in Samaria in the seventeenth year of Jehoshaphat king of Judah, and he ruled over Israel for two years.
11:22:52/He did evil in the eyes of the LORD, following the ways of his father, his mother, and Jeroboam son of Nebat, who led Israel into sin.
11:22:53/He served and worshiped Baal, angering the LORD, the God of Israel, just as his father had done.
12:1:1/Then Moab rebelled against Israel after the death of Ahab.
12:1:2/And Ahaziah fell through a lattice in his upper room in Samaria, and was injured: he sent messengers, saying, "Go, ask Baalzebub, the god of Ekron, if I will recover from this illness."
12:1:3/But the angel of the LORD told Elijah the Tishbite, "Get up, go to meet the king of Samaria's messengers, and ask them, 'Isn't it because there's no God in Israel that you're asking Baalzebub, the god of Ekron?'"
12:1:4/"So, this is what the LORD says: 'You won't leave the bed you're lying on; you will definitely die.'" And Elijah left.
12:1:5/When the messengers returned to him, he asked, "Why have you come back so soon?"
12:1:6/They replied, "A man came to meet us and said, 'Go back to the king who sent you and tell him, "This is what the LORD says: 'Isn't it because there's no God in Israel that you're sending to inquire of Baalzebub, the god of Ekron? Therefore, you won't leave the bed you're on; you will definitely die.'"'"
12:1:7/He asked them, "What did the man who met you and told you this look like?"
12:1:8/They answered, "He was a hairy man, wearing a leather belt around his waist." And he said, "That's Elijah the Tishbite."
12:1:9/Then the king sent a captain with his fifty men to Elijah. They found him sitting on top of a hill and said, "Man of God, the king orders you to come down."
12:1:10/Elijah replied to the captain of fifty, "If I am a man of God, may fire come down from heaven and consume you and your fifty men." And fire came down from heaven and consumed him and his fifty.
12:1:11/Again, the king sent another captain of fifty with his fifty men. He said to Elijah, "Man of God, the king demands you come down immediately."
12:1:12/Elijah answered them, "If I am a man of God, let fire come down from heaven and consume you and your fifty men." And God's fire came down from heaven and consumed him and his fifty.
12:1:13/Once more, the king sent a captain of a third fifty with his fifty. This captain went up, fell on his knees before Elijah, and pleaded, "Man of God, please value my life and the lives of these fifty men of yours."
12:1:14/"Look, fire came down from heaven and burned up the two previous captains and their fifties; so now, please let my life be valuable to you."
12:1:15/The angel of the LORD told Elijah, "Go down with him; don't be afraid of him." So he got up and went down with him to the king.
12:1:16/He told the king, "This is what the LORD says: 'Since you sent messengers to inquire of Baalzebub, the god of Ekron—as if there's no God in Israel to inquire of—therefore, you won't leave the bed you're on; you will definitely die.'"
12:1:17/So he died according to the word of the LORD that Elijah had spoken. And Jehoram became king in his place in the second year of Jehoram the son of Jehoshaphat king of Judah; because Ahaziah had no son.
12:1:18/Now the rest of the acts of Ahaziah which he did, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
12:2:1/It happened that when the LORD was about to take Elijah up to heaven in a whirlwind, Elijah and Elisha left Gilgal together.
12:2:2/Elijah said to Elisha, "Please stay here; the LORD has sent me to Bethel." But Elisha replied, "As surely as the LORD lives and as you live, I will not leave you." So they went down to Bethel.
12:2:3/The group of prophets at Bethel came out to Elisha and asked him, "Do you know that the LORD is going to take your master away from you today?" He answered, "Yes, I know; be quiet."
12:2:4/Then Elijah said to him, "Elisha, please stay here; the LORD has sent me to Jericho." But he replied, "As surely as the LORD lives and as you live, I will not leave you." So they went to Jericho.
12:2:5/The group of prophets at Jericho approached Elisha and asked, "Do you know that the LORD is going to take your master away from you today?" He answered, "Yes, I know; be quiet."
12:2:6/Then Elijah said to him, "Please stay here, for the LORD has sent me to the Jordan." But he replied, "As surely as the LORD lives and as you live, I will not leave you." So the two of them went on.
12:2:7/Fifty men from the group of prophets went and stood at a distance, while Elijah and Elisha stood by the Jordan.
12:2:8/Elijah took his cloak, rolled it up, and struck the water with it. The water divided to the right and to the left, and the two of them crossed on dry ground.
12:2:9/After they had crossed, Elijah said to Elisha, "Tell me, what can I do for you before I am taken from you?" Elisha replied, "Please let me inherit a double portion of your spirit."
12:2:10/Elijah said, "You have asked for something difficult. Yet, if you see me when I am taken from you, it will be yours—otherwise, it will not."
12:2:11/As they continued walking and talking, suddenly a chariot of fire and horses of fire appeared and separated the two of them, and Elijah went up to heaven in a whirlwind.
12:2:12/When Elisha saw this, he cried out, "My father, my father, the chariots and horsemen of Israel!" And he saw him no more. Then he took hold of his own clothes and tore them in two.
12:2:13/He also picked up the cloak that had fallen from Elijah and went back, standing by the bank of the Jordan.
12:2:14/He took the cloak that had fallen from Elijah, struck the water, and said, "Where is the LORD, the God of Elijah?" When he struck the water, it divided to the right and to the left, and Elisha crossed over.
12:2:15/When the group of prophets from Jericho saw him, they said, "The spirit of Elijah rests on Elisha." They went to meet him and bowed to the ground before him.
12:2:16/They said to him, "Look, we have fifty strong men with your servants. Please let them go and search for your master. Perhaps the Spirit of the LORD has lifted him up and thrown him onto some mountain or into some valley." But he said, "Do not send them."
12:2:17/However, they persisted until he was too embarrassed to refuse. So he said, "Send them." They sent fifty men, who searched for three days but did not find him.
12:2:18/When they returned to him (he was staying in Jericho), he said to them, "Didn't I tell you not to go?"
12:2:19/The people of the city said to Elisha, "Look, the location of this city is good, as my lord sees, but the water is bad, and the land is unproductive."
12:2:20/He said, "Bring me a new bowl and put salt in it." So they brought it to him.
12:2:21/Then he went out to the source of the water, threw the salt in it, and said, "This is what the LORD says: 'I have purified these waters; there will no longer be any death or unproductivity from them.'"
12:2:22/So the waters were purified to this day, according to the word Elisha had spoken.
12:2:23/From there he went up to Bethel. As he was walking along the road, some boys came out of the town and mocked him, saying, "Go up, you baldhead! Go up, you baldhead!"
12:2:24/He turned around, looked at them, and called down a curse on them in the name of the LORD. Then two bears came out of the woods and mauled forty-two of the boys.
12:2:25/He then went from there to Mount Carmel, and from there he returned to Samaria.
12:3:1/Jehoram, Ahab's son, started his reign over Israel in Samaria during the eighteenth year of Jehoshaphat, king of Judah, and ruled for twelve years.
12:3:2/He did evil in the eyes of the LORD, but not to the extent of his father and mother, since he removed the Baal idol his father had set up.
12:3:3/However, he continued to follow the sinful practices of Jeroboam son of Nebat, which led Israel into sin; he didn't turn away from them.
12:3:4/Mesha, the king of Moab, who was a major sheep breeder, paid the king of Israel a tribute of a hundred thousand lambs and the wool of a hundred thousand rams.
12:3:5/But after Ahab's death, the king of Moab rebelled against the king of Israel.
12:3:6/King Jehoram left Samaria at that time and mustered all of Israel.
12:3:7/He then sent a message to Jehoshaphat, king of Judah, "The king of Moab has rebelled against me. Will you join me in battle against Moab?" Jehoshaphat replied, "I'm in. Your people are my people, your horses are my horses."
12:3:8/He then asked, "Which route shall we attack from?" The response was, "Through the wilderness of Edom."
12:3:9/So the king of Israel, the king of Judah, and the king of Edom set out. They took a roundabout route of seven days, but there was no water for the army or the animals that followed them.
12:3:10/The king of Israel exclaimed, "Oh no! The LORD has brought us three kings together only to hand us over to Moab!"
12:3:11/But Jehoshaphat asked, "Isn't there a prophet of the LORD here through whom we can inquire of the LORD?" An officer of the king of Israel answered, "Elisha son of Shaphat is here, who used to pour water on the hands of Elijah."
12:3:12/Jehoshaphat said, "The word of the LORD is with him." So the king of Israel, Jehoshaphat, and the king of Edom went down to him.
12:3:13/Elisha said to the king of Israel, "What do we have to do with each other? Go to the prophets of your father and the prophets of your mother." But the king of Israel said to him, "No, for the LORD has summoned these three kings to deliver them into the hands of Moab."
12:3:14/Elisha replied, "As surely as the LORD Almighty lives, whom I serve, if I did not have respect for Jehoshaphat king of Judah, I wouldn't even look at you or notice you.
12:3:15/But now, bring me a musician." And when the musician played, the hand of the LORD came upon Elisha.
12:3:16/He declared, "This is what the LORD says: 'Dig this valley full of ditches.'"
12:3:17/"For this is what the LORD says: 'You will see neither wind nor rain, yet this valley will be filled with water, and you, your cattle, and your other animals will drink.'"
12:3:18/"And this is an easy thing in the eyes of the LORD; He will also deliver the Moabites into your hands."
12:3:19/"You will overthrow every fortified city and every major town. You will cut down every good tree, stop up all the springs of water, and ruin every good field with stones."
12:3:20/And in the morning, at the time of the grain offering, water suddenly flowed from the direction of Edom, and the land was filled with water.
12:3:21/When all the Moabites heard that the kings had come to fight against them, everyone who could bear arms, from the youngest to the oldest, was called up and stationed at the border.
12:3:22/They got up early in the morning, and the sun shone on the water, making it look red like blood to the Moabites.
12:3:23/They exclaimed, "That's blood! The kings must have fought and killed each other. Now, Moab, to the spoils!"
12:3:24/But when the Moabites came to the Israelite camp, the Israelites rose up and defeated the Moabites, who fled before them. They advanced, striking down the Moabites as they went.
12:3:25/They destroyed the cities, and each man threw a stone on every good piece of land until it was covered. They stopped all the springs of water and cut down all the good trees. Only in Kirharaseth did they leave the stones in place; however, the slingers surrounded it and attacked it.
12:3:26/When the king of Moab saw that the battle was too intense for him, he took seven hundred swordsmen to break through to the king of Edom, but they failed.
12:3:27/Then he took his eldest son, who was to succeed him as king, and sacrificed him as a burnt offering on the city wall. This caused great anger against Israel, and they withdrew and returned to their own land.
12:4:1/A woman, whose husband was one of the prophet's disciples, came to Elisha in distress. She said, "My husband, your servant, has passed away. You know he revered the LORD. Now, a creditor is coming to take my two sons as slaves."
12:4:2/Elisha asked her, "What can I do for you? Tell me, what do you have at home?" She replied, "Your servant has nothing at home except a jar of oil."
12:4:3/He then said, "Go outside, borrow containers from all your neighbors, and make sure you get plenty of them."
12:4:4/"Once you're back inside, close the door behind you and your sons. Then pour oil into all the containers, setting aside the full ones."
12:4:5/She followed his instructions, closing the door behind her and her sons. They brought the containers to her, and she filled them.
12:4:6/When all the containers were full, she asked her son for another, but he said, "There are no more." Then the oil stopped flowing.
12:4:7/She reported back to the man of God, who said, "Go, sell the oil, pay off your debt, and you and your sons can live on what's left."
12:4:8/One day, Elisha went to Shunem, where a prominent woman lived. She insisted that he stay for a meal. From then on, whenever he passed by, he would stop there to eat.
12:4:9/She said to her husband, "I'm sure this man who keeps stopping by is a holy man of God."
12:4:10/"Let's build a small room for him on the roof and furnish it with a bed, table, chair, and lamp, so he can stay with us whenever he comes."
12:4:11/One day, Elisha came and stayed in the room.
12:4:12/He asked his servant Gehazi to call the Shunammite woman. When she appeared before him,
12:4:13/he instructed Gehazi, "Tell her, 'You've gone to all this trouble for us. What can we do for you? Would you like us to speak on your behalf to the king or the commander of the army?'" She replied, "I have my home among my people."
12:4:14/He asked, "What can we do for her?" Gehazi said, "Actually, she has no son, and her husband is old."
12:4:15/Elisha said, "Call her." So he called her, and she stood in the doorway.
12:4:16/"Next year, at this time, you will hold a son in your arms," he said. But she replied, "No, my lord, man of God, do not mislead your servant."
12:4:17/Yet the woman conceived and gave birth to a son the following year, just as Elisha had told her.
12:4:18/When the child grew older, he went out to his father, who was with the reapers.
12:4:19/He complained to his father, "My head, my head!" His father told a servant, "Carry him to his mother."
12:4:20/The servant carried him to his mother, and he sat on her lap until noon, then he died.
12:4:21/She went up and laid him on the bed of the man of God, shut the door, and left.
12:4:22/Then she called to her husband, "Please send me one of the servants and a donkey so I can quickly go to the man of God and return."
12:4:23/He asked, "Why are you going to him today? It's not the New Moon or the Sabbath." She said, "It will be alright."
12:4:24/She saddled the donkey and told her servant, "Hurry, don't slow down unless I tell you to."
12:4:25/So she went to the man of God at Mount Carmel. When Elisha saw her coming, he said to Gehazi, "Look, there's the Shunammite woman.
12:4:26/"Run to meet her and ask, 'Are you alright? Is your husband alright? Is the child alright?'" She answered, "Everything is fine."
12:4:27/But when she reached the man of God at the mountain, she took hold of his feet. Gehazi approached to push her away, but the man of God said, "Leave her alone, she is deeply troubled, and the LORD has hidden the reason from me."
12:4:28/She said, "Did I ask for a son, my lord? Didn't I tell you not to raise my hopes?"
12:4:29/Elisha then said to Gehazi, "Tuck your cloak into your belt, take my staff, and go. If you meet anyone, don't greet them; if anyone greets you, don't answer. Lay my staff on the boy's face."
12:4:30/But the boy's mother said, "As surely as the LORD lives and as you live, I will not leave you." So he got up and followed her.
12:4:31/Gehazi went ahead and laid the staff on the boy's face, but there was no sound or response. So he went back to meet Elisha and told him, "The boy has not awakened."
12:4:32/When Elisha arrived at the house, he found the boy dead and lying on his bed.
12:4:33/He went in, closed the door on the two of them, and prayed to the LORD.
12:4:34/Then he got on the bed and lay on the boy, mouth to mouth, eyes to eyes, hands to hands. As he stretched himself out on him, the boy's body grew warm.
12:4:35/Elisha turned away and walked back and forth in the room, then got on the bed and stretched out on him again. The boy sneezed seven times and opened his eyes.
12:4:36/Elisha called Gehazi and said, "Call the Shunammite woman." So he did. When she came, he said, "Pick up your son."
12:4:37/She came in, fell at his feet, and bowed to the ground. Then she picked up her son and went out.
12:4:38/Elisha returned to Gilgal during a famine. The company of prophets was sitting before him, and he said to his servant, "Put on the large pot and cook some stew for the prophets."
12:4:39/One of them went out to the fields to gather herbs and found a wild vine. He gathered some of its gourds, filling his cloak, and came back to shred them into the pot of stew, though no one knew what they were.
12:4:40/They served the stew for the men to eat, but as they began eating, they cried out, "Man of God, there's poison in the pot!" And they couldn't eat it.
12:4:41/Elisha said, "Bring some flour." He threw it into the pot and said, "Serve it to the people to eat." And there was nothing harmful in the pot.
12:4:42/A man came from Baal-shalisha, bringing the man of God twenty loaves of barley bread and freshly ripened grain. Elisha said, "Give it to the people to eat."
12:4:43/His servant asked, "How can I set this before a hundred men?" But Elisha repeated, "Give it to the people to eat. For this is what the LORD says: 'They will eat and have some left over.'"
12:4:44/So he set it before them, and they ate and had leftovers, according to the word of the LORD.
12:5:1/Now Naaman, the commander of the Syrian king's army, was highly regarded by his master and honored because through him, the LORD had brought victory to Syria. He was also a brave warrior, but he had leprosy.
12:5:2/The Syrians had conducted raids and had taken a young girl from Israel captive; she served Naaman's wife.
12:5:3/She said to her mistress, "If only my master were with the prophet in Samaria! He would cure him of his leprosy."
12:5:4/Someone went and told his master, "This is what the girl from Israel has said."
12:5:5/The king of Syria said, "Go ahead, and I will send a letter to the king of Israel." So he left, taking with him ten talents of silver, six thousand pieces of gold, and ten sets of clothing.
12:5:6/He delivered the letter to the king of Israel, which read, "When this letter reaches you, know that I have sent my servant Naaman to you so you can cure him of his leprosy."
12:5:7/When the king of Israel read the letter, he tore his clothes in distress and said, "Am I God, able to kill and bring to life, that this man sends someone to me to be cured of his leprosy? See how he is trying to pick a fight with me!"
12:5:8/When Elisha, the man of God, heard that the king of Israel had torn his clothes, he sent a message to the king, "Why have you torn your clothes? Let him come to me, and he will know that there is a prophet in Israel."
12:5:9/So Naaman arrived with his horses and chariot and stood at the door of Elisha's house.
12:5:10/Elisha sent a messenger to him, saying, "Go and wash in the Jordan River seven times, and your skin will be restored, and you will be cleansed."
12:5:11/But Naaman became angry and left, saying, "I thought he would surely come out to me, stand and call on the name of the LORD his God, wave his hand over the spot, and cure the leprosy.
12:5:12/Aren't the Abana and Pharpar, the rivers of Damascus, better than all the waters of Israel? Couldn't I wash in them and be cleansed?" So he turned and left in a rage.
12:5:13/His servants approached him and said, "Father, if the prophet had told you to do something difficult, wouldn't you have done it? How much more, then, when he tells you, 'Wash and be cleansed'?"
12:5:14/So he went down and dipped himself in the Jordan seven times, as the man of God had instructed. His skin was restored like that of a young boy, and he was cleansed.
12:5:15/Then he returned to the man of God with all his entourage, stood before him, and declared, "Now I know that there is no God in all the world except in Israel. Please accept a gift from your servant."
12:5:16/But Elisha replied, "As surely as the LORD lives, whom I serve, I will not accept a thing." And even though Naaman urged him, he refused.
12:5:17/Then Naaman said, "If not, please let your servant be given as much earth as two mules can carry, for your servant will never again make burnt offerings and sacrifices to any god but the LORD.
12:5:18/However, may the LORD forgive your servant for this one thing: When my master enters the temple of Rimmon to worship there and leans on my arm, and I bow down in the temple of Rimmon, may the LORD forgive your servant for this."
12:5:19/Elisha said to him, "Go in peace." So he left him a short distance away.
12:5:20/But Gehazi, the servant of Elisha the man of God, thought, "My master has let Naaman the Syrian off too easily by not accepting what he brought. As surely as the LORD lives, I will run after him and get something from him."
12:5:21/So Gehazi chased after Naaman. When Naaman saw him running towards him, he got down from the chariot to meet him and asked, "Is everything alright?"
12:5:22/He replied, "Everything is fine. My master sent me to say, 'Just now two young men from the company of the prophets have come to me from the hill country of Ephraim. Please give them a talent of silver and two sets of clothing.'"
12:5:23/Naaman said, "Please take two talents." He insisted, and tied up two talents of silver in two bags, with two sets of clothing, and gave them to two of his servants, who carried them ahead of Gehazi.
12:5:24/When he arrived at the tower, he took the items from their hands and stored them in the house. Then he let the men go, and they left.
12:5:25/He then went in and stood before his master. Elisha asked him, "Where have you been, Gehazi?" He answered, "Your servant didn't go anywhere."
12:5:26/But Elisha said to him, "Wasn't my spirit with you when the man got down from his chariot to meet you? Is this the time to take money or to accept clothes, olive groves, vineyards, sheep, oxen, male and female servants?
12:5:27/Therefore, Naaman's leprosy will cling to you and your descendants forever." And Gehazi left his presence leprous, as white as snow.
12:6:1/The students of the prophets said to Elisha, "Look, the place where we're staying with you is too small for us.
12:6:2/Let's go to the Jordan River, and each of us can get a log to build a bigger place for us to live." And he said, "Go ahead."
12:6:3/One of them said, "Please, come with your servants." And he answered, "I'll come."
12:6:4/So he went with them. When they arrived at the Jordan, they began to cut down trees.
12:6:5/But as one was cutting down a tree, the axe head fell into the water. He cried out, "Oh no, my master! It was borrowed!"
12:6:6/The man of God asked, "Where did it fall?" When he showed him the place, Elisha cut a stick and threw it there, and the iron floated.
12:6:7/Then he said, "Pick it up." So he reached out his hand and took it.
12:6:8/The king of Syria was at war with Israel and discussed with his advisors, saying, "We will camp in such and such a place."
12:6:9/But the man of God sent a message to the king of Israel: "Be careful not to pass by this place, because the Syrians are heading there."
12:6:10/So the king of Israel checked the place the man of God had mentioned and warned him about, and he was careful to avoid it, not just once or twice.
12:6:11/This greatly upset the king of Syria. He called his officers and demanded, "Won't you tell me which of us is siding with the king of Israel?"
12:6:12/One of his officers said, "No, my lord, the king. It's Elisha, the prophet in Israel, who tells the king of Israel even the words you speak in your bedroom."
12:6:13/He said, "Go and find out where he is, so I can send people to capture him." They reported, "He's in Dothan."
12:6:14/So he sent horses, chariots, and a large army there. They arrived at night and surrounded the city.
12:6:15/When the servant of the man of God got up early and went out, he saw an army with horses and chariots surrounding the city. The servant said to him, "Oh no, my master! What are we going to do?"
12:6:16/He answered, "Don't be afraid. Those who are with us outnumber those who are with them."
12:6:17/Then Elisha prayed, "LORD, please open his eyes so he can see." And the LORD opened the servant's eyes, and he saw the hills full of horses and chariots of fire all around Elisha.
12:6:18/As the enemy came down toward him, Elisha prayed to the LORD, "Strike these people with blindness." And He struck them with blindness, as Elisha had asked.
12:6:19/Elisha told them, "This isn't the right way or the right city. Follow me, and I'll lead you to the man you're looking for." But he led them to Samaria.
12:6:20/When they entered Samaria, Elisha said, "LORD, open the eyes of these men so they can see." The LORD opened their eyes, and they realized they were inside Samaria.
12:6:21/When the king of Israel saw them, he asked Elisha, "Should I kill them, my father? Should I kill them?"
12:6:22/He answered, "Don't kill them. Would you kill those you've captured with your own sword or bow? Give them food and water so they can eat and drink, and then let them return to their master."
12:6:23/So he prepared a big feast for them, and after they had eaten and drunk, he sent them away, and they returned to their master. After that, the Syrian raiders stopped invading Israel's territory.
12:6:24/Afterward, Benhadad king of Syria mobilized his entire army and besieged Samaria.
12:6:25/There was a severe famine in Samaria, and they besieged it until a donkey's head was sold for eighty pieces of silver, and a quarter of a cab of dove's dung for five pieces of silver.
12:6:26/As the king of Israel was passing by on the wall, a woman cried out to him, "Help, my lord, O king!"
12:6:27/He said, "If the LORD doesn't help you, how can I? Can I offer help from the threshing floor or the winepress?"
12:6:28/The king asked her, "What's wrong?" She replied, "This woman said to me, 'Give up your son so we can eat him today, and tomorrow we'll eat my son.'"
12:6:29/So we cooked my son and ate him. Then I said to her the next day, 'Give up your son so we can eat him,' but she has hidden her son."
12:6:30/When the king heard the woman's words, he tore his clothes. As he walked along the wall, the people saw that he was wearing sackcloth on his body underneath.
12:6:31/He said, "May God deal with me, be it ever so severely, if the head of Elisha son of Shaphat remains on his shoulders today."
12:6:32/But Elisha was sitting in his house, and the elders were sitting with him. Before the king's messenger arrived, Elisha said to the elders, "Do you see how this murderer has sent someone to cut off my head? When the messenger comes, close the door and hold it shut against him. Isn't the sound of his master's footsteps behind him?"
12:6:33/While he was still talking to them, the messenger came down to him. And the king said, "This disaster is from the LORD. Why should I wait for the LORD any longer?"
12:7:1/Then Elisha said, "Listen to the word of the LORD; This is what the LORD says, 'Tomorrow at this time, a measure of fine flour will be sold for a shekel, and two measures of barley for a shekel, at the gate of Samaria.'"
12:7:2/Then an official on whom the king relied answered the man of God, "Look, even if the LORD were to open windows in heaven, could this happen?" And he said, "You will see it with your own eyes, but you will not eat any of it."
12:7:3/There were four men with leprosy at the entrance of the gate, and they said to each other, "Why are we sitting here until we die?"
12:7:4/"If we decide to go into the city, the famine is there, and we will die. And if we stay here, we will also die. So let's go over to the camp of the Syrians. If they spare us, we live; if they kill us, then we die."
12:7:5/So they got up at twilight to go to the camp of the Syrians. When they reached the edge of the Syrian camp, to their surprise, no one was there.
12:7:6/For the LORD had caused the Syrian army to hear the sound of chariots and horses, the sound of a great army, so they said to one another, "Look, the king of Israel has hired the Hittite and Egyptian kings to attack us."
12:7:7/So they got up and fled in the twilight, leaving their tents, horses, and donkeys behind, and the camp as it was, running for their lives.
12:7:8/When these lepers reached the edge of the camp, they entered one tent, ate and drank, and took silver, gold, and clothes, and went and hid them. Then they came back, entered another tent, took things from it, and went and hid them too.
12:7:9/Then they said to each other, "We're not doing right. Today is a day of good news, and we're keeping silent. If we wait until daylight, punishment will overtake us. Let's go and report this to the royal palace."
12:7:10/So they went and called out to the city gatekeepers and told them, "We went to the Syrian camp, and there was no one there, no human voice, only tethered horses and donkeys, and the tents left just as they were."
12:7:11/The gatekeepers shouted the news, and it was reported within the king's palace.
12:7:12/The king got up in the night and said to his servants, "Let me tell you what the Syrians have done to us. They know we're starving, so they've left the camp to hide in the countryside, thinking, 'When they come out of the city, we'll capture them alive and then enter the city.'"
12:7:13/One of his servants suggested, "Please, let some men take five of the remaining horses in the city. They're like all the multitude of Israel that's left here. Let's send them to see what's happened."
12:7:14/So they took two chariots with horses, and the king sent them after the Syrian army, saying, "Go and see."
12:7:15/They followed them to the Jordan River, and found the whole way littered with clothes and equipment the Syrians had thrown away in their haste. The messengers returned and reported to the king.
12:7:16/Then the people went out and plundered the Syrian camp. So a measure of fine flour was sold for a shekel, and two measures of barley for a shekel, just as the LORD had said.
12:7:17/The king had put the official who had doubted the word of the LORD in charge of the gate, but the people trampled him in the gate, and he died, just as the man of God had foretold when the king came down to him.
12:7:18/It happened just as the man of God had told the king, "Two measures of barley for a shekel, and a measure of fine flour for a shekel, will be available tomorrow at this time at the gate of Samaria."
12:7:19/And the official had answered the man of God, "Even if the LORD were to make windows in heaven, could such a thing happen?" And he had said, "You will see it with your own eyes, but you will not eat any of it."
12:7:20/And that's exactly what happened to him: the people trampled him in the gate, and he died.
12:8:1/Then Elisha spoke to the woman, whose son he had brought back to life, saying, "Get up, take your family, and find a place to stay wherever you can, because the LORD has announced a famine that will last seven years."
12:8:2/And the woman got up and did as the man of God instructed. She and her family moved to the land of the Philistines and lived there for seven years.
12:8:3/At the end of the seven years, the woman came back from the land of the Philistines. She went to appeal to the king for her house and her land.
12:8:4/And the king was speaking with Gehazi, the servant of the man of God, asking, "Please tell me about all the remarkable things Elisha has done."
12:8:5/While he was telling the king how he had brought a dead person back to life, the woman whose son he had brought back to life came to the king to plead for her house and her land. Gehazi said, "My lord, O king, this is the woman, and this is her son whom Elisha brought back to life."
12:8:6/When the king asked the woman about it, she told him. So the king assigned an official to her case, saying, "Give back everything that belonged to her, including all the income from her land from the day she left until now."
12:8:7/And Elisha went to Damascus; Benhadad, the king of Syria, was ill; and it was reported to him, saying, "The man of God has arrived here."
12:8:8/And the king said to Hazael, "Take a gift in your hand, go meet the man of God, and ask the LORD through him, saying, 'Will I recover from this illness?'"
12:8:9/So Hazael went to meet him, taking a gift with him, all kinds of good things from Damascus, enough for forty camels, and stood before him, saying, "Your son Benhadad, king of Syria, has sent me to you, asking, 'Will I recover from this illness?'"
12:8:10/And Elisha told him, "Go, tell him, 'You will definitely recover.' However, the LORD has shown me that he will certainly die."
12:8:11/And he stared at him fixedly until he was embarrassed, and then the man of God began to cry.
12:8:12/And Hazael asked, "Why is my lord crying?" He answered, "Because I know the harm you will do to the children of Israel: you will set their fortresses on fire, kill their young men with the sword, smash their children, and cut open their pregnant women."
12:8:13/And Hazael said, "But what, am I a dog, that I would do such a terrible thing?" And Elisha answered, "The LORD has shown me that you will become king over Syria."
12:8:14/So he left Elisha and returned to his master, who asked him, "What did Elisha say to you?" And he replied, "He told me you would surely recover."
12:8:15/But the next day, he took a thick cloth, soaked it in water, and spread it over his face, so that he died. And Hazael became king in his place.
12:8:16/In the fifth year of Joram, son of Ahab king of Israel, while Jehoshaphat was king of Judah, Jehoram, son of Jehoshaphat king of Judah, began to reign.
12:8:17/He was thirty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned for eight years in Jerusalem.
12:8:18/He followed the ways of the kings of Israel, just as the house of Ahab had done, because he married a daughter of Ahab. He did what was evil in the LORD's sight.
12:8:19/Yet the LORD did not want to destroy Judah, for the sake of David His servant, as He had promised to maintain a lamp for him and his descendants forever.
12:8:20/During his reign, Edom rebelled against Judah's authority and set up their own king.
12:8:21/So Joram crossed over to Zair with all his chariots. He set out at night and defeated the Edomites who had surrounded him, along with the commanders of his chariots. Then his army fled back to their tents.
12:8:22/But Edom continued to rebel against Judah's authority to this day. At the same time, Libnah also rebelled.
12:8:23/The rest of the events of Joram's reign, and all he did, are recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah.
12:8:24/And Joram rested with his ancestors and was buried with them in the city of David. And Ahaziah his son succeeded him as king.
12:8:25/In the twelfth year of Joram, son of Ahab king of Israel, Ahaziah, son of Jehoram king of Judah, began to reign.
12:8:26/Ahaziah was twenty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned for one year in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Athaliah, a granddaughter of Omri king of Israel.
12:8:27/He followed the ways of the house of Ahab and did evil in the eyes of the LORD, just as the house of Ahab had done, because he was related by marriage to the house of Ahab.
12:8:28/He joined Joram son of Ahab in a war against Hazael king of Syria at Ramoth Gilead, where the Syrians wounded Joram.
12:8:29/King Joram returned to Jezreel to recover from the wounds the Syrians had inflicted on him at Ramah during his battle with Hazael king of Syria. Ahaziah, son of Jehoram king of Judah, went down to see Joram son of Ahab in Jezreel because he was ill.
12:9:1/Elisha the prophet called one of the young prophets and said to him, "Get ready, take this flask of oil in your hand, and go to Ramothgilead.
12:9:2/When you arrive there, find Jehu, the son of Jehoshaphat, the son of Nimshi. Go in, have him stand up from among his brothers, and take him to a private room.
12:9:3/Then take the flask of oil, pour it on his head, and say, 'This is what the LORD says: I have anointed you king over Israel.' Then open the door, run away, and don't stop.
12:9:4/So the young man, the prophet, went to Ramothgilead.
