12:9:5/When he arrived, he found the army commanders sitting together. He said, "I have a message for you, commander." Jehu asked, "For which one of us?" He replied, "For you, commander."
12:9:6/Jehu stood up and went into the house. The young prophet poured the oil on Jehu's head and told him, "This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: I have anointed you king over the LORD's people, Israel.
12:9:7/You are to destroy the house of Ahab, your master, so I can avenge the blood of my servants, the prophets, and the blood of all the LORD's servants, shed by Jezebel.
12:9:8/The entire house of Ahab will perish: I will eliminate every male in Ahab's line, whether free or slave in Israel.
12:9:9/I will make Ahab's house like the house of Jeroboam, son of Nebat, and like the house of Baasha, son of Ahijah.
12:9:10/The dogs will eat Jezebel in the territory of Jezreel, and no one will bury her." Then he opened the door and ran away.
12:9:11/Then Jehu went out to his master's servants. They asked him, "Is everything alright? Why did this crazy man come to you?" He replied, "You know the man and his talk."
12:9:12/They said, "That's not true; tell us now." Jehu said, "He told me this and that, saying, 'This is what the LORD says: I have anointed you king over Israel.'"
12:9:13/They quickly took their cloaks, spread them under him on the bare steps, blew the trumpet, and proclaimed, "Jehu is king."
12:9:14/So Jehu, the son of Jehoshaphat, the son of Nimshi, plotted against Joram. (Now Joram and all Israel had been defending Ramothgilead against Hazael, king of Syria,
12:9:15/But King Joram had returned to Jezreel to recover from the wounds the Syrians had inflicted on him during the battle with Hazael, king of Syria.) Jehu said, "If you are with me, don't let anyone escape from the city to go and warn Jezreel."
12:9:16/So Jehu got into his chariot and went to Jezreel, where Joram was resting. Ahaziah, king of Judah, had come down to visit Joram.
12:9:17/A lookout standing on the tower in Jezreel saw Jehu's troops approaching and announced, "I see a group." Joram ordered, "Send a horseman to meet them and ask, 'Is it peace?'"
12:9:18/So a horseman went to meet Jehu and said, "The king asks, 'Is it peace?'" Jehu replied, "What do you care about peace? Fall in behind me." The lookout reported, "The messenger reached them, but he's not coming back."
12:9:19/Then Joram sent out a second horseman, who came to them and said, "The king asks, 'Is it peace?'" Jehu answered, "What do you care about peace? Fall in behind me."
12:9:20/The lookout reported, "He reached them, but he's not coming back either. The driving is like that of Jehu, the son of Nimshi—he drives furiously."
12:9:21/Joram said, "Get ready." They prepared his chariot. Then Joram, king of Israel, and Ahaziah, king of Judah, rode out, each in his chariot, to meet Jehu. They met him at the plot of land belonging to Naboth the Jezreelite.
12:9:22/When Joram saw Jehu, he asked, "Is it peace, Jehu?" Jehu replied, "How can there be peace as long as the idolatry and witchcraft of your mother Jezebel abound?"
12:9:23/Joram turned to flee and cried out to Ahaziah, "Treachery, Ahaziah!"
12:9:24/Jehu drew his bow with full strength and shot Jehoram between the shoulders. The arrow pierced his heart, and he slumped down in his chariot.
12:9:25/Then Jehu said to Bidkar, his officer, "Pick him up and throw him into the field of Naboth the Jezreelite. Remember how you and I were riding together behind Ahab, his father, when the LORD pronounced this judgment on him:
12:9:26/'Yesterday, I saw the blood of Naboth and the blood of his sons,' says the LORD, 'and I will repay you on this plot of land,' says the LORD. Now, pick him up and throw him onto the plot, according to the word of the LORD."
12:9:27/But when Ahaziah, king of Judah, saw this, he fled by the way of the garden house. Jehu followed him, shouting, "Hit him too, in the chariot." They did so at the ascent of Gur, near Ibleam. Ahaziah managed to reach Megiddo but died there.
12:9:28/His servants drove him in his chariot to Jerusalem and buried him in his tomb with his ancestors in the city of David.
12:9:29/In the eleventh year of Joram, son of Ahab, Ahaziah began to reign over Judah.
12:9:30/When Jehu arrived in Jezreel, Jezebel heard about it. She put on makeup, fixed her hair, and looked out of a window.
12:9:31/As Jehu entered the gate, she asked, "Did Zimri have peace after killing his master?"
12:9:32/He looked up at the window and shouted, "Who's on my side? Who?" Two or three eunuchs looked down at him.
12:9:33/He said, "Throw her down." So they threw her down, and her blood splattered on the wall and on the horses, and he trampled her underfoot.
12:9:34/After he had gone in, he ate and drank. Then he said, "Take care of this cursed woman and bury her, for she was a king's daughter."
12:9:35/But when they went to bury her, they found nothing but her skull, feet, and the palms of her hands.
12:9:36/So they went back and told Jehu. He said, "This fulfills the word of the LORD, which he spoke through his servant Elijah the Tishbite: 'In the plot of Jezreel, dogs will eat Jezebel's flesh.
12:9:37/Jezebel's body will be like dung on the ground in the plot at Jezreel, so that no one will be able to say, 'This is Jezebel.'"
12:10:1/Ahab had seventy sons in Samaria. Jehu wrote letters and sent them to Samaria, to the leaders of Jezreel, the elders, and those responsible for raising Ahab's children, saying,
12:10:2/As soon as you receive this letter, given that your master's sons are with you, along with chariots, horses, a fortified city, and weapons;
12:10:3/Select the best and most suitable of your master's sons, place him on his father's throne, and defend your master's dynasty.
12:10:4/But they were extremely afraid and said, "Two kings couldn't stand against him; how can we?"
12:10:5/The household manager, the city manager, the elders, and the caretakers of the children sent a message to Jehu, saying, "We are your servants and will do everything you tell us; we won't appoint any king. Do what you think is best."
12:10:6/Then he sent them a second letter, saying, "If you are on my side and will listen to me, take the heads of your master's sons and come to me in Jezreel by this time tomorrow." The king's sons, seventy in number, were with the city's leading men, who had raised them.
12:10:7/When the letter arrived, they killed the king's sons, all seventy of them, put their heads in baskets, and sent them to Jehu in Jezreel.
12:10:8/A messenger arrived and told him, "They have brought the heads of the king's sons." He said, "Stack them in two piles at the entrance of the gate until morning."
12:10:9/In the morning, he went out, stood before all the people, and said, "You are innocent. I plotted against my master and killed him, but who killed all these?
12:10:10/Know now that not a single word the LORD has spoken about the house of Ahab will fail; the LORD has done what he promised through his servant Elijah."
12:10:11/So Jehu killed everyone remaining from the house of Ahab in Jezreel, all his leading men, relatives, and priests, leaving him no survivors.
12:10:12/Then he set out and went to Samaria. On the way, at the shearing house,
12:10:13/Jehu met the relatives of Ahaziah, king of Judah, and asked, "Who are you?" They answered, "We are Ahaziah's relatives; we're going to greet the children of the king and the queen."
12:10:14/He said, "Capture them alive." They captured them alive and then killed them at the pit of the shearing house, forty-two men; he didn't spare any of them.
12:10:15/After leaving there, he met Jehonadab son of Rechab coming to meet him. He greeted him and said, "Is your heart as true to mine as mine is to yours?" Jehonadab answered, "It is." "If so, give me your hand." So he gave him his hand, and Jehu pulled him up into the chariot with him.
12:10:16/He said, "Join me and see my zeal for the LORD." So he had him ride in his chariot.
12:10:17/When he arrived in Samaria, he killed all who remained of Ahab's family in Samaria, eradicating them according to the word of the LORD spoken to Elijah.
12:10:18/Then Jehu gathered all the people and said to them, "Ahab served Baal a little; Jehu will serve him much more.
12:10:19/Now, summon all the prophets of Baal, all his worshippers, and all his priests; make sure no one is missing. I have a great sacrifice for Baal. Anyone who doesn't show up will not live." But Jehu was acting with cunning to destroy the worshippers of Baal.
12:10:20/Jehu said, "Declare a solemn assembly for Baal." And they announced it.
12:10:21/Jehu sent a message throughout all Israel, and all the worshippers of Baal came; not a single one stayed behind. They entered the temple of Baal, filling it from one end to the other.
12:10:22/He told the one in charge of the wardrobe, "Bring out robes for all the worshippers of Baal." So he brought out robes for them.
12:10:23/Jehu, along with Jehonadab son of Rechab, went into the temple of Baal and said to the worshippers of Baal, "Make sure there are no servants of the LORD here with you, only worshippers of Baal."
12:10:24/As they were making sacrifices and burnt offerings, Jehu stationed eighty men outside and said, "If any of the men I am entrusting to you escapes, it will be your life for his life."
12:10:25/As soon as he finished making the burnt offering, Jehu said to the guards and the captains, "Go in and kill them; let no one escape." So they struck them down with the sword; the guards and the captains threw the bodies out and then entered the inner temple of Baal.
12:10:26/They brought out the sacred pillars from the temple of Baal and burned them.
12:10:27/They demolished the sacred pillar of Baal, tore down the temple of Baal, and turned it into a latrine, which it remains to this day.
12:10:28/In this way, Jehu eradicated Baal worship from Israel.
12:10:29/However, Jehu did not turn away from the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat, which led Israel into sin—the golden calves that were in Bethel and Dan.
12:10:30/The LORD said to Jehu, "Because you have done well in carrying out what is right in my eyes, and have done to the house of Ahab all I had in mind, your descendants will sit on the throne of Israel to the fourth generation."
12:10:31/But Jehu was not careful to walk in the law of the LORD, the God of Israel, with all his heart; he did not turn away from the sins of Jeroboam, which led Israel into sin.
12:10:32/In those days, the LORD began to reduce the size of Israel. Hazael defeated them throughout the territory of Israel;
12:10:33/From the Jordan River eastward, all the land of Gilead—the Gadites, the Reubenites, and the Manassites—from Aroer by the Arnon River through Gilead to Bashan.
12:10:34/The rest of the acts of Jehu, all he did, and his achievements, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
12:10:35/Jehu rested with his ancestors and was buried in Samaria. Jehoahaz his son succeeded him as king.
12:10:36/Jehu reigned over Israel in Samaria for twenty-eight years.
12:11:1/When Athaliah, Ahaziah's mother, realized her son was dead, she got up and eliminated all the royal family members.
12:11:2/But Jehosheba, King Joram's daughter and Ahaziah's sister, took Joash, Ahaziah's son, and secretly took him away from the king’s sons who were being killed; she and his nurse hid him in a bedroom, saving him from Athaliah, so he was not killed.
12:11:3/He stayed hidden with her in the LORD's temple for six years while Athaliah ruled over the land.
12:11:4/In the seventh year, Jehoiada sent for the commanders of units of a hundred, the captains, and the guards, bringing them into the LORD's temple. He made a covenant with them, swore them to secrecy in the LORD's temple, and revealed the king's son to them.
12:11:5/He instructed them, saying, "Here's what you need to do: one third of you coming in on the Sabbath will guard the king's palace;
12:11:6/Another third will be at the Sur gate, and the last third at the gate behind the guards. This way, you'll ensure the palace is securely guarded.
12:11:7/Two thirds of you who go out on the Sabbath will guard the LORD's temple to protect the king.
12:11:8/You must surround the king, each of you armed; anyone who approaches must be killed. Stay close to the king, whether he's leaving or returning.
12:11:9/The commanders of units of a hundred did everything Jehoiada the priest ordered. They brought their men, those coming in and those going out on the Sabbath, to Jehoiada the priest.
12:11:10/Jehoiada gave the commanders King David's spears and shields that were stored in the LORD's temple.
12:11:11/The guards stood, each with his weapon, surrounding the king, from the right side to the left side of the temple, near the altar and inside the temple.
12:11:12/They brought out the king's son, crowned him, handed him the royal decree, and proclaimed him king. They anointed him, applauded, and shouted, "Long live the king!"
12:11:13/When Athaliah heard the sound of the guards and the crowd, she approached the crowd at the LORD's temple.
12:11:14/Upon seeing the king standing by a pillar, as was the custom, with princes and trumpeters beside him, and all the people of the land celebrating and blowing trumpets, Athaliah tore her clothes and screamed, "Treason! Treason!"
12:11:15/Jehoiada the priest ordered the commanders of hundreds, the army officers, to bring her out beyond the temple grounds and to kill with the sword anyone who followed her. He had declared, "She must not be killed inside the LORD's temple."
12:11:16/They seized her, and she was taken by the same path the horses used to enter the king's palace, where she was killed.
12:11:17/Jehoiada then established a covenant between the LORD, the king, and the people that they would be the LORD's people, as well as a covenant between the king and the people.
12:11:18/All the people went to the temple of Baal and demolished it. They smashed his altars and images completely and killed Mattan, the priest of Baal, in front of the altars. The priest then appointed officials over the LORD's temple.
12:11:19/He took the commanders of hundreds, the captains, the guards, and all the people of the land, and they escorted the king from the LORD's temple, through the guards' gate to the royal palace, where he took his seat on the throne.
12:11:20/All the people of the land celebrated, and the city was peaceful. Athaliah was executed beside the royal palace.
12:11:21/Jehoash was seven years old when he became king.
12:12:1/In the seventh year of Jehu, Jehoash began to reign; he ruled for forty years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Zibiah from Beersheba.
12:12:2/Jehoash did what was right in the eyes of the LORD throughout his reign, as long as he was guided by Jehoiada the priest.
12:12:3/However, the high places were not removed: people continued to offer sacrifices and burn incense there.
12:12:4/Jehoash told the priests, "All the money from the sacred donations that is brought into the temple of the LORD, including the census money, the personal redemption money, and any voluntary donations,
12:12:5/let the priests take it for themselves, each from his own donors, and use it to repair any damage found in the temple."
12:12:6/Yet, by the twenty-third year of King Jehoash's reign, the priests had not repaired the temple.
12:12:7/So King Jehoash summoned Jehoiada the priest and the other priests, and asked them, "Why haven't you repaired the temple? Stop taking money from your donors and hand it over for the temple repairs."
12:12:8/The priests agreed to no longer take money from the people and not to be responsible for the temple repairs.
12:12:9/But Jehoiada the priest took a chest, drilled a hole in its lid, and placed it beside the altar, on the right side as one enters the temple of the LORD. The doorkeepers put all the money brought into the temple of the LORD into it.
12:12:10/Whenever they noticed a large amount of money in the chest, the king's secretary and the high priest would come, bag the money, and count it.
12:12:11/Then they handed over the counted money to those in charge of the temple work, who paid the carpenters and builders working on the temple of the LORD,
12:12:12/as well as to the masons and stonecutters, and to purchase timber and cut stone to repair the temple of the LORD, and for any other expenses related to the repairs.
12:12:13/However, they did not make silver bowls, wick trimmers, sprinkling bowls, trumpets, or any gold or silver vessels with the money brought into the temple of the LORD;
12:12:14/instead, they used it to pay the workers and repair the temple of the LORD.
12:12:15/They did not require an accounting from the men to whom they gave the money to pay the workers, because they acted with integrity.
12:12:16/The money for guilt offerings and sin offerings was not brought into the temple of the LORD; it belonged to the priests.
12:12:17/Then Hazael, king of Syria, attacked and captured Gath, and then turned to attack Jerusalem.
12:12:18/Jehoash, king of Judah, took all the sacred objects dedicated by his ancestors—Jehoshaphat, Jehoram, and Ahaziah, kings of Judah—and his own sacred objects, along with all the gold found in the treasuries of the temple of the LORD and the royal palace, and sent them to Hazael, king of Syria, who then withdrew from Jerusalem.
12:12:19/The rest of the events of Joash's reign, including all he did, are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah.
12:12:20/Some of his officials conspired against him and assassinated him at the House of Millo, on the road to Silla.
12:12:21/Jozachar, son of Shimeath, and Jehozabad, son of Shomer, his officials, struck him down, and he died. He was buried with his ancestors in the City of David, and Amaziah, his son, succeeded him as king.
12:13:1/In the twenty-third year of Joash the son of Ahaziah king of Judah, Jehoahaz the son of Jehu began to rule over Israel in Samaria, and he ruled for seventeen years.
12:13:2/He did what was wrong in the eyes of the LORD, following the sins of Jeroboam the son of Nebat, which led Israel into sin; he did not turn away from them.
12:13:3/The LORD became angry with Israel and handed them over to Hazael king of Syria, and to Benhadad the son of Hazael, throughout their reign.
12:13:4/Jehoahaz pleaded with the LORD, and the LORD listened to him because he saw how severely Israel was oppressed by the king of Syria.
12:13:5/The LORD provided a deliverer for Israel, so they escaped from the Syrians' control, and the people of Israel lived in their homes as they had before.
12:13:6/However, they did not turn away from the sins of Jeroboam's family, which led Israel into sin; they continued in those sins, and the Asherah pole remained standing in Samaria.
12:13:7/The king of Syria left Jehoahaz with only fifty horsemen, ten chariots, and ten thousand foot soldiers because he had decimated them, making them like dust at threshing.
12:13:8/The rest of the events of Jehoahaz's reign, all he did, and his displays of power are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel.
12:13:9/Jehoahaz passed away and was buried in Samaria; and Joash his son succeeded him as king.
12:13:10/In the thirty-seventh year of Joash king of Judah, Jehoash the son of Jehoahaz began to rule over Israel in Samaria, and he ruled for sixteen years.
12:13:11/He did what was wrong in the eyes of the LORD; he did not turn away from any of the sins of Jeroboam the son of Nebat, which led Israel into sin; he continued in those sins.
12:13:12/The rest of the events of Joash's reign, all he did, and his displays of power, especially his battles against Amaziah king of Judah, are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel.
12:13:13/Joash passed away and was buried in Samaria with the kings of Israel; and Jeroboam took his place on the throne.
12:13:14/Now Elisha had become ill with the illness that would lead to his death. King Joash of Israel visited him, wept over him, and said, "My father, my father, the chariots and horsemen of Israel!"
12:13:15/Elisha told him, "Grab a bow and some arrows." And he grabbed a bow and arrows.
12:13:16/He instructed the king of Israel, "Place your hand on the bow." He did so, and Elisha placed his hands on the king's hands.
12:13:17/Then he said, "Open the east window." He opened it. Elisha said, "Shoot," and he shot. Elisha declared, "This is the LORD's arrow of victory, the arrow of victory over Syria. You will defeat the Syrians at Aphek until you have destroyed them."
12:13:18/He then said, "Take the arrows," and he took them. Elisha told the king of Israel, "Strike the ground." He struck the ground three times and stopped.
12:13:19/The man of God became angry with him and said, "You should have struck the ground five or six times; then you would have defeated Syria completely. Now, you will defeat Syria only three times."
12:13:20/Elisha died and was buried. Moabite raiders invaded the land at the start of the year.
12:13:21/As some people were burying a man, they saw a band of raiders and threw the man's body into Elisha's tomb. When the body touched Elisha's bones, the man came back to life and stood up on his feet.
12:13:22/But Hazael king of Syria oppressed Israel throughout the reign of Jehoahaz.
12:13:23/Yet the LORD was gracious to them, had compassion on them, and showed them favor because of his covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. He did not want to destroy them or cast them from his presence just yet.
12:13:24/So Hazael king of Syria died, and Benhadad his son succeeded him as king.
12:13:25/Jehoash the son of Jehoahaz recaptured from Benhadad the son of Hazael the cities that had been taken from his father Jehoahaz through war. Three times Joash defeated him and recovered the cities of Israel.
12:14:1/In the second year of Joash son of Jehoahaz king of Israel, Amaziah the son of Joash king of Judah began his reign.
12:14:2/He was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he ruled for twenty-nine years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Jehoaddan of Jerusalem.
12:14:3/He did what was right in the eyes of the LORD, but not as his ancestor David had done: he followed all the practices of his father Joash.
12:14:4/However, the high places were not removed: the people still offered sacrifices and burned incense there.
12:14:5/As soon as he felt secure in his reign, he executed the officials who had assassinated his father the king.
12:14:6/But he did not put to death the children of the assassins, in accordance with what is written in the Book of the Law of Moses, where the LORD commanded, "Parents are not to be put to death for their children, nor children for their parents; each will die for their own sin."
12:14:7/He killed 10,000 Edomites in the Valley of Salt and captured Selah by war, renaming it Joktheel, a name it has held to this day.
12:14:8/Then Amaziah sent messengers to Jehoash, son of Jehoahaz son of Jehu, king of Israel, with a challenge: "Come, let's face each other in battle."
12:14:9/But Jehoash king of Israel replied to Amaziah king of Judah with a parable: "A thistle in Lebanon sent a message to a cedar in Lebanon, 'Give your daughter to my son in marriage.' Then a wild animal in Lebanon came along and trampled the thistle underfoot.
12:14:10/You have indeed defeated Edom, and now you are arrogant. Glory in your victory, but stay at home. Why ask for trouble and provoke your own downfall and that of Judah as well?"
12:14:11/But Amaziah refused to listen. So Jehoash king of Israel advanced, and he and Amaziah king of Judah faced each other at Beth Shemesh, which belongs to Judah.
12:14:12/And Judah was defeated by Israel; every man fled to his tent.
12:14:13/Jehoash king of Israel captured Amaziah king of Judah, the son of Joash the son of Ahaziah, at Beth Shemesh. He then advanced to Jerusalem and broke down its wall from the Ephraim Gate to the Corner Gate—a distance of 400 cubits.
12:14:14/He took all the gold and silver, all the articles found in the temple of the LORD and in the treasuries of the royal palace, along with hostages, and returned to Samaria.
12:14:15/The rest of the events of Jehoash's reign, his achievements, and his battles with Amaziah king of Judah, are they not recorded in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel?
12:14:16/Jehoash rested with his ancestors and was buried in Samaria with the kings of Israel. His son Jeroboam succeeded him as king.
12:14:17/Amaziah son of Joash king of Judah lived for fifteen years after the death of Jehoash son of Jehoahaz king of Israel.
12:14:18/The rest of the events of Amaziah's reign, are they not recorded in the book of the annals of the kings of Judah?
12:14:19/They conspired against him in Jerusalem, and he fled to Lachish, but they sent men after him to Lachish and killed him there.
12:14:20/They brought him back on horses, and he was buried in Jerusalem with his ancestors in the City of David.
12:14:21/All the people of Judah then took Azariah, who was sixteen years old, and made him king in place of his father Amaziah.
12:14:22/He rebuilt Elath and restored it to Judah after the king rested with his ancestors.
12:14:23/In the fifteenth year of Amaziah son of Joash king of Judah, Jeroboam son of Joash king of Israel began to reign in Samaria, and he ruled for forty-one years.
12:14:24/He did evil in the eyes of the LORD and did not turn away from any of the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat, who had caused Israel to sin.
12:14:25/He restored the boundaries of Israel from the entrance of Hamath to the Sea of the Arabah, in accordance with the word of the LORD, the God of Israel, spoken through his servant Jonah son of Amittai, the prophet from Gath Hepher.
12:14:26/For the LORD saw how bitterly everyone in Israel, whether slave or free, was suffering; there was no one to help them.
12:14:27/And the LORD did not say he would blot out the name of Israel from under heaven, but he saved them through Jeroboam son of Joash.
12:14:28/The rest of the events of Jeroboam's reign, all he did, his power, how he waged war, and how he recovered Damascus and Hamath for Israel, which had belonged to Judah, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Israel?
12:14:29/Jeroboam rested with his ancestors, the kings of Israel. His son Zechariah succeeded him as king.
12:15:1/In the twenty and seventh year of Jeroboam king of Israel began Azariah son of Amaziah king of Judah to reign.
12:15:2/He was sixteen years old when he started his reign, and he ruled for fifty-two years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Jecholiah of Jerusalem.
12:15:3/He did what was right in the eyes of the LORD, following everything his father Amaziah had done;
12:15:4/However, the high places were not taken down: the people continued to offer sacrifices and burn incense on the high places.
12:15:5/The LORD struck the king with leprosy until the day he died, and he lived in a separate house. Jotham, the king's son, took charge of the palace and governed the people of the land.
12:15:6/The rest of the events of Azariah's reign, and everything he did, are they not recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah?
12:15:7/So Azariah rested with his ancestors; they buried him with his ancestors in the city of David, and Jotham his son succeeded him as king.
12:15:8/In the thirty-eighth year of Azariah king of Judah, Zachariah the son of Jeroboam became king over Israel in Samaria for six months.
12:15:9/He did what was evil in the eyes of the LORD, just as his ancestors had done. He did not turn away from the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat, who led Israel into sin.
12:15:10/Shallum son of Jabesh conspired against him, assassinated him in public, killed him, and took his place as king.
12:15:11/The rest of the events of Zachariah's reign are recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel.
12:15:12/This fulfilled the word of the LORD spoken to Jehu, saying, "Your descendants will sit on the throne of Israel to the fourth generation." And so it happened.
12:15:13/Shallum son of Jabesh became king in the thirty-ninth year of Uzziah king of Judah, and he reigned for one month in Samaria.
12:15:14/Menahem son of Gadi came from Tirzah to Samaria, attacked Shallum son of Jabesh in Samaria, killed him, and succeeded him as king.
12:15:15/The rest of the events of Shallum's reign, including his conspiracy, are recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel.
12:15:16/Then Menahem attacked Tiphsah and everyone in it, as well as its surrounding territories from Tirzah because they did not open their gates to him. He attacked it and ripped open all the pregnant women.
12:15:17/In the thirty-ninth year of Azariah king of Judah, Menahem son of Gadi began to reign over Israel, and he reigned for ten years in Samaria.
12:15:18/He did what was evil in the eyes of the LORD. Throughout his life, he never turned away from the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat, who led Israel into sin.
12:15:19/Pul king of Assyria invaded the land, and Menahem gave Pul a thousand talents of silver to gain his support and strengthen his own hold on the kingdom.
12:15:20/Menahem imposed a tax on Israel, extracting fifty shekels of silver from each wealthy man to pay the king of Assyria. So the king of Assyria withdrew and did not stay in the land.
12:15:21/The rest of the events of Menahem's reign, and everything he did, are they not recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
12:15:22/And Menahem rested with his ancestors, and Pekahiah his son succeeded him as king.
12:15:23/In the fiftieth year of Azariah king of Judah, Pekahiah son of Menahem began to reign over Israel in Samaria, and he reigned for two years.
12:15:24/He did what was evil in the eyes of the LORD, not turning away from the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat, who led Israel into sin.
12:15:25/But Pekah son of Remaliah, one of his officers, conspired against him. He struck him down in Samaria, in the royal palace, along with Argob and Arieh and fifty men of the Gileadites. He killed him and took his place as king.
12:15:26/The rest of the events of Pekahiah's reign, and everything he did, are recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel.
12:15:27/In the fifty-second year of Azariah king of Judah, Pekah son of Remaliah became king over Israel in Samaria, and he reigned for twenty years.
12:15:28/He did what was evil in the eyes of the LORD, not turning away from the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat, who led Israel into sin.
12:15:29/During the reign of Pekah king of Israel, Tiglathpileser king of Assyria came and captured Ijon, Abelbethmaachah, Janoah, Kedesh, Hazor, Gilead, Galilee, and all the land of Naphtali, and deported the people to Assyria.
12:15:30/Hoshea son of Elah conspired against Pekah son of Remaliah, assassinated him, and succeeded him as king in the twentieth year of Jotham son of Uzziah.
12:15:31/The rest of the events of Pekah's reign, and everything he did, are recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel.
12:15:32/In the second year of Pekah son of Remaliah king of Israel, Jotham son of Uzziah king of Judah began to reign.
12:15:33/He was twenty-five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for sixteen years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Jerusha, daughter of Zadok.
12:15:34/He did what was right in the eyes of the LORD, following everything his father Uzziah had done.
12:15:35/However, the high places were not removed: the people continued to offer sacrifices and burn incense on the high places. He built the upper gate of the house of the LORD.
12:15:36/The rest of the events of Jotham's reign, and everything he did, are they not recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah?
12:15:37/During those days, the LORD began to send Rezin king of Syria and Pekah son of Remaliah against Judah.
12:15:38/And Jotham rested with his ancestors and was buried with them in the city of David his father. Ahaz his son succeeded him as king.
12:16:1/In the seventeenth year of Pekah the son of Remaliah Ahaz the son of Jotham king of Judah began to reign.
12:16:2/Ahaz was twenty years old when he became king, and he ruled for sixteen years in Jerusalem. Unlike his ancestor David, he did not do what was right in the eyes of the LORD his God.
12:16:3/Instead, he followed the practices of the kings of Israel, even sacrificing his son in the fire, imitating the detestable practices of the nations the LORD had driven out before the Israelites.
12:16:4/He also offered sacrifices and burned incense at the high places, on the hills, and under every green tree.
12:16:5/Then Rezin king of Syria and Pekah son of Remaliah king of Israel advanced to Jerusalem to wage war. They besieged Ahaz but were unable to conquer him.
12:16:6/At that time, Rezin king of Syria regained Elath for Syria, expelling the Jews from Elath. The Syrians then moved into Elath and have lived there ever since.
12:16:7/So Ahaz sent messengers to Tiglathpileser king of Assyria, saying, "I am your servant and your son. Come up and save me from the king of Syria and the king of Israel who are attacking me."
12:16:8/Ahaz took the silver and gold found in the temple of the LORD and in the royal treasury and sent it as a gift to the king of Assyria.
12:16:9/The king of Assyria responded to his request. He attacked Damascus, captured it, deported its inhabitants to Kir, and killed Rezin.
12:16:10/When King Ahaz went to Damascus to meet Tiglathpileser king of Assyria, he saw an altar in Damascus. King Ahaz sent to Urijah the priest a model of the altar and detailed plans for its construction.
12:16:11/Urijah the priest built an altar according to all the specifications King Ahaz had sent from Damascus. Urijah finished it before King Ahaz returned from Damascus.
12:16:12/When the king came back from Damascus and saw the altar, he approached it and presented offerings on it.
12:16:13/He offered his burnt offering and his grain offering, poured his drink offering, and sprinkled the blood of his fellowship offerings on the altar.
12:16:14/He also relocated the bronze altar that was before the LORD from the front of the temple, from between the new altar and the temple of the LORD, and placed it on the north side of the new altar.
12:16:15/King Ahaz instructed Urijah the priest, "On the large altar, offer the morning burnt offering, the evening grain offering, the king's burnt sacrifice and his grain offering, along with the burnt offering of all the people of the land, their grain offering, and their drink offerings. Sprinkle on it all the blood of the burnt offering and all the blood of the sacrifices. The bronze altar will be for my personal use."
12:16:16/Urijah the priest did everything King Ahaz commanded.
12:16:17/King Ahaz removed the panels from the bases and removed the basin from them. He took down the Sea from the bronze bulls that supported it and placed it on a stone pavement.
12:16:18/He also removed the Sabbath canopy that had been built at the temple and the royal entrance outside the temple of the LORD, in deference to the king of Assyria.
12:16:19/Now the rest of the acts of Ahaz which he did, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah?
12:16:20/And Ahaz slept with his fathers, and was buried with his fathers in the city of David: and Hezekiah his son reigned in his stead.
12:17:1/In the twelfth year of Ahaz king of Judah, Hoshea son of Elah began his reign in Samaria over Israel, lasting nine years.
12:17:2/He did evil in the eyes of the LORD, but not to the extent of the previous kings of Israel.
12:17:3/Shalmaneser, the king of Assyria, attacked him; Hoshea became his vassal and paid him tribute.
12:17:4/The king of Assyria discovered Hoshea's betrayal because he had sent messengers to So, king of Egypt, and hadn't brought the annual tribute to the king of Assyria. As a result, the king of Assyria imprisoned him.
12:17:5/Then the king of Assyria invaded the entire land, approached Samaria, and laid siege to it for three years.
12:17:6/In the ninth year of Hoshea's reign, the king of Assyria captured Samaria and deported the Israelites to Assyria, settling them in Halah, in Habor by the river of Gozan, and in the cities of the Medes.
12:17:7/This happened because the Israelites sinned against the LORD their God, who had freed them from Egypt, from under the control of Pharaoh king of Egypt, and they worshiped other gods.
12:17:8/They followed the practices of the nations the LORD had driven out before them, as well as the customs the kings of Israel had introduced.
12:17:9/The Israelites secretly did things against the LORD their God that were not right. They built high places in all their towns, from watchtowers to fortified cities.
12:17:10/They set up sacred stones and Asherah poles on every high hill and under every spreading tree.
12:17:11/There they burned incense on all the high places, like the nations the LORD had driven out before them. They did wicked things that provoked the LORD to anger.
12:17:12/They worshiped idols, despite the LORD having told them, "You must not do this."
12:17:13/Yet the LORD warned Israel and Judah through all his prophets and seers: "Turn from your evil ways. Observe my commands and decrees, in accordance with the entire Law that I commanded your ancestors to obey and that I delivered to you through my servants the prophets."
12:17:14/But they would not listen and were as stiff-necked as their ancestors, who did not trust in the LORD their God.
12:17:15/They rejected his decrees and the covenant he had made with their ancestors and the warnings he had given them. They followed worthless idols and themselves became worthless, imitating the nations around them, despite the LORD's command not to do so.
12:17:16/They forsook all the commands of the LORD their God and made for themselves two idols cast in the shape of calves, and an Asherah pole. They bowed down to all the starry hosts, and they worshiped Baal.
12:17:17/They sacrificed their sons and daughters in the fire. They practiced divination and sought omens and sold themselves to do evil in the eyes of the LORD, arousing his anger.
12:17:18/So the LORD was very angry with Israel and removed them from his presence. Only the tribe of Judah was left.
12:17:19/But even Judah did not keep the commands of the LORD their God. They followed the practices Israel had introduced.
12:17:20/Therefore the LORD rejected all the descendants of Israel. He afflicted them and gave them into the hands of plunderers, until he thrust them from his presence.
12:17:21/When he tore Israel away from the house of David, they made Jeroboam son of Nebat their king. Jeroboam enticed Israel away from following the LORD and caused them to commit a great sin.
12:17:22/The Israelites persisted in all the sins of Jeroboam and did not turn away from them
12:17:23/until the LORD removed Israel from his presence, as he had warned through all his servants the prophets. So the people of Israel were taken from their homeland into exile in Assyria, where they are to this day.
12:17:24/The king of Assyria brought people from Babylon, Cuthah, Avva, Hamath, and Sepharvaim and settled them in the towns of Samaria to replace the Israelites. They took over Samaria and lived in its towns.
12:17:25/When they first lived there, they did not worship the LORD; so he sent lions among them and they killed some of the people.
12:17:26/It was reported to the king of Assyria: "The nations you have deported and settled in the towns of Samaria do not know what the god of the country requires. He has sent lions among them, which are killing them off, because the people do not know what he requires."
12:17:27/Then the king of Assyria gave this order: "Have one of the priests you took captive from Samaria go back to live there and teach the people what the god of the land requires."
12:17:28/So one of the priests who had been exiled from Samaria came to live in Bethel and taught them how to worship the LORD.
12:17:29/Nevertheless, each national group made its own gods in the several towns where they settled, and set them up in the shrines the people of Samaria had made at the high places.
12:17:30/The Babylonians made Sukkoth Benoth, the people of Cuth made Nergal, and the people of Hamath made Ashima.
12:17:31/The Avvites made Nibhaz and Tartak, and the Sepharvites burned their children in the fire as sacrifices to Adrammelech and Anammelech, the gods of Sepharvaim.
12:17:32/Even while these people were worshiping the LORD, they appointed all sorts of people to officiate for them as priests at the high places.
12:17:33/They worshiped the LORD, but they also served their own gods in accordance with the customs of the nations from which they had been brought.
12:17:34/To this day they persist in their former practices. They neither worship the LORD nor adhere to the decrees and regulations, the laws and commands that the LORD gave the descendants of Jacob, whom he named Israel.
12:17:35/With whom the LORD had made a covenant and commanded them: "Do not worship any other gods or bow down to them, serve them or sacrifice to them.
12:17:36/But the LORD, who brought you up out of Egypt with mighty power and an outstretched arm, is the one you must worship. To him you shall bow down and to him offer sacrifices.
12:17:37/You must always be careful to keep the decrees and regulations, the laws and commands he wrote for you. Do not worship other gods.
12:17:38/Do not forget the covenant I have made with you, and do not worship other gods.
12:17:39/Rather, worship the LORD your God; it is he who will deliver you from the hand of all your enemies."
12:17:40/However, they would not listen, instead they practiced their former customs.
12:17:41/So these nations feared the LORD and also served their carved images; their children likewise, and their children's children—as their ancestors did, so they do to this day.
12:18:1/In the third year of Hoshea son of Elah, king of Israel, Hezekiah, the son of Ahaz king of Judah, began his reign.
12:18:2/He was twenty-five years old when he started his reign and ruled for twenty-nine years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Abi, the daughter of Zachariah.
12:18:3/He did what was right in the eyes of the LORD, following everything David his ancestor had done.
12:18:4/He got rid of the high places, smashed the idols, cut down the sacred poles, and destroyed the bronze serpent Moses had made, because up until then, the Israelites had been burning incense to it. He called it Nehushtan.
12:18:5/He put his trust in the LORD, the God of Israel. There was no one like him among all the kings of Judah, either before or after him.
12:18:6/He remained loyal to the LORD and did not stop following him; he kept the commands the LORD had given Moses.
12:18:7/The LORD was with him; he was successful in whatever he undertook. He rebelled against the king of Assyria and did not serve him.
12:18:8/He defeated the Philistines as far as Gaza and its territory, from watchtower to fortified city.
12:18:9/In the fourth year of King Hezekiah, which was the seventh year of Hoshea son of Elah king of Israel, Shalmaneser king of Assyria came up against Samaria and besieged it.
12:18:10/After three years, they captured it. In the sixth year of Hezekiah, which was the ninth year of Hoshea king of Israel, Samaria was captured.
12:18:11/The king of Assyria deported the Israelites to Assyria and settled them in Halah, in Habor by the river of Gozan, and in the cities of the Medes:
12:18:12/Because they did not listen to the voice of the LORD their God but violated his covenant—all that Moses the servant of the LORD had commanded—they neither listened nor obeyed.
12:18:13/In the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah, Sennacherib king of Assyria attacked all the fortified cities of Judah and captured them.
12:18:14/Then Hezekiah king of Judah sent a message to the king of Assyria at Lachish, saying, "I have done wrong. Withdraw from me, and I will pay whatever you demand." The king of Assyria demanded from Hezekiah king of Judah three hundred talents of silver and thirty talents of gold.
12:18:15/So Hezekiah gave him all the silver found in the temple of the LORD and in the treasuries of the royal palace.
12:18:16/At that time, Hezekiah stripped the gold from the doors of the temple of the LORD and from the pillars he had overlaid and gave it to the king of Assyria.
12:18:17/The king of Assyria sent Tartan, Rabsaris, and Rabshakeh from Lachish with a large army to King Hezekiah at Jerusalem. They came up to Jerusalem and stopped at the aqueduct of the upper pool, on the road to the launderer's field.
12:18:18/When they called for the king, Eliakim son of Hilkiah, who was in charge of the palace, Shebna the secretary, and Joah son of Asaph the recorder came out to them.
12:18:19/Rabshakeh said to them, "Tell Hezekiah, 'This is what the great king, the king of Assyria, says: On what basis are you placing your confidence?
12:18:20/You claim to have strategy and military strength, but these are mere words. On whom are you depending, that you have rebelled against me?
12:18:21/Look, you are relying on Egypt, that splintered reed of a staff, which pierces the hand of anyone who leans on it! Such is Pharaoh king of Egypt to all who depend on him.
12:18:22/But if you say to me, 'We are depending on the LORD our God,' isn't he the one whose high places and altars Hezekiah removed, saying to Judah and Jerusalem, 'You must worship before this altar in Jerusalem'?
12:18:23/Now then, I urge you to pledge allegiance to my lord the king of Assyria, and I will give you two thousand horses—if you can put riders on them!
12:18:24/How can you repel one of the least of my master's officials, even relying on Egypt for chariots and horsemen?
12:18:25/Have I come to attack and destroy this place without the LORD's direction? The LORD himself told me to march against this country and destroy it."
12:18:26/Then Eliakim son of Hilkiah, Shebna, and Joah said to Rabshakeh, "Please speak to your servants in Aramaic, since we understand it. Don't speak to us in Hebrew in the hearing of the people on the wall."
12:18:27/But Rabshakeh replied, "Has my master sent me to speak these words only to your master and to you, and not to the men sitting on the wall—who, like you, will have to eat their own excrement and drink their own urine?"
12:18:28/Then Rabshakeh stood and called out in Hebrew, "Listen to the words of the great king, the king of Assyria:
12:18:29/This is what the king says: Do not let Hezekiah deceive you. He cannot deliver you from my hand.
12:18:30/Do not let Hezekiah persuade you to trust in the LORD by saying, 'The LORD will surely deliver us; this city will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.'
12:18:31/Do not listen to Hezekiah. This is what the king of Assyria says: Make peace with me and come out to me. Then each of you will eat from your own vine and fig tree and drink water from your own cistern,
12:18:32/until I come and take you to a land like your own—a land of grain and new wine, a land of bread and vineyards, a land of olive oil and honey. Choose life and not death! Do not listen to Hezekiah, for he is misleading you by saying, 'The LORD will deliver us.'
12:18:33/Has any of the gods of the nations ever delivered his land from the hand of the king of Assyria?
12:18:34/Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim, Hena, and Ivvah? Have they rescued Samaria from my hand?
12:18:35/Who among all the gods of these countries has been able to save his land from me? How then can the LORD deliver Jerusalem from my hand?"
12:18:36/But the people remained silent and did not answer him a word, for the king's command was, "Do not answer him."
12:18:37/Then Eliakim son of Hilkiah, who was in charge of the palace, Shebna the secretary, and Joah son of Asaph the recorder came to Hezekiah with their clothes torn and reported to him the words of Rabshakeh.
12:19:1/When King Hezekiah heard this, he tore his clothes, put on sackcloth, and went into the temple of the LORD.
12:19:2/He sent Eliakim, who was in charge of the palace, Shebna the secretary, and the senior priests, all wearing sackcloth, to the prophet Isaiah son of Amoz.
12:19:3/They told him, "This is what Hezekiah says: Today is a day of distress, rebuke, and disgrace; it's like when children are about to be born, but there's no strength to deliver them.
12:19:4/Perhaps the LORD your God will hear all the words of the field commander, whom his master, the king of Assyria, has sent to insult the living God, and will rebuke him for the words the LORD your God has heard. Therefore, pray for the surviving remnant."
12:19:5/So King Hezekiah's officials came to Isaiah.
12:19:6/Isaiah said to them, "Tell your master, 'This is what the LORD says: Do not be afraid of the words you have heard, with which the underlings of the king of Assyria have blasphemed me.
12:19:7/Look, I will send a spirit upon him, and he will hear a rumor and return to his own land; and I will make him fall by the sword in his own land.'"
12:19:8/So the field commander returned and found the king of Assyria fighting against Libnah, because he had heard that the king had left Lachish.
12:19:9/When he heard reports about Tirhakah king of Cush saying, "He has come out to fight against you," he sent messengers again to Hezekiah with this message:
12:19:10/"Tell Hezekiah king of Judah: Do not let your God, in whom you trust, deceive you by saying, 'Jerusalem will not be handed over to the king of Assyria.'
12:19:11/You have heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all countries, destroying them completely. And will you be delivered?
12:19:12/Did the gods of the nations that were destroyed by my predecessors deliver them—the nations such as Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, and the people of Eden who were in Telassar?
12:19:13/Where is the king of Hamath, the king of Arpad, the king of the city of Sepharvaim, or of Hena or Ivvah?"
12:19:14/Hezekiah received the letter from the messengers and read it. Then he went up to the temple of the LORD and spread it out before the LORD.
12:19:15/And Hezekiah prayed to the LORD: "LORD, God of Israel, enthroned between the cherubim, you alone are God over all the kingdoms of the earth. You have made heaven and earth.
12:19:16/LORD, bend down your ear and hear; open, LORD, your eyes and see; listen to the words Sennacherib has sent to insult the living God.
12:19:17/It is true, LORD, that the Assyrian kings have laid waste the nations and their lands
12:19:18/And have thrown their gods into the fire, for they were not gods but only wood and stone, fashioned by human hands. So they destroyed them.
12:19:19/Now, LORD our God, deliver us from his hand, so that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that you alone, LORD, are God."
12:19:20/Then Isaiah son of Amoz sent a message to Hezekiah: "This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: I have heard your prayer concerning Sennacherib king of Assyria.
12:19:21/This is the word the LORD has spoken against him: 'The Virgin Daughter Zion despises you and mocks you. The Daughter Jerusalem tosses her head as you flee.
12:19:22/Whom have you insulted and blasphemed? Against whom have you raised your voice and lifted your eyes in pride? Against the Holy One of Israel!
12:19:23/Through your messengers you have insulted the LORD, and you have said, "With my many chariots I have ascended the heights of the mountains, the utmost heights of Lebanon. I will cut down its tallest cedars, the choicest of its pines. I will reach its remotest parts, the finest of its forests.
12:19:24/I have dug wells in foreign lands and drunk the water there. With the soles of my feet, I have dried up all the rivers of Egypt."
12:19:25/Have you not heard? Long ago I ordained it. In days of old I planned it; now I have brought it to pass, that you have turned fortified cities into piles of stone.
12:19:26/Their inhabitants, powerless, are dismayed and put to shame. They are like plants in the field, like tender green shoots, like grass sprouting on the roof, scorched before it grows up.
12:19:27/But I know your sitting down, your going out and coming in, and your raging against me.
12:19:28/Because of your rage against me and your arrogance, which I have heard, I will put my hook in your nose and my bit in your mouth, and I will make you return by the way you came.'
12:19:29/This will be the sign for you: This year you will eat what grows by itself, and in the second year what springs from that. But in the third year, sow and reap, plant vineyards and eat their fruit.
12:19:30/The surviving remnant of the house of Judah will again take root downward and bear fruit upward.
12:19:31/For out of Jerusalem will come a remnant, and out of Mount Zion a band of survivors. The zeal of the LORD Almighty will accomplish this.
12:19:32/Therefore this is what the LORD says concerning the king of Assyria: He will not enter this city or shoot an arrow here. He will not come before it with shield or build a siege ramp against it.
12:19:33/By the way he came, by the same he will return; he will not enter this city, declares the LORD.
12:19:34/I will defend this city and save it, for my sake and for the sake of David my servant."
12:19:35/That night, the angel of the LORD went out and struck down 185,000 in the Assyrian camp. When people got up the next morning—there were all the dead bodies!
12:19:36/So Sennacherib king of Assyria broke camp and withdrew. He returned to Nineveh and stayed there.
12:19:37/One day, as he was worshiping in the temple of his god Nisroch, his sons Adrammelech and Sharezer killed him with the sword, and they escaped to the land of Ararat. And Esarhaddon his son succeeded him as king.
12:20:1/In those days, Hezekiah was seriously ill and near death. The prophet Isaiah, son of Amoz, visited him and said, "This is what the LORD says: Get your affairs in order, because you are going to die; you will not recover."
12:20:2/Then he turned his face to the wall and prayed to the LORD, saying,
12:20:3/"Please, LORD, remember how I have lived faithfully and wholeheartedly before you, and have done what is right in your eyes." And Hezekiah cried bitterly.
12:20:4/Before Isaiah had left the middle court, the word of the LORD came to him, saying,
12:20:5/"Go back and tell Hezekiah, the leader of my people, 'This is what the LORD, the God of your ancestor David, says: I have heard your prayer and seen your tears. Look, I will heal you. On the third day from now, you will go up to the temple of the LORD.
12:20:6/I will add fifteen years to your life. I will save you and this city from the king of Assyria's hand. I will protect this city for my sake and for the sake of my servant David.'"
12:20:7/Then Isaiah said, "Prepare a poultice of figs." They did so and applied it to the boil, and he recovered.
12:20:8/Hezekiah asked Isaiah, "What will be the sign that the LORD will heal me and that I will go up to the temple of the LORD on the third day?"
12:20:9/Isaiah replied, "This will be the sign to you from the LORD that the LORD will do what he has promised: Will the shadow go forward ten steps, or shall it go back ten steps?"
12:20:10/Hezekiah answered, "It's easy for the shadow to lengthen ten steps. Rather, let it go back ten steps."
12:20:11/Then Isaiah the prophet called out to the LORD, and the LORD made the shadow go back ten steps it had gone down on the stairway of Ahaz.
12:20:12/At that time, Berodach-Baladan, son of Baladan, king of Babylon, sent letters and a gift to Hezekiah, for he had heard about Hezekiah's illness.
12:20:13/Hezekiah listened to them and showed them all his treasure house—the silver, the gold, the spices, and the fine oil—his armory, and everything found among his treasures. There was nothing in his palace or in all his realm that Hezekiah did not show them.
12:20:14/Then Isaiah the prophet came to King Hezekiah and asked, "What did these men say, and where did they come from?" Hezekiah replied, "They came from a distant country, from Babylon."
12:20:15/Isaiah asked, "What have they seen in your palace?" Hezekiah answered, "They have seen everything in my palace. There is nothing among my treasures that I did not show them."
12:20:16/Then Isaiah said to Hezekiah, "Listen to the word of the LORD.
12:20:17/The time will come when everything in your palace, and all that your ancestors have stored up until this day, will be carried off to Babylon. Nothing will be left, says the LORD.
12:20:18/Some of your own descendants, your offspring, will be taken away and will become eunuchs in the palace of the king of Babylon."
12:20:19/Then Hezekiah said to Isaiah, "The word of the LORD you have spoken is good." He thought, "Isn't it good if there will be peace and security in my lifetime?"
12:20:20/The rest of the events of Hezekiah's reign, his power, and how he made the pool and the canal to bring water into the city, are recorded in the book of the annals of the kings of Judah.
12:20:21/Hezekiah rested with his ancestors, and Manasseh his son succeeded him as king.
12:21:1/Manasseh was twelve years old when he began to reign, and reigned fifty-five years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Hephzibah.
12:21:2/He did what was evil in the LORD's eyes, following the detestable practices of the nations the LORD had driven out before the Israelites.
12:21:3/He rebuilt the high places his father Hezekiah had destroyed; he also erected altars for Baal, made a sacred pole as Ahab king of Israel had done, worshipped all the celestial bodies, and served them.
12:21:4/He built altars in the temple of the LORD, even though the LORD had said, "In Jerusalem, I will put my name."
12:21:5/He constructed altars for all the celestial bodies in the two courtyards of the LORD's temple.
12:21:6/He made his son pass through fire, practiced divination, sought omens, and consulted mediums and spiritists. He did a great deal of evil in the LORD's sight, provoking him to anger.
12:21:7/He placed a carved idol of the Asherah pole he had made inside the temple, about which the LORD had told David and his son Solomon, "In this temple and in Jerusalem, which I have chosen out of all the tribes of Israel, I will put my name forever."
12:21:8/I will not make Israel's feet wander anymore from the land I gave their ancestors, if only they will be careful to do everything I have commanded them and will follow the whole Law that my servant Moses gave them.
12:21:9/But they did not listen, and Manasseh led them astray to do more evil than the nations the LORD had destroyed before the Israelites.
12:21:10/And the LORD spoke through his servants the prophets, saying,
12:21:11/"Because Manasseh king of Judah has committed these detestable acts, doing more evil than all the Amorites before him and leading Judah into sin with his idols,
12:21:12/Therefore, this is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: I am going to bring such disaster on Jerusalem and Judah that the ears of everyone who hears of it will tingle.
12:21:13/I will stretch over Jerusalem the measuring line used against Samaria and the plumb line used against the house of Ahab. I will wipe Jerusalem as one wipes a dish, wiping it and turning it upside down.
12:21:14/I will abandon the remnant of my inheritance and hand them over to their enemies. They will be looted and plundered by all their foes,
12:21:15/because they have done evil in my eyes and have provoked me to anger from the day their ancestors came out of Egypt until this day."
12:21:16/Moreover, Manasseh shed so much innocent blood that he filled Jerusalem from end to end, in addition to leading Judah to sin by doing evil in the sight of the LORD.
12:21:17/Now the rest of the acts of Manasseh, all he did, and the sin he committed, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah?
12:21:18/And Manasseh rested with his ancestors and was buried in the garden of his own house, in the garden of Uzza. And Amon his son succeeded him as king.
12:21:19/Amon was twenty-two years old when he began to reign, and he reigned two years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Meshullemeth, the daughter of Haruz of Jotbah.
12:21:20/He did what was evil in the LORD's eyes, just as his father Manasseh had done.
12:21:21/He followed all the ways his father had walked in, served the idols his father had served, and worshipped them.
12:21:22/He abandoned the LORD, the God of his ancestors, and did not walk in the way of the LORD.
12:21:23/Amon's servants conspired against him and assassinated the king in his own palace.
12:21:24/But the people of the land executed all those who had conspired against King Amon, and the people of the land made Josiah his son king in his place.
12:21:25/Now the rest of the acts of Amon that he did, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah?
12:21:26/And he was buried in his tomb in the garden of Uzza. And Josiah his son succeeded him as king.
12:22:1/Josiah was eight years old when he began to reign, and he reigned thirty-one years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Jedidah, the daughter of Adaiah from Boscath.
12:22:2/He did what was right in the eyes of the LORD, followed the path of his ancestor David without deviating to the right or the left.
12:22:3/In the eighteenth year of King Josiah's reign, he sent Shaphan, the son of Azaliah and grandson of Meshullam, who was a scribe, to the temple of the LORD with a message,
12:22:4/"Go to Hilkiah the high priest so he can total up the silver that has been brought into the temple of the LORD, which the gatekeepers have collected from the people.
12:22:5/Let them hand it over to the supervisors of the temple work, so they can pay the workers who are repairing the temple,
12:22:6/To the carpenters, builders, and masons, and to purchase timber and cut stone to fix the temple."
12:22:7/However, they did not require an accounting from those who were given the money to pay the workers, because they acted with integrity.
12:22:8/Hilkiah the high priest told Shaphan the scribe, "I have found the Book of the Law in the temple of the LORD." Hilkiah gave the book to Shaphan, who read it.
12:22:9/Shaphan the scribe went to the king, reported back, and said, "Your servants have collected the money found in the temple and have given it to the supervisors of the temple work."
12:22:10/Then Shaphan the scribe showed the king, saying, "Hilkiah the priest has given me a book." And Shaphan read it in front of the king.
12:22:11/When the king heard the words of the Book of the Law, he tore his clothes in distress.
12:22:12/The king ordered Hilkiah the priest, Ahikam son of Shaphan, Achbor son of Michaiah, Shaphan the scribe, and Asahiah, a servant of the king, saying,
12:22:13/"Go and inquire of the LORD for me, for the people, and for all of Judah about the contents of this book that has been found. The LORD's anger must be burning against us because our ancestors did not listen to the words of this book and did not live according to all that is written about us."
12:22:14/So Hilkiah the priest, Ahikam, Achbor, Shaphan, and Asahiah went to Huldah the prophetess, the wife of Shallum son of Tikvah, the son of Harhas, keeper of the wardrobe; she lived in Jerusalem in the Second District, and they spoke with her.
12:22:15/She told them, "This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: Tell the man who sent you to me,
12:22:16/'This is what the LORD says: I am going to bring disaster on this place and its inhabitants—all the curses written in the book that was read before the king of Judah—
12:22:17/Because they have abandoned me and burned incense to other gods, provoking me to anger with all the works of their hands. Therefore, my wrath will be ignited against this place and will not be extinguished.'"
12:22:18/"But to the king of Judah who sent you to inquire of the LORD, tell him, 'This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: Regarding the words you heard,
12:22:19/Because your heart was responsive and you humbled yourself before the LORD when you heard what I have spoken against this place and its inhabitants—that they would become a desolation and a curse—and because you tore your robes and wept in my presence, I have heard you, declares the LORD.
12:22:20/Therefore, I will gather you to your ancestors, and you will be buried in peace. Your eyes will not see all the disaster I am going to bring on this place.'" And they brought the message back to the king.
12:23:1/The king sent out a call, and all the elders of Judah and Jerusalem were gathered to him.
12:23:2/The king, along with all the men of Judah, the inhabitants of Jerusalem, the priests, the prophets, and all the people, both young and old, went up to the temple of the LORD. There, he read aloud all the words of the book of the covenant that had been found in the temple.
12:23:3/The king stood by a pillar and pledged before the LORD to follow the LORD, to keep His commandments, His testimonies, and His statutes with all their heart and soul, and to carry out the words of the covenant written in the book. All the people affirmed the covenant.
12:23:4/The king ordered Hilkiah the high priest, the second-order priests, and the doorkeepers to remove from the temple of the LORD all the items made for Baal, for Asherah, and for all the celestial bodies. He then burned them outside Jerusalem in the Kidron Valley and took their ashes to Bethel.
12:23:5/He removed the pagan priests appointed by the kings of Judah to burn incense on the high places in the cities of Judah and around Jerusalem, as well as those who burned incense to Baal, the sun, the moon, the constellations, and all the heavenly host.
12:23:6/He took the Asherah pole from the temple of the LORD to the Kidron Valley outside Jerusalem, burned it there, crushed it to dust, and scattered the dust over the graves of the common people.
12:23:7/He tore down the quarters of the male shrine prostitutes that were in the temple of the LORD, where women did weaving for Asherah.
12:23:8/He brought all the priests from the towns of Judah and defiled the high places where they had burned incense, from Geba to Beersheba. He destroyed the high places at the gates, including the entrance of the gate of Joshua, the city governor, which was on the left as one enters the city.
12:23:9/However, the priests of the high places did not come up to the altar of the LORD in Jerusalem, but they did eat unleavened bread with their fellow priests.
12:23:10/He desecrated Topheth, which is in the Valley of Ben Hinnom, so no one could use it to make their son or daughter pass through the fire to Molech.
12:23:11/He removed the horses that the kings of Judah had dedicated to the sun at the entrance to the temple of the LORD, near the chamber of Nathan-Melech the official, which was in the precincts. He also burned the chariots of the sun.
12:23:12/He pulled down the altars the kings of Judah had erected on the roof of Ahaz's upper chamber, and the altars Manasseh had built in the two courts of the temple of the LORD. He smashed them to pieces and threw their rubble into the Kidron Valley.
12:23:13/The king defiled the high places east of Jerusalem, south of the Mount of Corruption, which Solomon king of Israel had built for Ashtoreth the vile goddess of the Sidonians, for Chemosh the vile god of Moab, and for Milcom the detestable god of the Ammonites.
12:23:14/He smashed the sacred stones and cut down the Asherah poles, filling their places with human bones.
12:23:15/He also tore down the altar at Bethel, the high place made by Jeroboam son of Nebat, who had caused Israel to sin. He burned the high place, ground it to powder, and burned the Asherah pole.
12:23:16/As Josiah turned, he noticed the tombs on the hillside. He had the bones removed from the tombs and burned on the altar to defile it, in accordance with the word of the LORD proclaimed by the man of God who foretold these events.
12:23:17/Then he asked, "What is that monument I see?" The people of the city told him, "It is the tomb of the man of God who came from Judah and pronounced against the altar of Bethel the very things you have done."
12:23:18/He said, "Leave it alone; do not let anyone disturb his bones." So they spared his bones, along with the bones of the prophet who had come from Samaria.
12:23:19/Josiah also removed all the shrines at the high places in the cities of Samaria that the kings of Israel had built to provoke the LORD to anger. He did to them just as he had done in Bethel.
12:23:20/He executed all the priests of the high places who were there, on the altars, and burned human bones on them. Then he returned to Jerusalem.
12:23:21/The king commanded all the people, "Celebrate the Passover to the LORD your God as it is prescribed in this covenant book."
12:23:22/Indeed, no such Passover had been observed since the days of the judges who led Israel, nor during the entire period of the kings of Israel and the kings of Judah.
12:23:23/But in the eighteenth year of King Josiah, this Passover was celebrated to the LORD in Jerusalem.
12:23:24/Josiah also got rid of the mediums, the spiritists, the household gods, the idols, and all the detestable things seen in Judah and Jerusalem. This was to fulfill the requirements of the law written in the book that Hilkiah the priest found in the temple of the LORD.
12:23:25/There was no king like him before or after him who turned to the LORD with all his heart, soul, and strength, in accordance with all the Law of Moses.
12:23:26/Yet, the LORD did not turn away from the heat of His fierce anger, which burned against Judah because of all that Manasseh had done to provoke Him.
12:23:27/The LORD said, "I will also remove Judah from my presence as I removed Israel, and I will reject Jerusalem, the city I chose, and the temple about which I said, 'My Name shall be there.'"
12:23:28/The rest of the events of Josiah's reign, and all he did, are recorded in the book of the annals of the kings of Judah.
12:23:29/During his reign, Pharaoh Necho king of Egypt went up to the Euphrates River to help the king of Assyria. King Josiah marched out to confront him, but Necho killed him at Megiddo as soon as he saw him.
12:23:30/His servants transported his body in a chariot from Megiddo to Jerusalem and buried him in his own tomb. The people of the land then took Jehoahaz son of Josiah, anointed him, and made him king in place of his father.
12:23:31/Jehoahaz was twenty-three years old when he became king, and he reigned for three months in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Hamutal daughter of Jeremiah of Libnah.
12:23:32/He did evil in the eyes of the LORD, just as his ancestors had done.
12:23:33/Pharaoh Necho imprisoned him at Riblah in the land of Hamath to prevent him from ruling in Jerusalem, and imposed a levy of a hundred talents of silver and a talent of gold on the land.
12:23:34/Pharaoh Necho made Eliakim son of Josiah king in place of his father Josiah, changed his name to Jehoiakim, and took Jehoahaz away. He died in Egypt.
12:23:35/Jehoiakim paid the silver and gold to Pharaoh but taxed the land to meet Pharaoh's demand, extracting the silver and gold from the people of the land, each according to their wealth, to give to Pharaoh Necho.
12:23:36/Jehoiakim was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned for eleven years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Zebidah daughter of Pedaiah of Rumah.
12:23:37/He did evil in the eyes of the LORD, just as his ancestors had done.
12:24:1/During his reign, Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon invaded, and Jehoiakim became his vassal for three years before he rebelled against him.
12:24:2/And the LORD sent against him groups of the Chaldeans, Syrians, Moabites, and Ammonites, and sent them against Judah to destroy it, as the LORD had declared through his prophets.
12:24:3/Indeed, by the LORD's command, this disaster came upon Judah to remove them from his presence because of the sins of Manasseh and all he had done;
12:24:4/And also because of the innocent blood he spilled, filling Jerusalem with innocent blood, which the LORD would not forgive.
12:24:5/The rest of the deeds of Jehoiakim, and everything he did, are they not recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah?
12:24:6/So Jehoiakim died, and his son Jehoiachin succeeded him as king.
12:24:7/The king of Egypt did not invade the land again because the king of Babylon had taken control of all the territory from the river of Egypt to the river Euphrates, which belonged to the king of Egypt.
12:24:8/Jehoiachin was eighteen years old when he became king, and he ruled in Jerusalem for three months. His mother's name was Nehushta, daughter of Elnathan of Jerusalem.
12:24:9/And he did what was evil in the LORD's sight, just as his father had done.
12:24:10/At that time, the forces of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon advanced against Jerusalem, and the city was under siege.
12:24:11/Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon himself came against the city while his forces besieged it.
12:24:12/Jehoiachin the king of Judah surrendered to the king of Babylon, along with his mother, his servants, his princes, and his officials. The king of Babylon captured him in the eighth year of his reign.
12:24:13/He took from there all the treasures of the house of the LORD and the treasures of the royal palace, and destroyed all the gold objects that Solomon king of Israel had made for the temple of the LORD, as the LORD had foretold.
12:24:14/He took into exile all of Jerusalem, all the officials, all the military men of valor, ten thousand captives, and all the craftsmen and smiths. Only the poorest people of the land were left.
12:24:15/He took Jehoiachin to Babylon along with the king's mother, the king's wives, his officials, and the leading men of the land, he took them into exile from Jerusalem to Babylon.
12:24:16/And all the men of valor, seven thousand, and craftsmen and smiths, one thousand, all strong and fit for war, were taken captive to Babylon by the king of Babylon.
12:24:17/The king of Babylon appointed Mattaniah, Jehoiachin's uncle, as king in his place and changed his name to Zedekiah.
12:24:18/Zedekiah was twenty-one years old when he began to reign, and he reigned eleven years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Hamutal, the daughter of Jeremiah of Libnah.
12:24:19/And he did what was evil in the sight of the LORD, just as Jehoiakim had done.
12:24:20/Because of the LORD's anger, it came to pass in Jerusalem and Judah that he expelled them from his presence. Zedekiah rebelled against the king of Babylon.
12:25:1/In the ninth year of his reign, on the tenth day of the tenth month, Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon arrived with his entire army to besiege Jerusalem. They surrounded it and built siege works against it.
12:25:2/The city was under siege until the eleventh year of King Zedekiah.
12:25:3/By the ninth day of the fourth month, the famine had become severe in the city, and there was no food for the people.
12:25:4/The city's defenses were breached, and all the soldiers fled at night through a gate between two walls near the king's garden, while the Babylonians surrounded the city. The king escaped towards the plains.
12:25:5/The Babylonian army chased the king and caught up with him in the plains of Jericho, and his army was scattered from him.
12:25:6/They captured the king and took him to the king of Babylon at Riblah, where they passed sentence on him.
12:25:7/They killed Zedekiah's sons in front of him, then blinded him, shackled him with bronze fetters, and took him to Babylon.
12:25:8/On the seventh day of the fifth month, in the nineteenth year of King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon, Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard and servant of the king of Babylon, came to Jerusalem.
12:25:9/He set fire to the temple of the LORD, the royal palace, and all the houses of Jerusalem. Every significant building was burned down.
12:25:10/The entire Babylonian army under the captain of the guard demolished the walls around Jerusalem.
12:25:11/Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, deported the remaining people in the city, those who had defected to the king of Babylon, and the rest of the population.
12:25:12/But the captain of the guard left some of the poorest people of the land to work as vineyard keepers and farmers.
12:25:13/The Babylonians broke into pieces the bronze pillars, the movable stands, and the bronze sea in the temple of the LORD, and carried the bronze to Babylon.
12:25:14/They took away the pots, shovels, wick trimmers, dishes, and all the bronze articles used in temple service.
12:25:15/The firepans and bowls that were gold or silver were also taken away by the captain of the guard.
12:25:16/The two pillars, the one sea, and the stands that Solomon had made for the temple of the LORD—the bronze of all these articles was beyond measure.
12:25:17/One pillar was eighteen cubits high, and its bronze capital was three cubits high, decorated with a network and pomegranates of bronze all around. The second pillar was similar, with a network.
12:25:18/The captain of the guard took Seraiah the chief priest, Zephaniah the second priest, and the three doorkeepers.
12:25:19/He also took an official who was in charge of the soldiers, five royal advisers who were found in the city, the chief military recruiter, and sixty men from the populace who were found in the city.
12:25:20/Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, took them to the king of Babylon at Riblah.
12:25:21/And the king of Babylon struck them down and killed them at Riblah in the land of Hamath. Thus Judah was exiled from its land.
12:25:22/Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon appointed Gedaliah son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan, as governor over the people he had left behind in Judah.
12:25:23/When all the army commanders and their men heard that the king of Babylon had appointed Gedaliah as governor, they came to Gedaliah at Mizpah. This included Ishmael son of Nethaniah, Johanan son of Careah, Seraiah son of Tanhumeth the Netophathite, and Jaazaniah son of the Maachathite, along with their men.
12:25:24/Gedaliah assured them and their men, saying, "Do not be afraid to serve the Babylonians. Stay in the land, serve the king of Babylon, and it will go well with you."
12:25:25/But in the seventh month, Ishmael son of Nethaniah, son of Elishama, of royal blood, came with ten men and assassinated Gedaliah, along with the Jews and Babylonians who were with him at Mizpah.
12:25:26/Then all the people, both small and great, along with the army commanders, fled to Egypt for fear of the Babylonians.
12:25:27/In the thirty-seventh year of the exile of Jehoiachin king of Judah, on the twenty-seventh day of the twelfth month, Evilmerodach king of Babylon, in the year he began to reign, released Jehoiachin king of Judah from prison.
12:25:28/He spoke kindly to him and gave him a seat of honor higher than those of the other kings who were with him in Babylon.
12:25:29/He changed Jehoiachin's prison clothes, and Jehoiachin dined regularly at the king's table for the rest of his life.
12:25:30/The king gave Jehoiachin a daily allowance for the rest of his life.
13:1:1/Adam, Seth, Enosh,
13:1:2/Kenan, Mahalalel, Jared,
13:1:3/Enoch, Methuselah, Lamech,
13:1:4/Noah, Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
13:1:5/The sons of Japheth; Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras.
13:1:6/And the sons of Gomer; Ashkenaz, Riphath, and Togarmah.
13:1:7/And the sons of Javan; Elishah, Tarshish, Kittim, and Dodanim.
13:1:8/The sons of Ham; Cush, Mizraim, Put, and Canaan.
