13:28:13/He also provided for the divisions of the priests and Levites, for all the work of serving in the Lord's temple, and for all the articles used in service in the temple.
13:28:14/David allocated gold by weight for all gold articles for various services, and silver for all silver articles for various kinds of service.
13:28:15/He specified the weight for the gold lampstands and their gold lamps, with the weight for each lampstand and its lamps, and for the silver lampstands, each according to its service.
13:28:16/He provided gold by weight for the tables of the Bread of the Presence, for each table, and silver for the silver tables.
13:28:17/He also provided pure gold for the forks, bowls, and cups, and for the golden basins, he gave gold by weight for each basin, and silver by weight for each silver basin.
13:28:18/And for the altar of incense, he provided refined gold by weight, and gold for the model of the chariot of the cherubim that spread their wings and sheltered the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord.
13:28:19/David said, "The Lord gave me understanding in writing, by His hand upon me, of all the details of this plan."
13:28:20/And David told Solomon his son, "Be strong and courageous, and do the work. Do not be afraid or discouraged, for the Lord God, my God, is with you. He will not fail you or abandon you until all the work for the service of the temple of the Lord is finished.
13:28:21/And see, the divisions of the priests and Levites for all the service of God's temple are at your disposal. You will have with you every willing and skilled person for any kind of work. The officials and all the people will obey your every command."
13:29:1/David the king said to the whole assembly, "Solomon, my son, whom God has uniquely chosen, is still young and inexperienced, and the task is immense. This palace is not for humans, but for the LORD God.
13:29:2/I have done my utmost to prepare for the temple of my God, providing gold for the goldwork, silver for the silver, bronze for the bronze, iron for the ironwork, and wood for the woodwork; onyx stones and setting stones, stones of various colors, all kinds of precious stones, and plenty of marble.
13:29:3/Because I have set my heart on the temple of my God, I have given from my personal wealth toward the temple of my God, in addition to everything I've prepared for the holy temple.
13:29:4/I've provided 3,000 talents of gold from Ophir and 7,000 talents of refined silver to cover the walls of the buildings.
13:29:5/The gold for the goldwork, the silver for the silverwork, and for all kinds of craftsmanship. Now, who is willing to dedicate themselves to the LORD today?
13:29:6/Then the leaders of families, the princes of the tribes of Israel, the commanders of thousands and of hundreds, and the officials in charge of the king's work gave willingly.
13:29:7/They contributed to the service of the temple of God 5,000 talents and 10,000 darics of gold, 10,000 talents of silver, 18,000 talents of bronze, and 100,000 talents of iron.
13:29:8/Those who had precious stones gave them to the treasury of the temple of the LORD under the care of Jehiel the Gershonite.
13:29:9/The people rejoiced at their willingness to give, for they gave freely and wholeheartedly to the LORD. King David also rejoiced greatly.
13:29:10/Therefore, David praised the LORD in front of the whole assembly, saying, "Praise be to you, LORD, the God of our ancestor Israel, from everlasting to everlasting.
13:29:11/Yours, LORD, is the greatness, the power, the glory, the victory, and the majesty. Everything in heaven and on earth is yours; yours is the kingdom, O LORD, and you are exalted as head above all.
13:29:12/Wealth and honor come from you; you rule over everything. In your hands are strength and power to exalt and give strength to all.
13:29:13/Now, our God, we give you thanks and praise your glorious name.
13:29:14/But who am I, and who are my people, that we should be able to give as generously as this? Everything comes from you, and we have given you only what comes from your hand.
13:29:15/We are foreigners and strangers in your sight, as were all our ancestors. Our days on earth are like a shadow, without hope.
13:29:16/O LORD our God, all this abundance that we have provided for building you a temple for your holy name comes from your hand, and all of it belongs to you.
13:29:17/I know, my God, that you test the heart and are pleased with integrity. All these things I have given willingly and with honest intent. And now I have seen with joy how willingly your people who are here have given to you.
13:29:18/O LORD, the God of our ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, keep this desire in the hearts of your people forever, and keep their hearts loyal to you.
13:29:19/And give my son Solomon the wholehearted devotion to keep your commands, statutes and decrees and to do everything to build the palatial structure for which I have provided."
13:29:20/Then David said to the whole assembly, "Now praise the LORD your God." So the whole assembly praised the LORD, the God of their ancestors, and they bowed down, prostrating themselves before the LORD and the king.
13:29:21/They offered sacrifices to the LORD and presented burnt offerings to the LORD the next day: a thousand bulls, a thousand rams, a thousand lambs, along with their drink offerings, and sacrifices in abundance for all Israel.
13:29:22/They ate and drank with great joy in the presence of the LORD that day. Then they made Solomon, son of David, king for the second time, anointing him before the LORD to be ruler and Zadok to be priest.
13:29:23/Then Solomon sat on the throne of the LORD as king in place of his father David. He succeeded, and all Israel obeyed him.
13:29:24/All the officials, the mighty warriors, and all of King David's sons pledged their allegiance to King Solomon.
13:29:25/The LORD greatly exalted Solomon in the eyes of all Israel and bestowed on him royal splendor such as no king over Israel had ever had before.
13:29:26/David, son of Jesse, ruled over all Israel.
13:29:27/He ruled over Israel for forty years; seven years in Hebron and thirty-three in Jerusalem.
13:29:28/He died at a good old age, having enjoyed long life, wealth, and honor. His son Solomon succeeded him as king.
13:29:29/The acts of King David, from beginning to end, are written in the records of Samuel the seer, Nathan the prophet, and Gad the seer,
13:29:30/including all his reign, his power, and the events that affected him, Israel, and all the kingdoms of the lands.
14:1:1/Solomon, the son of David, became strong in his kingdom, with the LORD his God supporting him and greatly enhancing his stature.
14:1:2/Then Solomon addressed all of Israel, including the military commanders, judges, and every regional governor, the leaders of the families.
14:1:3/So Solomon, along with the entire assembly, went to the high place at Gibeon; because that was where the tent of meeting with God, which Moses, the LORD's servant, had made in the desert, was located.
14:1:4/However, the ark of God had been moved by David from Kirjathjearim to a site he had prepared for it; he had set up a tent for it in Jerusalem.
14:1:5/Furthermore, the bronze altar made by Bezaleel, the son of Uri, the son of Hur, was placed in front of the LORD's tent; Solomon and the assembly sought it out.
14:1:6/And Solomon went up to the bronze altar before the LORD, which was at the tent of meeting, and offered a thousand burnt offerings on it.
14:1:7/That night, God appeared to Solomon and said, "Ask for whatever you want me to give you."
14:1:8/And Solomon said to God, "You have shown great kindness to my father David, and have made me king in his place."
14:1:9/Now, LORD God, let your promise to my father David be fulfilled; for you have made me king over a people as numerous as the dust of the earth.
14:1:10/Grant me now wisdom and knowledge, so I can lead this people properly; for who can govern this great people of yours?
14:1:11/And God said to Solomon, "Because this was your desire, and you have not asked for riches, wealth, or honor, nor the death of your foes, nor have you asked for a long life; but have asked for wisdom and knowledge to govern my people, over whom I have made you king:
14:1:12/Wisdom and knowledge are given to you; and I will also give you riches, wealth, and honor unlike any kings before you, nor will any after you have the same."
14:1:13/Then Solomon returned from his trip to the high place at Gibeon to Jerusalem, from before the tent of meeting, and ruled over Israel.
14:1:14/And Solomon amassed chariots and horsemen: he had fourteen hundred chariots and twelve thousand horsemen, which he stationed in the chariot cities and with the king in Jerusalem.
14:1:15/The king made silver and gold as common in Jerusalem as stones, and he made cedar trees as plentiful as the sycamore trees in the lowlands.
14:1:16/And Solomon imported horses from Egypt and linen yarn; the king's merchants purchased the linen yarn at a fixed price.
14:1:17/They also imported and brought from Egypt a chariot for six hundred shekels of silver, and a horse for one hundred and fifty; thus, they supplied horses to all the kings of the Hittites and the kings of Syria through their intermediaries.
14:2:1/Solomon decided to build a temple for the LORD's name and a palace for his own reign.
14:2:2/Solomon assigned seventy thousand men to carry loads, eighty thousand to quarry in the mountains, and three thousand six hundred to supervise them.
14:2:3/Solomon sent a message to Huram, king of Tyre, saying, "Just as you dealt with my father David, sending him cedars to build a residence, please do the same for me.
14:2:4/"I am building a temple to honor the LORD my God, to dedicate it to him, to offer sweet incense before him, for the regular presentation of the showbread, and for the burnt offerings every morning and evening, on the Sabbaths, on the new moons, and during the LORD our God's appointed festivals. This will be a perpetual ordinance for Israel.
14:2:5/"The temple I am building will be magnificent because our God is greater than all other gods.
14:2:6/"But who can really build a temple for him, since even the heavens and the highest heavens cannot contain him? Who am I, then, to build a temple for him, except as a place to offer sacrifices before him?
14:2:7/"Therefore, send me a craftsman skilled in working with gold, silver, bronze, and iron, and in dyeing purple, crimson, and blue, and who knows how to engrave, to join the skilled craftsmen I have in Judah and Jerusalem, whom my father David provided.
14:2:8/"Also, send me cedar, fir, and algum trees from Lebanon, for I know your servants are experts at logging in Lebanon; and my servants will work alongside yours,
14:2:9/"to provide me with plenty of timber, because the temple I intend to build will be incredibly magnificent.
14:2:10/"And look, I will supply your workers, the loggers, with twenty thousand cors of crushed wheat, twenty thousand cors of barley, twenty thousand baths of wine, and twenty thousand baths of olive oil."
14:2:11/Then Huram, king of Tyre, replied in a letter to Solomon, "Because the LORD loves his people, he has made you their king."
14:2:12/Huram also said, "Praise be to the LORD, the God of Israel, who created the heavens and the earth, for giving David a wise son, endowed with intelligence and discernment, who will build a temple for the LORD and a royal palace for himself.
14:2:13/"Now, I am sending a skilled man, endowed with understanding, from Huram my father's lineage,
14:2:14/"He is the son of a woman from the tribe of Dan and his father was a man of Tyre, skilled in working with gold, silver, bronze, iron, stone, and wood, and in dyeing purple, blue, fine linen, and crimson. He is also skilled in engraving and can execute any design given to him, working alongside your skilled men and those of my lord David, your father.
14:2:15/"Now then, send the wheat, barley, oil, and wine you mentioned to your servants,
14:2:16/"and we will cut as much wood from Lebanon as you need and float it by sea to Joppa, so you can transport it to Jerusalem."
14:2:17/And Solomon registered all the foreigners in the land of Israel, following the census his father David had taken; they totaled one hundred fifty-three thousand six hundred.
14:2:18/He assigned seventy thousand of them as carriers, eighty thousand as stonecutters in the mountains, and three thousand six hundred as overseers to manage the workforce.
14:3:1/Solomon began constructing the LORD's temple in Jerusalem on Mount Moriah, where the Lord had appeared to his father David, at the site David had prepared on Ornan the Jebusite's threshing floor.
14:3:2/He started the construction on the second day of the second month, during the fourth year of his reign.
14:3:3/The construction plans for the temple of God included a length of sixty cubits and a width of twenty cubits, using the original measurements.
14:3:4/The front porch of the temple was as wide as the temple itself, twenty cubits, and it was one hundred and twenty cubits high. He covered the inside with pure gold.
14:3:5/He paneled the larger room with fir wood, which he covered with fine gold, and decorated it with palm trees and chains.
14:3:6/He adorned the temple with precious stones for beauty, and the gold used was the high-quality gold from Parvaim.
14:3:7/He also covered the temple's beams, posts, walls, and doors with gold, and carved cherubim on the walls.
14:3:8/He constructed the Most Holy Place, making it twenty cubits long and twenty cubits wide, matching the width of the temple, and covered it with fine gold totaling six hundred talents.
14:3:9/The nails weighed fifty shekels of gold. He also covered the upper rooms with gold.
14:3:10/In the Most Holy Place, he crafted two cherubim from wood and covered them with gold.
14:3:11/The wingspan of the cherubim was twenty cubits; one wing of the first cherub was five cubits long, touching the temple wall, and its other wing, also five cubits long, touched the wing of the second cherub.
14:3:12/One wing of the second cherub was five cubits long, touching the temple wall, and its other wing, five cubits long, touched the wing of the first cherub.
14:3:13/The cherubim spread their wings out twenty cubits. They stood on their feet, facing inward.
14:3:14/He made the veil of blue, purple, crimson, and fine linen, and embroidered cherubim on it.
14:3:15/He also constructed two pillars thirty-five cubits high in front of the temple, with a capital five cubits high on top of each.
14:3:16/He made chains as in the inner sanctuary and placed them on the tops of the pillars; he also made one hundred pomegranates and attached them to the chains.
14:3:17/He erected the pillars in front of the temple, one on the right and the other on the left, and named the right pillar Jachin and the left pillar Boaz.
14:4:1/Furthermore, he constructed an altar made of bronze, measuring twenty cubits in length and breadth, and ten cubits in height.
14:4:2/He also crafted a large bronze basin, ten cubits from edge to edge, circular in shape, five cubits tall, and surrounded by a thirty-cubit measuring line.
14:4:3/Beneath it were figures of oxen encircling it all around: ten per cubit, encircling the basin. Two rows of oxen were molded into it when it was cast.
14:4:4/It rested on twelve oxen, with three facing north, three facing west, three facing south, and three facing east; the basin was set on top of them, and all their rear parts were inward.
14:4:5/The basin's wall was as thick as the width of a hand, and its rim was like the edge of a cup decorated with lily flowers; it could hold and contain three thousand baths.
14:4:6/He also made ten washbasins and placed five on the right side and five on the left for washing; the items for the burnt offering were washed in them, but the large basin was for the priests to wash in.
14:4:7/And he crafted ten golden lampstands according to their design and placed them in the temple, five on the right side and five on the left.
14:4:8/He also made ten tables and arranged them in the temple, five on the right side and five on the left. And he made a hundred golden basins.
14:4:9/Additionally, he constructed the courtyard for the priests, the large courtyard, and the doors for the courtyard, covering the doors with bronze.
14:4:10/And he positioned the large basin on the right side of the temple's east end, facing south.
14:4:11/And Huram crafted the pots, shovels, and basins. Huram completed the work he had been commissioned to do for King Solomon in the house of God;
14:4:12/Namely, the two pillars, the capitals on top of the pillars, and the two networks to decorate the two capitals on top of the pillars;
14:4:13/And four hundred pomegranates for the two networks, with two rows of pomegranates for each network, to decorate the two capitals on top of the pillars.
14:4:14/He also made stands and placed the washbasins on the stands;
14:4:15/A large basin and twelve oxen beneath it.
14:4:16/The pots, shovels, meat hooks, and all their accessories, Huram his father crafted for King Solomon for the LORD's house out of polished bronze.
14:4:17/In the Jordan plain, the king had them cast in the clay soil between Succoth and Zeredathah.
14:4:18/Thus, Solomon made all these items in great quantity; the weight of the bronze was beyond measure.
14:4:19/And Solomon made all the items for God's house, including the golden altar and the tables for the bread of the Presence;
14:4:20/Also the lampstands and their lamps of pure gold to burn in the prescribed manner in front of the inner sanctuary;
14:4:21/And the flowers, lamps, and tongs, he made of gold, of the finest quality;
14:4:22/And the trimmers, basins, ladles, and censers, of pure gold. As for the entrance of the temple, the inner doors for the Most Holy Place, and the doors of the main hall of the temple, they were gold.
14:5:1/So, all the work Solomon did for the LORD's house was completed: Solomon brought in everything his father David had dedicated; the silver, gold, and all the equipment were placed among the treasures of God's house.
14:5:2/Then Solomon gathered the elders of Israel, all the tribal leaders, and the heads of the families of the Israelites in Jerusalem, to move the ark of the covenant of the LORD from the City of David, which is Zion.
14:5:3/That's why all the men of Israel came together to the king during the festival in the seventh month.
14:5:4/All the elders of Israel arrived; and the Levites carried the ark.
14:5:5/They moved the ark, the meeting tent, and all the sacred objects in the tent; the priests and Levites brought them up.
14:5:6/King Solomon and the entire assembly of Israel gathered before the ark, offering so many sheep and oxen they couldn't be counted.
14:5:7/The priests then placed the ark of the covenant of the LORD in its spot, in the inner sanctuary of the temple, under the wings of the cherubim.
14:5:8/The cherubim spread their wings over the ark's location, covering the ark and its carrying poles from above.
14:5:9/They extended the poles of the ark so that the ends were visible from the Holy of Holies but not from outside, and they are still there today.
14:5:10/The only items in the ark were the two stone tablets Moses had placed there at Horeb, where the LORD made a covenant with the Israelites after they left Egypt.
14:5:11/When the priests exited the sanctuary (for all the priests present had purified themselves, not adhering to their divisions,
14:5:12/The Levite singers, all from Asaph, Heman, Jeduthun, along with their sons and relatives, dressed in white linen, with cymbals, lyres, and harps, stood at the east side of the altar, accompanied by 120 priests blowing trumpets.)
14:5:13/As the trumpeters and singers united in one voice to praise and thank the LORD, and when they raised their voices, accompanied by trumpets, cymbals, and other musical instruments, in praise to the LORD, saying, "For he is good; his love endures forever," a cloud filled the temple, the house of the LORD.
14:5:14/So intense was the cloud, the glory of the LORD filled God's house, that the priests couldn't continue their service.
14:6:1/Then Solomon said, "The LORD has declared He would dwell in deep darkness.
14:6:2/But I have built a house for You to live in, a place for You to dwell forever.
14:6:3/And the king turned around, blessing the entire assembly of Israel while they all stood.
14:6:4/He said, "Praise be to the LORD, the God of Israel, who with His own hands has fulfilled what He promised with His mouth to my father David, saying,
14:6:5/'Since the day I brought My people out of Egypt, I did not choose any city among all the tribes of Israel to build a house where My Name would be. I did not choose anyone to be the leader over My people Israel.
14:6:6/But I have chosen Jerusalem for My Name to be there, and I have chosen David to rule over My people Israel.'
14:6:7/It was in the heart of my father David to build a house for the Name of the LORD, the God of Israel.
14:6:8/But the LORD said to my father David, 'Because it was in your heart to build a house for My Name, you did well to have this in your heart.
14:6:9/However, you will not build the house; instead, your son, who will come from your own body, he will build the house for My Name.'
14:6:10/The LORD has kept the promise He made: I have succeeded David my father and now sit on the throne of Israel, just as the LORD promised, and I have built the house for the Name of the LORD, the God of Israel.
14:6:11/And in it, I have placed the ark, which contains the covenant of the LORD that He made with the people of Israel.
14:6:12/He stood before the altar of the LORD in front of the entire assembly of Israel and spread out his hands.
14:6:13/For Solomon had made a bronze platform, five cubits long, five cubits wide, and three cubits high, and had set it in the center of the courtyard. On it, he stood, then knelt down before the whole assembly of Israel and spread out his hands toward heaven.
14:6:14/And said, "O LORD, the God of Israel, there is no God like You in heaven or on earth, keeping covenant and showing steadfast love to Your servants who walk before You with all their heart,
14:6:15/You who have kept Your promise to Your servant David my father; what You declared with Your mouth, You have fulfilled with Your hand, as it is today.
14:6:16/Now, O LORD, the God of Israel, keep for Your servant David my father what You have promised him, saying, 'You shall not lack a man to sit before Me on the throne of Israel, if only your sons pay close attention to their way, to walk in My law as you have walked before Me.'
14:6:17/Now, O LORD, the God of Israel, let Your word that You have promised to Your servant David be confirmed.
14:6:18/But will God indeed dwell with humans on the earth? Behold, heaven and the highest heaven cannot contain You, how much less this house that I have built!
14:6:19/Yet have regard to the prayer of Your servant and to his plea, O LORD my God, listening to the cry and to the prayer that Your servant prays before You,
14:6:20/That Your eyes may be open day and night toward this house, the place where You have said You would put Your Name, to listen to the prayer that Your servant prays toward this place.
14:6:21/Listen to the pleas of Your servant and of Your people Israel, when they pray toward this place. Hear from Your dwelling place, from heaven; and when You hear, forgive.
14:6:22/If someone sins against their neighbor and is required to take an oath, and they come and swear the oath before Your altar in this house,
14:6:23/Then hear from heaven and act. Judge Your servants, repaying the guilty by bringing their conduct on their own heads, and vindicating the righteous by rewarding them according to their righteousness.
14:6:24/If Your people Israel are defeated before an enemy because they have sinned against You, and they return to You and confess Your name, praying and pleading with You in this house,
14:6:25/Then hear from heaven and forgive the sin of Your people Israel and bring them back to the land You gave to them and their ancestors.
14:6:26/When the heavens are shut up and there is no rain because they have sinned against You, yet if they pray toward this place and confess Your name, turning from their sin when You afflict them,
14:6:27/Then hear in heaven and forgive the sin of Your servants, Your people Israel, teaching them the good way in which they should walk, and send rain on Your land, which You have given to Your people as an inheritance.
14:6:28/If there is famine in the land, if there is pestilence, blight, mildew, locust, or caterpillar; if their enemies besiege them in the land at their gates, whatever plague, whatever sickness there is,
14:6:29/Whatever prayer, whatever plea is made by any individual or by all Your people Israel, each knowing their own affliction and their own sorrow and stretching out their hands toward this house,
14:6:30/Then hear from heaven Your dwelling place, and forgive, and render to each whose heart You know, according to all his ways, for You, You only, know the hearts of the children of mankind,
14:6:31/That they may fear You and walk in Your ways all the days that they live in the land that You gave to our ancestors.
14:6:32/Also concerning the foreigner, who is not of Your people Israel but comes from a far country for the sake of Your great name and Your mighty hand and Your outstretched arm, when they come and pray in this house,
14:6:33/Then hear from heaven, from Your dwelling place, and do according to all for which the foreigner calls to You, so that all the peoples of the earth may know Your name and fear You, as do Your people Israel, and may know that this house that I have built is called by Your name.
14:6:34/If Your people go out to battle against their enemies, by whatever way You shall send them, and they pray to You toward this city that You have chosen and the house that I have built for Your name,
14:6:35/Then hear from heaven their prayer and their plea, and maintain their cause.
14:6:36/If they sin against You—for there is no one who does not sin—and You are angry with them and give them to an enemy, so that they are taken captive to a land far or near,
14:6:37/Yet if they turn their hearts in the land to which they have been taken captive, and repent and plead with You in the land of their captivity, saying, 'We have sinned and have acted perversely and wickedly,'
14:6:38/If they return to You with all their heart and with all their soul in the land of their captivity, where they have been taken captive, and pray toward their land, which You gave to their fathers, the city that You have chosen, and the house that I have built for Your name,
14:6:39/Then hear from heaven, from Your dwelling place, their prayer and their pleas, and maintain their cause and forgive Your people who have sinned against You.
14:6:40/Now, my God, may Your eyes be open and Your ears attentive to the prayer made in this place.
14:6:41/Now therefore arise, O LORD God, to Your resting place, You and the ark of Your might. Let Your priests, O LORD God, be clothed with salvation, and let Your faithful ones rejoice in goodness.
14:6:42/O LORD God, do not turn away the face of Your anointed one. Remember Your steadfast love for David Your servant.
14:7:1/After Solomon finished praying, fire descended from heaven, consuming the burnt offering and sacrifices; and the LORD's glory filled the temple.
14:7:2/The priests couldn't enter the LORD's temple because the LORD's glory had completely filled it.
14:7:3/When all the Israelites saw the fire descend and the LORD's glory over the temple, they knelt with their faces to the ground on the pavement, worshiping and praising the LORD, saying, "For he is good; his love lasts forever."
14:7:4/Then the king and all the people presented sacrifices to the LORD.
14:7:5/King Solomon sacrificed 22,000 oxen and 120,000 sheep: thus, the king and all the people dedicated the temple of God.
14:7:6/The priests performed their duties: the Levites too, with musical instruments of the LORD that King David had made to praise the LORD, "because his love endures forever," as David praised through their ministry; and the priests played trumpets before them, and all Israel stood.
14:7:7/Furthermore, Solomon consecrated the middle of the courtyard in front of the LORD's temple: there he offered burnt offerings and the fat of the peace offerings, because the bronze altar Solomon had made couldn't hold the burnt offerings, grain offerings, and the fat.
14:7:8/At the same time, Solomon celebrated the festival for seven days, along with a vast assembly from all over Israel, from the entrance of Hamath to the Brook of Egypt.
14:7:9/And on the eighth day they held a solemn assembly, having celebrated the dedication of the altar for seven days and the festival for seven days.
14:7:10/On the twenty-third day of the seventh month, he sent the people to their homes, joyful and glad of heart for the goodness the LORD had shown to David, Solomon, and to his people Israel.
14:7:11/So Solomon completed the LORD's temple and the royal palace. Everything that Solomon had planned to do in the LORD's temple and in his own palace succeeded.
14:7:12/The LORD appeared to Solomon at night and said to him, "I have heard your prayer and have chosen this place for myself as a temple for sacrifices.
14:7:13/If I close the sky so there's no rain, or command locusts to devour the land, or send a plague among my people;
14:7:14/If my people, who are called by my name, will humble themselves, pray, seek my face, and turn from their wicked ways; then I will hear from heaven, forgive their sin, and heal their land.
14:7:15/Now my eyes will be open and my ears attentive to the prayers offered in this place.
14:7:16/For now, I have chosen and consecrated this temple so that my name may be there forever; my eyes and my heart will always be there.
14:7:17/And as for you, if you walk before me as David your father did, and do everything I command, and keep my decrees and laws;
14:7:18/Then I will establish your royal throne, as I covenanted with David your father, saying, 'You will never fail to have a successor to rule over Israel.'
14:7:19/But if you turn away and abandon my decrees and commands I have set before you and go off to serve other gods and worship them;
14:7:20/Then I will uproot Israel from my land, which I have given them; and this temple, which I have consecrated for my name, I will cast out of my sight, and it will become a proverb and a byword among all peoples.
14:7:21/And this temple, now exalted, will become a ruin. Everyone passing by will be shocked and will ask, 'Why has the LORD done such a thing to this land and to this temple?'
14:7:22/And the answer will be, 'Because they abandoned the LORD, the God of their ancestors, who brought them out of Egypt, and embraced other gods, worshiping and serving them. That is why he brought all this disaster on them.'
14:8:1/After twenty years, during which Solomon had built the temple of the LORD and his own palace,
14:8:2/Solomon rebuilt the cities Huram had given back to him and settled the Israelites in them.
14:8:3/Solomon also conquered Hamathzobah.
14:8:4/He built Tadmor in the desert and all the storage cities he constructed in Hamath.
14:8:5/He also constructed both Upper and Lower Bethhoron as fortified cities with walls, gates, and bars;
14:8:6/And Baalath, as well as all the storage cities Solomon had, the cities for his chariots and horsemen, and everything Solomon wanted to build in Jerusalem, in Lebanon, and throughout his entire territory.
14:8:7/Regarding all the people left from the Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites, who were not Israelites,
14:8:8/But from their descendants, who remained in the land after them, whom the Israelites did not completely destroy, Solomon imposed forced labor that continues to this day.
14:8:9/However, Solomon did not make slaves out of the Israelites; they served as soldiers, commanders of his army, and officers of his chariots and cavalry.
14:8:10/These were the chief officials of King Solomon, numbering two hundred and fifty, who oversaw the people.
14:8:11/Solomon moved Pharaoh's daughter from the City of David to the palace he had built for her, saying, "My wife shall not live in King David's palace of Israel, because the places the Ark of the LORD has entered are sacred."
14:8:12/Then Solomon offered burnt offerings to the LORD on the altar of the LORD he had built in front of the temple porch,
14:8:13/Offering sacrifices according to Moses' commandment every day, on Sabbaths, new moons, and during the three annual festivals—the Festival of Unleavened Bread, the Festival of Weeks, and the Festival of Tabernacles.
14:8:14/He followed his father David's instructions regarding the divisions of the priests for their duties and the Levites for their roles of praise and service before the priests as required each day. He also organized the gatekeepers by their divisions at each gate, as David, the man of God, had ordered.
14:8:15/They did not deviate from the king's commands to the priests and Levites concerning any matter, including the treasuries.
14:8:16/All of Solomon's work was prepared up to the day the foundation of the LORD's temple was laid, and until its completion. Thus, the temple of the LORD was finished.
14:8:17/Then Solomon went to Eziongeber and Eloth on the seashore in the land of Edom.
14:8:18/Huram sent him ships and experienced seafaring men through his servants. They sailed with Solomon's servants to Ophir, collected four hundred and fifty talents of gold, and brought them back to King Solomon.
14:9:1/When the queen of Sheba heard about Solomon's fame, she came to test him with difficult questions in Jerusalem, bringing a huge entourage, camels loaded with spices, lots of gold, and precious stones. Upon arriving, she discussed everything on her mind with Solomon.
14:9:2/Solomon answered all her questions; there was nothing he couldn't explain to her.
14:9:3/When the queen of Sheba witnessed Solomon's wisdom, and the palace he had built,
14:9:4/And saw the food on his table, the organization of his servants, the service and attire of his ministers, his cupbearers, and their uniforms, and the stairway he used to go up to the house of the LORD, she was utterly amazed.
14:9:5/She told the king, "The reports I heard in my own country about your achievements and wisdom are true.
14:9:6/But I didn't believe them until I came and saw with my own eyes. Indeed, not even half of your wisdom was told to me; you surpass the fame I had heard.
14:9:7/Your officials and servants are fortunate to stand before you and hear your wisdom.
14:9:8/Blessed be the LORD your God, who has delighted in you, setting you on his throne as king for the LORD your God. Because your God loves Israel and wants to establish them forever, he has made you king over them, to rule with justice and righteousness.
14:9:9/She gave the king 120 talents of gold, a huge quantity of spices, and precious stones. There was no spice like the ones the queen of Sheba gave to King Solomon.
14:9:10/The servants of Huram and Solomon, who brought gold from Ophir, also brought algum trees and precious stones.
14:9:11/The king used the algum trees to make steps for the LORD's temple and the royal palace, and to make harps and lyres for the musicians. Nothing like them had ever been seen before in Judah.
14:9:12/King Solomon gave the queen of Sheba all she desired and asked for, in addition to what she had brought to the king. Then she returned to her own country with her servants.
14:9:13/In one year, Solomon received 666 talents of gold,
14:9:14/Besides what was brought by the merchants and traders. Moreover, all the kings of Arabia and the governors of the land brought gold and silver to Solomon.
14:9:15/King Solomon made 200 large shields of hammered gold; 600 shekels of gold went into each shield.
14:9:16/He also made 300 smaller shields of hammered gold, with three minas of gold in each shield. The king placed them in the House of the Forest of Lebanon.
14:9:17/Furthermore, the king made a great throne of ivory and overlaid it with pure gold.
14:9:18/The throne had six steps, and a gold footstool was attached to it. There were armrests on either side of the seat, and two lions stood beside the armrests.
14:9:19/Twelve lions stood on the six steps, one at either end of each step. No other kingdom had anything like it.
14:9:20/All of King Solomon's drinking vessels were gold, and all the utensils of the House of the Forest of Lebanon were pure gold. Silver was considered of little value in Solomon's days.
14:9:21/The king's ships went to Tarshish with the servants of Huram. Every three years, the ships of Tarshish would return, bringing gold, silver, ivory, apes, and peacocks.
14:9:22/King Solomon surpassed all the kings of the earth in riches and wisdom.
14:9:23/All the kings of the earth sought an audience with Solomon to hear the wisdom God had placed in his heart.
14:9:24/They brought gifts: silver and gold vessels, garments, weapons, spices, horses, and mules, year after year.
14:9:25/Solomon had 4,000 stalls for horses and chariots, and 12,000 horsemen, whom he stationed in the chariot cities and with the king in Jerusalem.
14:9:26/He ruled over all the kings from the Euphrates River to the land of the Philistines and to the border of Egypt.
14:9:27/The king made silver as common in Jerusalem as stones, and he made cedar trees as plentiful as the sycamores in the foothills.
14:9:28/People brought horses to Solomon from Egypt and from all countries.
14:9:29/The rest of the acts of Solomon, from first to last, are written in the records of Nathan the prophet, in the prophecy of Ahijah the Shilonite, and in the visions of Iddo the seer concerning Jeroboam the son of Nebat.
14:9:30/Solomon reigned in Jerusalem over all Israel for forty years.
14:9:31/Solomon passed away and was buried in the city of David his father, and his son Rehoboam succeeded him as king.
14:10:1/And Rehoboam went to Shechem: for to Shechem were all Israel come to make him king.
14:10:2/When Jeroboam, son of Nebat, who had fled to Egypt to escape King Solomon, heard about it, he came back from Egypt.
14:10:3/They sent for him, and Jeroboam and all of Israel came and spoke to Rehoboam, saying,
14:10:4/Your father made our burden heavy: now, please lighten the harsh labor and the heavy yoke he put on us, and we will serve you.
14:10:5/He told them, "Come back to me in three days." So the people left.
14:10:6/King Rehoboam consulted with the elders who had served his father Solomon during his lifetime, asking, "What is your advice on how to respond to these people?"
14:10:7/They replied, "If you are kind to these people, please them, and speak kindly to them, they will be your servants forever."
14:10:8/But he ignored the advice the elders gave him and consulted the young men he had grown up with, who were now his advisors.
14:10:9/He asked them, "What is your advice for us to answer these people who have said to me, 'Lighten the yoke your father put on us'?"
14:10:10/The young men he had grown up with told him, "Tell the people who said to you, 'Your father made our yoke heavy, but you make it lighter for us,' that 'My little finger is thicker than my father’s waist.
14:10:11/While my father laid a heavy yoke on you, I will add to your yoke: my father disciplined you with whips, but I will discipline you with scorpions."
14:10:12/So Jeroboam and all the people came to Rehoboam on the third day, as the king had directed, saying, "Come back to me on the third day."
14:10:13/And the king answered them harshly; King Rehoboam disregarded the advice of the elders,
14:10:14/And responded according to the young men's advice, saying, "My father made your yoke heavy, but I will make it even heavier: my father disciplined you with whips, but I will discipline you with scorpions."
14:10:15/So the king did not listen to the people, for this turn of events was from God, to fulfill His word, which He had spoken through Ahijah the Shilonite to Jeroboam son of Nebat.
14:10:16/When all Israel realized that the king had refused to listen to them, they answered the king, "What share do we have in David? We have no inheritance in the son of Jesse. To your tents, O Israel! Now, David, take care of your own house!" So all Israel went to their tents.
14:10:17/But as for the Israelites who lived in the towns of Judah, Rehoboam still ruled over them.
14:10:18/Then King Rehoboam sent out Hadoram, who was in charge of forced labor, but the Israelites stoned him to death. King Rehoboam managed to get to his chariot and escape to Jerusalem.
14:10:19/And Israel has been in rebellion against the house of David to this day.
14:11:1/When Rehoboam arrived in Jerusalem, he assembled 180,000 elite warriors from Judah and Benjamin to wage war against Israel and reclaim the kingdom for himself.
14:11:2/But God spoke to Shemaiah, the man of God, with a message,
14:11:3/Tell Rehoboam, son of Solomon and king of Judah, and all the people of Judah and Benjamin,
14:11:4/"This is what the LORD says: Do not attack your relatives. Everyone go back home, because I am the one who has caused this situation." They listened to the LORD's command and stopped their march against Jeroboam.
14:11:5/Rehoboam stayed in Jerusalem and started fortifying cities in Judah for defense.
14:11:6/He fortified Bethlehem, Etam, and Tekoa,
14:11:7/And Bethzur, Shoco, and Adullam,
14:11:8/And Gath, Mareshah, and Ziph,
14:11:9/And Adoraim, Lachish, and Azekah,
14:11:10/And Zorah, Aijalon, and Hebron, which are fortified cities in Judah and Benjamin.
14:11:11/He strengthened the fortresses, appointed commanders, and stocked them with food, oil, and wine.
14:11:12/In every city, he placed shields and spears, making them very strong, with the support of Judah and Benjamin.
14:11:13/Priests and Levites from all over Israel joined him in Jerusalem from their regions.
14:11:14/The Levites left their rural areas and properties to come to Judah and Jerusalem because Jeroboam and his sons had excluded them from serving as priests to the LORD.
14:11:15/He appointed his own priests for the high places, for the goat idols, and for the calves he had made.
14:11:16/Those from all the tribes of Israel who were determined to seek the LORD God of Israel followed them to Jerusalem to offer sacrifices to the LORD, the God of their ancestors.
14:11:17/This strengthened the kingdom of Judah and supported Rehoboam, son of Solomon, for three years because they followed the ways of David and Solomon during this time.
14:11:18/Rehoboam married Mahalath, daughter of Jerimoth, son of David, and Abihail, daughter of Eliab, son of Jesse;
14:11:19/She bore him children: Jeush, Shamariah, and Zaham.
14:11:20/After her, he married Maachah, daughter of Absalom, who bore him Abijah, Attai, Ziza, and Shelomith.
14:11:21/Rehoboam loved Maachah, daughter of Absalom, more than all his other wives and concubines. He had eighteen wives, sixty concubines, twenty-eight sons, and sixty daughters.
14:11:22/Rehoboam appointed Abijah, son of Maachah, as the chief among his brothers, intending to make him king.
14:11:23/He acted wisely, distributing his children throughout all the territories of Judah and Benjamin, to every fortified city, providing them with plenty of food. And he sought many wives.
14:12:1/When Rehoboam had solidified his rule and strengthened himself, he abandoned the LORD's laws, and all of Israel followed suit.
14:12:2/In the fifth year of King Rehoboam's reign, Shishak, the king of Egypt, attacked Jerusalem because they had violated the LORD's commands.
14:12:3/He came with twelve hundred chariots and sixty thousand horsemen, and the number of people with him from Egypt was beyond counting; this included the Lubims, the Sukkiims, and the Ethiopians.
14:12:4/He captured the fortified cities belonging to Judah and advanced to Jerusalem.
14:12:5/Then Shemaiah the prophet came to Rehoboam and the princes of Judah who had assembled in Jerusalem because of Shishak, and he told them, "This is what the LORD says: You have abandoned me, so I have left you in the hands of Shishak."
14:12:6/In response, the princes of Israel and the king humbled themselves and said, "The LORD is just."
14:12:7/When the LORD saw that they had humbled themselves, He sent this message through Shemaiah: "They have humbled themselves; therefore, I will not destroy them. I will give them some relief, and my anger will not be unleashed on Jerusalem through Shishak."
14:12:8/However, they will become his subjects, so they may learn the difference between serving me and serving the kingdoms of other lands.
14:12:9/So Shishak, the king of Egypt, attacked Jerusalem and took the treasures of the LORD's house and the royal palace. He took everything, including the gold shields Solomon had made.
14:12:10/In their place, King Rehoboam made bronze shields and assigned them to the commanders of the guard who protected the palace entrance.
14:12:11/Whenever the king went to the LORD's house, the guards would carry these shields, and afterward, they would return them to the guardroom.
14:12:12/When he humbled himself, the LORD's anger subsided, and He decided not to destroy him completely. Moreover, conditions in Judah improved.
14:12:13/So King Rehoboam consolidated his power in Jerusalem and continued to reign. Rehoboam was forty-one years old when he became king, and he ruled for seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city the LORD had chosen from all the tribes of Israel for His name to be honored. His mother was Naamah, an Ammonite.
14:12:14/He did wrong because he did not set his heart on seeking the LORD.
14:12:15/The events of Rehoboam's reign, from beginning to end, are recorded in the writings of Shemaiah the prophet and Iddo the seer, which include genealogies. And there were ongoing wars between Rehoboam and Jeroboam.
14:12:16/Rehoboam passed away and was buried in the City of David. His son Abijah succeeded him as king.
14:13:1/Now in the eighteenth year of King Jeroboam, Abijah began to rule over Judah.
14:13:2/He ruled for three years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Michaiah, the daughter of Uriel from Gibeah. And there was war between Abijah and Jeroboam.
14:13:3/Abijah prepared for battle with an army of valiant warriors, totaling four hundred thousand select men. Jeroboam also prepared for battle against him with eight hundred thousand select men, who were mighty warriors.
14:13:4/Abijah stood on Mount Zemaraim, which is in the Ephraim range, and said, "Listen to me, Jeroboam, and all of Israel;
14:13:5/Shouldn't you know that the LORD, the God of Israel, granted the kingdom over Israel to David forever, to him and his descendants through a perpetual covenant?
14:13:6/Yet Jeroboam, the son of Nebat and a servant of Solomon, son of David, has risen and rebelled against his master.
14:13:7/He has gathered worthless men, rebels, around him and has grown strong against Rehoboam, the son of Solomon, when Rehoboam was young and inexperienced and unable to stand up to them.
14:13:8/And now you think you can resist the kingdom of the LORD, which is in the hands of David's descendants. You are a vast multitude, and you have with you the golden calves that Jeroboam made as your gods.
14:13:9/Have you not expelled the LORD's priests, the descendants of Aaron, and the Levites, and appointed your own priests like the nations around you? Anyone who comes to consecrate himself with a young bull and seven rams can become a priest of what are not gods.
14:13:10/But as for us, the LORD is our God, and we have not abandoned Him. The priests serving the LORD are from Aaron's descendants, and the Levites attend to their duties.
14:13:11/They offer burnt sacrifices and fragrant incense to the LORD every morning and every evening. They also set the showbread in order on the pure table and light the gold lampstand with its lamps every evening. We are faithful to the LORD our God's commands, but you have abandoned Him.
14:13:12/Look, God Himself is with us as our leader, and His priests with their trumpets will sound the battle cry against you. Children of Israel, do not fight against the LORD, the God of your ancestors, for you will not succeed.
14:13:13/But Jeroboam set an ambush to attack them from behind. So they were in front of Judah, and the ambush was behind them.
14:13:14/When Judah turned and saw the battle was in front and behind, they cried out to the LORD, and the priests blew the trumpets.
14:13:15/Then the men of Judah gave a battle cry. As they shouted, God struck Jeroboam and all Israel before Abijah and Judah.
14:13:16/The Israelites fled before Judah, and God handed them over to Judah.
14:13:17/Abijah and his people inflicted a great defeat on them, killing five hundred thousand of Israel's select warriors.
14:13:18/So the Israelites were subdued at that time, and the people of Judah were victorious because they relied on the LORD, the God of their ancestors.
14:13:19/Abijah pursued Jeroboam and captured cities from him, including Bethel and its surrounding towns, Jeshanah with its towns, and Ephron with its towns.
14:13:20/Jeroboam did not regain power during the reign of Abijah. The LORD struck him down, and he died.
14:13:21/But Abijah grew powerful, married fourteen wives, and fathered twenty-two sons and sixteen daughters.
14:13:22/The rest of the events of Abijah's reign, his actions, and his words are recorded in the chronicles of the prophet Iddo.
14:14:1/So Abijah passed away and was buried in the city of David. Asa his son took over as king. During his reign, the land experienced peace for ten years.
14:14:2/And Asa did what was good and right in the eyes of the LORD his God.
14:14:3/For he removed the altars of foreign gods, the high places, destroyed the idols, and cut down the sacred groves.
14:14:4/And he instructed Judah to seek the LORD God of their ancestors, and to follow the law and the commandments.
14:14:5/He also removed from all the cities of Judah the high places and the idols, and the kingdom was at peace under his rule.
14:14:6/And he built fortified cities in Judah, for the land was at peace, and he faced no war in those years; because the LORD had given him rest.
14:14:7/Therefore, he said to Judah, "Let's build these cities, and surround them with walls, towers, gates, and bars, while the land is still ours; because we have sought the LORD our God, we have sought him, and he has given us peace on every side." So they built and prospered.
14:14:8/And Asa had an army of men equipped with shields and spears, from Judah three hundred thousand; and from Benjamin, those who carried shields and were archers, two hundred and eighty thousand: all these were valiant warriors.
14:14:9/And Zerah the Ethiopian came against them with an army of a million men and three hundred chariots; and he arrived at Mareshah.
14:14:10/Then Asa went out to meet him, and they arranged their forces in the valley of Zephathah at Mareshah.
14:14:11/And Asa called out to the LORD his God, saying, "LORD, it is easy for you to help, whether with many or with those who have no power. Help us, O LORD our God; for we rely on you, and in your name we face this vast army. O LORD, you are our God; do not let anyone defeat you."
14:14:12/So the LORD struck down the Ethiopians before Asa and Judah, and the Ethiopians fled.
14:14:13/And Asa and his forces pursued them to Gerar, and the Ethiopians were so thoroughly defeated that they could not recover; they were devastated before the LORD and his forces, and they took a great amount of loot.
14:14:14/And they attacked all the cities around Gerar, for the fear of the LORD fell upon them. They plundered all the cities, for there was a great deal of loot in them.
14:14:15/They also struck down the livestock encampments, and carried away sheep and camels in great numbers, and then returned to Jerusalem.
14:15:1/The Spirit of God came upon Azariah, the son of Oded.
14:15:2/He went out to meet Asa and said to him, "Listen to me, Asa, and all of Judah and Benjamin; The LORD is with you as long as you are with him; if you seek him, you will find him; but if you abandon him, he will abandon you."
14:15:3/For a long time, Israel has been without the true God, without a teaching priest, and without law.
14:15:4/But when they turned to the LORD God of Israel in their distress and sought him, he was found by them.
14:15:5/During those times, there was no peace for anyone going out or coming in, but great troubles were upon all the inhabitants of the lands.
14:15:6/Nation was destroyed by nation, and city by city, for God troubled them with all kinds of adversity.
14:15:7/So be strong and do not let your hands be weak, for your work will be rewarded.
14:15:8/When Asa heard these words and the prophecy of Oded the prophet, he took courage, removed the detestable idols from all the land of Judah and Benjamin and from the cities he had captured in the hill country of Ephraim, and restored the altar of the LORD that was in front of the portico of the LORD.
14:15:9/He gathered all Judah and Benjamin, along with the foreigners from Ephraim, Manasseh, and Simeon who had joined them, because they saw that the LORD his God was with him.
14:15:10/They assembled at Jerusalem in the third month of the fifteenth year of Asa's reign.
14:15:11/At that time, they sacrificed to the LORD from the plunder they had brought back, seven hundred oxen and seven thousand sheep.
14:15:12/They entered into a covenant to seek the LORD, the God of their ancestors, with all their heart and soul.
14:15:13/Anyone who would not seek the LORD, the God of Israel, was to be put to death, whether small or great, man or woman.
14:15:14/They swore an oath to the LORD with loud acclamation, with shouting, with trumpets, and with horns.
14:15:15/All Judah rejoiced about the oath because they had sworn it wholeheartedly. They sought him eagerly, and he was found by them. So the LORD gave them rest on every side.
14:15:16/Regarding Maachah, the mother of King Asa, he removed her from her position as queen mother because she had made a repulsive idol for Asherah. Asa cut down her idol, crushed it, and burned it in the Kidron Valley.
14:15:17/However, the high places were not removed from Israel, yet Asa's heart was fully committed all his days.
14:15:18/He brought into the house of God the items his father had dedicated and those he himself had dedicated—silver, gold, and vessels.
14:15:19/There was no more war until the thirty-fifth year of Asa's reign.
14:16:1/In the thirty-sixth year of Asa's reign, Baasha king of Israel attacked Judah and built Ramah, aiming to block anyone from going to or from Asa king of Judah.
14:16:2/Then Asa took silver and gold from the treasuries of the LORD's house and the royal palace, and sent it to Benhadad king of Syria, who lived in Damascus, saying,
14:16:3/"We have an alliance, just as our fathers did. Look, I'm sending you silver and gold; break your alliance with Baasha king of Israel so he will leave me alone."
14:16:4/And Benhadad listened to King Asa and sent his army commanders against the cities of Israel; they conquered Ijon, Dan, Abelmaim, and all the supply cities of Naphtali.
14:16:5/When Baasha heard about it, he stopped building Ramah and abandoned his work.
14:16:6/Then King Asa mobilized all of Judah, and they removed the stones and timber Baasha had used for building Ramah; with them, he built Geba and Mizpah.
14:16:7/At that time, Hanani the seer came to Asa king of Judah and told him, "Because you depended on the king of Syria instead of the LORD your God, the army of the king of Syria has escaped from you.
14:16:8/Weren't the Ethiopians and the Lubims a massive army with many chariots and horsemen? Yet, because you relied on the LORD, he handed them over to you.
14:16:9/The LORD's eyes scan the whole earth to strengthen those whose hearts are fully committed to him. You have acted foolishly in this matter. From now on, you will face wars."
14:16:10/Then Asa became furious with the seer and put him in prison because he was enraged over this. And at that time, Asa also oppressed some of the people.
14:16:11/Indeed, the events of Asa's reign, from beginning to end, are recorded in the book of the kings of Judah and Israel.
14:16:12/In the thirty-ninth year of his reign, Asa developed a severe foot disease. Yet even in his illness, he did not seek the LORD but turned to physicians.
14:16:13/And Asa passed away, joining his ancestors in death in the forty-first year of his reign.
14:16:14/They buried him in his own tomb, which he had carved out for himself in the city of David. They laid him on a bed filled with fragrances and various kinds of spices prepared by perfumers' skill, and they held a very great funeral pyre for him.
14:17:1/Jehoshaphat, his son, took over as king, strengthening his position against Israel.
14:17:2/He stationed troops in all the fortified cities of Judah and established military posts in the land of Judah and the cities of Ephraim that his father Asa had captured.
14:17:3/The LORD supported Jehoshaphat because he followed the early ways of his ancestor David and did not worship Baalim;
14:17:4/Instead, he sought the Lord God of his father, followed His commandments, and did not imitate the practices of Israel.
14:17:5/As a result, the LORD solidified his reign; all of Judah brought Jehoshaphat gifts, and he accumulated great wealth and honor.
14:17:6/He was deeply committed to the ways of the LORD and removed the pagan shrines and groves from Judah.
14:17:7/In the third year of his reign, he sent his officials, including Benhail, Obadiah, Zechariah, Nethaneel, and Michaiah, to teach in the cities of Judah.
14:17:8/He also sent Levites with them, namely Shemaiah, Nethaniah, Zebadiah, Asahel, Shemiramoth, Jehonathan, Adonijah, Tobijah, and Tobadonijah, along with the priests Elishama and Jehoram.
14:17:9/They taught throughout Judah, carrying the book of the law of the LORD with them, and educated the people in all the cities of Judah.
14:17:10/The fear of the LORD spread to all the neighboring kingdoms, so they did not wage war against Jehoshaphat.
14:17:11/Even some Philistines brought Jehoshaphat gifts and tribute silver; and the Arabians brought him flocks, seven thousand and seven hundred rams, and seven thousand and seven hundred goats.
14:17:12/Jehoshaphat's power grew immensely; he built fortresses and supply cities in Judah.
14:17:13/He was heavily involved in the affairs of the cities of Judah, and his army, composed of valiant warriors, was based in Jerusalem.
14:17:14/The military forces were organized by ancestral houses: From Judah, the commanders of thousands included Adnah the chief, who had three hundred thousand valiant warriors.
14:17:15/Next to him was Jehohanan the commander, with two hundred and eighty thousand men.
14:17:16/Following him was Amasiah, son of Zichri, who volunteered for the LORD, with two hundred thousand valiant warriors.
14:17:17/From Benjamin, Eliada, a valiant warrior, led two hundred thousand men armed with bows and shields.
14:17:18/Next to him was Jehozabad, with one hundred and eighty thousand men ready for war.
14:17:19/These forces served the king, in addition to those stationed in the fortified cities throughout Judah.
14:18:1/Jehoshaphat was very wealthy and honored, and he formed an alliance with Ahab.
14:18:2/After a few years, he visited Ahab in Samaria. Ahab slaughtered many sheep and oxen for him and the people with him, and convinced him to join him in attacking Ramothgilead.
14:18:3/Ahab, the king of Israel, asked Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, "Will you join me in attacking Ramothgilead?" Jehoshaphat replied, "I am with you, my people are your people; we will join you in battle."
14:18:4/Then Jehoshaphat suggested to the king of Israel, "Please seek the LORD's guidance today."
14:18:5/So the king of Israel brought together 400 prophets and asked them, "Should we go to war against Ramothgilead, or should I hold back?" They answered, "Go ahead, for God will give it into the king's hand."
14:18:6/But Jehoshaphat asked, "Isn't there a prophet of the LORD here we can inquire of?"
14:18:7/The king of Israel told Jehoshaphat, "There is one more man who could inquire of the LORD for us, but I dislike him because he never prophesies anything good about me, only bad—Micaiah, son of Imla." Jehoshaphat replied, "The king shouldn't say such things."
14:18:8/Then the king of Israel called an officer and said, "Bring Micaiah, son of Imla, quickly."
14:18:9/The king of Israel and Jehoshaphat, king of Judah, were sitting on their thrones, dressed in their royal robes, at the entrance of the gate of Samaria, with all the prophets prophesying before them.
14:18:10/Zedekiah, son of Chenaanah, made iron horns and declared, "This is what the LORD says: 'With these, you will gore the Syrians until they are destroyed.'"
14:18:11/All the prophets were predicting success, saying, "Attack Ramothgilead and be victorious, for the LORD will give it into the king's hand."
14:18:12/The messenger who had gone to summon Micaiah said to him, "Look, the other prophets are unanimously predicting success for the king. Please let your word be like theirs and speak favorably."
14:18:13/But Micaiah replied, "As surely as the LORD lives, I can only speak what my God tells me."
14:18:14/When he arrived, the king asked him, "Micaiah, should we go to war against Ramothgilead, or should I refrain?" He answered, "Go ahead, you will be successful, and they will be given into your hands."
14:18:15/But the king said to him, "How many times must I make you swear to tell me nothing but the truth in the name of the LORD?"
14:18:16/Then Micaiah said, "I saw all Israel scattered on the hills like sheep without a shepherd. And the LORD said, 'These people have no leader. Let them go home in peace.'"
14:18:17/Then the king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, "Didn't I tell you he never prophesies anything good about me, only bad?"
14:18:18/Again Micaiah said, "Listen to the word of the LORD: I saw the LORD sitting on his throne with all the armies of heaven standing by, on his right and on his left."
14:18:19/And the LORD said, "Who will entice Ahab king of Israel to attack Ramothgilead and fall there?" One suggested this, and another that.
14:18:20/Then a spirit came forward, stood before the LORD, and said, "I will entice him." "How?" asked the LORD.
14:18:21/The spirit replied, "I will go and be a lying spirit in the mouths of all his prophets." And the LORD said, "You will succeed in enticing him. Go and do it."
14:18:22/So now, the LORD has put a lying spirit in the mouths of these prophets of yours, and the LORD has decreed disaster for you.
14:18:23/Then Zedekiah, son of Chenaanah, approached, struck Micaiah on the cheek, and asked, "How did the Spirit of the LORD go from me to speak to you?"
14:18:24/Micaiah replied, "You will find out on the day you go into an inner room to hide."
14:18:25/Then the king of Israel ordered, "Take Micaiah back to Amon, the governor of the city, and to Joash, the king's son,
14:18:26/and say, 'This is what the king says: Put this man in prison and feed him only bread and water until I return safely.'"
14:18:27/Micaiah declared, "If you ever return safely, the LORD has not spoken through me. Listen, everyone!"
14:18:28/So the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat, king of Judah, went up to Ramothgilead.
14:18:29/The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, "I will disguise myself and go into the battle, but you wear your royal robes." So the king of Israel disguised himself, and they went into battle.
14:18:30/The king of Syria had ordered his chariot commanders, "Do not fight with anyone, small or great, except the king of Israel."
14:18:31/When the chariot commanders saw Jehoshaphat, they thought, "Surely this is the king of Israel," and they turned to attack him. But Jehoshaphat cried out, and the LORD helped him; God drew them away from him.
14:18:32/As soon as the chariot commanders realized he was not the king of Israel, they stopped pursuing him.
14:18:33/Then a random arrow shot by an archer struck the king of Israel between the sections of his armor. So he said to his charioteer, "Turn around and get me out of the battle; I've been wounded."
14:18:34/The battle intensified throughout the day, and the king of Israel was propped up in his chariot facing the Syrians until evening. As the sun set, he died.
14:19:1/And Jehoshaphat the king of Judah returned to his house in peace to Jerusalem.
14:19:2/And Jehu the son of Hanani the seer went out to meet him, and said to king Jehoshaphat, "Should you help the wicked and love those who hate the LORD? Because of this, the LORD's wrath is upon you."
14:19:3/Nevertheless, you have done good things, such as removing the pagan shrines from the land and setting your heart on seeking God.
14:19:4/And Jehoshaphat stayed in Jerusalem. He went out again among the people from Beersheba to mount Ephraim and led them back to the LORD God of their ancestors.
14:19:5/And he appointed judges throughout all the fortified cities of Judah, in each city,
14:19:6/And said to the judges, "Be careful in what you do, for you are not judging for humans, but for the LORD, who is with you in making decisions."
14:19:7/Therefore, let the fear of the LORD be upon you; be careful and do it, for there is no injustice with the LORD our God, nor favoritism, nor accepting bribes.
14:19:8/Furthermore, in Jerusalem, Jehoshaphat appointed Levites, priests, and leading family heads of Israel for the LORD's judgment and to settle disputes when they returned to Jerusalem.
14:19:9/And he instructed them, saying, "Do this in the fear of the LORD, faithfully and with a whole heart."
14:19:10/And whatever case comes to you from your fellow citizens living in your cities, whether it concerns bloodshed or law and commandment, statutes and judgments, you must warn them so they do not sin against the LORD and his wrath come upon you and your kin. Do this, and you will not be guilty.
14:19:11/And, behold, Amariah the chief priest is over you in all matters of the LORD; and Zebadiah the son of Ishmael, the ruler of the house of Judah, for all the king’s matters: also the Levites shall be officers before you. Act courageously, and the LORD will be with those who do good.
14:20:1/After this, the Moabites, the Ammonites, and others with them came to fight against Jehoshaphat.
14:20:2/Some people came and told Jehoshaphat, "A huge army is coming against you from the other side of the sea, from Syria; they are in Hazazontamar, which is Engedi."
14:20:3/Jehoshaphat was afraid and decided to seek the LORD. He proclaimed a fast throughout all of Judah.
14:20:4/The people of Judah came together to seek help from the LORD; from every town in Judah they came to seek the LORD.
14:20:5/Jehoshaphat stood in the assembly of Judah and Jerusalem, in the house of the LORD, before the new courtyard,
14:20:6/And said, "O LORD, God of our ancestors, aren't you the God in heaven? You rule over all the kingdoms of the nations. Power and might are in your hand, and no one can withstand you.
14:20:7/Aren't you our God, who drove out the inhabitants of this land before your people Israel and gave it forever to the descendants of Abraham your friend?
14:20:8/They have lived in it and have built a sanctuary for your name, saying,
14:20:9/'If disaster comes upon us, whether the sword of judgment, or plague or famine, we will stand in your presence before this temple that bears your Name and will cry out to you in our distress, and you will hear us and save us.'
14:20:10/Now here are the Ammonites, Moabites, and people from Mount Seir, whose territory you did not allow Israel to invade when they came from Egypt, so they turned away from them and did not destroy them.
14:20:11/See how they are repaying us by coming to drive us out of the possession you gave us as an inheritance.
14:20:12/O our God, will you not judge them? For we have no power to face this vast army that is attacking us. We do not know what to do, but our eyes are on you."
14:20:13/All the men of Judah, with their wives and children and little ones, stood there before the LORD.
14:20:14/Then the Spirit of the LORD came on Jahaziel son of Zechariah, the son of Benaiah, the son of Jeiel, the son of Mattaniah, a Levite and descendant of Asaph, as he stood in the assembly.
14:20:15/He said: "Listen, King Jehoshaphat and all who live in Judah and Jerusalem! This is what the LORD says to you: 'Do not be afraid or discouraged because of this vast army. For the battle is not yours, but God's.
14:20:16/Tomorrow march down against them. They will be climbing up by the Pass of Ziz, and you will find them at the end of the gorge in the Desert of Jeruel.
14:20:17/You will not have to fight this battle. Take up your positions; stand firm and see the deliverance the LORD will give you, Judah and Jerusalem. Do not be afraid; do not be discouraged. Go out to face them tomorrow, and the LORD will be with you.'"
14:20:18/Jehoshaphat bowed down with his face to the ground, and all the people of Judah and Jerusalem fell down in worship before the LORD.
14:20:19/Then the Levites from the Kohathites and Korahites stood up and praised the LORD, the God of Israel, with a very loud voice.
14:20:20/Early in the morning they left for the Desert of Tekoa. As they set out, Jehoshaphat stood and said, "Listen to me, Judah and people of Jerusalem! Have faith in the LORD your God and you will be upheld; have faith in his prophets and you will be successful."
14:20:21/After consulting the people, Jehoshaphat appointed men to sing to the LORD and to praise him for the splendor of his holiness as they went out at the head of the army, saying: "Give thanks to the LORD, for his love endures forever."
14:20:22/As they began to sing and praise, the LORD set ambushes against the men of Ammon and Moab and Mount Seir who were invading Judah, and they were defeated.
14:20:23/The Ammonites and Moabites rose up against the men from Mount Seir to destroy and annihilate them. After they finished slaughtering the men from Seir, they helped to destroy one another.
14:20:24/When the men of Judah came to the place that overlooks the desert and looked toward the vast army, they saw only dead bodies lying on the ground; no one had escaped.
14:20:25/When Jehoshaphat and his people came to take their spoil, they found among them a great amount of equipment and clothing and also articles of value—more than they could take away. There was so much plunder that it took three days to collect it.
14:20:26/On the fourth day they assembled in the Valley of Berakah, where they praised the LORD. That is why it is called the Valley of Berakah to this day.
14:20:27/Then, led by Jehoshaphat, all the men of Judah and Jerusalem returned joyfully to Jerusalem, for the LORD had made them rejoice over their enemies.
14:20:28/They entered Jerusalem and went to the temple of the LORD with harps and lyres and trumpets.
14:20:29/The fear of God came on all the surrounding kingdoms when they heard how the LORD had fought against the enemies of Israel.
14:20:30/And the kingdom of Jehoshaphat was at peace, for his God had given him rest on every side.
14:20:31/Jehoshaphat reigned over Judah. He was thirty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for twenty-five years. His mother's name was Azubah daughter of Shilhi.
14:20:32/He followed the ways of his father Asa and did not stray from them; he did what was right in the eyes of the LORD.
14:20:33/However, the high places were not removed; the people had not yet set their hearts on the God of their ancestors.
14:20:34/The other events of Jehoshaphat's reign, from beginning to end, are written in the annals of Jehu son of Hanani, which are recorded in the book of the kings of Israel.
14:20:35/Later, Jehoshaphat king of Judah made an alliance with Ahaziah king of Israel, who was guilty of wickedness.
14:20:36/He agreed with him to construct a fleet of trading ships. After these were built at Ezion Geber,
14:20:37/Eliezer son of Dodavahu of Mareshah prophesied against Jehoshaphat, saying, "Because you have allied yourself with Ahaziah, the LORD will destroy what you have made." And the ships were wrecked and were not able to sail to Tarshish.
14:21:1/Jehoshaphat passed away and was buried with his ancestors in the city of David. Jehoram, his son, took over as king.
14:21:2/He had brothers, the sons of Jehoshaphat: Azariah, Jehiel, Zechariah, Azariah, Michael, and Shephatiah. All these were sons of Jehoshaphat, the king of Israel.
14:21:3/Their father gave them generous gifts of silver, gold, and valuable items, along with fortified cities in Judah. However, he gave the kingdom to Jehoram because he was the eldest.
14:21:4/Once Jehoram became king, he secured his position by killing all his brothers and several of Israel's princes.
14:21:5/Jehoram was thirty-two years old when he began to reign, and he ruled for eight years in Jerusalem.
14:21:6/He followed the practices of the kings of Israel, just as the house of Ahab had done, because he was married to Ahab's daughter. He did evil in the sight of the LORD.
14:21:7/However, the LORD did not want to destroy the house of David because of the covenant he had made with David. He had promised to maintain a lamp for him and his descendants forever.
14:21:8/During his reign, the Edomites rebelled against Judah's control and appointed their own king.
14:21:9/Jehoram attacked with his princes and all his chariots. He launched a surprise attack at night and defeated the Edomites who had surrounded him, along with their chariot commanders.
14:21:10/So, the Edomites broke free from Judah's control and remain independent to this day. At the same time, Libnah also rebelled because Jehoram had abandoned the LORD, the God of his ancestors.
14:21:11/He also built pagan shrines in the hills of Judah and led the people of Jerusalem and Judah into idolatry.
14:21:12/Elijah the prophet sent him a letter that said, "This is what the LORD, the God of your ancestor David, says: Because you have not followed the paths of your father Jehoshaphat or Asa, king of Judah,
14:21:13/But have walked in the ways of the kings of Israel, leading Judah and the people of Jerusalem into idolatry, just as the house of Ahab did, and because you have killed your brothers, your own family, who were better than you,
14:21:14/The LORD will strike your people, your children, your wives, and all your possessions with a severe plague.
14:21:15/And you will suffer a severe illness, a disease of your intestines, until your intestines come out because of the sickness, day by day."
14:21:16/The LORD incited the Philistines and the Arabs who lived near the Ethiopians to attack Jehoram.
14:21:17/They invaded Judah, broke into it, and took all the possessions found in the king's palace, along with his sons and wives. Only Jehoahaz, his youngest son, was left.
14:21:18/After all this, the LORD afflicted him with an incurable disease in his intestines.
14:21:19/Eventually, after two years, his intestines came out because of the illness, and he died in great pain. His people did not make a funeral fire in his honor, as they had for his ancestors.
14:21:20/He was thirty-two years old when he became king and reigned in Jerusalem for eight years. He died to no one's regret and was buried in the city of David, but not in the tombs of the kings.
14:22:1/The people of Jerusalem made Ahaziah, his youngest son, king in his place because a group of men who came with the Arabians to the camp had killed all his older siblings. So Ahaziah, the son of Jehoram king of Judah, took the throne.
14:22:2/Ahaziah was forty-two years old when he became king, and he ruled for one year in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Athaliah, the daughter of Omri.
14:22:3/He followed the ways of the house of Ahab because his mother advised him to do evil.
14:22:4/Therefore, he did what was evil in the LORD's eyes, just like the house of Ahab, because they advised him after his father's death, leading to his downfall.
14:22:5/He also followed their advice and joined Jehoram, the son of Ahab king of Israel, in battle against Hazael king of Syria at Ramothgilead, where the Syrians defeated Joram.
14:22:6/He returned to be healed in Jezreel from the injuries he received at Ramah during the battle with Hazael king of Syria. And Azariah, the son of Jehoram king of Judah, went down to see Jehoram, the son of Ahab at Jezreel, because he was ill.
14:22:7/Ahaziah's downfall was orchestrated by God when he visited Joram. Upon his arrival, he joined Jehoram in battle against Jehu, the son of Nimshi, whom the LORD had anointed to eliminate the house of Ahab.
14:22:8/When Jehu was carrying out judgment on the house of Ahab and found the princes of Judah and the sons of Ahaziah's brothers who served Ahaziah, he killed them.
14:22:9/They searched for Ahaziah, and after capturing him (he was hiding in Samaria), they brought him to Jehu. After killing him, they buried him because they said, "He is the son of Jehoshaphat, who sought the LORD with all his heart." Thus, the house of Ahaziah was unable to retain the kingdom.
14:22:10/But when Athaliah, Ahaziah's mother, saw that her son was dead, she rose up and destroyed all the royal family of the house of Judah.
14:22:11/However, Jehoshabeath, the king's daughter, took Joash, the son of Ahaziah, and rescued him from among the king's sons who were being killed. She placed him and his nurse in a bedroom. Thus, Jehoshabeath, the daughter of King Jehoram and wife of Jehoiada the priest (since she was Ahaziah's sister), hid him from Athaliah so she did not kill him.
14:22:12/He was hidden with them in the house of God for six years while Athaliah ruled over the land.
14:23:1/In the seventh year, Jehoiada gained strength and formed an alliance with the captains of hundreds: Azariah son of Jeroham, Ishmael son of Jehohanan, Azariah son of Obed, Maaseiah son of Adaiah, and Elishaphat son of Zichri.
14:23:2/They traveled throughout Judah, gathering the Levites from all the cities of Judah, and the leaders of the families of Israel, and they went to Jerusalem.
14:23:3/The entire assembly made a covenant with the king in the temple of God. He told them, "The king's son will reign, as the LORD has promised concerning the descendants of David."
14:23:4/Here's what you need to do: A third of you, including the priests and Levites, who come on the Sabbath, will guard the doors;
14:23:5/Another third will be at the royal palace; and the last third at the Foundation Gate. All the other people will be in the courtyards of the temple of the LORD.
14:23:6/But no one except the priests and serving Levites may enter the temple of the LORD, for they are holy. All the other people must observe the LORD's command.
14:23:7/The Levites will surround the king, each with his weapons in hand; anyone else who enters the temple will be put to death. Stay close to the king, whether he's coming or going.
14:23:8/So the Levites and all of Judah did everything Jehoiada the priest had ordered. They took their positions, both those coming in and those going out on the Sabbath, as Jehoiada the priest had not dismissed any of their groups.
14:23:9/Jehoiada the priest also gave the captains of hundreds spears, shields, and body armor that had belonged to King David and were stored in the temple of God.
