14:23:10/He positioned all the people, each holding a weapon, from the south side to the north side of the temple, around the altar and the temple, to protect the king on all sides.
14:23:11/Then they brought out the king's son, crowned him, presented him with the decree, and proclaimed him king. Jehoiada and his sons anointed him and declared, "Long live the king!"
14:23:12/When Athaliah heard the noise of the people running and praising the king, she joined them at the temple of the LORD.
14:23:13/She saw the king standing by his column at the entrance, with the officers and trumpeters beside the king, and all the people of the land rejoicing and blowing trumpets, while musicians with their instruments led the celebration. Athaliah tore her robes and shouted, "Treason! Treason!"
14:23:14/Jehoiada the priest then brought out the commanders of units of a hundred, who were in charge of the troops, and said to them, "Take her outside the temple grounds, and anyone who follows her, kill with the sword." For the priest had said, "Do not put her to death in the temple of the LORD."
14:23:15/So they seized her, and when she reached the entrance of the Horse Gate on the palace grounds, they killed her there.
14:23:16/Jehoiada then made a covenant between himself, all the people, and the king, that they would be the LORD's people.
14:23:17/After that, all the people went to the temple of Baal and demolished it. They smashed his altars and images to pieces and killed Mattan, the priest of Baal, in front of the altars.
14:23:18/Jehoiada also assigned the responsibilities of the temple of the LORD to the priests and Levites, whom David had organized to offer the burnt offerings to the LORD, as prescribed in the Law of Moses, with joy and singing, according to David's instructions.
14:23:19/He stationed gatekeepers at the gates of the temple of the LORD so that no one who was in any way unclean might enter.
14:23:20/He then took the commanders of hundreds, the nobility, the rulers of the people, and all the people of the land, and led the king down from the temple of the LORD. They entered the royal palace through the Upper Gate and seated the king on the royal throne.
14:23:21/All the people of the land rejoiced, and the city was peaceful after they had killed Athaliah with the sword.
14:24:1/Joash was seven years old when he began to reign, and he reigned forty years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name also was Zibiah of Beersheba.
14:24:2/Joash did what was right in the eyes of the LORD throughout the time Jehoiada the priest was alive.
14:24:3/Jehoiada found him two wives, and he had sons and daughters.
14:24:4/Afterward, Joash decided to restore the temple of the LORD.
14:24:5/He assembled the priests and Levites and told them, "Go out to the towns of Judah and collect money from all Israel to repair your God's temple annually. Make sure you do this quickly." However, the Levites did not act promptly.
14:24:6/The king summoned Jehoiada the chief priest and asked, "Why haven't you demanded the Levites to bring in the tax from Judah and Jerusalem as instructed by Moses, the servant of the LORD, and as required by the assembly of Israel for the tent of the testimony?"
14:24:7/For the sons of Athaliah, that wicked woman, had damaged the temple of God; and they had also used all the sacred objects of the temple of the LORD for the Baals.
14:24:8/Upon the king's order, they made a chest and placed it outside at the entrance of the temple of the LORD.
14:24:9/They issued a proclamation throughout Judah and Jerusalem to bring to the LORD the tax that Moses, the servant of God, had imposed on Israel in the wilderness.
14:24:10/All the leaders and the people were glad, and they brought their contributions and dropped them into the chest until it was full.
14:24:11/Whenever the chest was brought to the royal officials by the Levites and they saw there was a large amount of money, the king's secretary and the high priest's officer would come, empty the chest, and then return it to its place. This happened regularly, and they collected a great deal of money.
14:24:12/The king and Jehoiada allocated the funds to those doing the work on the temple of the LORD. They hired masons and carpenters to restore the temple of the LORD, as well as workers in iron and bronze to repair the temple.
14:24:13/The workers labored, and the restoration work progressed under their hands. They restored God's temple to its original condition and strengthened it.
14:24:14/When the work was completed, they presented the remaining money to the king and Jehoiada, which was used to make articles for the temple of the LORD—articles for service and for burnt offerings, including pans and other gold and silver items. Burnt offerings were made in the temple of the LORD continuously throughout Jehoiada's lifetime.
14:24:15/But Jehoiada grew old and died full of years; he was one hundred and thirty years old at his death.
14:24:16/They buried him in the City of David among the kings because of the good he had done in Israel for God and His temple.
14:24:17/After Jehoiada's death, the leaders of Judah came and paid homage to the king, and the king listened to them.
14:24:18/They abandoned the temple of the LORD, the God of their ancestors, and worshiped Asherah poles and idols. Because of their guilt, God's anger came on Judah and Jerusalem.
14:24:19/Yet God sent prophets to them to bring them back to Him; the prophets testified against them, but they would not listen.
14:24:20/The Spirit of God came upon Zechariah, son of Jehoiada the priest. He stood before the people and said, "This is what God says: 'Why do you disobey the LORD's commands? You will not prosper. Because you have forsaken the LORD, He has also forsaken you.'"
14:24:21/But they conspired against him and stoned him to death by the king's command in the courtyard of the LORD's temple.
14:24:22/Joash the king did not remember the kindness Jehoiada, Zechariah's father, had shown him but killed his son. As Zechariah died, he said, "May the LORD see this and call you to account."
14:24:23/At the end of the year, the army of Aram attacked. They came to Judah and Jerusalem, destroyed all the leaders of the people, and sent all the plunder to the king of Damascus.
14:24:24/Although the Aramean army came with only a few men, the LORD delivered a very large army into their hands because the people of Judah had forsaken the LORD, the God of their ancestors. Thus, they executed judgment on Joash.
14:24:25/After they had left him (for they left him severely wounded), his own officials conspired against him because of the murder of the son of Jehoiada the priest, and they killed him on his bed. So he died and was not buried in the tombs of the kings.
14:24:26/Those who conspired against him were Zabad, son of Shimeath the Ammonite, and Jehozabad, son of Shimrith the Moabite.
14:24:27/Regarding his sons, the many prophecies about him, and the restoration of the temple of God, these are recorded in the commentary on the book of the kings. And his son Amaziah succeeded him as king.
14:25:1/Amaziah was twenty-five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned twenty-nine years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Jehoaddan of Jerusalem.
14:25:2/He did what was right in the eyes of the LORD, but his heart wasn't fully committed.
14:25:3/Once his rule was established, he executed the servants who had murdered his father, the king.
14:25:4/However, he did not kill their children, following the law in the book of Moses, as the LORD commanded: "Parents shall not be put to death for their children, nor children for their parents; each person shall die for their own sin."
14:25:5/Amaziah also organized Judah, appointing leaders over thousands and hundreds according to their families, throughout all Judah and Benjamin. He counted those twenty years old and above, finding three hundred thousand select troops ready for battle, skilled with spear and shield.
14:25:6/He also hired one hundred thousand experienced warriors from Israel for one hundred talents of silver.
14:25:7/But a man of God came to him and said, "King, do not let the Israelite army join you, for the LORD is not with Israel, especially not with the people of Ephraim."
14:25:8/"If you go ahead and fight, be strong for battle, but God will let you fall before the enemy. God has the power to help or to overthrow."
14:25:9/Amaziah asked the man of God, "But what about the hundred talents I paid for the Israelite troops?" The man of God replied, "The LORD can give you much more than that."
14:25:10/So Amaziah dismissed the troops from Ephraim to go home, which made them very angry with Judah and they left in a rage.
14:25:11/Amaziah then courageously led his people to the Valley of Salt, where he defeated ten thousand men of Seir.
14:25:12/He also captured another ten thousand alive, took them to the top of a cliff, and threw them off, breaking them to pieces.
14:25:13/Meanwhile, the troops Amaziah had sent away, refusing them to join the battle, attacked cities in Judah from Samaria to Beth Horon, killing three thousand people and taking a lot of plunder.
14:25:14/After defeating the Edomites, Amaziah brought back the gods of the people of Seir, set them up as his own gods, worshiped them, and burned incense to them.
14:25:15/This angered the LORD, and He sent a prophet to Amaziah, who asked, "Why are you worshiping these gods that couldn't even save their own people from you?"
14:25:16/While the prophet was speaking, the king interrupted, "Did we appoint you as an advisor to the king? Stop, or you might get hurt." But the prophet stopped and said, "I know God has decided to destroy you because you've done this and haven't listened to my advice."
14:25:17/Then Amaziah, king of Judah, took advice and sent a challenge to Joash, the son of Jehoahaz, the son of Jehu, king of Israel, saying, "Let's meet face to face."
14:25:18/Joash, king of Israel, replied to Amaziah, king of Judah, with a parable: "A thistle in Lebanon sent a message to a cedar in Lebanon, 'Give your daughter to my son in marriage.' Then a wild animal in Lebanon walked over the thistle and crushed it.
14:25:19/You're saying, 'Look, I've defeated Edom,' and now you're arrogant. Stay at home! Why provoke trouble that will only bring you and Judah down?"
14:25:20/But Amaziah wouldn't listen; it was God's will to hand them over to their enemies because they had sought the gods of Edom.
14:25:21/So Joash, king of Israel, advanced, and he and Amaziah, king of Judah, faced off at Beth Shemesh, which belongs to Judah.
14:25:22/And Judah was defeated by Israel; everyone fled to their homes.
14:25:23/Joash, king of Israel, captured Amaziah, king of Judah, at Beth Shemesh, then brought him to Jerusalem and broke down a section of Jerusalem's wall, from the Ephraim Gate to the Corner Gate—a distance of four hundred cubits.
14:25:24/He took all the gold and silver, all the vessels found in the house of God with Obed-Edom, the treasures of the royal palace, and hostages, then returned to Samaria.
14:25:25/Amaziah, son of Joash, king of Judah, lived fifteen years after the death of Joash, son of Jehoahaz, king of Israel.
14:25:26/The rest of the events of Amaziah's reign, from beginning to end, are recorded in the Book of the Kings of Judah and Israel.
14:25:27/After Amaziah turned away from following the LORD, they conspired against him in Jerusalem. He fled to Lachish, but they sent assassins after him and killed him there.
14:25:28/They transported his body on horses and buried him with his ancestors in the city of Judah.
14:26:1/Then all the people of Judah took Uzziah, who was sixteen years old, and made him king in place of his father Amaziah.
14:26:2/He rebuilt Eloth and returned it to Judah, after the king passed away.
14:26:3/Uzziah was sixteen when he began to reign, and he ruled for fifty-two years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Jecoliah of Jerusalem.
14:26:4/And he did what was right in the eyes of the LORD, following everything his father Amaziah had done.
14:26:5/He sought God during the days of Zechariah, who had insight into the visions of God: and as long as he sought the LORD, God made him prosper.
14:26:6/He went out and fought against the Philistines, destroying the walls of Gath, Jabneh, and Ashdod, and built cities around Ashdod and in Philistine territory.
14:26:7/And God supported him against the Philistines, the Arabians living in Gurbaal, and the Mehunims.
14:26:8/The Ammonites paid tribute to Uzziah: and his fame spread even to Egypt; for he became extremely powerful.
14:26:9/Furthermore, Uzziah built towers in Jerusalem at the corner gate, the valley gate, and at the turning of the wall, and strengthened them.
14:26:10/He also constructed towers in the desert and dug many wells, because he had a lot of livestock in the lowlands and on the plains. He had farmers and vine growers in the hills and in Carmel, for he loved agriculture.
14:26:11/Moreover, Uzziah had an army of warriors who went out to battle in groups, according to their count by Jeiel the scribe and Maaseiah the officer, under the command of Hananiah, one of the king's chiefs.
14:26:12/The total number of family heads among the valiant warriors was two thousand six hundred.
14:26:13/And under their command was an army of three hundred thousand seven thousand and five hundred, who fought with great power to support the king against the enemy.
14:26:14/And Uzziah supplied the entire army with shields, spears, helmets, body armor, bows, and slings for throwing stones.
14:26:15/He also created in Jerusalem machines designed by skilled inventors to be placed on the towers and the corners for shooting arrows and large stones. And his fame spread widely; for he was incredibly helped until he became powerful.
14:26:16/But when he became powerful, his pride led to his downfall: he sinned against the LORD his God by entering the temple of the LORD to burn incense on the altar of incense.
14:26:17/And Azariah the priest followed him in, along with eighty other courageous priests of the LORD.
14:26:18/They confronted King Uzziah and said to him, "It's not your role, Uzziah, to burn incense to the LORD, but that of the priests, the descendants of Aaron, who are consecrated for this purpose. Leave the sanctuary, for you have trespassed, and this will not bring you honor from the LORD God."
14:26:19/Then Uzziah became angry, and while he was arguing with the priests, leprosy broke out on his forehead in the presence of the priests in the temple of the LORD, beside the incense altar.
14:26:20/And Azariah the chief priest and all the priests looked at him, and there he was, leprous on his forehead. They hurriedly expelled him from there, and he himself rushed to leave because the LORD had struck him.
14:26:21/And King Uzziah was a leper until the day of his death, living in isolation, for he was excluded from the house of the LORD. And Jotham his son took charge of the palace and governed the people of the land.
14:26:22/The rest of the events of Uzziah's reign, from beginning to end, were recorded by the prophet Isaiah, son of Amoz.
14:26:23/So Uzziah rested with his ancestors, and they buried him with his ancestors in the burial field that belonged to the kings; for they said, "He is a leper." And Jotham his son succeeded him as king.
14:27:1/Jotham was twenty-five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned sixteen years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name also was Jerushah, the daughter of Zadok.
14:27:2/And he did what was right in the eyes of the LORD, following all the practices of his father Uzziah, except he did not enter the temple of the LORD. Yet the people continued in their corrupt ways.
14:27:3/He built the upper gate of the temple of the LORD, and he constructed extensively on the wall of Ophel.
14:27:4/Moreover, he built cities in the mountains of Judah, and in the forests he constructed fortresses and watchtowers.
14:27:5/He also fought against the king of the Ammonites and defeated them. The Ammonites paid him that year one hundred talents of silver, ten thousand measures of wheat, and ten thousand of barley. This tribute was paid to him in the second and third year as well.
14:27:6/So Jotham became powerful because he ordered his ways before the LORD his God.
14:27:7/Now the rest of the acts of Jotham, including all his wars and his deeds, are recorded in the book of the kings of Israel and Judah.
14:27:8/He was twenty-five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned sixteen years in Jerusalem.
14:27:9/And Jotham rested with his ancestors, and they buried him in the city of David. Ahaz his son succeeded him as king.
14:28:1/Ahaz was twenty years old when he began to reign, and he reigned sixteen years in Jerusalem: but he did not do what was right in the eyes of the LORD, unlike his ancestor David.
14:28:2/For he followed the practices of the kings of Israel and also made metal idols for Baal.
14:28:3/Moreover, he burned incense in the Valley of Ben Hinnom and sacrificed his children in the fire, following the detestable practices of the nations the LORD had driven out before the Israelites.
14:28:4/He also offered sacrifices and burned incense on the high places, on the hills, and under every green tree.
14:28:5/Therefore, the LORD his God handed him over to the king of Aram, who defeated him and took many of his people as prisoners, bringing them to Damascus. He was also handed over to the king of Israel, who inflicted a great defeat on him.
14:28:6/For Pekah the son of Remaliah killed 120,000 in Judah in one day, all of them valiant warriors, because they had abandoned the LORD, the God of their ancestors.
14:28:7/And Zichri, a mighty warrior from Ephraim, killed Maaseiah the king's son, Azrikam the palace administrator, and Elkanah, second to the king.
14:28:8/The Israelites took 200,000 of their fellow Israelites captive, including women, sons, and daughters. They also took a great deal of plunder, which they brought back to Samaria.
14:28:9/But a prophet of the LORD named Oded was there, and he went out to meet the army returning to Samaria and said to them, "Look, because the LORD, the God of your ancestors, was angry with Judah, he gave them into your hands. But you have killed them in a rage that reaches to heaven.
14:28:10/And now you intend to subjugate the people of Judah and Jerusalem as male and female slaves. But aren't you also guilty of sins against the LORD your God?
14:28:11/Now listen to me and send back the captives you have taken from your fellow Israelites, for the LORD's fierce anger is upon you."
14:28:12/Then some of the leaders in Ephraim—Azariah son of Johanan, Berechiah son of Meshillemoth, Jehizkiah son of Shallum, and Amasa son of Hadlai—confronted those returning from the battle.
14:28:13/And said to them, "You must not bring the captives here, for we already have sinned against the LORD. You intend to add to our sins and to our guilt. For our guilt is already great, and there is fierce anger against Israel."
14:28:14/So the soldiers gave up the captives and the plunder in the presence of the officials and all the assembly.
14:28:15/The men designated by name took the captives, and from the plunder they clothed all who were naked. They provided them with clothes and sandals, food and drink, and healing balm. All those who were weak they put on donkeys. So they took them back to their fellow Israelites at Jericho, the City of Palms, and then returned to Samaria.
14:28:16/At that time, King Ahaz sent to the kings of Assyria for help.
14:28:17/For the Edomites had come again, attacked Judah, and taken captives.
14:28:18/The Philistines also had raided towns in the foothills and the Negev of Judah, capturing Beth Shemesh, Aijalon, Gederoth, Soco with its villages, Timnah with its villages, and Gimzo with its villages, and they settled there.
14:28:19/For the LORD humbled Judah because of Ahaz king of Israel, for he had encouraged moral decline in Judah and had been most unfaithful to the LORD.
14:28:20/Tilgath-Pilneser king of Assyria came to him, but he troubled him rather than strengthening him.
14:28:21/For Ahaz took a portion from the temple of the LORD and from the royal palace and from the officials and gave it to the king of Assyria, but it did not help him.
14:28:22/In his time of trouble King Ahaz became even more unfaithful to the LORD.
14:28:23/He offered sacrifices to the gods of Damascus who had defeated him, for he thought, "Since the gods of the kings of Aram have helped them, I will sacrifice to them so they will help me." But they were his downfall and the downfall of all Israel.
14:28:24/Ahaz collected the furnishings from the temple of God, cut them in pieces, shut the doors of the LORD's temple, and set up altars at every street corner in Jerusalem.
14:28:25/In every town in Judah he built high places to burn incense to other gods, and provoked the LORD, the God of his ancestors, to anger.
14:28:26/Now the rest of his acts and all his ways, from beginning to end, are written in the book of the kings of Judah and Israel.
14:28:27/And Ahaz rested with his ancestors and was buried in the city, in Jerusalem, but he was not placed in the tombs of the kings of Israel. And Hezekiah his son succeeded him as king.
14:29:1/Hezekiah began to reign when he was twenty-five years old, and he reigned twenty-nine years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Abijah, the daughter of Zechariah.
14:29:2/He did what was right in the eyes of the LORD, following everything his ancestor David had done.
14:29:3/In the first year of his reign, in the first month, he opened the doors of the LORD's temple and repaired them.
14:29:4/He brought in the priests and the Levites and assembled them in the eastern square,
14:29:5/And said to them, "Listen to me, Levites. Purify yourselves now and purify the temple of the LORD, the God of your ancestors, and remove all the impurities from the sanctuary.
14:29:6/Our ancestors trespassed and did what was evil in the sight of the LORD our God. They abandoned Him, turned their backs on the LORD's dwelling place, and turned away.
14:29:7/They also closed the doors of the vestibule, extinguished the lamps, and stopped offering incense and presenting burnt offerings in the sanctuary to the God of Israel.
14:29:8/Therefore, the LORD's anger has been upon Judah and Jerusalem, and He has made them an object of dismay, astonishment, and ridicule, as you can see with your own eyes.
14:29:9/Indeed, our fathers fell by the sword, and our sons, daughters, and wives have been taken captive because of this.
14:29:10/Now, I intend to make a covenant with the LORD, the God of Israel, so that His fierce anger may turn away from us.
14:29:11/My sons, do not be negligent now, for the LORD has chosen you to stand in His presence, to serve Him, and to be His ministers and burn incense."
14:29:12/Then the Levites got up, Mahath the son of Amasai, and Joel the son of Azariah, from the Kohathites; from the Merarites, Kish the son of Abdi, and Azariah the son of Jehalelel; from the Gershonites, Joah the son of Zimmah, and Eden the son of Joah;
14:29:13/From the sons of Elizaphan, Shimri and Jeiel; from the sons of Asaph, Zechariah and Mattaniah;
14:29:14/From the sons of Heman, Jehiel and Shimei; and from the sons of Jeduthun, Shemaiah and Uzziel.
14:29:15/They gathered their fellow Levites, purified themselves, and came as the king commanded, according to the word of the LORD, to cleanse the LORD's temple.
14:29:16/The priests entered the interior of the LORD's temple to cleanse it, and they brought out all the impurities they found in the temple of the LORD to the courtyard of the LORD's temple. The Levites took them to the Kidron Valley to dispose of them.
14:29:17/They began the purification on the first day of the first month, and by the eighth day of the month they reached the LORD's vestibule. They purified the LORD's temple in eight days, and on the sixteenth day of the first month, they finished.
14:29:18/Then they went to King Hezekiah and reported, "We have purified the entire temple of the LORD, the altar of burnt offering with all its utensils, and the table for the bread of the Presence with all its utensils.
14:29:19/We have also restored and purified all the items that King Ahaz discarded during his reign in his unfaithfulness. They are now in front of the LORD's altar."
14:29:20/Then King Hezekiah rose early, gathered the city officials, and went up to the house of the LORD.
14:29:21/They brought seven bulls, seven rams, seven lambs, and seven male goats as a sin offering for the kingdom, the sanctuary, and Judah. He instructed the priests, the descendants of Aaron, to offer them on the LORD's altar.
14:29:22/So they slaughtered the bulls, and the priests took the blood and sprinkled it on the altar. Likewise, when they slaughtered the rams, they sprinkled the blood on the altar. They also slaughtered the lambs and sprinkled the blood on the altar.
14:29:23/They presented the male goats for the sin offering before the king and the assembly, and they laid their hands on them.
14:29:24/The priests slaughtered them and made atonement with their blood on the altar to atone for all Israel, because the king had ordered the burnt offering and the sin offering for all Israel.
14:29:25/Hezekiah stationed the Levites in the LORD's temple with cymbals, lyres, and harps, as David, Gad the king's seer, and Nathan the prophet had commanded, by the authority of the LORD through His prophets.
14:29:26/The Levites stood with David's instruments, and the priests with the trumpets.
14:29:27/Hezekiah ordered the burnt offering to be offered on the altar. As the burnt offering began, the song to the LORD also began, accompanied by the trumpets and the instruments David, king of Israel, had ordained.
14:29:28/The whole assembly worshiped, the singers sang, and the trumpeters played; all this continued until the burnt offering was completed.
14:29:29/When the offering was finished, the king and everyone present with him knelt down and worshiped.
14:29:30/Moreover, King Hezekiah and the officials ordered the Levites to praise the LORD with the words of David and of Asaph the seer. They sang praises joyfully and bowed down and worshiped.
14:29:31/Then Hezekiah said, "You have now dedicated yourselves to the LORD. Come and bring sacrifices and thank offerings to the house of the LORD." So the assembly brought in sacrifices and thank offerings, and all who were willing brought burnt offerings.
14:29:32/The total number of burnt offerings brought by the assembly was seventy bulls, a hundred rams, and two hundred lambs—all of these for a burnt offering to the LORD.
14:29:33/The consecrated items were six hundred bulls and three thousand sheep.
14:29:34/But there were too few priests to skin all the burnt offerings, so their Levite brothers helped them until the work was finished and until other priests had purified themselves. For the Levites were more conscientious in purifying themselves than the priests.
14:29:35/Also, the burnt offerings were abundant, along with the fat of the peace offerings and the drink offerings for each burnt offering. Thus, the service of the LORD's house was reestablished.
14:29:36/And Hezekiah and all the people rejoiced because God had prepared the people, for the work was done quickly.
14:30:1/Hezekiah reached out to all of Israel and Judah, and also sent letters to Ephraim and Manasseh, inviting them to come to the LORD's house in Jerusalem to celebrate the Passover in honor of the LORD God of Israel.
14:30:2/The king, after consulting with his advisors and the entire assembly in Jerusalem, decided to celebrate the Passover in the second month.
14:30:3/They were unable to celebrate it at the usual time because the priests had not purified themselves in time, and the people had not assembled in Jerusalem.
14:30:4/The plan received the king's and the entire assembly's approval.
14:30:5/Therefore, they issued a decree to be announced throughout all Israel, from Beersheba to Dan, inviting them to come to Jerusalem to celebrate the Passover in honor of the LORD God of Israel, something they hadn't done according to the prescribed manner in a long time.
14:30:6/The couriers went out with letters from the king and his officials throughout all Israel and Judah, following the king's command, saying, "People of Israel, return to the LORD, the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, and he will return to those of you who have escaped from the hands of the Assyrian kings.
14:30:7/And do not be like your ancestors and your kin who rebelled against the LORD, the God of their ancestors, leading to their ruin, as you can see.
14:30:8/Now, do not be stubborn like your ancestors; instead, submit to the LORD. Enter his sanctuary, which he has consecrated forever, and serve the LORD your God so that his fierce anger may turn away from you.
14:30:9/For if you return to the LORD, your relatives and your children will find mercy before those who have taken them captive and will be able to return to this land. For the LORD your God is gracious and compassionate, and he will not turn his face from you if you return to him."
14:30:10/So the couriers went from town to town in Ephraim and Manasseh, and as far as Zebulun, but they were met with laughter and ridicule.
14:30:11/However, some people from Asher, Manasseh, and Zebulun humbled themselves and went to Jerusalem.
14:30:12/In Judah, God worked to unite them in following the command of the king and the officials, according to the word of the LORD.
14:30:13/A large crowd gathered in Jerusalem to celebrate the Festival of Unleavened Bread in the second month, a very large assembly.
14:30:14/They got up and removed the altars in Jerusalem, and all the incense altars were taken away and thrown into the Kidron Valley.
14:30:15/Then they slaughtered the Passover lambs on the fourteenth day of the second month. The priests and Levites felt ashamed, purified themselves, and brought burnt offerings to the LORD's house.
14:30:16/They took their positions as prescribed by the law of Moses, the man of God. The priests sprinkled the blood received from the Levites.
14:30:17/Because many in the assembly had not purified themselves, the Levites were responsible for slaughtering the Passover lambs for everyone who was not ceremonially clean, to dedicate them to the LORD.
14:30:18/A large number of people from Ephraim, Manasseh, Issachar, and Zebulun had not purified themselves, yet they ate the Passover contrary to what was written. But Hezekiah prayed for them, saying, "May the good LORD pardon everyone
14:30:19/who sets their heart on seeking God, the LORD, the God of their ancestors, even if they are not purified according to the rules of the sanctuary."
14:30:20/And the LORD listened to Hezekiah and healed the people.
14:30:21/The Israelites present in Jerusalem celebrated the Festival of Unleavened Bread for seven days with great joy, and the Levites and priests praised the LORD every day with loud instruments dedicated to the LORD.
14:30:22/Hezekiah encouraged all the Levites who showed deep understanding of the LORD. They ate the festival meals for seven days, offering peace offerings and confessing to the LORD, the God of their ancestors.
14:30:23/Then the whole assembly agreed to celebrate for another seven days, and they celebrated joyfully for another seven days.
14:30:24/For Hezekiah, king of Judah, provided a thousand bulls and seven thousand sheep for the assembly, and the officials gave the assembly a thousand bulls and ten thousand sheep. A great number of priests consecrated themselves.
14:30:25/And the entire assembly of Judah, together with the priests, the Levites, all the assembly that came from Israel, the foreigners who came from the land of Israel, and those residing in Judah, rejoiced.
14:30:26/There was great joy in Jerusalem, for since the days of Solomon son of David, king of Israel, there had been nothing like this in Jerusalem.
14:30:27/Then the priests and Levites stood and blessed the people, and their prayer reached his holy dwelling place in heaven.
14:31:1/After completing all this, everyone from Israel who was present went to the cities of Judah. They destroyed the idols, cut down the sacred groves, and demolished the high places and altars throughout Judah and Benjamin, as well as in Ephraim and Manasseh, until they had completely eliminated them. Then, all the Israelites went back to their own cities, each to their own property.
14:31:2/Hezekiah organized the duties of the priests and Levites, assigning each person according to their role, including those responsible for burnt offerings and peace offerings, to serve, give thanks, and praise at the entrance of the LORD's dwelling.
14:31:3/He also set aside a portion of his own wealth for the burnt offerings, including those for the morning and evening, the Sabbaths, the new moons, and the appointed festivals, as prescribed in the LORD's law.
14:31:4/Furthermore, he instructed the residents of Jerusalem to contribute to the priests and Levites so they could devote themselves fully to the LORD's law.
14:31:5/As soon as the order was given, the Israelites generously brought the firstfruits of their grain, wine, oil, honey, and all the produce of the fields; they also brought a tenth of everything in great abundance.
14:31:6/The people of Israel and Judah living in the cities of Judah also brought a tenth of their cattle and sheep, and a tenth of the sacred items dedicated to the LORD their God, and they piled them up in heaps.
14:31:7/They started forming these heaps in the third month and finished in the seventh month.
14:31:8/When Hezekiah and his officials saw the heaps, they praised the LORD and His people Israel.
14:31:9/Then Hezekiah asked the priests and Levites about the heaps.
14:31:10/Azariah, the chief priest from the family of Zadok, replied, "Ever since the people began bringing their offerings to the LORD's house, we have had enough to eat with plenty to spare, because the LORD has blessed His people, and this large amount is what's left over."
14:31:11/Hezekiah then ordered that storerooms be prepared in the LORD's house, and they did so.
14:31:12/They faithfully brought in the offerings, tithes, and dedicated items. Cononiah the Levite was in charge, with his brother Shimei as his assistant.
14:31:13/Jehiel, Azaziah, Nahath, Asahel, Jerimoth, Jozabad, Eliel, Ismachiah, Mahath, and Benaiah served as supervisors under Cononiah and Shimei's direction, following King Hezekiah and Azariah's orders, the official in charge of God's house.
14:31:14/Kore son of Imnah the Levite, the gatekeeper at the east gate, was responsible for distributing the voluntary offerings made to God, the sacred gifts, and the most holy offerings.
14:31:15/Assisting him were Eden, Miniamin, Jeshua, Shemaiah, Amariah, and Shecaniah, in the priestly cities, tasked with distributing to their fellow priests according to their divisions, both to the prominent and the lesser.
14:31:16/This included all males three years old and up who entered the LORD's house, providing them with their daily portion for their service according to their duties.
14:31:17/It applied to the priests listed by their ancestral houses and the Levites twenty years old and up according to their duties and divisions.
14:31:18/It also included all their children, wives, sons, and daughters—the entire community—since they were committed to purity in their sacred duties.
14:31:19/And for the sons of Aaron, the priests, who were in the fields of the outskirts of their towns, in every town, men were designated by name to distribute portions to all the male priests and to all who were listed in the Levitical genealogies.
14:31:20/In this way, Hezekiah did throughout all Judah, doing what was good, right, and faithful before the LORD his God.
14:31:21/In every endeavor that he undertook in the service of God's house, in following the law and the commandments, seeking his God, he did with all his heart and was successful.
14:32:1/After these events, Sennacherib, the king of Assyria, arrived and invaded Judah, laying siege to its fortified cities, intending to conquer them for himself.
14:32:2/When Hezekiah realized that Sennacherib had arrived and was planning to attack Jerusalem,
14:32:3/He consulted with his officials and warriors about cutting off the water supply from the springs outside the city, and they supported his plan.
14:32:4/So many people came together and blocked all the springs and the stream that flowed through the area, asking, "Why should the kings of Assyria come and find plenty of water?"
14:32:5/He also fortified himself, repaired all the damaged walls, built them up to the towers, added another wall outside, fixed up the Millo in the City of David, and produced a large number of spears and shields.
14:32:6/He appointed military commanders over the people, gathered them in the city square at the gate, and encouraged them with these words,
14:32:7/"Be strong and brave. Do not be afraid or discouraged because of the king of Assyria and the vast army with him, for there is a greater power with us than with him.
14:32:8/He has mere human strength, but we have the LORD our God to help us and to fight our battles." And the people were inspired by the words of Hezekiah, king of Judah.
14:32:9/After this, Sennacherib, king of Assyria, sent his envoys to Jerusalem while he himself was laying siege to Lachish, along with all his forces, to Hezekiah, king of Judah, and to all the people of Judah in Jerusalem, saying,
14:32:10/"This is what Sennacherib, king of Assyria, says: On what are you basing your confidence that you remain under siege in Jerusalem?
14:32:11/Is it not Hezekiah who misleads you, making you risk death by starvation and thirst, claiming, 'The LORD our God will save us from the hand of the king of Assyria'?
14:32:12/Hasn't the same Hezekiah removed his high places and altars, insisting that you worship before one altar and burn incense on it?
14:32:13/Don't you realize what I and my ancestors have done to all the peoples of other lands? Were the gods of those nations able to protect their lands from my power?
14:32:14/Which of all the gods of these nations that my ancestors completely destroyed could save their people from me, that your God should be able to save you from my hand?
14:32:15/So now, don't let Hezekiah deceive you or mislead you like this, and don't believe him. No god of any nation or kingdom has been able to save their people from my hand or the hand of my ancestors. How much less will your God save you from my hand!"
14:32:16/And his envoys spoke even more against the LORD God and against his servant Hezekiah.
14:32:17/He also wrote letters insulting the LORD, the God of Israel, and speaking against him, saying, "Just as the gods of the nations of other lands did not rescue their people from my hand, so the God of Hezekiah will not rescue his people from my hand."
14:32:18/Then they shouted loudly in the language of the Jews to the people of Jerusalem who were on the wall, trying to frighten them and disturb them so that they could capture the city.
14:32:19/And they spoke about the God of Jerusalem as they did about the gods of the peoples of the earth, which are the work of human hands.
14:32:20/Because of this, King Hezekiah and the prophet Isaiah, son of Amoz, prayed and cried out to heaven.
14:32:21/And the LORD sent an angel who annihilated all the valiant warriors, leaders, and commanders in the camp of the Assyrian king. So he returned in disgrace to his own land. When he entered the temple of his god, some of his own offspring killed him there with the sword.
14:32:22/In this way, the LORD saved Hezekiah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem from Sennacherib, the king of Assyria, and from all other threats, and he protected them on every side.
14:32:23/Many brought offerings to the LORD in Jerusalem and valuable gifts to Hezekiah, king of Judah, so that from then on he was held in high esteem by all nations.
14:32:24/During that time, Hezekiah became deathly ill. He prayed to the LORD, who responded to him and gave him a miraculous sign.
14:32:25/But Hezekiah did not respond with gratitude for the kindness shown to him; his heart became proud. Therefore, wrath came upon him and upon Judah and Jerusalem.
14:32:26/However, Hezekiah humbled himself for the pride in his heart, as did the inhabitants of Jerusalem, so the LORD's wrath did not come upon them during Hezekiah's lifetime.
14:32:27/Hezekiah accumulated great wealth and honor. He created treasuries for silver, gold, precious stones, spices, shields, and all kinds of valuable items;
14:32:28/He also built storehouses for the harvest of grain, wine, and oil; and pens for all kinds of livestock, and enclosures for flocks.
14:32:29/Besides, he acquired cities and had flocks and herds in abundance, for God had given him very great wealth.
14:32:30/Hezekiah also redirected the upper watercourse of Gihon and channeled it directly to the west side of the City of David. Hezekiah succeeded in everything he did.
14:32:31/However, regarding the envoys of the princes of Babylon, who were sent to him to inquire about the miraculous sign that had occurred in the land, God left him to test him, to know everything in his heart.
14:32:32/The rest of the events of Hezekiah's reign, including his acts of devotion, are recorded in the vision of Isaiah the prophet, son of Amoz, and in the chronicles of the kings of Judah and Israel.
14:32:33/Hezekiah passed away and was buried in the most distinguished of the tombs of the descendants of David. All of Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem honored him at his death. And Manasseh, his son, succeeded him as king.
14:33:1/Manasseh was twelve years old when he began to reign, and he reigned fifty-five years in Jerusalem.
14:33:2/But he did what was evil in the sight of the LORD, similar to the detestable practices of the nations the LORD had driven out before the Israelites.
14:33:3/For he rebuilt the high places his father Hezekiah had destroyed; he also erected altars to Baal, made Asherah poles, and bowed down to all the starry hosts and worshiped them.
14:33:4/He even built altars in the temple of the LORD, which the LORD had declared, "My name will remain in Jerusalem forever."
14:33:5/And he constructed altars for all the starry hosts in both courts of the temple of the LORD.
14:33:6/He made his sons pass through fire in the Valley of Ben Hinnom, practiced divination and witchcraft, sought omens, and consulted mediums and spiritists. He did a great deal of evil in the LORD's sight, provoking him to anger.
14:33:7/He placed a carved idol, the image he had made, in the temple of God, where God had told David and Solomon his son, "In this temple and in Jerusalem, which I have chosen out of all the tribes of Israel, I will put my name forever.
14:33:8/I will not again make the feet of the Israelites leave the land I assigned to your ancestors, if only they will be careful to do everything I have commanded them concerning all the laws, decrees, and regulations given through Moses."
14:33:9/So Manasseh led Judah and the people of Jerusalem astray, causing them to do worse than the nations the LORD had destroyed before the Israelites.
14:33:10/The LORD spoke to Manasseh and his people, but they paid no attention.
14:33:11/Therefore, the LORD brought against them the army commanders of the king of Assyria, who captured Manasseh with hooks, bound him with bronze shackles, and took him to Babylon.
14:33:12/In his distress, he sought the favor of the LORD his God and humbled himself greatly before the God of his ancestors.
14:33:13/He prayed to him, and God was moved by his entreaty, heard his plea, and brought him back to Jerusalem into his kingdom. Then Manasseh knew that the LORD is God.
14:33:14/Afterward, he built an outer wall for the City of David, west of Gihon in the valley, as far as the entrance of the Fish Gate, encircling the hill of Ophel; he also made it very high. He placed military commanders in all the fortified cities in Judah.
14:33:15/He removed the foreign gods and the idol from the temple of the LORD, as well as all the altars he had built on the temple hill and in Jerusalem; and he threw them out of the city.
14:33:16/Then he restored the altar of the LORD and sacrificed fellowship offerings and thank offerings on it, and told Judah to serve the LORD, the God of Israel.
14:33:17/However, the people still sacrificed at the high places, but only to the LORD their God.
14:33:18/The other events of Manasseh's reign, including his prayer to his God and the words the seers spoke to him in the name of the LORD, the God of Israel, are written in the annals of the kings of Israel.
14:33:19/His prayer and how God was moved by his entreaty, as well as all his sins, his unfaithfulness, and the sites where he built high places and set up Asherah poles and idols before he humbled himself—all are written in the records of the seers.
14:33:20/So Manasseh rested with his ancestors and was buried in his palace. And Amon his son succeeded him as king.
14:33:21/Amon was twenty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned two years in Jerusalem.
14:33:22/But he did what was evil in the sight of the LORD, as his father Manasseh had done. Amon worshiped and served all the idols his father Manasseh had made.
14:33:23/And unlike his father Manasseh, he did not humble himself before the LORD; Amon increased his guilt.
14:33:24/His officials conspired against him and assassinated him in his palace.
14:33:25/But the people of the land killed all who had conspired against King Amon, and the people of the land made Josiah his son king in his place.
14:34:1/Josiah was eight years old when he began to reign, and he reigned in Jerusalem one and thirty years.
14:34:2/And he did what was right in the eyes of the LORD, and followed the ways of his ancestor David, without turning aside to the right or to the left.
14:34:3/For in the eighth year of his reign, while he was still young, he began to seek the God of his ancestor David: and in the twelfth year he started to cleanse Judah and Jerusalem of the high places, the Asherah poles, and the carved and cast images.
14:34:4/And they demolished the altars of the Baals in his presence; and the idols, that were placed high above them, he cut down; and the Asherah poles, and the carved and cast images, he smashed to pieces, turned them into dust, and scattered it over the graves of those who had sacrificed to them.
14:34:5/And he burned the bones of the priests on their altars, and purified Judah and Jerusalem.
14:34:6/And he did the same in the cities of Manasseh, Ephraim, and Simeon, even as far as Naphtali, with their tools all around.
14:34:7/And when he had torn down the altars and the Asherah poles, and had ground the carved images into powder, and cut down all the idols throughout the land of Israel, he returned to Jerusalem.
14:34:8/Now in the eighteenth year of his reign, after he had purified the land and the temple, he sent Shaphan the son of Azaliah, Maaseiah the governor of the city, and Joah the son of Joahaz the recorder, to repair the temple of the LORD his God.
14:34:9/And when they came to Hilkiah the high priest, they delivered the money that had been brought into the temple of God, which the Levites who kept the doors had collected from Manasseh and Ephraim, and from all the remnant of Israel, and from all Judah and Benjamin; and they returned to Jerusalem.
14:34:10/And they put it in the hands of the workmen who had the oversight of the temple of the LORD, and they paid it to the workmen who were working in the temple of the LORD, to repair and restore the temple:
14:34:11/They also gave it to the craftsmen and builders to buy quarried stone, and timber for joists and beams for the buildings that the kings of Judah had let deteriorate.
14:34:12/And the men carried out the work faithfully: the overseers of them were Jahath and Obadiah, Levites from the descendants of Merari; and Zechariah and Meshullam, from the descendants of the Kohathites, to supervise; and other Levites, all skilled in playing musical instruments.
14:34:13/They were also in charge of the laborers and supervised all the workers in any kind of service: and among the Levites there were scribes, officials, and gatekeepers.
14:34:14/And when they brought out the money that had been brought into the temple of the LORD, Hilkiah the priest found the Book of the Law of the LORD given through Moses.
14:34:15/And Hilkiah said to Shaphan the secretary, "I have found the Book of the Law in the temple of the LORD." And Hilkiah gave the book to Shaphan.
14:34:16/And Shaphan brought the book to the king, and also reported to the king, saying, "Everything that was entrusted to your servants, they are doing.
14:34:17/And they have gathered the money that was found in the temple of the LORD and have handed it over to the overseers and to the workmen."
14:34:18/Then Shaphan the secretary informed the king, saying, "Hilkiah the priest has given me a book." And Shaphan read it in the presence of the king.
14:34:19/And when the king heard the words of the Law, he tore his clothes.
14:34:20/And the king commanded Hilkiah, Ahikam the son of Shaphan, Abdon the son of Micah, Shaphan the secretary, and Asaiah a servant of the king, saying,
14:34:21/"Go, inquire of the LORD for me, and for those who are left in Israel and in Judah, concerning the words of the book that has been found. For great is the anger of the LORD that has been poured out on us because our ancestors did not obey the word of the LORD, to do everything written in this book."
14:34:22/And Hilkiah and those the king had designated went to Huldah the prophetess, the wife of Shallum the son of Tikvath, the son of Hasrah, keeper of the wardrobe; (she lived in Jerusalem in the Second District) and they spoke to her about this.
14:34:23/And she responded to them, "This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: Tell the man who sent you to me,
14:34:24/'This is what the LORD says: I am going to bring disaster on this place and its inhabitants—all the curses written in the book that was read before the king of Judah—
14:34:25/Because they have abandoned me and burned incense to other gods, provoking me to anger with all the works of their hands, my wrath will be poured out on this place and will not be quenched.'
14:34:26/But to the king of Judah, who sent you to inquire of the LORD, you shall say to him, 'This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says regarding the words you have heard:
14:34:27/Because your heart was responsive and you humbled yourself before God when you heard his words against this place and its inhabitants, and because you humbled yourself before me, tore your clothes, and wept before me, I have heard you, says the LORD.
14:34:28/Behold, I will gather you to your ancestors, and you will be buried in peace. Your eyes will not see all the disaster I am going to bring on this place and its inhabitants.'" So they brought the message back to the king.
14:34:29/Then the king summoned all the elders of Judah and Jerusalem.
14:34:30/And the king went up to the temple of the LORD, with all the people of Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem, the priests, the Levites, and all the people, from the greatest to the least. He read in their hearing all the words of the Book of the Covenant that had been found in the temple of the LORD.
14:34:31/And the king stood by his pillar and made a covenant before the LORD, to follow the LORD and to keep his commandments, his testimonies, and his statutes with all his heart and all his soul, to perform the words of the covenant written in this book.
14:34:32/And he made all who were present in Jerusalem and Benjamin pledge allegiance. The inhabitants of Jerusalem acted according to the covenant of God, the God of their ancestors.
14:34:33/And Josiah removed all the detestable idols from all the territory belonging to the Israelites, and he made all who were present in Israel serve the LORD their God. Throughout his lifetime, they did not turn away from following the LORD, the God of their ancestors.
14:35:1/Furthermore, Josiah celebrated a Passover to the LORD in Jerusalem, and they slaughtered the Passover lamb on the fourteenth day of the first month.
14:35:2/He assigned the priests to their duties and motivated them for the service of the LORD's house,
14:35:3/And told the Levites who instructed all Israel and were dedicated to the LORD, "Place the holy ark in the temple that Solomon, son of David, king of Israel, built; it shouldn't be a burden on your shoulders: now serve the LORD your God and his people Israel,
14:35:4/And get ready according to your ancestral houses, following the instructions of David king of Israel, and Solomon his son.
14:35:5/And stand in the holy place as per the divisions of the families of your ancestors among the people, and according to the division of the Levite families.
14:35:6/So slaughter the Passover lamb, purify yourselves, and prepare your brothers so they may follow the LORD's instructions through Moses.
14:35:7/And Josiah provided for the people, from the flock, lambs and young goats, all for the Passover sacrifices, for everyone present, totaling thirty thousand, plus three thousand bulls: these were from the king’s own possessions.
14:35:8/And his officials generously contributed to the people, the priests, and the Levites: Hilkiah, Zechariah, and Jehiel, leaders of God's house, gave the priests two thousand six hundred small livestock and three hundred oxen for the Passover sacrifices.
14:35:9/Conaniah, Shemaiah, Nethaneel, his brothers, Hashabiah, Jeiel, and Jozabad, leaders of the Levites, provided the Levites with five thousand small livestock and five hundred oxen for Passover sacrifices.
14:35:10/Thus, the service was arranged, and the priests stood in their positions, and the Levites in their groups, as per the king's order.
14:35:11/And they slaughtered the Passover lamb, the priests sprinkled the blood they received, and the Levites skinned the animals.
14:35:12/And they arranged the burnt offerings to distribute them according to the family divisions of the people, to offer to the LORD as written in the book of Moses. They did the same with the oxen.
14:35:13/And they cooked the Passover lamb over fire as prescribed; but the other sacred offerings were boiled in pots, cauldrons, and pans, and quickly distributed among all the people.
14:35:14/Afterward, they prepared for themselves and for the priests, because the priests, the sons of Aaron, were busy offering burnt offerings and the fat until night; so the Levites prepared for themselves and for the priests, the sons of Aaron.
14:35:15/And the singers, the sons of Asaph, were in their places, following the commands of David, Asaph, Heman, and Jeduthun, the king's seer; and the gatekeepers were at every gate; they did not leave their duties because their fellow Levites prepared for them.
14:35:16/So all the service for the LORD was arranged that day, to celebrate the Passover and to offer burnt offerings on the altar of the LORD, as per the command of King Josiah.
14:35:17/And the Israelites who were present celebrated the Passover at that time, and the Feast of Unleavened Bread for seven days.
14:35:18/And no Passover like the one kept by Josiah had been celebrated in Israel since the days of Samuel the prophet; nor had any of the kings of Israel held such a Passover as Josiah did, with the priests, Levites, all of Judah and Israel who were present, and the inhabitants of Jerusalem.
14:35:19/This Passover was celebrated in the eighteenth year of Josiah's reign.
14:35:20/After all this, when Josiah had restored the temple, Necho king of Egypt came up to fight at Carchemish on the Euphrates, and Josiah went out to confront him.
14:35:21/But Necho sent messengers to him, saying, "What conflict is between us, king of Judah? I have not come against you today but against a kingdom with which I am at war, and God has directed me to hurry. Stop interfering with God, who is with me, so he doesn't destroy you."
14:35:22/However, Josiah would not turn away from him, but disguised himself to engage him in battle, ignoring Necho's warnings from God, and went to fight in the Valley of Megiddo.
14:35:23/And archers shot King Josiah; and he said to his servants, "Take me away; I am badly wounded."
14:35:24/So his servants took him out of his chariot, transferred him to his second chariot, and brought him to Jerusalem, where he died and was buried in the tombs of his ancestors. And all of Judah and Jerusalem mourned for Josiah.
14:35:25/And Jeremiah mourned for Josiah, and all the male and female singers talk about Josiah in their laments to this day, and they established it as a tradition in Israel; and indeed, they are recorded in the Lamentations.
14:35:26/Now the rest of the acts of Josiah, and his acts of kindness, as written in the law of the LORD,
14:35:27/And his deeds, from beginning to end, are recorded in the book of the kings of Israel and Judah.
14:36:1/Then the locals made Jehoahaz, Josiah's son, king in his father's place in Jerusalem.
14:36:2/Jehoahaz was twenty-three years old when he became king, and he ruled for three months in Jerusalem.
14:36:3/The king of Egypt overthrew him in Jerusalem, and fined the land a hundred talents of silver and a talent of gold.
14:36:4/The king of Egypt appointed Eliakim, his brother, as king over Judah and Jerusalem, changing his name to Jehoiakim. And Necho took Jehoahaz, his brother, and brought him to Egypt.
14:36:5/Jehoiakim was twenty-five years old when he started his reign, and he ruled for eleven years in Jerusalem, doing what was evil in the eyes of the LORD his God.
14:36:6/Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, attacked him, captured him, and took him to Babylon in chains.
14:36:7/Nebuchadnezzar also took the sacred objects from the LORD's temple to Babylon and placed them in his temple there.
14:36:8/The rest of Jehoiakim's deeds, his detestable acts, and his wrongdoings are recorded in the book of the kings of Israel and Judah. Jehoiachin, his son, succeeded him as king.
14:36:9/Jehoiachin was eight years old when he began to rule, and he ruled for three months and ten days in Jerusalem, doing what was evil in the LORD's eyes.
14:36:10/At the end of the year, King Nebuchadnezzar sent for him and brought him to Babylon, along with the precious objects from the LORD's temple, and made Zedekiah, his brother, king over Judah and Jerusalem.
14:36:11/Zedekiah was twenty-one years old when he started his reign, and he ruled for eleven years in Jerusalem.
14:36:12/He did what was evil in the eyes of the LORD his God and did not humble himself before Jeremiah the prophet, who spoke for the LORD.
14:36:13/He also rebelled against King Nebuchadnezzar, despite having sworn an oath by God. He became stubborn and hardened his heart, refusing to turn back to the LORD God of Israel.
14:36:14/Furthermore, all the leading priests and the people greatly sinned, following the detestable practices of other nations, and defiled the LORD's temple that had been consecrated in Jerusalem.
14:36:15/The LORD, the God of their ancestors, repeatedly sent his messengers to them because he had compassion on his people and his dwelling place.
14:36:16/But they mocked God's messengers, disregarded his words, and mistreated his prophets, until the LORD's anger against his people was so fierce that there was no remedy.
14:36:17/Therefore, he brought against them the king of the Chaldeans, who killed their young men with the sword in their holy temple, and showed no mercy to anyone, young or old, man or woman.
14:36:18/He took all the objects from God's temple, both large and small, the treasures of the LORD's temple, the treasures of the king and his officials, and brought them all to Babylon.
14:36:19/They set fire to God's temple, broke down the walls of Jerusalem, burned all its palaces, and destroyed all its valuable items.
14:36:20/Those who survived the sword were taken to Babylon, where they became servants to him and his descendants until the Persian kingdom took over.
14:36:21/This fulfilled the word of the LORD spoken by Jeremiah, until the land had enjoyed its sabbaths; during its desolation, it rested until the seventy years were completed.
14:36:22/In the first year of Cyrus king of Persia, to fulfill the word of the LORD spoken by Jeremiah, the LORD moved the heart of Cyrus king of Persia to make a proclamation throughout his realm and also to put it in writing:
14:36:23/"This is what Cyrus king of Persia says: 'The LORD, the God of heaven, has given me all the kingdoms of the earth, and he has charged me to build him a house in Jerusalem, which is in Judah. Whoever among you belongs to his people, may the LORD his God be with him, and let him go up.'"
15:1:1/In the first year of Cyrus, king of Persia, to fulfill the prophecy spoken by Jeremiah, the LORD inspired Cyrus, king of Persia, to issue a decree throughout his entire kingdom, which he also recorded in writing, saying,
15:1:2/"This is what Cyrus, king of Persia, says: The LORD, the God of heaven, has given me all the kingdoms of the earth, and He has commanded me to build Him a temple in Jerusalem, which is in Judah.
15:1:3/Who among you belongs to His people? May his God be with him, and let him go up to Jerusalem in Judah and build the temple of the LORD, the God of Israel, the God who is in Jerusalem.
15:1:4/And anyone who remains in any place where he lives should support him with silver, gold, goods, and livestock, in addition to a voluntary offering for the temple of God in Jerusalem.
15:1:5/Then the leaders of the families of Judah and Benjamin, the priests, and the Levites, along with all those whose spirits God had moved, rose to go up and build the temple of the LORD in Jerusalem.
15:1:6/And all those around them bolstered their efforts with silver and gold, goods, livestock, and valuable gifts, in addition to all that was given freely.
15:1:7/Cyrus the king also returned the vessels of the temple of the LORD, which Nebuchadnezzar had taken from Jerusalem and placed in the temple of his gods;
15:1:8/These, Cyrus king of Persia had brought out by the hand of Mithredath the treasurer, and counted them out to Sheshbazzar, the prince of Judah.
15:1:9/Here is the inventory: thirty gold dishes, a thousand silver dishes, twenty-nine knives,
15:1:10/Thirty gold bowls, four hundred and ten silver bowls of a second kind, and a thousand other articles.
15:1:11/All the gold and silver articles totaled five thousand four hundred. All these were brought up by Sheshbazzar, along with the exiles who were brought up from Babylon to Jerusalem.
