15:3:1/When the seventh month arrived, and the children of Israel were in their cities, the people came together as one to Jerusalem.
15:3:2/Jeshua, the son of Jozadak, along with his fellow priests, and Zerubbabel, the son of Shealtiel, and his brothers, stood up and constructed the altar of the God of Israel to offer burnt offerings on it, as prescribed in the law of Moses, the man of God.
15:3:3/They placed the altar on its foundations; they were motivated by fear of the people from the surrounding regions: and they presented burnt offerings to the LORD, including morning and evening burnt offerings.
15:3:4/They also celebrated the Feast of Tabernacles, following the instructions written down, and offered the daily burnt offerings in the prescribed numbers, fulfilling the daily requirements.
15:3:5/Then they offered the regular burnt offering, for the new moons, for all the designated feasts of the LORD that were set apart, and for everyone who voluntarily brought a freewill offering to the LORD.
15:3:6/From the first day of the seventh month, they began to present burnt offerings to the LORD, even though the foundation of the LORD's temple had not yet been laid.
15:3:7/They also paid the masons and carpenters; and provided food, drink, and oil to those from Sidon and Tyre to bring cedar trees from Lebanon to the sea of Joppa, in accordance with the permission granted by Cyrus, king of Persia.
15:3:8/In the second year after their arrival at the house of God in Jerusalem, in the second month, Zerubbabel, the son of Shealtiel, and Jeshua, the son of Jozadak, along with the rest of their fellow priests and Levites, and all who had returned from the captivity to Jerusalem, began the work. They appointed Levites, twenty years old and above, to oversee the work of the house of the LORD.
15:3:9/Jeshua, his sons and brothers, Kadmiel and his sons, the sons of Judah, stood together to supervise the workers in the house of God, along with the sons of Henadad, their sons, and their Levite brothers.
15:3:10/When the builders laid the foundation of the temple of the LORD, they positioned the priests in their attire with trumpets, and the Levites, the sons of Asaph, with cymbals, to praise the LORD, following the practices established by David, king of Israel.
15:3:11/They sang responsively in praise and thanks to the LORD, proclaiming, "He is good, and His steadfast love toward Israel endures forever." And all the people raised a great shout of joy in praise of the LORD, celebrating the laying of the foundation of the house of the LORD.
15:3:12/However, many of the priests, Levites, and family heads, who were elderly and had seen the first temple, wept loudly when they saw the foundation of this temple being laid, while many others shouted aloud for joy.
15:3:13/The sound was so mixed that it was impossible to distinguish the joyful shouts from the sounds of weeping among the people: for the people shouted loudly, and the noise was heard from far away.
15:4:1/When the enemies of Judah and Benjamin found out that the exiles were rebuilding the temple for the LORD God of Israel;
15:4:2/they approached Zerubbabel and the leading elders and proposed, "Let us help you build because we seek your God just as you do; we have been sacrificing to Him since the days of Esarhaddon king of Assyria, who brought us here."
15:4:3/But Zerubbabel, Jeshua, and the other leading elders of Israel told them, "You have no part with us in building a temple for our God; we alone will build it for the LORD God of Israel, as King Cyrus of Persia has commanded us."
15:4:4/The local people then began to discourage the people of Judah and made them afraid to build,
15:4:5/and even hired advisors to work against them and thwart their plans during the entire reign of Cyrus king of Persia and until the reign of Darius king of Persia.
15:4:6/During the reign of Ahasuerus, at the beginning of his reign, they filed a formal complaint against the residents of Judah and Jerusalem.
15:4:7/And during the time of Artaxerxes, Bishlam, Mithredath, Tabeel, and their associates wrote to Artaxerxes king of Persia. The letter was written in Aramaic script and translated into Aramaic.
15:4:8/Rehum the commanding officer and Shimshai the secretary wrote a letter against Jerusalem to King Artaxerxes as follows:
15:4:9/Then Rehum the commanding officer, Shimshai the secretary, and their colleagues—the Dinaites, the Apharsathchites, the Tarpelites, the Apharsites, the Archevites, the Babylonians, the Susanchites, the Dehavites, and the Elamites,
15:4:10/and the other nations whom the great and noble Osnapper deported and settled in the cities of Samaria and elsewhere in the region west of the Euphrates River.
15:4:11/This is a copy of the letter they sent to him, to King Artaxerxes from your servants, the men west of the Euphrates River.
15:4:12/Let it be known to the king that the Jews who came up from you to us have gone to Jerusalem and are rebuilding that rebellious and wicked city. They are restoring its walls and repairing its foundations.
15:4:13/Let it now be known to the king that if this city is rebuilt and its walls are completed, they will not pay tax, tribute, or duty, and the royal revenues will suffer.
15:4:14/Now since we are under obligation to the palace and it is not right for us to see the king dishonored, we are sending this message to inform the king,
15:4:15/so that a search may be made in the archives of your ancestors. In these records, you will find and learn that this city is a rebellious city, harmful to kings and provinces, and that sedition has been stirred up in it from ancient times. That is why this city was destroyed.
15:4:16/We want to make it clear to the king that if this city is rebuilt and its walls are restored, you will have no possession west of the Euphrates.
15:4:17/The king sent this reply: To Rehum the commanding officer, to Shimshai the secretary, and to the rest of their associates living in Samaria and elsewhere west of the Euphrates, greetings.
15:4:18/The letter you sent us has been read in my presence.
15:4:19/I issued a decree and a search was made, and it was found that this city has a long history of rebellion against kings and has been a hotbed of revolt and sedition.
15:4:20/It was also found that Jerusalem has had powerful kings ruling over the whole region west of the Euphrates, and tribute, taxes, and duties were paid to them.
15:4:21/Therefore, issue an order for these men to stop work, so that this city will not be rebuilt until I so command.
15:4:22/Be careful not to neglect this matter. Why let this threat grow, to the detriment of the royal interests?
15:4:23/As soon as the text of King Artaxerxes’ letter was read to Rehum, Shimshai the secretary, and their associates, they hurried to Jerusalem to the Jews and stopped them by force.
15:4:24/Thus, the work on the house of God in Jerusalem came to a standstill until the second year of the reign of Darius king of Persia.
15:5:1/Then the prophets, Haggai and Zechariah, son of Iddo, delivered prophecies to the Jews in Judah and Jerusalem in the name of the God of Israel, directly to them.
15:5:2/Then Zerubbabel, son of Shealtiel, and Jeshua, son of Jozadak, started to rebuild the house of God in Jerusalem, with the prophets of God assisting them.
15:5:3/At that time, Tatnai, the governor west of the river, Shetharboznai, and their associates came to them and questioned, "Who gave you permission to rebuild this temple and restore this wall?"
15:5:4/We then asked them, "Can you tell us the names of the people working on this construction?"
15:5:5/But God was watching over the Jewish elders, preventing any interference until the issue was reported to Darius, and a written response was received.
15:5:6/The letter sent by Tatnai, the governor west of the river, Shetharboznai, and his associates, the Apharsachites, to King Darius was as follows:
15:5:7/They wrote a letter to him, which said: "To King Darius, greetings of peace."
15:5:8/Let it be known to the king that we visited the province of Judea and the temple of the great God, which is being built with large stones and timber in its walls. The work is progressing rapidly and is successful.
15:5:9/We then questioned the elders, asking, "Who authorized you to rebuild this temple and construct these walls?"
15:5:10/We also asked for their names to inform you, so we could record the leaders of this project.
15:5:11/They responded, "We are servants of the God of heaven and earth, rebuilding the temple that was constructed many years ago, a project initiated by a great king of Israel."
15:5:12/However, after our ancestors angered the God of heaven, He handed them over to Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, the Chaldean, who demolished this temple and exiled the people to Babylon.
15:5:13/But in the first year of Cyrus, king of Babylon, Cyrus himself issued a decree to rebuild this temple of God.
15:5:14/Also, the gold and silver vessels of the temple of God, which Nebuchadnezzar had taken from the temple in Jerusalem and brought to Babylon, were returned by King Cyrus. He entrusted them to Sheshbazzar, whom he appointed as governor.
15:5:15/He instructed him, "Take these vessels, go, and place them in the temple in Jerusalem, and let the temple of God be rebuilt on its original site."
15:5:16/Then Sheshbazzar came and laid the foundation of the temple of God in Jerusalem. From that time until now, it has been under construction and is not yet completed.
15:5:17/Therefore, if it seems appropriate to the king, let a search be conducted in the royal archives in Babylon to verify whether a decree was indeed issued by King Cyrus to rebuild this temple of God in Jerusalem. And let the king send us his decision regarding this matter.
15:6:1/Then King Darius issued a decree, and a search was conducted in the archives where the treasures were stored in Babylon.
15:6:2/In Achmetha, within the palace in the province of the Medes, a scroll was discovered, and it contained the following record:
15:6:3/In the first year of King Cyrus, Cyrus himself decreed concerning the temple of God in Jerusalem: Let the temple be rebuilt as a place where sacrifices are made, and let its foundations be solidly laid; its height to be sixty cubits and its width sixty cubits;
15:6:4/With three layers of large stones and a layer of new timber; and let the costs be covered by the royal treasury:
15:6:5/Also, let the gold and silver vessels of the temple of God, which Nebuchadnezzar took from the temple in Jerusalem and brought to Babylon, be returned and restored to their places in the temple in Jerusalem, and let them be placed in the temple of God.
15:6:6/Now therefore, Tatnai, governor of the region west of the Euphrates, Shetharboznai, and your colleagues the Apharsachites who are west of the river, stay away from there:
15:6:7/Leave the construction of this temple of God alone; let the governor of the Jews and the Jewish elders rebuild this temple of God on its site.
15:6:8/Furthermore, I have issued a decree regarding what you are to do for the Jewish elders for the construction of this temple of God: ensure that the costs are fully covered from the royal treasury from the revenues of the region west of the river, so that the work is not delayed.
15:6:9/And provide them with whatever they need - young bulls, rams, and lambs for burnt offerings to the God of heaven, and also wheat, salt, wine, and oil, as requested by the priests in Jerusalem - without fail every day:
15:6:10/So they may offer pleasing sacrifices to the God of heaven and pray for the well-being of the king and his sons.
15:6:11/I have also decreed that anyone who changes this order shall have a beam removed from their house, be impaled on it, and their house shall be turned into a pile of rubble for this offense.
15:6:12/May the God who has chosen to dwell there destroy any king or people who attempt to change this decree or destroy this temple of God in Jerusalem. I, Darius, have issued this decree; let it be carried out promptly.
15:6:13/Then Tatnai, governor west of the river, Shetharboznai, and their colleagues complied with what King Darius had ordered, and did so promptly.
15:6:14/And the Jewish elders continued to build and prosper under the preaching of Haggai the prophet and Zechariah son of Iddo. They finished building the temple according to the command of the God of Israel and the decrees of Cyrus, Darius, and Artaxerxes, kings of Persia.
15:6:15/This temple was completed on the third day of the month of Adar, in the sixth year of the reign of King Darius.
15:6:16/And the people of Israel, the priests, the Levites, and the rest of the exiles, celebrated the dedication of this temple of God with joy.
15:6:17/At the dedication of this temple of God, they offered one hundred bulls, two hundred rams, four hundred lambs; and as a sin offering for all Israel, twelve male goats, according to the number of the tribes of Israel.
15:6:18/They appointed the priests to their divisions and the Levites to their groups for the service of God in Jerusalem, as written in the Book of Moses.
15:6:19/The exiles observed the Passover on the fourteenth day of the first month.
15:6:20/For the priests and the Levites had purified themselves together; all of them were clean. They slaughtered the Passover lamb for all the exiles, for their fellow priests, and for themselves.
15:6:21/And the Israelites who had returned from exile, along with everyone who had separated themselves from the impurity of the nations of the land to worship the LORD, the God of Israel, ate the Passover,
15:6:22/And they celebrated the Festival of Unleavened Bread for seven days with joy, because the LORD had made them joyful and had turned the heart of the king of Assyria toward them, strengthening their hands in the work on the temple of God, the God of Israel.
15:7:1/After these events, during the reign of Artaxerxes king of Persia, Ezra, the son of Seraiah, the son of Azariah, the son of Hilkiah,
15:7:2/the son of Shallum, the son of Zadok, the son of Ahitub,
15:7:3/the son of Amariah, the son of Azariah, the son of Meraioth,
15:7:4/the son of Zerahiah, the son of Uzzi, the son of Bukki,
15:7:5/the son of Abishua, the son of Phinehas, the son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron the chief priest:
15:7:6/Ezra left Babylon; he was a skilled scribe in the law of Moses, which the LORD God of Israel had given. The king granted him everything he asked for, because the LORD his God was with him.
15:7:7/Some of the Israelites, including priests, Levites, singers, gatekeepers, and temple servants, went up to Jerusalem in the seventh year of King Artaxerxes.
15:7:8/He arrived in Jerusalem in the fifth month of the seventh year of the king's reign.
15:7:9/He began his journey from Babylon on the first day of the first month, and he arrived in Jerusalem on the first day of the fifth month, because the gracious hand of his God was on him.
15:7:10/Ezra had set his heart to study the law of the LORD, to practice it, and to teach its statutes and rules in Israel.
15:7:11/This is the text of the letter that King Artaxerxes gave to Ezra the priest, the scribe, a scholar of the words of the LORD's commandments and statutes for Israel:
15:7:12/Artaxerxes, king of kings, to Ezra the priest, a scribe of the law of the God of heaven, perfect peace, and at such a time.
15:7:13/I issue a decree that any of the people of Israel, their priests and Levites in my kingdom, who wish to go to Jerusalem with you, may do so.
15:7:14/Since you are being sent by the king and his seven advisers to investigate the situation in Judah and Jerusalem according to the law of your God, which is in your hand,
15:7:15/and to carry the silver and gold, which the king and his advisers have freely given to the God of Israel, whose dwelling is in Jerusalem,
15:7:16/along with all the silver and gold you can find in the entire province of Babylon, plus the freewill offerings of the people and priests, which are given willingly for the temple of their God in Jerusalem,
15:7:17/you are to use this money promptly to buy bulls, rams, lambs, grain offerings, and drink offerings, and offer them on the altar of the temple of your God in Jerusalem.
15:7:18/And whatever you and your fellow Israelites decide to do with the rest of the silver and gold, you can do in accordance with the will of your God.
15:7:19/The articles given to you for the service of the temple of your God, you are to deliver before the God of Jerusalem.
15:7:20/And anything else needed for the temple of your God that you are responsible to supply, you may provide from the royal treasury.
15:7:21/I, King Artaxerxes, decree to all the treasurers in the region beyond the River, that whatever Ezra the priest, the scribe of the law of the God of heaven, requires of you, it is to be done promptly,
15:7:22/up to a hundred talents of silver, a hundred cors of wheat, a hundred baths of wine, a hundred baths of oil, and salt without limit.
15:7:23/Everything commanded by the God of heaven must be carried out diligently for the temple of the God of heaven. Why should there be wrath against the realm of the king and his sons?
15:7:24/We also inform you that it is not permitted to impose taxes, tolls, or tribute on any of the priests, Levites, singers, gatekeepers, temple servants, or other workers at this house of God.
15:7:25/And you, Ezra, according to the wisdom of your God that is in your hand, appoint magistrates and judges to judge all the people in the region beyond the River, all who know the laws of your God; and teach anyone who does not know them.
15:7:26/Anyone who does not obey the law of your God and the law of the king must be punished promptly, whether it be by death, banishment, confiscation of their goods, or imprisonment.
15:7:27/Praise be to the LORD, the God of our ancestors, who has put it into the king's heart to beautify the temple of the LORD in Jerusalem,
15:7:28/and who has shown me favor in the presence of the king, his advisers, and all the king's powerful officials. I was encouraged because the hand of the LORD my God was on me, and I gathered leading men from Israel to go up with me.
15:8:1/Here are the main leaders of their families, and this is the family tree of those who came with me from Babylon during King Artaxerxes' reign.
15:8:2/From the descendants of Phinehas; Gershom. From the descendants of Ithamar; Daniel. From the descendants of David; Hattush.
15:8:3/From the descendants of Shechaniah, from the family of Pharosh; Zechariah, and with him were counted by genealogy 150 men.
15:8:4/From the descendants of Pahathmoab; Elihoenai the son of Zerahiah, and with him 200 men.
15:8:5/From the descendants of Shechaniah; the son of Jahaziel, and with him 300 men.
15:8:6/Also from the descendants of Adin; Ebed the son of Jonathan, and with him 50 men.
15:8:7/And from the descendants of Elam; Jeshaiah the son of Athaliah, and with him 70 men.
15:8:8/And from the descendants of Shephatiah; Zebadiah the son of Michael, and with him 80 men.
15:8:9/From the descendants of Joab; Obadiah the son of Jehiel, and with him 218 men.
15:8:10/And from the descendants of Shelomith; the son of Josiphiah, and with him 160 men.
15:8:11/And from the descendants of Bebai; Zechariah the son of Bebai, and with him 28 men.
15:8:12/And from the descendants of Azgad; Johanan the son of Hakkatan, and with him 110 men.
15:8:13/And from the last descendants of Adonikam, whose names are these, Eliphelet, Jeiel, and Shemaiah, and with them 60 men.
15:8:14/Also from the descendants of Bigvai; Uthai, and Zabbud, and with them 70 men.
15:8:15/And I gathered them at the river that flows to Ahava; and we camped there for three days. I reviewed the people and the priests and found none of the descendants of Levi.
15:8:16/Then I sent for Eliezer, Ariel, Shemaiah, Elnathan, Jarib, Elnathan, Nathan, Zechariah, and Meshullam, leading men; also for Joiarib, and Elnathan, men of insight.
15:8:17/And I sent them with instructions to Iddo, the leader in Casiphia, telling them what to say to Iddo and his fellow temple servants in Casiphia, to bring us ministers for the house of our God.
15:8:18/And because of our God's gracious hand on us, they brought us a man of insight from the descendants of Mahli, son of Levi, the son of Israel, and Sherebiah, with his sons and brothers, 18 in total;
15:8:19/And Hashabiah, along with Jeshaiah from the descendants of Merari, his brothers and their sons, 20 in total;
15:8:20/Also 220 of the temple servants, whom David and the officials had assigned to assist the Levites, all listed by name.
15:8:21/Then I declared a fast there, by the river Ahava, so we could humble ourselves before our God, to seek from him a safe journey for us, our children, and all our possessions.
15:8:22/For I was embarrassed to ask the king for soldiers and horsemen to protect us from enemies on the road, because we had told the king, "The hand of our God is favorably upon all who seek him, but his power and wrath are against all who forsake him."
15:8:23/So we fasted and pleaded with our God about this, and he listened to our plea.
15:8:24/Then I set apart twelve of the leading priests, Sherebiah, Hashabiah, and ten of their brothers with them,
15:8:25/And weighed out to them the silver, the gold, and the utensils, the offering for the house of our God that the king, his counselors, his lords, and all Israel present had offered.
15:8:26/I handed over to them 650 talents of silver, silver vessels weighing 100 talents, 100 talents of gold,
15:8:27/Also 20 gold bowls worth 1,000 darics, and two fine polished bronze vessels as precious as gold.
15:8:28/And I said to them, "You are sacred to the LORD, as are the vessels and the silver and gold, which are a voluntary offering to the LORD, the God of your ancestors.
15:8:29/Keep watch over them until you weigh them in the presence of the leading priests, the Levites, and the heads of the families of Israel at Jerusalem, in the chambers of the house of the LORD."
15:8:30/So the priests and the Levites took charge of the silver, the gold, and the utensils to bring them to Jerusalem to the house of our God.
15:8:31/Then we left the river Ahava on the twelfth day of the first month to go to Jerusalem. The hand of our God was on us, and he protected us from enemies and bandits along the way.
15:8:32/And we arrived in Jerusalem, where we rested for three days.
15:8:33/On the fourth day, in the house of our God, we weighed out the silver, the gold, and the utensils. Meremoth son of Uriah the priest was there, along with Eleazar son of Phinehas; and with them were Jozabad son of Jeshua and Noadiah son of Binnui, the Levites.
15:8:34/Everything was accounted for by number and weight, and the total weight was recorded at that time.
15:8:35/The exiles who had returned from captivity offered burnt offerings to the God of Israel: twelve bulls for all Israel, ninety-six rams, seventy-seven lambs, and twelve male goats as a sin offering. All this was a burnt offering to the LORD.
15:8:36/They delivered the king's orders to the king's satraps and to the governors of the province Beyond the River, who then supported the people and the house of God.
15:9:1/After all this was done, the leaders came to me and said, "The people of Israel, including the priests and Levites, haven't kept themselves separate from the neighboring peoples with their detestable practices, like those of the Canaanites, Hittites, Perizzites, Jebusites, Ammonites, Moabites, Egyptians, and Amorites.
15:9:2/They have taken their daughters as wives for themselves and their sons, so the holy lineage has mixed with the peoples of those lands. Indeed, the leaders and officials have led the way in this wrongdoing.
15:9:3/When I heard this, I tore my clothes and cloak, pulled hair from my head and beard, and sat down in shock.
15:9:4/Everyone who was appalled by the words of the God of Israel gathered around me because of the unfaithfulness of the exiles. And I sat there in shock until the evening sacrifice.
15:9:5/At the time of the evening sacrifice, I got up from my distress. With my clothes and cloak torn, I fell on my knees with my hands spread out to the LORD my God,
15:9:6/And said, "Oh my God, I am too embarrassed and ashamed to lift my face to you, my God, because our sins are higher than our heads and our guilt has reached the heavens.
15:9:7/From the days of our ancestors until now, our guilt has been great. Because of our sins, we, our kings, and our priests have been handed over to the kings of the lands, to the sword, to captivity, to plundering, and to utter shame, as is the case today.
15:9:8/But now, for a brief moment, grace has been shown from the LORD our God, who has left us a remnant to escape and given us a secure hold within his holy place, so that our God may brighten our eyes and give us a little relief in our slavery.
15:9:9/Even though we were slaves, our God has not abandoned us in our bondage. He has extended kindness to us in the presence of the kings of Persia, granting us new life to rebuild the house of our God and repair its ruins, and giving us a protective wall in Judah and Jerusalem.
15:9:10/And now, our God, what can we say after this? We have disregarded your commands,
15:9:11/Which you gave through your servants the prophets, saying, 'The land you are entering to possess is a polluted land with the pollution of the peoples of the lands, with their detestable practices that have filled it from end to end with their impurity.
15:9:12/Therefore, do not give your daughters in marriage to their sons or take their daughters for your sons. Do not seek their peace or prosperity, so that you may be strong, eat the good things of the land, and leave it as an inheritance to your children forever.'
15:9:13/After everything that has happened to us because of our evil deeds and great guilt, and considering that you, our God, have punished us less than our sins deserve and have given us such a remnant,
15:9:14/Should we again violate your commands and intermarry with the peoples who commit these detestable practices? Would you not be angry enough with us to destroy us, leaving no remnant or survivor?
15:9:15/O LORD, God of Israel, you are righteous. We are left as a remnant today. Here we are before you in our guilt, though because of it not one of us can stand in your presence.
15:10:1/When Ezra prayed and confessed, weeping and throwing himself down in front of God's house, a very large crowd of men, women, and children from Israel gathered around him because the people were crying bitterly.
15:10:2/Shechaniah, son of Jehiel, from the descendants of Elam, spoke up and said to Ezra, "We have sinned against our God by marrying foreign women from the local peoples, but there is still hope for Israel regarding this issue."
15:10:3/"So, let's make a promise to our God to send away all these wives and their children, following the advice of my lord and those who respect God's commandments; let's do it according to the law."
15:10:4/"Get up, because this task is yours to handle. We will support you, so be strong and take action."
15:10:5/Then Ezra got up and had the leading priests, Levites, and all Israel pledge to do what was proposed. And they took the oath.
15:10:6/Ezra then left the front of God's house and went to the room of Johanan, son of Eliashib. While there, he didn't eat bread or drink water because he was mourning over the unfaithfulness of the exiles.
15:10:7/A call was made throughout Judah and Jerusalem for all the exiles to gather in Jerusalem.
15:10:8/And it was announced that anyone who didn't show up within three days, as decided by the leaders and elders, would forfeit all their property and be excluded from the community of the exiles.
15:10:9/So all the men of Judah and Benjamin assembled in Jerusalem within the three days. It was the ninth month, on the twentieth day, and all the people sat in the square in front of God's house, trembling because of the situation and because of the heavy rain.
15:10:10/Then Ezra the priest stood up and said to them, "You have broken faith by marrying foreign women, adding to Israel's guilt.
15:10:11/Now, confess to the LORD, the God of your ancestors, and do what pleases Him. Separate yourselves from the peoples of the land and from the foreign wives."
15:10:12/Then the whole assembly responded loudly, "You're right! We must do as you say.
15:10:13/But there are many of us, and it's raining heavily. We can't just stand outside, and this isn't a matter that can be resolved in one or two days, for we have greatly sinned in this matter.
15:10:14/Let our leaders represent the entire assembly. Then, everyone who has married a foreign woman in our towns will come at set times, along with the elders and judges of each town, until the fierce anger of our God over this matter is turned away from us."
15:10:15/Only Jonathan, son of Asahel, and Jahaziah, son of Tikvah, were appointed to handle this matter, assisted by Meshullam and Shabbethai the Levite.
15:10:16/The exiles did as proposed. Ezra the priest selected men who were family heads, one from each family division, and all of them by name. On the first day of the tenth month, they sat down to investigate the cases.
15:10:17/By the first day of the first month, they had dealt with all the men who had married foreign women.
15:10:18/Among the priests, there were found to have married foreign women: from the descendants of Jeshua son of Jozadak and his brothers; Maaseiah, Eliezer, Jarib, and Gedaliah.
15:10:19/They pledged to send away their wives, and as a guilt offering, they presented a ram from the flock.
15:10:20/From the descendants of Immer: Hanani and Zebadiah.

15:10:22/From the descendants of Pashur: Elioenai, Maaseiah, Ishmael, Nethaneel, Jozabad, and Elasah.
15:10:23/Among the Levites: Jozabad, Shimei, Kelaiah (also known as Kelita), Pethahiah, Judah, and Eliezer.
15:10:24/Among the singers: Eliashib. And among the gatekeepers: Shallum, Telem, and Uri.
15:10:25/From the Israelites: from the descendants of Parosh; Ramiah, Jeziah, Malchiah, Miamin, Eleazar, Malchijah, and Benaiah.
15:10:26/From the descendants of Elam: Mattaniah, Zechariah, Jehiel, Abdi, Jeremoth, and Eliah.
15:10:27/From the descendants of Zattu: Elioenai, Eliashib, Mattaniah, Jeremoth, Zabad, and Aziza.
15:10:28/From the descendants of Bebai: Jehohanan, Hananiah, Zabbai, and Athlai.
15:10:29/From the descendants of Bani: Meshullam, Malluch, and Adaiah, Jashub, and Sheal, and Ramoth.
15:10:30/From the descendants of Pahathmoab: Adna, and Chelal, Benaiah, Maaseiah, Mattaniah, Bezaleel, and Binnui, and Manasseh.
15:10:31/From the descendants of Harim: Eliezer, Ishijah, Malchiah, Shemaiah, Shimeon,
15:10:32/Benjamin, Malluch, and Shemariah.
15:10:33/From the descendants of Hashum: Mattenai, Mattathah, Zabad, Eliphelet, Jeremai, Manasseh, and Shimei.

16:1:1/The words of Nehemiah the son of Hachaliah. And it happened in the month of Chisleu, in the twentieth year, while I was in Shushan the palace,
16:1:2/That Hanani, one of my brothers, arrived, along with some men from Judah; and I asked them about the Jews who had survived, those who were left from the captivity, and about Jerusalem.
16:1:3/And they told me, "The survivors from the captivity in the province are in great trouble and disgrace: the wall of Jerusalem is broken down, and its gates have been burned with fire."
16:1:4/When I heard these words, I sat down and cried, and mourned for several days, and fasted, and prayed before the God of heaven,
16:1:5/And said, "Please, O LORD God of heaven, the great and awe-inspiring God, who keeps covenant and steadfast love for those who love him and keep his commandments:
16:1:6/Let your ear now be attentive, and your eyes open, to hear the prayer of your servant, which I am praying before you now, day and night, for the children of Israel your servants, and confessing the sins of the children of Israel, which we have committed against you: both I and my father’s house have sinned.
16:1:7/We have acted very wickedly against you, and have not kept the commandments, nor the statutes, nor the judgments, which you commanded your servant Moses.
16:1:8/Remember, please, the word that you commanded your servant Moses, saying, 'If you are unfaithful, I will scatter you among the nations:
16:1:9/But if you return to me, and keep my commandments and do them; even if your outcasts are at the farthest horizon, I will gather them from there and bring them to the place that I have chosen to set my name.'
16:1:10/Now these are your servants and your people, whom you have redeemed by your great power, and by your strong hand.
16:1:11/O LORD, please, let your ear be attentive to the prayer of your servant, and to the prayer of your servants who delight to revere your name: and please, make your servant successful today, and grant him mercy in the sight of this man. For I was the king’s cupbearer.
16:2:1/In the month of Nisan, during the twentieth year of King Artaxerxes' reign, I was serving wine to him. I took the wine and gave it to the king. Until then, I had never appeared sad in his presence.
16:2:2/So the king asked me, "Why do you look so sad when you're not ill? This must be deep sorrow." I was terrified,
16:2:3/But I said to the king, "May the king live forever! How can I not look sad when the city where my ancestors are buried is in ruins, and its gates have been destroyed by fire?"
16:2:4/The king then asked me, "What is it you want?" So I prayed to the God of heaven.
16:2:5/And I answered the king, "If it pleases the king, and if your servant has found favor in your sight, send me to Judah, to the city of my ancestors' graves, so I can rebuild it."
16:2:6/The king, with the queen sitting beside him, asked me, "How long will your journey take, and when will you return?" It pleased the king to send me, so I set a time.
16:2:7/Then I said to the king, "If it pleases the king, may I have letters for the governors of the region beyond the river, so they will provide me safe passage until I arrive in Judah?"
16:2:8/And a letter for Asaph, the keeper of the royal forest, so he will give me timber to make beams for the gates of the fortress near the temple, for the city wall, and for the residence I will occupy." And the king granted my requests, because the gracious hand of my God was on me.
16:2:9/So I went to the governors beyond the river and gave them the king's letters. The king had also sent army officers and cavalry with me.
16:2:10/When Sanballat the Horonite and Tobiah the Ammonite official heard about this, they were very much disturbed that someone had come to promote the welfare of the Israelites.
16:2:11/When I arrived in Jerusalem, I stayed there three days.
16:2:12/Then, during the night, I set out with a few men. I hadn't told anyone what my God had inspired me to do for Jerusalem. There were no animals with me except the one I was riding.
16:2:13/That night, I went out through the Valley Gate toward the Dragon Spring and the Dung Gate, examining the walls of Jerusalem, which had been broken down, and its gates, which had been destroyed by fire.
16:2:14/Then I moved on to the Fountain Gate and the King's Pool, but there was not enough room for my mount to get through;
16:2:15/So I went up the valley by night, examining the wall. Finally, I turned back and re-entered through the Valley Gate.
16:2:16/The officials did not know where I had gone or what I was doing, because as yet I had said nothing to the Jews or the priests or nobles or officials or any others who would be doing the work.
16:2:17/Then I said to them, "You see the trouble we are in: Jerusalem lies in ruins, and its gates have been burned with fire. Come, let us rebuild the wall of Jerusalem, and we will no longer be in disgrace."
16:2:18/I also told them about the gracious hand of my God on me and what the king had said to me. They replied, "Let's start rebuilding." So they began this good work with enthusiasm.
16:2:19/But when Sanballat the Horonite, Tobiah the Ammonite official, and Geshem the Arabian heard about it, they mocked and ridiculed us. "What is this you're doing?" they asked. "Are you rebelling against the king?"
16:2:20/I answered them by saying, "The God of heaven will give us success. We, his servants, will start building, but you have no share, legal right, or historic claim in Jerusalem."
16:3:1/Then Eliashib the high priest got up with his fellow priests, and they built the sheep gate; they dedicated it, and installed its doors; all the way to the tower of Meah they dedicated it, up to the tower of Hananeel.
16:3:2/And right next to him, the men of Jericho built. And next to them, Zaccur the son of Imri built.
16:3:3/However, the fish gate was built by the sons of Hassenaah, who also put in place its beams, and installed its doors, its locks, and its bars.
16:3:4/And right next to them, Meremoth the son of Urijah, the son of Koz, made repairs. And next to them, Meshullam the son of Berechiah, the son of Meshezabeel, made repairs. And next to them, Zadok the son of Baana made repairs.
16:3:5/And right next to them, the Tekoites made repairs; but their nobles did not commit to the work of their Lord.
16:3:6/Also, the old gate was repaired by Jehoiada the son of Paseah, and Meshullam the son of Besodeiah; they put in place its beams, and installed its doors, its locks, and its bars.
16:3:7/And right next to them, Melatiah the Gibeonite, and Jadon the Meronothite, the men of Gibeon, and of Mizpah, made repairs, up to the residence of the governor on this side of the river.
16:3:8/Next to him, Uzziel the son of Harhaiah, one of the goldsmiths, made repairs. Next to him also, Hananiah the son of one of the perfumers, made repairs, and they strengthened Jerusalem up to the broad wall.
16:3:9/And right next to them, Rephaiah the son of Hur, the leader of half of Jerusalem, made repairs.
16:3:10/And right next to them, Jedaiah the son of Harumaph made repairs, right across from his house. And next to him, Hattush the son of Hashabniah made repairs.
16:3:11/Malchijah the son of Harim, and Hashub the son of Pahathmoab, repaired another section, and the tower of the furnaces.
16:3:12/And right next to him, Shallum the son of Halohesh, the leader of half of Jerusalem, made repairs, he and his daughters.
16:3:13/The valley gate was repaired by Hanun, and the inhabitants of Zanoah; they built it, and installed its doors, its locks, and its bars, and a thousand cubits on the wall up to the dung gate.
16:3:14/But the dung gate was repaired by Malchiah the son of Rechab, the leader of part of Bethhaccerem; he built it, and installed its doors, its locks, and its bars.
16:3:15/But the gate of the fountain was repaired by Shallun the son of Colhozeh, the leader of part of Mizpah; he built it, covered it, and installed its doors, its locks, and its bars, and the wall of the pool of Siloah by the king’s garden, and up to the stairs that go down from the city of David.
16:3:16/After him, Nehemiah the son of Azbuk, the leader of half of Bethzur, made repairs, up to the area opposite the tombs of David, and to the pool that was made, and up to the house of the warriors.
16:3:17/After him, the Levites, Rehum the son of Bani, made repairs. Next to him, Hashabiah, the leader of half of Keilah, made repairs in his area.
16:3:18/After him, their brothers, Bavai the son of Henadad, the leader of half of Keilah, made repairs.
16:3:19/And next to him, Ezer the son of Jeshua, the leader of Mizpah, repaired another section opposite the ascent to the armory at the angle of the wall.
16:3:20/After him, Baruch the son of Zabbai zealously repaired another section, from the angle of the wall to the door of the house of Eliashib the high priest.
16:3:21/After him, Meremoth the son of Urijah the son of Koz repaired another section, from the door of the house of Eliashib to the end of the house of Eliashib.
16:3:22/And after him, the priests, the men of the plain, made repairs.
16:3:23/After him, Benjamin and Hashub made repairs opposite their house. After him, Azariah the son of Maaseiah the son of Ananiah made repairs beside his house.
16:3:24/After him, Binnui the son of Henadad repaired another section, from the house of Azariah to the angle of the wall, even to the corner.
16:3:25/Palal the son of Uzai, opposite the angle of the wall, and the tower projecting from the king’s upper house, that was by the court of the prison. After him, Pedaiah the son of Parosh.
16:3:26/Moreover, the temple servants lived in Ophel, up to the area opposite the water gate toward the east, and the projecting tower.
16:3:27/After them, the Tekoites repaired another section, opposite the great projecting tower, and up to the wall of Ophel.
16:3:28/Above the horse gate, the priests made repairs, each one opposite his house.
16:3:29/After them, Zadok the son of Immer made repairs opposite his house. After him, Shemaiah the son of Shechaniah, the keeper of the east gate, made repairs.
16:3:30/After him, Hananiah the son of Shelemiah, and Hanun the sixth son of Zalaph, repaired another section. After him, Meshullam the son of Berechiah made repairs opposite his living quarters.
16:3:31/After him, Malchiah one of the goldsmiths made repairs up to the area of the temple servants and the merchants, opposite the Inspection Gate, and up to the room above the corner.
16:3:32/And between the room above the corner to the sheep gate, the goldsmiths and the merchants made repairs.
16:4:1/But it happened that when Sanballat heard we were rebuilding the wall, he became furious, greatly insulted, and ridiculed the Jews.
16:4:2/He spoke in front of his brothers and the Samarian army, saying, "What are these weak Jews doing? Can they restore their walls? Will they offer sacrifices? Can they finish in a day? Can they bring the stones back to life from the piles of rubble that have been burned?"
16:4:3/Now Tobiah the Ammonite was with him, and he said, "Even if a fox climbed on what they are building, it would break down their stone wall."
16:4:4/Hear us, O our God, for we are scorned: turn their mockery back on them and make them captives in a land of exile.
16:4:5/Do not cover their guilt or let their sin be erased from your sight, for they have angered you in front of the builders.
16:4:6/So we continued to build the wall; and the entire wall was joined together up to half its height, because the people were committed to the work.
16:4:7/But when Sanballat, Tobiah, the Arabs, the Ammonites, and the people of Ashdod heard that the repairs to Jerusalem's walls were progressing and the gaps were being closed, they were extremely angry.
16:4:8/They all plotted together to come and fight against Jerusalem and create confusion.
16:4:9/However, we prayed to our God and posted a guard day and night to meet this threat.
16:4:10/And Judah said, "The strength of the laborers is failing, and there is so much rubble that we cannot rebuild the wall."
16:4:11/Our enemies said, "They won't know or see anything until we're right among them, killing them and stopping the work."
16:4:12/When the Jews living near them came and told us ten times over, "Wherever you turn, they will attack us,"
16:4:13/So I stationed people in the lowest parts of the space behind the wall, in exposed places, and I stationed them by families with their swords, spears, and bows.
16:4:14/Then I looked things over and stood up and said to the nobles, the officials, and the rest of the people, "Don't be afraid of them. Remember the Lord, who is great and awe-inspiring, and fight for your brothers, your sons, your daughters, your wives, and your homes."
16:4:15/When our enemies heard that we were aware of their plot and that God had frustrated it, we all returned to the wall, each to our own work.
16:4:16/From that day on, half of my men did the work, while the other half were equipped with spears, shields, bows, and armor. The officials supported all the people of Judah,
16:4:17/who were building the wall. Those who carried materials did their work with one hand and held a weapon with the other,
16:4:18/And each of the builders had his sword strapped at his side while he built. The man who sounded the trumpet stayed with me.
16:4:19/And I said to the nobles, the officials, and the rest of the people, "The work is extensive and spread out, and we are widely separated from each other along the wall.
16:4:20/Wherever you hear the sound of the trumpet, join us there. Our God will fight for us."
16:4:21/So we continued the work with half the men holding spears from the first light of dawn until the stars came out.
16:4:22/At the same time, I also said to the people, "Let every man and his servant spend the night inside Jerusalem, so they can serve as guards by night and work by day."
16:4:23/So neither I, my brothers, my servants, nor the men of the guard who followed me, took off our clothes; each kept his weapon at his right hand, except when washing.
16:5:1/There was a loud outcry from the people and their wives against their fellow Jews.
16:5:2/Many said, "We have large families: we need to get grain so we can eat and stay alive."
16:5:3/Others said, "We've had to mortgage our lands, vineyards, and homes to buy grain because of the famine."
16:5:4/Some said, "We've had to borrow money to pay the king's tax, using our lands and vineyards as collateral."
16:5:5/Yet now, we are no different from our fellow Jews; our children are like theirs. Yet we are forced to enslave our sons and daughters, and some of our daughters have already been enslaved. We are powerless to help them, for others now own our lands and vineyards.
16:5:6/I was extremely angry when I heard their outcry and these complaints.
16:5:7/So I thought it over and confronted the nobles and officials, telling them, "You are charging your own people interest!" Then I called a large meeting to deal with them.
16:5:8/I told them, "We have done our best to buy back our fellow Jews who were sold to the Gentiles. And now you are selling your own people, only for them to be sold back to us!" They kept quiet, unable to respond.
16:5:9/I also said, "What you're doing isn't right. Shouldn't you walk in the fear of our God to avoid the reproach of our Gentile enemies?"
16:5:10/I and my brothers and my men could also claim money and grain from them, but let's stop charging this interest.
16:5:11/Please, give back to them today their fields, vineyards, olive groves, and houses, and also the interest on the money, grain, new wine, and olive oil that you have been charging them."
16:5:12/They said, "We will give it back and will not demand anything more from them. We will do as you say." Then I summoned the priests and made the nobles and officials swear to do what they had promised.
16:5:13/I also shook out the folds of my robe and said, "In this way may God shake out of their house and possessions anyone who does not keep this promise. So may such a person be shaken out and emptied!" The whole assembly said, "Amen," and praised the Lord. And the people did as they had promised.
16:5:14/Moreover, from the time I was appointed as their governor in the land of Judah, from the twentieth year to the thirty-second year of King Artaxerxes—twelve years—I and my brothers did not eat the food allotted to the governor.
16:5:15/But the earlier governors—those preceding me—placed a heavy burden on the people and took forty shekels of silver from them in addition to food and wine. Their assistants also lorded it over the people. But out of reverence for God, I did not act like that.
16:5:16/Instead, I devoted myself to the work on this wall. All my men were assembled there for the work; we did not acquire any land.
16:5:17/Furthermore, at my table were 150 Jews and officials, in addition to those who came to us from the nations around us.
16:5:18/Now what was prepared for me daily was one ox and six choice sheep, and birds, and every ten days an abundant supply of wine of all kinds. Yet with all this, I did not demand the governor's provisions, because the demands were heavy on this people.
16:5:19/Remember me with favor, my God, for all I have done for these people.
16:6:1/When Sanballat, Tobiah, Geshem the Arabian, and our other enemies found out that I had rebuilt the wall without any gaps left in it (even though I hadn't yet installed the gates), 
16:6:2/Sanballat and Geshem sent me a message, suggesting we meet in one of the villages in the plain of Ono. But they were planning to harm me.
16:6:3/I sent messengers back to them, saying, "I'm working on a big project and can't come down. Why should the work stop while I leave it to come down to you?"
16:6:4/They kept sending me the same message four times, and I responded in the same way each time.
16:6:5/Then Sanballat sent his servant to me with the same message a fifth time, holding an open letter.
16:6:6/The letter claimed, "It's rumored among the nations, and Gashmu says it's true, that you and the Jews plan to rebel. That's why you're building the wall, and you aim to be their king, as the rumors say.
16:6:7/You've also supposedly appointed prophets to proclaim in Jerusalem that there's a king in Judah. Now, these rumors will reach the king. So, let's meet and discuss this."
16:6:8/I sent back a message saying, "Nothing like what you're saying is happening; you're just making it up in your head."
16:6:9/They were all trying to scare us, thinking, "Their hands will get too weak for the work, and it won't be completed." But I prayed, "Now, God, strengthen my hands."
16:6:10/Later, I went to the house of Shemaiah, who was confined to his home. He said, "Let's meet inside the temple and close the doors, because they're coming to kill you—at night, they're coming to kill you."
16:6:11/But I said, "Should someone like me run away? And who like me would go into the temple to save his life? I won't go in."
16:6:12/Then I realized that God hadn't sent him, but he had prophesied against me because Tobiah and Sanballat had hired him.
16:6:13/He was hired to intimidate me so I would commit a sin by doing this, and then they would have something to use to discredit me.
16:6:14/My God, remember Tobiah and Sanballat for what they have done, and also the prophetess Noadiah and the rest of the prophets who have been trying to scare me.
16:6:15/So the wall was completed on the twenty-fifth day of the month Elul, in fifty-two days.
16:6:16/When all our enemies heard about this, all the surrounding nations were afraid and lost their self-confidence, because they realized that this work had been done with the help of our God.
16:6:17/Meanwhile, during this time, the nobles of Judah sent many letters to Tobiah, and Tobiah's letters came to them.
16:6:18/For many in Judah were bound by oath to him because he was the son-in-law of Shechaniah the son of Arah, and his son Johanan had married the daughter of Meshullam the son of Berechiah.
16:6:19/They kept telling me about his good deeds and then telling him what I said. And Tobiah sent letters to intimidate me.
16:7:1/When the wall was finished, and I had installed the doors, and assigned roles to the gatekeepers, musicians, and Levites,
16:7:2/I put my brother Hanani, along with Hananiah, the palace administrator, in charge of Jerusalem because he was a reliable man who revered God more than most.
16:7:3/I instructed them not to open the gates of Jerusalem until the sun was high in the sky; and even then, they should close and secure the doors while they stood guard. Also, I arranged for residents of Jerusalem to take turns on watch, each in front of his own home.
16:7:4/Although the city was large and spacious, there were few people living in it, and the houses had not yet been rebuilt.
16:7:5/God inspired me to assemble the nobles, officials, and common people to be registered by family. I found the family records of those who had first returned from exile and recorded them.
16:7:6/These are the people of the province who returned from the captivity of those who had been exiled, whom Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, had taken away, and who came back to Jerusalem and Judah, each to his own city;
16:7:7/Among them were Zerubbabel, Jeshua, Nehemiah, Azariah, Raamiah, Nahamani, Mordecai, Bilshan, Mispereth, Bigvai, Nehum, Baanah. The total number of men from the people of Israel was as follows;

16:7:60/All the temple servants and the descendants of Solomon’s servants totaled three hundred ninety-two.
16:7:61/These are the ones who came up from Tel Melah, Tel Harsha, Cherub, Addon, and Immer, but they could not prove their families or lineage as being from Israel:
16:7:62/The descendants of Delaiah, the descendants of Tobiah, the descendants of Nekoda, six hundred forty-two.
16:7:63/Among the priests: the descendants of Hobaiah, the descendants of Koz, the descendants of Barzillai, who married one of the daughters of Barzillai the Gileadite and was called by their name.
16:7:64/They searched for their records in the genealogical listings, but they were not found, so they were disqualified from the priesthood as unclean.
16:7:65/The governor told them they could not eat from the most sacred offerings until a priest could consult the Urim and Thummim.
16:7:66/The entire assembly numbered forty-two thousand three hundred sixty,
16:7:67/Besides their male and female servants, who numbered seven thousand three hundred thirty-seven. They also had two hundred forty-five male and female singers.
16:7:68/They had seven hundred thirty-six horses, two hundred forty-five mules,
16:7:69/Four hundred thirty-five camels, and six thousand seven hundred twenty donkeys.
16:7:70/Some of the heads of families contributed to the work. The governor gave to the treasury one thousand drams of gold, fifty basins, and five hundred thirty priestly garments.
16:7:71/Some of the heads of families gave to the treasury for the work twenty thousand drams of gold and two thousand two hundred pounds of silver.
16:7:72/And what the rest of the people gave was twenty thousand drams of gold, two thousand pounds of silver, and sixty-seven priestly garments.
16:7:73/So the priests, the Levites, the gatekeepers, the singers, some of the people, the temple servants, and all Israel, settled in their towns. By the seventh month, the Israelites were in their own towns.
16:8:1/All the people came together as one in the street before the water gate; they asked Ezra the scribe to bring out the book of the law of Moses, which the LORD had given to Israel.
16:8:2/Ezra the priest brought the law before the assembly, which included men, women, and all who could understand, on the first day of the seventh month.
16:8:3/He read from it in the street before the water gate from morning until noon, in front of the men, women, and those who could understand; and everyone listened attentively to the book of the law.
16:8:4/Ezra the scribe stood on a wooden platform built for the occasion. Beside him stood Mattithiah, Shema, Anaiah, Urijah, Hilkiah, and Maaseiah on his right side; and on his left side, Pedaiah, Mishael, Malchiah, Hashum, Hashbadana, Zechariah, and Meshullam.
16:8:5/Ezra opened the book in full view of all the people; (since he was above everyone;) and when he opened it, everyone stood up.
16:8:6/Ezra praised the LORD, the great God. And all the people responded, "Amen, Amen," lifting their hands. Then they bowed down and worshiped the LORD with their faces to the ground.
16:8:7/Also Jeshua, Bani, Sherebiah, Jamin, Akkub, Shabbethai, Hodijah, Maaseiah, Kelita, Azariah, Jozabad, Hanan, Pelaiah, and the Levites helped the people understand the law: and the people remained in their places.
16:8:8/So they read from the book of the law of God clearly, and explained it, helping the people understand the meaning.
16:8:9/Nehemiah, who was the governor, Ezra the priest and scribe, and the Levites who were instructing the people said to them, "This day is sacred to the LORD your God; do not mourn or weep." For all the people were weeping as they listened to the words of the law.
16:8:10/Then he said to them, "Go and enjoy choice food and sweet drinks, and send some to those who have nothing prepared. This day is sacred to our LORD. Do not grieve, for the joy of the LORD is your strength."
16:8:11/The Levites calmed all the people, saying, "Be still, for this is a sacred day. Do not be sad."
16:8:12/And all the people went away to eat and drink, to send portions of food, and to celebrate with great joy, because they now understood the words that had been made known to them.
16:8:13/On the second day, the heads of all the families, along with the priests and the Levites, gathered around Ezra the scribe to study the words of the law.
16:8:14/They discovered in the law, which the LORD had commanded through Moses, that the Israelites were to live in temporary shelters during the festival of the seventh month.
16:8:15/They were to announce and proclaim in all their towns and in Jerusalem: "Go out to the hills and bring back branches from olive and wild olive trees, and from myrtles, palms and other leafy trees to make temporary shelters—as it is written."
16:8:16/So the people went out and brought back branches and built themselves temporary shelters on their own roofs, in their courtyards, in the courtyards of the house of God, and in the squares at the Water Gate and the Gate of Ephraim.
16:8:17/The whole company that had returned from exile built temporary shelters and lived in them. From the days of Joshua son of Nun until that day, the Israelites had not celebrated it like this. And their joy was very great.
16:8:18/Day after day, from the first day to the last, Ezra read from the book of the law of God. They celebrated the festival for seven days, and on the eighth day, in accordance with the regulation, there was an assembly.
16:9:1/On the twenty-fourth day of this month, the people of Israel gathered together, fasting, wearing sackcloth, and with dust on their heads.
16:9:2/The people of Israel separated themselves from all foreigners, stood up, and confessed their sins and the wrongdoings of their ancestors.
16:9:3/They stood in their places and read from the book of the law of the LORD their God for a quarter of the day; for another quarter, they confessed and worshiped the LORD their God.
16:9:4/Then, the Levites—Jeshua, Bani, Kadmiel, Shebaniah, Bunni, Sherebiah, Bani, and Chenani—stood on the steps and called out to the LORD their God with loud voices.
16:9:5/Then the Levites—Jeshua, Kadmiel, Bani, Hashabniah, Sherebiah, Hodijah, Shebaniah, and Pethahiah—said, "Stand up and praise the LORD your God forever and ever: and may your glorious name be blessed, exalted above all blessing and praise."
16:9:6/You alone are LORD; you created the heavens, the highest heavens with all their stars, the earth and everything on it, the seas and all within them. You give life to everything, and the heavenly hosts worship you.
16:9:7/You are the LORD God, who chose Abram, led him out of Ur of the Chaldeans, and named him Abraham.
16:9:8/You found his heart faithful before you, made a covenant with him to give the land of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Jebusites, and Girgashites to his descendants. You have kept your promise because you are righteous.
16:9:9/You saw the suffering of our ancestors in Egypt and heard their cry at the Red Sea.
16:9:10/You performed signs and wonders against Pharaoh, all his servants, and the people of his land, because you knew they were arrogant toward them. You made a name for yourself, which remains to this day.
16:9:11/You split the sea before them, so they passed through it on dry ground, but you hurled their pursuers into the depths, like a stone into mighty waters.
16:9:12/You led them with a pillar of cloud by day and a pillar of fire by night to light the way they should go.
16:9:13/You came down on Mount Sinai, spoke to them from heaven, and gave them just laws, true teachings, good statutes, and commandments.
16:9:14/You made known to them your holy Sabbath and gave them commands, statutes, and laws through your servant Moses.
16:9:15/You provided them bread from heaven for their hunger and brought water from a rock for their thirst. You promised them that they would enter and possess the land you had sworn to give them.
16:9:16/But they and our ancestors acted arrogantly, stiffened their necks, and did not obey your commands.
16:9:17/They refused to listen and failed to remember the wonders you performed among them. They became stiff-necked and in their rebellion appointed a leader to return to their slavery. But you are a forgiving God, gracious and compassionate, slow to anger and abounding in love. Therefore, you did not abandon them.
16:9:18/Even when they made for themselves a cast image of a calf and said, 'This is your god who brought you up out of Egypt,' and committed great blasphemies,
16:9:19/In your great mercy, you did not abandon them in the wilderness. The pillar of cloud did not fail to guide them on their path by day, nor the pillar of fire by night to shine on the way they were to take.
16:9:20/You gave your good Spirit to instruct them, did not withhold your manna from their mouths, and gave them water for their thirst.
16:9:21/For forty years you sustained them in the wilderness; they lacked nothing, their clothes did not wear out, and their feet did not swell.
16:9:22/You gave them kingdoms and nations, allotting to them even the remotest frontiers. They took over the land of Sihon king of Heshbon and the land of Og king of Bashan.
16:9:23/You made their children as numerous as the stars in the sky, and you brought them into the land that you told their parents to enter and possess.
16:9:24/So their descendants went in and possessed the land; you subdued before them the Canaanites, who inhabited the land. You gave the Canaanites over to them, along with their kings and the peoples of the land, to deal with as they wished.
16:9:25/They captured fortified cities and fertile land; they took possession of houses filled with all kinds of good things, wells already dug, vineyards, olive groves, and fruit trees in abundance. They ate to the full and were well-nourished; they reveled in your great goodness.
16:9:26/Yet they were disobedient and rebelled against you; they turned their backs on your law. They killed your prophets, who had warned them in order to turn them back to you; they committed awful blasphemies.
16:9:27/So you delivered them into the hands of their enemies, who oppressed them. But when they were oppressed, they cried out to you. From heaven you heard them, and in your great compassion you gave them deliverers, who rescued them from the hand of their enemies.
16:9:28/But as soon as they had rest, they did evil again before you. Therefore, you left them in the hands of their enemies so that they had dominion over them. Yet when they turned and cried to you, you heard from heaven, and many times you delivered them according to your mercies.
16:9:29/You warned them in order to turn them back to your law, but they became arrogant and disobeyed your commands; they sinned against your ordinances, which if a person follows, they will live by them. Stubbornly they turned their backs on you, became stiff-necked, and refused to listen.
16:9:30/For many years you were patient with them. By your Spirit you warned them through your prophets. Yet they would not listen, so you gave them into the hands of the neighboring peoples.
16:9:31/However, in your great mercy you did not put an end to them or abandon them, for you are a gracious and merciful God.
16:9:32/Now, our God, the great, mighty, and awe-inspiring God, who keeps his covenant of love, do not let all the hardship seem trivial before you that has come upon us, our kings and leaders, our priests and prophets, our ancestors and all your people, from the days of the kings of Assyria until today.
16:9:33/In all that has happened to us, you have remained righteous; you have acted faithfully, while we acted wickedly.
16:9:34/Our kings, our leaders, our priests, and our ancestors did not follow your law; they did not pay attention to your commands or the statutes you warned them to keep.
16:9:35/Even in their own kingdom, enjoying your great goodness to them in the vast and fertile land you gave them, they did not serve you or turn from their evil deeds.
16:9:36/See, we are slaves today, slaves in the land you gave our ancestors so they could eat its fruit and the other good things it produces.
16:9:37/Because of our sins, its abundant harvest goes to the kings you have placed over us. They rule over our bodies and our cattle as they please. We are in great distress.
16:9:38/In view of all this, we are making a binding agreement, putting it in writing, and our leaders, our Levites, and our priests are affixing their seals to it.
16:10:1/Now those who made the agreement were Nehemiah, the governor, the son of Hachaliah, and Zidkijah,
16:10:2/Seraiah, Azariah, Jeremiah,
16:10:3/Pashur, Amariah, Malchijah,
16:10:4/Hattush, Shebaniah, Malluch,

16:10:6/Daniel, Ginnethon, Baruch,
16:10:7/Meshullam, Abijah, Mijamin,
16:10:8/Maaziah, Bilgai, Shemaiah: these were the priests.

16:10:17/Ater, Hizkijah, Azzur,

16:10:27/Malluch, Harim, Baanah.
16:10:28/And the rest of the people, the priests, the Levites, the gatekeepers, the singers, the temple servants, and all who had separated themselves from the people of the lands to follow the law of God, their wives, their sons, and their daughters, everyone who had knowledge and understanding;
16:10:29/They joined with their fellow leaders and entered into a binding agreement to follow the law of God given through Moses the servant of God, to obey all the commands of the LORD our Lord, and his rules and statutes;
16:10:30/And that we would not marry our daughters to the people of the land or take their daughters for our sons;
16:10:31/And if the people of the land bring goods or any food to sell on the Sabbath, we would not buy it from them on the Sabbath or on a holy day. And we would forego the seventh year's produce and the cancellation of every debt.
16:10:32/Also, we agreed to impose on ourselves an annual tax of a third of a shekel for the service of the house of our God;
16:10:33/For the bread set on the table, for the regular grain offering, for the regular burnt offering, for the Sabbaths, the new moons, for the appointed festivals, for the holy things, and for the sin offerings to make atonement for Israel, and for all the work of the house of our God.
16:10:34/And we cast lots among the priests, the Levites, and the people for the supply of wood to bring to the house of our God, according to our family divisions, at set times each year, to burn on the altar of the LORD our God as it is written in the law.
16:10:35/And to bring the firstfruits of our soil and the firstfruits of all fruit from all trees, year by year, to the house of the LORD;
16:10:36/Also the firstborn of our sons and of our cattle, as it is written in the law, and the firstborn of our herds and flocks, to bring to the house of our God, to the priests ministering in the house of our God;
16:10:37/And to bring the first of our dough, our contributions, the fruit from all kinds of trees, the new wine and oil, to the priests, to the chambers of the house of our God; and to bring to the Levites the tithes from our ground, for it is the Levites who collect the tithes in all our agricultural towns.
16:10:38/And the priest, the descendant of Aaron, shall be with the Levites when the Levites receive tithes, and the Levites shall bring up a tenth of the tithes to the house of our God, to the chambers, into the treasury.
16:10:39/For the children of Israel and the children of Levi shall bring the contribution of grain, new wine, and oil to the chambers where the vessels of the sanctuary are, as well as the ministering priests, the gatekeepers, and the singers. And we will not neglect the house of our God.
16:11:1/The leaders of the people lived in Jerusalem: the rest of the people also drew lots, to bring one out of every ten to live in Jerusalem, the holy city, while the other nine parts lived in other cities.
16:11:2/And the people praised all the men who willingly offered themselves to live in Jerusalem.
16:11:3/These are the main leaders of the province who lived in Jerusalem: but in the cities of Judah, everyone lived on their own property in their cities, including Israelites, priests, Levites, temple servants, and the descendants of Solomon's servants.
16:11:4/In Jerusalem lived some of the descendants of Judah and Benjamin. From the descendants of Judah: Athaiah son of Uzziah, son of Zechariah, son of Amariah, son of Shephatiah, son of Mahalaleel, from the descendants of Perez;
16:11:5/And Maaseiah son of Baruch, son of Colhozeh, son of Hazaiah, son of Adaiah, son of Joiarib, son of Zechariah, son of Shiloni.
16:11:6/All the descendants of Perez who lived in Jerusalem were four hundred sixty-eight brave men.
16:11:7/And these are the descendants of Benjamin; Sallu son of Meshullam, son of Joed, son of Pedaiah, son of Kolaiah, son of Maaseiah, son of Ithiel, son of Jesaiah.
16:11:8/And following him were Gabbai, Sallai, nine hundred twenty-eight.
16:11:9/And Joel son of Zichri was their overseer; and Judah son of Senuah was second in charge of the city.
16:11:10/Among the priests: Jedaiah son of Joiarib, Jachin.
16:11:11/Seraiah son of Hilkiah, son of Meshullam, son of Zadok, son of Meraioth, son of Ahitub, was the leader of the house of God.
16:11:12/And their brothers who worked in the house were eight hundred twenty-two: and Adaiah son of Jeroham, son of Pelaliah, son of Amzi, son of Zechariah, son of Pashur, son of Malchiah.
16:11:13/And his brothers, leaders of the families, two hundred forty-two: and Amashai son of Azareel, son of Ahasai, son of Meshillemoth, son of Immer,
16:11:14/And their brothers, strong warriors, one hundred twenty-eight: and their overseer was Zabdiel, son of one of the great men.
16:11:15/Also among the Levites: Shemaiah son of Hashub, son of Azrikam, son of Hashabiah, son of Bunni;
16:11:16/And Shabbethai and Jozabad, among the leaders of the Levites, were in charge of the external affairs of the house of God.
16:11:17/And Mattaniah son of Micha, son of Zabdi, son of Asaph, was the lead in starting the thanksgiving in prayer: and Bakbukiah the second among his brothers, and Abda son of Shammua, son of Galal, son of Jeduthun.
16:11:18/All the Levites in the holy city were two hundred eighty-four.
16:11:19/Furthermore, the gatekeepers, Akkub, Talmon, and their brothers who guarded the gates, were one hundred seventy-two.
16:11:20/And the rest of Israel, the priests, and the Levites, were in all the cities of Judah, each in his inheritance.
16:11:21/But the temple servants lived in Ophel: and Ziha and Gispa were in charge of the temple servants.
16:11:22/The overseer of the Levites in Jerusalem was Uzzi son of Bani, son of Hashabiah, son of Mattaniah, son of Micha. From the descendants of Asaph, the singers were in charge of the service of the house of God.
16:11:23/For it was the king's command concerning them, that a specific portion should be for the singers, as due for every day.
16:11:24/And Pethahiah son of Meshezabeel, from the descendants of Zerah son of Judah, was the king's advisor in all matters concerning the people.
16:11:25/And regarding the villages and their fields, some of the descendants of Judah lived at Kirjatharba and its surrounding villages, at Dibon and its villages, and at Jekabzeel and its villages,

16:12:11/And Joiada fathered Jonathan, and Jonathan fathered Jaddua.
