16:12:20/From Sallai's, Kallai; from Amok's, Eber;
16:12:21/From Hilkiah's, Hashabiah; from Jedaiah's, Nethaneel.
16:12:22/During the time of Eliashib, Joiada, Johanan, and Jaddua, the Levites were recorded as heads of fathers' houses; likewise, the priests during the reign of Darius the Persian.
16:12:23/The descendants of Levi, the heads of fathers' houses, were documented in the chronicles until the time of Johanan son of Eliashib.
16:12:24/And the leaders of the Levites were Hashabiah, Sherebiah, and Jeshua son of Kadmiel, along with their relatives opposite them, to praise and give thanks as prescribed by David the man of God, section opposite section.
16:12:25/Mattaniah, Bakbukiah, Obadiah, Meshullam, Talmon, Akkub were gatekeepers guarding the storerooms at the gateways.
16:12:26/This occurred during the time of Joiakim son of Jeshua, son of Jozadak, and during the time of Nehemiah the governor and Ezra the priest and scribe.
16:12:27/For the dedication of the wall of Jerusalem, they sought out the Levites from all their places to bring them to Jerusalem to celebrate the dedication joyfully with thanksgivings, singing, cymbals, lyres, and harps.
16:12:28/The singers gathered from the region around Jerusalem, from the villages of the Netophathites,
16:12:29/Also from the house of Gilgal and the fields of Geba and Azmaveth, for the singers had built villages for themselves around Jerusalem.
16:12:30/The priests and Levites purified themselves, and also purified the people, the gates, and the wall.
16:12:31/Then I led the leaders of Judah up onto the wall and organized two large choirs to give thanks. One group proceeded to the right on the wall toward the Dung Gate.
16:12:32/And following them went Hoshaiah and half the leaders of Judah,
16:12:33/And Azariah, Ezra, and Meshullam,
16:12:34/Judah, Benjamin, Shemaiah, and Jeremiah,
16:12:35/And some of the priests' sons with trumpets; namely, Zechariah son of Jonathan, son of Shemaiah, son of Mattaniah, son of Michaiah, son of Zaccur, son of Asaph,
16:12:36/And his relatives, Shemaiah, Azarael, Milalai, Gilalai, Maai, Nethaneel, Judah, and Hanani, with the musical instruments of David the man of God. Ezra the scribe led the procession.
16:12:37/At the Fountain Gate, opposite them, they went up the steps of the city of David on the ascent of the wall, above the house of David, to the Water Gate on the east.
16:12:38/The second choir proceeded in the opposite direction. I followed them on the wall, along with half the people, past the Tower of the Ovens to the Broad Wall,
16:12:39/And past the Gate of Ephraim, the Old Gate, the Fish Gate, the Tower of Hananel, and the Tower of the Hundred, to the Sheep Gate. They stopped at the Gate of the Guard.
16:12:40/So both choirs took their positions in the house of God. So did I, along with half the officials,
16:12:41/And the priests; Eliakim, Maaseiah, Miniamin, Michaiah, Elioenai, Zechariah, and Hananiah, with trumpets,
16:12:42/And Maaseiah, Shemaiah, Eleazar, Uzzi, Jehohanan, Malchijah, Elam, and Ezer. The singers sang loudly under the direction of Jezrahiah.
16:12:43/On that day, they offered great sacrifices and rejoiced because God had given them great joy. The women and children also rejoiced, so the joy of Jerusalem was heard far away.
16:12:44/At that time, officials were appointed over the storerooms for the contributions, firstfruits, and tithes. From the fields of the cities, they were to collect the portions required by the law for the priests and Levites, for Judah was pleased with the ministering priests and Levites.
16:12:45/And they performed the service of their God and the service of purification, as did the singers and gatekeepers, according to the commandments of David and his son Solomon.
16:12:46/For long ago, in the days of David and Asaph, there were leaders of the singers and songs of praise and thanksgiving to God.
16:12:47/And all Israel, during the times of Zerubbabel and Nehemiah, provided for the singers and gatekeepers their daily portions. They also set aside the sacred portion for the Levites, and the Levites consecrated it for the descendants of Aaron.
16:13:1/On that day, they read from the book of Moses to the people; and it was found written that the Ammonite and the Moabite should never be allowed into the congregation of God;
16:13:2/Because they did not welcome the children of Israel with food and water, but instead hired Balaam to curse them. However, our God turned the curse into a blessing.
16:13:3/So, when they heard the law, they excluded from Israel all those of mixed ancestry.
16:13:4/Before this, Eliashib the priest, who was in charge of the storerooms of our God's house, had allied himself with Tobiah:
16:13:5/He had prepared a large room for him, previously used to store the grain offerings, the incense, and the temple vessels, as well as the tithes of grain, wine, and oil prescribed for the Levites, musicians, gatekeepers, and the contributions for the priests.
16:13:6/But during all this time, I was not in Jerusalem, for in the thirty-second year of Artaxerxes king of Babylon, I had gone to the king. After some time, I asked the king for permission to return,
16:13:7/And when I arrived in Jerusalem, I learned about the wrong Eliashib had done for Tobiah by providing him a room in the courts of God's house.
16:13:8/This greatly upset me, so I threw all of Tobiah's household goods out of the room.
16:13:9/Then I ordered the rooms to be purified, and I brought back into them the temple vessels, along with the grain offering and the incense.
16:13:10/And I noticed that the portions for the Levites had not been given to them, causing the Levites and musicians responsible for the service to abandon their duties and return to their fields.
16:13:11/So I rebuked the officials and asked, "Why is God's house being neglected?" Then I gathered them together and reinstated them to their positions.
16:13:12/Then all Judah brought the tithe of the grain, wine, and oil into the storerooms.
16:13:13/And I appointed as treasurers over the storerooms Shelemiah the priest, Zadok the scribe, and Pedaiah of the Levites, with Hanan son of Zaccur, son of Mattaniah, assisting them because they were considered trustworthy. Their responsibility was to distribute the supplies to their fellow Levites.
16:13:14/Remember me for this, my God, and do not erase the good deeds I have done for the house of my God and its services.
16:13:15/At that time, I saw in Judah people treading winepresses on the Sabbath, bringing in heaps of grain and loading donkeys with wine, grapes, figs, and all kinds of burdens, which they brought into Jerusalem on the Sabbath day. I warned them on the day they sold food.
16:13:16/Merchants from Tyre who lived in the city were bringing in fish and all kinds of goods and selling them on the Sabbath to the people of Judah in Jerusalem.
16:13:17/Then I confronted the nobles of Judah and said to them, "What is this evil thing you are doing, desecrating the Sabbath day?
16:13:18/Didn't your ancestors do the same, and didn't our God bring all this disaster on us and on this city? Yet you are adding to the wrath against Israel by desecrating the Sabbath."
16:13:19/When the gates of Jerusalem began to be dark before the Sabbath, I ordered the gates to be shut and not opened until after the Sabbath. I stationed some of my men at the gates to ensure that no load would be brought in on the Sabbath day.
16:13:20/So the merchants and sellers of all kinds of goods spent the night outside Jerusalem once or twice.
16:13:21/Then I warned them and said, "Why do you spend the night by the wall? If you do this again, I will use force against you." From that time on, they did not come on the Sabbath.
16:13:22/And I commanded the Levites to purify themselves and guard the gates to keep the Sabbath day holy. Remember me for this also, my God, and show me mercy according to your great love.
16:13:23/In those days, I also saw Jews who had married women from Ashdod, Ammon, and Moab;
16:13:24/And their children spoke half in the language of Ashdod and could not speak the language of the Jews, but only the language of each people.
16:13:25/And I confronted them, cursed them, beat some of their men, and pulled out their hair. I made them swear by God, "You shall not give your daughters in marriage to their sons, nor take their daughters for your sons or yourselves.
16:13:26/Didn't Solomon king of Israel sin because of such women? Despite his wisdom, foreign women led him into sin.
16:13:27/Should we then listen to you and do all this great evil, acting unfaithfully against our God by marrying foreign women?"
16:13:28/And one of the sons of Joiada, son of Eliashib the high priest, was son-in-law to Sanballat the Horonite, so I drove him away from me.
16:13:29/Remember them, my God, for defiling the priesthood and the covenant of the priesthood and the Levites.
16:13:30/So I purified them from everything foreign and assigned duties to the priests and Levites, each to his own task;
16:13:31/And for the wood offering, at designated times, and for the firstfruits. Remember me, my God, for good.
17:1:1/It happened during the reign of Ahasuerus, (this Ahasuerus ruled from India to Ethiopia, over 127 provinces):
17:1:2/In those days, when King Ahasuerus sat on his throne in Shushan the palace,
17:1:3/In the third year of his reign, he hosted a banquet for all his officials and servants; the military leaders of Persia and Media, the nobles, and the governors of the provinces were in attendance:
17:1:4/He displayed the wealth of his magnificent kingdom and the splendor of his majesty for many days, 180 days to be exact.
17:1:5/When these days were over, the king held a banquet for all the people present in Shushan the palace, both important and less so, for seven days, in the garden courtyard of the king's palace;
17:1:6/The courtyard had white, green, and blue curtains, tied with cords of fine linen and purple to silver rings and marble pillars: the couches were made of gold and silver, set upon a mosaic floor of red, blue, white, and black marble.
17:1:7/They served drinks in golden goblets, each one different from the other, and royal wine in abundance, as befits the king's wealth.
17:1:8/The drinking was without restraint; the king had ordered that everyone could drink as they pleased.
17:1:9/Queen Vashti also held a banquet for the women in the royal palace of King Ahasuerus.
17:1:10/On the seventh day, when King Ahasuerus was in high spirits from wine, he ordered Mehuman, Biztha, Harbona, Bigtha, Abagtha, Zethar, and Carcas, the seven eunuchs who served him,
17:1:11/To bring Queen Vashti before him, wearing her royal crown, to show off her beauty to the people and officials, for she was very beautiful.
17:1:12/But Queen Vashti refused to come at the king's command delivered by his eunuchs; therefore, the king became furious, and his anger burned within him.
17:1:13/Then the king consulted the experts who understood the times (for this was the king's procedure toward all who were versed in law and judgment:
17:1:14/And next to him were Carshena, Shethar, Admatha, Tarshish, Meres, Marsena, and Memucan, the seven princes of Persia and Media, who had access to the king and ranked highest in the kingdom);
17:1:15/"What action should be taken according to law against Queen Vashti for not obeying the command of King Ahasuerus delivered by the eunuchs?"
17:1:16/And Memucan replied in the presence of the king and the princes, "Queen Vashti has wronged not only the king but also all the princes and all the people in all the provinces of King Ahasuerus.
17:1:17/For the queen's behavior will become known to all women, causing them to look down on their husbands when they learn that King Ahasuerus commanded Queen Vashti to be brought before him, but she did not come.
17:1:18/This very day the noblewomen of Persia and Media who have heard about the queen's actions will say the same to all the king's officials, resulting in much contempt and anger.
17:1:19/If it pleases the king, let him issue a royal decree, and let it be written among the laws of the Persians and the Medes, so that it cannot be repealed, that Vashti is never again to enter the presence of King Ahasuerus. And let the king give her royal position to someone else who is better than she.
17:1:20/When the decree made by the king is proclaimed throughout his vast realm, all women will respect their husbands, from the greatest to the least."
17:1:21/The proposal pleased the king and the princes, and the king did as Memucan suggested:
17:1:22/He sent dispatches to all the king's provinces, to each province in its own script and to every people in their own language, declaring that every man should be master in his own house and that this should be proclaimed in the language of every people.
17:2:1/After these events, when King Ahasuerus's anger had cooled down, he remembered Vashti, what she had done, and the decree against her.
17:2:2/Then the king's attendants suggested, "Let beautiful young virgins be searched for the king:
17:2:3/And let the king appoint officials throughout all the provinces of his kingdom to bring all the beautiful young virgins to the palace in Shushan, to the women's quarters, under the care of Hegai, the king's eunuch in charge of the women, and let beauty treatments be provided for them:
17:2:4/And let the young woman who pleases the king become queen instead of Vashti." This idea pleased the king, and he followed through with it.
17:2:5/Now in the palace at Shushan, there lived a Jew named Mordecai, son of Jair, son of Shimei, son of Kish, a Benjaminite;
17:2:6/Who had been exiled from Jerusalem with the captives taken with Jeconiah king of Judah, whom Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon had exiled.
17:2:7/He was raising Hadassah, that is, Esther, his uncle's daughter, because she had no father or mother. The young woman was lovely and beautiful. When her parents died, Mordecai took her as his own daughter.
17:2:8/So when the king's command and decree were proclaimed, and many young women were brought to the palace in Shushan under the care of Hegai, Esther was also taken to the king's palace and placed under the care of Hegai, who was in charge of the women.
17:2:9/Esther won his favor and kindness, and he quickly provided her with her beauty treatments and special food, and assigned her seven maids from the king's palace. He moved her and her maids into the best place in the women's quarters.
17:2:10/Esther had not revealed her nationality or family background, because Mordecai had instructed her not to.
17:2:11/Mordecai walked back and forth near the courtyard of the women's quarters every day to find out how Esther was doing and what was happening to her.
17:2:12/When it was each young woman's turn to go to King Ahasuerus, after she had completed twelve months of beauty treatments prescribed for the women (six months with oil of myrrh and six months with perfumes and cosmetics),
17:2:13/She would go to the king in this way: whatever she desired was given to her to take with her from the women's quarters to the king's palace.
17:2:14/In the evening she would go, and in the morning she would return to the second women's quarters, under the care of Shaashgaz, the king's eunuch who was in charge of the concubines. She would not go to the king again unless he was pleased with her and summoned her by name.
17:2:15/When it was Esther's turn, the daughter of Abihail the uncle of Mordecai, who had taken her as his daughter, to go to the king, she asked for nothing except what Hegai, the king's eunuch in charge of the women, suggested. And Esther won the favor of everyone who saw her.
17:2:16/So Esther was taken to King Ahasuerus in his royal residence in the tenth month, the month of Tebeth, in the seventh year of his reign.
17:2:17/And the king loved Esther more than all the women, and she won his grace and favor more than all the virgins; so he placed the royal crown on her head and made her queen instead of Vashti.
17:2:18/Then the king threw a great banquet for all his officials and servants—it was Esther's banquet. He also declared a holiday for the provinces and gave gifts with royal generosity.
17:2:19/When the virgins were assembled a second time, Mordecai was sitting at the king's gate.
17:2:20/Esther had still not revealed her family background or her ethnicity, as Mordecai had instructed her. She followed Mordecai's orders just as she did when she was under his care.
17:2:21/At that time, while Mordecai was sitting at the king's gate, Bigthan and Teresh, two of the king's officers who guarded the doorway, became angry and conspired to assassinate King Ahasuerus.
17:2:22/But Mordecai found out about the plot and told Queen Esther, who in turn reported it to the king, giving credit to Mordecai.
17:2:23/When the affair was investigated and found to be true, the two officers were hanged on a gallows. And it was recorded in the book of the chronicles in the presence of the king.
17:3:1/After these events, King Ahasuerus promoted Haman, the son of Hammedatha the Agagite, elevating him and placing his seat above all the other princes.
17:3:2/All the king's servants at the king's gate bowed and showed respect to Haman, as the king had commanded. But Mordecai did not bow or show him respect.
17:3:3/Then the king's servants at the gate asked Mordecai, "Why are you disobeying the king's command?"
17:3:4/When they questioned him day after day and he did not listen to them, they told Haman to see if Mordecai's behavior would be tolerated since he had told them he was a Jew.
17:3:5/And when Haman noticed that Mordecai did not bow or show him respect, he was filled with anger.
17:3:6/But he scorned the idea of laying hands on Mordecai alone; after learning about Mordecai's people, Haman sought to destroy all the Jews throughout the entire kingdom of Ahasuerus, Mordecai's people.
17:3:7/In the first month, Nisan, in the twelfth year of King Ahasuerus, they cast Pur (that is, the lot) before Haman from day to day, and from month to month, until the twelfth month, Adar.
17:3:8/And Haman told King Ahasuerus, "There is a certain people scattered and dispersed among the peoples in all the provinces of your kingdom; their laws are different from those of all other people, and they do not obey the king's laws. Therefore, it is not in the king's interest to tolerate them.
17:3:9/"If it pleases the king, let a decree be issued to destroy them, and I will pay ten thousand talents of silver to the officials to bring into the king's treasuries."
17:3:10/And the king took his ring from his hand and gave it to Haman, the son of Hammedatha the Agagite, the enemy of the Jews.
17:3:11/Then the king said to Haman, "The money is given to you, and the people, to do with them as you see fit."
17:3:12/On the thirteenth day of the first month, the king's scribes were summoned, and a decree was written as Haman commanded to the king's satraps, the governors of every province, and the officials of every people, to each province in its own script and to each people in their own language. It was written in the name of King Ahasuerus and sealed with the king's ring.
17:3:13/The letters were sent by couriers to all the king's provinces with the order to destroy, kill, and annihilate all Jews, young and old, children and women, on a single day, the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, which is the month of Adar, and to plunder their possessions.
17:3:14/A copy of the edict to be issued as law in every province was made public to all the peoples, so that they would be ready for that day.
17:3:15/The couriers went out, spurred on by the king's command, and the decree was issued in the citadel of Susa. The king and Haman sat down to drink, but the city of Susa was bewildered.
17:4:1/When Mordecai realized everything that had happened, he tore his clothes, put on sackcloth and ashes, and went out into the city, crying loudly and bitterly.
17:4:2/And he went as far as the king's gate because no one was allowed to enter the king's gate wearing sackcloth.
17:4:3/In every province, wherever the king's command and decree reached, there was deep mourning among the Jews, with fasting, crying, and lamenting; and many wore sackcloth and ashes.
17:4:4/So when Esther's maids and eunuchs told her, the queen was deeply distressed; she sent clothes to dress Mordecai and to remove his sackcloth, but he did not accept them.
17:4:5/Then Esther summoned Hatach, one of the king's eunuchs assigned to her, and ordered him to go to Mordecai to find out what was happening and why.
17:4:6/So Hatach went out to Mordecai in the city square in front of the king's gate.
17:4:7/And Mordecai told him everything that had happened to him, including the amount of money Haman had promised to pay into the king's treasuries to have the Jews destroyed.
17:4:8/He also gave him a copy of the decree issued in Susa for their destruction to show to Esther and explain it to her, and he told her to go to the king to beg for mercy and plead with him for her people.
17:4:9/And Hatach went back and reported to Esther what Mordecai had said.
17:4:10/Again Esther spoke to Hatach and gave him a message for Mordecai:
17:4:11/Everyone in the king's service and the people of the king's provinces know that for any man or woman who approaches the king in the inner court without being summoned, the penalty is death, unless the king extends the gold scepter to them and spares their life. But it has been thirty days since I was called to go to the king.
17:4:12/And they relayed Esther's words to Mordecai.
17:4:13/Then Mordecai sent back this reply to Esther: "Do not think that because you are in the king's house, you alone of all the Jews will escape.
17:4:14/For if you remain silent at this time, relief and deliverance for the Jews will arise from another place, but you and your father's family will perish. And who knows but that you have come to your royal position for such a time as this?"
17:4:15/Then Esther sent this reply to Mordecai:
17:4:16/"Go, gather all the Jews who are in Susa, and fast for me. Do not eat or drink for three days, night or day. I and my attendants will fast as you do. After that, I will go to the king, even though it is against the law. And if I perish, I perish."
17:4:17/So Mordecai went away and carried out all of Esther's instructions.
17:5:1/On the third day, Esther put on her royal clothes and stood in the inner court of the king's palace, facing the king's residence. The king was sitting on his royal throne in the palace, facing the entrance.
17:5:2/When the king saw Queen Esther standing in the court, she won his favor. He extended to Esther the golden scepter in his hand. So, Esther approached and touched the top of the scepter.
17:5:3/The king then asked her, "What do you want, Queen Esther? What is your request? It will be granted to you, even up to half of the kingdom."
17:5:4/Esther replied, "If it pleases the king, I would like the king and Haman to join me today at a banquet I have prepared for them."
17:5:5/The king said, "Hurry and get Haman, so he can do as Esther has requested." So, the king and Haman went to the banquet Esther had prepared.
17:5:6/At the wine banquet, the king asked Esther, "What is your wish? It will be granted. What is your request? Even up to half of the kingdom, it will be fulfilled."
17:5:7/Then Esther answered, "My wish and my request is;
17:5:8/If I have found favor with the king, and if it pleases the king to grant my wish and fulfill my request, let the king and Haman come to another banquet I will prepare for them tomorrow, and then I will answer the king's question."
17:5:9/Haman left that day happy and in high spirits. But when he saw Mordecai at the king's gate, who didn't stand or move for him, he was filled with anger towards Mordecai.
17:5:10/However, Haman controlled himself and went home. He then summoned his friends and his wife Zeresh.
17:5:11/Haman boasted about his vast wealth, his many children, all the ways the king had honored him, and how he had been promoted above the other nobles and servants.
17:5:12/Furthermore, Haman said, "Even Queen Esther let no one but me join the king at the banquet she had prepared. And tomorrow, I am invited by her along with the king."
17:5:13/Yet all this means nothing to me as long as I see Mordecai the Jew sitting at the king's gate."
17:5:14/Then Zeresh, his wife, and all his friends suggested, "Have a gallows built, seventy-five feet high, and tomorrow ask the king to have Mordecai hanged on it. Then you can go happily with the king to the banquet." This idea pleased Haman, and he had the gallows built.
17:6:1/That night, the king couldn't sleep, so he ordered the book of records, the chronicles, to be brought and read to him.
17:6:2/It was discovered that Mordecai had exposed Bigthana and Teresh, two of the king’s chamberlains and doorkeepers, who had plotted against King Ahasuerus.
17:6:3/The king asked, "What honor and recognition has Mordecai received for this?" The king's servants replied, "Nothing has been done for him."
17:6:4/The king then asked, "Who is in the court?" At that moment, Haman had arrived in the outer court of the king's palace, intending to ask the king to hang Mordecai on the gallows he had prepared.
17:6:5/The king's servants told him, "Haman is standing in the court." The king said, "Let him come in."
17:6:6/So Haman entered. The king asked him, "What should be done for the man the king wishes to honor?" Haman thought to himself, "Who would the king want to honor more than me?"
17:6:7/And Haman answered the king, "For the man the king wishes to honor,
17:6:8/let royal robes be brought, which the king himself wears, and the horse the king rides, adorned with a royal crown,
17:6:9/and let these robes and horse be entrusted to one of the king's most noble officials. Let them dress the man the king wishes to honor, and parade him on horseback through the city streets, proclaiming before him, 'This is what is done for the man the king wishes to honor!'"
17:6:10/Then the king told Haman, "Hurry, take the robes and the horse as you've suggested, and do exactly that for Mordecai the Jew, who sits at the king's gate. Don't leave out anything you've mentioned."
17:6:11/Haman took the robes and the horse, dressed Mordecai, and led him on horseback through the city streets, proclaiming, "This is what is done for the man the king wishes to honor!"
17:6:12/Afterward, Mordecai returned to the king's gate. But Haman rushed home, distraught and with his head covered.
17:6:13/Haman recounted to Zeresh his wife and all his friends everything that had happened. His advisors and Zeresh his wife said to him, "If Mordecai is of Jewish descent, whom you have started to fall before, you won't overcome him but will surely fall before him."
17:6:14/While they were still talking with him, the king's chamberlains arrived and hurried to take Haman to the banquet Esther had prepared.
17:7:1/So the king and Haman came to dine with Queen Esther.
17:7:2/And the king asked Esther again on the second day during the wine banquet, "What do you wish for, Queen Esther? It will be given to you. And what is your request? It will be fulfilled, up to half of the kingdom."
17:7:3/Then Queen Esther answered, "If I have won your favor, O king, and if it pleases the king, let my life be spared as my plea, and let my people be saved as my request:
17:7:4/Because my people and I have been sold to be destroyed, killed, and eliminated. If we had only been sold as slaves, I would have remained silent, even though the enemy could never compensate for the king’s loss."
17:7:5/Then King Ahasuerus responded to Queen Esther, "Who is he, and where is he, who would dare to do such a thing?"
17:7:6/And Esther said, "The adversary and enemy is this evil Haman." Then Haman was terrified in the presence of the king and queen.
17:7:7/And the king, in his anger, left the wine banquet for the palace garden: and Haman stood up to beg Queen Esther for his life; for he realized that the king had decided his doom.
17:7:8/Then the king came back from the palace garden to the wine banquet area; and found Haman had fallen onto the couch where Esther was. Then the king exclaimed, "Will he even assault the queen right here in front of me in the palace?" As soon as the words left the king’s mouth, they covered Haman’s face.
17:7:9/And Harbonah, one of the attendants, said to the king, "Look, there are the gallows fifty cubits high, which Haman had built for Mordecai, who had spoken well on behalf of the king, standing at Haman's house." Then the king ordered, "Hang him on it."
17:7:10/So they hanged Haman on the gallows he had prepared for Mordecai. Then the king’s anger was calmed.
17:8:1/On that day, King Ahasuerus gave Esther the queen the estate of Haman, the enemy of the Jews. And Mordecai was presented to the king because Esther had revealed his relationship to her.
17:8:2/And the king removed his ring, which he had taken from Haman, and presented it to Mordecai. Esther then appointed Mordecai over Haman's estate.
17:8:3/Esther spoke again to the king, fell at his feet, and tearfully pleaded with him to undo the harmful plans Haman the Agagite had devised against the Jews.
17:8:4/Then the king extended the golden scepter towards Esther. So Esther got up and stood before the king,
17:8:5/And said, "If it pleases the king, and if I have found favor with him, if this proposal seems right to the king, and I am pleasing in his eyes, let an order be issued to counteract the letters devised by Haman the son of Hammedatha the Agagite, which he wrote to annihilate the Jews in all the king’s provinces:
17:8:6/For how can I bear to witness the calamity that will befall my people? Or how can I endure to see the destruction of my relatives?"
17:8:7/Then King Ahasuerus said to Queen Esther and to Mordecai the Jew, "Look, I have given Esther the estate of Haman, and they have hanged him on the gallows because he attacked the Jews.
17:8:8/Now write on behalf of the Jews as you see fit, in the king’s name, and seal it with the king’s ring: for a document written in the king’s name and sealed with the king’s ring cannot be revoked."
17:8:9/At that time, in the third month, which is the month of Sivan, on the twenty-third day, the king’s scribes were summoned. They wrote all that Mordecai commanded to the Jews, the satraps, the governors, and the officials of the provinces from India to Ethiopia, one hundred twenty-seven provinces in total, to each province in its own script and to each people in their own language, as well as to the Jews in their script and language.
17:8:10/He wrote in the name of King Ahasuerus, sealed the letters with the king’s ring, and sent them by mounted couriers on horses and riding on mules, camels, and young dromedaries:
17:8:11/In these letters, the king permitted the Jews in every city to unite and defend their lives, to destroy, kill, and annihilate any armed force of any people or province that might attack them, including their children and women, and to plunder their possessions,
17:8:12/On a single day across all the provinces of King Ahasuerus, on the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, which is the month of Adar.
17:8:13/The content of the decree was made public in every province, informing all the people so that the Jews would be ready on that day to take revenge on their enemies.
17:8:14/The couriers, mounted on mules and camels, went out in haste and urgency by the king’s command. And the edict was issued in the citadel of Susa.
17:8:15/And Mordecai left the king's presence in royal garments of blue and white, with a large gold crown and a cloak of fine linen and purple. And the city of Susa erupted in joy and celebration.
17:8:16/The Jews experienced relief, happiness, joy, and honor.
17:8:17/And in every province and every city, wherever the king’s command and his decree reached, the Jews celebrated with joy and gladness, feasting and observing a holiday. And many people of the land became Jews because the fear of the Jews had seized them.
17:9:1/Now in the twelfth month, that is, the month Adar, on the thirteenth day of the same, when the king’s command and his decree were about to be carried out, on the day the enemies of the Jews hoped to overpower them, it turned out the opposite, with the Jews gaining control over those who despised them.
17:9:2/The Jews came together in their cities across all the provinces of King Ahasuerus, to defend themselves against those who sought to harm them: and no one could stand against them; for fear of them spread among all the people.
17:9:3/And all the provincial governors, the lieutenants, the deputies, and the king's officials supported the Jews; because they were afraid of Mordecai.
17:9:4/For Mordecai was highly regarded in the royal palace, and his reputation spread throughout all the provinces: for Mordecai's influence continued to grow.
17:9:5/So the Jews struck down all their enemies with the sword, killing and annihilating them, and did as they pleased to those who hated them.
17:9:6/And in the citadel of Susa the Jews killed and annihilated five hundred men.
17:9:7/And Parshandatha, and Dalphon, and Aspatha,
17:9:8/And Poratha, and Adalia, and Aridatha,
17:9:9/And Parmashta, and Arisai, and Aridai, and Vajezatha,
17:9:10/The ten sons of Haman the son of Hammedatha, the adversary of the Jews, they killed; but they did not lay their hands on the plunder.
17:9:11/On that day the number of those killed in the citadel of Susa was reported to the king.
17:9:12/And the king said to Queen Esther, "The Jews have killed and annihilated five hundred men in the citadel of Susa, including Haman’s ten sons; what have they done in the rest of the provinces? Now, what is your request? It will be given to you. What is your further wish? It will be fulfilled."
17:9:13/Then Esther said, "If it pleases the king, allow the Jews in Susa to do tomorrow as they have done today, and let Haman’s ten sons be hanged on the gallows."
17:9:14/And the king ordered this to be done: a decree was issued in Susa, and Haman’s ten sons were hanged.
17:9:15/The Jews in Susa came together again on the fourteenth day of the month Adar and killed three hundred men in Susa, but they did not take the plunder.
17:9:16/But the other Jews throughout the king’s provinces also gathered to defend their lives and gained relief from their enemies, killing seventy-five thousand of their foes, but they did not take the plunder,
17:9:17/On the thirteenth day of the month Adar; and on the fourteenth day they rested and made it a day of feasting and joy.
17:9:18/But the Jews in Susa assembled on the thirteenth and fourteenth days, and on the fifteenth day they rested and made it a day of feasting and joy.
17:9:19/Therefore, the Jews in the rural areas, living in unwalled towns, celebrated the fourteenth day of the month Adar with joy and feasting, a festive day, and by sending gifts of food to one another.
17:9:20/And Mordecai recorded these events, and he sent letters to all the Jews throughout the provinces of King Ahasuerus, near and far,
17:9:21/To establish among them that they should celebrate the fourteenth and fifteenth days of the month Adar every year,
17:9:22/As the days when the Jews gained relief from their enemies, and the month which was transformed for them from sorrow to joy, and from mourning into a festive day: that they should make them days of feasting and joy, and of sending gifts of food to one another, and presents to the poor.
17:9:23/And the Jews committed to continue as they had started, and as Mordecai had written to them;
17:9:24/Because Haman the son of Hammedatha, the Agagite, the enemy of all the Jews, had plotted against the Jews to destroy them, and had cast Pur (that is, the lot) to crush and to destroy them;
17:9:25/But when Esther approached the king, he issued a decree that Haman’s wicked scheme against the Jews should come back on his own head, and that he and his sons should be hanged on the gallows.
17:9:26/Therefore, they called these days Purim, after the name Pur. Hence, because of all the words of this letter, what they had experienced in this matter, and what had happened to them,
17:9:27/The Jews established and took it upon themselves, their descendants, and all who would join them, without fail to celebrate these two days according to the written instructions and at the appointed time every year.
17:9:28/And that these days should be remembered and celebrated throughout every generation, in every family, province, and city; and that these days of Purim should never cease among the Jews, nor the memory of them fade from their descendants.
17:9:29/Then Queen Esther, daughter of Abihail, along with Mordecai the Jew, wrote with full authority to confirm this second letter about Purim.
17:9:30/And he sent letters to all the Jews in the 127 provinces of the kingdom of Ahasuerus, with words of peace and truth,
17:9:31/To establish these days of Purim at their designated times, as Mordecai the Jew and Queen Esther had decreed for them, and as they had decreed for themselves and their descendants concerning the observance of fasting and lamentation.
17:9:32/And Esther’s decree confirmed these practices of Purim; and it was recorded in writing.
17:10:1/King Ahasuerus imposed taxes on the land and the islands of the sea.
17:10:2/All the records of his power and might, and the story of how Mordecai was honored, are they not documented in the chronicles of the kings of Media and Persia?
17:10:3/Mordecai the Jew was second only to King Ahasuerus, held in high esteem among the Jews, favored by many of his people, working for their prosperity, and promoting peace for all his descendants.
18:1:1/There was a man in the land of Uz, named Job; this man was flawless and honest, someone who respected God and avoided evil.
18:1:2/He had seven sons and three daughters.
18:1:3/He owned seven thousand sheep, three thousand camels, five hundred pairs of oxen, and five hundred female donkeys, along with a very large household; making him the most prominent man in the east.
18:1:4/His sons would hold feasts in their homes on their respective birthdays; they would invite their three sisters to eat and drink with them.
18:1:5/When the feast days cycled through, Job would purify them, getting up early in the morning to offer burnt offerings for each of them, thinking, "Perhaps my children have sinned and blasphemed God in their hearts." This was Job's regular practice.
18:1:6/Then there came a day when the angels presented themselves before the LORD, and Satan also came with them.
18:1:7/The LORD asked Satan, "Where have you come from?" Satan answered the LORD, "From roaming throughout the earth, going back and forth on it."
18:1:8/Then the LORD said to Satan, "Have you considered my servant Job? There is no one on earth like him; he is blameless and upright, a man who fears God and shuns evil."
18:1:9/Satan replied to the LORD, "Does Job fear God for nothing?
18:1:10/Haven't you protected him, his household, and everything he has on every side? You have blessed the work of his hands, and his possessions have increased in the land.
18:1:11/But now, stretch out your hand and strike everything he has, and he will surely curse you to your face."
18:1:12/And the LORD said to Satan, "Very well, everything he has is in your power, but on the man himself, do not lay a finger." So Satan left the presence of the LORD.
18:1:13/One day when his sons and daughters were feasting and drinking wine at the oldest brother's house,
18:1:14/A messenger came to Job and said, "The oxen were plowing and the donkeys were grazing nearby,
18:1:15/And the Sabeans attacked and made off with them. They put the servants to the sword, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you."
18:1:16/While he was still speaking, another messenger came and said, "The fire of God fell from the sky and burned up the sheep and the servants, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you."
18:1:17/While he was still speaking, another messenger came and said, "The Chaldeans formed three raiding parties and swept down on your camels and made off with them. They put the servants to the sword, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you."
18:1:18/While he was still speaking, yet another messenger came and said, "Your sons and daughters were feasting and drinking wine at the oldest brother's house,
18:1:19/When suddenly a mighty wind swept in from the desert and struck the four corners of the house. It collapsed on the young people and they are dead, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you."
18:1:20/Then Job stood up, tore his robe, shaved his head, fell to the ground, and worshipped,
18:1:21/And said, "I came into this world with nothing, and I will leave with nothing. The LORD gave, and the LORD has taken away; may the name of the LORD be praised."
18:1:22/Through all this, Job did not sin or blame God for anything.
18:2:1/Once again, there was a day when the sons of God gathered to present themselves before the LORD, and Satan also came among them to present himself before the LORD.
18:2:2/And the LORD asked Satan, "Where have you come from?" Satan replied to the LORD, "From roaming throughout the earth, going back and forth on it."
18:2:3/Then the LORD said to Satan, "Have you considered my servant Job? There's no one like him on the earth, a blameless and upright man, who fears God and avoids evil. And yet he still clings to his integrity, even though you incited me against him to ruin him without any reason."
18:2:4/Satan responded to the LORD, "A person will give everything they have for their own life.
18:2:5/But now, stretch out your hand and strike his flesh and bones, and he will surely curse you to your face."
18:2:6/And the LORD said to Satan, "Very well, he is in your power; but you must spare his life."
18:2:7/So Satan left the LORD's presence and inflicted Job with painful sores from the soles of his feet to the crown of his head.
18:2:8/Job took a piece of broken pottery to scrape himself while he sat in the ashes.
18:2:9/Then his wife said to him, "Do you still hold on to your integrity? Curse God and die."
18:2:10/But he replied to her, "You're talking like a foolish woman. Should we accept good from God and not trouble?" In all this, Job did not sin with his words.
18:2:11/When Job’s three friends heard about all the troubles that had come upon him, they each came from their own homes; Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite. They had agreed to come together to sympathize with him and comfort him.
18:2:12/When they saw him from a distance, they could hardly recognize him; they began to weep aloud, tearing their robes and throwing dust into the air over their heads.
18:2:13/They sat on the ground with him for seven days and seven nights, and no one said a word to him because they saw how great his suffering was.
18:3:1/After this, Job opened his mouth and cursed the day he was born.
18:3:2/And Job spoke, saying,
18:3:3/May the day I was born perish, and the night when it was announced, 'A boy is conceived.'
18:3:4/Let that day turn to darkness; may God above ignore it, and no light shine on it.
18:3:5/May darkness and the shadow of death claim it; may clouds linger over it; may the terror of darkness frighten it.
18:3:6/As for that night, may darkness take it away; let it not join the days of the year or be counted among the months.
18:3:7/May that night be utterly lonely, with no sounds of joy within it.
18:3:8/Let those who curse days curse it, those who are skilled in rousing Leviathan.
18:3:9/May the stars of its twilight be dim; may it hope for light but find none, nor see the first rays of dawn.
18:3:10/Because it did not shut the doors of my mother's womb, nor hide trouble from my eyes.
18:3:11/Why didn't I die at birth, expire as I came from the womb?
18:3:12/Why were there knees to receive me, or breasts for me to nurse?
18:3:13/For now, I would be lying in peace; I would be asleep and at rest
18:3:14/With kings and counselors of the earth who built ruins for themselves,
18:3:15/Or with princes who had gold, who filled their houses with silver.
18:3:16/Or I would have been like a stillborn child, like infants who never saw the light.
18:3:17/There, the wicked stop causing trouble, and the weary find rest.
18:3:18/There, the prisoners are at ease together; they do not hear the voice of the taskmaster.
18:3:19/The small and the great are there, and the slave is free from his master.
18:3:20/Why is light given to those in misery, and life to the bitter of soul,
18:3:21/To those who long for death that does not come, who search for it more than for hidden treasures,
18:3:22/Who are overjoyed and rejoice when they find the grave?
18:3:23/Why is light given to a man whose path is hidden, whom God has hedged in?
18:3:24/For my sighing comes before I eat, and my groanings pour out like water.
18:3:25/For the thing I feared has overtaken me, and what I dreaded has happened to me.
18:3:26/I was not at peace, nor was I quiet; I had no rest, yet trouble came.
18:4:1/Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said,
18:4:2/If we try to talk with you, will you be upset? But who can keep from speaking?
18:4:3/Look, you've taught many people, and you've given strength to weak hands.
18:4:4/Your words have supported those who were falling, and you've made weak knees strong.
18:4:5/But now it's happening to you, and you're discouraged; it affects you, and you're distressed.
18:4:6/Isn't this your fear, your confidence, your hope, and the integrity of your ways?
18:4:7/Remember, please, who ever perished being innocent? Or where were the upright ever destroyed?
18:4:8/As I've seen, those who do wrong and sow evil, reap the same.
18:4:9/By God's blast they perish, and by the breath of his nostrils they are consumed.
18:4:10/The roar of the lion, the voice of the fierce lion, and the teeth of the young lions, are broken.
18:4:11/The old lion perishes for lack of prey, and the strong lion's cubs are scattered.
18:4:12/Now a message was secretly brought to me, and my ear caught a whisper of it.
18:4:13/In thoughts from visions of the night, when deep sleep falls on people,
18:4:14/Fear came upon me, and trembling, which made all my bones shake.
18:4:15/Then a spirit glided past my face; the hair on my body stood up.
18:4:16/It stood still, but I couldn't make out its appearance. A form was before my eyes, there was silence, and then I heard a voice saying,
18:4:17/Can a mortal be more righteous than God? Can a man be more pure than his Maker?
18:4:18/Behold, he doesn't trust his servants; and he charges his angels with error.
18:4:19/How much less those who live in houses of clay, whose foundation is in the dust, who are crushed more easily than a moth?
18:4:20/They are destroyed from morning to evening: they perish forever without anyone noticing.
18:4:21/Doesn't their dignity depart from them? They die, even without wisdom.
18:5:1/Go ahead, call out; is there anyone who will answer you? Which of the holy ones will you turn to?
18:5:2/Anger kills the foolish, and jealousy destroys the naive.
18:5:3/I've seen the foolish taking root, but suddenly I condemned their home.
18:5:4/Their children are far from safety, crushed without anyone to rescue them.
18:5:5/The hungry consume their harvest, even snatching it from the thorns, and the thief devours their wealth.
18:5:6/Though suffering doesn't come from the dust, nor does trouble sprout from the ground,
18:5:7/Yet humans are born to trouble as surely as sparks fly upward.
18:5:8/I would seek God and commit my cause to Him,
18:5:9/Who does great and unfathomable things, wonders without number.
18:5:10/He provides rain for the earth and sends water on the fields,
18:5:11/To lift up those who are low, so that those who mourn may be raised to safety.
18:5:12/He thwarts the plans of the cunning, so their hands achieve no success.
18:5:13/He catches the wise in their own cleverness, and the schemes of the deceitful are rushed to their end.
18:5:14/They encounter darkness in broad daylight, fumbling at noon as if it were night.
18:5:15/But He saves the needy from the sword, from their mouths, and from the hand of the powerful.
18:5:16/So the poor have hope, and wrongdoing is silenced.
18:5:17/See, blessed is the one whom God corrects; so do not despise the discipline of the Almighty.
18:5:18/For He wounds, but He also binds up; He injures, but His hands also heal.
18:5:19/He will rescue you from six calamities; in seven, no harm will touch you.
18:5:20/In famine, He will save you from death, and in battle, from the stroke of the sword.
18:5:21/You will be protected from the lash of the tongue, and need not fear when destruction comes.
18:5:22/You will laugh at destruction and famine, and need not fear the beasts of the earth.
18:5:23/For you will have a covenant with the stones of the field, and the wild animals will be at peace with you.
18:5:24/You will know that your tent is secure; you will inspect your property and find nothing amiss.
18:5:25/You will also know that your descendants will be many, and your offspring like the grass of the earth.
18:5:26/You will come to your grave in ripe old age, like a sheaf of grain harvested at the proper time.
18:5:27/See, this is what we have discovered; it is true. Hear it and apply it for your own good.
18:6:1/But Job answered and said,
18:6:2/If only my grief could be fully measured, and my troubles weighed all at once!
18:6:3/For they would be heavier than the sand of the sea: that's why my words are rushed.
18:6:4/The arrows of the Almighty are inside me, their poison drains my spirit: the terrors of God stand against me.
18:6:5/Does the wild donkey bray when it has grass? Or does the ox bellow over its feed?
18:6:6/Can something tasteless be eaten without salt? Or is there any flavor in the white of an egg?
18:6:7/The things I once refused to touch are now my mournful food.
18:6:8/If only I could have my request; and that God would grant what I deeply desire!
18:6:9/That it would please God to crush me; to let go of his hand and cut me off!
18:6:10/Then I would still have some comfort; yes, I would rejoice in unrelenting pain, for I have not denied the words of the Holy One.
18:6:11/What strength do I have, that I should still hope? What is my future, that I should be patient?
18:6:12/Is my strength the strength of stones? Or is my flesh made of bronze?
18:6:13/Isn't my help within me? And has wisdom been driven away from me?
18:6:14/One who is suffering deserves kindness from their friend, even if they forsake the fear of the Almighty.
18:6:15/My brothers have been as unreliable as a stream, like the seasonal torrents that vanish,
18:6:16/Which are dark because of the ice, and into which the snow disappears.
18:6:17/When they warm up, they disappear; when it's hot, they vanish from their place.
18:6:18/The paths of their course turn aside; they go nowhere and perish.
18:6:19/The caravans of Tema looked, the travelers of Sheba hoped for them.
18:6:20/They were distressed because they had hoped; they came there and were disappointed.
18:6:21/Now you are nothing; you see my plight and fear.
18:6:22/Did I ever say, 'Bring something to me'? or, 'Pay a ransom for me from your wealth'?
18:6:23/Or, 'Save me from the enemy's hand'? or, 'Rescue me from the grip of the powerful'?
18:6:24/Teach me, and I will be silent; make me understand where I have gone wrong.
18:6:25/How powerful are honest words! But what does your arguing prove?
18:6:26/Do you think to reprimand mere words, when the speeches of a despairing person are as wind?
18:6:27/Indeed, you would cast lots for the orphan and barter over your friend.
18:6:28/Now then, be so kind as to look at me. It's obvious if I'm lying.
18:6:29/Please, reconsider; let there be no injustice. Yes, reconsider; my righteousness is at stake.
18:6:30/Is there any wickedness on my tongue? Can't my palate discern the taste of calamity?
18:7:1/Isn't there a set time for humans on earth? Aren't their days just like those of a hired worker?
18:7:2/Just as a servant eagerly looks forward to the shade, and as a hired worker waits for their pay:
18:7:3/So I am burdened with months of emptiness, and nights filled with exhaustion are my lot.
18:7:4/When I lie down, I wonder, When will I get up, and when will the night end? I toss and turn until the break of day.
18:7:5/My body is covered with worms and clumps of dirt; my skin is cracked and repulsive.
18:7:6/My days fly by faster than a weaver's shuttle, and they end without hope.
18:7:7/Oh, remember that my life is just a breath: I will no longer see happiness.
18:7:8/Those who have seen me will see me no more; your eyes are on me, but I am gone.
18:7:9/Just as a cloud dissolves and vanishes, so one who goes down to the grave does not return.
18:7:10/He will never return to his home, and his place will know him no more.
18:7:11/Therefore, I will not hold back my words; I will speak in the anguish of my spirit; I will complain in the bitterness of my soul.
18:7:12/Am I the sea, or a sea monster, that you set a guard over me?
18:7:13/When I think, My bed will comfort me, my couch will ease my complaint;
18:7:14/Then you frighten me with dreams and terrify me with visions:
18:7:15/So that I prefer strangling and death over my life.
18:7:16/I despise it; I don't want to live forever: leave me alone; for my days are meaningless.
18:7:17/What is a human, that you should make so much of them, and that you should care for them so deeply?
18:7:18/And that you should visit them every morning, and test them every moment?
18:7:19/How long will you not look away from me, nor leave me alone even to swallow my saliva?
18:7:20/I have sinned; what can I do for you, O guardian of humanity? Why have you made me your target, so that I am a burden to myself?
18:7:21/And why do you not forgive my transgression and take away my sin? For now, I will lie down in the dust; and you will seek me in the morning, but I will be no more.
18:8:1/Then answered Bildad the Shuhite, and said, 
18:8:2/How long will you keep talking like this? And how long will your words be as forceful as a strong wind?
18:8:3/Does God twist justice? Or does the Almighty twist what is right?
18:8:4/If your children have sinned against him, and he has rejected them because of their sin;
18:8:5/If you would earnestly seek God and plead with the Almighty;
18:8:6/If you were pure and upright, surely now he would awaken for you and make your righteous dwelling prosper.
18:8:7/Even though your beginning was small, your future would greatly increase.
18:8:8/Please, look into the past, and prepare yourself by studying the experiences of our ancestors:
18:8:9/(For we are only of yesterday and know nothing, because our days on earth are like a shadow:)
18:8:10/Won't they teach you and tell you and express truths from their hearts?
18:8:11/Can papyrus grow tall where there is no marsh? Can reeds thrive without water?
18:8:12/While still growing and uncut, they wither more quickly than any other plant.
18:8:13/So are the paths of all who forget God; and the hope of the hypocrite will perish:
18:8:14/Whose confidence will be shattered, and whose trust is as fragile as a spider's web.
18:8:15/He will lean on his house, but it won't stand; he will cling to it, but it won't last.
18:8:16/He thrives before the sun, and his shoots spread out over his garden.
18:8:17/His roots entwine around a pile of rocks and look for a place among the stones.
18:8:18/But if he is uprooted from his place, then it will deny him, saying, 'I never saw you.'
18:8:19/Surely, this is the joy of his way, and from the soil others will spring.
18:8:20/Indeed, God will not reject a blameless person, nor will he support evildoers:
18:8:21/Until he fills your mouth with laughter and your lips with shouts of joy.
18:8:22/Those who hate you will be clothed with shame; and the dwelling of the wicked will vanish.
18:9:1/Then Job answered and said,
18:9:2/I know this is true, but how can a person be right before God?
18:9:3/If someone wanted to argue with Him, they couldn't answer Him once in a thousand times.
18:9:4/He is wise in heart and strong in power: who has ever defied Him and succeeded?
18:9:5/He moves mountains without them knowing it and overturns them in His anger.
18:9:6/He shakes the earth from its place, making its pillars tremble.
18:9:7/He commands the sun not to rise and seals off the stars.
18:9:8/He alone stretches out the heavens and walks on the waves of the sea.
18:9:9/He creates the constellations: the Bear, Orion, the Pleiades, and the southern stars.
18:9:10/He performs wonders that cannot be fathomed, miracles that cannot be counted.
18:9:11/Behold, He goes by me, and I do not see Him; He moves past, but I do not perceive Him.
18:9:12/Behold, He snatches away; who can stop Him? Who will say to Him, 'What are You doing?'
18:9:13/If God does not hold back His anger, the proud must bow beneath Him.
18:9:14/How much less can I answer Him or choose my arguments against Him?
18:9:15/Even if I were innocent, I could not answer; I could only plead with my Judge.
18:9:16/If I called and He answered, I do not believe He would listen to my voice.
18:9:17/For He crushes me with a storm and multiplies my wounds for no reason.
18:9:18/He does not let me catch my breath but fills me with bitterness.
18:9:19/If it's a matter of strength, He is mighty! And if it's a matter of justice, who can challenge Him?
18:9:20/Even if I were righteous, my own mouth would condemn me; if I were blameless, it would declare me guilty.
18:9:21/Even if I were blameless, I would not recognize myself; I would despise my life.
18:9:22/This is why I say, He destroys both the blameless and the wicked.
18:9:23/When disaster brings sudden death, He mocks the despair of the innocent.
18:9:24/The earth is handed over to the wicked; He covers the faces of its judges. If it is not He, then who is it?
18:9:25/Now my days are swifter than a runner; they flee away, they see no good.
18:9:26/They pass by like swift ships, like an eagle swooping on its prey.
18:9:27/If I say, 'I will forget my complaint, I will change my expression and smile,'
18:9:28/I still dread all my sufferings, for I know You will not declare me innocent.
18:9:29/If I am guilty, why then do I labor in vain?
18:9:30/If I wash myself with snow and cleanse my hands with soap,
18:9:31/You would still plunge me into filth, and my own clothes would detest me.
18:9:32/For He is not a man like me that I might answer Him, that we might confront each other in court.
18:9:33/There is no mediator between us, who might lay his hand on us both.
18:9:34/Let Him remove His rod from me, and let not His terror frighten me.
18:9:35/Then I would speak without fear of Him, but as it stands, I cannot.
18:10:1/My soul is exhausted with my life; I will express my grievances freely; I will speak from the depth of my distress.
18:10:2/I will ask God, Do not judge me harshly; show me why you are in conflict with me.
18:10:3/Is it beneficial for you to oppress me, to scorn the work of your hands, and favor the plans of the wicked?
18:10:4/Do you have human eyes? Or do you see as humans see?
18:10:5/Are your days like those of a human? Are your years like a man's years,
18:10:6/That you look into my faults, and search for my sin?
18:10:7/You know I am not evil; and no one can rescue from your hand.
18:10:8/Your hands have created and shaped me completely; yet you are destroying me.
18:10:9/Remember, please, that you molded me like clay; will you then return me to dust?
18:10:10/Did you not pour me out like milk, and thicken me like cheese?
18:10:11/You have clothed me with skin and flesh, and knit me together with bones and tendons.
18:10:12/You have given me life and kindness, and your care has preserved my spirit.
18:10:13/And you have kept these things in your heart; I am aware that this is within you.
18:10:14/If I sin, then you track me, and you will not clear me of my guilt.
18:10:15/If I am evil, woe to me; and if I am righteous, still I will not raise my head. I am overwhelmed with shame; therefore, acknowledge my suffering;
18:10:16/For it grows. You hunt me like a fierce lion: and then you reveal your power over me anew.
18:10:17/You bring new witnesses against me, and increase your anger towards me; changes and conflict are against me.
18:10:18/Why then did you bring me out of the womb? I wish I had died before any eye saw me!
18:10:19/I would have been as though I had never existed; I would have been taken straight from the womb to the grave.
18:10:20/Are not my days few? Then stop, and leave me be, that I might find a little comfort,
18:10:21/Before I go to a place of no return, to the land of gloom and deep shadow;
18:10:22/A land as dark as darkness itself, of deep shadow and disorder, where even the light is like darkness.
18:11:1/Then Zophar the Naamathite responded, saying,
18:11:2/Shouldn't a flood of words be answered? And should someone who talks a lot be considered right?
18:11:3/Should your lies make people remain silent? And when you mock, shouldn't someone put you in your place?
18:11:4/For you have claimed, 'My teaching is flawless, and I am without fault in your eyes.'
18:11:5/But if only God would speak and argue against you;
18:11:6/And show you the depths of wisdom, which are twice as much as you know! Understand then that God demands from you less than your sins deserve.
18:11:7/Can you by searching grasp God? Can you comprehend the Almighty completely?
18:11:8/It's as high as the heavens; what can you do? Deeper than the underworld; what can you know?
18:11:9/Its measure is longer than the earth and wider than the sea.
18:11:10/If he decides to cut off, or shut up, or bring together, then who can stop him?
18:11:11/For he knows deceitful men; he sees wickedness too; won't he then take it into account?
18:11:12/For empty-headed men would be wise, even though humans are born as wild as a donkey's colt.
18:11:13/If you prepare your heart and stretch out your hands to him;
18:11:14/If you put away the sin that is in your hand, and allow no evil to dwell in your home,
18:11:15/Then you will lift up your face without shame; you will stand firm and without fear.
18:11:16/Because you will forget your misery, recalling it only as waters gone by.
18:11:17/And your life will be brighter than the noonday; you will emerge from the darkness, shining like the morning.
18:11:18/You will feel secure, because there is hope; you will look around and take your rest in safety.
18:11:19/You will lie down with no one to make you afraid, and many will seek your favor.
18:11:20/But the eyes of the wicked will fail, and they will find no way to escape, and their hope will be the exhaling of their last breath.
18:12:1/And Job answered and said,
18:12:2/No doubt you think you're the only smart ones, and wisdom will die with you.
18:12:3/But I have just as much understanding as you; I'm not less than you. Indeed, who doesn't know these things?
18:12:4/I'm like someone mocked by his neighbor, who calls on God, and God answers him: the just and upright man is ridiculed.
18:12:5/The one about to trip is like a lamp scorned by those who are complacent.
18:12:6/The tents of thieves thrive, and those who challenge God feel safe; into their hands God brings plenty.
18:12:7/But ask the animals, and they will teach you; the birds of the sky, and they will tell you:
18:12:8/Or talk to the earth, and it will teach you; and the fish of the sea will explain to you.
18:12:9/Who doesn't know from all these that the hand of the LORD has done this?
18:12:10/In his hand is the life of every creature and the breath of all humankind.
18:12:11/Doesn't the ear test words as the tongue tastes food?
18:12:12/Wisdom is with the aged, and understanding comes with long life.
18:12:13/With him are wisdom and power; he has counsel and understanding.
18:12:14/See, he tears down, and it can't be rebuilt; he imprisons a man, and there can be no release.
18:12:15/See, he holds back the waters, and they dry up; also he sends them out, and they overturn the earth.
18:12:16/With him are strength and insight; the misled and the misleader belong to him.

18:13:1/Indeed, my eyes have seen all this, my ears have heard and understood it.
18:13:2/What you know, I know too: I am not less than you.
18:13:3/I surely want to speak to the Almighty, and I wish to argue my case with God.
18:13:4/But you fabricate lies, you are all worthless healers.

18:13:6/Listen to my argument, and pay attention to the defense of my lips.
18:13:7/Will you speak unjustly on God's behalf? And speak deceitfully for him?
18:13:8/Will you show him partiality? Will you argue for God?
18:13:9/Is it good that he should scrutinize you? Or as one person mocks another, do you mock him?
18:13:10/He will surely correct you, if you secretly show partiality.
18:13:11/Shouldn't his majesty terrify you? And his dread fall upon you?
18:13:12/Your memories are like ashes, your bodies like clay.
18:13:13/Be quiet, let me alone, so I can speak, and let happen to me what will.
18:13:14/Why do I risk my life and take my life in my hands?
18:13:15/Even if he kills me, I will hope in him: but I will defend my ways to his face.
18:13:16/He will also be my salvation: for a hypocrite cannot come before him.
18:13:17/Listen carefully to my speech, and to my declaration with your ears.
