21:1:14/I have seen all the deeds that are done under the sun; and indeed, all is meaningless and a chasing after the wind.
21:1:15/What is twisted cannot be straightened; what is lacking cannot be counted.
21:1:16/I said to myself, "Look, I have increased in wisdom more than anyone who has ruled over Jerusalem before me; my mind has experienced wisdom and knowledge."
21:1:17/And I applied my heart to know wisdom and to know madness and folly. I realized that this, too, is a chasing after the wind.
21:1:18/For with much wisdom comes much sorrow; the more knowledge, the more grief.
21:2:1/I told myself, "Come on, let's try pleasure. Let's look for the 'good life.'" But I found that this, too, was meaningless.
21:2:2/I said of laughter, "It's crazy," and of pleasure, "What does it accomplish?"
21:2:3/I decided to cheer myself with wine, all the while my mind still guiding me with wisdom. I wanted to see what was worthwhile for people to do under the heavens during the few days of their lives.
21:2:4/I undertook great projects; I built houses for myself and planted vineyards.
21:2:5/I made gardens and parks, planting all kinds of fruit trees in them.
21:2:6/I created pools of water to irrigate the groves of flourishing trees.
21:2:7/I acquired male and female servants, and had servants born in my household. I also owned more herds and flocks than anyone in Jerusalem before me.
21:2:8/I amassed silver and gold for myself, and the treasure of kings and provinces. I acquired male and female singers, and the delights of a man's heart, musical instruments of all kinds.
21:2:9/So I became greater than anyone in Jerusalem before me, yet my wisdom stayed with me.
21:2:10/I denied myself nothing my eyes desired; I refused my heart no pleasure. My heart took delight in all my labor, and this was the reward for all my toil.
21:2:11/Yet when I surveyed all that my hands had done and what I had toiled to achieve, everything was meaningless, a chasing after the wind; nothing was gained under the sun.
21:2:12/Then I turned my thoughts to consider wisdom, and also madness and folly. What more can the king's successor do than what has already been done?
21:2:13/I saw that wisdom is better than folly, just as light is better than darkness.
21:2:14/The wise have eyes in their heads, while the fool walks in the darkness; but I came to realize that the same fate overtakes them both.
21:2:15/I said to myself, "The fate of the fool will overtake me also. What then do I gain by being wise?" I said to myself, "This too is meaningless."
21:2:16/For the wise, like the fool, will not be long remembered; the days have already come when both have been forgotten. Like the fool, the wise too must die!
21:2:17/So I despised life, because the work that is done under the sun was grievous to me. All of it is meaningless, a chasing after the wind.
21:2:18/I hated all the things I had toiled for under the sun, because I must leave them to the one who comes after me.
21:2:19/And who knows whether that person will be wise or foolish? Yet they will have control over all the fruit of my toil into which I have poured my effort and skill under the sun. This too is meaningless.
21:2:20/So my heart began to despair over all my toilsome labor under the sun.
21:2:21/For a person may labor with wisdom, knowledge, and skill, and then they must leave all they own to another who has not toiled for it. This too is meaningless and a great misfortune.
21:2:22/What do people get for all the toil and anxious striving with which they labor under the sun?
21:2:23/All their days their work is grief and pain; even at night their minds do not rest. This too is meaningless.
21:2:24/There is nothing better for a person than to eat and drink and find satisfaction in their own toil. This too, I see, is from the hand of God.
21:2:25/For who can eat and who can have enjoyment more than I?
21:2:26/For to the person who pleases him, God gives wisdom, knowledge, and happiness, but to the sinner he gives the task of gathering and storing up wealth to hand it over to the one who pleases God. This too is meaningless, a chasing after the wind.
21:3:1/For everything, there is a season, and a time for every purpose under the sky:
21:3:2/A time to be born, and a time to die; a time to plant, and a time to uproot what is planted;
21:3:3/A time to kill, and a time to heal; a time to tear down, and a time to build;
21:3:4/A time to cry, and a time to laugh; a time to grieve, and a time to dance;
21:3:5/A time to throw stones away, and a time to gather stones together; a time to hug, and a time to avoid hugging;
21:3:6/A time to acquire, and a time to lose; a time to keep, and a time to throw away;
21:3:7/A time to tear, and a time to mend; a time to be silent, and a time to speak;
21:3:8/A time to love, and a time to hate; a time for war, and a time for peace.
21:3:9/What advantage does the worker gain from his toil?
21:3:10/I have observed the task that God has given humans to occupy themselves with.
21:3:11/He has made everything beautiful in its time. He has also set eternity in the human heart, yet no one can fathom what God has done from beginning to end.
21:3:12/I know that there is nothing better for them than to be joyful and to do good throughout their lives.
21:3:13/And also that everyone should eat and drink and take pleasure in all their toil—this is God's gift to man.
21:3:14/I know that whatever God does endures forever; nothing can be added to it, nor anything taken from it. God does it so that people will fear him.
21:3:15/What has been is now, and what is to be has already been; and God seeks what has been driven away.
21:3:16/Moreover, I saw under the sun that in the place of justice, there was wickedness, and in the place of righteousness, there was wickedness as well.
21:3:17/I said in my heart, God will judge the righteous and the wicked, for there is a time for every matter and for every work.
21:3:18/I said in my heart with regard to the condition of humans that God is testing them to show them that they are but animals.
21:3:19/For the fate of humans and the fate of animals is the same; as one dies, so dies the other. They all have the same breath, and humans have no advantage over animals; for all is vanity.
21:3:20/All go to one place; all are from the dust, and all return to dust.
21:3:21/Who knows whether the spirit of humans ascends upward, and the spirit of animals descends downward to the earth?
21:3:22/So I saw that there is nothing better than for a person to enjoy their work, because that is their lot. For who can bring them to see what will happen after them?
21:4:1/So I went back and observed all the oppression happening under the sun: and saw the tears of the oppressed, with no one to comfort them. Power was on the side of their oppressors, yet they had no comforter.
21:4:2/That's why I praised those who are already dead more than those who are still alive.
21:4:3/Indeed, better off is the one who has never been born, who has not seen the evil actions done under the sun.
21:4:4/Then, I observed all the hard work and skillful endeavors, only to see that this too causes envy among people. This is also meaningless, a chasing after the wind.
21:4:5/The fool sits back, doing nothing, and ends up harming themselves.
21:4:6/It's better to have a little with peace than to have much with turmoil and frustration.
21:4:7/Then I looked again at the meaningless things happening under the sun.
21:4:8/There are people who are completely alone, without a partner or even a brother, yet they work endlessly, never satisfied with their wealth. They never ask themselves, "For whom am I working so hard, depriving myself of pleasure?" This too is meaningless, a miserable business.
21:4:9/Two are better than one because they have a good return for their labor.
21:4:10/For if they fall, one can help the other up. But pity anyone who falls and has no one to help them up.
21:4:11/Also, if two lie down together, they will keep warm. But how can one keep warm alone?
21:4:12/And if someone might overpower one person, two can resist them. A cord of three strands is not quickly broken.
21:4:13/A poor but wise youth is better than an old and foolish king who no longer knows how to take advice.
21:4:14/For he might come from prison to the throne, even though in his kingdom he was born poor.
21:4:15/I saw all the living who move about under the sun, alongside that youth who steps into the king's place.
21:4:16/There is no end to all the people, to all who were before them, and even those to come will not be happy with him. This too is meaningless, a chasing after the wind.
21:5:1/Be mindful of your actions when you enter the house of God, and be more eager to listen than to offer the sacrifices of fools, who don't realize they're doing wrong.
21:5:2/Don't be impulsive with your words, and don't let your heart rush to say anything before God: for God is in heaven, and you are on earth: so keep your words to a minimum.
21:5:3/Dreams come through a lot of activity; and a fool's voice is recognized by a flood of words.
21:5:4/When you make a promise to God, don't delay in fulfilling it; for he has no pleasure in fools: fulfill your promise.
21:5:5/It's better not to make a vow than to make one and not fulfill it.
21:5:6/Don't let your mouth lead you into sin; and don't claim before the messenger that it was a mistake: why should God be angered by your voice, and destroy the work of your hands?
21:5:7/For in the multitude of dreams and many words there are also various vanities: but fear God.
21:5:8/If you see the oppression of the poor, and the violent perversion of justice and righteousness in a province, don't be amazed at the situation: for someone higher than the highest is watching; and there are higher ones than them.
21:5:9/The profit of the earth benefits everyone: the king himself is dependent on the field.
21:5:10/Whoever loves money will never be satisfied with money; nor will anyone who loves wealth be satisfied with their income: this too is meaningless.
21:5:11/When wealth increases, those who consume it increase: and what benefit is it to the owners except to gaze upon it?
21:5:12/The sleep of a laboring person is sweet, whether they eat little or much: but the abundance of the rich won't let them sleep.
21:5:13/There is a severe misfortune I have seen under the sun: wealth hoarded to the harm of its owner.
21:5:14/But that wealth perishes through misfortune: and if they have a child, there is nothing in their hand.
21:5:15/Just as they came from their mother's womb, they will return as naked as they came, and will take nothing for their toil that they can carry in their hand.
21:5:16/And this too is a severe misfortune: just as they came, so will they go: and what profit do they have from toiling for the wind?
21:5:17/All their days they eat in darkness, with great frustration, illness, and anger.
21:5:18/See, what I have observed to be good: it is fitting to eat, drink, and enjoy the good of all one's labor under the sun during the days of one's life, which God gives them: for this is their lot.
21:5:19/Moreover, every person to whom God has given wealth and possessions, and the ability to enjoy them, and to accept their lot and find joy in their toil—this is a gift from God.
21:5:20/For they will not dwell much on the days of their life because God keeps them occupied with the joy of their heart.
21:6:1/There is a kind of evil I've observed in the world, and it's widespread among people:
21:6:2/A person whom God has blessed with wealth, riches, and honor, so that they lack nothing they desire, yet God does not grant them the ability to enjoy it, and instead, a stranger enjoys it. This is pointless and a grievous affliction.
21:6:3/Even if a person has a hundred children and lives for many years, so that their life is long, but they do not experience fulfillment or receive a decent burial, I say that a stillborn child is better off than they are.
21:6:4/Because they enter the world with nothing and leave it in darkness, their name will be shrouded in obscurity.
21:6:5/Furthermore, they have not seen the sun or known anything; this state has more peace than the other.
21:6:6/Indeed, even if they live for two thousand years but do not experience anything good, don't we all end up in the same place?
21:6:7/All of a person's efforts are for their sustenance, yet their hunger is never satisfied.
21:6:8/What advantage does the wise person have over the fool? What does the poor person gain by knowing how to conduct themselves in life?
21:6:9/It is better to enjoy what you see with your eyes than to chase after your desires. This too is meaningless, a chasing after the wind.
21:6:10/What exists has already been named, and it is known that it is human; they cannot dispute with one who is stronger than they are.
21:6:11/Since there are so many things that increase vanity, what benefit is there for people?
21:6:12/For who knows what is good for a person during their fleeting life, which they spend like a shadow? Who can tell anyone what will happen after them under the sun?
21:7:1/A good reputation is more valuable than expensive perfume; and the day of death is better than the day of birth.
21:7:2/It's better to attend a funeral than a party: because that's everyone's fate; and the living should take it to heart.
21:7:3/Sadness is more beneficial than laughter: because through a sad face, the heart becomes better.
21:7:4/The wise person's heart is in the place of mourning; but the fool's heart is in the place of joy.
21:7:5/Listening to the criticism of the wise is better than listening to the songs of fools.
21:7:6/Just as the crackling of thorns under a pot is meaningless, so is the laughter of a fool.
21:7:7/Indeed, oppression can drive a wise person crazy; and a bribe corrupts the heart.
21:7:8/The end of something is better than its beginning: and being patient is better than being proud.
21:7:9/Don't be quick to get angry: because anger resides in the heart of fools.
21:7:10/Don't ask why the past was better than now; it's not a wise question.
21:7:11/Wisdom is beneficial when combined with an inheritance: and it benefits those who see the sun.
21:7:12/Wisdom is a protection, just as money is a protection: but the advantage of knowledge is that wisdom gives life to those who have it.
21:7:13/Think about the work of God: for who can straighten what he has made crooked?
21:7:14/In times of success, be happy, but in difficult times, reflect: God has made one as well as the other, so that people cannot predict their future.
21:7:15/I have seen everything during my fleeting life: there is a righteous person who perishes in their righteousness, and there is a wicked person who lives long in their wickedness.
21:7:16/Don't be overly righteous or too wise: why destroy yourself?
21:7:17/Don't be too wicked or foolish: why die before your time?
21:7:18/It's good to grasp this and not let go: for the one who fears God will avoid all extremes.
21:7:19/Wisdom makes the wise stronger than ten rulers in a city.
21:7:20/For there is not a righteous person on earth who does good and never sins.
21:7:21/Also, pay no attention to every word people say; otherwise, you might hear your servant cursing you.
21:7:22/For many times, you know in your heart that you yourself have cursed others.
21:7:23/All this I tested by wisdom and said, "I will be wise," but it was beyond me.
21:7:24/What is far off and very deep, who can discover it?
21:7:25/I applied my heart to know, to investigate, and to seek wisdom and the explanation of things, and to understand the stupidity of wickedness and the madness of folly.
21:7:26/And I find more bitter than death the woman whose heart is a trap and whose hands are chains. Whoever pleases God will escape her, but the sinner will be caught by her.
21:7:27/See, this is what I found, says the teacher, adding one thing to another to find the explanation.
21:7:28/Which my soul still seeks but I have not found: I have found one man among a thousand, but I have not found a woman among all these.
21:7:29/See, this only have I found, that God made humans upright, but they have sought out many schemes.
21:8:1/Who is as wise as the wise person? And who understands the meaning of things? A person's wisdom makes their face shine, and the confidence of their face will change.
21:8:2/I advise you to follow the king's command, especially because of your oath to God.
21:8:3/Don't be quick to leave his presence; don't stand for something wrong; for he does whatever he wants.
21:8:4/Where the king's word is, there's power: and who can question him, saying, "What are you doing?"
21:8:5/Anyone who follows the command will not experience harm; and a wise person's heart understands both the right time and the right way.
21:8:6/Because there is a right time and way for everything, the suffering of humanity is great.
21:8:7/For no one knows what will happen: for who can tell them when it will happen?
21:8:8/No one has control over their spirit to keep the spirit; nor do they have control over the day of death: and there is no escape in that battle; nor will wrongdoing save those committed to it.
21:8:9/All this I have seen, and I have given my heart to every deed that is done under the sun: there is a time when one person rules over another to their detriment.
21:8:10/And so I saw the wicked buried, who had come and gone from the holy place, and they were forgotten in the city where they had done so: this too is meaningless.
21:8:11/Because punishment for a wrong deed is not carried out quickly, the hearts of people are fully set on doing evil.
21:8:12/Even though a sinner does wrong a hundred times and lives a long life, I am sure it will go well with those who fear God, who show reverence before him:
21:8:13/But it will not go well for the wicked, nor will their days be extended, which are like a shadow; because they do not fear God.
21:8:14/There is a meaningless occurrence on earth; there are righteous people who get what the wicked deserve, and wicked people who get what the righteous deserve: I said that this too is meaningless.
21:8:15/Then I praised joy, because there is nothing better under the sun than to eat, drink, and be joyful: for this will accompany them in their toil throughout the days of their life, which God gives them under the sun.
21:8:16/When I dedicated myself to understand wisdom and to observe the activity done on earth: (even though some never see sleep day or night:)
21:8:17/Then I saw all the work of God, that no one can comprehend what happens under the sun: despite their efforts to search it out, they will not find it; and even if a wise person thinks they can understand it, they will not be able to grasp it.
21:9:1/For all this I thought deeply in my heart to declare that the righteous, the wise, and their actions are in God's control: no one can truly understand love or hatred by everything that is apparent to them.
21:9:2/Everything happens similarly to everyone: the same fate befalls the righteous and the wicked, the pure and the impure, those who offer sacrifices and those who do not. Just as it is with the good, so it is with the sinner; and the one who makes vows is like the one who is afraid to make them.
21:9:3/This is a tragedy among all things that happen under the sun, that everyone shares the same fate: moreover, people's hearts are full of evil, and madness fills their hearts during their lives, and afterwards, they join the dead.
21:9:4/For anyone who is connected to the living there is hope: for a living dog is better off than a dead lion.
21:9:5/For the living are aware that they will die: but the dead know nothing, nor do they have any more rewards; for their memory is forgotten.
21:9:6/Also, their love, their hatred, and their jealousy have now vanished; they no longer have any share in anything that happens under the sun.
21:9:7/Go ahead, eat your bread with happiness, and drink your wine with a joyful heart; for God now approves of your deeds.
21:9:8/Always wear clean clothes; and make sure your head is never without oil.
21:9:9/Enjoy life with the spouse you love all the days of your fleeting life, which God has given you under the sun—all your fleeting days: for this is your lot in life and in your toilsome labor under the sun.
21:9:10/Whatever your hand finds to do, do it with all your strength; for there is no activity, planning, knowledge, or wisdom in the grave where you are heading.
21:9:11/I observed and saw under the sun that the race is not always won by the swift, nor the battle by the strong, nor does food always come to the wise, nor wealth to the intelligent, nor favor to the knowledgeable; but time and chance happen to them all.
21:9:12/For people do not know their time: like fish caught in a cruel net, and birds trapped in a snare, so are humans ensnared at an unfortunate time when it suddenly falls upon them.
21:9:13/This wisdom I have also seen under the sun, and it seemed significant to me: 
21:9:14/There was a small city with few people in it; and a great king came against it, besieged it, and built huge siege works against it.
21:9:15/But there was found in it a poor wise man, and he by his wisdom saved the city; yet no one remembered that poor man afterward.
21:9:16/Then I said, Wisdom is better than strength: but the poor man's wisdom is ignored, and his words are not heeded.
21:9:17/The quiet words of the wise are more to be heeded than the shouts of a ruler among fools.
21:9:18/Wisdom is better than weapons of war, but one sinner can destroy much that is good.
21:10:1/Dead flies make a perfumer's oil stink, so a little foolishness outweighs wisdom and honor.
21:10:2/A wise person's heart guides them correctly, but a fool's heart leads them astray.
21:10:3/Indeed, when a fool walks down the road, they lack sense and show everyone that they are a fool.
21:10:4/If a ruler becomes angry with you, don't leave your post; calmness can defuse major conflicts.
21:10:5/There's a problem I've observed: mistakes made by those in power.
21:10:6/Foolishness is often treated with respect, while the wealthy are looked down upon.
21:10:7/I've seen servants on horseback while princes walk on foot like servants.
21:10:8/Whoever digs a pit will fall into it; if someone breaks through a wall, a snake will bite them.
21:10:9/Anyone who moves stones may be injured by them; and someone who splits logs may be endangered by the task.
21:10:10/If the axe is dull and its edge unsharpened, more strength is needed, but skill will bring success.
21:10:11/A snake will bite if it's not charmed; a gossip is no different.
21:10:12/The words from a wise person's mouth are gracious, but a fool's lips will swallow them up.
21:10:13/The beginning of their talk is foolishness, and the end of their speech is dangerous madness.
21:10:14/A fool is full of words; no one knows what will happen, and who can tell them what will happen after them?
21:10:15/The work of fools is exhausting to them because they don't know how to go to the city.
21:10:16/Woe to you, O land, when your king is inexperienced, and your leaders feast in the morning!
21:10:17/Blessed are you, O land, when your king is of noble birth, and your leaders eat at appropriate times for strength, not for drunkenness!
21:10:18/Through laziness, the rafters sag; because of idle hands, the house leaks.
21:10:19/A feast is made for laughter, and wine makes life merry, but money is the answer for everything.
21:10:20/Do not curse the king, even in your thoughts; do not curse the wealthy in your bedroom, for a bird may carry your voice, or some winged creature may report your words.
21:11:1/Share your resources freely, for you will reap the benefits in time.
21:11:2/Be generous to many, not knowing when you might face hardship.
21:11:3/When clouds are heavy, they release rain upon the earth; and wherever a tree falls, north or south, there it lies.
21:11:4/Those who wait for perfect conditions will never get anything done.
21:11:5/Just as you can't predict the path of the wind or how a baby forms in the womb, you cannot understand the works of God who does everything.
21:11:6/Plant your seeds in the morning and keep working until evening, because you don't know which efforts will succeed, if any, or if both will be equally good.
21:11:7/Indeed, light is delightful, and it's wonderful for the eyes to see the sun.
21:11:8/But even if a person lives many years and enjoys them all, they should remember the dark days, for there will be many. Everything to come is uncertain.
21:11:9/Enjoy your youth, young person; let your heart be happy while you're young. Follow the desires of your heart and what you see with your eyes, but remember that God will judge all these things.
21:11:10/So, rid your heart of sorrow and keep your body from harm, for childhood and youth are fleeting.
21:12:1/Remember your Creator in your youth, before the difficult days arrive and the years approach when you'll say, "I find no joy in them."
21:12:2/Before the sun, the light, the moon, and the stars grow dark, and the clouds come back after the rain.
21:12:3/When the guardians of the house tremble, the strong men stoop, the women grinding grain stop because they are few, and those looking through the windows see dimly.
21:12:4/When the street doors are closed, the sound of the mill fades, one wakes up at the chirp of a bird, and all the singers grow faint.
21:12:5/Also, when people fear heights and dangers in the streets; when the almond tree blossoms, the grasshopper drags itself along, and desire no longer stirs, because people are going to their eternal home and mourners go about the streets.
21:12:6/Before the silver cord is snapped, or the golden bowl is broken; before the pitcher is shattered at the spring, or the wheel broken at the well.
21:12:7/Then the dust returns to the earth as it was, and the spirit returns to God who gave it.
21:12:8/"Meaningless! Meaningless!" says the teacher. "Everything is meaningless!"
21:12:9/Moreover, because the teacher was wise, he continually shared knowledge with the people. He pondered, searched out, and arranged many proverbs.
21:12:10/The teacher sought to find delightful sayings and write down truthful words accurately.
21:12:11/The words of the wise prod us like goads, and like nails firmly fixed are the collected sayings given by one shepherd.
21:12:12/And further, my child, be warned: there is no end to the making of many books, and much study wearies the body.
21:12:13/Here's the conclusion of the matter: Fear God and keep his commandments, for this is the entirety of everyone's duty.
21:12:14/For God will bring every deed into judgment, including every hidden thing, whether it is good or evil.
22:1:1/The song of songs, which is Solomon’s.
22:1:2/Let him kiss me with the passion of his lips: for your love is more delightful than wine.
22:1:3/Because of the fragrance of your fine perfumes your name is like perfume poured out, no wonder the young women love you.
22:1:4/Draw me after you; let's run together. The king has brought me into his private rooms: we will celebrate and delight in you, we will cherish your love more than wine: the upright adore you.
22:1:5/I am dark but beautiful, O daughters of Jerusalem, like the tents of Kedar, like the pavilions of Solomon.
22:1:6/Do not stare at me because I am dark, because the sun has tanned me. My mother's sons were angry with me; they made me take care of the vineyards; my own vineyard I have neglected.
22:1:7/Tell me, you whom my soul loves, where you pasture your flock, where you make it lie down at noon; for why should I be like one who veils herself beside the flocks of your companions?
22:1:8/If you do not know, most beautiful of women, follow the tracks of the sheep and graze your young goats by the tents of the shepherds.
22:1:9/I compare you, my love, to a mare among Pharaoh's chariots.
22:1:10/Your cheeks are lovely with ornaments, your neck with strings of jewels.
22:1:11/We will make you earrings of gold, studded with silver.
22:1:12/While the king was at his table, my perfume spread its fragrance.
22:1:13/My beloved is to me a sachet of myrrh resting between my breasts.
22:1:14/My beloved is to me a cluster of henna blossoms from the vineyards of Engedi.
22:1:15/How beautiful you are, my darling! Oh, how beautiful! Your eyes are like doves.
22:1:16/How handsome you are, my beloved! Oh, how charming! And our bed is verdant.
22:1:17/The beams of our house are cedar; our rafters are pine.
22:2:1/I am the rose of Sharon, and the lily of the valleys.
22:2:2/Just as a lily stands out among thorns, so does my love stand out among the women.
22:2:3/Like an apple tree among the forest trees, so is my beloved among the men. I eagerly sat in his shade, finding his fruit sweet to my taste.
22:2:4/He led me to the banquet hall, where his love for me was the flag flying high.
22:2:5/Support me with raisin cakes, refresh me with apples, for I am overwhelmed with love.
22:2:6/His left hand cradles my head, while his right hand embraces me.
22:2:7/I urge you, O women of Jerusalem, by the gazelles and by the does of the field, do not disturb or awaken love until it so desires.
22:2:8/The sound of my beloved! Look, here he comes, leaping over the mountains, bounding over the hills.
22:2:9/My beloved is swift and graceful as a gazelle or a young stag. Look, there he stands behind our wall, gazing through the windows, peering through the lattice.
22:2:10/My beloved spoke and said to me, "Get up, my love, my beautiful one, and come with me.
22:2:11/See, the winter is over, the rains have come and gone.
22:2:12/Flowers are appearing on the earth; the season for singing has come, and the cooing of doves is heard in our land.
22:2:13/The fig tree forms its early fruit; the blossoming vines spread their fragrance. Get up, my love, my beautiful one, and come with me."
22:2:14/Oh my dove, hidden in the cliffs of the rock, in the secret recesses of the cliff, let me see your face, let me hear your voice; for your voice is sweet, and your face is lovely.
22:2:15/Catch for us the foxes, the little foxes that ruin the vineyards, our vineyards that are in bloom.
22:2:16/My beloved belongs to me, and I belong to him; he browses among the lilies.
22:2:17/Until the day breathes and the shadows flee, turn, my beloved, and be like a gazelle or a young stag on the rugged hills.
22:3:1/At night on my bed, I searched for the one my soul loves: I searched for him, but I didn't find him.
22:3:2/I'll get up now, and walk around the city, in the streets and wide avenues, I'll look for the one my soul loves: I looked for him, but I didn't find him.
22:3:3/The watchmen roaming the city found me: I asked them, "Have you seen the one my soul loves?"
22:3:4/It was only a short while after I left them, that I found the one my soul loves: I held onto him and wouldn't let him go, until I had brought him to my mother's house, to the room of the one who gave birth to me.
22:3:5/I urge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, by the gazelles and by the does of the field, not to stir or awaken my love until he desires.
22:3:6/Who is this coming from the wilderness like columns of smoke, scented with myrrh and frankincense, and all the fragrant powders of the merchant?
22:3:7/Look, it's Solomon's bed; sixty mighty men surround it, from the mighty men of Israel.
22:3:8/They all wield swords, skilled in warfare: each man has his sword at his side, because of fears at night.
22:3:9/King Solomon made himself a carriage from the cedars of Lebanon.
22:3:10/He made its pillars of silver, its base of gold, its covering of purple, its interior lovingly inlaid by the daughters of Jerusalem.
22:3:11/Come out, O daughters of Zion, and see King Solomon wearing the crown with which his mother crowned him on his wedding day, on the joyful day of his heart.
22:4:1/Look at you, so beautiful, my love; truly, you are beautiful. Your eyes behind your veil are like doves; your hair cascades like a herd of goats streaming down Mount Gilead.
22:4:2/Your teeth are as smooth and white as a flock of sheep freshly trimmed, coming up from being washed; each has its twin, and not one is missing.
22:4:3/Your lips are like a ribbon of scarlet, and your words are lovely. Your cheeks are like halves of a pomegranate behind your veil.
22:4:4/Your neck is as majestic as the tower of David, built to display a thousand shields, all the armor of warriors.
22:4:5/Your breasts are like two fawns, twins of a gazelle, grazing among the lilies.
22:4:6/Until the day breaks and the shadows disappear, I will go to the mountain of myrrh and to the hill of incense.
22:4:7/You are completely beautiful, my love; there is no flaw in you.
22:4:8/Come with me from Lebanon, my bride, come with me from Lebanon. Descend from the peak of Amana, from the peak of Senir and Hermon, from the dens of lions, from the mountains of leopards.
22:4:9/You have captured my heart, my sister, my bride; you have captured my heart with one glance of your eyes, with one jewel of your necklace.
22:4:10/How delightful is your love, my sister, my bride! How much more pleasing is your love than wine, and the fragrance of your perfume than any spice!
22:4:11/Your lips, my bride, drip with honey; honey and milk are under your tongue; the fragrance of your garments is like the fragrance of Lebanon.
22:4:12/You are a private garden, my sister, my bride; you are a spring enclosed, a sealed fountain.
22:4:13/Your plants are an orchard of pomegranates with choice fruits, with henna and nard,
22:4:14/Nard and saffron, calamus and cinnamon, with every kind of incense tree, with myrrh and aloes, and all the finest spices.
22:4:15/You are a garden fountain, a well of flowing water streaming down from Lebanon.
22:4:16/Awake, north wind; and come, south wind! Blow on my garden, that its fragrance may spread everywhere. Let my beloved come into his garden and taste its choice fruits.
22:5:1/I've entered my garden, my sister, my partner: I've collected my myrrh and my spices; I've eaten my honeycomb with my honey; I've drunk my wine with my milk: eat, friends; drink, yes, drink deeply, beloved.
22:5:2/I'm asleep, but my heart is awake: it's the voice of my beloved knocking, saying, "Open for me, my sister, my love, my dove, my flawless one: for my head is wet with dew, and my hair with the dampness of the night."
22:5:3/I've taken off my robe; how can I put it on again? I've washed my feet; how can I soil them?
22:5:4/My beloved reached in through the latch-opening, and my heart stirred for him.
22:5:5/I got up to open for my beloved; and my hands dripped with myrrh, and my fingers with flowing myrrh, on the handles of the bolt.
22:5:6/I opened for my beloved; but my beloved had left, he was gone: my heart sank at his departure: I looked for him, but did not find him; I called him, but he did not answer.
22:5:7/The watchmen who patrolled the city found me, they beat me, they injured me; the guards of the walls took my veil from me.
22:5:8/I urge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, if you find my beloved, tell him I am lovesick.
22:5:9/What makes your beloved better than another, O most beautiful among women? What makes your beloved better than another, that you so adjure us?
22:5:10/My beloved is radiant and ruddy, outstanding among ten thousand.
22:5:11/His head is the finest gold, his hair is wavy, and black as a raven.
22:5:12/His eyes are like doves beside streams of water, bathed in milk, and perfectly set.
22:5:13/His cheeks are like beds of spices, mounds of sweet-smelling herbs. His lips are like lilies, dripping with flowing myrrh.
22:5:14/His arms are rods of gold set with beryl. His body is like polished ivory decorated with sapphires.
22:5:15/His legs are pillars of marble set on bases of pure gold. His appearance is like Lebanon, choice as the cedars.
22:5:16/His mouth is sweetness itself; he is altogether desirable. This is my beloved, this is my friend, O daughters of Jerusalem.
22:6:1/Where has your beloved gone, O most beautiful among women? Where has your beloved turned so we can help you find him?
22:6:2/My beloved has gone down to his garden, to the beds of spices, to feed in the gardens, and to gather lilies.
22:6:3/I belong to my beloved, and my beloved belongs to me: he feeds among the lilies.
22:6:4/You are beautiful, my love, as Tirzah, lovely as Jerusalem, awe-inspiring as an army with banners.
22:6:5/Look away from me, for your eyes have overwhelmed me: your hair is like a flock of goats streaming down from Gilead.
22:6:6/Your teeth are like a flock of sheep just washed, each bearing twins, and none among them is barren.
22:6:7/Your temples behind your veil are like the halves of a pomegranate.
22:6:8/There are sixty queens, eighty concubines, and countless virgins.
22:6:9/My dove, my perfect one, is unique; she is the only one of her mother, the favorite of the one who bore her. The daughters saw her and called her blessed; the queens and concubines also, and they praised her.
22:6:10/Who is she that shines forth like the dawn, beautiful as the moon, bright as the sun, awe-inspiring as an army with banners?
22:6:11/I went down to the nut garden to see the blossoms of the valley, to see whether the vines had budded and the pomegranates were in bloom.
22:6:12/Before I realized it, my desire set me among the royal chariots of my people.
22:6:13/Come back, come back, O Shulamite; come back, come back, that we may gaze at you. Why should you gaze at the Shulamite, as at the dance of two armies?
22:7:1/Your feet look so beautiful in sandals, O daughter of a prince! The curves of your thighs are like jewels, crafted by skilled hands.
22:7:2/Your navel is like a round goblet that never lacks blended wine; your belly is like a mound of wheat encircled by lilies.
22:7:3/Your two breasts are like two fawns, twins of a gazelle.
22:7:4/Your neck is like a tower of ivory; your eyes are like the fish pools in Heshbon, by the gate of Bath-rabbim. Your nose is like the tower of Lebanon looking toward Damascus.
22:7:5/The hair on your head is like the royal tapestries of Mount Carmel, and your hair is like royal purple; the king is captivated by your tresses.
22:7:6/How beautiful and delightful you are, my love, with all your charms!
22:7:7/Your stature is like that of a palm tree, and your breasts like clusters of fruit.
22:7:8/I thought, "I will climb the palm tree; I will take hold of its fruit." May your breasts be like clusters of grapes on the vine, the fragrance of your breath like apples,
22:7:9/And your mouth like the best wine, flowing smoothly for my beloved, gliding over lips and teeth.
22:7:10/I belong to my beloved, and his desire is for me.
22:7:11/Come, my beloved, let us go to the countryside, let us spend the night in the villages.
22:7:12/Let's go early to the vineyards to see if the vines have budded, if their blossoms have opened, and if the pomegranates are in bloom—there I will give you my love.
22:7:13/The mandrakes send out their fragrance, and at our door is every delicacy, both new and old, that I have stored up for you, my beloved.
22:8:1/I wish you were like a brother to me, one who nursed at my mother's breasts. If I found you outside, I could kiss you without anyone looking down on us.
22:8:2/I would lead you and bring you to my mother's house, where she would teach me. I would give you spiced wine to drink, from the juice of my pomegranate.
22:8:3/His left hand would be under my head, and his right hand would embrace me.
22:8:4/I urge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, not to disturb or awaken my love until he desires.
22:8:5/Who is this coming up from the wilderness, leaning on her beloved? Under the apple tree I awakened you; there your mother gave birth to you, there she who bore you gave birth.
22:8:6/Place me like a seal over your heart, like a seal on your arm; for love is as strong as death, jealousy as relentless as the grave. Its flames are blazing flames, the fiercest of all.
22:8:7/Many waters cannot quench love; rivers cannot sweep it away. If one were to give all the wealth of his house for love, it would be utterly scorned.
22:8:8/We have a little sister, and she has no breasts. What shall we do for our sister on the day she is spoken for?
22:8:9/If she is a wall, we will build on her a battlement of silver; if she is a door, we will enclose her with panels of cedar.
22:8:10/I am a wall, and my breasts are like towers. Thus, I have become in his eyes like one bringing contentment.
22:8:11/Solomon had a vineyard at Baal-hamon; he leased the vineyard to keepers; each was to bring for its fruit a thousand pieces of silver.
22:8:12/My own vineyard is before me. You, O Solomon, may have the thousand, and the keepers of the fruit two hundred.
22:8:13/You who dwell in the gardens, with companions listening for your voice, let me hear it.
22:8:14/Hurry, my beloved, and be like a gazelle or a young stag on the mountains of spices.
23:1:1/The vision of Isaiah the son of Amoz, which he saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem in the days of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah.
23:1:2/Listen, heavens, and pay attention, earth: for the LORD has spoken, "I have raised and cared for children, but they have rebelled against me."
23:1:3/Even an ox recognizes its owner, and a donkey knows where its master feeds it, but Israel doesn't recognize me; my people don't understand."
23:1:4/Oh, what a sinful nation, burdened with wrongdoing, offspring of evildoers, children who corrupt! They have abandoned the LORD, angered the Holy One of Israel, and turned their backs on him.
23:1:5/Why should you be punished any more? You only continue to rebel. The entire body is sick, and the whole heart is weak.
23:1:6/From head to toe, there's no health in it—only wounds, bruises, and infected sores that haven't been treated or bandaged or soothed with ointment.
23:1:7/Your country lies in ruins, your cities are burned down; foreigners devour your land in front of you, leaving it desolate, destroyed by outsiders.
23:1:8/And the daughter of Zion is left like a shelter in a vineyard, like a hut in a field of melons, like a city under siege.
23:1:9/If the LORD Almighty hadn't left us some survivors, we would have been wiped out like Sodom, we would have been destroyed like Gomorrah.
23:1:10/Listen to the LORD's message, you rulers of Sodom; pay attention to the teaching of our God, you people of Gomorrah.
23:1:11/"What's the point of all your sacrifices to me?" says the LORD. "I've had enough of burnt offerings of rams and the fat of well-fed animals; I take no pleasure in the blood of bulls, lambs, or goats.
23:1:12/When you come to meet me, who asked you to trample through my courts with your meaningless offerings?
23:1:13/Stop bringing worthless offerings; your incense is detestable to me. New Moons, Sabbaths, and convocations—I cannot stand iniquity mixed with celebration.
23:1:14/I hate your New Moons and your appointed festivals; they have become a burden to me, and I'm tired of bearing them.
23:1:15/When you spread out your hands in prayer, I will hide my eyes from you; even when you offer many prayers, I will not listen. Your hands are covered with blood.
23:1:16/Cleanse yourselves, make yourselves pure; remove your evil deeds from my sight. Stop doing wrong.
23:1:17/Learn to do right; seek justice, defend the oppressed, take up the cause of the fatherless, plead the case of the widow.
23:1:18/"Come now, let's settle this," says the LORD. "Though your sins are like scarlet, they shall be as white as snow; though they are red as crimson, they shall be like wool.
23:1:19/If you are willing and obedient, you will enjoy the best of the land.
23:1:20/But if you resist and rebel, you will be devoured by the sword." For the mouth of the LORD has spoken.
23:1:21/How the faithful city has become a prostitute! She was full of justice; righteousness used to dwell in her, but now murderers.
23:1:22/Your silver has become worthless, your choice wine diluted with water.
23:1:23/Your leaders are rebels, friends of thieves; they all love bribes and chase after gifts. They do not defend the cause of the fatherless; the widow's case does not come before them.
23:1:24/Therefore, the LORD, the LORD Almighty, the mighty One of Israel, declares, "Ah, I will get relief from my foes and avenge myself on my enemies.
23:1:25/And I will turn my hand against you; I will thoroughly purge away your dross and remove all your impurities.
23:1:26/I will restore your judges as in the days of old, your counselors as at the beginning. Afterward, you will be called the City of Righteousness, the Faithful City."
23:1:27/Zion will be redeemed with justice, her penitent ones with righteousness.
23:1:28/But rebels and sinners will be destroyed together, and those who forsake the LORD will perish.
23:1:29/You will be ashamed of the sacred oaks in which you delighted; you will be disgraced because of the gardens that you have chosen.
23:1:30/You will be like an oak with fading leaves, like a garden without water.
23:1:31/The mighty will become tinder, and their work a spark; both will burn together, with no one to quench the fire.
23:2:1/The message that Isaiah, the son of Amoz, received about Judah and Jerusalem.
23:2:2/In the future, the mountain where the LORD's temple stands will be the highest of all, towering above the hills. People from all nations will stream towards it.
23:2:3/Many will come and say, "Let's go up to the mountain of the LORD, to the temple of the God of Jacob. He will teach us his ways, so we can walk in his paths." The law will go out from Zion, the word of the LORD from Jerusalem.
23:2:4/He will settle disputes for many nations and provide guidance for many peoples. They will turn their swords into plowshares and their spears into pruning hooks. Nation will not take up sword against nation, nor will they train for war anymore.
23:2:5/Come, descendants of Jacob, let us walk in the light of the LORD.
23:2:6/You have abandoned your people, the descendants of Jacob, because they are filled with influences from the east, they practice divination like the Philistines, and they embrace foreign customs.
23:2:7/Their land is filled with silver and gold; there is no end to their treasures. Their land is also full of horses; there is no end to their chariots.
23:2:8/Their land is full of idols; they bow down to the work of their hands, to what their own fingers have made.
23:2:9/So people of low and high status humble themselves, but do not forgive them.
23:2:10/Go into the rocks, hide in the ground from dread of the LORD and the splendor of his majesty.
23:2:11/The proud looks of people will be brought low, the arrogance of everyone will be humbled, and the LORD alone will be exalted on that day.
23:2:12/For the day of the LORD Almighty will come against everyone who is proud and lofty, against everyone who is lifted up—and they will be brought low.
23:2:13/It will come against all the tall cedars of Lebanon, high and lifted up, and against all the oaks of Bashan,
23:2:14/Against all the towering mountains and all the high hills,
23:2:15/Against every lofty tower and every fortified wall,
23:2:16/Against all the ships of Tarshish and all the beautiful craft.
23:2:17/The pride of humanity will be brought low and human arrogance humbled, and the LORD alone will be exalted on that day.
23:2:18/And the idols will completely vanish.
23:2:19/People will flee to caves in the rocks and to holes in the ground from the terror of the LORD and the splendor of his majesty, when he rises to shake the earth.
23:2:20/In that day people will throw away to the moles and bats their idols of silver and idols of gold, which they made to worship.
23:2:21/They will flee to caverns in the rocks and to the overhangs of the cliffs from the terror of the LORD and the splendor of his majesty, when he rises to shake the earth.
23:2:22/Stop trusting in mere humans, who have but a breath in their nostrils. Why hold them in esteem?
23:3:1/Indeed, the Lord, the LORD of hosts, will remove from Jerusalem and from Judah all support and sustenance, the entire supply of bread and all the water.
23:3:2/The warrior, the soldier, the judge, the prophet, the wise, and the elder,
23:3:3/The commander of fifty, the respected figure, the advisor, the skilled craftsman, and the articulate speaker.
23:3:4/And I will appoint inexperienced youths as their leaders, and children will govern them.
23:3:5/And the people will oppress each other, neighbor against neighbor: the young will disrespect the old, and the dishonorable will rise against the respected.
23:3:6/When someone grabs his brother in his father's house and says, "You have clothes, you be our leader, take charge of this ruin,"
23:3:7/On that day he will protest, saying, "I can't help; I have neither food nor clothes in my house. Don't make me the leader of the people."
23:3:8/For Jerusalem is in ruins, and Judah has fallen: because their words and actions are against the LORD, provoking His glorious presence.
23:3:9/Their faces testify against them; they parade their sin like Sodom, not hiding it. Woe to them! For they bring trouble upon themselves.
23:3:10/Tell the righteous it will go well with them: they will enjoy the fruits of their actions.
23:3:11/Woe to the wicked! It will go badly for him: he will be repaid for what his hands have done.
23:3:12/My people are oppressed by children, and women rule over them. Oh my people, your leaders mislead you and disrupt your paths.
23:3:13/The LORD stands up to argue His case, and stands to judge the people.
23:3:14/The LORD will bring judgment upon the elders and leaders of His people: "You have devoured the vineyard; the plunder of the poor is in your houses.
23:3:15/Why do you crush my people and grind the faces of the poor?" declares the Lord GOD of hosts.
23:3:16/Furthermore, the LORD says, "Because the daughters of Zion are proud, walking with outstretched necks and seductive eyes, strutting as they go, making tinkling sounds with their feet:
23:3:17/Therefore, the LORD will afflict the heads of the daughters of Zion with scabs, and the LORD will expose their shame.
23:3:18/On that day, the Lord will strip away the finery of their ankle bracelets, headbands, crescent necklaces,
23:3:19/The chains, bracelets, and veils,
23:3:20/The headdresses, ankle chains, sashes, perfume boxes, and amulets,
23:3:21/The rings and nose jewels,
23:3:22/The festive robes, capes, cloaks, and purses,
23:3:23/The mirrors, linen garments, turbans, and veils.
23:3:24/And it will happen that, instead of fragrance, there will be a stench; instead of a belt, a rope; instead of well-styled hair, baldness; instead of fine clothing, sackcloth; and branding instead of beauty.
23:3:25/Your men will fall by the sword, and your warriors in battle.
23:3:26/And her gates will lament and mourn; deserted, she will sit on the ground.
23:4:1/And on that day, seven women will cling to one man, saying, "We will provide our own food and clothes; just let us carry your name to remove our disgrace."
23:4:2/On that day, the LORD's branch will be magnificent and splendid, and the earth's produce will be superb and attractive for those of Israel who have survived.
23:4:3/And it will happen that those who remain in Zion and in Jerusalem will be called holy, every one who is recorded among the living in Jerusalem.
23:4:4/When the Lord has cleansed the filth of Zion's daughters and rinsed out Jerusalem's bloodstains with the spirit of judgment and the spirit of fire.
23:4:5/And the LORD will create over every home on Mount Zion and over its gatherings, a cloud and smoke by day, and the glow of a blazing fire by night; for over all the splendor there will be a protective covering.
23:4:6/And there will be a shelter to provide shade from the daytime heat, and a refuge and hiding place from the storm and rain.
23:5:1/Now I will sing for my beloved a song about his vineyard. My beloved had a vineyard on a fertile hillside.
23:5:2/He protected it, cleared it of stones, and planted it with the best vines. He built a watchtower in the middle and carved out a winepress as well. He expected it to produce good grapes, but it only produced bad ones.
23:5:3/And now, residents of Jerusalem and people of Judah, please judge between me and my vineyard.
23:5:4/What more could have been done for my vineyard that I haven't done? Why, when I expected it to produce good grapes, did it produce bad ones?
23:5:5/So now, let me tell you what I will do to my vineyard: I will remove its hedge, and it will be consumed; I will break down its wall, and it will be trampled.
23:5:6/I will make it a wasteland; it will not be pruned or tended, and briers and thorns will grow up. I will also command the clouds not to rain on it.
23:5:7/For the vineyard of the LORD Almighty is the nation of Israel, and the people of Judah are the vines he delighted in. He looked for justice, but saw bloodshed; for righteousness, but heard cries of distress.
23:5:8/Woe to those who add house to house and join field to field until no space is left and they live alone in the land!
23:5:9/The LORD Almighty has declared in my hearing: Surely many houses will become desolate, large and beautiful ones without occupants.
23:5:10/Indeed, ten acres of vineyard will yield only a bath of wine, and a homer of seed will yield only an ephah of grain.
23:5:11/Woe to those who get up early in the morning to run after their drinks, who stay up late at night until they are inflamed with wine.
23:5:12/They have harps and lyres at their banquets, pipes and timbrels and wine, but they disregard the deeds of the LORD and fail to see the work of his hands.
23:5:13/Therefore my people will go into exile for lack of understanding; their men of honor will die from hunger and their masses parched with thirst.
23:5:14/Therefore the grave enlarges its appetite and opens its mouth without limit; into it will descend their nobles and masses along with all their brawlers and revelers.
23:5:15/So people will be brought low and everyone humbled, the eyes of the arrogant humbled.
23:5:16/But the LORD Almighty will be exalted by his justice, and the holy God will be proved holy by his righteous acts.
23:5:17/Then sheep will graze as in their own pasture; lambs will feed among the ruins of the rich.
23:5:18/Woe to those who drag wickedness with cords of deceit, and sin as if with cart ropes.
23:5:19/They say, "Let God hurry; let him hasten his work so we may see it. Let the plan of the Holy One of Israel come so we may know it."
23:5:20/Woe to those who call evil good and good evil, who put darkness for light and light for darkness, who put bitter for sweet and sweet for bitter.
23:5:21/Woe to those who are wise in their own eyes and clever in their own sight.
23:5:22/Woe to those who are heroes at drinking wine and champions at mixing drinks,
23:5:23/Who acquit the guilty for a bribe, but deny justice to the innocent.
23:5:24/Therefore, as fire consumes stubble and as flame burns away chaff, their roots will decay and their flowers blow away like dust; for they have rejected the law of the LORD Almighty and spurned the word of the Holy One of Israel.
23:5:25/Therefore the LORD's anger burns against his people; he has raised his hand against them and struck them down. The mountains quake, and their dead bodies are like refuse in the streets. Yet his anger is not turned away, his hand is still upraised.
23:5:26/He will raise a banner for the distant nations and whistle for them from the ends of the earth; and behold, they will come quickly and swiftly.
23:5:27/None will grow tired or stumble among them; none will slumber or sleep; not a belt is loosened, not a sandal strap broken.
23:5:28/Their arrows are sharp, all their bows strung; their horses' hooves seem like flint, their chariot wheels like a whirlwind.
23:5:29/Their roar is like that of a lion, they roar like young lions; they growl and seize their prey and carry it off with no one to rescue.
23:5:30/In that day they will roar over it like the roaring of the sea. And if one looks at the land, there is darkness and distress; even the light is darkened by the clouds.
23:6:1/In the year that King Uzziah died, I also saw the LORD seated on a throne, high and exalted, with His robe filling the temple.
23:6:2/Above Him stood seraphim, each with six wings: with two they covered their faces, with two they covered their feet, and with two they flew.
23:6:3/And one called to another, saying, "Holy, holy, holy, is the LORD Almighty; the whole earth is filled with His glory."
23:6:4/And the foundations of the thresholds shook at the voice of the one who called out, and the temple was filled with smoke.
23:6:5/Then I said, "Woe is me! I am ruined; because I am a man of unclean lips, living among a people of unclean lips; for my eyes have seen the King, the LORD Almighty."
23:6:6/Then one of the seraphim flew to me, holding a live coal in his hand, which he had taken with tongs from the altar.
23:6:7/And he touched my mouth with it and said, "See, this has touched your lips; your guilt is taken away, and your sin atoned for."
23:6:8/Then I heard the voice of the Lord saying, "Whom shall I send, and who will go for us?" And I said, "Here I am. Send me."
23:6:9/And He said, "Go, and tell this people, 'Listen carefully, but do not understand; look closely, but do not perceive.'"
23:6:10/"Make the hearts of this people calloused; make their ears dull and close their eyes. Otherwise, they might see with their eyes, hear with their ears, understand with their hearts, and turn and be healed."
23:6:11/Then I asked, "For how long, Lord?" And He replied, "Until the cities lie ruined and without inhabitants, the houses are without people, and the land is utterly desolate,"
23:6:12/And the LORD has sent everyone far away, and the land is greatly abandoned.
23:6:13/But even then, a tenth will remain in it, and it will again be subject to burning, like a terebinth or an oak, whose stump remains when it is cut down. The holy seed will be its stump.
23:7:1/In the time of Ahaz son of Jotham, son of Uzziah, king of Judah, Rezin king of Syria, and Pekah son of Remaliah, king of Israel, attacked Jerusalem but failed to conquer it.
23:7:2/News reached the royal family of David: "Syria has allied with Ephraim." This news shook Ahaz and his people like wind shaking trees in a forest.
23:7:3/Then the LORD said to Isaiah, "Go out to meet Ahaz, you and your son Shearjashub, at the end of the upper pool's conduit on the fuller’s field road; 
23:7:4/And tell him, 'Stay calm and don't be afraid. Don't lose heart because of these two smoldering stubs of firewood—Rezin of Syria and Pekah son of Remaliah.'
23:7:5/Because Syria, Ephraim, and the son of Remaliah have plotted your downfall, saying, 
23:7:6/'Let's attack Judah, stir up trouble, and install the son of Tabeal as king in the midst of it.'
23:7:7/But the Sovereign LORD says, 'This will not happen; it will not come to be.'
23:7:8/'The capital of Syria is Damascus, and the head of Damascus is Rezin. Within sixty-five years, Ephraim will be shattered, no longer a nation.'
23:7:9/'The capital of Ephraim is Samaria, and the head of Samaria is the son of Remaliah. If you do not stand firm in faith, you will not stand at all.'
23:7:10/Furthermore, the LORD spoke to Ahaz, saying, 
23:7:11/'Ask for a sign from the LORD your God; let it be deep as the grave or high as the sky.'
23:7:12/But Ahaz said, 'I will not ask; I will not put the LORD to the test.'
23:7:13/Then Isaiah said, 'Listen now, house of David! Is it not enough to try the patience of humans, will you also try the patience of my God?'
23:7:14/Therefore, the Lord himself will give you a sign: Look, a young woman will conceive and give birth to a son, and will call him Immanuel.
23:7:15/He will eat curds and honey when he knows enough to reject the wrong and choose the right.
23:7:16/For before the boy knows how to reject the wrong and choose the right, the land of the two kings you dread will be deserted.
23:7:17/The LORD will bring on you, your people, and your father's house such days as have not come since Ephraim broke away from Judah—the king of Assyria is coming.
23:7:18/In that day, the LORD will whistle for the flies from the farthest streams of Egypt and for the bees from the land of Assyria.
23:7:19/They will all come and settle in the steep ravines, in the crevices of the rocks, on all the thornbushes, and at all the water holes.
23:7:20/On that day, the Lord will use a razor hired from beyond the Euphrates River—the king of Assyria—to shave your head, the hair of your legs, and also to remove your beard.
23:7:21/In that day, a person will keep alive a young cow and two sheep; 
23:7:22/And because of the abundance of milk they give, everyone left in the land will eat curds and honey.
23:7:23/In that day, every place where there used to be a thousand vines worth a thousand silver coins, will be overrun with briers and thorns.
23:7:24/People will go there with bows and arrows because the whole land will be briers and thorns.
23:7:25/And all the hills that used to be cultivated with a hoe, you will not go there for fear of briers and thorns; but they will become places where cattle are let loose and where sheep run.
