26:43:7/He told me, "Son of man, this is the place of my throne and the place for the soles of my feet, where I will live among the Israelites forever. The people of Israel will no longer defile my holy name—neither they nor their kings—by their prostitution and the corpses of their kings at their high places.
26:43:8/When they placed their threshold next to my threshold and their doorposts beside my doorposts, with only a wall between me and them, they defiled my holy name by their detestable practices. So I destroyed them in my anger.
26:43:9/Now let them put away their prostitution and the corpses of their kings far from me, and I will live among them forever.
26:43:10/You, son of man, describe the temple to the people of Israel, that they may be ashamed of their sins. Let them consider its perfection.
26:43:11/And if they are ashamed of all they have done, show them the design of the temple—its arrangement, its exits and entrances—its whole design and all its regulations and laws. Write it down in their sight so that they may follow its design and all its regulations and carry them out.
26:43:12/This is the law of the temple: The whole area surrounding the mountaintop is most holy. Behold, this is the law of the temple.
26:43:13/Here are the measurements of the altar in cubits (each cubit is a cubit and a handbreadth): The base shall be a cubit high and a cubit wide, with a rim of one span around its edge. This is the height of the altar.
26:43:14/From the base on the ground to the lower ledge shall be two cubits, with a width of one cubit; from the smaller ledge to the larger ledge shall be four cubits, and the width one cubit.
26:43:15/The altar hearth shall be four cubits high, and from the altar hearth extending upwards shall be four horns.
26:43:16/The altar hearth shall be twelve cubits long by twelve wide, square on its four sides.
26:43:17/The ledge shall be fourteen cubits long by fourteen wide on its four sides; the rim around it shall be half a cubit, and its base shall be one cubit all around. Its steps shall face east.
26:43:18/He said to me, "Son of man, this is what the Sovereign LORD says: These are the regulations for the altar on the day it is constructed for offering burnt offerings on it and for sprinkling blood on it.
26:43:19/You are to give a young bull as a sin offering to the priests, the Levites who are from the offspring of Zadok, who approach me to minister to me, declares the Sovereign LORD.
26:43:20/You shall take some of its blood and put it on the four horns of the altar and on the four corners of the ledge and on the rim all around. Thus you shall purify it and make atonement for it.
26:43:21/You shall also take the bull for the sin offering, and it shall be burned in the designated part of the temple, outside the sanctuary.
26:43:22/On the second day, you shall offer a male goat without defect as a sin offering, and they shall purify the altar as they did with the bull.
26:43:23/When you finish purifying it, you shall offer a young bull without defect and a ram from the flock without defect.
26:43:24/You shall present them before the LORD, and the priests shall throw salt on them and offer them as a burnt offering to the LORD.
26:43:25/For seven days you shall prepare a goat for a sin offering each day. They shall also prepare a young bull and a ram from the flock, both without defect.
26:43:26/For seven days they shall make atonement for the altar and cleanse it; thus they shall consecrate it.
26:43:27/And when these days are over, on the eighth day and thereafter, the priests shall offer your burnt offerings on the altar and your peace offerings; and I will accept you, declares the Sovereign LORD.
26:44:1/Then he led me back to the gate of the outer sanctuary facing east, but it was closed.
26:44:2/Then the LORD said to me, "This gate is to remain shut. It must not be opened, and no one is to enter through it because the LORD, the God of Israel, has entered through it. Therefore, it must stay shut.
26:44:3/It is reserved for the prince. The prince himself may sit in it to eat a meal before the LORD. He must enter through the porch of the gate and leave the same way."
26:44:4/Then he took me to the north gate in front of the temple. I looked, and the glory of the LORD filled the LORD's temple, and I fell facedown.
26:44:5/And the LORD said to me, "Son of man, pay close attention, see with your eyes, and listen with your ears to everything I tell you about all the regulations and laws of the LORD's temple. Take note of the entrance to the temple and all the exits of the sanctuary.
26:44:6/Tell the rebellious house of Israel, 'This is what the Sovereign LORD says: Enough of all your detestable practices, house of Israel,
26:44:7/when you brought foreigners, uncircumcised in heart and flesh, into my sanctuary, desecrating my temple while you offered my food, the fat, and the blood. You broke my covenant with all your detestable practices.
26:44:8/You have not kept charge of my holy things but have appointed others to keep charge of my sanctuary for you.
26:44:9/This is what the Sovereign LORD says: No foreigner, uncircumcised in heart and flesh, is to enter my sanctuary, including any foreigner living among the Israelites.
26:44:10/Even the Levites who strayed away from me when Israel went astray, who strayed away from me after their idols, must bear the consequences of their sin.
26:44:11/Yet they will serve in my sanctuary, overseeing the gates of the temple and serving in the temple; they will slaughter the burnt offerings and sacrifices for the people and stand before the people to serve them.
26:44:12/Because they served them in front of their idols and led the house of Israel into sin, therefore I have sworn against them, declares the Sovereign LORD, and they will bear their guilt.
26:44:13/They are not to come near to serve me as priests or come near any of my holy things or the most holy offerings; they must bear the shame of their detestable practices.
26:44:14/Yet I will make them responsible for the upkeep of the temple, for all its work, and for everything done in it.
26:44:15/But the Levitical priests, the descendants of Zadok, who faithfully performed the duties of my sanctuary when the Israelites strayed from me, are to come near to serve me; they are to stand before me to offer sacrifices of fat and blood, declares the Sovereign LORD.
26:44:16/They are to enter my sanctuary, approach my table to serve me, and carry out my requirements.
26:44:17/When they enter the gates of the inner court, they are to wear linen clothes; they must not wear any woolen garment while serving at the gates of the inner court or inside the temple.
26:44:18/They are to wear linen turbans on their heads and linen undergarments around their waists. They must not wear anything that makes them sweat.
26:44:19/When they go out to the outer court where the people are, they must take off the clothes they have been serving in and leave them in the holy rooms. They are to put on other clothes so they do not consecrate the people with their garments.
26:44:20/They must not shave their heads or let their hair grow long; they are only to trim their hair.
26:44:21/No priest is to drink wine when they enter the inner court.
26:44:22/They must not marry widows or divorced women; they may only marry virgins of the offspring of the house of Israel, or widows of priests.
26:44:23/They are to teach my people the difference between the holy and the common and show them how to distinguish between the unclean and the clean.
26:44:24/In legal disputes, they are to stand as judges, and judge it according to my judgments. They are to keep my laws and my statutes in all my appointed festivals, and they are to keep my Sabbaths holy.
26:44:25/They must not defile themselves by going near a dead person. However, they may defile themselves for a father, mother, son, daughter, brother, or an unmarried sister.
26:44:26/After he is cleansed, they must count off seven days for him.
26:44:27/On the day he goes into the sanctuary, into the inner court to serve in the sanctuary, he must offer his sin offering, declares the Sovereign LORD.
26:44:28/This will be their inheritance: I am their inheritance. You are to give them no property in Israel; I am their property.
26:44:29/They will eat the grain offering, the sin offering, and the guilt offering; and everything in Israel devoted to the LORD will belong to them.
26:44:30/The best of all the firstfruits and of all your special gifts will belong to the priests. You are to give them the first portion of your ground meal so that a blessing may rest on your household.
26:44:31/The priests must not eat anything, bird or beast, that has died naturally or been torn by wild animals.
26:45:1/Furthermore, when you divide the land for inheritance by lot, you must present an offering to the LORD, a sacred portion of the land: its length will be twenty-five thousand cubits, and its width ten thousand. This area will be sacred throughout all its borders.
26:45:2/From this area, a section for the sanctuary will measure five hundred by five hundred cubits, forming a square all around; and there will be a fifty-cubit open space around it.
26:45:3/From this specified area, you will measure a length of twenty-five thousand and a width of ten thousand cubits: within it will be the sanctuary, the most holy place.
26:45:4/The sacred portion of the land will be for the priests, the ministers of the sanctuary, who come near to serve the LORD: it will provide space for their homes and a sacred area for the sanctuary.
26:45:5/And the area measuring twenty-five thousand in length and ten thousand in width will also be for the Levites, the ministers of the temple, for their own possession, to accommodate twenty chambers.
26:45:6/You must designate the city's land allocation as five thousand cubits wide and twenty-five thousand cubits long, adjacent to the sacred offering: it will be for the entire house of Israel.
26:45:7/A portion will be allocated for the prince on both sides of the sacred offering and the city's land, in front of the sacred offering and the city's land, from the west side to the east side: and the length will match one of the portions, from the western border to the eastern border.
26:45:8/This land will be his possession in Israel: and my princes will no longer oppress my people; the rest of the land will be given to the house of Israel according to their tribes.
26:45:9/This is what the Sovereign LORD says; Enough, O princes of Israel: stop violence and destruction, and do what is just and right. Remove your demands from my people, says the Sovereign LORD.
26:45:10/You must use accurate scales, and fair ephah and bath measures.
26:45:11/The ephah and the bath must be of the same size, so that the bath contains a tenth of a homer, and the ephah also a tenth of a homer; the standard measurement will be based on the homer.
26:45:12/And the shekel will be twenty gerahs: your maneh will consist of twenty shekels, plus twenty-five shekels, plus fifteen shekels.
26:45:13/This is the offering you are to present: a sixth of an ephah from a homer of wheat, and you are to give a sixth of an ephah from a homer of barley.
26:45:14/Regarding the oil measurement, you are to offer a tenth of a bath from a cor, which is a homer of ten baths; for ten baths make a homer.
26:45:15/And one lamb from the flock, out of every two hundred, from the rich pastures of Israel; for a grain offering, and for a burnt offering, and for peace offerings, to make atonement for them, says the Sovereign LORD.
26:45:16/All the people of the land are to contribute this offering for the prince in Israel.
26:45:17/It will be the prince's responsibility to provide burnt offerings, grain offerings, and drink offerings, at the festivals, the new moons, and the Sabbaths, at all the appointed feasts of the house of Israel. He will provide the sin offerings, grain offerings, burnt offerings, and fellowship offerings to make atonement for the house of Israel.
26:45:18/This is what the Sovereign LORD says; On the first day of the first month, you are to take a young bull without defect and purify the sanctuary.
26:45:19/The priest is to take some of the blood of the sin offering and put it on the doorposts of the temple, on the four corners of the altar's ledge, and on the posts of the gate of the inner court.
26:45:20/And you are to do the same on the seventh day of the month for anyone who sins unintentionally or through ignorance. So you will make atonement for the temple.
26:45:21/On the fourteenth day of the first month, you are to celebrate the Passover, a festival lasting seven days, during which you shall eat bread made without yeast.
26:45:22/On that day, the prince is to provide for himself and all the people of the land a bull as a sin offering.
26:45:23/For the seven days of the festival, he is to provide a burnt offering to the LORD, seven bulls and seven rams without defect each day for the seven days, and a male goat each day for a sin offering.
26:45:24/He is to provide a grain offering of an ephah for each bull and an ephah for each ram, along with a hin of oil for each ephah.
26:45:25/On the fifteenth day of the seventh month, he is to do the same during the seven-day festival, according to the sin offering, burnt offering, grain offering, and oil.
26:46:1/The Lord GOD says: The gate of the inner court facing east will be closed during the six working days; however, it will be opened on the sabbath and on the day of the new moon.
26:46:2/The prince will enter through the porch of that gate from the outside, and will stand by the gatepost, while the priests prepare his burnt offering and his peace offerings. He will worship at the gate's threshold, then he will leave, but the gate will remain open until the evening.
26:46:3/Similarly, the people of the land will worship at the entrance of this gate before the LORD on the sabbaths and the new moons.
26:46:4/The burnt offering that the prince will present to the LORD on the sabbath day will consist of six lambs without any defects, and a ram without any defects.
26:46:5/The grain offering will be an ephah for a ram, and the grain offering for the lambs will be whatever he can afford, along with a hin of oil for each ephah.
26:46:6/On the day of the new moon, the offering will be a young bull without any defects, six lambs, and a ram, all without any defects.
26:46:7/He will prepare a grain offering of an ephah for a bull, an ephah for a ram, and for the lambs whatever he can afford, along with a hin of oil for each ephah.
26:46:8/When the prince enters, he will do so through the porch of that gate, and he will exit the same way.
26:46:9/But when the people of the land come before the LORD during the appointed festivals, anyone entering through the north gate to worship must exit through the south gate; and anyone entering through the south gate must exit through the north gate. They must not return through the gate they entered but must go straight ahead.
26:46:10/The prince will be among them, entering when they enter and leaving when they leave.
26:46:11/During the festivals and the solemn assemblies, the grain offering will be an ephah for a bull, an ephah for a ram, and for the lambs whatever he can afford, along with a hin of oil for each ephah.
26:46:12/Whenever the prince makes a voluntary burnt offering or peace offerings to the LORD, the gate facing east will be opened for him. He will offer his burnt offering and his peace offerings as he does on the sabbath day. Then he will leave, and the gate will be shut after him.
26:46:13/You must daily offer to the LORD a burnt offering of a lamb of the first year without any defects; this must be done every morning.
26:46:14/Every morning, you must also prepare a grain offering to accompany it, consisting of one-sixth of an ephah and one-third of a hin of oil to mix with the fine flour. This is a continual grain offering to the LORD, to be observed forever.
26:46:15/This is how the lamb, the grain offering, and the oil must be prepared every morning as a regular burnt offering.
26:46:16/The Lord GOD says: If the prince gives a gift to any of his sons, it will become their inheritance; it will belong to them by right.
26:46:17/However, if he gives a gift from his inheritance to one of his servants, it will belong to the servant only until the year of freedom; after that, it will return to the prince. But his inheritance will belong to his sons permanently.
26:46:18/The prince must not take any of the people's inheritance by force, displacing them from their property; instead, he must provide for his sons from his own property, so that my people are not displaced from their own possessions.
26:46:19/He then led me through the entrance beside the gate into the sacred rooms for the priests, which faced north. There, I saw a place at the western end.
26:46:20/He said to me, "This is where the priests will cook the guilt offering and the sin offering, and where they will bake the grain offering, to avoid bringing them into the outer court and consecrating the people."
26:46:21/He then took me out to the outer court and led me around its four corners. I noticed that each corner of the court had a smaller court.
26:46:22/In the four corners of the court, there were enclosed courts, forty cubits long and thirty wide; all four corners were the same size.
26:46:23/There was a row of buildings around the inside of these courts, and under these buildings were places for cooking.
26:46:24/He said to me, "These are the kitchens where those who minister at the temple will cook the sacrifices of the people."
26:47:1/Afterward, he took me back to the entrance of the temple, and I saw water flowing from beneath the threshold of the temple towards the east, since the temple faced east. The water was flowing down from under the right side of the temple, south of the altar.
26:47:2/Then he led me out through the north gate and around to the outer east gate, and I saw water trickling from the south side.
26:47:3/As the man with the measuring line went eastward, he measured off a thousand cubits and then led me through water that was ankle-deep.
26:47:4/He measured another thousand cubits and led me through water that was knee-deep. He measured another thousand and led me through water that was waist-deep.
26:47:5/After measuring another thousand, it became a river that I could not cross, because the water had risen and was deep enough to swim in—a river that could not be crossed on foot.
26:47:6/He asked me, "Do you see this, son of man?" Then he led me back to the bank of the river.
26:47:7/When I returned, I saw a great number of trees on each side of the riverbank.
26:47:8/He explained to me, "These waters flow towards the eastern region, go down into the desert, and enter the sea. When they reach the sea, the water there becomes fresh.
26:47:9/Every living creature that swarms will live wherever the river flows. There will be a very large number of fish, because this water goes there and the waters of the sea become fresh; so everything will live where the river goes.
26:47:10/Fishermen will stand along the shore; from En Gedi to En Eglaim there will be places for spreading nets. The fish will be of many kinds—like the fish of the Great Sea, but in great abundance.
26:47:11/However, its swamps and marshes will not become fresh; they will be left for salt.
26:47:12/Along the bank of the river, on both sides, will grow all kinds of trees used for food. Their leaves will not wither, nor will their fruit fail. Every month they will bear fruit, because the water from the sanctuary flows to them. Their fruit will serve for food and their leaves for healing."
26:47:13/This is what the Sovereign LORD says: "This will be the boundary by which you will divide the land for inheritance among the twelve tribes of Israel. Joseph will have two portions.
26:47:14/You will inherit it equally, one as well as another, a land I swore to give to your ancestors. This land will become your inheritance.
26:47:15/This will be the boundary of the land on the north side, from the Great Sea by way of Hethlon to the entrance of Zedad;
26:47:16/Hamath, Berothah, Sibraim (which lies on the border between Damascus and Hamath), as far as Hazer Hatticon, which is on the border of Hauran.
26:47:17/The boundary will extend from the sea to Hazar Enan along the northern border of Damascus, with the border of Hamath to the north. This will be the north side.
26:47:18/The eastern boundary will run between Hauran and Damascus, along the Jordan between Gilead and the land of Israel, to the Eastern Sea and as far as Tamar. This will be the east side.
26:47:19/The south side will run from Tamar to the waters of Meribah Kadesh, then along the Wadi of Egypt to the Great Sea. This will be the south side.
26:47:20/The western boundary will be the Great Sea from the southern boundary straight up to a point opposite Lebo Hamath. This will be the west side.
26:47:21/You are to distribute this land among yourselves according to the tribes of Israel.
26:47:22/It will happen that you will divide it by lot as an inheritance for yourselves and for the foreigners residing among you who have children. They will be treated as native-born Israelites; along with you they will be allotted an inheritance among the tribes of Israel.
26:47:23/In whatever tribe the foreigner resides, there you will give them their inheritance," declares the Sovereign LORD.
26:48:1/Here are the names of the tribes. From the north end to the coast along the route to Hethlon, heading towards Hamath, Hazarenan, the northern border of Damascus, up to the coast of Hamath; these are its boundaries east and west; a portion for Dan.
26:48:2/Next to Dan's territory, from the east side to the west side, a portion for Asher.
26:48:3/Next to Asher's territory, from the east side to the west side, a portion for Naphtali.
26:48:4/Next to Naphtali's territory, from the east side to the west side, a portion for Manasseh.
26:48:5/Next to Manasseh's territory, from the east side to the west side, a portion for Ephraim.
26:48:6/Next to Ephraim's territory, from the east side to the west side, a portion for Reuben.
26:48:7/Next to Reuben's territory, from the east side to the west side, a portion for Judah.
26:48:8/Next to Judah's territory, from the east side to the west side, will be the offering area, 25,000 reeds wide, and as long as the other portions from east to west; the sanctuary will be in the center.
26:48:9/The offering you shall present to the LORD will be 25,000 in length and 10,000 in width.
26:48:10/For the priests, there will be a sacred offering area; to the north 25,000 in length, to the west 10,000 in width, to the east 10,000 in width, and to the south 25,000 in length; and the LORD's sanctuary will be in the center.
26:48:11/This will be for the priests who are set apart, from the descendants of Zadok, who faithfully followed my instructions and did not stray when the Israelites strayed, unlike the Levites.
26:48:12/And the offered land will be a most holy area next to the territory of the Levites.
26:48:13/Opposite the priests' territory, the Levites will have an area 25,000 in length and 10,000 in width; the total length will be 25,000 and the width 10,000.
26:48:14/They must not sell, trade, or transfer the firstfruits of the land because it is sacred to the LORD.
26:48:15/The 5,000 that are left in width next to the 25,000 will be a common area for the city, for housing, and for suburbs; and the city will be in the center.

26:48:17/And the city's suburbs will extend 250 to the north, 250 to the south, 250 to the east, and 250 to the west.

26:48:19/Those who work in the city will come from all the tribes of Israel.
26:48:20/The entire offering area will be 25,000 by 25,000; you shall offer the sacred square area along with the city property.
26:48:21/The remaining area will belong to the prince, on both sides of the sacred offering and the city property, adjacent to the 25,000 of the offering to the east border, and westward adjacent to the 25,000 towards the west border, alongside the portions for the prince; and the sacred offering and the sanctuary of the temple will be in the center.

26:48:24/Next to Benjamin's territory, from the east side to the west side, Simeon will have a portion.
26:48:25/Next to Simeon's territory, from the east side to the west side, Issachar will have a portion.
26:48:26/Next to Issachar's territory, from the east side to the west side, Zebulun will have a portion.
26:48:27/Next to Zebulun's territory, from the east side to the west side, Gad will have a portion.
26:48:28/Next to Gad's territory, on the south side southward, the border will run from Tamar to the waters of Meribah in Kadesh, then along the river towards the Great Sea.

26:48:31/The city gates will be named after the tribes of Israel: three gates to the north; one gate for Reuben, one gate for Judah, one gate for Levi.
26:48:32/And on the east side 4,500, with three gates; one gate for Joseph, one gate for Benjamin, one gate for Dan.
26:48:33/And on the south side 4,500 measures, with three gates; one gate for Simeon, one gate for Issachar, one gate for Zebulun.
26:48:34/On the west side 4,500, with their three gates; one gate for Gad, one gate for Asher, one gate for Naphtali.
26:48:35/It was around 18,000 measures in total: and from that day the name of the city will be, The LORD is There.
27:1:1/In the third year of Jehoiakim's reign as king of Judah, Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, came to Jerusalem and laid siege to it.
27:1:2/And the Lord handed Jehoiakim, the king of Judah, over to him, along with some of the sacred vessels from the house of God. These he took to the land of Shinar, to his god's temple, placing the vessels in the treasury of his god.
27:1:3/The king instructed Ashpenaz, his chief eunuch, to bring some of the Israelites from the royal family and the nobility.
27:1:4/He wanted young men without any physical defect, handsome, showing aptitude for every kind of learning, well-informed, quick to understand, and qualified to serve in the king's palace. He planned to teach them the language and literature of the Babylonians.
27:1:5/The king assigned them a daily amount of food and wine from the king's table. They were to be trained for three years, and afterward, they were to enter the king's service.
27:1:6/Among these were some from Judah: Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah.
27:1:7/The chief of the eunuchs gave them new names: Daniel he called Belteshazzar, Hananiah he called Shadrach, Mishael he called Meshach, and Azariah he called Abednego.
27:1:8/But Daniel resolved not to defile himself with the royal food and wine, and he asked the chief of the eunuchs for permission not to defile himself this way.
27:1:9/And God caused Daniel to find favor and compassion in the sight of the chief of the eunuchs.
27:1:10/But the chief of the eunuchs said to Daniel, "I am afraid of my lord the king, who has assigned your food and drink. Why should he see you looking worse than the other young men your age? The king would then have my head because of you."
27:1:11/Then Daniel said to the guard whom the chief of the eunuchs had appointed over Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah,
27:1:12/"Please test your servants for ten days: Give us nothing but vegetables to eat and water to drink.
27:1:13/Then compare our appearance with that of the young men who eat the royal food, and treat your servants in accordance with what you see."
27:1:14/So he agreed to this and tested them for ten days.
27:1:15/At the end of the ten days, they looked healthier and better nourished than any of the young men who ate the royal food.
27:1:16/So the guard took away their choice food and the wine they were to drink and gave them vegetables instead.
27:1:17/To these four young men, God gave knowledge and understanding of all kinds of literature and learning. And Daniel could understand visions and dreams of all kinds.
27:1:18/When the time came for them to be presented to the king, the chief of the eunuchs presented them to Nebuchadnezzar.
27:1:19/The king talked with them, and he found none equal to Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah; so they entered the king's service.
27:1:20/In every matter of wisdom and understanding about which the king questioned them, he found them ten times better than all the magicians and enchanters in his whole kingdom.
27:1:21/And Daniel remained there until the first year of King Cyrus.
27:2:1/In the second year of King Nebuchadnezzar's reign, he had dreams that troubled him so much that he couldn't sleep.
27:2:2/So the king ordered the magicians, astrologers, sorcerers, and Chaldeans to be summoned to interpret his dreams. They came and stood before the king.
27:2:3/The king told them, "I had a dream that has disturbed me and I want to know what it means."
27:2:4/The Chaldeans spoke to the king in Aramaic, "O king, may you live forever! Tell your servants the dream, and we will explain its meaning."
27:2:5/The king replied to the Chaldeans, "I have forgotten the dream. If you don't tell me the dream and its interpretation, you will be executed, and your houses will be turned into rubble."
27:2:6/"But if you reveal the dream and its interpretation, you will receive gifts, rewards, and great honor from me. So, tell me the dream and its interpretation."
27:2:7/They responded again, "Please, tell your servants the dream, and we will give you the interpretation."
27:2:8/The king answered, "I am certain you are trying to buy time, realizing that I have forgotten the dream."
27:2:9/"If you don't tell me the dream, there is only one penalty for you. You have conspired to tell me misleading and wicked things, hoping the situation will change. So, tell me the dream, and I will know you can interpret it for me."
27:2:10/The Chaldeans replied to the king, "No one on earth can do what the king asks! No king, however great and mighty, has ever asked such a thing of any magician, astrologer, or Chaldean."
27:2:11/"What the king requests is difficult, and no one can reveal it to the king except the gods, who do not live among humans."
27:2:12/This made the king so angry and furious that he ordered the execution of all the wise men of Babylon.
27:2:13/So the decree was issued to kill the wise men, and men were sent to find and kill Daniel and his friends.
27:2:14/Daniel spoke with wisdom and tact to Arioch, the commander of the king's guard, who had gone out to execute the wise men of Babylon.
27:2:15/He asked Arioch, the king's commander, "Why is the king's decree so urgent?" Arioch then explained the situation to Daniel.
27:2:16/Daniel then went in and asked the king to give him time, promising to interpret the dream for him.
27:2:17/Daniel returned to his house and explained the matter to his friends Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah.
27:2:18/He urged them to plead for mercy from the God of heaven concerning this mystery, so that he and his friends might not be executed with the rest of the wise men of Babylon.
27:2:19/That night, the mystery was revealed to Daniel in a vision. Daniel praised the God of heaven.
27:2:20/Daniel said, "Praise be to the name of God forever and ever; wisdom and power are his."
27:2:21/"He changes times and seasons; he deposes kings and raises up others. He gives wisdom to the wise and knowledge to the discerning."
27:2:22/"He reveals deep and hidden things; he knows what lies in darkness, and light dwells with him."
27:2:23/"I thank and praise you, God of my ancestors, for giving me wisdom and power, and for revealing to us what we asked of you; for you have shown us the king's demand."
27:2:24/So Daniel went to Arioch, whom the king had appointed to execute the wise men of Babylon, and said to him, "Do not execute the wise men of Babylon. Take me to the king, and I will interpret his dream for him."
27:2:25/Arioch quickly brought Daniel before the king and said, "I have found a man among the exiles from Judah who can tell the king the interpretation."
27:2:26/The king asked Daniel, also known as Belteshazzar, "Can you tell me what I saw in my dream and interpret it?"
27:2:27/Daniel replied in the presence of the king, "The wise men, astrologers, magicians, and diviners cannot reveal to the king the mystery he has asked about."
27:2:28/"But there is a God in heaven who reveals mysteries, and he has shown King Nebuchadnezzar what will happen in the future. Your dream and the visions that passed through your mind as you were lying in bed are these:"
27:2:29/"As for you, O king, thoughts came to your mind while on your bed about what would happen in the future, and the revealer of mysteries has made known to you what is going to happen."
27:2:30/"As for me, this mystery has been revealed to me not because I have greater wisdom than anyone else alive, but so that Your Majesty may know the interpretation and that you may understand what went through your mind."
27:2:31/"You, O king, saw a great statue. This statue, which was large and of extraordinary splendor, stood before you, and its appearance was terrifying."
27:2:32/"The head of the statue was made of pure gold, its chest and arms of silver, its belly and thighs of bronze,"
27:2:33/"its legs of iron, its feet partly of iron and partly of baked clay."
27:2:34/"As you watched, a rock was cut out, but not by human hands. It struck the statue on its feet of iron and clay and smashed them."
27:2:35/"Then the iron, the clay, the bronze, the silver, and the gold were all broken to pieces and became like chaff on a threshing floor in the summer. The wind swept them away without leaving a trace. But the rock that struck the statue became a huge mountain and filled the whole earth."
27:2:36/"This was the dream, and now we will interpret it to the king."
27:2:37/"You, O king, the king of kings, to whom the God of heaven has given the kingdom, power, strength, and glory,"
27:2:38/"and into whose hand he has given human beings, wherever they live, the beasts of the field and the birds in the sky, granting you authority over them all—you are the head of gold."
27:2:39/"After you, another kingdom will arise, inferior to yours; then a third kingdom, one of bronze, will rule over the whole earth."
27:2:40/"Finally, there will be a fourth kingdom, strong as iron—for iron breaks and smashes everything—and as iron breaks things to pieces, so it will crush and break all the others."
27:2:41/"Just as you saw that the feet and toes were partly of baked clay and partly of iron, so this will be a divided kingdom; yet it will have some of the strength of iron in it, even as you saw iron mixed with clay."
27:2:42/"As the toes were partly iron and partly clay, so this kingdom will be partly strong and partly brittle."
27:2:43/"And just as you saw the iron mixed with baked clay, so the people will be a mixture and will not remain united, any more than iron mixes with clay."
27:2:44/"In the time of those kings, the God of heaven will set up a kingdom that will never be destroyed, nor will it be left to another people. It will crush all those kingdoms and bring them to an end, but it will itself endure forever."
27:2:45/"This is the meaning of the vision of the rock cut out of a mountain, but not by human hands—a rock that broke the iron, the bronze, the clay, the silver and the gold to pieces. The great God has shown the king what will take place in the future. The dream is true and its interpretation is trustworthy."
27:2:46/Then King Nebuchadnezzar fell prostrate before Daniel, paid him honor, and ordered that an offering and incense be presented to him.
27:2:47/The king said to Daniel, "Surely your God is the God of gods and the Lord of kings and a revealer of mysteries, for you were able to reveal this mystery."
27:2:48/Then the king placed Daniel in a high position and lavished many gifts on him. He made him ruler over the entire province of Babylon and placed him in charge of all its wise men.
27:2:49/At Daniel's request, the king appointed Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego to administer the province of Babylon, while Daniel himself remained at the royal court.
27:3:1/King Nebuchadnezzar made a gold statue, sixty cubits tall and six cubits wide, and set it up on the plain of Dura in the province of Babylon.
27:3:2/Then King Nebuchadnezzar summoned the princes, governors, captains, judges, treasurers, counselors, sheriffs, and all provincial officials to attend the dedication of the statue he had erected.
27:3:3/So the princes, governors, captains, judges, treasurers, counselors, sheriffs, and all provincial officials assembled for the dedication of the statue that King Nebuchadnezzar had set up, and they stood before it.
27:3:4/Then a herald loudly proclaimed, "People of all nations and languages, listen up!
27:3:5/Whenever you hear the sound of the horn, flute, zither, lyre, harp, pipes, and all kinds of music, you must fall down and worship the gold statue that King Nebuchadnezzar has set up.
27:3:6/Anyone who does not fall down and worship will immediately be thrown into a blazing furnace."
27:3:7/Therefore, as soon as all the people heard the sound of the horn, flute, zither, lyre, harp, and all kinds of music, people of every nation and language fell down and worshiped the gold statue that King Nebuchadnezzar had set up.
27:3:8/At that time, some Chaldeans came forward and maliciously accused the Jews.
27:3:9/They said to King Nebuchadnezzar, "May the king live forever!
27:3:10/You, O king, have issued a decree that everyone who hears the sound of the horn, flute, zither, lyre, harp, pipes, and all kinds of music must fall down and worship the gold statue,
27:3:11/and that anyone who does not fall down and worship should be thrown into a blazing furnace.
27:3:12/There are some Jews you have appointed over the affairs of the province of Babylon—Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego—who have ignored your command, O king. They do not serve your gods or worship the gold statue you have set up."
27:3:13/In a furious rage, Nebuchadnezzar ordered Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego to be brought before him. So they were brought before the king.
27:3:14/Nebuchadnezzar said to them, "Is it true, Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, that you do not serve my gods or worship the gold statue I have set up?
27:3:15/Now, if you are ready, when you hear the sound of the horn, flute, zither, lyre, harp, pipes, and all kinds of music, to fall down and worship the statue I made, good. But if you do not worship, you will be thrown immediately into a blazing furnace. And who is the god who will rescue you from my hands?"
27:3:16/Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego replied to the king, "O Nebuchadnezzar, we do not need to defend ourselves before you in this matter.
27:3:17/If we are thrown into the blazing furnace, the God we serve is able to save us from it, and He will rescue us from your hand, O king.
27:3:18/But even if He does not, we want you to know, O king, that we will not serve your gods or worship the gold statue you have set up."
27:3:19/Then Nebuchadnezzar was furious with Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, and his attitude toward them changed. He ordered the furnace heated seven times hotter than usual.
27:3:20/And he commanded some of the strongest soldiers in his army to tie up Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego and throw them into the blazing furnace.
27:3:21/So these men, wearing their robes, trousers, turbans, and other clothes, were bound and thrown into the blazing furnace.
27:3:22/The king's command was so urgent and the furnace so hot that the flames of the fire killed the soldiers who took up Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego,
27:3:23/and these three men, firmly tied, fell into the blazing furnace.
27:3:24/Then King Nebuchadnezzar leaped to his feet in amazement and asked his advisers, "Weren't there three men that we tied up and threw into the fire?" They replied, "Certainly, O king."
27:3:25/He said, "Look! I see four men walking around in the fire, unbound and unharmed, and the fourth looks like a son of the gods."
27:3:26/Nebuchadnezzar then approached the opening of the blazing furnace and shouted, "Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, servants of the Most High God, come out! Come here!" So Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego came out of the fire,
27:3:27/and the princes, governors, captains, and the king's advisers crowded around them. They saw that the fire had not harmed their bodies, nor was a hair of their heads singed; their robes were not scorched, and there was no smell of fire on them.
27:3:28/Then Nebuchadnezzar said, "Praise be to the God of Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, who has sent His angel and rescued His servants! They trusted in Him and defied the king's command and were willing to give up their lives rather than serve or worship any god except their own God.
27:3:29/Therefore I decree that the people of any nation or language who say anything against the God of Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego be cut into pieces and their houses be turned into piles of rubble, for no other god can save in this way."
27:3:30/Then the king promoted Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego in the province of Babylon.
27:4:1/Nebuchadnezzar the king, to all peoples, nations, and languages living across the earth; may peace be greatly increased for you.
27:4:2/I thought it was important to share the miraculous signs and wonders that the high God has performed for me.
27:4:3/How incredible are his signs! And how powerful are his wonders! His kingdom lasts forever, and his rule extends from one generation to the next.
27:4:4/I, Nebuchadnezzar, was at peace in my home, thriving in my palace.
27:4:5/I had a dream that frightened me, and the thoughts on my bed and the visions in my mind disturbed me.
27:4:6/So, I issued a decree to summon all the wise men of Babylon to me, so they could explain the dream's meaning.
27:4:7/The magicians, astrologers, Chaldeans, and diviners came, but they couldn't explain the dream to me.
27:4:8/Finally, Daniel came before me, who is named Belteshazzar after my god, and in whom is the spirit of the holy gods. I shared the dream with him, saying,
27:4:9/"O Belteshazzar, chief of the magicians, because I know the spirit of the holy gods is in you and no mystery baffles you, tell me what my dream means and its interpretation."
27:4:10/In my dream, I saw a tree at the center of the earth, towering high.
27:4:11/The tree grew strong, its top touching the sky, visible to the ends of the earth.
27:4:12/Its leaves were beautiful, its fruit abundant, providing food for all. Wild animals found shade under it, birds lived in its branches, and every creature was fed from it.
27:4:13/In my dream, I saw a sentinel, a holy one, coming down from heaven.
27:4:14/He shouted, 'Cut down the tree, trim off its branches, shake off its leaves, and scatter its fruit. Let the animals flee from beneath it and the birds from its branches.
27:4:15/However, leave the stump with its roots in the ground, bound with iron and bronze, surrounded by tender grass. Let it be drenched with the dew of heaven, and let it share the lot of the animals in the grass of the earth.
27:4:16/Let its human heart be replaced with the heart of an animal, and let this condition prevail for seven periods of time.
27:4:17/This decree is issued by the sentinels, and the sentence by the word of the holy ones, so that all living may know that the Most High rules over the kingdoms of men and gives them to whomever he wishes, setting over them the lowliest of people.'
27:4:18/This is the dream I, King Nebuchadnezzar, had. Now, Belteshazzar, tell me its interpretation, since none of the wise men in my kingdom can explain it to me. But you can, because the spirit of the holy gods is in you.
27:4:19/Then Daniel, also known as Belteshazzar, was stunned for a moment, and his thoughts alarmed him. The king said, 'Belteshazzar, don't let the dream or its interpretation worry you.' Belteshazzar replied, 'My lord, may the dream apply to those who oppose you, and its interpretation to your adversaries.'
27:4:20/The tree you saw, which grew large and strong, reaching to the sky and visible to the whole earth,
27:4:21/with beautiful leaves and abundant fruit, providing food for all, under which wild animals lived, and in whose branches birds made their nests,
27:4:22/it represents you, O king, who have grown and become strong. Your greatness has grown and reaches to the sky, and your dominion extends to the ends of the earth.
27:4:23/And as for the king seeing a sentinel, a holy one, coming down from heaven and saying, 'Cut down the tree and destroy it, but leave the stump of its roots in the ground, with a band of iron and bronze, in the tender grass of the field; let it be drenched with the dew of heaven, and let him share the lot of the animals of the field until seven periods of time pass over him,'
27:4:24/this is the interpretation, O king, and it is the decree of the Most High that has come upon my lord the king:
27:4:25/You will be driven away from people and will live with the wild animals; you will eat grass like oxen and be drenched with the dew of heaven. Seven periods of time will pass over you until you acknowledge that the Most High is sovereign over the kingdoms of men and gives them to anyone he wishes.
27:4:26/And as for the command to leave the stump of the tree roots, your kingdom will be restored to you once you acknowledge that Heaven rules.
27:4:27/Therefore, O king, let my advice be acceptable to you: renounce your sins by doing what is right, and your wickedness by being kind to the oppressed. It may be that then your prosperity will continue.'
27:4:28/All this happened to King Nebuchadnezzar.
27:4:29/After twelve months, he was walking on the roof of the royal palace of Babylon.
27:4:30/The king exclaimed, 'Is this not the great Babylon I have built as the royal residence, by my mighty power and for the glory of my majesty?'
27:4:31/While the words were still in the king's mouth, a voice came from heaven, 'O King Nebuchadnezzar, to you it is declared: The kingdom has been taken from you.
27:4:32/You will be driven away from people and will live with the wild animals; you will eat grass like oxen, and seven periods of time will pass over you until you acknowledge that the Most High is sovereign over the kingdoms of men and gives them to anyone he wishes.'
27:4:33/Immediately, the sentence was carried out on Nebuchadnezzar: he was driven from people, ate grass like oxen, and his body was drenched with the dew of heaven, until his hair grew like the feathers of an eagle and his nails like the claws of a bird.
27:4:34/At the end of that time, I, Nebuchadnezzar, raised my eyes to heaven, and my sanity was restored. Then I praised the Most High; I honored and glorified him who lives forever. His dominion is an eternal dominion; his kingdom endures from generation to generation.
27:4:35/All the peoples of the earth are regarded as nothing. He does as he pleases with the powers of heaven and the peoples of the earth. No one can hold back his hand or say to him, 'What have you done?'
27:4:36/At the same time, my sanity was restored, along with the glory of my kingdom, my honor and splendor returned to me. My advisers and nobles sought me out, and I was restored to my throne and became even greater than before.
27:4:37/Now I, Nebuchadnezzar, praise and exalt and glorify the King of heaven, because all his acts are true and his ways just. And he can humble those who walk in pride.
27:5:1/Belshazzar the king threw a massive party for a thousand of his lords, and drank wine in front of them all.
27:5:2/While enjoying the wine, Belshazzar ordered to bring the gold and silver vessels that his father Nebuchadnezzar had taken from the temple in Jerusalem; so that he, his princes, his wives, and his concubines could drink from them.
27:5:3/So they brought the gold vessels that had been taken from the temple of God in Jerusalem; and the king, his princes, his wives, and his concubines drank from them.
27:5:4/They drank wine and praised the gods made of gold, silver, bronze, iron, wood, and stone.
27:5:5/At that very moment, fingers of a human hand appeared and wrote on the plaster of the wall of the king's palace, near the lampstand. The king saw the hand as it wrote.
27:5:6/The king's face turned pale, and his thoughts terrified him. His hips gave way, and his knees knocked together.
27:5:7/The king shouted to bring in the enchanters, the Chaldeans, and the diviners. He said to the wise men of Babylon, "Whoever reads this writing and tells me its meaning will be dressed in purple, have a gold chain placed around his neck, and be made the third highest ruler in the kingdom."
27:5:8/All the king's wise men came in, but they could not read the writing or tell the king what it meant.
27:5:9/King Belshazzar became even more terrified, his face grew more pale, and his lords were baffled.
27:5:10/The queen, because of what the king and his lords had said, came into the banquet hall. "O king, live forever!" she said. "Don't let your thoughts alarm you or your face be pale.
27:5:11/There is a man in your kingdom who has the spirit of the holy gods in him. In the time of your father, he was found to have insight and intelligence and wisdom like that of the gods. King Nebuchadnezzar, your father—your father the king, I say—appointed him chief of the magicians, enchanters, Chaldeans, and diviners.
27:5:12/This man, Daniel, whom the king named Belteshazzar, was found to have a keen mind and knowledge and understanding, and also the ability to interpret dreams, explain riddles and solve difficult problems. Call for Daniel, and he will tell you what the writing means."
27:5:13/So Daniel was brought before the king, and the king said to him, "Are you Daniel, one of the exiles my father the king brought from Judah?
27:5:14/I have heard that the spirit of the gods is in you and that you have insight, intelligence and outstanding wisdom.
27:5:15/The wise men and enchanters were brought before me to read this writing and tell me its meaning, but they could not explain it.
27:5:16/But I have heard that you can give interpretations and solve difficult problems. If you can read the writing and tell me its meaning, you will be clothed in purple, have a gold chain placed around your neck, and be made the third highest ruler in the kingdom."
27:5:17/Then Daniel replied to the king, "Keep your gifts for yourself or give your rewards to someone else. Nevertheless, I will read the writing for the king and tell him what it means.
27:5:18/"Your Majesty, the Most High God gave your father Nebuchadnezzar sovereignty and greatness, glory and honor.
27:5:19/And because of the high position he gave him, all the peoples and nations of every language dreaded and feared him. Those he wanted to put to death, he put to death; those he wanted to spare, he spared; those he wanted to promote, he promoted; and those he wanted to humble, he humbled.
27:5:20/But when his heart became arrogant and hardened with pride, he was deposed from his royal throne and stripped of his glory.
27:5:21/He was driven away from people and given the mind of an animal; he lived with the wild donkeys and ate grass like the ox; and his body was drenched with the dew of heaven, until he acknowledged that the Most High God is sovereign over all kingdoms on earth and sets over them anyone he wishes.
27:5:22/"But you, his son, O Belshazzar, have not humbled yourself, though you knew all this.
27:5:23/Instead, you have set yourself up against the Lord of heaven. You had the goblets from his temple brought to you, and you and your nobles, your wives and your concubines drank wine from them. You praised the gods of silver and gold, of bronze, iron, wood and stone, which cannot see or hear or understand. But you did not honor the God who holds in his hand your life and all your ways.
27:5:24/Therefore he sent the hand that wrote the inscription.
27:5:25/"This is the inscription that was written: MENE, MENE, TEKEL, UPHARSIN.
27:5:26/"This is what these words mean: Mene: God has numbered the days of your reign and brought it to an end.
27:5:27/Tekel: You have been weighed on the scales and found lacking.
27:5:28/Peres: Your kingdom is divided and given to the Medes and Persians."
27:5:29/At Belshazzar's command, Daniel was clothed in purple, a gold chain was placed around his neck, and he was proclaimed the third highest ruler in the kingdom.
27:5:30/That very night Belshazzar, king of the Babylonians, was killed.
27:5:31/And Darius the Mede took over the kingdom, at the age of sixty-two.
27:6:1/Darius decided to appoint 120 princes to govern the entire kingdom;
27:6:2/And above these, three presidents, with Daniel being the foremost, so the princes would report to them, ensuring the king suffered no loss.
27:6:3/Daniel was favored above the presidents and princes because he possessed an exceptional spirit, and the king planned to place him in charge of the entire kingdom.
27:6:4/However, the presidents and princes tried to find reasons to accuse Daniel in matters of state, but they could not find any fault or error in him because he was trustworthy.
27:6:5/These men concluded, "We will not find any grounds for accusation against Daniel unless it has to do with the law of his God."
27:6:6/So these presidents and princes went as a group to the king and said, "King Darius, may you live forever.
27:6:7/All the kingdom's presidents, governors, princes, advisors, and commanders have agreed to establish a royal law and enforce a strict decree that anyone who petitions any god or man except you, O king, for thirty days, shall be thrown into the lions' den.
27:6:8/Now, O king, issue this decree and sign the document so that it cannot be altered, in accordance with the laws of the Medes and Persians, which are irrevocable."
27:6:9/Therefore, King Darius signed the document and decree.
27:6:10/When Daniel learned that the decree had been signed, he went home. With his windows open towards Jerusalem, he knelt down to pray and give thanks to his God three times a day, just as he had always done.
27:6:11/Then these men found Daniel praying and pleading before his God.
27:6:12/They approached the king and questioned him about his decree, "Did you not sign a decree that anyone who petitions any god or man within thirty days, except you, O king, would be thrown into the lions' den?" The king confirmed, "The decree stands, in accordance with the law of the Medes and Persians, which cannot be repealed."
27:6:13/They then said to the king, "Daniel, one of the exiles from Judah, pays no attention to you, O king, or to the decree you signed, but prays three times a day."
27:6:14/Upon hearing this, the king was greatly distressed and was determined to save Daniel, working until sunset to find a way to rescue him.
27:6:15/But these men insisted to the king, "Remember, O king, that according to the law of the Medes and Persians, no decree or statute the king establishes can be changed."
27:6:16/So the king ordered Daniel to be brought and thrown into the lions' den. The king said to Daniel, "May your God, whom you serve so faithfully, rescue you."
27:6:17/A stone was brought and placed over the mouth of the den, and the king sealed it with his own seal and the seals of his lords, so that Daniel's situation might not be altered.
27:6:18/Then the king returned to his palace and spent the night fasting; no entertainment was provided for him, and he could not sleep.
27:6:19/At the first light of dawn, the king got up and hurried to the lions' den.
27:6:20/As he approached the den, he called out to Daniel in anguish, "O Daniel, servant of the living God, has your God, whom you serve so faithfully, been able to rescue you from the lions?"
27:6:21/Daniel replied to the king, "May the king live forever.
27:6:22/My God sent his angel to shut the lions' mouths, and they have not harmed me, because I was found innocent in his sight. And also before you, O king, I have done no wrong."
27:6:23/The king was overjoyed and ordered that Daniel be lifted from the den. When Daniel was brought up out of the den, no injury was found on him, because he had trusted in his God.
27:6:24/The king then commanded that those men who had falsely accused Daniel be thrown into the lions' den, along with their families. Before they reached the floor of the den, the lions overpowered them and broke all their bones.
27:6:25/Then King Darius wrote to all the peoples, nations, and languages that dwell in all the earth: "May you have abundant peace.
27:6:26/I decree that in every part of my kingdom people must fear and reverence the God of Daniel. For he is the living God, enduring forever; his kingdom will not be destroyed, and his dominion will never end.
27:6:27/He rescues and saves; he performs signs and wonders in the heavens and on the earth. He has rescued Daniel from the power of the lions."
27:6:28/Thus, Daniel prospered during the reign of Darius and the reign of Cyrus the Persian.
27:7:1/In the first year of Belshazzar king of Babylon, Daniel had a dream and visions while sleeping: then he wrote the dream down, and summarized the events.
27:7:2/Daniel spoke and said, I saw in my vision at night, and, look, the four winds of heaven were stirring up the great sea.
27:7:3/And four huge beasts emerged from the sea, each different from the others.
27:7:4/The first was like a lion, but had eagle’s wings: I watched until its wings were torn off, and it was lifted from the ground, made to stand on two feet like a human, and given a human heart.
27:7:5/And then another beast appeared, a second one, resembling a bear. It propped itself up on one side, and it had three ribs in its mouth between its teeth: and they said to it, 'Get up, consume a lot of flesh.'
27:7:6/After this, I looked, and there was another, like a leopard, which had four bird wings on its back; the beast also had four heads; and power was given to it.
27:7:7/After this, in my night visions, I saw a fourth beast, terrifying and frightening, and extremely strong; it had huge iron teeth: it devoured and crushed, and trampled what was left with its feet: it was different from all the beasts before it; and it had ten horns.
27:7:8/I focused on the horns, and, look, another small horn sprouted among them, before which three of the first horns were uprooted: and, look, in this horn were eyes like human eyes, and a mouth speaking boastful words.
27:7:9/I watched until thrones were set in place, and the Ancient of Days took His seat, His clothing was as white as snow, and the hair of His head like the purest wool: His throne was like flames of fire, and its wheels were ablaze.
27:7:10/A river of fire was flowing and coming out from before Him: thousands upon thousands served Him, and ten thousand times ten thousand stood before Him: the court was convened, and the books were opened.
27:7:11/I watched then because of the boastful words the horn was speaking: I watched until the beast was killed, and its body destroyed and thrown into the blazing fire.
27:7:12/Regarding the rest of the beasts, their power was taken away, but their lives were extended for a period of time.
27:7:13/In my night visions, I saw someone like a human being coming with the clouds of heaven, approaching the Ancient of Days, who was presented before Him.
27:7:14/He was given authority, honor, and a kingdom, so that people of all nations and languages would serve Him: His dominion is an everlasting dominion that will not pass away, and His kingdom is one that will never be destroyed.
27:7:15/I, Daniel, was distressed in my spirit, and the visions that passed through my mind alarmed me.
27:7:16/I approached one of those standing nearby and asked him the true meaning of all this. So he explained it to me and revealed the interpretation of these events:
27:7:17/These great beasts, which are four in number, represent four kings who will rise from the earth.
27:7:18/But the holy people of the Most High will receive the kingdom and will possess it forever—yes, for eternity.
27:7:19/Then I wanted to know the true meaning of the fourth beast, which was different from all the others, extremely terrifying, with its iron teeth and bronze claws—the beast that devoured, crushed, and trampled its victims underfoot;
27:7:20/And about the ten horns on its head, and the other horn that came up, before which three of them fell—the horn that had eyes and a mouth that spoke boastfully and looked more imposing than the others.
27:7:21/I watched as that horn waged war against the holy people and defeated them,
27:7:22/Until the Ancient of Days came and pronounced judgment in favor of the holy people of the Most High, and the time came when they possessed the kingdom.
27:7:23/He explained, "The fourth beast will be a fourth kingdom on earth, which will be different from all other kingdoms. It will devour the whole earth, trample it down, and crush it.
27:7:24/The ten horns are ten kings who will come from this kingdom. After them, another king will arise, different from the earlier ones; he will subdue three kings.
27:7:25/He will speak against the Most High and oppress His holy people, intending to change the set times and laws. They will be handed over to him for a time, times, and half a time.
27:7:26/But the court will sit, and his power will be taken away, to be completely destroyed forever.
27:7:27/Then the sovereignty, power, and greatness of all the kingdoms under heaven will be handed over to the holy people of the Most High. His kingdom will be an everlasting kingdom, and all rulers will worship and obey Him."
27:7:28/This is the end of the matter. As for me, Daniel, my thoughts greatly troubled me, and my face turned pale, but I kept the matter to myself.
27:8:1/In the third year of King Belshazzar's reign, I, Daniel, had a vision, following the first one that had come to me.
27:8:2/In this vision, I found myself in Shushan, the palace, located in the province of Elam; I was beside the Ulai River.
27:8:3/When I looked up, I saw a ram standing by the river with two horns; both horns were long, but one was longer than the other, and the longer one grew out last.
27:8:4/The ram charged westward, northward, and southward, overpowering all animals in its path so that none could stand against it or escape from its power; it did as it pleased and became very powerful.
27:8:5/While I was thinking about this, suddenly a goat with a conspicuous horn between its eyes came from the west, covering the ground without touching it.
27:8:6/This goat charged the two-horned ram I had seen standing by the river, attacking it with furious power.
27:8:7/I saw the goat approach the ram in a rage, strike the ram, break its two horns, and the ram had no strength to stand against it. The goat knocked the ram to the ground and trampled on it, and no one could rescue the ram from its power.
27:8:8/As a result, the goat grew extremely powerful; but at the height of its power, the large horn was broken off, and in its place, four prominent horns grew toward the four winds of heaven.
27:8:9/From one of these horns, a small one emerged and grew exceedingly great toward the south, the east, and the beautiful land.
27:8:10/It grew so great it reached the host of heaven, and it threw some of the starry host down to the earth and trampled on them.
27:8:11/It even challenged the commander of the host; it removed the daily sacrifice from him, and the place of his sanctuary was overthrown.
27:8:12/Because of rebellion, a host was given over to the horn along with the daily sacrifice, and it threw truth to the ground; it did all this and prospered.
27:8:13/Then I heard one holy one speaking, and another holy one said to the speaker, "How long will the vision about the daily sacrifice and the devastating rebellion last, allowing the sanctuary and the host to be trampled?"
27:8:14/He replied, "For 2,300 evenings and mornings; then the sanctuary will be restored."
27:8:15/After I, Daniel, had seen the vision and was trying to understand it, suddenly I saw someone who looked like a man standing before me.
27:8:16/I heard a human voice from the Ulai calling out, "Gabriel, explain the vision to this man."
27:8:17/So he came near where I stood, and when he approached, I was terrified and fell prostrate. But he said to me, "Understand, son of man, that the vision is about the time of the end."
27:8:18/While he was speaking to me, I fell into a deep sleep with my face to the ground. But he touched me, lifting me to my feet.
27:8:19/He said, "I am going to tell you what will happen in the final period of wrath, for it concerns the appointed time of the end."
27:8:20/The ram you saw with the two horns represents the kings of Media and Persia.
27:8:21/The shaggy goat is the king of Greece, and the large horn between its eyes is the first king.
27:8:22/After it is broken, four kingdoms will arise from the nation, but they will not have the same power.
27:8:23/In the latter part of their reign, when rebels have become completely wicked, a fierce king, skilled in intrigue, will arise.
27:8:24/His power will be great, but not by his own power. He will cause astounding devastation and will succeed in whatever he does. He will destroy the powerful, along with the holy people.
27:8:25/He will cause deceit to prosper, and he will consider himself superior. When they feel secure, he will destroy many and take his stand against the Prince of princes. Yet he will be destroyed, but not by human power.
27:8:26/The vision of the evenings and mornings that has been given to you is true, but seal up the vision, for it concerns the distant future.
27:8:27/And I, Daniel, was exhausted and lay ill for several days. Then I got up and went about the king's business. I was appalled by the vision; it was beyond understanding.
27:9:1/In the first year of Darius the son of Ahasuerus, from the Medes' lineage, who became king over the Chaldeans;
27:9:2/In his first year as king, I, Daniel, learned from the scriptures the number of years that the LORD had told Jeremiah the prophet it would take to complete the seventy years of Jerusalem's desolation.
27:9:3/So I turned my attention to the Lord God, seeking him through prayer and pleas for mercy, with fasting, sackcloth, and ashes.
27:9:4/And I prayed to the LORD my God, confessing my sins, and said, "O Lord, the great and awe-inspiring God, who keeps his covenant and shows mercy to those who love him and keep his commandments;
27:9:5/We have sinned, acted unjustly, behaved wickedly, and rebelled, turning away from your commands and laws.
27:9:6/We have not listened to your servants the prophets, who spoke in your name to our kings, our leaders, our ancestors, and all the people of the land.
27:9:7/O LORD, righteousness belongs to you, but to us, shame is evident today—to the people of Judah, the inhabitants of Jerusalem, and all Israel, both near and far, in all the countries where you have scattered them because of their unfaithfulness to you.
27:9:8/O Lord, shame faces us, our kings, our leaders, and our ancestors, because we have sinned against you.
27:9:9/To the Lord our God belong mercy and forgiveness, even though we have rebelled against him;
27:9:10/We have not obeyed the LORD our God or followed the laws he gave us through his servants the prophets.
27:9:11/Indeed, all Israel has violated your law and turned away, refusing to listen to your voice; so the curse and oath written in the Law of Moses, the servant of God, have been poured out on us because we have sinned against you.
27:9:12/He has fulfilled his words, which he spoke against us and our rulers by bringing upon us a great disaster. Under the entire heaven, nothing has been done like what has been done to Jerusalem.
27:9:13/As it is written in the Law of Moses, all this disaster has come upon us, yet we have not sought the favor of the LORD our God by turning from our iniquities and giving attention to your truth.
27:9:14/Therefore, the LORD has kept the disaster in mind and brought it upon us, for the LORD our God is righteous in all he does; yet we have not obeyed his voice.
27:9:15/And now, O Lord our God, who brought your people out of the land of Egypt with a mighty hand and made yourself a name that endures to this day, we have sinned, we have done wrong.
27:9:16/O LORD, in keeping with all your righteous acts, let your anger and your wrath turn away from your city Jerusalem, your holy hill. Our sins and the iniquities of our ancestors have made Jerusalem and your people an object of scorn to all those around us.
27:9:17/Now, our God, hear the prayers and petitions of your servant. For your sake, Lord, look with favor on your desolate sanctuary.
27:9:18/Give ear, my God, and hear; open your eyes and see the desolation of the city that bears your name. We do not make requests of you because we are righteous, but because of your great mercy.
27:9:19/O Lord, listen! O Lord, forgive! O Lord, pay attention and act! Do not delay for your own sake, my God, because your city and your people bear your name."
27:9:20/While I was speaking, praying, confessing my sin and the sin of my people Israel, and laying my plea before the LORD my God for his holy hill—
27:9:21/Yes, while I was praying, Gabriel, the man I had seen in the earlier vision, came to me in swift flight about the time of the evening sacrifice.
27:9:22/He instructed me and said, "Daniel, I have now come to give you insight and understanding.
27:9:23/As soon as you began to pray, a command was issued, and I have come to tell you, for you are highly esteemed. Therefore, consider the message and understand the vision:
27:9:24/Seventy 'sevens' are decreed for your people and your holy city to finish transgression, to put an end to sin, to atone for wickedness, to bring in everlasting righteousness, to seal up vision and prophecy, and to anoint the Most Holy Place.
27:9:25/Know and understand this: From the time the word goes out to restore and rebuild Jerusalem until the Anointed One, the ruler, comes, there will be seven 'sevens,' and sixty-two 'sevens.' It will be rebuilt with streets and a trench, but in times of trouble.
27:9:26/After the sixty-two 'sevens,' the Anointed One will be put to death and will have nothing. The people of the ruler who will come will destroy the city and the sanctuary. The end will come like a flood: War will continue until the end, and desolations have been decreed.
27:9:27/He will confirm a covenant with many for one 'seven.' In the middle of the 'seven' he will put an end to sacrifice and offering. And at the temple, he will set up an abomination that causes desolation, until the end that is decreed is poured out on the desolator.
27:10:1/In the third year of Cyrus king of Persia, a revelation was given to Daniel, who was also known as Belteshazzar. The revelation was true and concerned a great conflict. Daniel understood the message and what the vision meant.
27:10:2/During that time, I, Daniel, was in mourning for three full weeks.
27:10:3/I didn't eat any tasty food, nor did I consume meat or wine, nor did I use any oils, until the three weeks were completely over.
27:10:4/On the twenty-fourth day of the first month, as I was by the side of the great river, the Tigris,
27:10:5/I looked up and saw a man dressed in linen, with a belt of fine gold from Uphaz around his waist.
27:10:6/His body was like topaz, his face shone like lightning, his eyes were like flaming torches, his arms and legs gleamed like polished bronze, and his voice sounded like a multitude.
27:10:7/Only I, Daniel, saw the vision. The men with me didn't see it, but a great terror fell on them, and they ran away to hide.
27:10:8/So I was left alone, gazing at this great vision. I had no strength left, my face turned deathly pale, and I was powerless.
27:10:9/Yet I heard the sound of his words. As I listened, I fell into a deep sleep, my face to the ground.
27:10:10/Then a hand touched me and set me trembling on my hands and knees.
27:10:11/He said to me, "Daniel, you are highly esteemed. Understand the words I am speaking to you, and stand up, for I have been sent to you." When he said this to me, I stood up, but I was still trembling.
27:10:12/Then he said to me, "Do not be afraid, Daniel. Since the first day you set your mind to gain understanding and to humble yourself before your God, your words were heard, and I have come in response to them.
27:10:13/However, the prince of the Persian kingdom resisted me for twenty-one days. Then Michael, one of the chief princes, came to help me, because I was detained there with the king of Persia.
27:10:14/Now I have come to explain to you what will happen to your people in the future, for the vision concerns a time yet to come."
27:10:15/When he said this to me, I bowed my face toward the ground and was speechless.
27:10:16/Then one who looked like a man touched my lips, and I opened my mouth and began to speak. I said to the one standing before me, "My lord, because of the vision, I am overcome with anguish, and I have no strength.
27:10:17/How can I, your servant, talk with you, my lord? My strength is gone, and I can hardly breathe."
27:10:18/Again the one who looked like a man touched me and gave me strength.
27:10:19/He said, "Do not be afraid, you who are highly esteemed. Peace be with you; be strong, now be strong." When he spoke to me, I was strengthened and said, "Speak, my lord, since you have given me strength."
27:10:20/Then he said, "Do you know why I have come to you? Soon I will return to fight against the prince of Persia, and when I go, the prince of Greece will come.
27:10:21/But first, I will tell you what is written in the Book of Truth. No one supports me against them except Michael, your prince.
27:11:1/Also I, in the first year of Darius the Mede, stood by to support and strengthen him.
27:11:2/And now, I will show you the truth. Look, there will rise three more kings in Persia; and the fourth will be far wealthier than all of them: and with his wealth, he will provoke everyone against the kingdom of Greece.
27:11:3/A powerful king will rise, who will rule with vast dominion and do as he pleases.
27:11:4/But when he rises, his kingdom will be shattered and divided towards the four winds of heaven; not to his descendants, nor according to the power he wielded, because his kingdom will be uprooted for others, not his own.
27:11:5/The king of the south will become strong, along with one of his leaders; he will be stronger than the other and have dominion; his dominion will be a vast one.
27:11:6/After some years, they will form an alliance; the daughter of the king of the south will come to the king of the north to make an agreement, but she will not retain her power, nor will he endure, nor his power: but she will be handed over, along with those who brought her, her father, and he who supported her in those times.
27:11:7/However, from her family line, someone will arise in his place, who will come with an army, enter the fortress of the king of the north, confront them, and triumph.
27:11:8/He will also take their gods, their princes, and their valuable silver and gold items as captives to Egypt; and he will rule longer than the king of the north.
27:11:9/So the king of the south will enter his kingdom and then return to his own land.
27:11:10/But his sons will be provoked and gather a large army: one will certainly come, overflow, and pass through; then he will return, and be provoked, even to his fortress.
27:11:11/The king of the south, enraged, will march out and fight with the king of the north, who will raise a large army, but that army will be handed over to his enemy.
27:11:12/After capturing the army, his confidence will swell; he will overthrow tens of thousands, but he will not prevail.
27:11:13/The king of the north will return with a larger army than before, and after some years, he will come with a great army and abundant resources.
27:11:14/In those times, many will rise against the king of the south. The violent among your own people will also rise to fulfill the vision, but they will fail.
27:11:15/Then the king of the north will come, build siege ramps, and capture a fortified city. The forces of the south will not stand, nor will their elite troops; there will be no strength to resist.
27:11:16/But the one who comes against him will do as he pleases, and no one will be able to withstand him. He will stand in the beautiful land, with destruction in his hand.
27:11:17/He will set his sights on conquering the entire kingdom with the help of a select few; this is what he will accomplish. He will offer the daughter of women to corrupt her, but she will not stand with him or be for him.
27:11:18/Afterwards, he will turn his attention to the coastal lands and capture many, but a commander will put an end to his insult against him; instead, he will turn the insult back on him.
27:11:19/Then he will turn back towards the fortresses of his own country, but he will stumble, fall, and be seen no more.
27:11:20/His successor will send an oppressor through the jewel of his kingdom, but within a few days, he will be broken, though not in anger or in battle.
27:11:21/In his place, a contemptible person will arise, someone not given the honor of royalty. He will come in a time of peace and seize the kingdom through smooth talk.
27:11:22/Overwhelming forces will be swept away before him and broken, including the leader of the covenant.
27:11:23/After making an alliance, he will act deceitfully, and with only a few supporters, he will become powerful.
27:11:24/Without warning, he will enter the richest areas of the land and do what his fathers and forefathers never did, distributing plunder, loot, and wealth among them. He will plot the downfall of fortresses—but only for a time.
27:11:25/He will stir up his strength and courage against the king of the south with a large army; the king of the south will wage war with a very large and powerful army, but he will not stand because of plots devised against him.
27:11:26/Those who eat from the king's provisions will try to destroy him; his army will be swept away, and many will fall in battle.
27:11:27/The two kings, with their hearts bent on evil, will sit at the same table and lie to each other, but to no avail, because an end will still come at the appointed time.
27:11:28/He will return to his land with great wealth, but his heart will be set against the holy covenant. He will take action and then return to his own country.
27:11:29/At the appointed time, he will invade the south again, but this time the outcome will be different from what it was before.
27:11:30/Ships from the western coastlands will oppose him, and he will lose heart. Then he will turn back and vent his fury against the holy covenant. He will return and show favor to those who forsake the holy covenant.
27:11:31/His forces will rise up and desecrate the temple fortress. They will abolish the daily sacrifice and set up the abomination that causes desolation.
27:11:32/He will corrupt those who violate the covenant with smooth words, but the people who know their God will stand firm and take action.
27:11:33/Those with insight among the people will instruct many, though for a time they will fall by sword or flame, or be captured or plundered.
27:11:34/When they fall, they will receive a little help, and many who are not sincere will join them.
27:11:35/Some of the wise will stumble, so that they may be refined, purified, and made spotless until the time of the end, for it will still come at the appointed time.
