41:10:33/saying, "Look, we are going up to Jerusalem, and the Son of Man will be delivered to the chief priests and the teachers of the law. They will condemn him to death and will hand him over to the Gentiles,
41:10:34/who will mock him, spit on him, flog him, and kill him. Three days later he will rise."
41:10:35/James and John, the sons of Zebedee, approached him and said, "Teacher, we want you to do for us whatever we ask."
41:10:36/He asked them, "What do you want me to do for you?"
41:10:37/They replied, "Let one of us sit at your right and the other at your left in your glory."
41:10:38/But Jesus said to them, "You don't know what you're asking. Can you drink the cup I drink or be baptized with the baptism I am baptized with?"
41:10:39/They answered, "We can." Jesus said to them, "You will indeed drink the cup I drink and be baptized with the baptism I am baptized with,
41:10:40/but to sit at my right or left is not for me to grant. These places belong to those for whom they have been prepared."
41:10:41/When the ten heard about this, they became indignant with James and John.
41:10:42/Jesus called them together and said, "You know that those who are regarded as rulers of the Gentiles lord it over them, and their high officials exercise authority over them.
41:10:43/But it shall not be so among you. Instead, whoever wants to become great among you must be your servant,
41:10:44/and whoever wants to be first must be slave of all.
41:10:45/For even the Son of Man did not come to be served, but to serve, and to give his life as a ransom for many."
41:10:46/They reached Jericho. As Jesus and his disciples, together with a large crowd, were leaving the city, a blind man named Bartimaeus (that is, the son of Timaeus) was sitting by the roadside begging.
41:10:47/When he heard that it was Jesus of Nazareth, he began to shout, "Jesus, Son of David, have mercy on me!"
41:10:48/Many rebuked him, telling him to be silent, but he shouted all the more, "Son of David, have mercy on me!"
41:10:49/Jesus stopped and ordered him to be called. They called the blind man, saying, "Cheer up! Get on your feet; he's calling you."
41:10:50/Throwing aside his cloak, he jumped up and came to Jesus.
41:10:51/Jesus asked him, "What do you want me to do for you?" The blind man said, "Rabbi, I want to see."
41:10:52/Jesus told him, "Go, your faith has healed you." Immediately he received his sight and followed Jesus along the road.
41:11:1/As they approached Jerusalem, near Bethphage and Bethany at the Mount of Olives, he sent two of his disciples ahead,
41:11:2/And instructed them, "Go into the village opposite you, and as soon as you enter it, you will find a colt tied up, one that no one has ever ridden; untie it and bring it here.
41:11:3/If anyone asks you, 'Why are you doing this?' say, 'The Lord needs it and will send it back here immediately.'"
41:11:4/So they went and found the colt tied outside at a crossroads and untied it.
41:11:5/Some people standing there asked, "What are you doing, untying the colt?"
41:11:6/They replied just as Jesus had instructed them, and the people allowed them to go.
41:11:7/They brought the colt to Jesus, threw their cloaks over it, and he sat on it.
41:11:8/Many people spread their cloaks on the road, while others spread branches they had cut from the fields.
41:11:9/Those leading the way and those following shouted, "Hosanna! Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord!"
41:11:10/"Blessed is the coming kingdom of our ancestor David! Hosanna in the highest heaven!"
41:11:11/Jesus entered Jerusalem and went into the temple courts. He looked around at everything, but since it was already late, he went out to Bethany with the Twelve.
41:11:12/The next day, as they were leaving Bethany, Jesus was hungry.
41:11:13/Seeing a fig tree in the distance with leaves, he went to find if it had any fruit. When he reached it, he found nothing but leaves, because it was not the season for figs.
41:11:14/Then Jesus said to the tree, "May no one ever eat fruit from you again." And his disciples heard him say it.
41:11:15/When they arrived in Jerusalem, Jesus entered the temple courts and began driving out those who were buying and selling there. He overturned the tables of the money changers and the benches of those selling doves,
41:11:16/and would not allow anyone to carry merchandise through the temple courts.
41:11:17/And he taught them, saying, "Isn't it written, 'My house will be called a house of prayer for all nations'? But you have made it a den of robbers."
41:11:18/The chief priests and the teachers of the law heard this and began looking for a way to kill him, for they feared him because the whole crowd was amazed at his teaching.
41:11:19/When evening came, Jesus and his disciples left the city.
41:11:20/In the morning, as they passed by, they saw the fig tree withered from the roots.
41:11:21/Peter remembered and said to Jesus, "Rabbi, look! The fig tree you cursed has withered!"
41:11:22/Jesus replied, "Have faith in God.
41:11:23/Truly I tell you, if anyone says to this mountain, 'Go, throw yourself into the sea,' and does not doubt in their heart but believes that what they say will happen, it will be done for them.
41:11:24/Therefore, I tell you, whatever you ask for in prayer, believe that you have received it, and it will be yours.
41:11:25/And when you stand praying, if you hold anything against anyone, forgive them, so that your Father in heaven may forgive you your sins."
41:11:26/But if you do not forgive, neither will your Father in heaven forgive your sins.
41:11:27/They returned to Jerusalem, and as Jesus was walking in the temple courts, the chief priests, the teachers of the law, and the elders came to him.
41:11:28/They questioned him, "By what authority are you doing these things? And who gave you the authority to do this?"
41:11:29/Jesus replied, "I will ask you one question. Answer me, and I will tell you by what authority I am doing these things.
41:11:30/Was John's baptism from heaven, or of human origin? Tell me."
41:11:31/They discussed it among themselves and said, "If we say, 'From heaven,' he will ask, 'Then why didn't you believe him?'
41:11:32/But if we say, 'Of human origin'...?" (They feared the people, for everyone believed that John was truly a prophet.)
41:11:33/So they answered Jesus, "We don't know." And Jesus said to them, "Neither will I tell you by what authority I am doing these things."
41:12:1/He started telling them stories. A man planted a vineyard, put a fence around it, dug a pit for the winepress, built a watchtower, leased it to some farmers, and then went away.
41:12:2/When it was time, he sent a servant to the tenants to collect his share of the vineyard's produce.
41:12:3/But they grabbed him, beat him up, and sent him back empty-handed.
41:12:4/Then he sent another servant to them; this one they hit with stones, injured his head, and sent him back humiliated.
41:12:5/He sent another, and they killed him, along with many others; some they beat, others they killed.
41:12:6/So, he had one person left, his beloved son. He sent him last, thinking, 'They will respect my son.'
41:12:7/But those tenants said to each other, 'This is the heir. Let's kill him, and the inheritance will be ours.'
41:12:8/So they took him, killed him, and threw him out of the vineyard.
41:12:9/What will the owner of the vineyard do? He will come and destroy the tenants and give the vineyard to others.
41:12:10/Haven't you read this passage: 'The stone the builders rejected has become the cornerstone'?
41:12:11/This was the Lord's doing, and it's amazing to us?
41:12:12/They wanted to arrest him but were afraid of the crowd because they knew he had told this story against them. So they left him and went away.
41:12:13/Then they sent some Pharisees and Herodians to him, trying to trap him with his words.
41:12:14/When they arrived, they said, "Teacher, we know you are honest and don't care about anyone's opinion. You don't favor anyone but teach God's way truthfully. Is it right to pay taxes to Caesar or not?
41:12:15/Should we pay, or shouldn't we?" But knowing their hypocrisy, he said to them, "Why are you trying to trap me? Bring me a denarius to look at."
41:12:16/They brought one, and he asked them, "Whose image and inscription is this?" They said, "Caesar's."
41:12:17/Then Jesus said, "Give back to Caesar what is Caesar's, and to God what is God's." And they were amazed at him.
41:12:18/Then the Sadducees, who say there is no resurrection, came to him with a question.
41:12:19/They said, "Teacher, Moses wrote for us that if a man's brother dies, leaves a wife but no children, the man must marry the widow and raise offspring for his brother.
41:12:20/Now there were seven brothers. The first one married and died without leaving any children.
41:12:21/The second one married the widow, but he also died without leaving any children. And the same thing happened with the third.
41:12:22/In the end, all seven had married her and left no children. Last of all, the woman died too.
41:12:23/So in the resurrection, when they rise again, whose wife will she be, since all seven were married to her?"
41:12:24/Jesus replied, "Aren't you mistaken, because you don't know the Scriptures or the power of God?
41:12:25/When people rise from the dead, they neither marry nor are given in marriage; instead, they are like the angels in heaven.
41:12:26/Regarding the dead rising, haven't you read in the book of Moses, in the passage about the bush, how God said to him, 'I am the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob'?
41:12:27/He is not the God of the dead, but of the living. You are badly mistaken."
41:12:28/One of the teachers of the law came and heard them debating. Noticing that Jesus had given them a good answer, he asked him, "Of all the commandments, which is the most important?"
41:12:29/Jesus answered, "The most important one is this: 'Listen, Israel, the Lord our God, the Lord is one.
41:12:30/Love the Lord your God with all your heart, with all your soul, with all your mind, and with all your strength.' This is the most important commandment.
41:12:31/And the second is like it: 'Love your neighbor as yourself.' There is no commandment greater than these."
41:12:32/The teacher of the law said to him, "Well said, Teacher. You are right in saying that God is one and there is no other but him.
41:12:33/To love him with all your heart, with all your understanding, with all your soul, and with all your strength, and to love your neighbor as yourself is more important than all burnt offerings and sacrifices."
41:12:34/When Jesus saw that he had answered wisely, he said to him, "You are not far from the kingdom of God." After that, no one dared to ask him any more questions.
41:12:35/While Jesus was teaching in the temple courts, he asked, "How can the teachers of the law say that the Messiah is the son of David?
41:12:36/David himself, speaking by the Holy Spirit, declared: 'The Lord said to my Lord: Sit at my right hand until I put your enemies under your feet.'
41:12:37/David himself calls him 'Lord.' How then can he be his son?" The large crowd listened to him with delight.
41:12:38/In his teaching, he said, "Watch out for the teachers of the law. They like to walk around in flowing robes and be greeted with respect in the marketplaces,
41:12:39/and have the most important seats in the synagogues and the places of honor at banquets.
41:12:40/They devour widows' houses and for a show make lengthy prayers. These men will be punished most severely."
41:12:41/Jesus sat down opposite the place where the offerings were put and watched the crowd putting their money into the temple treasury. Many rich people threw in large amounts.
41:12:42/But a poor widow came and put in two very small copper coins, worth only a few cents.
41:12:43/He called his disciples to him and said, "Truly I tell you, this poor widow has put more into the treasury than all the others.
41:12:44/They all gave out of their wealth; but she, out of her poverty, put in everything—all she had to live on."
41:13:1/As he was leaving the temple, one of his disciples said to him, "Teacher, look at these amazing stones and buildings!"
41:13:2/Jesus replied, "Do you see these great buildings? Not one stone will be left on another; every one will be thrown down."
41:13:3/While sitting on the Mount of Olives across from the temple, Peter, James, John, and Andrew asked him privately,
41:13:4/"Tell us, when will these things happen? And what will be the sign that all these things are about to be fulfilled?"
41:13:5/Jesus began to say to them, "Be careful that no one deceives you."
41:13:6/"Many will come in my name, claiming, 'I am the Messiah,' and will deceive many."
41:13:7/"When you hear of wars and rumors of wars, don't be alarmed. These things must happen, but it's not the end yet."
41:13:8/"Nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom. There will be earthquakes in various places, and famines and troubles. These are the beginning of birth pains."
41:13:9/"But be on your guard. They will hand you over to local councils, and you will be beaten in synagogues. You will stand before governors and kings for my sake, as a witness to them."
41:13:10/"But first, the gospel must be preached to all nations."
41:13:11/"When they arrest you and hand you over, don't worry beforehand about what to say. Just say whatever is given to you at the time, for it is not you speaking, but the Holy Spirit."
41:13:12/"Brother will betray brother to death, and a father his child. Children will rebel against their parents and have them killed."
41:13:13/"Everyone will hate you because of me, but the one who stands firm to the end will be saved."
41:13:14/"When you see 'the abomination that causes desolation' standing where it does not belong—let the reader understand—then let those who are in Judea flee to the mountains."
41:13:15/"If someone is on the rooftop, they must not go down or enter the house to take anything out."
41:13:16/"If someone is in the field, they must not go back to get their cloak."
41:13:17/"How dreadful it will be in those days for pregnant women and nursing mothers!"
41:13:18/"Pray that this will not take place in winter."
41:13:19/"For those days will be a time of distress unequaled from the beginning, when God created the world, until now—and never to be equaled again."
41:13:20/"If the Lord had not cut short those days, no one would survive. But for the sake of the elect, whom he has chosen, he has shortened them."
41:13:21/"At that time if anyone says to you, 'Look, here is the Messiah!' or, 'Look, there he is!' do not believe it."
41:13:22/"For false messiahs and false prophets will appear and perform signs and wonders to deceive, if possible, even the elect."
41:13:23/"So be on your guard; I have told you everything ahead of time."
41:13:24/"But in those days, following that distress, 'the sun will be darkened, and the moon will not give its light,'"
41:13:25/"'The stars will fall from the sky, and the heavenly bodies will be shaken.'"
41:13:26/"At that time people will see the Son of Man coming in clouds with great power and glory."
41:13:27/"And he will send his angels and gather his elect from the four winds, from the ends of the earth to the ends of the heavens."
41:13:28/"Now learn this lesson from the fig tree: As soon as its twigs get tender and its leaves come out, you know that summer is near."
41:13:29/"In the same way, when you see these things happening, you know that it is near, right at the door."
41:13:30/"Truly I tell you, this generation will certainly not pass away until all these things have happened."
41:13:31/"Heaven and earth will pass away, but my words will never pass away."
41:13:32/"But about that day or hour no one knows, not even the angels in heaven, nor the Son, but only the Father."
41:13:33/"Be on guard, be alert and pray; you do not know when that time will come."
41:13:34/"It's like a man going away: He leaves his house and puts his servants in charge, each with their assigned task, and tells the one at the door to keep watch."
41:13:35/"Therefore keep watch because you do not know when the owner of the house will come back—whether in the evening, or at midnight, or when the rooster crows, or at dawn."
41:13:36/"If he comes suddenly, do not let him find you sleeping."
41:13:37/"What I say to you, I say to everyone: 'Watch!'"
41:14:1/In two days, it was the Passover feast and the Feast of Unleavened Bread. The chief priests and the scribes were looking for a way to arrest him secretly and kill him.
41:14:2/But they said, "Not during the feast, or there may be a riot among the people."
41:14:3/While he was in Bethany, at the home of Simon the leper, sitting at the table, a woman came with an alabaster jar of very expensive perfume made of pure nard. She broke the jar and poured the perfume on his head.
41:14:4/Some of those present were indignant and said to one another, "Why this waste of perfume?
41:14:5/It could have been sold for more than three hundred denarii and the money given to the poor." And they criticized her sharply.
41:14:6/But Jesus said, "Leave her alone. Why are you bothering her? She has done a beautiful thing to me.
41:14:7/You will always have the poor among you, and you can help them anytime you want. But you will not always have me.
41:14:8/She did what she could. She poured perfume on my body beforehand to prepare for my burial.
41:14:9/Truly I tell you, wherever the gospel is preached throughout the world, what she has done will also be told, in memory of her."
41:14:10/Then Judas Iscariot, one of the Twelve, went to the chief priests to betray Jesus to them.
41:14:11/When they heard this, they were delighted and promised to give him money. So he looked for an opportunity to betray him.
41:14:12/On the first day of the Festival of Unleavened Bread, when it was customary to sacrifice the Passover lamb, Jesus' disciples asked him, "Where do you want us to go and make preparations for you to eat the Passover?"
41:14:13/So he sent two of his disciples, telling them, "Go into the city, and a man carrying a jar of water will meet you. Follow him.
41:14:14/Say to the owner of the house he enters, 'The Teacher asks: Where is my guest room, where I may eat the Passover with my disciples?'
41:14:15/He will show you a large room upstairs, furnished and ready. Make preparations for us there."
41:14:16/The disciples left, went into the city, and found things just as Jesus had told them. So they prepared the Passover.
41:14:17/When evening came, Jesus arrived with the Twelve.
41:14:18/While they were reclining at the table eating, he said, "Truly I tell you, one of you will betray me—one who is eating with me."
41:14:19/They were saddened, and one by one they said to him, "Surely you don't mean me?"
41:14:20/He replied, "It is one of the Twelve, one who dips bread into the bowl with me.
41:14:21/The Son of Man will go just as it is written about him. But woe to that man who betrays the Son of Man! It would be better for him if he had not been born."
41:14:22/While they were eating, Jesus took bread, and when he had given thanks, he broke it and gave it to his disciples, saying, "Take it; this is my body."
41:14:23/Then he took a cup, and when he had given thanks, he gave it to them, and they all drank from it.
41:14:24/He said to them, "This is my blood of the covenant, which is poured out for many.
41:14:25/Truly I tell you, I will not drink again from the fruit of the vine until that day when I drink it new in the kingdom of God."
41:14:26/After singing a hymn, they went out to the Mount of Olives.
41:14:27/Then Jesus said to them, "You will all fall away, for it is written: 'I will strike the shepherd, and the sheep will be scattered.'
41:14:28/But after I have risen, I will go ahead of you into Galilee."
41:14:29/Peter declared, "Even if all fall away, I will not."
41:14:30/Truly I tell you," Jesus answered, "today—yes, tonight—before the rooster crows twice, you yourself will disown me three times."
41:14:31/But Peter insisted emphatically, "Even if I have to die with you, I will never disown you." And all the others said the same.
41:14:32/They went to a place called Gethsemane, and Jesus said to his disciples, "Sit here while I pray."
41:14:33/He took Peter, James, and John along with him, and he began to be deeply distressed and troubled.
41:14:34/"My soul is overwhelmed with sorrow to the point of death," he said to them. "Stay here and keep watch."
41:14:35/Going a little farther, he fell to the ground and prayed that if possible the hour might pass from him.
41:14:36/"Abba, Father," he said, "everything is possible for you. Take this cup from me. Yet not what I will, but what you will."
41:14:37/Then he returned to his disciples and found them sleeping. "Simon," he said to Peter, "are you asleep? Couldn't you keep watch for one hour?
41:14:38/Watch and pray so that you will not fall into temptation. The spirit is willing, but the flesh is weak."
41:14:39/Once more he went away and prayed, saying the same thing.
41:14:40/When he came back, he again found them sleeping, because their eyes were heavy. They did not know what to say to him.
41:14:41/Returning the third time, he said to them, "Are you still sleeping and resting? Enough! The hour has come. Look, the Son of Man is delivered into the hands of sinners.
41:14:42/Rise! Let us go! Here comes my betrayer!"
41:14:43/Just as he was speaking, Judas, one of the Twelve, appeared. With him was a crowd armed with swords and clubs, sent from the chief priests, the teachers of the law, and the elders.
41:14:44/Now the betrayer had arranged a signal with them: "The one I kiss is the man; arrest him and lead him away under guard."
41:14:45/Going at once to Jesus, Judas said, "Rabbi!" and kissed him.
41:14:46/The men seized Jesus and arrested him.
41:14:47/Then one of those standing near drew his sword and struck the servant of the high priest, cutting off his ear.
41:14:48/"Am I leading a rebellion," said Jesus, "that you have come out with swords and clubs to capture me?
41:14:49/Every day I was with you, teaching in the temple courts, and you did not arrest me. But the Scriptures must be fulfilled."
41:14:50/Then everyone deserted him and fled.
41:14:51/A young man, wearing nothing but a linen garment, was following Jesus. When they seized him,
41:14:52/he fled naked, leaving his garment behind.
41:14:53/They took Jesus to the high priest, and all the chief priests, the elders and the teachers of the law came together.
41:14:54/Peter followed him at a distance, right into the courtyard of the high priest. There he sat with the guards and warmed himself at the fire.
41:14:55/The chief priests and the whole Sanhedrin were looking for evidence against Jesus so they could put him to death, but they did not find any.
41:14:56/Many testified falsely against him, but their statements did not agree.
41:14:57/Then some stood up and gave this false testimony against him:
41:14:58/"We heard him say, 'I will destroy this man-made temple and in three days will build another, not made by man.'"
41:14:59/Yet even then their testimony did not agree.
41:14:60/The high priest stood up before them and asked Jesus, "Aren't you going to answer? What is this testimony that these men are bringing against you?"
41:14:61/But Jesus remained silent and gave no answer. Again the high priest asked him, "Are you the Messiah, the Son of the Blessed One?"
41:14:62/"I am," said Jesus. "And you will see the Son of Man sitting at the right hand of the Mighty One and coming on the clouds of heaven."
41:14:63/The high priest tore his clothes. "Why do we need any more witnesses?" he asked.
41:14:64/"You have heard the blasphemy. What do you think?" They all condemned him as worthy of death.
41:14:65/Then some began to spit at him; they blindfolded him, struck him with their fists, and said, "Prophesy!" And the guards took him and beat him.
41:14:66/While Peter was below in the courtyard, one of the servant girls of the high priest came by.
41:14:67/When she saw Peter warming himself, she looked closely at him. "You also were with that Nazarene, Jesus," she said.
41:14:68/But he denied it. "I don't know or understand what you're talking about," he said, and went out into the entryway, and the rooster crowed.
41:14:69/The servant girl saw him there and said again to those standing around, "This fellow is one of them."
41:14:70/Again he denied it. After a little while, those standing near said to Peter, "Surely you are one of them, for you are a Galilean."
41:14:71/He began to call down curses, and he swore to them, "I don't know this man you're talking about."
41:14:72/Immediately the rooster crowed the second time. Then Peter remembered the word Jesus had spoken to him: "Before the rooster crows twice, you will disown me three times." And he broke down and wept.
41:15:1/Early in the morning, the chief priests, along with the elders, scribes, and the entire council, arrested Jesus, tied him up, and took him to Pilate.
41:15:2/Pilate asked him, "Are you the King of the Jews?" Jesus replied, "You have said so."
41:15:3/The chief priests accused him of many things, but he didn't respond.
41:15:4/Pilate questioned him again, "Aren't you going to answer? See how many accusations they're making against you."
41:15:5/But Jesus still didn't say anything, which amazed Pilate.
41:15:6/During the festival, Pilate would release a prisoner chosen by the crowd.
41:15:7/There was a man named Barabbas, imprisoned with rebels who had committed murder during an uprising.
41:15:8/The crowd shouted, asking Pilate to do what he usually did for them.
41:15:9/Pilate responded, "Do you want me to release the King of the Jews to you?"
41:15:10/He knew the chief priests had handed Jesus over because they were jealous.
41:15:11/But the chief priests persuaded the crowd to ask for Barabbas's release instead.
41:15:12/Pilate asked them again, "Then what should I do with the one you call the King of the Jews?"
41:15:13/They shouted back, "Crucify him."
41:15:14/Pilate asked, "Why? What crime has he committed?" But they shouted even louder, "Crucify him!"
41:15:15/So Pilate, wanting to satisfy the crowd, released Barabbas to them. He had Jesus flogged and then handed him over to be crucified.
41:15:16/The soldiers took Jesus into the governor's palace and gathered the whole company around him.
41:15:17/They dressed him in a purple robe, twisted together a crown of thorns, and put it on his head,
41:15:18/And began to salute him, "Hail, King of the Jews!"
41:15:19/They struck him on the head with a staff, spat on him, and knelt in mock worship.
41:15:20/After mocking him, they took off the purple robe and put his own clothes back on him. Then they led him out to crucify him.
41:15:21/They forced a man named Simon from Cyrene, who was passing by, to carry Jesus's cross.
41:15:22/They brought Jesus to the place called Golgotha, which means "Place of the Skull."
41:15:23/They offered him wine mixed with myrrh, but he did not take it.
41:15:24/After crucifying him, they divided his clothes among themselves by casting lots.
41:15:25/It was nine in the morning when they crucified him.
41:15:26/The charge against him read, "THE KING OF THE JEWS."
41:15:27/They crucified two robbers with him, one on his right and one on his left.
41:15:28/This fulfilled the scripture that says, "He was counted among the lawbreakers."
41:15:29/People passing by insulted him, shaking their heads and saying, "So, you who would destroy the temple and rebuild it in three days,
41:15:30/Save yourself and come down from the cross."
41:15:31/Similarly, the chief priests and scribes mocked him among themselves, saying, "He saved others, but he can't save himself.
41:15:32/Let the Messiah, the King of Israel, come down now from the cross, so we can see and believe." Even those crucified with him taunted him.
41:15:33/At noon, darkness fell across the whole land until three in the afternoon.
41:15:34/At three, Jesus cried out loudly, "Eloi, Eloi, lema sabachthani?" which means, "My God, my God, why have you abandoned me?"
41:15:35/Some bystanders, hearing this, said, "Listen, he's calling for Elijah."
41:15:36/Someone ran, soaked a sponge in vinegar, put it on a stick, and offered it to Jesus to drink, saying, "Wait, let's see if Elijah comes to take him down."
41:15:37/Jesus cried out loudly and then died.
41:15:38/The curtain of the temple was torn in two from top to bottom.
41:15:39/When the centurion standing there saw how Jesus died, he said, "Truly, this man was the Son of God."
41:15:40/Some women were watching from a distance, including Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James the younger and of Joses, and Salome,
41:15:41/Who had followed him and cared for his needs in Galilee, along with many other women who had come up with him to Jerusalem.
41:15:42/As evening approached, since it was the day of Preparation, the day before the Sabbath,
41:15:43/Joseph of Arimathea, a respected member of the council, who was also waiting for the kingdom of God, bravely went to Pilate and asked for Jesus's body.
41:15:44/Pilate was surprised to hear that Jesus was already dead. He summoned the centurion to ask if Jesus had died some time ago.
41:15:45/When he learned from the centurion that it was so, he gave the body to Joseph.
41:15:46/Joseph bought some linen cloth, took down the body, wrapped it in the linen, and placed it in a tomb cut out of rock. Then he rolled a stone against the entrance of the tomb.
41:15:47/Mary Magdalene and Mary the mother of Joses saw where he was laid.
41:16:1/After the Sabbath was over, Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James, and Salome bought fragrant spices so they could go and anoint Jesus' body.
41:16:2/Early on the first day of the week, just after sunrise, they went to the tomb.
41:16:3/They were wondering among themselves, "Who will roll the stone away from the entrance of the tomb for us?"
41:16:4/But when they looked up, they saw that the stone, which was very large, had already been rolled aside.
41:16:5/When they entered the tomb, they saw a young man dressed in a white robe sitting on the right side, and they were startled.
41:16:6/He said to them, "Don't be alarmed. You are looking for Jesus the Nazarene, who was crucified. He has risen; he is not here. Look, this is the place where they laid him.
41:16:7/But go, tell his disciples and Peter, 'He is going ahead of you into Galilee. There you will see him, just as he told you.'"
41:16:8/They left the tomb quickly, running away from it in terror and amazement. And they said nothing to anyone, because they were afraid.
41:16:9/Now after Jesus had risen early on the first day of the week, he appeared first to Mary Magdalene, from whom he had driven out seven demons.
41:16:10/She went and told those who had been with him, who were mourning and weeping.
41:16:11/But when they heard that he was alive and that she had seen him, they did not believe it.
41:16:12/Later, Jesus appeared in a different form to two of them while they were walking in the countryside.
41:16:13/These returned and reported it to the rest; but they did not believe them either.
41:16:14/Later, he appeared to the eleven as they were eating; he rebuked them for their lack of faith and their stubborn refusal to believe those who had seen him after he had risen.
41:16:15/He said to them, "Go into all the world and proclaim the good news to all creation.
41:16:16/Whoever believes and is baptized will be saved, but whoever does not believe will be condemned.
41:16:17/And these signs will accompany those who believe: In my name, they will drive out demons; they will speak in new languages;
41:16:18/They will pick up snakes; and if they drink any poisonous thing, it will not harm them; they will lay hands on the sick, and they will get well."
41:16:19/So then, after the Lord had spoken to them, he was taken up into heaven and sat at the right hand of God.
41:16:20/And they went out and preached everywhere, the Lord working with them and confirming the message by accompanying signs. Amen.
42:1:1/Many have tried to compile a narrative of the events that are firmly believed among us,
42:1:2/Just as they were passed down to us by those who from the beginning were eyewitnesses and servants of the word.
42:1:3/So, it seemed good to me as well, having carefully investigated everything from the start, to write an orderly account for you, most excellent Theophilus,
42:1:4/So that you may know the certainty of the teachings you have received.
42:1:5/During the time of King Herod of Judea, there was a priest named Zacharias, who belonged to the priestly division of Abijah. His wife, Elisabeth, was also a descendant of Aaron.
42:1:6/Both of them were righteous in the sight of God, observing all the Lord's commands and decrees blamelessly.
42:1:7/But they were childless because Elisabeth was unable to conceive, and they were both very old.
42:1:8/Once, when Zacharias was serving as priest before God and his division was on duty,
42:1:9/He was chosen by lot, according to the custom of the priesthood, to enter the temple of the Lord and burn incense.
42:1:10/And the whole assembly of the people was praying outside at the time of incense.
42:1:11/Then an angel of the Lord appeared to him, standing at the right side of the altar of incense.
42:1:12/When Zacharias saw him, he was startled and overcome with fear.
42:1:13/But the angel said to him, "Do not be afraid, Zacharias, because your prayer has been heard. Your wife Elisabeth will bear you a son, and you are to name him John.
42:1:14/You will have joy and gladness, and many will rejoice at his birth.
42:1:15/For he will be great in the sight of the Lord. He must never drink wine or fermented drink, and he will be filled with the Holy Spirit even from birth.
42:1:16/Many of the people of Israel will he bring back to the Lord their God.
42:1:17/And he will go on before the Lord, in the spirit and power of Elijah, to turn the hearts of the parents to their children and the disobedient to the wisdom of the righteous—to make ready a people prepared for the Lord."
42:1:18/Zacharias asked the angel, "How can I be sure of this? I am an old man and my wife is well along in years."
42:1:19/The angel answered, "I am Gabriel. I stand in the presence of God, and I have been sent to speak to you and to tell you this good news.
42:1:20/Now, you will be silent and not able to speak until the day this happens, because you did not believe my words, which will come true at their appointed time."
42:1:21/Meanwhile, the people were waiting for Zacharias and wondering why he stayed so long in the temple.
42:1:22/When he came out, he could not speak to them. They realized he had seen a vision in the temple, for he kept making signs to them but remained unable to speak.
42:1:23/When his time of service was completed, he returned home.
42:1:24/After this, his wife Elisabeth became pregnant and for five months remained in seclusion. She said,
42:1:25/"This is how the Lord has dealt with me in the days when he looked on me, to take away my disgrace among people."
42:1:26/In the sixth month, God sent the angel Gabriel to Nazareth, a town in Galilee,
42:1:27/To a virgin pledged to be married to a man named Joseph, a descendant of David. The virgin's name was Mary.
42:1:28/The angel went to her and said, "Greetings, you who are highly favored! The Lord is with you."
42:1:29/Mary was greatly troubled at his words and wondered what kind of greeting this might be.
42:1:30/But the angel said to her, "Do not be afraid, Mary; you have found favor with God.
42:1:31/You will conceive and give birth to a son, and you are to call him Jesus.
42:1:32/He will be great and will be called the Son of the Most High. The Lord God will give him the throne of his father David,
42:1:33/And he will reign over Jacob's descendants forever; his kingdom will never end."
42:1:34/Mary asked the angel, "How will this be, since I am a virgin?"
42:1:35/The angel answered, "The Holy Spirit will come on you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you. So the holy one to be born will be called the Son of God.
42:1:36/Even Elizabeth your relative is going to have a child in her old age, and she who was said to be unable to conceive is in her sixth month.
42:1:37/For no word from God will ever fail."
42:1:38/Mary said, "I am the Lord's servant. May your word to me be fulfilled." Then the angel left her.
42:1:39/Mary got up and hurried to a town in the hill country of Judea,
42:1:40/Where she entered Zacharias' home and greeted Elisabeth.
42:1:41/When Elisabeth heard Mary's greeting, the baby leaped in her womb, and Elisabeth was filled with the Holy Spirit.
42:1:42/In a loud voice she exclaimed: "Blessed are you among women, and blessed is the child you will bear!
42:1:43/But why am I so favored, that the mother of my Lord should come to me?
42:1:44/As soon as the sound of your greeting reached my ears, the baby in my womb leaped for joy.
42:1:45/Blessed is she who has believed that the Lord would fulfill his promises to her!"
42:1:46/And Mary said, "My soul glorifies the Lord,
42:1:47/And my spirit rejoices in God my Savior.
42:1:48/For he has been mindful of the humble state of his servant. From now on all generations will call me blessed,
42:1:49/For the Mighty One has done great things for me—holy is his name.
42:1:50/His mercy extends to those who fear him, from generation to generation.
42:1:51/He has performed mighty deeds with his arm; he has scattered those who are proud in their inmost thoughts.
42:1:52/He has brought down rulers from their thrones but has lifted up the humble.
42:1:53/He has filled the hungry with good things but has sent the rich away empty.
42:1:54/He has helped his servant Israel, remembering to be merciful
42:1:55/To Abraham and his descendants forever, just as he promised our ancestors."
42:1:56/Mary stayed with Elisabeth for about three months and then returned home.
42:1:57/When it was time for Elisabeth to have her baby, she gave birth to a son.
42:1:58/Her neighbors and relatives heard that the Lord had shown her great mercy, and they rejoiced with her.
42:1:59/On the eighth day they came to circumcise the child, and they were going to name him after his father Zacharias,
42:1:60/But his mother spoke up and said, "No! He is to be called John."
42:1:61/They said to her, "There is no one among your relatives who has that name."
42:1:62/Then they made signs to his father, to find out what he would like to name the child.
42:1:63/He asked for a writing tablet, and to everyone's astonishment he wrote, "His name is John."
42:1:64/Immediately his mouth was opened and his tongue set free, and he began to speak, praising God.
42:1:65/All the neighbors were filled with awe, and throughout the hill country of Judea people were talking about all these things.
42:1:66/Everyone who heard this wondered about it, asking, "What then is this child going to be?" For the Lord's hand was with him.
42:1:67/His father Zacharias was filled with the Holy Spirit and prophesied:
42:1:68/"Praise be to the Lord, the God of Israel, because he has come to his people and redeemed them.
42:1:69/He has raised up a horn of salvation for us in the house of his servant David
42:1:70/(as he said through his holy prophets of long ago),
42:1:71/That we would be saved from our enemies and from the hand of all who hate us.
42:1:72/To show mercy to our ancestors and to remember his holy covenant,
42:1:73/The oath he swore to our father Abraham:
42:1:74/To rescue us from the hand of our enemies, and to enable us to serve him without fear
42:1:75/In holiness and righteousness before him all our days.
42:1:76/And you, my child, will be called a prophet of the Most High; for you will go on before the Lord to prepare the way for him,
42:1:77/To give his people the knowledge of salvation through the forgiveness of their sins,
42:1:78/Because of the tender mercy of our God, by which the rising sun will come to us from heaven
42:1:79/To shine on those living in darkness and in the shadow of death, to guide our feet into the path of peace."
42:1:80/And the child grew and became strong in spirit; and he lived in the wilderness until he appeared publicly to Israel.
42:2:1/At that time, Caesar Augustus issued a decree that a census should be taken of the entire Roman world.
42:2:2/(This was the first census that took place while Quirinius was governor of Syria.)
42:2:3/Everyone went to their own town to register.
42:2:4/Joseph also went up from the town of Nazareth in Galilee to Judea, to Bethlehem the town of David, because he belonged to the house and line of David.
42:2:5/He went there to register with Mary, who was pledged to be married to him and was expecting a child.
42:2:6/While they were there, the time came for the baby to be born,
42:2:7/and she gave birth to her firstborn, a son. She wrapped him in cloths and placed him in a manger, because there was no guest room available for them.
42:2:8/And there were shepherds living out in the fields nearby, keeping watch over their flocks at night.
42:2:9/An angel of the Lord appeared to them, and the glory of the Lord shone around them, and they were terrified.
42:2:10/But the angel said to them, "Do not be afraid. I bring you good news that will cause great joy for all the people.
42:2:11/Today in the town of David a Savior has been born to you; he is the Messiah, the Lord.
42:2:12/This will be a sign to you: You will find a baby wrapped in cloths and lying in a manger."
42:2:13/Suddenly a great company of the heavenly host appeared with the angel, praising God and saying,
42:2:14/"Glory to God in the highest heaven, and on earth peace to those on whom his favor rests."
42:2:15/When the angels had left them and gone into heaven, the shepherds said to one another, "Let's go to Bethlehem and see this thing that has happened, which the Lord has told us about."
42:2:16/So they hurried off and found Mary and Joseph, and the baby, who was lying in the manger.
42:2:17/When they had seen him, they spread the word concerning what had been told them about this child,
42:2:18/and all who heard it were amazed at what the shepherds said to them.
42:2:19/But Mary treasured up all these things and pondered them in her heart.
42:2:20/The shepherds returned, glorifying and praising God for all the things they had heard and seen, which were just as they had been told.
42:2:21/On the eighth day, when it was time to circumcise the child, he was named Jesus, the name the angel had given him before he was conceived.
42:2:22/When the time came for the purification rites required by the Law of Moses, Joseph and Mary took him to Jerusalem to present him to the Lord
42:2:23/(as it is written in the Law of the Lord, "Every firstborn male is to be consecrated to the Lord"),
42:2:24/and to offer a sacrifice in keeping with what is said in the Law of the Lord: "a pair of doves or two young pigeons."
42:2:25/Now there was a man in Jerusalem called Simeon, who was righteous and devout. He was waiting for the consolation of Israel, and the Holy Spirit was on him.
42:2:26/It had been revealed to him by the Holy Spirit that he would not die before he had seen the Lord's Messiah.
42:2:27/Moved by the Spirit, he went into the temple courts. When the parents brought in the child Jesus to do for him what the custom of the Law required,
42:2:28/Simeon took him in his arms and praised God, saying,
42:2:29/"Sovereign Lord, as you have promised, you may now dismiss your servant in peace.
42:2:30/For my eyes have seen your salvation,
42:2:31/which you have prepared in the sight of all nations:
42:2:32/a light for revelation to the Gentiles, and the glory of your people Israel."
42:2:33/His father and mother marveled at what was said about him.
42:2:34/Then Simeon blessed them and said to Mary, his mother: "This child is destined to cause the falling and rising of many in Israel, and to be a sign that will be spoken against,
42:2:35/so that the thoughts of many hearts will be revealed. And a sword will pierce your own soul too."
42:2:36/There was also a prophet, Anna, the daughter of Penuel, of the tribe of Asher. She was very old; she had lived with her husband seven years after her marriage,
42:2:37/and then was a widow until she was eighty-four. She never left the temple but worshiped night and day, fasting and praying.
42:2:38/Coming up to them at that very moment, she gave thanks to God and spoke about the child to all who were looking forward to the redemption of Jerusalem.
42:2:39/When Joseph and Mary had done everything required by the Law of the Lord, they returned to Galilee to their own town of Nazareth.
42:2:40/And the child grew and became strong; he was filled with wisdom, and the grace of God was on him.
42:2:41/Every year Jesus' parents went to Jerusalem for the Festival of the Passover.
42:2:42/When he was twelve years old, they went up to the festival, according to the custom.
42:2:43/After the festival was over, while his parents were returning home, the boy Jesus stayed behind in Jerusalem, but they were unaware of it.
42:2:44/Thinking he was in their company, they traveled on for a day. Then they began looking for him among their relatives and friends.
42:2:45/When they did not find him, they went back to Jerusalem to look for him.
42:2:46/After three days they found him in the temple courts, sitting among the teachers, listening to them and asking questions.
42:2:47/Everyone who heard him was amazed at his understanding and his answers.
42:2:48/When his parents saw him, they were astonished. His mother said to him, "Son, why have you treated us like this? Your father and I have been anxiously searching for you."
42:2:49/"Why were you searching for me?" he asked. "Didn't you know I had to be in my Father's house?"
42:2:50/But they did not understand what he was saying to them.
42:2:51/Then he went down to Nazareth with them and was obedient to them. But his mother treasured all these things in her heart.
42:2:52/And Jesus grew in wisdom and stature, and in favor with God and people.
42:3:1/Now in the fifteenth year of Tiberius Caesar's reign, with Pontius Pilate as governor of Judaea, Herod as tetrarch of Galilee, his brother Philip as tetrarch of Ituraea and the Trachonitis region, and Lysanias as the tetrarch of Abilene,
42:3:2/Annas and Caiaphas being the high priests, God's message came to John, Zacharias's son, in the wilderness.
42:3:3/He traveled throughout the region around the Jordan River, preaching a baptism of repentance to forgive sins;
42:3:4/As it is written in the book of the words of Isaiah the prophet, saying, "A voice of one calling in the wilderness, 'Prepare the way for the Lord, make his paths straight.'"
42:3:5/"Every valley shall be filled in, and every mountain and hill made low; the crooked roads shall become straight, and the rough ways smooth;"
42:3:6/And everyone will see God's salvation.
42:3:7/Then he said to the crowds coming out to be baptized by him, "You brood of vipers, who warned you to escape the coming wrath?
42:3:8/Therefore, produce fruit in keeping with repentance. And do not start thinking to yourselves, 'We have Abraham as our father.' For I tell you, God can raise up children for Abraham from these stones.
42:3:9/And now the axe is already at the root of the trees. Every tree that does not produce good fruit will be cut down and thrown into the fire."
42:3:10/And the crowds asked him, "What should we do then?"
42:3:11/He replied, "Whoever has two shirts should share with the one who has none, and whoever has food should do the same."
42:3:12/Even tax collectors came to be baptized and asked him, "Teacher, what should we do?"
42:3:13/He told them, "Don't collect any more than you are required to."
42:3:14/Then some soldiers asked him, "And what should we do?" He replied, "Don't extort money and don't accuse people falsely—be satisfied with your pay."
42:3:15/While the people were filled with expectation and all were wondering in their hearts if John might possibly be the Messiah,
42:3:16/John answered them all, "I baptize you with water. But one more powerful than I will come, the straps of whose sandals I am not worthy to untie. He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and fire.
42:3:17/His winnowing fork is in his hand to clear his threshing floor and to gather the wheat into his barn, but he will burn up the chaff with unquenchable fire."
42:3:18/And with many other words, he preached good news to the people.
42:3:19/But when Herod the tetrarch was rebuked by him because of Herodias, his brother Philip's wife, and for all the other evil things Herod had done,
42:3:20/Herod added this to them all: he locked John up in prison.
42:3:21/Now when all the people were baptized, and when Jesus had also been baptized and was praying, the heavens were opened,
42:3:22/And the Holy Spirit descended on him in bodily form like a dove. And a voice came from heaven: "You are my Son, whom I love; with you I am well pleased."
42:3:23/And Jesus himself was about thirty years old when he began his ministry. He was (as was thought) the son of Joseph, the son of Heli,
42:3:24/The son of Matthat, the son of Levi, the son of Melchi, the son of Janna, the son of Joseph,
42:3:25/The son of Mattathias, the son of Amos, the son of Naum, the son of Esli, the son of Nagge,
42:3:26/The son of Maath, the son of Mattathias, the son of Semei, the son of Joseph, the son of Juda,
42:3:27/The son of Joanna, the son of Rhesa, the son of Zorobabel, the son of Salathiel, the son of Neri,
42:3:28/The son of Melchi, the son of Addi, the son of Cosam, the son of Elmodam, the son of Er,
42:3:29/The son of Jose, the son of Eliezer, the son of Jorim, the son of Matthat, the son of Levi,
42:3:30/The son of Simeon, the son of Juda, the son of Joseph, the son of Jonan, the son of Eliakim,
42:3:31/The son of Melea, the son of Menan, the son of Mattatha, the son of Nathan, the son of David,
42:3:32/The son of Jesse, the son of Obed, the son of Booz, the son of Salmon, the son of Naasson,
42:3:33/The son of Aminadab, the son of Aram, the son of Esrom, the son of Phares, the son of Juda,
42:3:34/The son of Jacob, the son of Isaac, the son of Abraham, the son of Thara, the son of Nachor,
42:3:35/The son of Saruch, the son of Ragau, the son of Phalec, the son of Heber, the son of Sala,
42:3:36/The son of Cainan, the son of Arphaxad, the son of Sem, the son of Noe, the son of Lamech,
42:3:37/The son of Mathusala, the son of Enoch, the son of Jared, the son of Maleleel, the son of Cainan,
42:3:38/The son of Enos, the son of Seth, the son of Adam, the son of God.
42:4:1/And Jesus, filled with the Holy Spirit, returned from the Jordan and was led by the Spirit into the wilderness,
42:4:2/For forty days, he was tempted by the devil. During those days, he ate nothing, and at the end, he was hungry.
42:4:3/The devil said to him, "If you are the Son of God, tell this stone to become bread."
42:4:4/Jesus answered, "It is written, 'People do not live on bread alone, but on every word that comes from the mouth of God.'"
42:4:5/The devil took him to a high mountain and showed him all the kingdoms of the world in an instant.
42:4:6/The devil said to him, "I will give you all this authority and their glory, for it has been given to me, and I can give it to anyone I want to.
42:4:7/If you worship me, it will all be yours."
42:4:8/Jesus replied, "It is written: 'Worship the Lord your God and serve him only.'"
42:4:9/Then he took him to Jerusalem, set him on the highest point of the temple, and said, "If you are the Son of God, throw yourself down from here.
42:4:10/For it is written: 'He will command his angels concerning you to guard you carefully;
42:4:11/and they will lift you up in their hands, so that you will not strike your foot against a stone.'"
42:4:12/Jesus answered, "It is said: 'Do not put the Lord your God to the test.'"
42:4:13/When the devil had finished all this tempting, he left him until an opportune time.
42:4:14/Jesus returned to Galilee in the power of the Spirit, and news about him spread through the whole countryside.
42:4:15/He was teaching in their synagogues, and everyone praised him.
42:4:16/He went to Nazareth, where he had been brought up, and on the Sabbath day he went into the synagogue, as was his custom. He stood up to read,
42:4:17/and the scroll of the prophet Isaiah was handed to him. Unrolling it, he found the place where it is written,
42:4:18/"The Spirit of the Lord is on me, because he has anointed me to proclaim good news to the poor. He has sent me to proclaim freedom for the prisoners and recovery of sight for the blind, to set the oppressed free,
42:4:19/to proclaim the year of the Lord's favor."
42:4:20/Then he rolled up the scroll, gave it back to the attendant and sat down. The eyes of everyone in the synagogue were fastened on him.
42:4:21/He began by saying to them, "Today this scripture is fulfilled in your hearing."
42:4:22/All spoke well of him and were amazed at the gracious words that came from his lips. "Isn't this Joseph's son?" they asked.
42:4:23/He said to them, "Surely you will quote this proverb to me: 'Physician, heal yourself! Do here in your hometown what we have heard that you did in Capernaum.'"
42:4:24/"Truly I tell you," he continued, "no prophet is accepted in his hometown.
42:4:25/But I tell you the truth, there were many widows in Israel in Elijah's time, when the sky was shut for three and a half years and there was a severe famine throughout the land.
42:4:26/Yet Elijah was not sent to any of them, but to a widow in Zarephath in the region of Sidon.
42:4:27/And there were many in Israel with leprosy in the time of Elisha the prophet, yet not one of them was cleansed—only Naaman the Syrian."
42:4:28/All the people in the synagogue were furious when they heard this.
42:4:29/They got up, drove him out of the town, and took him to the brow of the hill on which the town was built, in order to throw him off the cliff.
42:4:30/But he walked right through the crowd and went on his way.
42:4:31/Then he went down to Capernaum, a town in Galilee, and on the Sabbath he taught the people.
42:4:32/They were amazed at his teaching because his words had authority.
42:4:33/In the synagogue there was a man possessed by a demon, an impure spirit. He cried out at the top of his voice,
42:4:34/"Ha! What do you want with us, Jesus of Nazareth? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are—the Holy One of God!"
42:4:35/Jesus rebuked him, saying, "Be quiet, and come out of him!" And the demon threw the man down before them all and came out without injuring him.
42:4:36/Everyone was amazed and said to each other, "What words these are! With authority and power he gives orders to impure spirits and they come out!"
42:4:37/And the news about him spread throughout the surrounding area.
42:4:38/Jesus left the synagogue and went to Simon's house. Simon's mother-in-law was suffering from a high fever, and they asked Jesus to help her.
42:4:39/So he bent over her, rebuked the fever, and it left her. She got up at once and began to serve them.
42:4:40/At sunset, the people brought to Jesus all who had various kinds of sickness, and laying his hands on each one, he healed them.
42:4:41/Moreover, demons came out of many people, shouting, "You are the Son of God!" But he rebuked them and would not allow them to speak because they knew he was the Messiah.
42:4:42/At daybreak, Jesus went out to a solitary place. The people were looking for him and when they came to where he was, they tried to keep him from leaving them.
42:4:43/But he said, "I must proclaim the good news of the kingdom of God to the other towns also, because that is why I was sent."
42:4:44/And he kept on preaching in the synagogues of Judea.
42:5:1/As the crowd gathered around him to listen to the word of God, he stood by the lake of Gennesaret,
42:5:2/He noticed two boats by the lake; the fishermen had left them and were cleaning their nets.
42:5:3/He got into one of the boats, which belonged to Simon, and asked him to push off a bit from the shore. Then he sat down and taught the people from the boat.
42:5:4/After he finished speaking, he told Simon, "Head out into the deep water and let down your nets for a catch."
42:5:5/Simon replied, "Master, we've worked hard all night and haven't caught anything. But because you say so, I'll let down the nets."
42:5:6/When they did, they caught such a large number of fish that their nets began to tear.
42:5:7/They signaled to their partners in the other boat to come and help them. They came and filled both boats so full that they started to sink.
42:5:8/Seeing this, Simon Peter fell at Jesus' knees and said, "Leave me, Lord; I'm a sinful man."
42:5:9/He and everyone with him were amazed at the catch of fish they had taken,
42:5:10/As were James and John, the sons of Zebedee, Simon's partners. Then Jesus said to Simon, "Don't be afraid; from now on you'll be fishing for people."
42:5:11/When they brought their boats to shore, they left everything and followed him.
42:5:12/While in a certain city, a man covered in leprosy saw Jesus, fell on his face, and begged him, "Lord, if you are willing, you can make me clean."
42:5:13/Jesus reached out his hand, touched him, and said, "I am willing; be clean." Immediately the leprosy left him.
42:5:14/He instructed him not to tell anyone, but to go show himself to the priest and offer the sacrifices Moses commanded for his cleansing, as a testimony to them.
42:5:15/But news about him spread even more, and large crowds gathered to listen and to be healed of their sicknesses.
42:5:16/Yet, he often withdrew to deserted places and prayed.
42:5:17/One day, as he was teaching, Pharisees and teachers of the law were sitting nearby. They had come from every village of Galilee and Judea and from Jerusalem. And the power of the Lord was with him to heal.
42:5:18/Some men came carrying a paralyzed man on a mat and tried to take him into the house to lay him before Jesus.
42:5:19/When they couldn't find a way to do this because of the crowd, they went up on the roof and lowered him on his mat through the tiles into the middle of the crowd, right in front of Jesus.
42:5:20/Seeing their faith, Jesus said, "Friend, your sins are forgiven."
42:5:21/But the scribes and Pharisees began to think to themselves, "Who is this who speaks blasphemy? Who can forgive sins but God alone?"
42:5:22/Knowing their thoughts, Jesus asked, "Why are you thinking these things in your hearts?
42:5:23/Which is easier: to say, 'Your sins are forgiven,' or to say, 'Get up and walk'?
42:5:24/But so you may know that the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sins..." He said to the paralyzed man, "I tell you, get up, take your mat and go home."
42:5:25/Immediately he stood up in front of them, took what he had been lying on, and went home praising God.
42:5:26/Everyone was amazed and praised God. They were filled with awe and said, "We have seen remarkable things today."
42:5:27/After this, he went out and saw a tax collector named Levi sitting at his tax booth. "Follow me," Jesus said to him.
42:5:28/And leaving everything, he got up and followed him.
42:5:29/Levi held a large banquet for Jesus at his house. A large crowd of tax collectors and others were eating with them.
42:5:30/But the Pharisees and their scribes complained to his disciples, asking, "Why do you eat and drink with tax collectors and sinners?"
42:5:31/Jesus answered them, "It's not the healthy who need a doctor, but the sick.
42:5:32/I have not come to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance."
42:5:33/They asked him, "Why do John's disciples often fast and pray, and so do the disciples of the Pharisees, but yours eat and drink?"
42:5:34/He replied, "Can you make the friends of the bridegroom fast while he is with them?
42:5:35/But the time will come when the bridegroom will be taken from them; in those days they will fast."
42:5:36/He also told them a parable: "No one tears a piece from a new garment and sews it on an old one. If he does, he will have torn the new garment, and the patch from the new will not match the old.
42:5:37/And no one pours new wine into old wineskins. If he does, the new wine will burst the skins, the wine will run out, and the wineskins will be ruined.
42:5:38/But new wine must be put into new wineskins.
42:5:39/And no one after drinking old wine wants the new, for he says, 'The old is better.'"
42:6:1/On the second Sabbath after the first, he walked through the grain fields; his disciples picked some heads of grain, ate them, rubbing them in their hands.
42:6:2/Some of the Pharisees asked, "Why are you doing what is not lawful on the Sabbath?"
42:6:3/Jesus answered them, "Haven't you ever read what David did when he and his companions were hungry?
42:6:4/He entered the house of God, took and ate the consecrated bread, and also gave some to his companions, which is not lawful for anyone but the priests to eat."
42:6:5/Then he told them, "The Son of Man is Lord of the Sabbath."
42:6:6/On another Sabbath, he went into the synagogue and taught, and a man was there whose right hand was shriveled.
42:6:7/The scribes and Pharisees watched him closely to see if he would heal on the Sabbath, so they could find a reason to accuse him.
42:6:8/But knowing their thoughts, he said to the man with the shriveled hand, "Get up and stand in front of everyone." So he got up and stood there.
42:6:9/Then Jesus said to them, "I ask you, is it lawful on the Sabbath to do good or to do evil, to save life or to destroy it?"
42:6:10/He looked around at them all and then said to the man, "Stretch out your hand." He did so, and his hand was completely restored.
42:6:11/But they were furious and began to discuss with one another what they might do to Jesus.
42:6:12/During those days, he went out to a mountain to pray and spent the night praying to God.
42:6:13/When daylight came, he called his disciples to him and chose twelve of them, whom he also designated apostles:
42:6:14/Simon (whom he named Peter), his brother Andrew, James, John, Philip, Bartholomew,
42:6:15/Matthew, Thomas, James son of Alphaeus, Simon called the Zealot,
42:6:16/Judas son of James, and Judas Iscariot, who became a traitor.
42:6:17/He went down with them and stood on a level place. A large crowd of his disciples was there and a great number of people from all over Judea, Jerusalem, and the coastal region of Tyre and Sidon,
42:6:18/who had come to hear him and to be healed of their diseases. Those troubled by impure spirits were cured,
42:6:19/and the people all tried to touch him, because power was coming from him and healing them all.
42:6:20/Looking at his disciples, he said, "Blessed are you who are poor, for yours is the kingdom of God.
42:6:21/Blessed are you who are hungry now, for you will be satisfied. Blessed are you who weep now, for you will laugh.
42:6:22/Blessed are you when people hate you, when they exclude you and insult you and reject your name as evil, because of the Son of Man.
42:6:23/Rejoice in that day and leap for joy, because great is your reward in heaven. For that is how their ancestors treated the prophets.
42:6:24/But woe to you who are rich, for you have already received your comfort.
42:6:25/Woe to you who are well fed now, for you will go hungry. Woe to you who laugh now, for you will mourn and weep.
42:6:26/Woe to you when everyone speaks well of you, for that is how their ancestors treated the false prophets.
42:6:27/But to you who are listening I say: Love your enemies, do good to those who hate you,
42:6:28/Bless those who curse you, pray for those who mistreat you.
42:6:29/If someone slaps you on one cheek, turn to them the other also. If someone takes your coat, do not withhold your shirt from them.
42:6:30/Give to everyone who asks you, and if anyone takes what belongs to you, do not demand it back.
42:6:31/Do to others as you would have them do to you.
42:6:32/If you love those who love you, what credit is that to you? Even sinners love those who love them.
42:6:33/And if you do good to those who are good to you, what credit is that to you? Even sinners do that.
42:6:34/And if you lend to those from whom you expect repayment, what credit is that to you? Even sinners lend to sinners, expecting to be repaid in full.
42:6:35/But love your enemies, do good to them, and lend to them without expecting to get anything back. Then your reward will be great, and you will be children of the Most High, because he is kind to the ungrateful and wicked.
42:6:36/Be merciful, just as your Father is merciful.
42:6:37/Do not judge, and you will not be judged. Do not condemn, and you will not be condemned. Forgive, and you will be forgiven.
42:6:38/Give, and it will be given to you. A good measure, pressed down, shaken together and running over, will be poured into your lap. For with the measure you use, it will be measured to you."
42:6:39/He told them this parable: "Can the blind lead the blind? Will they not both fall into a pit?
42:6:40/A student is not above the teacher, but everyone who is fully trained will be like their teacher.
42:6:41/Why do you look at the speck of sawdust in your brother's eye and pay no attention to the plank in your own eye?
42:6:42/How can you say to your brother, 'Brother, let me take the speck out of your eye,' when you yourself fail to see the plank in your own eye? You hypocrite, first take the plank out of your own eye, and then you will see clearly to remove the speck from your brother's eye.
42:6:43/A good tree does not bear bad fruit, nor does a bad tree bear good fruit.
42:6:44/Each tree is recognized by its own fruit. People do not pick figs from thornbushes, or grapes from briers.
42:6:45/A good person brings good things out of the good stored up in their heart, and an evil person brings evil things out of the evil stored up in their heart. For the mouth speaks what the heart is full of.
42:6:46/Why do you call me, 'Lord, Lord,' and do not do what I say?
42:6:47/Everyone who comes to me and hears my words and puts them into practice, I will show you what they are like:
42:6:48/They are like a person building a house, who dug down deep and laid the foundation on rock. When a flood came, the torrent struck that house but could not shake it, because it was well built.
42:6:49/But the one who hears my words and does not put them into practice is like a person who built a house on the ground without a foundation. The moment the torrent struck that house, it collapsed and its destruction was complete.
42:7:1/After finishing all his teachings in front of the crowd, he went into Capernaum.
42:7:2/A centurion had a servant who was very important to him, and this servant was ill and close to death.
42:7:3/When the centurion heard about Jesus, he sent some Jewish elders to ask him to come and heal his servant.
42:7:4/They approached Jesus and urgently pleaded with him, saying, "He deserves your help because:
42:7:5/He loves our people and even built a synagogue for us."
42:7:6/So, Jesus went with them. When he wasn't far from the house, the centurion sent friends to tell him, "Lord, don't trouble yourself. I don't deserve to have you come under my roof,
42:7:7/That's why I didn't consider myself worthy to come to you. But just say the word, and my servant will be healed.
42:7:8/I too am a man under authority, with soldiers under me. I tell one 'Go,' and he goes; another 'Come,' and he comes; and to my servant 'Do this,' and he does it."
42:7:9/Amazed by what he heard, Jesus turned to the crowd following him and said, "I tell you, I haven't found such great faith even in Israel."
42:7:10/The messengers returned to the house and found the servant completely healed.
42:7:11/The next day, he went to a town called Nain, accompanied by his disciples and a large crowd.
42:7:12/As he approached the town gate, a funeral procession was coming out. The dead man was the only son of a widow, and a large crowd from the town was with her.
42:7:13/Seeing her, the Lord felt compassion for her and said, "Don't cry."
42:7:14/He went up and touched the coffin, and the bearers stopped. He said, "Young man, I tell you, get up."
42:7:15/The dead man sat up and began to talk, and Jesus gave him back to his mother.
42:7:16/Everyone was filled with awe and praised God, saying, "A great prophet has appeared among us," and "God has come to help his people."
42:7:17/News about him spread throughout Judea and the surrounding area.
42:7:18/John's disciples told him about all these things.
42:7:19/John called two of his disciples and sent them to the Lord to ask, "Are you the one who is to come, or should we expect someone else?"
42:7:20/When the men arrived, they said, "John the Baptist sent us to ask you, 'Are you the one who is to come, or should we look for another?'"
42:7:21/Right then, he healed many people of their diseases, afflictions, and evil spirits, and he gave sight to many who were blind.
42:7:22/So Jesus replied, "Go back and report to John what you have seen and heard: the blind regain their sight, the lame walk, those with leprosy are cleansed, the deaf hear, the dead are raised, and the good news is proclaimed to the poor.
42:7:23/And blessed is anyone who does not stumble on account of me."
42:7:24/After John's messengers left, Jesus began to speak to the crowd about John: "What did you go out into the wilderness to see? A reed swayed by the wind?
42:7:25/What did you go out to see? A man dressed in fine clothes? No, those who wear expensive clothes and indulge in luxury are in palaces.
42:7:26/But what did you go out to see? A prophet? Yes, I tell you, and more than a prophet.
42:7:27/He is the one about whom it is written, 'Look, I am sending my messenger ahead of you, who will prepare your way before you.'
42:7:28/I tell you, among those born of women there is no one greater than John; yet the one who is least in the kingdom of God is greater than he."
42:7:29/Everyone who heard this, including the tax collectors, acknowledged God's justice, having been baptized with John's baptism.
42:7:30/But the Pharisees and experts in the law rejected God's purpose for themselves, not having been baptized by John.
42:7:31/Then the Lord said, "To what, then, can I compare the people of this generation? What are they like?
42:7:32/They are like children sitting in the marketplace and calling to each other: 'We played the flute for you, and you didn't dance; we sang a dirge, and you didn't cry.'
42:7:33/For John the Baptist came neither eating bread nor drinking wine, and you say, 'He has a demon.'
42:7:34/The Son of Man came eating and drinking, and you say, 'Look, a glutton and a drunkard, a friend of tax collectors and sinners!'
42:7:35/Yet wisdom is proved right by all her children."
42:7:36/A Pharisee invited him to dine with him, so he went to the Pharisee's house and reclined at the table.
42:7:37/And there was a woman in the city who was known as a sinner. When she found out Jesus was dining at the Pharisee's house, she brought an alabaster jar of perfume,
42:7:38/and stood behind him at his feet, crying. She began to wet his feet with her tears, then wiped them with her hair, kissed them, and anointed them with the perfume.
42:7:39/When the Pharisee who had invited him saw this, he thought to himself, "If this man were a prophet, he would know who is touching him and what kind of woman she is—that she's a sinner."
42:7:40/Jesus responded, "Simon, I have something to tell you." "Go ahead, Teacher," he said.
42:7:41/"Two people owed money to a certain moneylender. One owed him five hundred denarii, and the other fifty.
42:7:42/Neither of them had the money to pay him back, so he forgave the debts of both. Now which of them will love him more?"
42:7:43/Simon replied, "I suppose the one who had the bigger debt forgiven." "You have judged correctly," Jesus said.
42:7:44/Then he turned toward the woman and said to Simon, "Do you see this woman? I came into your house, and you didn't provide water for my feet, but she has wet my feet with her tears and wiped them with her hair.
42:7:45/You didn't give me a kiss, but this woman, from the time I entered, has not stopped kissing my feet.
42:7:46/You didn't anoint my head with oil, but she has anointed my feet with perfume.
42:7:47/Therefore, I tell you, her many sins have been forgiven—as her great love has shown. But whoever has been forgiven little loves little."
42:7:48/Then he said to her, "Your sins are forgiven."
42:7:49/The other guests began to say among themselves, "Who is this who even forgives sins?"
42:7:50/And he said to the woman, "Your faith has saved you; go in peace."
42:8:1/After that, he traveled through every city and village, spreading the good news of God's kingdom, accompanied by the twelve.
42:8:2/Among them were women who had been cured of evil spirits and illnesses, including Mary called Magdalene, from whom seven demons had been expelled,
42:8:3/Joanna, the wife of Chuza, Herod's steward, Susanna, and many others who supported him with their resources.
42:8:4/When a large crowd had gathered and people came to him from every city, he told them a parable:
42:8:5/A farmer went out to plant his seeds. As he scattered them, some seeds fell along the path, where they were stepped on, and birds ate them up.
42:8:6/Some seeds fell on rocky ground, and when they sprouted, they withered away because they had no moisture.
42:8:7/Other seeds fell among thorns, which grew up with them and choked the plants.
42:8:8/Still, other seeds fell on fertile soil, grew, and produced a crop a hundred times more than was sown. After saying this, he shouted, "Anyone with ears to hear should listen and understand."
42:8:9/His disciples asked him what this parable meant.
42:8:10/He replied, "You have been given the knowledge of the secrets of God's kingdom, but to others, I speak in parables so that 'though they see, they may not see; though they hear, they may not understand.'"
42:8:11/This is the meaning of the parable: The seed is God's word.
42:8:12/The seeds along the path represent those who hear, but then the devil comes and takes away the word from their hearts, preventing them from believing and being saved.
42:8:13/The seeds on the rock represent those who receive the word with joy when they hear it, but they have no root. They believe for a while, but in times of testing, they fall away.
42:8:14/The seeds that fell among thorns stand for those who hear, but as they go on their way, they are choked by life's worries, riches, and pleasures, and they do not mature.
42:8:15/But the seeds on good soil represent those with a noble and good heart, who hear the word, retain it, and by persevering produce a crop.
42:8:16/No one lights a lamp and then covers it with a bowl or hides it under a bed. Instead, they put it on a stand, so those who come in can see the light.
42:8:17/For there is nothing hidden that will not be disclosed, and nothing concealed that will not be known or brought out into the open.
42:8:18/Therefore, consider carefully how you listen. Whoever has will be given more; whoever does not have, even what they think they have will be taken from them."
42:8:19/Then his mother and brothers came to see him but couldn't get through the crowd.
42:8:20/Someone told him, "Your mother and brothers are standing outside, wanting to see you."
42:8:21/He replied, "My mother and brothers are those who hear God's word and put it into practice."
42:8:22/One day, he got into a boat with his disciples and said, "Let's go across to the other side of the lake." So they set out.
42:8:23/While they were sailing, he fell asleep. A storm swept down on the lake, and they were taking on water and were in danger.
42:8:24/They went to him and woke him, shouting, "Master, Master, we're going to drown!" He got up, rebuked the wind and the raging waters; the storm subsided, and all was calm.
42:8:25/He asked them, "Where is your faith?" In fear and amazement, they asked one another, "Who is this? He commands even the winds and the water, and they obey him."
42:8:26/They sailed to the region of the Gerasenes, which is across the lake from Galilee.
42:8:27/When Jesus stepped ashore, he was met by a man from the town who was possessed by demons. For a long time, this man had not worn clothes or lived in a house but had lived in the tombs.
42:8:28/Seeing Jesus, he cried out and fell at his feet, shouting at the top of his voice, "What do you want with me, Jesus, Son of the Most High God? I beg you, don't torture me!"
42:8:29/(For Jesus had commanded the impure spirit to come out of the man. Many times it had seized him, and though he was chained hand and foot and kept under guard, he had broken his chains and had been driven by the demon into solitary places.)
42:8:30/Jesus asked him, "What is your name?" "Legion," he replied, because many demons had gone into him.
42:8:31/And they begged Jesus repeatedly not to order them to go into the Abyss.
42:8:32/A large herd of pigs was feeding there on the hillside. The demons begged Jesus to let them go into the pigs, and he gave them permission.
42:8:33/When the demons came out of the man, they went into the pigs, and the herd rushed down the steep bank into the lake and drowned.
42:8:34/When those tending the pigs saw what had happened, they ran off and reported this in the town and countryside,
42:8:35/and the people went out to see what had happened. When they came to Jesus, they found the man from whom the demons had gone out, sitting at Jesus' feet, dressed and in his right mind; and they were afraid.
42:8:36/Those who had seen it told the people how the demon-possessed man had been cured.
42:8:37/Then all the people of the region of the Gerasenes asked Jesus to leave them, because they were overcome with fear. So he got into the boat and left.
42:8:38/The man from whom the demons had gone out begged to go with him, but Jesus sent him away, saying,
42:8:39/"Go back to your home, and tell how much God has done for you." So the man went away and told all over the town how much Jesus had done for him.
42:8:40/When Jesus returned, a crowd welcomed him, for they were all expecting him.
42:8:41/Then a man named Jairus, a synagogue leader, came and fell at Jesus' feet, pleading with him to come to his house
42:8:42/because his only daughter, a girl of about twelve, was dying. As Jesus was on his way, the crowds almost crushed him.
42:8:43/And a woman was there who had been subject to bleeding for twelve years, but no one could heal her.
42:8:44/She came up behind him and touched the edge of his cloak, and immediately her bleeding stopped.
42:8:45/Jesus asked, "Who touched me?" When everyone denied it, Peter said, "Master, the people are crowding and pressing against you."
42:8:46/But Jesus said, "Someone touched me; I know that power has gone out from me."
42:8:47/Then the woman, seeing that she could not go unnoticed, came trembling and fell at his feet. In the presence of all the people, she told why she had touched him and how she had been instantly healed.
42:8:48/He said to her, "Daughter, your faith has healed you. Go in peace."
42:8:49/While he was still speaking, someone came from the house of Jairus, the synagogue leader. "Your daughter is dead," he said. "Don't bother the teacher anymore."
42:8:50/Hearing this, Jesus said to Jairus, "Don't be afraid; just believe, and she will be healed."
42:8:51/When he arrived at the house, he did not let anyone go in with him except Peter, John, James, and the girl's father and mother.
