44:12:5/Meanwhile, Peter was held in prison, but the church was fervently praying to God for him.
44:12:6/On the night before Herod was to bring him to trial, Peter was sleeping between two soldiers, bound with two chains, and sentries stood guard at the entrance.
44:12:7/Suddenly, an angel of the Lord appeared and a light shone in the cell. He struck Peter on the side to wake him up and said, "Quick, get up!" And the chains fell off Peter’s wrists.
44:12:8/The angel told him, "Get dressed and put on your sandals." Peter did so, and the angel said, "Wrap your cloak around you and follow me."
44:12:9/Peter followed him out of the prison, but he had no idea that what the angel was doing was really happening; he thought he was seeing a vision.
44:12:10/They passed the first and second guards and came to the iron gate leading to the city, which opened for them by itself. They went through it, and when they had walked the length of one street, suddenly the angel left him.
44:12:11/Then Peter came to himself and said, "Now I am sure that the Lord has sent his angel and rescued me from Herod’s clutches and from everything the Jewish people were anticipating."
44:12:12/After this realization, he went to the house of Mary, the mother of John also called Mark, where many people had gathered and were praying.
44:12:13/When Peter knocked at the outer entrance, a servant named Rhoda came to answer.
44:12:14/Recognizing Peter’s voice, she was so overjoyed she ran back without opening the gate and exclaimed, "Peter is at the door!"
44:12:15/They told her, "You're out of your mind." But she kept insisting that it was so. They said, "It must be his angel."
44:12:16/Meanwhile, Peter continued knocking. When they opened the door and saw him, they were amazed.
44:12:17/Motioning to them with his hand to be quiet, he described how the Lord had led him out of prison. "Tell James and the other brothers and sisters about this," he said, and then he left for another place.
44:12:18/At dawn, there was a great commotion among the soldiers as to what had become of Peter.
44:12:19/After Herod had a thorough search made for him and did not find him, he cross-examined the guards and ordered that they be executed. Then Herod went from Judea to Caesarea and stayed there.
44:12:20/Herod was furious with the people of Tyre and Sidon; but they came to him in a united front, and having secured the support of Blastus, the king’s personal aide, they asked for peace because their regions depended on the king’s country for food.
44:12:21/On the appointed day, Herod, wearing his royal robes, sat on his throne and delivered a public address to them.
44:12:22/The people shouted, "This is the voice of a god, not of a man."
44:12:23/Immediately, because Herod did not give praise to God, an angel of the Lord struck him down, and he was eaten by worms and died.
44:12:24/But the word of God continued to spread and flourish.
44:12:25/Barnabas and Saul returned from Jerusalem after completing their mission, taking with them John, also known as Mark.
44:13:1/In the church at Antioch, there were some prophets and teachers, including Barnabas, Simeon called Niger, Lucius of Cyrene, Manaen who had been brought up with Herod the tetrarch, and Saul.
44:13:2/While they were serving the Lord and fasting, the Holy Spirit said, "Set apart Barnabas and Saul for the mission I have called them to."
44:13:3/After they had fasted and prayed, and laid their hands on them, they sent them off.
44:13:4/So, being sent by the Holy Spirit, they went down to Seleucia and from there sailed to Cyprus.
44:13:5/When they arrived at Salamis, they proclaimed the word of God in the Jewish synagogues. They also had John as their assistant.
44:13:6/As they traveled through the island to Paphos, they encountered a sorcerer, a false prophet, a Jew named Barjesus,
44:13:7/who was with the proconsul, Sergius Paulus, an intelligent man. He called for Barnabas and Saul because he wanted to hear the word of God.
44:13:8/But Elymas the sorcerer (which is what his name means) opposed them, trying to turn the proconsul away from the faith.
44:13:9/Then Saul, also known as Paul, filled with the Holy Spirit, looked straight at him
44:13:10/and said, "You are full of all kinds of deceit and trickery, you son of the devil, you enemy of all righteousness! Will you never stop perverting the true ways of the Lord?
44:13:11/Now, the hand of the Lord is against you. You are going to be blind, and for a time you will not see the light of the sun." Immediately mist and darkness fell on him, and he groped about, seeking someone to lead him by the hand.
44:13:12/When the proconsul saw what had happened, he believed, for he was amazed at the teaching about the Lord.
44:13:13/After leaving Paphos, Paul and his companions sailed to Perga in Pamphylia. John left them to return to Jerusalem.
44:13:14/But they went on from Perga and arrived at Antioch in Pisidia. On the Sabbath, they entered the synagogue and sat down.
44:13:15/After the reading from the Law and the Prophets, the synagogue leaders sent word to them, saying, "Brothers, if you have a message of encouragement for the people, please speak."
44:13:16/Paul stood up, motioned with his hand, and said, "Fellow Israelites and you Gentiles who worship God, listen to me.
44:13:17/The God of the people of Israel chose our ancestors; he made the people prosper during their stay in Egypt, and with mighty power he led them out of that country.
44:13:18/For about forty years he endured their conduct in the wilderness.
44:13:19/He overthrew seven nations in Canaan, giving their land to his people as their inheritance.
44:13:20/All this took about 450 years. After that, God gave them judges until the time of Samuel the prophet.
44:13:21/Then the people asked for a king, and God gave them Saul son of Kish, a man of the tribe of Benjamin, who ruled forty years.
44:13:22/After removing Saul, he made David their king. God testified concerning him: 'I have found David son of Jesse, a man after my own heart; he will do everything I want him to do.'
44:13:23/From this man's descendants God has brought to Israel the Savior Jesus, as he promised.
44:13:24/Before Jesus came, John preached repentance and baptism to all the people of Israel.
44:13:25/As John was completing his work, he said: 'Who do you think I am? I am not the one. No, but he is coming after me, whose sandals I am not worthy to untie.'
44:13:26/Fellow children of Abraham and all of you who fear God, this message of salvation has been sent to us.
44:13:27/The people of Jerusalem and their rulers did not recognize Jesus, yet in condemning him, they fulfilled the words of the prophets that are read every Sabbath.
44:13:28/Though they found no proper ground for a death sentence, they asked Pilate to have him executed.
44:13:29/When they had carried out all that was written about him, they took him down from the cross and laid him in a tomb.
44:13:30/But God raised him from the dead,
44:13:31/and for many days he was seen by those who had traveled with him from Galilee to Jerusalem. They are now his witnesses to our people.
44:13:32/We tell you the good news: What God promised our ancestors
44:13:33/he has fulfilled for us, their children, by raising up Jesus. As it is written in the second Psalm: 'You are my Son; today I have become your Father.'
44:13:34/In fact, regarding his resurrection from the dead, never to decay, he has spoken in this way: 'I will give you the holy and sure blessings promised to David.'
44:13:35/So it is also stated elsewhere: 'You will not let your Holy One see decay.'
44:13:36/For David, after he had served the purpose of God in his own generation, died, was buried with his ancestors, and his body decayed.
44:13:37/But the one whom God raised from the dead did not see decay.
44:13:38/Therefore, my friends, I want you to know that through Jesus the forgiveness of sins is proclaimed to you.
44:13:39/Through him everyone who believes is set free from every sin, a justification you were not able to obtain under the law of Moses.
44:13:40/Take care that what the prophets have said does not happen to you:
44:13:41/'Look, you scoffers, wonder and perish, for I am going to do something in your days that you would never believe, even if someone told you.'
44:13:42/As Paul and Barnabas were leaving the synagogue, the people invited them to speak further about these things on the next Sabbath.
44:13:43/When the meeting of the synagogue broke up, many Jews and devout converts to Judaism followed Paul and Barnabas, who talked with them and urged them to continue in the grace of God.
44:13:44/On the next Sabbath almost the whole city gathered to hear the word of the Lord.
44:13:45/But when the Jews saw the crowds, they were filled with jealousy and began to contradict what was spoken by Paul, reviling him.
44:13:46/Then Paul and Barnabas answered boldly: "It was necessary that the word of God be spoken first to you. Since you reject it and do not consider yourselves worthy of eternal life, we now turn to the Gentiles.
44:13:47/For this is what the Lord has commanded us: 'I have made you a light for the Gentiles, that you may bring salvation to the ends of the earth.'"
44:13:48/When the Gentiles heard this, they were glad and honored the word of the Lord; and all who were appointed for eternal life believed.
44:13:49/The word of the Lord spread throughout the whole region.
44:13:50/But the Jews incited the devout women of high standing and the leading men of the city, stirred up persecution against Paul and Barnabas, and expelled them from their region.
44:13:51/So they shook the dust off their feet as a warning to them and went to Iconium.
44:13:52/And the disciples were filled with joy and with the Holy Spirit.
44:14:1/In Iconium, they both went into the synagogue of the Jews and spoke so effectively that a large number of both Jews and Greeks believed.
44:14:2/However, the Jews who did not believe stirred up the Gentiles and poisoned their minds against the believers.
44:14:3/So, they spent a considerable time there, speaking boldly for the Lord, who confirmed the message of his grace by enabling them to perform signs and wonders.
44:14:4/But the city was divided; some sided with the Jews, others with the apostles.
44:14:5/When an attack was planned against them by both Gentiles and Jews, along with their leaders, to mistreat them and stone them,
44:14:6/they became aware of it and fled to the cities of Lystra and Derbe in Lycaonia, and to the surrounding region,
44:14:7/where they continued to preach the gospel.
44:14:8/In Lystra, there was a man who couldn't use his feet, crippled from birth, who had never walked.
44:14:9/This man listened to Paul speaking. Paul looked directly at him, saw that he had faith to be healed,
44:14:10/and called out, "Stand up on your feet!" At that, the man jumped up and began to walk.
44:14:11/When the crowd saw what Paul had done, they shouted in the Lycaonian language, "The gods have come down to us in human form!"
44:14:12/They called Barnabas Zeus, and Paul Hermes, because he was the main speaker.
44:14:13/The priest of Zeus, whose temple was just outside the city, brought bulls and wreaths to the city gates because he wanted to offer sacrifices with the crowds.
44:14:14/But when the apostles Barnabas and Paul heard of this, they tore their clothes and rushed out into the crowd, shouting,
44:14:15/"Friends, why are you doing this? We are just humans like you, and we are telling you to turn away from these worthless things to the living God, who made the heavens, the earth, the sea, and everything in them.
44:14:16/In the past, he let all nations go their own way.
44:14:17/Yet he has not left himself without testimony: He has shown kindness by giving you rain from heaven and crops in their seasons; he provides you with plenty of food and fills your hearts with joy."
44:14:18/Even with these words, they had difficulty keeping the crowd from sacrificing to them.
44:14:19/Then some Jews came from Antioch and Iconium and won the crowd over. They stoned Paul and dragged him outside the city, thinking he was dead.
44:14:20/But after the disciples had gathered around him, he got up and went back into the city. The next day he and Barnabas left for Derbe.
44:14:21/After preaching the gospel in that city and making many disciples, they returned to Lystra, Iconium, and Antioch,
44:14:22/strengthening the disciples and encouraging them to remain true to the faith. "We must go through many hardships to enter the kingdom of God," they said.
44:14:23/When they had appointed elders for them in each church and had prayed with fasting, they committed them to the Lord, in whom they had put their trust.
44:14:24/After going through Pisidia, they came into Pamphylia.
44:14:25/And when they had preached the word in Perga, they went down to Attalia.
44:14:26/From there they sailed back to Antioch, where they had been committed to the grace of God for the work they had now completed.
44:14:27/On arriving there, they gathered the church together and reported all that God had done through them and how he had opened a door of faith to the Gentiles.
44:14:28/And they spent a considerable time with the disciples.
44:15:1/Some men from Judea came and taught the believers, "Unless you are circumcised according to the custom taught by Moses, you cannot be saved."
44:15:2/So when Paul and Barnabas had a significant disagreement and debate with them, it was decided that Paul and Barnabas, along with some other believers, should go to Jerusalem to discuss this issue with the apostles and elders.
44:15:3/With the church's support, they traveled through Phoenicia and Samaria, sharing the news of the Gentiles converting, which brought great joy to all the believers.
44:15:4/Upon arriving in Jerusalem, they were welcomed by the church, the apostles, and the elders, and they reported everything God had done through them.
44:15:5/However, some believers who belonged to the party of the Pharisees stood up and said, "The Gentiles must be circumcised and required to keep the law of Moses."
44:15:6/The apostles and elders met to consider this matter.
44:15:7/After much discussion, Peter stood up and said to them, "Brothers, you know that some time ago God made a choice among you that the Gentiles might hear from my lips the message of the gospel and believe.
44:15:8/God, who knows the heart, showed that he accepted them by giving the Holy Spirit to them, just as he did to us.
44:15:9/He made no distinction between us and them, for he purified their hearts by faith.
44:15:10/Now then, why do you test God by putting on the necks of the disciples a yoke that neither we nor our ancestors have been able to bear?
44:15:11/But we believe it is through the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ that we are saved, just as they are."
44:15:12/The whole assembly became silent as they listened to Barnabas and Paul telling about the signs and wonders God had done among the Gentiles through them.
44:15:13/When they finished, James spoke up, "Brothers, listen to me.
44:15:14/Simon has described to us how God first intervened to choose a people for his name from the Gentiles.
44:15:15/The words of the prophets are in agreement with this, as it is written,
44:15:16/'After this I will return and rebuild David's fallen tent. Its ruins I will rebuild, and I will restore it,
44:15:17/so that the rest of mankind may seek the Lord, even all the Gentiles who bear my name, says the Lord, who does these things—
44:15:18/things known from long ago.
44:15:19/It is my judgment, therefore, that we should not make it difficult for the Gentiles who are turning to God.
44:15:20/Instead we should write to them, telling them to abstain from food polluted by idols, from sexual immorality, from the meat of strangled animals, and from blood.
44:15:21/For the law of Moses has been preached in every city from the earliest times and is read in the synagogues on every Sabbath."
44:15:22/Then the apostles and elders, with the whole church, decided to choose some of their own men and send them to Antioch with Paul and Barnabas. They chose Judas (called Barsabbas) and Silas, men who were leaders among the believers.
44:15:23/They sent the following letter: The apostles and elders, your brothers, To the Gentile believers in Antioch, Syria and Cilicia: Greetings.
44:15:24/We have heard that some went out from us without our authorization and disturbed you, troubling your minds by what they said.
44:15:25/So we all agreed to choose some men and send them to you with our dear friends Barnabas and Paul—
44:15:26/men who have risked their lives for the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.
44:15:27/Therefore we are sending Judas and Silas to confirm by word of mouth what we are writing.
44:15:28/It seemed good to the Holy Spirit and to us not to burden you with anything beyond the following requirements:
44:15:29/You are to abstain from food sacrificed to idols, from blood, from the meat of strangled animals, and from sexual immorality. If you keep yourselves from these, you will do well. Farewell.
44:15:30/So the messengers were sent off and went to Antioch, where they gathered the congregation and delivered the letter.
44:15:31/When they read it, they were glad for its encouraging message.
44:15:32/Judas and Silas, who themselves were prophets, said much to encourage and strengthen the believers.
44:15:33/After spending some time there, they were sent off by the believers with the blessing of peace to return to those who had sent them.
44:15:34/However, Silas decided to stay there.
44:15:35/Paul and Barnabas remained in Antioch, where they and many others taught and preached the word of the Lord.
44:15:36/Some time later Paul said to Barnabas, "Let's go back and visit the believers in all the towns where we preached the word of the Lord and see how they are doing."
44:15:37/Barnabas wanted to take John, also called Mark, with them.
44:15:38/But Paul did not think it wise to take him, because he had deserted them in Pamphylia and had not continued with them in the work.
44:15:39/They had such a sharp disagreement that they parted ways. Barnabas took Mark and sailed for Cyprus,
44:15:40/while Paul chose Silas and left, commended by the believers to the grace of the Lord.
44:15:41/He went through Syria and Cilicia, strengthening the churches.
44:16:1/Then he arrived in Derbe and Lystra, and there was a disciple named Timothy, the son of a Jewish woman who was a believer, but his father was Greek.
44:16:2/He was well spoken of by the believers in Lystra and Iconium.
44:16:3/Paul wanted Timothy to join him on his journey, so he circumcised him because of the Jewish people in those areas, who all knew that his father was Greek.
44:16:4/As they traveled from city to city, they shared the decisions made by the apostles and elders in Jerusalem for the people to follow.
44:16:5/And so, the churches were strengthened in their faith and grew in numbers every day.
44:16:6/After traveling through Phrygia and Galatia, they were prevented by the Holy Spirit from preaching the word in Asia.
44:16:7/When they reached Mysia, they tried to enter Bithynia, but the Spirit did not allow them.
44:16:8/So, bypassing Mysia, they went down to Troas.
44:16:9/That night, Paul had a vision of a man from Macedonia begging him, "Come over to Macedonia and help us."
44:16:10/After seeing the vision, we immediately tried to go to Macedonia, concluding that God had called us to preach the gospel to them.
44:16:11/Setting sail from Troas, we made a direct voyage to Samothrace, and the next day to Neapolis,
44:16:12/and from there to Philippi, a leading city of that part of Macedonia and a Roman colony. We stayed in this city for several days.
44:16:13/On the Sabbath, we went outside the city gate to the river, where we expected to find a place of prayer. We sat down and began speaking to the women who had gathered there.
44:16:14/One of the women listening was named Lydia, a dealer in purple cloth from the city of Thyatira, who worshiped God. The Lord opened her heart to pay attention to what Paul was saying.
44:16:15/After she and her household were baptized, she urged us, "If you consider me a believer in the Lord, come and stay at my house." And she persuaded us.
44:16:16/As we were going to the place of prayer, we were met by a slave girl who had a spirit of divination and brought her owners a lot of profit by fortune-telling.
44:16:17/She followed Paul and us, shouting, "These men are servants of the Most High God, who are telling you the way to be saved."
44:16:18/She kept doing this for many days. Finally, Paul became so annoyed that he turned around and said to the spirit, "In the name of Jesus Christ, I command you to come out of her!" And it came out at that very moment.
44:16:19/When her owners realized that their hope of making money was gone, they seized Paul and Silas and dragged them into the marketplace to face the authorities,
44:16:20/and they brought them before the magistrates, saying, "These men are Jews, and are causing trouble in our city,
44:16:21/and are advocating customs unlawful for us Romans to accept or practice."
44:16:22/The crowd joined in the attack against them, and the magistrates ordered them to be stripped and beaten with rods.
44:16:23/After they had been severely flogged, they were thrown into prison, and the jailer was commanded to guard them carefully.
44:16:24/Upon receiving such orders, he put them in the inner cell and fastened their feet in the stocks.
44:16:25/About midnight, Paul and Silas were praying and singing hymns to God, and the other prisoners were listening to them.
44:16:26/Suddenly there was such a violent earthquake that the foundations of the prison were shaken. At once all the prison doors flew open, and everyone's chains came loose.
44:16:27/The jailer woke up, and when he saw the prison doors open, he drew his sword and was about to kill himself because he thought the prisoners had escaped.
44:16:28/But Paul shouted, "Don't harm yourself! We are all here!"
44:16:29/The jailer called for lights, rushed in and fell trembling before Paul and Silas.
44:16:30/He then brought them out and asked, "Sirs, what must I do to be saved?"
44:16:31/They replied, "Believe in the Lord Jesus, and you will be saved—you and your household."
44:16:32/Then they spoke the word of the Lord to him and to all the others in his house.
44:16:33/At that hour of the night, the jailer took them and washed their wounds; then immediately he and all his household were baptized.
44:16:34/The jailer brought them into his house and set a meal before them; he was filled with joy because he had come to believe in God—he and his whole household.
44:16:35/When it was daylight, the magistrates sent their officers to the jailer with the order: "Release those men."
44:16:36/The jailer told Paul, "The magistrates have ordered that you and Silas be released. Now you can leave. Go in peace."
44:16:37/But Paul said to the officers: "They beat us publicly without a trial, even though we are Roman citizens, and threw us into prison. And now do they want to get rid of us quietly? No! Let them come themselves and escort us out."
44:16:38/The officers reported this to the magistrates, and they were afraid when they heard that Paul and Silas were Roman citizens.
44:16:39/So they came to appease them and escorted them from the prison, requesting them to leave the city.
44:16:40/After leaving the prison, they went to Lydia’s house, where they saw and encouraged the brothers and sisters, then they left.
44:17:1/After traveling through Amphipolis and Apollonia, they arrived in Thessalonica, where there was a Jewish synagogue.
44:17:2/Paul, as was his custom, went to them, and for three Sabbath days engaged in discussions with them, using the scriptures,
44:17:3/Explaining and proving that the Messiah had to suffer and rise from the dead; and that this Jesus, whom I proclaim to you, is the Messiah.
44:17:4/Some of them were convinced and joined Paul and Silas, including a large number of God-fearing Greeks and quite a few prominent women.
44:17:5/But the Jews who were not persuaded became jealous and gathered some troublemakers from the marketplace to form a mob and start a riot in the city. They attacked Jason's house in search of Paul and Silas, to bring them out to the crowd.
44:17:6/Not finding them, they dragged Jason and some other believers before the city officials, shouting, "These men who have caused trouble all over the world have now come here,
44:17:7/and Jason has welcomed them into his house. They all defy Caesar's decrees, saying that there is another king, Jesus."
44:17:8/This caused a disturbance among the people and the city officials who heard this.
44:17:9/After securing bail from Jason and the others, they let them go.
44:17:10/That very night, the believers sent Paul and Silas away to Berea. Upon arriving, they went into the Jewish synagogue.
44:17:11/The Bereans were more open-minded than those in Thessalonica, eagerly accepting the message and examining the scriptures every day to see if what Paul said was true.
44:17:12/As a result, many of them believed, including a number of prominent Greek women and many Greek men.
44:17:13/But when the Jews in Thessalonica learned that Paul was preaching the word of God in Berea, they went there too, agitating and stirring up the crowds.
44:17:14/At once, the believers sent Paul to the coast, while Silas and Timothy stayed behind.
44:17:15/Those escorting Paul brought him to Athens and then left with instructions for Silas and Timothy to join him as soon as possible.
44:17:16/While Paul was waiting for them in Athens, he was greatly distressed to see that the city was full of idols.
44:17:17/So he debated in the synagogue with the Jews and the God-fearing Greeks, as well as in the marketplace day by day with those who happened to be there.
44:17:18/Some Epicurean and Stoic philosophers began to debate with him. Some of them asked, "What is this babbler trying to say?" Others remarked, "He seems to be advocating foreign gods," because he was preaching the good news about Jesus and the resurrection.
44:17:19/They took him and brought him to a meeting of the Areopagus, where they said, "Can we know what this new teaching is that you are presenting?
44:17:20/You are bringing some strange ideas to our ears, and we would like to know what they mean."
44:17:21/(All the Athenians and the foreigners living there spent their time doing nothing but talking about and listening to the latest ideas.)
44:17:22/Then Paul stood up in the meeting of the Areopagus and said: "People of Athens! I see that in every way you are very religious.
44:17:23/As I walked around and looked carefully at your objects of worship, I even found an altar with this inscription: TO AN UNKNOWN GOD. So what you worship as something unknown, I am going to proclaim to you.
44:17:24/The God who made the world and everything in it is the Lord of heaven and earth and does not live in temples built by hands.
44:17:25/And he is not served by human hands, as if he needed anything. Rather, he himself gives everyone life and breath and everything else.
44:17:26/From one man he made all the nations, that they should inhabit the whole earth; and he marked out their appointed times in history and the boundaries of their lands.
44:17:27/God did this so that they would seek him and perhaps reach out for him and find him, though he is not far from any one of us.
44:17:28/'For in him we live and move and have our being.' As some of your own poets have said, 'We are his offspring.'
44:17:29/Therefore, since we are God's offspring, we should not think that the divine being is like gold or silver or stone—an image made by human design and skill.
44:17:30/In the past, God overlooked such ignorance, but now he commands all people everywhere to repent.
44:17:31/For he has set a day when he will judge the world with justice by the man he has appointed. He has given proof of this to everyone by raising him from the dead."
44:17:32/When they heard about the resurrection of the dead, some of them sneered, but others said, "We want to hear you again on this subject."
44:17:33/So Paul left the council.
44:17:34/Some people joined him and believed, including Dionysius, a member of the Areopagus, also a woman named Damaris, and others with them.
44:18:1/After these events, Paul left Athens and went to Corinth;
44:18:2/And met a Jew named Aquila, originally from Pontus, who had recently arrived from Italy with his wife Priscilla; (because Claudius had ordered all Jews to leave Rome:) and he joined them.
44:18:3/Since he shared the same profession, he stayed with them and worked together, as they were tentmakers by trade.
44:18:4/He engaged in discussions in the synagogue every Sabbath, convincing both Jews and Greeks.
44:18:5/When Silas and Timothy arrived from Macedonia, Paul felt compelled by the Spirit and declared to the Jews that Jesus was the Messiah.
44:18:6/But when they resisted and insulted him, he shook out his clothes in protest and said to them, "Your blood be on your own heads; I am innocent. From now on I will go to the Gentiles."
44:18:7/He then moved on and stayed at the home of a man named Justus, a worshipper of God, whose house was next to the synagogue.
44:18:8/Crispus, the synagogue leader, and his entire household believed in the Lord; and many Corinthians who heard Paul believed and were baptized.
44:18:9/One night, the Lord said to Paul in a vision, "Do not be afraid, but keep on speaking and do not be silent.
44:18:10/For I am with you, and no one will attack you to harm you; for I have many people in this city."
44:18:11/And he stayed there for a year and a half, teaching them the word of God.
44:18:12/While Gallio was proconsul of Achaia, the Jews united against Paul and brought him before the tribunal,
44:18:13/Claiming, "This man is persuading people to worship God in ways contrary to the law."
44:18:14/Just as Paul was about to speak, Gallio said to the Jews, "If this were a matter of wrongdoing or serious crime, O Jews, it would be reasonable for me to listen to you.
44:18:15/But since it involves questions about words and names and your own law, deal with it yourselves. I refuse to be a judge of these matters."
44:18:16/And he dismissed them from the tribunal.
44:18:17/Then all the Greeks seized Sosthenes, the synagogue leader, and beat him in front of the tribunal. But Gallio showed no concern for any of this.
44:18:18/Paul stayed on for a while longer, then said goodbye to the brothers and sisters and sailed for Syria, accompanied by Priscilla and Aquila. He had his hair cut off at Cenchrea because of a vow he had taken.
44:18:19/Upon arriving in Ephesus, he left them there, but he himself went into the synagogue and engaged in discussion with the Jews.
44:18:20/When they asked him to stay longer, he declined.
44:18:21/But he left them with a promise, "I will come back to you if it's God's will." Then he set sail from Ephesus.
44:18:22/When he landed at Caesarea, he went up to greet the church and then went down to Antioch.
44:18:23/After spending some time there, he left and traveled systematically through the region of Galatia and Phrygia, strengthening all the disciples.
44:18:24/A Jew named Apollos, from Alexandria, an eloquent speaker and well-versed in the Scriptures, arrived in Ephesus.
44:18:25/He had been instructed in the way of the Lord; and being passionate in spirit, he spoke and taught accurately about Jesus, though he knew only the baptism of John.
44:18:26/He began to speak boldly in the synagogue. When Aquila and Priscilla heard him, they took him aside and explained to him the way of God more accurately.
44:18:27/When he wanted to go to Achaia, the brothers and sisters encouraged him and wrote to the disciples there to welcome him. Upon arriving, he was a great help to those who by grace had believed.
44:18:28/For he vigorously refuted the Jews in public debate, proving from the Scriptures that Jesus was the Messiah.
44:19:1/It happened that while Apollos was in Corinth, Paul traveled through the upper regions and arrived at Ephesus, where he found some disciples.
44:19:2/He asked them, "Did you receive the Holy Spirit when you believed?" They replied, "We haven't even heard that there is a Holy Spirit."
44:19:3/So he asked, "Then what baptism did you receive?" They answered, "John's baptism."
44:19:4/Paul explained, "John's baptism was a baptism of repentance. He told the people to believe in the one coming after him, that is, in Jesus."
44:19:5/Upon hearing this, they were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.
44:19:6/When Paul placed his hands on them, the Holy Spirit came on them, and they spoke in tongues and prophesied.
44:19:7/There were about twelve men in all.
44:19:8/Paul entered the synagogue and spoke boldly there for three months, arguing persuasively about the kingdom of God.
44:19:9/But some of them became obstinate; they refused to believe and publicly maligned the Way. So Paul left them. He took the disciples with him and had discussions daily in the lecture hall of Tyrannus.
44:19:10/This went on for two years, so that all the residents of Asia, both Jews and Greeks, heard the word of the Lord.
44:19:11/God did extraordinary miracles through Paul,
44:19:12/so that even handkerchiefs and aprons that had touched him were taken to the sick, and their illnesses were cured and the evil spirits left them.
44:19:13/Some Jews who went around driving out evil spirits tried to invoke the name of the Lord Jesus over those who were demon-possessed. They would say, "In the name of Jesus, whom Paul preaches, I command you to come out."
44:19:14/Seven sons of Sceva, a Jewish chief priest, were doing this.
44:19:15/But one day the evil spirit answered them, "Jesus I recognize, and I know about Paul, but who are you?"
44:19:16/Then the man who had the evil spirit jumped on them and overpowered them all. He gave them such a beating that they ran out of the house naked and bleeding.
44:19:17/When this became known to the Jews and Greeks living in Ephesus, they were all seized with fear, and the name of the Lord Jesus was held in high honor.
44:19:18/Many of those who believed now came and openly confessed what they had done.
44:19:19/A number who had practiced sorcery brought their scrolls together and burned them publicly. When they calculated the value of the scrolls, the total came to fifty thousand pieces of silver.
44:19:20/In this way the word of the Lord spread widely and grew in power.
44:19:21/After all this had happened, Paul decided to go to Jerusalem, passing through Macedonia and Achaia. "After I have been there," he said, "I must visit Rome also."
44:19:22/He sent two of his helpers, Timothy and Erastus, to Macedonia, while he stayed in the province of Asia a little longer.
44:19:23/About that time there arose a great disturbance about the Way.
44:19:24/A silversmith named Demetrius, who made silver shrines of Artemis, brought in a lot of business for the craftsmen there.
44:19:25/He called them together, along with the workers in related trades, and said: "You know, gentlemen, that we earn a good income from this business.
44:19:26/And you see and hear how this fellow Paul has convinced and led astray large numbers of people here in Ephesus and in practically the whole province of Asia. He says that gods made by human hands are no gods at all.
44:19:27/There is danger not only that our trade will lose its good name, but also that the temple of the great goddess Artemis will be discredited, and the goddess herself, who is worshiped throughout the province of Asia and the world, will be robbed of her divine majesty."
44:19:28/When they heard this, they were furious and began shouting: "Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!"
44:19:29/Soon the whole city was in an uproar. The people seized Gaius and Aristarchus, Paul's traveling companions from Macedonia, and all of them rushed into the theater together.
44:19:30/Paul wanted to appear before the crowd, but the disciples would not let him.
44:19:31/Even some of the officials of the province, friends of Paul, sent him a message begging him not to venture into the theater.
44:19:32/The assembly was in confusion: Some were shouting one thing, some another. Most of the people did not even know why they were there.
44:19:33/The Jews pushed Alexander to the front, and he motioned for silence in order to make a defense before the people.
44:19:34/But when they realized he was a Jew, they all shouted in unison for about two hours: "Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!"
44:19:35/The city clerk quieted the crowd and said: "Fellow Ephesians, doesn't everyone know that the city of Ephesus is the guardian of the temple of the great Artemis and of her image, which fell from heaven?
44:19:36/Since these facts are undeniable, you ought to calm down and not do anything rash.
44:19:37/You have brought these men here, though they have neither robbed temples nor blasphemed our goddess.
44:19:38/If then, Demetrius and his fellow craftsmen have a grievance against anybody, the courts are open and there are proconsuls. They can press charges.
44:19:39/If there is anything further you want to bring up, it must be settled in a legal assembly.
44:19:40/As it is, we are in danger of being charged with rioting because of today's events. In that case we would not be able to account for this commotion, since there is no reason for it."
44:19:41/After he had said this, he dismissed the assembly.
44:20:1/After the commotion had settled, Paul gathered the disciples, hugged them, and set off for Macedonia.
44:20:2/Traveling through those regions and offering a lot of encouragement, he arrived in Greece,
44:20:3/Where he stayed for three months. When the Jews plotted against him as he was about to sail to Syria, he decided to return through Macedonia.
44:20:4/Joining him on the journey to Asia were Sopater from Berea; Aristarchus and Secundus from Thessalonica; Gaius from Derbe; Timothy; and Tychicus and Trophimus from Asia.
44:20:5/These men went ahead and waited for us at Troas.
44:20:6/We left Philippi after the Festival of Unleavened Bread and met them in Troas five days later, where we stayed for a week.
44:20:7/On the first day of the week, when we gathered to break bread, Paul spoke to the group, intending to leave the next day, and he kept talking until midnight.
44:20:8/The room upstairs where we were meeting was brightly lit with many lamps.
44:20:9/A young man named Eutychus, sitting in a window, fell into a deep sleep while Paul was speaking. Overcome by sleep, he fell from the third story and was picked up dead.
44:20:10/Paul went down, threw his arms around him, and said, "Don't be alarmed; he's alive!"
44:20:11/After going back upstairs, breaking bread, and eating, Paul talked a long while, until dawn, and then left.
44:20:12/They brought the young man back alive and were greatly comforted.
44:20:13/We went ahead to the ship and sailed for Assos, planning to pick up Paul there. That was his arrangement since he intended to go on foot.
44:20:14/When he met us at Assos, we took him aboard and went to Mitylene.
44:20:15/We sailed from there and arrived opposite Chios the next day. The following day we crossed to Samos, and the day after that we arrived at Miletus.
44:20:16/Paul had decided to sail past Ephesus to avoid spending time in Asia. He was in a hurry to reach Jerusalem, if possible, by the day of Pentecost.
44:20:17/From Miletus, he sent a message to Ephesus, calling for the elders of the church.
44:20:18/When they arrived, he said to them, "You know how I lived among you from the first day I arrived in Asia,
44:20:19/Serving the Lord with all humility, through tears and trials that came to me because of the Jews' plots.
44:20:20/I didn't hold back anything that was beneficial to you. I taught you publicly and from house to house,
44:20:21/Emphasizing repentance toward God and faith in our Lord Jesus Christ to both Jews and Greeks.
44:20:22/And now, compelled by the Spirit, I'm going to Jerusalem, not knowing what will happen to me there,
44:20:23/Except that the Holy Spirit warns me in every city that imprisonment and hardships are waiting for me.
44:20:24/But I consider my life worth nothing to me; my only aim is to finish the race and complete the task the Lord Jesus has given me—the task of testifying to the good news of God's grace.
44:20:25/And now, I know that none of you among whom I have gone about preaching the kingdom will ever see my face again.
44:20:26/Therefore, I declare to you today that I am innocent of the blood of all people.
44:20:27/For I haven't hesitated to proclaim to you the whole will of God.
44:20:28/So be on your guard! Remember that for three years I never stopped warning each of you night and day with tears.
44:20:29/I know that after I leave, savage wolves will come in among you and will not spare the flock.
44:20:30/Even from your own number, men will arise and distort the truth to draw away disciples after them.
44:20:31/So be alert and remember that for three years I never stopped warning each of you night and day with tears.
44:20:32/Now I commit you to God and to the message of his grace, which can build you up and give you an inheritance among all those who are sanctified.
44:20:33/I have not coveted anyone's silver or gold or clothing.
44:20:34/You yourselves know that these hands of mine have supplied my own needs and the needs of my companions.
44:20:35/In everything I did, I showed you that by this kind of hard work we must help the weak, remembering the words the Lord Jesus himself said: 'It is more blessed to give than to receive.'"
44:20:36/After he said this, he knelt down with all of them and prayed.
44:20:37/They all wept openly and hugged Paul,
44:20:38/Grieving most of all because of his statement that they would never see his face again. Then they escorted him to the ship.
44:21:1/After we left them and set sail, we went directly to Coos, then to Rhodes the next day, and from there to Patara.
44:21:2/Finding a ship crossing over to Phoenicia, we boarded and set off.
44:21:3/When we spotted Cyprus, we left it on our left side and sailed to Syria, landing at Tyre because the ship needed to unload its cargo there.
44:21:4/We found some disciples and stayed with them for seven days. They, through the Spirit, advised Paul not to go to Jerusalem.
44:21:5/After spending those days, we left and continued on our journey; everyone, including wives and children, escorted us out of the city. We knelt down on the shore and prayed.
44:21:6/After saying goodbye to each other, we boarded the ship, and they went back home.
44:21:7/Completing our voyage from Tyre, we arrived at Ptolemais, greeted the brothers and sisters, and stayed with them for one day.
44:21:8/The next day, Paul's group and I left and went to Caesarea. We entered the house of Philip the evangelist, one of the seven, and stayed with him.
44:21:9/This man had four daughters who were virgins and had the gift of prophecy.
44:21:10/While we were staying there for several days, a prophet named Agabus came down from Judea.
44:21:11/When he arrived, he took Paul's belt, tied his own hands and feet, and said, "The Holy Spirit says, 'This is how the Jews in Jerusalem will bind the owner of this belt and hand him over to the Gentiles.'"
44:21:12/When we heard this, we and the local believers begged Paul not to go up to Jerusalem.
44:21:13/Paul responded, "Why are you crying and breaking my heart? I'm not only prepared to be bound but also to die in Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus."
44:21:14/When he wouldn't be convinced, we gave up and said, "Let the Lord's will be done."
44:21:15/After those days, we got ready and went up to Jerusalem.
44:21:16/Some disciples from Caesarea also went with us, bringing Mnason of Cyprus, an early disciple, with whom we were to stay.
44:21:17/Upon our arrival in Jerusalem, the brothers and sisters welcomed us warmly.
44:21:18/The next day, Paul and we went to see James, and all the elders were present.
44:21:19/After greeting them, Paul detailed what God had done among the Gentiles through his ministry.
44:21:20/When they heard it, they praised God and said to him, "You see, brother, how many thousands of Jews have believed, and they are all zealous for the law.
44:21:21/They have been informed about you—that you teach all the Jews living among the Gentiles to abandon Moses, telling them not to circumcise their children or follow our customs.
44:21:22/What should we do? They will definitely hear that you've come.
44:21:23/So do what we tell you: We have four men who have taken a vow.
44:21:24/Take these men, join in their purification rites, and pay their expenses so they can shave their heads. Then everyone will know there is no truth in these reports about you, but that you yourself are living in obedience to the law.
44:21:25/As for the Gentile believers, we have already written to them our decision that they should abstain from food sacrificed to idols, from blood, from the meat of strangled animals, and from sexual immorality."
44:21:26/Then Paul took the men, and the next day, he purified himself along with them and went into the temple to give notice of the completion of the purification days, until the offering was made for each of them.
44:21:27/When the seven days were nearly over, some Jews from Asia saw Paul in the temple, stirred up the whole crowd, and seized him,
44:21:28/Shouting, "Fellow Israelites, help! This is the man who teaches everyone everywhere against our people, our law, and this place. He has even brought Greeks into the temple and defiled this holy place."
44:21:29/(They had previously seen Trophimus the Ephesian with him in the city and assumed that Paul had brought him into the temple.)
44:21:30/The whole city was in an uproar, and the people came running from all directions. They seized Paul and dragged him out of the temple, and immediately the gates were shut.
44:21:31/While they were trying to kill him, news reached the commander of the Roman troops that all Jerusalem was in chaos.
44:21:32/He immediately took some officers and soldiers and ran down to the crowd. When they saw the commander and his soldiers, they stopped beating Paul.
44:21:33/The commander came up, arrested Paul, and ordered him to be bound with two chains. He then asked who he was and what he had done.
44:21:34/Some in the crowd shouted one thing, some another, and because of the uproar, the commander couldn't get the facts, so he ordered Paul to be taken into the barracks.
44:21:35/As Paul reached the steps, he had to be carried by the soldiers because of the violence of the crowd,
44:21:36/For the mob of people followed, shouting, "Get rid of him!"
44:21:37/As Paul was about to be taken into the barracks, he asked the commander, "May I say something to you?" The commander replied, "Do you speak Greek?
44:21:38/Aren't you the Egyptian who started a revolt some time ago and led four thousand terrorists out into the desert?"
44:21:39/But Paul said, "I am a Jew from Tarsus in Cilicia, a citizen of no ordinary city. Please let me speak to the people."
44:21:40/With the commander's permission, Paul stood on the steps and motioned to the people. When they were all silent, he spoke to them in Aramaic, saying,
44:22:1/Men, brothers, and fathers, listen to my defense that I now present to you.
44:22:2/(And when they realized he was speaking to them in Hebrew, they became even more silent: and he said,)
44:22:3/I am truly a man who is a Jew, born in Tarsus, a city in Cilicia, but raised in this city under the tutelage of Gamaliel, educated in the strict tradition of our ancestors' law, and fervent for God, just as all of you are today.
44:22:4/And I aggressively persecuted this movement to the point of death, arresting and imprisoning both men and women.
44:22:5/As the high priest and all the council of elders can attest, from whom I also received letters to the brothers, and went to Damascus to bring those who were there in chains back to Jerusalem to be punished.
44:22:6/And as I was on my way, approaching Damascus around noon, suddenly a great light from heaven shone around me.
44:22:7/And I fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to me, 'Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?'
44:22:8/And I replied, 'Who are you, Lord?' And he said to me, 'I am Jesus of Nazareth, whom you are persecuting.'
44:22:9/And those who were with me saw the light for sure and were terrified, but they did not hear the voice of the one who spoke to me.
44:22:10/And I asked, 'What should I do, LORD?' And the Lord told me, 'Get up and go into Damascus, and there you will be told about everything you are destined to do.'
44:22:11/And because I couldn't see due to the brilliance of that light, I was led by the hand by those who were with me, and I arrived in Damascus.
44:22:12/And a man named Ananias, devout according to the law and well spoken of by all the Jews living there,
44:22:13/Came to me, stood by me, and said, 'Brother Saul, regain your sight.' And at that very moment, I looked up at him.
44:22:14/And he said, 'The God of our ancestors has chosen you to know his will, to see the Righteous One, and to hear words from his mouth.
44:22:15/For you will be his witness to everyone about what you have seen and heard.
44:22:16/And now, why delay? Get up, be baptized, and wash away your sins, calling on his name.'
44:22:17/And it happened that, when I returned to Jerusalem and was praying in the temple, I fell into a trance;
44:22:18/And saw him telling me, 'Hurry and leave Jerusalem quickly, because they will not accept your testimony about me.'
44:22:19/And I said, 'Lord, they know that I imprisoned and beat those who believed in you in every synagogue;
44:22:20/And when the blood of your martyr Stephen was being shed, I was also there, approving of his death, and guarding the clothes of those who were killing him.'
44:22:21/And he said to me, 'Go, for I will send you far away to the Gentiles.'
44:22:22/And they listened to him up to this point, and then they raised their voices, saying, 'Get rid of such a person from the earth; it's not right for him to live.'
44:22:23/And as they were shouting, throwing off their cloaks, and tossing dust into the air,
44:22:24/The commander ordered him to be brought into the barracks and directed that he be interrogated under whipping, to find out why they were shouting against him like this.
44:22:25/And as they tied him up with straps, Paul said to the centurion standing there, 'Is it legal for you to whip a Roman citizen who hasn't been convicted?'
44:22:26/When the centurion heard this, he went and reported to the commander, saying, 'Be careful what you do, for this man is a Roman citizen.'
44:22:27/Then the commander came and asked him, 'Tell me, are you a Roman citizen?' He said, 'Yes.'
44:22:28/And the commander replied, 'I acquired this citizenship with a large sum of money.' And Paul said, 'But I was born a citizen.'
44:22:29/Immediately, those who were about to interrogate him withdrew, and the commander was also afraid after realizing that he was a Roman citizen and because he had bound him.
44:22:30/The next day, wanting to know the exact reason why he was being accused by the Jews, he released him from his chains and ordered the chief priests and all the Sanhedrin to convene, and he brought Paul down and set him before them.
44:23:1/Paul, looking intently at the council, said, "Fellow men, I have lived with a clear conscience before God up to this day."
44:23:2/Then the high priest Ananias ordered those standing near him to hit him on the mouth.
44:23:3/Paul then said to him, "God will strike you, you whitewashed wall! You sit there to judge me according to the law, yet you violate the law by ordering me to be struck!"
44:23:4/Those standing nearby asked, "Are you insulting God’s high priest?"
44:23:5/Paul replied, "I didn't realize, brothers, that he was the high priest; for it is written, 'You must not speak evil of the leader of your people.'"
44:23:6/But noticing that one group were Sadducees and the other Pharisees, Paul shouted in the council, "Fellow men, I am a Pharisee, a son of Pharisees. I am on trial because of my hope in the resurrection of the dead."
44:23:7/When he said this, a dispute broke out between the Pharisees and the Sadducees, and the assembly was divided.
44:23:8/For the Sadducees say there is no resurrection, nor angel, nor spirit, but the Pharisees acknowledge all these.
44:23:9/Then a loud outcry ensued, and some of the scribes from the Pharisees' side stood up and argued, "We find nothing wrong with this man. What if a spirit or an angel has spoken to him?"
44:23:10/As the dispute became more violent, the commander was afraid Paul might be torn apart by them, so he ordered the troops to go down, take him by force, and bring him into the barracks.
44:23:11/The following night the Lord stood near Paul and said, "Take courage, Paul. Just as you have testified about me in Jerusalem, you must also testify in Rome."
44:23:12/When daylight came, some Jews formed a conspiracy and bound themselves with an oath not to eat or drink until they had killed Paul.
44:23:13/There were more than forty who formed this plot.
44:23:14/They went to the chief priests and elders and said, "We have bound ourselves with a solemn oath not to eat anything until we have killed Paul."
44:23:15/Now then, you and the council must inform the commander to bring Paul down to you tomorrow, as if you were going to examine his case more thoroughly. But before he gets here, we are ready to kill him."
44:23:16/When Paul’s nephew heard about the ambush, he went into the barracks and told Paul.
44:23:17/Paul called one of the centurions and said, "Take this young man to the commander; he has something to tell him."
44:23:18/So he took him to the commander and said, "The prisoner Paul called me and asked me to bring this young man to you because he has something to tell you."
44:23:19/The commander took him by the hand, stepped aside, and asked privately, "What is it that you have to tell me?"
44:23:20/He said, "The Jews have agreed to ask you to bring Paul down to the council tomorrow, pretending they want to inquire more thoroughly about him."
44:23:21/But don't give in to them, because more than forty of them are waiting in ambush for him. They have sworn not to eat or drink until they have killed him, and they are ready now, waiting for your consent."
44:23:22/The commander then let the young man go, instructing him, "Don’t tell anyone that you have reported this to me."
44:23:23/He called two of his centurions and ordered, "Get ready 200 soldiers, 70 horsemen, and 200 spearmen to go to Caesarea at nine tonight."
44:23:24/"Also provide mounts for Paul to ride and ensure his safe arrival to Governor Felix."
44:23:25/And he wrote a letter as follows:
44:23:26/Claudius Lysias to the most excellent Governor Felix, greetings.
44:23:27/This man was seized by the Jews and was about to be killed by them when I arrived with the troops and rescued him, having learned that he is a Roman citizen.
44:23:28/And wanting to know why they were accusing him, I brought him to their council.
44:23:29/I found that he was accused concerning questions of their law, but was not charged with anything deserving death or imprisonment.
44:23:30/When I was informed of a plot against the man, I sent him to you at once, ordering his accusers also to state their case against him before you. Farewell.
44:23:31/Then the soldiers, following their orders, took Paul and brought him by night to Antipatris.
44:23:32/The next day they let the horsemen go on with him, while they returned to the barracks.
44:23:33/When they arrived at Caesarea and delivered the letter to the governor, they also presented Paul before him.
44:23:34/After reading the letter, the governor asked which province he was from. Learning that he was from Cilicia,
44:23:35/he said, "I will hear your case when your accusers arrive." And he ordered Paul to be kept under guard in Herod’s Praetorium.
44:24:1/And after five days Ananias the high priest arrived with the elders, and a certain speaker named Tertullus, who presented their case against Paul to the governor.
44:24:2/And when he was summoned, Tertullus began to accuse him, saying, "Thanks to you, we enjoy great peace, and your leadership has brought significant benefits to our nation,
44:24:3/We always welcome this, in every place, most noble Felix, with deep gratitude.
44:24:4/However, to avoid taking up too much of your time, I request that you kindly listen to us briefly out of your goodwill.
44:24:5/For we have discovered this man to be a troublemaker, stirring up riots among Jews all over the world, and he's a leading figure in the sect of the Nazarenes:
44:24:6/He even tried to desecrate the temple; we arrested him and wanted to judge him by our law.
44:24:7/But commander Lysias came, forcefully took him from us,
44:24:8/And ordered his accusers to come to you: by examining him yourself, you can verify all these accusations we bring against him.
44:24:9/And the Jews also agreed, affirming that these things were true.
44:24:10/Then Paul, after the governor signaled for him to speak, responded, "Knowing that you have been a judge over this nation for many years, I gladly make my defense:
44:24:11/Because you can verify that it has only been twelve days since I went up to Jerusalem to worship.
44:24:12/And they did not find me arguing with anyone in the temple, nor inciting a crowd, neither in the synagogues nor anywhere in the city:
44:24:13/Nor can they prove the charges they now bring against me.
44:24:14/But I do admit to you that I worship the God of my ancestors according to the way they call a sect, believing everything laid down by the law and written in the prophets:
44:24:15/And I have hope in God, which they themselves also accept, that there will be a resurrection of both the righteous and the wicked.
44:24:16/In this belief, I strive to always maintain a clear conscience before God and people.
44:24:17/Now after many years, I returned to bring gifts for my people and to offer sacrifices.
44:24:18/While I was doing this, some Jews from Asia found me in the temple, cleansed, without any crowd or disturbance.
44:24:19/They should have been here before you to make their accusations if they had anything against me.
44:24:20/Or else, let these here present say if they found any wrongdoing in me while I stood before the council,
44:24:21/Except for this one statement I shouted while standing among them, 'It is concerning the resurrection of the dead that I am on trial before you today.'"
44:24:22/And when Felix heard these things, having a better understanding of the Way, he postponed the proceedings and said, "When commander Lysias comes down, I will decide your case."
44:24:23/He ordered a centurion to guard Paul but to allow him some freedom and not to prevent any of his friends from taking care of his needs.
44:24:24/And after a few days, when Felix came with his wife Drusilla, who was Jewish, he sent for Paul and listened to him speak about faith in Christ.
44:24:25/As Paul discussed righteousness, self-control, and the coming judgment, Felix became frightened and said, "You may leave for now; when I find the time, I will summon you."
44:24:26/He also hoped that Paul would offer him money for his release, which is why he sent for him frequently to talk.
44:24:27/But after two years, Porcius Festus succeeded Felix, and Felix, wanting to do the Jews a favor, left Paul in prison.
44:25:1/Now when Festus arrived in the province, he went up from Caesarea to Jerusalem three days later.
44:25:2/Then the high priest and the Jewish leaders presented their case against Paul to him, pleading for action,
44:25:3/They requested a favor against him, asking that he be summoned to Jerusalem, planning to ambush and kill him on the way.
44:25:4/But Festus replied that Paul would be kept in Caesarea, and that he himself would be going there soon.
44:25:5/"Therefore," he said, "let those among you who are capable, accompany me and present your accusations against him if there is any wrongdoing."
44:25:6/After spending more than ten days with them, he went down to Caesarea; the following day, he took his seat on the judgment bench and ordered that Paul be brought in.
44:25:7/When Paul arrived, the Jews who had come down from Jerusalem surrounded him, bringing numerous serious charges against him, which they couldn't substantiate.
44:25:8/Paul defended himself by saying, "I have not committed any offense against the Jewish law, the temple, or even against Caesar."
44:25:9/However, Festus, wanting to please the Jews, asked Paul, "Would you be willing to go up to Jerusalem and be tried on these charges before me there?"
44:25:10/Paul responded, "I am standing before Caesar's tribunal, where I should be judged. I have done no wrong to the Jews, as you very well know.
44:25:11/If I am guilty of anything deserving death, I do not refuse to die. But if there is nothing to their accusations, no one has the right to hand me over to them. I appeal to Caesar."
44:25:12/Then Festus, after discussing it with his council, replied, "You have appealed to Caesar? To Caesar you shall go."
44:25:13/Some days later, King Agrippa and Bernice arrived in Caesarea to pay their respects to Festus.
44:25:14/After they had been there for several days, Festus presented Paul's case to the king, saying, "There is a man left in prison by Felix:
44:25:15/About whom, when I was in Jerusalem, the chief priests and the elders of the Jews informed me, asking for a judgment against him.
44:25:16/I told them that it is not the Roman custom to hand over anyone before the accused meets the accusers face to face and has an opportunity to defend themselves against the charges.
44:25:17/So when they came here, without any delay, the next day I sat on the judgment seat and ordered the man to be brought in.
44:25:18/When the accusers stood up, they did not charge him with any of the crimes I had expected:
44:25:19/Instead, they had some disputes with him about their own religion and about a certain Jesus who had died, but whom Paul claimed was alive.
44:25:20/Because I was uncertain about how to investigate these matters, I asked if he would be willing to go to Jerusalem and be tried there on these issues.
44:25:21/But when Paul appealed to be held for the Emperor's decision, I ordered him to be kept in custody until I could send him to Caesar."
44:25:22/Then Agrippa said to Festus, "I would like to hear this man myself." "Tomorrow," Festus replied, "you will hear him."
44:25:23/The next day, Agrippa and Bernice arrived with great ceremony and entered the auditorium with the high-ranking military officers and prominent men of the city. At Festus's command, Paul was brought in.
44:25:24/And Festus said, "King Agrippa, and all who are present with us, you see this man whom the whole Jewish community has petitioned me about, both in Jerusalem and here, shouting that he should not be allowed to live any longer.
44:25:25/But I found he had done nothing deserving death, and since he himself has appealed to the Emperor, I decided to send him.
44:25:26/However, I have nothing definite to write to my lord about him. Therefore, I have brought him before all of you, and especially before you, King Agrippa, so that after this examination, I might have something to write.
44:25:27/For it seems unreasonable to me to send a prisoner without specifying the charges against him.
44:26:1/Then Agrippa said to Paul, "You may speak for yourself." So Paul stretched out his hand and began his defense:
44:26:2/"I consider myself fortunate, King Agrippa, to be able to present my case before you today regarding all the accusations the Jews have made against me.
44:26:3/Especially since I know you are well acquainted with all the Jewish customs and controversies. Therefore, I beg you to listen to me patiently.
44:26:4/All the Jews know how I have lived since my youth, spending my early years among my own people in Jerusalem.
44:26:5/They have known me for a long time and could testify, if they were willing, that I lived as a Pharisee, adhering strictly to our religion's most rigorous sect.
44:26:6/And now I am on trial because of my hope in the promise God made to our ancestors,
44:26:7/a promise our twelve tribes hope to see fulfilled as they earnestly serve God day and night. It is because of this hope, King Agrippa, that I am accused by the Jews.
44:26:8/Why should it be considered unbelievable by you that God raises the dead?
44:26:9/I once believed I should do everything in my power to oppose the name of Jesus of Nazareth.
44:26:10/And that is exactly what I did in Jerusalem. Authorized by the chief priests, I imprisoned many of the saints, and when they were executed, I cast my vote against them.
44:26:11/I frequently punished them in all the synagogues and tried to force them to blaspheme. Driven by extreme hostility towards them, I even pursued them to foreign cities.
44:26:12/On one such journey to Damascus, with the authority and commission of the chief priests,
44:26:13/at midday, O king, I saw a light from heaven, brighter than the sun, shining around me and my companions.
44:26:14/We all fell to the ground, and I heard a voice saying to me in Hebrew, 'Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me? It's hard for you to kick against the goads.'
44:26:15/I asked, 'Who are you, Lord?' And the Lord said, 'I am Jesus, whom you are persecuting.
44:26:16/But get up and stand on your feet. I have appeared to you for this purpose: to appoint you as a servant and witness of what you have seen and of what I will show you.
44:26:17/I will rescue you from your own people and from the Gentiles. I am sending you to them
44:26:18/to open their eyes and turn them from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan to God, so that they may receive forgiveness of sins and a place among those who are sanctified by faith in me.'
44:26:19/Therefore, King Agrippa, I was not disobedient to the heavenly vision.
44:26:20/Instead, I first proclaimed to those in Damascus, then in Jerusalem and throughout Judea, and also to the Gentiles, that they should repent and turn to God, performing deeds consistent with repentance.
44:26:21/For these reasons, the Jews seized me in the temple and tried to kill me.
44:26:22/But with God's help, I have stood firm to this day, testifying to both small and great, saying nothing beyond what the prophets and Moses said would happen:
44:26:23/that the Messiah would suffer and, as the first to rise from the dead, would bring light to our people and to the Gentiles."
44:26:24/As he made his defense, Festus exclaimed loudly, "Paul, you are out of your mind! Your great learning is driving you insane."
44:26:25/But Paul replied, "I am not insane, most excellent Festus. I am speaking the sober truth.
44:26:26/The king is familiar with these matters, and I can speak freely to him. I am convinced that none of this has escaped his notice, for it was not done in a corner.
44:26:27/King Agrippa, do you believe the prophets? I know you do."
44:26:28/Then Agrippa said to Paul, "You almost persuade me to become a Christian."
44:26:29/Paul replied, "I pray to God that not only you but all who are listening to me today may become what I am, except for these chains."
44:26:30/When he had finished speaking, the king stood up, as did the governor, Bernice, and those sitting with them.
44:26:31/After they left the room, they began saying to one another, "This man is not doing anything that deserves death or imprisonment."
44:26:32/Agrippa said to Festus, "This man could have been set free if he had not appealed to Caesar."
44:27:1/When it was decided that we should sail to Italy, Paul and some other prisoners were handed over to a centurion named Julius, who was part of Augustus' regiment.
44:27:2/Boarding a ship from Adramyttium, we set sail, planning to travel along the coasts of Asia; Aristarchus, a Macedonian from Thessalonica, was with us.
44:27:3/The next day we stopped at Sidon. Julius treated Paul kindly, allowing him to visit his friends and refresh himself.
44:27:4/After leaving there, we sailed under the shelter of Cyprus because the winds were against us.
44:27:5/After navigating the sea off Cilicia and Pamphylia, we arrived at Myra, a city in Lycia.
44:27:6/There, the centurion found a ship from Alexandria heading to Italy and put us on board.
44:27:7/After sailing slowly for many days and barely making it past Cnidus because the wind was against us, we sailed under the lee of Crete, opposite Salmone.
44:27:8/With difficulty, we sailed past it and arrived at a place called Fair Havens, near the city of Lasea.
44:27:9/After spending a lot of time there, and with sailing becoming dangerous because the Fast was already over, Paul warned them,
44:27:10/"Gentlemen, I can see that this voyage is going to end in disaster and heavy loss, not just of the cargo and the ship, but also of our lives."
44:27:11/However, the centurion trusted the ship's captain and owner more than what Paul said.
44:27:12/And because the harbor was not suitable to winter in, most decided to set sail from there, hoping somehow to reach Phoenix, a harbor in Crete facing southwest and northwest, to spend the winter.
44:27:13/When a gentle south wind began to blow, they thought they had achieved their goal, so they weighed anchor and sailed along the coast of Crete.
44:27:14/But not long after, a violent wind, called the Northeaster, struck.
44:27:15/When the ship was caught and could not face the wind, we gave up and let it be driven along.
44:27:16/Running under the shelter of a small island called Cauda, we had difficulty securing the ship's boat.
44:27:17/After hoisting it aboard, they used supports to reinforce the ship. Fearing they might run aground on the Syrtis Sands, they lowered the gear, and thus they were driven along.
44:27:18/As we were violently battered by the storm, the next day they began to throw the cargo overboard,
44:27:19/And on the third day, with our own hands, we threw the ship's gear overboard.
44:27:20/When neither sun nor stars appeared for many days and the storm continued raging, we finally gave up all hope of being saved.
44:27:21/After they had gone a long time without food, Paul stood up among them and said, "Men, you should have listened to me and not set sail from Crete; then you would have avoided this damage and loss.
44:27:22/But now I urge you to keep up your courage, because not one of you will be lost; only the ship will be destroyed.
44:27:23/For last night an angel of the God to whom I belong and whom I serve stood beside me,
44:27:24/And said, 'Do not be afraid, Paul. You must stand trial before Caesar; and God has graciously given you the lives of all who sail with you.'
44:27:25/So keep up your courage, men, for I have faith in God that it will happen just as he told me.
44:27:26/However, we must run aground on some island."
44:27:27/On the fourteenth night, as we were being driven across the Adriatic Sea, about midnight the sailors sensed they were approaching land.
44:27:28/They took soundings and found the water was twenty fathoms deep. A little later, they took soundings again and found it was fifteen fathoms deep.
44:27:29/Fearing we might crash into the rocks, they dropped four anchors from the stern and prayed for daylight.
44:27:30/In an attempt to escape from the ship, the sailors let down the lifeboat into the sea, pretending they were going to lower some anchors from the bow.
44:27:31/Paul said to the centurion and the soldiers, "Unless these men stay with the ship, you cannot be saved."
44:27:32/So the soldiers cut the ropes that held the lifeboat and let it drift away.
44:27:33/Just before dawn, Paul urged everyone to eat, saying, "Today is the fourteenth day you have been in suspense and without food, having eaten nothing.
44:27:34/So I urge you to take some food. It will help you survive. Not a hair of your head will be lost."
44:27:35/After he said this, he took some bread, gave thanks to God in front of them all, broke it, and began to eat.
44:27:36/They were all encouraged and ate some food themselves.
44:27:37/In all, there were 276 of us on the ship.
44:27:38/After they had eaten as much as they wanted, they lightened the ship by throwing the grain into the sea.
44:27:39/When daylight came, they did not recognize the land, but they saw a bay with a sandy beach, where they decided to run the ship aground if they could.
44:27:40/After cutting loose the anchors, they left them in the sea and at the same time untied the ropes that held the rudders. Then they hoisted the foresail to the wind and made for the beach.
44:27:41/But they struck a sandbar and ran the ship aground; the bow stuck fast and would not move, while the stern was broken to pieces by the pounding of the surf.
44:27:42/The soldiers planned to kill the prisoners to prevent any of them from swimming away and escaping.
44:27:43/But the centurion, wanting to save Paul, kept them from carrying out their plan. He ordered those who could swim to jump overboard first and get to land,
44:27:44/And the rest to get there on planks or on other pieces of the ship. In this way, everyone reached land safely.
44:28:1/After escaping, we realized the island was called Melita.
44:28:2/The local people showed us incredible kindness; they started a fire and welcomed all of us because it was raining and cold.
44:28:3/When Paul was gathering sticks and put them on the fire, a viper, driven out by the heat, bit his hand.
44:28:4/Seeing the snake hanging from his hand, the locals thought, "Surely this man is a murderer. Even though he survived the sea, divine justice won't let him live."
44:28:5/But Paul shook the snake off into the fire and wasn't hurt.
44:28:6/They expected him to swell up or suddenly drop dead, but after waiting a long time and seeing nothing happen to him, they changed their minds and said he was a god.
44:28:7/Nearby lived the leading man of the island, named Publius, who welcomed and hosted us warmly for three days.
44:28:8/Publius' father was sick with fever and dysentery. Paul visited him, prayed, laid his hands on him, and healed him.
44:28:9/After this, others on the island with diseases came and were healed.
44:28:10/They honored us greatly, and when we were ready to leave, they provided us with everything we needed.
44:28:11/Three months later, we set sail on a ship from Alexandria that had wintered on the island, marked by the figures of Castor and Pollux.
44:28:12/Arriving at Syracuse, we stayed there for three days.
44:28:13/Then we set sail again and reached Rhegium. The next day, a south wind carried us to Puteoli in a day.
44:28:14/There, we found fellow believers who asked us to stay with them for seven days. Then we headed towards Rome.
44:28:15/When the believers in Rome heard about us, they came to meet us as far as Appii Forum and The Three Taverns. Seeing them, Paul thanked God and was encouraged.
44:28:16/Upon our arrival in Rome, the centurion handed the prisoners over to the captain of the guard, but Paul was allowed to live by himself with a soldier guarding him.
44:28:17/Three days later, Paul called together the local Jewish leaders. He said to them, "Brothers, although I've done nothing against our people or the customs of our ancestors, I was arrested in Jerusalem and handed over to the Romans.
44:28:18/The Romans, after examining me, wanted to release me because there was no reason for me to be executed.
44:28:19/But when the Jews objected, I was forced to appeal to Caesar—not that I had any charge to bring against my own people.
44:28:20/That's why I've asked to see you and talk with you. It's because of the hope of Israel that I'm bound with this chain."
44:28:21/They replied, "We haven't received any letters from Judea about you, nor has anyone who's come reported or said anything bad about you.
44:28:22/But we want to hear what your views are, for we know that people everywhere are speaking against this sect."
44:28:23/They set a day to meet with him, and many came to his lodging. From morning till evening, he explained and testified about the kingdom of God, trying to convince them about Jesus through the Law of Moses and the Prophets.
44:28:24/Some were convinced by what he said, but others did not believe.
44:28:25/When they couldn't agree among themselves, they left after Paul had made one statement: "The Holy Spirit spoke the truth to your ancestors through Isaiah the prophet,
44:28:26/saying, 'Go to this people and say, "You will hear but never understand; you will see but never perceive."
44:28:27/For this people's heart has become calloused; they hardly hear with their ears, and they have closed their eyes. Otherwise, they might see with their eyes, hear with their ears, understand with their hearts, and turn, and I would heal them.'
44:28:28/So know this: God's salvation has been sent to the Gentiles, and they will listen."
44:28:29/After he said this, the Jews left, arguing vigorously among themselves.
44:28:30/Paul lived for two whole years in his own rented house, welcoming all who came to see him,
44:28:31/proclaiming the kingdom of God and teaching about the Lord Jesus Christ with all boldness and without hindrance.
45:1:1/Paul, a servant of Jesus Christ, called to be an apostle, set apart for the gospel of God,
45:1:2/(Which he had promised beforehand through his prophets in the holy scriptures,)
45:1:3/Regarding his Son Jesus Christ our Lord, who was born from the lineage of David according to the flesh;
45:1:4/And was proven to be the Son of God with power, in line with the spirit of holiness, through the resurrection from the dead:
45:1:5/Through whom we have received grace and the role of apostles, to promote obedience to the faith among all nations, for his name:
45:1:6/Among whom you also are the called of Jesus Christ:
45:1:7/To all in Rome, loved by God, called to be holy: Grace to you and peace from God our Father, and the Lord Jesus Christ.
45:1:8/First, I thank my God through Jesus Christ for all of you, because your faith is being talked about all over the world.
45:1:9/For God is my witness, whom I serve with my spirit in the gospel of his Son, that I constantly remember you in my prayers without fail;
45:1:10/Praying that, if it is God's will, I may at last succeed in coming to you.
45:1:11/For I long to see you, so that I may share with you some spiritual gift, so that you may be strengthened;
45:1:12/That is, that we may be mutually encouraged by each other's faith, both yours and mine.
45:1:13/I want you to know, brothers and sisters, that I have often planned to come to you (but have been prevented until now) in order to have some fruit among you, just as among the other Gentiles.
45:1:14/I am obligated both to Greeks and non-Greeks, both to the wise and the foolish.
45:1:15/So I am eager to preach the gospel to you who are in Rome as well.
45:1:16/For I am not ashamed of the gospel of Christ: for it is the power of God for salvation to everyone who believes; first to the Jew, and also to the Greek.
45:1:17/For in it the righteousness of God is revealed from faith to faith: as it is written, "The righteous shall live by faith."
45:1:18/For the wrath of God is revealed from heaven against all godlessness and wickedness of people, who suppress the truth by their wickedness;
45:1:19/Because what can be known about God is plain to them; for God has shown it to them.
