46:10:16/The cup of blessing that we bless, isn't it a sharing in the blood of Christ? The bread that we break, isn't it a sharing in the body of Christ?
46:10:17/Because there is one bread, we, who are many, are one body, for we all share the one bread.
46:10:18/Look at Israel according to the flesh: Are not those who eat the sacrifices participants in the altar?
46:10:19/What am I saying then? That an idol is anything, or that what is offered to idols is anything?
46:10:20/But I say that the things which the Gentiles sacrifice, they sacrifice to demons and not to God, and I do not want you to have fellowship with demons.
46:10:21/You cannot drink the cup of the Lord and the cup of demons; you cannot partake of the Lord’s table and of the table of demons.
46:10:22/Are we trying to provoke the Lord to jealousy? Are we stronger than He?
46:10:23/All things are permissible for me, but not all things are beneficial. All things are permissible for me, but not all things build up.
46:10:24/Let no one seek their own good, but the good of others.
46:10:25/Eat whatever is sold in the meat market without raising questions of conscience,
46:10:26/For the earth is the Lord's, and everything in it.
46:10:27/If an unbeliever invites you to a meal and you want to go, eat whatever is put before you without raising questions of conscience.
46:10:28/But if someone tells you, "This has been offered in sacrifice," then do not eat it, both for the sake of the one who told you and for the sake of conscience.
46:10:29/I am referring to the other person's conscience, not yours. For why should my freedom be judged by another's conscience?
46:10:30/If I partake with thankfulness, why am I denounced because of something I thank God for?
46:10:31/So whether you eat or drink or whatever you do, do it all for the glory of God.
46:10:32/Do not cause anyone to stumble, whether Jews, Greeks or the church of God—
46:10:33/Just as I try to please everyone in every way. Not seeking my own advantage, but that of many, so that they may be saved.
46:11:1/Follow my example, just as I follow Christ's.
46:11:2/I commend you for remembering me in everything and for holding on to the traditions just as I passed them on to you.
46:11:3/But I want you to understand that Christ is the head of every man, the man is the head of a woman, and God is the head of Christ.
46:11:4/Any man who prays or prophesies with his head covered dishonors his head.
46:11:5/But any woman who prays or prophesies with her head uncovered dishonors her head—it is the same as having her head shaved.
46:11:6/If a woman does not cover her head, she might as well have her hair cut off; but if it is disgraceful for a woman to have her hair cut off or her head shaved, then she should cover her head.
46:11:7/A man should not cover his head, since he is the image and glory of God; but woman is the glory of man.
46:11:8/For man did not come from woman, but woman from man.
46:11:9/Neither was man created for woman, but woman for man.
46:11:10/For this reason, a woman ought to have a symbol of authority on her head, because of the angels.
46:11:11/However, in the Lord, woman is not independent of man, nor is man independent of woman.
46:11:12/For as woman came from man, so also man is born of woman. But everything comes from God.
46:11:13/Judge for yourselves: Is it proper for a woman to pray to God with her head uncovered?
46:11:14/Doesn't nature itself teach you that if a man has long hair, it is a disgrace to him?
46:11:15/But if a woman has long hair, it is her glory? For long hair is given to her as a covering.
46:11:16/If anyone wants to be contentious about this, we have no other practice—nor do the churches of God.
46:11:17/But in the following instructions, I do not commend you, because when you come together it is not for the better but for the worse.
46:11:18/First of all, when you come together as a church, I hear that there are divisions among you, and to some extent I believe it.
46:11:19/Indeed, there have to be differences among you to show which of you have God's approval.
46:11:20/So then, when you come together, it is not the Lord's Supper you eat,
46:11:21/for when you are eating, some of you go ahead with your own private suppers. As a result, one person remains hungry and another gets drunk.
46:11:22/What? Don't you have homes to eat and drink in? Or do you despise the church of God and humiliate those who have nothing? What shall I say to you? Shall I praise you? Certainly not in this matter.
46:11:23/For I received from the Lord what I also passed on to you: The Lord Jesus, on the night he was betrayed, took bread,
46:11:24/and when he had given thanks, he broke it and said, "Take, eat; this is my body which is broken for you; do this in remembrance of me."
46:11:25/In the same way, after supper he took the cup, saying, "This cup is the new covenant in my blood; do this, whenever you drink it, in remembrance of me."
46:11:26/For whenever you eat this bread and drink this cup, you proclaim the Lord's death until he comes.
46:11:27/Therefore, whoever eats the bread or drinks the cup of the Lord in an unworthy manner will be guilty of sinning against the body and blood of the Lord.
46:11:28/But a person should examine themselves, and in this way let them eat of the bread and drink of the cup.
46:11:29/For anyone who eats and drinks without discerning the body eats and drinks judgment on themselves.
46:11:30/That is why many among you are weak and sick, and a number of you have fallen asleep.
46:11:31/But if we were more discerning with regard to ourselves, we would not come under such judgment.
46:11:32/However, when we are judged in this way by the Lord, we are being disciplined so that we will not be finally condemned with the world.
46:11:33/So then, my brothers and sisters, when you gather to eat, wait for each other.
46:11:34/If anyone is hungry, they should eat at home, so that when you meet together it may not result in judgment. And when I come I will give further directions.
46:12:1/Now regarding spiritual gifts, friends, I don't want you to be uninformed.
46:12:2/You know that when you were non-believers, you were swayed toward mute idols, following wherever you were led.
46:12:3/Therefore, I want you to understand that no one speaking by God's Spirit says Jesus is cursed, and no one can say Jesus is Lord except by the Holy Spirit.
46:12:4/There are different kinds of gifts, but the same Spirit.
46:12:5/And there are different ways to serve, but the same Lord.
46:12:6/There are different kinds of working, but in all of them and in everyone it is the same God at work.
46:12:7/However, the manifestation of the Spirit is given to each person for the common good.
46:12:8/To one person the Spirit gives the ability to share wisdom; to another the same Spirit gives a message of knowledge.
46:12:9/To another faith by the same Spirit; to another gifts of healing by that one Spirit;
46:12:10/To another miraculous powers; to another prophecy; to another distinguishing between spirits; to another speaking in different kinds of tongues; and to yet another the interpretation of tongues.
46:12:11/But all these are the work of one and the same Spirit, who distributes to each one individually as He wishes.
46:12:12/Just as the body is one and has many parts, and all the parts of the body, though many, are one body, so it is with Christ.
46:12:13/For we were all baptized by one Spirit so as to form one body—whether Jews or Gentiles, slave or free—and we were all given the one Spirit to drink.
46:12:14/Indeed, the body is not made up of one part but of many.
46:12:15/If the foot should say, "Because I'm not a hand, I don't belong to the body," it would not for that reason stop being part of the body.
46:12:16/And if the ear should say, "Because I'm not an eye, I don't belong to the body," it would not for that reason stop being part of the body.
46:12:17/If the whole body were an eye, where would the sense of hearing be? If the whole body were an ear, where would the sense of smell be?
46:12:18/But in fact, God has placed the parts in the body, every one of them, just as he wanted them to be.
46:12:19/If they were all one part, where would the body be?
46:12:20/As it is, there are many parts, but one body.
46:12:21/The eye cannot say to the hand, "I don't need you!" And the head cannot say to the feet, "I don't need you!"
46:12:22/On the contrary, those parts of the body that seem to be weaker are indispensable,
46:12:23/And the parts that we think are less honorable we treat with special honor. And the parts that are unpresentable are treated with special modesty,
46:12:24/While our presentable parts need no special treatment. But God has put the body together, giving greater honor to the parts that lacked it,
46:12:25/So that there should be no division in the body, but that its parts should have equal concern for each other.
46:12:26/If one part suffers, every part suffers with it; if one part is honored, every part rejoices with it.
46:12:27/Now you are the body of Christ, and each one of you is a part of it.
46:12:28/And God has placed in the church first of all apostles, second prophets, third teachers, then miracles, then gifts of healing, of helping, of guidance, and of different kinds of tongues.
46:12:29/Are all apostles? Are all prophets? Are all teachers? Do all work miracles?
46:12:30/Do all have gifts of healing? Do all speak in tongues? Do all interpret?
46:12:31/But eagerly desire the greater gifts. And now I will show you the most excellent way.
46:13:1/Even if I speak in the languages of humans and angels but don't have love, I'm just making noise like a loud gong or a clanging cymbal.
46:13:2/And if I have the gift of prophecy, can understand all mysteries and all knowledge, and if I have all faith, enough to move mountains, but don't have love, I am nothing.
46:13:3/And even if I give away all my possessions to feed the poor, and offer my body to be burned, but don't have love, it benefits me nothing.
46:13:4/Love is patient and kind; love does not envy; love does not boast, it is not arrogant,
46:13:5/It does not act improperly, is not selfish, is not easily angered, keeps no record of wrongs;
46:13:6/Does not delight in wrongdoing, but rejoices with the truth;
46:13:7/It always protects, always trusts, always hopes, always perseveres.
46:13:8/Love never fails. But where there are prophecies, they will come to an end; where there are tongues, they will be stilled; where there is knowledge, it will pass away.
46:13:9/For we know in part and we prophesy in part,
46:13:10/But when completeness comes, what is in part disappears.
46:13:11/When I was a child, I talked like a child, I thought like a child, I reasoned like a child. When I became an adult, I left behind childish ways.
46:13:12/Now we see only a reflection as in a mirror; then we shall see face to face. Now I know in part; then I shall know fully, even as I am fully known.
46:13:13/And now these three remain: faith, hope, and love. But the greatest of these is love.
46:14:1/Pursue love, and eagerly desire spiritual gifts, especially the gift of prophecy.
46:14:2/For the one who speaks in a tongue does not speak to people but to God. Indeed, no one understands them; they utter mysteries by the Spirit.
46:14:3/However, the one who prophesies speaks to people for their strengthening, encouragement, and comfort.
46:14:4/The one who speaks in a tongue builds up themselves, but the one who prophesies builds up the church.
46:14:5/I wish all of you could speak in tongues, but even more that you would prophesy. The one who prophesies is greater than the one who speaks in tongues, unless someone interprets, so that the church may be edified.
46:14:6/Now, brothers and sisters, if I come to you speaking in tongues, what good will I be to you, unless I bring you some revelation or knowledge or prophecy or teaching?
46:14:7/Even lifeless instruments, like the flute or the harp, if they do not make distinct notes, how will anyone know what is being played?
46:14:8/And if the trumpet makes an unclear sound, who will get ready for battle?
46:14:9/So it is with you. Unless you speak intelligible words with your tongue, how will anyone know what you are saying? You will just be speaking into the air.
46:14:10/There are doubtless many different languages in the world, yet none of them is without meaning.
46:14:11/If then I do not grasp the meaning of what someone is saying, I am a foreigner to the speaker, and the speaker is a foreigner to me.
46:14:12/So it is with you. Since you are eager for gifts of the Spirit, try to excel in those that build up the church.
46:14:13/For this reason the one who speaks in a tongue should pray that they may interpret what they say.
46:14:14/For if I pray in a tongue, my spirit prays, but my mind is unproductive.
46:14:15/What should I do then? I will pray with my spirit, but I will also pray with my mind; I will sing with my spirit, but I will also sing with my mind.
46:14:16/Otherwise when you are praising God in the Spirit, how can someone else, who is now put in the position of an inquirer, say "Amen" to your thanksgiving, since they do not know what you are saying?
46:14:17/You are certainly giving thanks well enough, but the other person is not being built up.
46:14:18/I thank God that I speak in tongues more than all of you.
46:14:19/But in the church I would rather speak five intelligible words to instruct others than ten thousand words in a tongue.
46:14:20/Brothers and sisters, do not be children in your thinking. Be infants in evil, but in your thinking be mature.
46:14:21/It is written in the Law: "With people of other tongues and through the lips of foreigners I will speak to this people, but even then they will not listen to me, says the Lord."
46:14:22/Tongues, then, are a sign, not for believers but for unbelievers; prophecy, however, is not for unbelievers but for believers.
46:14:23/So if the whole church comes together and everyone speaks in tongues, and inquirers or unbelievers come in, will they not say that you are out of your minds?
46:14:24/But if an unbeliever or an inquirer comes in while everyone is prophesying, they are convicted of sin and are brought under judgment by all,
46:14:25/as the secrets of their hearts are laid bare. So they will fall down and worship God, exclaiming, "God is really among you!"
46:14:26/What then shall we say, brothers and sisters? When you come together, each of you has a hymn, or a word of instruction, a revelation, a tongue, or an interpretation. Everything must be done so that the church may be built up.
46:14:27/If anyone speaks in a tongue, two—or at the most three—should speak, one at a time, and someone must interpret.
46:14:28/If there is no interpreter, the speaker should keep quiet in the church and speak to themselves and to God.
46:14:29/Two or three prophets should speak, and the others should weigh carefully what is said.
46:14:30/And if a revelation comes to someone who is sitting down, the first speaker should stop.
46:14:31/For you can all prophesy in turn so that everyone may be instructed and encouraged.
46:14:32/The spirits of prophets are subject to the control of prophets.
46:14:33/For God is not a God of disorder but of peace—as in all the congregations of the Lord’s people.
46:14:34/Women should remain silent in the churches. They are not allowed to speak, but must be in submission, as the law says.
46:14:35/If they want to inquire about something, they should ask their own husbands at home; for it is disgraceful for a woman to speak in the church.
46:14:36/Or did the word of God originate with you? Or are you the only people it has reached?
46:14:37/If anyone thinks they are a prophet or otherwise gifted by the Spirit, let them acknowledge that what I am writing to you is the Lord’s command.
46:14:38/But if anyone ignores this, they will themselves be ignored.
46:14:39/Therefore, my brothers and sisters, be eager to prophesy, and do not forbid speaking in tongues.
46:14:40/But everything should be done in a fitting and orderly way.
46:15:1/Furthermore, friends, I want to remind you of the gospel I preached to you, which you accepted and on which you have taken your stand.
46:15:2/Through this gospel you are saved, if you hold firmly to the message I preached to you—unless you believed without genuine faith.
46:15:3/First and foremost, I passed on to you what I also received: that Christ died for our sins, fulfilling the scriptures;
46:15:4/That he was buried, and that he was raised on the third day, in accordance with the scriptures;
46:15:5/And that he appeared to Cephas, and then to the twelve disciples.
46:15:6/After that, he appeared to more than five hundred of the believers at one time, most of whom are still alive, though some have passed away.
46:15:7/Then he appeared to James, and afterward to all the apostles.
46:15:8/And last of all, he appeared to me too, as to one abnormally born.
46:15:9/For I am the least of the apostles and do not even deserve to be called an apostle, because I persecuted the church of God.
46:15:10/But by the grace of God, I am what I am, and his grace to me was not without effect. I worked harder than all of them—yet not I, but the grace of God that was with me.
46:15:11/So whether it was I or they, this is what we preach, and this is what you believed.
46:15:12/Now if it is proclaimed that Christ has been raised from the dead, how can some of you say there is no resurrection of the dead?
46:15:13/If there is no resurrection of the dead, then not even Christ has been raised.
46:15:14/And if Christ has not been raised, then our preaching is useless and so is your faith.
46:15:15/Moreover, we would be found to be false witnesses about God, for we have testified about God that he raised Christ from the dead. But he did not raise him if in fact the dead are not raised.
46:15:16/For if the dead are not raised, then Christ has not been raised either.
46:15:17/And if Christ has not been raised, your faith is futile; you are still in your sins.
46:15:18/Then those also who have fallen asleep in Christ are lost.
46:15:19/If only for this life we have hope in Christ, we are of all people most to be pitied.
46:15:20/But in fact, Christ has been raised from the dead, the firstfruits of those who have fallen asleep.
46:15:21/For since death came through a man, the resurrection of the dead comes also through a man.
46:15:22/For as in Adam all die, so in Christ all will be made alive.
46:15:23/But each in turn: Christ, the firstfruits; then, when he comes, those who belong to him.
46:15:24/Then comes the end, when he hands over the kingdom to God the Father after he has destroyed all dominion, authority and power.
46:15:25/For he must reign until he has put all his enemies under his feet.
46:15:26/The last enemy to be destroyed is death.
46:15:27/For he has put everything under his feet. Now when it says that everything has been put under him, it is clear that this does not include God himself, who put everything under Christ.
46:15:28/When he has done this, then the Son himself will be made subject to him who put everything under him, so that God may be all in all.
46:15:29/Otherwise, what will those do who are baptized for the dead? If the dead are not raised at all, why are people baptized for them?
46:15:30/And why do we endanger ourselves every hour?
46:15:31/I face death every day—yes, just as surely as I boast about you in Christ Jesus our Lord.
46:15:32/If I fought wild beasts in Ephesus with merely human hopes, what have I gained? If the dead are not raised, "Let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we die."
46:15:33/Do not be misled: "Bad company corrupts good character."
46:15:34/Come back to your senses as you ought, and stop sinning; for there are some who are ignorant of God—I say this to your shame.
46:15:35/But someone will ask, "How are the dead raised? With what kind of body will they come?"
46:15:36/You foolish person! What you sow does not come to life unless it dies.
46:15:37/And what you sow is not the body that is to be, but a bare seed, perhaps of wheat or of some other grain.
46:15:38/But God gives it a body as he has determined, and to each kind of seed he gives its own body.
46:15:39/Not all flesh is the same: People have one kind of flesh, animals have another, birds another and fish another.
46:15:40/There are also heavenly bodies and earthly bodies, but the splendor of the heavenly bodies is one kind, and the splendor of the earthly bodies is another.
46:15:41/There is one glory of the sun, another glory of the moon, and another glory of the stars; for one star differs from another star in glory.
46:15:42/So will it be with the resurrection of the dead. The body that is sown is perishable, it is raised imperishable;
46:15:43/It is sown in dishonor, it is raised in glory; it is sown in weakness, it is raised in power;
46:15:44/It is sown a natural body, it is raised a spiritual body. If there is a natural body, there is also a spiritual body.
46:15:45/Thus it is written, "The first man Adam became a living being"; the last Adam, a life-giving spirit.
46:15:46/However, the spiritual is not first, but the natural, and then the spiritual.
46:15:47/The first man was of the dust of the earth; the second man is from heaven.
46:15:48/As was the earthly man, so are those who are of the earth; and as is the heavenly man, so also are those who are of heaven.
46:15:49/And just as we have borne the image of the earthly man, so shall we bear the image of the heavenly man.
46:15:50/I declare to you, brothers and sisters, that flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God, nor does the perishable inherit the imperishable.
46:15:51/Listen, I tell you a mystery: We will not all sleep, but we will all be changed,
46:15:52/In a flash, in the blink of an eye, at the last trumpet. For the trumpet will sound, the dead will be raised imperishable, and we will be changed.
46:15:53/For the perishable must clothe itself with the imperishable, and the mortal with immortality.
46:15:54/So when the perishable has been clothed with the imperishable, and the mortal with immortality, then the saying that is written will come true: "Death has been swallowed up in victory."
46:15:55/"Where, O death, is your victory? Where, O death, is your sting?"
46:15:56/The sting of death is sin, and the power of sin is the law.
46:15:57/But thanks be to God! He gives us the victory through our Lord Jesus Christ.
46:15:58/Therefore, my dear brothers and sisters, stand firm. Let nothing move you. Always give yourselves fully to the work of the Lord, because you know that your labor in the Lord is not in vain.
46:16:1/Regarding the collection for the saints, just as I instructed the churches in Galatia, you should do the same.
46:16:2/Every Sunday, each of you should set aside a portion of your income, saving it up, so that there won't need to be any fundraising when I arrive.
46:16:3/And when I arrive, whoever you endorse through your letters, I will send them to deliver your generous donation to Jerusalem.
46:16:4/And if it seems appropriate for me to go as well, they will accompany me.
46:16:5/I plan to visit you after I travel through Macedonia, since I will be passing through there.
46:16:6/It's possible that I'll stay with you for a while, maybe even spend the winter, so you can help me on my journey, wherever I decide to go.
46:16:7/For now, I won't be stopping to see you; but I hope to spend some time with you later, if the Lord allows.
46:16:8/But I'll stay in Ephesus until Pentecost.
46:16:9/Because a great and effective opportunity has opened up for me here, even though there are many who oppose me.
46:16:10/If Timothy arrives, make sure he feels safe with you, for he is doing the Lord's work, just as I am.
46:16:11/So, don't let anyone look down on him. Help him on his way in peace so he can return to me, as I am expecting him along with the brothers.
46:16:12/Regarding our brother Apollos, I strongly encouraged him to visit you with the other brothers. However, he was not willing to come at this time. He will come when he has the opportunity.
46:16:13/Stay alert, stand firm in your faith, be courageous, be strong.
46:16:14/Make sure everything you do is done with love.
46:16:15/I urge you, brothers and sisters, you know the household of Stephanas was the first convert in Achaia and they have devoted themselves to serving the saints.
46:16:16/Respect such people and everyone who works and labors with us.
46:16:17/I am delighted with the arrival of Stephanas, Fortunatus, and Achaicus because they have made up for your absence.
46:16:18/They have refreshed my spirit as well as yours. Therefore, recognize people like them.
46:16:19/The churches in Asia send their greetings. Aquila and Priscilla greet you warmly in the Lord, along with the church that meets at their house.
46:16:20/All the brothers and sisters send their greetings. Greet one another with a holy kiss.
46:16:21/This greeting is in my own hand—Paul.
46:16:22/If anyone does not love the Lord Jesus Christ, let them be cursed. Our Lord, come!
46:16:23/May the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you.
46:16:24/My love to all of you in Christ Jesus. Amen.
47:1:1/Paul, an apostle of Jesus Christ by God's will, and Timothy our brother, to the church of God in Corinth, along with all the saints throughout Achaia:
47:1:2/May grace and peace be yours from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
47:1:3/Praise be to God, the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of compassion, and the God who comforts us in every way.
47:1:4/He comforts us in all our troubles so that we can comfort those in any trouble with the comfort we ourselves receive from God.
47:1:5/Just as we share abundantly in Christ's sufferings, so also our comfort abounds through Christ.
47:1:6/If we are distressed, it's for your comfort and salvation; if we are comforted, it's for your comfort, which produces in you patient endurance of the same sufferings we suffer.
47:1:7/And our hope for you is firm, because we know that just as you share in our sufferings, so also you share in our comfort.
47:1:8/We don't want you to be unaware, brothers and sisters, of the troubles we experienced in Asia. We were under great pressure, far beyond our ability to endure, so that we despaired of life itself.
47:1:9/Indeed, we felt we had received the sentence of death. But this happened that we might not rely on ourselves but on God, who raises the dead.
47:1:10/He has delivered us from such a deadly peril, and he will deliver us again. On him we have set our hope that he will continue to deliver us,
47:1:11/as you help us by your prayers. Then many will give thanks on our behalf for the gracious favor granted us in answer to the prayers of many.
47:1:12/Our pride is this: the testimony of our conscience that we have conducted ourselves in the world, and especially in our relations with you, with integrity and godly sincerity. We have done so, relying not on worldly wisdom but on God's grace.
47:1:13/We write to you nothing other than what you can read and understand. And I hope you will fully understand,
47:1:14/just as you have partially understood us, that you can be proud of us just as we will be proud of you in the day of our Lord Jesus.
47:1:15/Confident of this, I planned to visit you first so that you might benefit twice.
47:1:16/I planned to visit you on my way to Macedonia and to come back to you from Macedonia, and then to have you send me on my way to Judea.
47:1:17/When I planned this, did I do it lightly? Or do I make my plans in a worldly manner so that in the same breath I say, "Yes, yes" and "No, no"?
47:1:18/But as surely as God is faithful, our message to you is not "Yes" and "No."
47:1:19/For the Son of God, Jesus Christ, who was preached among you by us—by me and Silvanus and Timothy—was not "Yes" and "No," but in him it has always been "Yes."
47:1:20/For no matter how many promises God has made, they are "Yes" in Christ. And so through him the "Amen" is spoken by us to the glory of God.
47:1:21/Now it is God who makes both us and you stand firm in Christ. He anointed us,
47:1:22/set his seal of ownership on us, and put his Spirit in our hearts as a deposit, guaranteeing what is to come.
47:1:23/I call God as my witness—and I stake my life on it—that it was to spare you that I did not return to Corinth.
47:1:24/Not that we lord it over your faith, but we work with you for your joy, because it is by faith you stand firm.
47:2:1/I decided that I wouldn't visit you again if it meant bringing sadness.
47:2:2/Because if I make you sad, who's there to make me happy except the one I've made sad?
47:2:3/And I wrote to you for this reason, so that when I came, I wouldn't be saddened by those I should be rejoicing with; trusting that all of you share in my joy.
47:2:4/With a heavy heart and many tears, I wrote to you, not to upset you, but to let you know the deep love I have for you.
47:2:5/But if anyone has caused sadness, they haven't just upset me, but to some extent—not to overstate it—all of you.
47:2:6/The punishment given by many is enough for such a person.
47:2:7/Instead, you should forgive and comfort him, so he isn't overwhelmed by excessive sadness.
47:2:8/That's why I urge you to reaffirm your love for him.
47:2:9/I wrote for this reason: to test your willingness to obey in everything.
47:2:10/If you forgive anyone, I do too. And what I have forgiven—if there was anything to forgive—I did it for your sake, in the presence of Christ,
47:2:11/So that we wouldn't be outwitted by Satan; we're not unaware of his schemes.
47:2:12/When I went to Troas to spread the gospel of Christ and found an opportunity from the Lord,
47:2:13/I had no peace because I didn't find my brother Titus there. So I said goodbye and went on to Macedonia.
47:2:14/But thanks be to God, who always leads us in triumph in Christ and uses us to spread the aroma of the knowledge of him everywhere.
47:2:15/For we are to God the pleasing aroma of Christ among those who are being saved and those who are perishing.
47:2:16/To the one, we are an aroma that brings death; to the other, an aroma that brings life. And who is qualified for such a task?
47:2:17/Unlike so many, we don't peddle the word of God for profit. On the contrary, in Christ we speak before God with sincerity, as those sent from God.
47:3:1/Are we starting to praise ourselves again? Or do we need, like some people, letters of introduction to you or from you?
47:3:2/You yourselves are our letter, written on our hearts, known and read by everyone.
47:3:3/It's clear that you are a letter from Christ delivered by us, not written with ink but with the Spirit of the living God; not on tablets of stone but on the human heart.
47:3:4/And we have such confidence through Christ towards God.
47:3:5/It's not that we think we can do anything on our own; our ability comes from God.
47:3:6/He has also made us competent as ministers of a new covenant; not of the letter but of the Spirit, for the letter kills, but the Spirit gives life.
47:3:7/But if the ministry that brought death, carved in letters on stone, came with glory, so that the Israelites couldn't gaze at Moses' face because of its glory, which was fading away,
47:3:8/How will the ministry of the Spirit not be even more glorious?
47:3:9/For if there was glory in the ministry of condemnation, the ministry of righteousness far exceeds it in glory.
47:3:10/Indeed, in this case, what once had glory has lost its glory because of the greater glory.
47:3:11/For if what was fading away came with glory, much more will what is permanent have glory.
47:3:12/Therefore, since we have such hope, we are very bold,
47:3:13/Not like Moses, who put a veil over his face so that the Israelites might not gaze at the outcome of what was being brought to an end.
47:3:14/But their minds were hardened. For to this day, when they read the old covenant, that same veil remains unlifted, because only through Christ is it taken away.
47:3:15/Yes, to this day whenever Moses is read, a veil lies over their hearts.
47:3:16/But whenever anyone turns to the Lord, the veil is removed.
47:3:17/Now the Lord is the Spirit, and where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is freedom.
47:3:18/And we all, with unveiled faces, looking as in a mirror at the glory of the Lord, are being transformed into the same image from one degree of glory to another; and this comes from the Lord, the Spirit.
47:4:1/So, since we have this ministry because we were shown mercy, we do not lose heart.
47:4:2/But we have rejected shameful, hidden practices, not acting with deceit or distorting God's word. Instead, by presenting the truth plainly, we commend ourselves to everyone's conscience in the presence of God.
47:4:3/But if our good news is veiled, it is veiled to those who are perishing.
47:4:4/In their case, the god of this age has blinded the minds of unbelievers to keep them from seeing the light of the gospel of the glory of Christ, who is the image of God.
47:4:5/For we do not preach ourselves, but Jesus Christ as Lord, and ourselves as your servants for Jesus' sake.
47:4:6/For God, who said, "Let light shine out of darkness," has shone in our hearts to give us the light of the knowledge of God's glory displayed in the face of Christ.
47:4:7/But we have this treasure in jars of clay to show that this all-surpassing power is from God and not from us.
47:4:8/We are hard-pressed on every side, but not crushed; perplexed, but not driven to despair;
47:4:9/Persecuted, but not abandoned; struck down, but not destroyed;
47:4:10/Always carrying in our body the death of Jesus, so that the life of Jesus may also be revealed in our body.
47:4:11/For we who are alive are always being given over to death for Jesus' sake, so that his life may also be revealed in our mortal body.
47:4:12/So then, death is at work in us, but life is at work in you.
47:4:13/With that same spirit of faith, according to what is written, "I believed; therefore, I have spoken," we also believe and therefore speak,
47:4:14/Knowing that the one who raised the Lord Jesus from the dead will also raise us with Jesus and present us with you.
47:4:15/For all this is for your benefit, so that the grace that is reaching more and more people may cause thanksgiving to overflow to the glory of God.
47:4:16/Therefore we do not lose heart. Though outwardly we are wasting away, yet inwardly we are being renewed day by day.
47:4:17/For our light and momentary troubles are achieving for us an eternal glory that far outweighs them all.
47:4:18/So we fix our eyes not on what is seen, but on what is unseen, since what is seen is temporary, but what is unseen is eternal.
47:5:1/We know that if our earthly body, our temporary home, is destroyed, we have a building from God, a home not made by human hands, eternal in the heavens.
47:5:2/In this body, we sigh with longing, eagerly waiting to be clothed with our heavenly dwelling,
47:5:3/So that when we are clothed, we will not be found naked.
47:5:4/While we live in this body, we groan under our burdens, not wishing to be stripped of it but to be clothed with our heavenly body, so that what is mortal may be swallowed up by life.
47:5:5/Now the one who has prepared us for this very purpose is God, who has also given us the Spirit as a guarantee.
47:5:6/So we are always confident, knowing that as long as we are at home in the body, we are away from the Lord.
47:5:7/(For we live by faith, not by what we see.)
47:5:8/We are confident, I say, and would prefer to be away from the body and at home with the Lord.
47:5:9/So we make it our goal to please him, whether we are at home in the body or away from it.
47:5:10/For we must all appear before the judgment seat of Christ, so that each of us may receive what is due for the things done while in the body, whether good or bad.
47:5:11/Knowing the fear of the Lord, we try to persuade others. We are well known to God, and I hope we are also well known to your consciences.
47:5:12/We are not trying to commend ourselves to you again, but are giving you an opportunity to take pride in us, so you can have an answer for those who take pride in what is seen rather than in what is in the heart.
47:5:13/Whether we are out of our mind, it is for God; or whether we are in our right mind, it is for you.
47:5:14/For Christ's love compels us, because we are convinced that one died for all, and therefore all died.
47:5:15/And he died for all, that those who live should no longer live for themselves but for him who died for them and was raised again.
47:5:16/So from now on we regard no one from a worldly point of view. Though we once regarded Christ in this way, we do so no longer.
47:5:17/Therefore, if anyone is in Christ, the new creation has come: The old has gone, the new is here!
47:5:18/All this is from God, who reconciled us to himself through Christ and gave us the ministry of reconciliation,
47:5:19/That is, in Christ God was reconciling the world to himself, not counting people's sins against them. And he has committed to us the message of reconciliation.
47:5:20/We are therefore Christ's ambassadors, as though God were making his appeal through us. We implore you on Christ's behalf: Be reconciled to God.
47:5:21/For God made him who had no sin to be sin for us, so that in him we might become the righteousness of God.
47:6:1/We then, as coworkers with him, urge you also not to receive God's grace in vain.
47:6:2/(For he says, "I have listened to you at the perfect time, and on the day of salvation, I have helped you: look, now is the perfect time; look, now is the day of salvation.")
47:6:3/Avoiding any offense in anything, so that the ministry is not criticized:
47:6:4/But in everything presenting ourselves as servants of God, with great patience, in hardships, in needs, in distresses,
47:6:5/Through beatings, imprisonments, riots, hard work, sleepless nights, and fasting;
47:6:6/By purity, by knowledge, by patience, by kindness, by the Holy Spirit, by sincere love,
47:6:7/Through the message of truth, by the power of God, with the weapons of righteousness in the right hand and in the left,
47:6:8/Through honor and dishonor, through bad report and good report: as deceivers, yet truthful;
47:6:9/As unknown, yet well recognized; as dying, and see, we live; as disciplined, and not put to death;
47:6:10/As sad, yet always joyful; as poor, yet enriching many; as having nothing, and yet possessing everything.
47:6:11/O Corinthians, we have spoken openly to you, our heart is wide open.
47:6:12/You are not restricted by us, but you are restricted by your own affections.
47:6:13/Now in return (I speak as to my children), be also open-hearted.
47:6:14/Do not be mismatched with unbelievers: for what partnership does righteousness have with wickedness? Or what fellowship does light have with darkness?
47:6:15/And what agreement does Christ have with Belial? Or what share does a believer have with an unbeliever?
47:6:16/And what accord does the temple of God have with idols? For you are the temple of the living God; as God has said, "I will live with them and walk among them; and I will be their God, and they shall be my people."
47:6:17/Therefore, separate yourselves from them, says the Lord, and do not touch the unclean thing; and I will welcome you.
47:6:18/And I will be a Father to you, and you shall be my sons and daughters, says the Lord Almighty.
47:7:1/Having these promises, dear friends, let's purify ourselves from everything that contaminates body and spirit, striving for complete holiness out of reverence for God.
47:7:2/Accept us; we haven't wronged anyone, we haven't corrupted anyone, we haven't cheated anyone.
47:7:3/I'm not saying this to condemn you: I've already told you that you have a place in our hearts, to share both life and death.
47:7:4/My openness in speaking to you is great, my pride in you is immense: I am filled with comfort, I am overwhelmingly joyful despite all our troubles.
47:7:5/For when we arrived in Macedonia, we had no rest, but faced trouble at every turn—conflicts on the outside, fears within.
47:7:6/But God, who comforts the downhearted, comforted us by the arrival of Titus;
47:7:7/And not only by his arrival, but also by the comfort you had given him. He told us about your longing for me, your deep sorrow, your ardent concern for me, so that my joy was greater than ever.
47:7:8/Even if my letter made you sad, I don't regret it. Though I did regret it—I see that that letter made you sad, even if only for a little while.
47:7:9/Now I'm glad, not because you were made sad, but because your sadness led to repentance. You became sad in a godly way, so that you were not harmed by us in any way.
47:7:10/For sadness that is according to God produces a repentance that leads to salvation, leaving no regret, but worldly sadness brings death.
47:7:11/See what this godly sadness has produced in you: what earnestness, what eagerness to clear yourselves, what indignation, what fear, what longing, what zeal, what punishment! In every way, you have proved yourselves to be innocent in this matter.
47:7:12/So even though I wrote to you, it wasn’t for the sake of the offender or the victim, but to show you before God how much you care for us.
47:7:13/That's why we were comforted. And in our comfort, we rejoiced even more at the joy of Titus, because his spirit has been refreshed by all of you.
47:7:14/For if I have boasted to him about anything concerning you, I am not ashamed. But as we spoke everything to you in truth, so our boasting to Titus has been proven true.
47:7:15/And his affection for you is all the greater when he remembers that all of you were obedient, receiving him with fear and trembling.
47:7:16/I am therefore very happy that I can have complete confidence in you in everything.
47:8:1/Furthermore, friends, we want to tell you about the grace of God that has been given to the churches of Macedonia;
47:8:2/Despite facing severe trials and extreme poverty, their overflowing joy and generosity resulted in rich generosity.
47:8:3/Indeed, I can testify that they gave as much as they could, and even beyond their ability, entirely on their own initiative;
47:8:4/They urgently pleaded with us for the privilege of sharing in this service to the saints.
47:8:5/And they did this not as we had expected, but they first gave themselves to the Lord and then to us in accordance with God's will.
47:8:6/So much so that we asked Titus to complete this act of grace among you as well.
47:8:7/Therefore, just as you excel in everything—in faith, in speech, in knowledge, in complete earnestness, and in your love for us—see that you also excel in this grace of giving.
47:8:8/I'm not commanding you, but I want to test the sincerity of your love by comparing it with the eagerness of others.
47:8:9/For you know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, that although he was rich, for your sake he became poor, so that you through his poverty might become rich.
47:8:10/And in this matter I am giving my advice: It is beneficial for you, who a year ago started not only to do this work but also to desire to do it.
47:8:11/Now finish the work, so that your eager willingness to do it may be matched by your completion of it, according to your means.
47:8:12/For if the willingness is there, the gift is acceptable according to what one has, not according to what one does not have.
47:8:13/My intention is not that others should be relieved while you are burdened, but that there might be equality.
47:8:14/At the present time, your surplus will meet their need, so that in turn their surplus will meet your need, and in this way there will be equality.
47:8:15/As it is written: "The one who gathered much did not have too much, and the one who gathered little did not have too little."
47:8:16/But thanks be to God, who put into the heart of Titus the same concern I have for you.
47:8:17/For he not only accepted our appeal, but being very eager, he is coming to you on his own initiative.
47:8:18/And we are sending along with him the brother who is praised by all the churches for his service to the gospel.
47:8:19/Not only that, but he was also chosen by the churches to accompany us as we carry this act of grace, which is administered by us for the glory of the Lord himself and to show our eagerness to help.
47:8:20/We want to avoid any criticism of the way we administer this liberal gift.
47:8:21/For we are taking pains to do what is right, not only in the eyes of the Lord but also in the eyes of people.
47:8:22/And we are sending with them our brother, whom we have often tested and found diligent in many matters, but now even more so because of his great confidence in you.
47:8:23/As for Titus, he is my partner and co-worker among you; as for our brothers, they are representatives of the churches and an honor to Christ.
47:8:24/Therefore, show them the proof of your love and the reason for our pride in you, in the sight of the churches.
47:9:1/Regarding helping the saints, it's really not necessary for me to write to you about it.
47:9:2/I'm aware of your eagerness, which I've proudly told the people of Macedonia about, saying that Achaia was ready a year ago; and your enthusiasm has inspired many others.
47:9:3/However, I've sent the brothers to make sure that our boasting about you isn't empty in this matter; that, as I said, you may be prepared:
47:9:4/So that if the Macedonians come with me and see you unprepared, we (not to mention you) would be embarrassed about this confident boasting.
47:9:5/That's why I thought it necessary to urge the brothers to visit you in advance and arrange your generous donation, which you had previously promised, so that it would be ready as a generous gift, not as something you felt forced to do.
47:9:6/But what I'm saying is, the one who plants sparingly will also harvest sparingly; and the one who plants generously will also harvest generously.
47:9:7/Each person should give what they have decided in their heart to give, not reluctantly or under compulsion, because God loves a cheerful giver.
47:9:8/And God is able to bless you abundantly, so that in all things at all times, having all that you need, you will abound in every good work:
47:9:9/(As it is written, "He has scattered his gifts to the poor; his righteousness endures forever."
47:9:10/Now the one who provides seed to the sower and bread for food will also supply and increase your store of seed and will enlarge the harvest of your righteousness.)
47:9:11/You will be enriched in every way so that you can be generous on every occasion, and through us your generosity will result in thanksgiving to God.
47:9:12/This service that you perform is not only supplying the needs of the Lord's people but is also overflowing in many expressions of thanks to God.
47:9:13/Because of the service by which you have proved yourselves, others will praise God for the obedience that accompanies your confession of the gospel of Christ, and for your generosity in sharing with them and with everyone else.
47:9:14/And in their prayers for you, their hearts will go out to you, because of the surpassing grace God has given you.
47:9:15/Thanks be to God for his indescribable gift.
47:10:1/I, Paul, am asking you with the humility and kindness of Christ. I might seem unimpressive in person, but I'm bold when I'm not with you.
47:10:2/But I'm asking you so that I won't have to be as bold in person as I expect to be against some people who think we live by worldly standards.
47:10:3/Even though we live in human bodies, we don't fight with human plans and methods.
47:10:4/Our weapons in this fight are not human but are powerful through God for tearing down strongholds.
47:10:5/We demolish arguments and every pretension that sets itself up against the knowledge of God, and we take captive every thought to make it obedient to Christ.
47:10:6/And we are ready to punish all disobedience, once your obedience is complete.
47:10:7/Do you judge by appearances? If anyone is confident that they belong to Christ, they should reconsider that we belong to Christ just as much as they do.
47:10:8/Even if I boast a little too much about the authority the Lord gave us to build you up and not tear you down, I won't be ashamed.
47:10:9/So that I won't seem like I'm trying to scare you with my letters.
47:10:10/Some say, "His letters are serious and forceful, but in person he is weak, and his speaking amounts to nothing."
47:10:11/Such people should realize that what we are in our letters when we are absent, we will be in our actions when we are present.
47:10:12/We don't dare to classify or compare ourselves with some who commend themselves. When they measure themselves by themselves and compare themselves with themselves, they lack understanding.
47:10:13/We, however, will not boast beyond our proper limits, but will confine our boasting to the field God has assigned to us, a field that reaches even to you.
47:10:14/We are not overstepping our bounds, as if we hadn't come to you, for we were the first to come all the way to you with the gospel of Christ.
47:10:15/We don't boast about work done by others outside our assigned area. But we have hope that as your faith grows, our area of activity among you will greatly expand,
47:10:16/So we can preach the gospel in the regions beyond you, without boasting about work already done in someone else's territory.
47:10:17/But, "Let the one who boasts, boast in the Lord."
47:10:18/For it's not the one who commends themselves who is approved, but the one whom the Lord commends.
47:11:1/I wish you could put up with a little of my foolishness; please bear with me.
47:11:2/I feel a divine jealousy for you, since I promised you to one husband, to present you as a pure virgin to Christ.
47:11:3/But I'm afraid that, just as the serpent deceived Eve by his cunning, your thoughts might be led astray from a sincere and pure devotion to Christ.
47:11:4/If someone comes and preaches a different Jesus than the one we preached, or if you receive a different spirit or a different gospel than the one you accepted, you might well put up with it.
47:11:5/I consider myself not in the least inferior to the most eminent apostles.
47:11:6/Even if I am unskilled in speech, I am not so in knowledge; indeed, we have made this clear to you in every way.
47:11:7/Did I commit a sin by humbling myself so that you could be elevated, because I preached God's gospel to you free of charge?
47:11:8/I robbed other churches by accepting support from them in order to serve you.
47:11:9/And when I was with you and in need, I was not a burden to anyone, for the brothers who came from Macedonia supplied what I needed. I have kept myself from being a burden to you in any way, and will continue to do so.
47:11:10/As surely as the truth of Christ is in me, nobody in the regions of Achaia will stop this boasting of mine.
47:11:11/Why? Because I don't love you? God knows I do.
47:11:12/But what I do, I will continue to do, to cut off the opportunity from those who want an opportunity to be considered equal with us in the things they boast about.
47:11:13/For such people are false apostles, deceitful workers, masquerading as apostles of Christ.
47:11:14/And no wonder, for even Satan disguises himself as an angel of light.
47:11:15/So it is no surprise if his servants also disguise themselves as servants of righteousness. Their end will correspond to their deeds.
47:11:16/I repeat, let no one think me foolish. But if you do, then accept me as a fool, so that I too may boast a little.
47:11:17/What I am saying with this boastful confidence, I say not as the Lord would but as a fool.
47:11:18/Since many boast according to the flesh, I too will boast.
47:11:19/For you gladly bear with fools, being wise yourselves.
47:11:20/For you bear it if someone makes you slaves, or devours you, or takes advantage of you, or puts on airs, or strikes you in the face.
47:11:21/To my shame, I must say, we were too weak for that! But in whatever anyone is bold—I am speaking foolishly—I also am bold.
47:11:22/Are they Hebrews? So am I. Are they Israelites? So am I. Are they offspring of Abraham? So am I.
47:11:23/Are they servants of Christ? I am out of my mind to talk like this—I am more. I have worked much harder, been in prison more frequently, been flogged more severely, and been exposed to death again and again.
47:11:24/Five times I received from the Jews the forty lashes minus one.
47:11:25/Three times I was beaten with rods, once I was pelted with stones, three times I was shipwrecked, I spent a night and a day in the open sea;
47:11:26/I have been constantly on the move. I have been in danger from rivers, in danger from bandits, in danger from my fellow Jews, in danger from Gentiles; in danger in the city, in danger in the country, in danger at sea; and in danger from false believers.
47:11:27/I have labored and toiled and have often gone without sleep; I have known hunger and thirst and have often gone without food; I have been cold and naked.
47:11:28/Besides everything else, I face daily the pressure of my concern for all the churches.
47:11:29/Who is weak, and I do not feel weak? Who is led into sin, and I do not inwardly burn?
47:11:30/If I must boast, I will boast of the things that show my weakness.
47:11:31/The God and Father of the Lord Jesus, who is to be praised forever, knows that I am not lying.
47:11:32/In Damascus, the governor under King Aretas had the city of the Damascenes guarded in order to arrest me.
47:11:33/But I was lowered in a basket from a window in the wall and slipped through his hands.
47:12:1/It's not really beneficial for me to boast. I'm going to talk about visions and revelations from the Lord instead.
47:12:2/I knew someone in Christ more than fourteen years ago, (whether physically present or not, I can't say; God knows) who was taken up to the third heaven.
47:12:3/And I knew such a person, (whether in the body or out of the body, I can't say; God knows)
47:12:4/How he was taken up into paradise and heard indescribable things, which no one is permitted to tell.
47:12:5/I will boast about such a person, but not about myself, except about my weaknesses.
47:12:6/Even though I might want to boast, I won't be foolish; I'll stick to the truth. But I'm holding back so no one thinks more of me than what they see or hear from me.
47:12:7/To keep me from becoming conceited because of these surpassingly great revelations, there was given to me a thorn in my flesh, a messenger of Satan, to torment me.
47:12:8/Three times I pleaded with the Lord to take it away from me.
47:12:9/But he said to me, "My grace is all you need. My power works best in weakness." So I will boast all the more gladly about my weaknesses, so that Christ's power may rest on me.
47:12:10/That's why I delight in weaknesses, in insults, in hardships, in persecutions, in difficulties for the sake of Christ. For when I am weak, then I am strong.
47:12:11/I've been made to look foolish for boasting. You forced me to it, because I should have been commended by you. For I am not at all inferior to the most eminent apostles, even though I am nothing.
47:12:12/The true signs of an apostle were performed among you with utmost patience, with signs, wonders, and miracles.
47:12:13/How were you inferior to other churches, except that I was not a burden to you? Forgive me this wrong.
47:12:14/Look, I'm ready to visit you for the third time, and I won't be a burden. I don't want what you have, but you. For children shouldn't save up for their parents, but parents for their children.
47:12:15/And I will most gladly spend and be spent for you. Even if the more I love you, the less I am loved.
47:12:16/But let it be. I didn't burden you. Yet, being crafty, I caught you by trickery.
47:12:17/Did I exploit you through any of those I sent to you?
47:12:18/I urged Titus to go, and sent a brother with him. Did Titus take advantage of you? Didn't we act in the same spirit and follow the same steps?
47:12:19/Do you think we're defending ourselves to you? We speak in the sight of God in Christ. But everything we do, dear friends, is for your strengthening.
47:12:20/I'm afraid that when I come I may not find you as I hope, and you may not find me as you wish. I fear there may be quarreling, jealousy, anger, hostility, slander, gossip, arrogance, and disorder.
47:12:21/I'm afraid that when I come again my God will humble me before you, and I will mourn over many who have sinned earlier and have not repented of the impurity, sexual sin, and debauchery they have practiced.
47:13:1/This is the third time I'm coming to you. Every statement will be confirmed by two or three witnesses.
47:13:2/I warned you before, and I'm warning you again as if I were there in person, even though I'm not there now. I'm writing to those who have sinned before and to everyone else, warning you that I won't hold back if I have to come again.
47:13:3/Since you're looking for proof that Christ is speaking through me, who is not weak in dealing with you but is powerful among you.
47:13:4/Even though he was crucified in weakness, he lives by the power of God. We too are weak in him, but we will live with him by the power of God directed toward you.
47:13:5/Test yourselves to see if you're in the faith; examine yourselves. Don't you realize that Jesus Christ is in you—unless, of course, you fail the test?
47:13:6/But I trust that you will realize that we are not failures.
47:13:7/Now I pray to God that you do no wrong, not so we can prove ourselves, but so you can do what is right, even though we may seem like failures to you.
47:13:8/We can't act against the truth, only for the truth.
47:13:9/We are happy when we are weak but you are strong. What we really want is for you to become mature.
47:13:10/That's why I'm writing these things while I'm away, so I don't have to be harsh when I'm with you, using the authority the Lord gave me for building you up, not tearing you down.
47:13:11/Finally, friends, goodbye. Aim for perfection, be encouraged, be of one mind, live in peace; and the God of love and peace will be with you.
47:13:12/Greet each other with a sacred kiss.
47:13:13/All the saints send their greetings.
47:13:14/May the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ, the love of God, and the fellowship of the Holy Spirit be with you all. Amen.
48:1:1/Paul, an apostle, (not appointed by people, nor through a person, but by Jesus Christ, and God the Father, who raised him from the dead;) 
48:1:2/And all the brothers and sisters with me, to the churches in Galatia: 
48:1:3/May grace and peace be yours from God the Father, and from our Lord Jesus Christ, 
48:1:4/Who sacrificed himself for our sins, to rescue us from this current evil age, in line with God's will and our Father: 
48:1:5/To whom be glory forever and ever. Amen.
48:1:6/I'm amazed that you are so quickly deserting the one who called you by the grace of Christ for a different gospel; 
48:1:7/Which is really not another gospel at all. However, there are some who are disturbing you and want to distort the gospel of Christ.
48:1:8/But even if we, or an angel from heaven, should preach to you a gospel contrary to what we have preached to you, let them be under God's curse.
48:1:9/As we have said before, so now I say again, if anyone preaches to you a gospel contrary to the one you received, let them be under God's curse.
48:1:10/Am I now trying to win the approval of human beings, or of God? Or am I trying to please people? If I were still trying to please people, I would not be a servant of Christ.
48:1:11/But I want you to know, brothers and sisters, that the gospel I preached is not of human origin.
48:1:12/I did not receive it from any human source, nor was I taught it, but it came through a revelation from Jesus Christ.
48:1:13/You have heard about my previous way of life in Judaism, how I intensely persecuted God's church and tried to destroy it. 
48:1:14/And I was advancing in Judaism beyond many of my own age among my people, being more extremely zealous for the traditions of my ancestors.
48:1:15/But when God, who set me apart from my mother's womb and called me by his grace, was pleased 
48:1:16/To reveal his Son in me so that I might preach him among the Gentiles, I did not immediately consult with anyone. 
48:1:17/I did not go up to Jerusalem to see those who were apostles before me, but I went into Arabia, and later returned to Damascus.
48:1:18/Then after three years, I went up to Jerusalem to get acquainted with Peter and stayed with him fifteen days.
48:1:19/But I saw none of the other apostles—only James, the Lord's brother.
48:1:20/Now concerning the things I am writing to you, I assure you before God that I am not lying.
48:1:21/Later I went to the regions of Syria and Cilicia; 
48:1:22/And I was personally unknown to the churches of Judea that are in Christ.
48:1:23/But they only heard the report: "The man who formerly persecuted us is now preaching the faith he once tried to destroy."
48:1:24/And they praised God because of me.
48:2:1/Then fourteen years later, I went back to Jerusalem with Barnabas, bringing Titus along too.
48:2:2/I went there because of a revelation and shared with them the gospel I preach among the Gentiles, but I did this privately with those who were influential, to make sure I wasn't working or hadn't worked for nothing.
48:2:3/But Titus, who was with me and is Greek, wasn't forced to be circumcised:
48:2:4/This was because of some fake believers who had sneaked in to spy on the freedom we have in Christ Jesus, aiming to enslave us.
48:2:5/We didn't give in to them for a moment, so that the truth of the gospel would remain with you.
48:2:6/But from those who seemed to be important (whatever they were, it makes no difference to me; God shows no favoritism) - those recognized leaders added nothing to my message.
48:2:7/On the contrary, when they saw that I had been entrusted with the gospel to the uncircumcised just as Peter had been to the circumcised,
48:2:8/(For the one who worked powerfully in Peter for his apostolic ministry to the circumcised worked powerfully in me towards the Gentiles),
48:2:9/And when James, Cephas (Peter), and John, who were recognized as pillars, realized the grace given to me, they extended the right hand of fellowship to Barnabas and me, agreeing that we should go to the Gentiles and they to the circumcised.
48:2:10/They only asked us to remember the poor, which was something I was eager to do anyway.
48:2:11/But when Peter came to Antioch, I opposed him to his face because he was clearly in the wrong.
48:2:12/Before certain people came from James, he used to eat with the Gentiles. But when they arrived, he began to withdraw and separate himself, fearing those from the circumcision group.
48:2:13/The other Jews joined him in this hypocrisy, so much so that even Barnabas was led astray by their hypocrisy.
48:2:14/But when I saw that they were not acting in line with the truth of the gospel, I said to Peter in front of them all, "If you, a Jew, live like a Gentile and not like a Jew, how can you force the Gentiles to follow Jewish customs?"
48:2:15/We are Jews by birth and not 'Gentile sinners',
48:2:16/Yet we know that a person is not justified by the works of the law but through faith in Jesus Christ. So we, too, have put our faith in Christ Jesus, so that we may be justified by faith in Christ and not by the works of the law, because by the works of the law no one will be justified.
48:2:17/But if, in seeking to be justified in Christ, we Jews find ourselves also among the sinners, doesn’t that mean Christ promotes sin? Absolutely not!
48:2:18/If I rebuild what I once destroyed, then I really would be a lawbreaker.
48:2:19/Through the law, I died to the law so that I might live for God.
48:2:20/I have been crucified with Christ and I no longer live, but Christ lives in me. The life I now live in the body, I live by faith in the Son of God, who loved me and gave himself for me.
48:2:21/I do not set aside the grace of God, for if righteousness could be gained through the law, then Christ died for nothing.
48:3:1/Oh foolish Galatians, who has tricked you into not following the truth, when Jesus Christ was clearly portrayed among you as crucified?
48:3:2/I only want to ask you this: Did you receive the Spirit by following the law, or by believing what you heard?
48:3:3/Are you so foolish? After starting with the Spirit, are you now trying to become perfect by your own human effort?
48:3:4/Have you experienced so much for nothing—if it really was for nothing?
48:3:5/So, the one who provides you with the Spirit and works miracles among you, does he do it by the works of the law, or by your believing what you heard?
48:3:6/Just as Abraham believed God, and it was credited to him as righteousness.
48:3:7/Know then that those who have faith are the children of Abraham.
48:3:8/And the scripture, foreseeing that God would justify the Gentiles by faith, preached the gospel beforehand to Abraham, saying, "In you shall all nations be blessed."
48:3:9/So then, those who have faith are blessed along with Abraham, the man of faith.
48:3:10/For all who rely on the works of the law are under a curse, as it is written: "Cursed is everyone who does not continue to do everything written in the Book of the Law."
48:3:11/But it is clear that no one is justified before God by the law, because "The righteous will live by faith."
48:3:12/The law is not based on faith; on the contrary, it says, "The person who does these things will live by them."
48:3:13/Christ redeemed us from the curse of the law by becoming a curse for us, for it is written: "Cursed is everyone who is hung on a pole."
48:3:14/He did this so that the blessing of Abraham might come to the Gentiles through Christ Jesus, so that by faith we might receive the promise of the Spirit.
48:3:15/Brothers and sisters, let me take an example from everyday life. Just as no one can set aside or add to a human covenant that has been duly established, so it is in this case.
48:3:16/The promises were spoken to Abraham and to his seed. Scripture does not say "and to seeds," meaning many people, but "and to your seed," meaning one person, who is Christ.
48:3:17/What I mean is this: The law, introduced 430 years later, does not set aside the covenant previously established by God and thus do away with the promise.
48:3:18/For if the inheritance depends on the law, then it no longer depends on the promise; but God in his grace gave it to Abraham through a promise.
48:3:19/Why, then, was the law given at all? It was added because of transgressions until the Seed to whom the promise referred had come. The law was given through angels and entrusted to a mediator.
48:3:20/A mediator, however, implies more than one party; but God is one.
48:3:21/Is the law, therefore, opposed to the promises of God? Absolutely not! For if a law had been given that could impart life, then righteousness would certainly have come by the law.
48:3:22/But Scripture has locked up everything under the control of sin, so that what was promised, being given through faith in Jesus Christ, might be given to those who believe.
48:3:23/Before faith came, we were held in custody under the law, locked up until the faith that was to come would be revealed.
48:3:24/So the law was our guardian until Christ came that we might be justified by faith.
48:3:25/But now that faith has come, we are no longer under a guardian.
48:3:26/For you are all children of God through faith in Christ Jesus.
48:3:27/For all of you who were baptized into Christ have clothed yourselves with Christ.
48:3:28/There is neither Jew nor Greek, there is neither slave nor free, there is no male and female, for you are all one in Christ Jesus.
48:3:29/And if you belong to Christ, then you are Abraham's seed, and heirs according to the promise.
48:4:1/Now I'm saying, the heir, as long as they are a child, is no different from a servant, even though they are the master of everything;
48:4:2/But is under guardians and managers until the time set by the father.
48:4:3/In the same way, when we were children, we were enslaved to the basic principles of the world.
48:4:4/But when the right time came, God sent his Son, born of a woman, born under the law,
48:4:5/To free those who were under the law, so that we might become God's children.
48:4:6/And because you are children, God sent the Spirit of his Son into our hearts, calling out, "Father, my Father."
48:4:7/Therefore, you are no longer a servant, but a child; and if a child, then an heir through God in Christ.
48:4:8/However, back then, when you didn't know God, you served those who are not really gods at all.
48:4:9/But now, after getting to know God—or rather being known by God—how can you turn back to those weak and worthless principles, wanting to be enslaved by them all over again?
48:4:10/You observe special days, months, seasons, and years.
48:4:11/I'm worried about you, that perhaps I have wasted my efforts on you.
48:4:12/Brothers and sisters, I urge you to be like me, because I am like you. You have done me no wrong.
48:4:13/You know that it was because of an illness that I first preached the gospel to you.
48:4:14/And even though my illness was a trial to you, you did not treat me with contempt or scorn. Instead, you welcomed me as if I were an angel of God, as if I were Christ Jesus himself.
48:4:15/What has happened to all your joy? I can testify that if it had been possible, you would have torn out your eyes and given them to me.
48:4:16/So have I become your enemy by telling you the truth?
48:4:17/They are zealous to win you over, but for no good. What they want is to alienate you from us, so that you may have zeal for them.
48:4:18/It's good to be zealous, provided the purpose is good, and to be so always, not just when I am with you.
48:4:19/My dear children, for whom I am again in the pains of childbirth until Christ is formed in you,
48:4:20/I wish I could be with you now and change my tone, because I am perplexed about you.
48:4:21/Tell me, you who want to be under the law, don't you listen to the law?
48:4:22/For it is written that Abraham had two sons, one by the slave woman and the other by the free woman.
48:4:23/But the son by the slave woman was born according to the flesh, while the son by the free woman was born through promise.
48:4:24/These things are symbolic. For these women are two covenants. One is from Mount Sinai, bearing children for slavery; she is Hagar.
48:4:25/Now Hagar stands for Mount Sinai in Arabia and corresponds to the present Jerusalem, for she is in slavery with her children.
48:4:26/But the Jerusalem above is free, and she is our mother.
48:4:27/For it is written, "Rejoice, barren woman who does not give birth; shout for joy and cry out, you who are not in labor! For the children of the desolate woman will be more numerous than those of the woman who has a husband."
48:4:28/Now you, brothers and sisters, like Isaac, are children of promise.
48:4:29/At that time the son born according to the flesh persecuted the son born by the power of the Spirit. It is the same now.
48:4:30/But what does the Scripture say? "Get rid of the slave woman and her son, for the son of the slave woman will not share the inheritance with the son of the free woman."
48:4:31/So then, brothers and sisters, we are not children of the slave woman, but of the free woman.
48:5:1/Therefore, stand firm in the freedom Christ has given us, and don't get caught up again in a life of bondage.
48:5:2/Listen, I, Paul, am telling you that if you get circumcised, Christ won't be of any benefit to you.
48:5:3/I'm saying it again to anyone who gets circumcised: you're obligated to follow the entire law.
48:5:4/If you try to be justified by the law, Christ won't mean anything to you; you've lost your connection to grace.
48:5:5/Through the Spirit, we eagerly await the righteousness we hope for, which comes through faith.
48:5:6/In Jesus Christ, it doesn't matter whether you are circumcised or not; what matters is faith expressing itself through love.
48:5:7/You were doing so well; who stopped you from following the truth?
48:5:8/This kind of persuasion doesn't come from the One who calls you.
48:5:9/Just a little yeast works through the whole batch of dough.
48:5:10/I'm confident in the Lord that you will take no other view. The one who is troubling you will face punishment, whoever they are.
48:5:11/And if I'm still preaching circumcision, why am I still being persecuted? In that case, the offense of the cross has been eliminated.
48:5:12/I wish those who unsettle you would castrate themselves!
48:5:13/Brothers and sisters, you were called to be free; but don't use your freedom to indulge the flesh. Instead, serve one another humbly in love.
48:5:14/The entire law is fulfilled in keeping this one command: "Love your neighbor as yourself."
48:5:15/But if you bite and devour each other, watch out or you will be destroyed by each other.
48:5:16/So I say, live by the Spirit, and you will not gratify the desires of the flesh.
48:5:17/For the flesh desires what is contrary to the Spirit, and the Spirit what is contrary to the flesh. They are in conflict with each other, so you are not to do whatever you want.
48:5:18/But if you are led by the Spirit, you are not under the law.
48:5:19/Now the acts of the flesh are obvious: sexual immorality, impurity, debauchery,
48:5:20/idolatry, sorcery, hostility, quarreling, jealousy, outbursts of anger, selfish ambition, dissension, division,
48:5:21/envy, murder, drunkenness, wild parties, and things like these. I warn you, as I did before, that those who live like this will not inherit the kingdom of God.
48:5:22/But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness,
48:5:23/gentleness, and self-control. Against such things there is no law.
48:5:24/Those who belong to Christ Jesus have nailed the passions and desires of the flesh to the cross.
48:5:25/If we live by the Spirit, let's also keep in step with the Spirit.
48:5:26/Let's not become conceited, provoking and envying each other.
48:6:1/Friends, if someone is caught in a mistake, those of you who are spiritual should help that person back on the right path gently. But watch yourself, or you might also be tempted.
48:6:2/Help carry each other's burdens, and in this way, you will fulfill the law of Christ.
48:6:3/If anyone thinks they are something when they are not, they deceive themselves.
48:6:4/But each person should test their own actions. Then they can take pride in themselves alone, without comparing themselves to someone else.
48:6:5/For each person will have to carry their own load.
48:6:6/Those who receive instruction in the word should share all good things with their instructor.
48:6:7/Do not be misled; God cannot be mocked. A person reaps what they sow.
48:6:8/Those who sow to please their flesh, from the flesh will reap destruction; but those who sow to please the Spirit, from the Spirit will reap eternal life.
48:6:9/Let's not get tired of doing what is good. At just the right time we will reap a harvest if we don't give up.
48:6:10/Therefore, whenever we have the opportunity, let's do good to everyone, especially to those in the family of faith.
48:6:11/You see how large a letter I have written to you with my own hand.
48:6:12/Those who want to make a good impression outwardly are trying to compel you to be circumcised. The only reason they do this is to avoid being persecuted for the cross of Christ.
48:6:13/For even those who are circumcised do not themselves keep the law, but they want you to be circumcised so that they can boast about your flesh.
48:6:14/But as for me, may I never boast about anything except the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ, through which the world has been crucified to me, and I to the world.
48:6:15/For neither circumcision nor uncircumcision means anything; what counts is the new creation.
48:6:16/Peace and mercy to all who follow this rule—to the Israel of God.
48:6:17/From now on, let no one cause me trouble, for I bear on my body the marks of Jesus.
48:6:18/Brothers and sisters, may the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit. Amen.
49:1:1/Paul, an apostle of Jesus Christ by God's will, to the saints in Ephesus, and to those faithful in Christ Jesus:
49:1:2/May grace and peace be yours, from God our Father, and from the Lord Jesus Christ.
49:1:3/Praise be to the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who has blessed us with every spiritual blessing in the heavenly realms in Christ:
49:1:4/He chose us in him before the creation of the world to be holy and blameless in his sight, out of love:
49:1:5/He predestined us for adoption to sonship through Jesus Christ, in accordance with his pleasure and will,
49:1:6/To the praise of his glorious grace, which he has freely given us in the One he loves.
49:1:7/In him we have redemption through his blood, the forgiveness of sins, in accordance with the riches of God's grace
49:1:8/That he lavished on us. With all wisdom and understanding,
49:1:9/He made known to us the mystery of his will according to his good pleasure, which he purposed in Christ,
49:1:10/To be put into effect when the times reach their fulfillment—to bring unity to all things in heaven and on earth under Christ.
49:1:11/In him we were also chosen, having been predestined according to the plan of him who works out everything in conformity with the purpose of his will,
49:1:12/So that we, who were the first to put our hope in Christ, might be for the praise of his glory.
49:1:13/And you also were included in Christ when you heard the message of truth, the gospel of your salvation. When you believed, you were marked in him with a seal, the promised Holy Spirit,
49:1:14/Who is a deposit guaranteeing our inheritance until the redemption of those who are God's possession—to the praise of his glory.
49:1:15/That's why, after hearing about your faith in the Lord Jesus and your love for all the saints,
49:1:16/I have not stopped giving thanks for you, remembering you in my prayers.
49:1:17/I keep asking that the God of our Lord Jesus Christ, the glorious Father, may give you the Spirit of wisdom and revelation, so you can know him better.
49:1:18/I pray that the eyes of your heart may be enlightened in order that you may know the hope to which he has called you, the riches of his glorious inheritance in his holy people,
49:1:19/And his incomparably great power for us who believe. That power is the same as the mighty strength
49:1:20/He exerted when he raised Christ from the dead and seated him at his right hand in the heavenly realms,
49:1:21/Far above all rule and authority, power and dominion, and every name that is invoked, not only in the present age but also in the one to come.
49:1:22/And God placed all things under his feet and appointed him to be head over everything for the church,
49:1:23/Which is his body, the fullness of him who fills everything in every way.
49:2:1/And you, he has made alive, who were dead in your wrongdoings and sins;
49:2:2/In which you once lived following the ways of this world, under the influence of the ruler of the kingdom of the air, the spirit that is now at work in those who disobey.
49:2:3/Among them, we too all previously lived, indulging in the cravings of our flesh, following its desires and thoughts. Like the rest, we were naturally deserving of wrath.
49:2:4/But God, being rich in mercy, because of the great love with which he loved us,
49:2:5/Even when we were dead in our sins, made us alive together with Christ - by grace you have been saved -
