56:2:1/But talk about the things that align with healthy teaching:
56:2:2/Encourage older men to be self-controlled, dignified, wise, strong in faith, in love, and in endurance.
56:2:3/Similarly, older women should behave in a way that reflects holiness, not spreading rumors, not overindulging in wine, and teaching what is good.
56:2:4/So they can guide younger women to be self-controlled, to love their husbands and children,
56:2:5/To be sensible, pure, managing their households well, kind, and to be supportive of their husbands, so that no one can criticize the word of God.
56:2:6/Encourage young men as well to be level-headed.
56:2:7/Show yourself as an example of good actions in everything. In your teaching show integrity, seriousness, and sincerity,
56:2:8/Use speech that is beyond reproach, so that anyone opposing you may be embarrassed because they have nothing bad to say about us.
56:2:9/Urge workers to be respectful to their employers, to try to please them in every way, not talking back,
56:2:10/Not stealing, but showing that they can be completely trusted, so that in every way they will make the teaching about God our Savior attractive.
56:2:11/For the grace of God has appeared, bringing salvation for all people,
56:2:12/Teaching us to say "No" to ungodliness and worldly passions, and to live self-controlled, upright, and godly lives in this current age,
56:2:13/While we wait for the blessed hope—the appearing of the glory of our great God and Savior, Jesus Christ,
56:2:14/Who gave himself for us to redeem us from all wickedness and to purify for himself a people that are his very own, eager to do what is good.
56:2:15/Talk about these things, encourage, and correct with full authority. Don't let anyone disregard you.
56:3:1/Remind them to respect and obey those in authority, to follow the laws, and to be ready to do good deeds,
56:3:2/To not badmouth anyone, to avoid fighting, but to be gentle, showing kindness to everyone.
56:3:3/For we were once foolish, disobedient, misled, chasing after various desires and pleasures, living in malice and jealousy, detestable, and detesting one another.
56:3:4/But then the kindness and love of God our Savior for humanity was revealed,
56:3:5/Not because of righteous deeds we had done, but because of His mercy He saved us, through the cleansing of a new birth and renewal by the Holy Spirit,
56:3:6/Whom He poured out on us generously through Jesus Christ our Savior,
56:3:7/So that, being justified by His grace, we might become heirs having the hope of eternal life.
56:3:8/This saying is trustworthy, and I want you to insist on these things, so that those who have believed in God may be careful to devote themselves to good deeds. These things are beneficial for everyone.
56:3:9/But avoid foolish debates, genealogies, arguments, and quarrels about the law, because they are unproductive and useless.
56:3:10/Reject a divisive person after a first and second warning,
56:3:11/Knowing that such a person is warped and sinful; they condemn themselves.
56:3:12/When I send Artemas or Tychicus to you, make every effort to come to me in Nicopolis, for I have decided to spend the winter there.
56:3:13/Help Zenas the lawyer and Apollos on their journey thoroughly, so that they lack nothing.
56:3:14/And let our people also learn to engage in good deeds to meet urgent needs, so that they will not be unproductive.
56:3:15/Everyone with me sends you greetings. Greet those who love us in the faith. May grace be with you all. Amen.
57:1:1/Paul, a prisoner of Jesus Christ, and Timothy our brother, to Philemon our dearly beloved, and fellow worker,
57:1:2/And to our beloved Apphia, and Archippus our fellow soldier, and to the church in your house:
57:1:3/Grace to you, and peace, from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
57:1:4/I thank my God, always mentioning you in my prayers,
57:1:5/Hearing of your love and faith, which you have toward the Lord Jesus, and toward all the saints;
57:1:6/So that the sharing of your faith may become effective by recognizing every good thing that is in you in Christ Jesus.
57:1:7/For we have great joy and comfort in your love, because you, brother, have refreshed the hearts of the saints.
57:1:8/Therefore, although I could be very bold in Christ to command you to do what is proper,
57:1:9/I prefer to appeal to you out of love, being such a person as Paul, now an old man, and also a prisoner of Jesus Christ.
57:1:10/I appeal to you for my son Onesimus, whom I have fathered while in my chains,
57:1:11/Who in the past was useless to you, but now is useful to both you and me.
57:1:12/I am sending him back to you, sending my very heart.
57:1:13/I wanted to keep him with me, so that on your behalf he might serve me while I am in chains for the gospel.
57:1:14/But I didn't want to do anything without your consent, so that your good deed might not be by compulsion, but of your own free will.
57:1:15/Perhaps he was separated from you for a while for this reason, that you might have him back forever,
57:1:16/No longer as a slave, but more than a slave, a beloved brother, especially to me, but how much more to you, both in the flesh and in the Lord.
57:1:17/If you consider me a partner, welcome him as you would welcome me.
57:1:18/If he has wronged you in any way, or owes you anything, charge that to my account;
57:1:19/I, Paul, am writing this with my own hand, I will repay it—to say nothing of your owing me even your own self.
57:1:20/Yes, brother, let me benefit from you in the Lord; refresh my heart in the Lord.
57:1:21/Confident of your obedience, I write to you, knowing that you will do even more than I say.
57:1:22/And also, prepare a guest room for me, for I hope that through your prayers I will be graciously given to you.
57:1:23/Epaphras, my fellow prisoner in Christ Jesus, sends you greetings;
57:1:24/Mark, Aristarchus, Demas, Luke, my fellow workers, send you their greetings.
57:1:25/The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit. Amen.
58:1:1/God, who at various times and in different ways spoke in the past to our ancestors through the prophets,
58:1:2/Has in these last days spoken to us through his Son, whom he has appointed heir of everything, through whom he also created the universe.
58:1:3/Who being the radiance of his glory, and the exact representation of his being, and sustaining all things by his powerful word, after he had provided purification for sins, sat down at the right hand of the Majesty in heaven.
58:1:4/Becoming so much superior to the angels, as he has inherited a name more excellent than theirs.
58:1:5/For to which of the angels did God ever say, "You are my Son, today I have become your Father"? Or again, "I will be his Father, and he will be my Son"?
58:1:6/And again, when he brings the firstborn into the world, he says, "Let all God's angels worship him."
58:1:7/Regarding the angels he says, "He makes his angels spirits, and his servants flames of fire."
58:1:8/But to the Son he says, "Your throne, O God, will last forever and ever; a scepter of justice will be the scepter of your kingdom."
58:1:9/You have loved righteousness and hated wickedness; therefore God, your God, has set you above your companions by anointing you with the oil of joy.
58:1:10/And, "You, Lord, laid the foundation of the earth in the beginning, and the heavens are the work of your hands;
58:1:11/They will perish, but you remain; they will all wear out like a garment;
58:1:12/You will roll them up like a robe; like a garment they will be changed. But you are the same, and your years will never end."
58:1:13/But to which of the angels has he ever said, "Sit at my right hand until I make your enemies a footstool for your feet"?
58:1:14/Aren't they all ministering spirits, sent out to serve for the sake of those who are to inherit salvation?
58:2:1/So, we should pay much closer attention to what we have heard, to prevent us from drifting away.
58:2:2/Because if the message delivered by angels was binding, and every violation and disobedience received a fair punishment;
58:2:3/How can we possibly escape if we ignore such a great salvation? This salvation, which was first announced by the Lord, was confirmed to us by those who heard him.
58:2:4/God also testified to it by signs, wonders, various miracles, and gifts of the Holy Spirit, distributed according to his will.
58:2:5/He did not subject the coming world, about which we are speaking, to angels.
58:2:6/But someone has testified somewhere, saying, "What is mankind that you are mindful of them, or the son of man that you care for him?
58:2:7/You made him a little lower than the angels; you crowned him with glory and honor and put everything under his feet."
58:2:8/In putting everything under him, God left nothing that is not subject to him. Yet at present, we do not see everything subject to him.
58:2:9/But we do see Jesus, who was made a little lower than the angels, now crowned with glory and honor because he suffered death, so that by the grace of God he might taste death for everyone.
58:2:10/It was fitting for him, for whom and through whom everything exists, in bringing many children to glory, to perfect the pioneer of their salvation through sufferings.
58:2:11/For both the one who makes people holy and those who are made holy are of the same family. So Jesus is not ashamed to call them brothers and sisters,
58:2:12/Saying, "I will proclaim your name to my brothers and sisters; in the assembly I will sing your praises."
58:2:13/And again, "I will put my trust in him." And again, "Here am I, and the children God has given me."
58:2:14/Since the children have flesh and blood, he too shared in their humanity so that by his death he might break the power of him who holds the power of death—that is, the devil—
58:2:15/And free those who all their lives were held in slavery by their fear of death.
58:2:16/For surely it is not angels he helps, but Abraham's descendants.
58:2:17/For this reason he had to be made like them, fully human in every way, in order that he might become a merciful and faithful high priest in service to God, and that he might make atonement for the sins of the people.
58:2:18/Because he himself suffered when he was tempted, he is able to help those who are being tempted.
58:3:1/Therefore, dear brothers and sisters, who share in the heavenly calling, pay attention to the Apostle and High Priest of our faith, Jesus Christ;
58:3:2/He was loyal to the one who appointed him, just as Moses was loyal in all God's household.
58:3:3/This man, Jesus, was considered more glorious than Moses because the builder of a house has more honor than the house itself.
58:3:4/Indeed, every house is built by someone, but God is the builder of everything.
58:3:5/And Moses was indeed faithful in all God's household as a servant, to bear witness to what would be spoken later;
58:3:6/But Christ is faithful as a son over his own house; and we are his house, if we hold firmly to our confidence and the joy of our hope until the end.
58:3:7/Therefore, as the Holy Spirit says, "Today, if you hear his voice,
58:3:8/Do not harden your hearts as you did during the rebellion, on the day of testing in the desert,
58:3:9/Where your ancestors tested and tried me, though they had seen my works for forty years.
58:3:10/That is why I was angry with that generation and said, 'Their hearts always go astray, and they have not known my ways.'
58:3:11/So in my anger, I took an oath: 'They shall never enter my rest.'"
58:3:12/Be careful, brothers and sisters, that none of you has a sinful, unbelieving heart that turns away from the living God.
58:3:13/But encourage one another daily, as long as it is called "Today," so that none of you may be hardened by sin's deceitfulness.
58:3:14/We have come to share in Christ, if indeed we hold our original conviction firmly to the very end.
58:3:15/As it has been said, "Today, if you hear his voice, do not harden your hearts as you did in the rebellion."
58:3:16/Indeed, some who heard the message provoked God. However, not all who came out of Egypt with Moses did so.
58:3:17/But with whom was God angry for forty years? Was it not with those who sinned, whose bodies perished in the wilderness?
58:3:18/And to whom did God swear that they would never enter his rest if not to those who disobeyed?
58:3:19/So we see that they were unable to enter because of unbelief.
58:4:1/So, let's be cautious, because there's a promise of entering into his rest, and we wouldn't want any of you to miss out.
58:4:2/The good news was shared with us just as it was with them. However, the message they heard didn't benefit them because they didn't mix it with faith.
58:4:3/For those of us who have believed are entering that rest, as he has said, "I swore in my anger, they shall never enter my rest," even though his works were completed from the creation of the world.
58:4:4/He mentioned the seventh day specifically, saying, "And on the seventh day, God rested from all his works."
58:4:5/And again, in this context, "They shall never enter my rest."
58:4:6/It still stands that some will enter that rest, and those who first heard the good news failed to enter because of their disbelief.
58:4:7/He sets a specific day, "Today," through David after such a long time; as it has been said, "Today, if you hear his voice, do not harden your hearts."
58:4:8/If Joshua had given them rest, God would not have spoken about another day later on.
58:4:9/So, there is still a rest available for the people of God.
58:4:10/For anyone who enters God's rest also rests from their works, just as God did from his.
58:4:11/Therefore, let's make every effort to enter that rest, so that no one will fall by following their example of disobedience.
58:4:12/For the word of God is alive and active, sharper than any double-edged sword, it penetrates even to dividing soul and spirit, joints and marrow; it judges the thoughts and attitudes of the heart.
58:4:13/And there is no creature hidden from his sight, but all are naked and exposed to the eyes of him to whom we must give account.
58:4:14/Since we have a great high priest who has ascended into heaven, Jesus the Son of God, let's hold firmly to the faith we profess.
58:4:15/For we do not have a high priest who is unable to empathize with our weaknesses, but we have one who has been tempted in every way, just as we are—yet he did not sin.
58:4:16/So, let's approach the throne of grace with confidence, so that we may receive mercy and find grace to help us in our time of need.
58:5:1/Every high priest is chosen from among people to serve on behalf of others in matters related to God, so that he can offer gifts and sacrifices for sins.
58:5:2/He can empathize with those who are ignorant or have strayed because he himself is also subject to weakness.
58:5:3/And for this reason, he must offer sacrifices for sins, not just for the people, but also for himself.
58:5:4/And no one takes this honor on himself, but he receives it when called by God, just as Aaron was.
58:5:5/In the same way, Christ did not glorify himself to become a high priest, but God said to him, "You are my Son; today I have become your father."
58:5:6/As he also says in another passage, "You are a priest forever, in the order of Melchizedek."
58:5:7/In his earthly life, he offered prayers and pleas with loud cries and tears to the one who could save him from death, and he was heard because of his reverent submission.
58:5:8/Although he was a Son, he learned obedience from what he suffered.
58:5:9/And having been perfected, he became the source of eternal salvation for all who obey him,
58:5:10/Being designated by God as a high priest according to the order of Melchizedek.
58:5:11/We have much to say about this, but it's difficult to explain because you have become slow to understand.
58:5:12/By now, you should be teachers, but you need someone to teach you the basic principles of God's word all over again. You need milk, not solid food.
58:5:13/Anyone who lives on milk, being still an infant, is not acquainted with the teaching about righteousness.
58:5:14/But solid food is for the mature, who by constant use have trained themselves to distinguish good from evil.
58:6:1/So, let's move beyond the basic teachings about Christ and advance toward maturity, not laying again the groundwork of turning away from useless actions and believing in God,
58:6:2/Including teachings about different baptisms, laying on of hands, the resurrection of the dead, and eternal judgment.
58:6:3/And we will do this, if God allows.
58:6:4/For it's impossible for those who have once been enlightened, experienced the heavenly gift, and shared in the Holy Spirit,
58:6:5/And have savored the good message of God and the powers of the coming age,
58:6:6/If they fall away, to bring them back to repentance, since they are re-crucifying the Son of God for themselves and publicly disgracing him.
58:6:7/Just as the earth absorbs the rain that frequently falls on it and produces useful crops for those who farm it, receiving blessings from God,
58:6:8/But land that produces thorns and thistles is worthless and close to being cursed; its end is to be burned.
58:6:9/However, dear friends, we are convinced of better things in your case—things that have to do with salvation, even though we speak like this.
58:6:10/For God is not unjust; he will not forget your work and the love you have shown him as you have helped his people and continue to help them.
58:6:11/And we want each of you to show this same diligence to the very end, so that what you hope for may be fully realized.
58:6:12/We don't want you to become lazy, but to imitate those who through faith and patience inherit what has been promised.
58:6:13/When God made his promise to Abraham, since there was no one greater for him to swear by, he swore by himself,
58:6:14/Saying, "I will surely bless you and give you many descendants."
58:6:15/And so, after waiting patiently, Abraham received what was promised.
58:6:16/People swear by someone greater than themselves, and the oath confirms what is said and puts an end to all argument.
58:6:17/Because God wanted to make the unchanging nature of his purpose very clear to the heirs of what was promised, he confirmed it with an oath.
58:6:18/So that by two unchangeable things, in which it is impossible for God to lie, we who have fled to take hold of the hope set before us may be greatly encouraged.
58:6:19/We have this hope as an anchor for the soul, firm and secure. It enters the inner sanctuary behind the curtain,
58:6:20/Where Jesus, who went before us, has entered on our behalf. He has become a high priest forever, in the order of Melchizedek.
58:7:1/For this Melchisedec, king of Salem, priest of the most high God, met Abraham as he was returning from defeating the kings and blessed him.
58:7:2/To whom Abraham also gave a tenth of everything. He was first named King of Righteousness, and then also King of Salem, meaning King of Peace.
58:7:3/He had no father or mother, no genealogy, no beginning of days or end of life, resembling the Son of God, he remains a priest forever.
58:7:4/Now think about how great this man was, to whom even the patriarch Abraham gave a tenth of the plunder.
58:7:5/Indeed, those who are descendants of Levi, who receive the priestly office, have a command to collect a tenth from the people according to the law, that is, from their own brothers, even though they also are descended from Abraham.
58:7:6/But this man, whose lineage is not traced from them, collected a tenth from Abraham and blessed him who had received the promises.
58:7:7/And without any doubt, the lesser is blessed by the greater.
58:7:8/Here mortal men receive tithes, but there he receives them, of whom it is testified that he lives.
58:7:9/And, so to speak, through Abraham even Levi, who receives tithes, paid tithes.
58:7:10/For he was still in the body of his ancestor when Melchisedec met him.
58:7:11/If perfection could have been attained through the Levitical priesthood—and indeed the law given to the people established that priesthood—why was there still need for another priest to come, one in the order of Melchisedec, not in the order of Aaron?
58:7:12/For when there is a change in the priesthood, there must also be a change in the law.
58:7:13/He of whom these things are said belonged to a different tribe, and no one from that tribe has ever served at the altar.
58:7:14/For it is clear that our Lord descended from Judah, and in regard to that tribe Moses said nothing about priests.
58:7:15/And what we have said is even more clear if another priest like Melchisedec appears,
58:7:16/One who has become a priest not on the basis of a regulation as to his ancestry but on the basis of the power of an indestructible life.
58:7:17/For it is declared: "You are a priest forever, in the order of Melchisedec."
58:7:18/The former regulation is set aside because it was weak and useless
58:7:19/(for the law made nothing perfect), and a better hope is introduced, by which we draw near to God.
58:7:20/And it was not without an oath! Others became priests without any oath,
58:7:21/but he became a priest with an oath when God said to him: "The Lord has sworn and will not change his mind: 'You are a priest forever.'"
58:7:22/Because of this oath, Jesus has become the guarantor of a better covenant.
58:7:23/Now there have been many of those priests, since death prevented them from continuing in office;
58:7:24/but because Jesus lives forever, he has a permanent priesthood.
58:7:25/Therefore, he is able to save completely those who come to God through him, because he always lives to intercede for them.
58:7:26/Such a high priest truly meets our need—one who is holy, blameless, pure, set apart from sinners, exalted above the heavens.
58:7:27/Unlike the other high priests, he does not need to offer sacrifices day after day, first for his own sins, and then for the sins of the people. He sacrificed for their sins once for all when he offered himself.
58:7:28/For the law appoints as high priests men in all their weakness; but the oath, which came after the law, appointed the Son, who has been made perfect forever.
58:8:1/To sum up what we've discussed: We have a high priest seated at the right hand of the throne of the Majesty in heaven.
58:8:2/This high priest serves in the sanctuary and the true tent set up by the Lord, not by humans.
58:8:3/Every high priest is appointed to offer gifts and sacrifices, so it's necessary for this one to have something to offer as well.
58:8:4/If he were on earth, he wouldn't be a priest at all, since there are already priests who offer gifts according to the law.
58:8:5/These serve as a copy and shadow of the heavenly things, just as Moses was warned by God when he was about to build the tabernacle: "Make sure you make everything according to the pattern shown to you on the mountain."
58:8:6/But now, he has obtained a more excellent ministry, by so much more as he is also the mediator of a better covenant, which has been enacted on better promises.
58:8:7/If the first covenant had been perfect, there would have been no need for a second one.
58:8:8/But God found fault with the people and said: "The days are coming, declares the Lord, when I will make a new covenant with the house of Israel and with the house of Judah."
58:8:9/It won't be like the covenant I made with their ancestors when I took them by the hand to lead them out of Egypt, because they didn't remain faithful to my covenant, and I turned away from them, says the Lord.
58:8:10/This is the covenant I will establish with the house of Israel after that time, declares the Lord: I will put my laws in their minds and write them on their hearts. I will be their God, and they will be my people.
58:8:11/No longer will they teach their neighbor, or say to one another, 'Know the Lord,' because they will all know me, from the least of them to the greatest.
58:8:12/For I will forgive their wickedness and will remember their sins no more.
58:8:13/By calling this covenant "new," he has made the first one obsolete; and what is obsolete and aging will soon disappear.
58:9:1/Indeed, the first agreement also had its own rituals of worship and a physical place of worship.
58:9:2/There was a tent set up; the first part contained the lampstand, the table, and the consecrated bread; this is known as the sanctuary.
58:9:3/Beyond the second curtain was the tent called the Most Holy Place;
58:9:4/Which housed the golden incense altar, and the ark of the covenant covered all around with gold, in which was the golden jar holding manna, Aaron’s rod that sprouted, and the stone tablets of the covenant;
58:9:5/And above it were the cherubim of glory overshadowing the atonement cover; about these things we cannot now go into detail.
58:9:6/When everything had been arranged like this, the priests always entered the first part of the tent to carry out their religious duties.
58:9:7/But only the high priest entered the inner room, and that only once a year, and never without blood, which he offered for himself and for the sins the people had committed in ignorance.
58:9:8/The Holy Spirit was showing by this that the way into the Most Holy Place had not yet been disclosed as long as the first tent was still functioning.
58:9:9/This is an illustration for the present time, indicating that the gifts and sacrifices being offered were not able to clear the conscience of the worshiper.
58:9:10/They are only a matter of food and drink and various ceremonial washings—external regulations applying until the time of the new order.
58:9:11/But Christ has come as the high priest of the good things that are now already here, by a greater and more perfect tent not made with human hands, that is to say, not a part of this creation.
58:9:12/He did not enter by means of the blood of goats and calves; but he entered the Most Holy Place once for all by his own blood, thus securing eternal redemption.
58:9:13/For if the blood of goats and bulls and the ashes of a heifer sprinkling those who are ceremonially unclean sanctify them so that they are outwardly clean,
58:9:14/How much more, then, will the blood of Christ, who through the eternal Spirit offered himself unblemished to God, cleanse our consciences from acts that lead to death, so that we may serve the living God!
58:9:15/For this reason Christ is the mediator of a new covenant, that those who are called may receive the promised eternal inheritance—now that he has died as a ransom to set them free from the sins committed under the first covenant.
58:9:16/In the case of a will, it is necessary to prove the death of the one who made it,
58:9:17/Because a will is in force only when somebody has died; it never takes effect while the one who made it is alive.
58:9:18/This is why even the first covenant was not put into effect without blood.
58:9:19/When Moses had proclaimed every command of the law to all the people, he took the blood of calves, together with water, scarlet wool, and branches of hyssop, and sprinkled the scroll and all the people,
58:9:20/Saying, "This is the blood of the covenant which God has commanded you to keep."
58:9:21/In the same way, he sprinkled with blood both the tent and all the vessels used in worship.
58:9:22/In fact, the law requires that nearly everything be cleansed with blood, and without the shedding of blood there is no forgiveness.
58:9:23/It was necessary, then, for the copies of the heavenly things to be purified with these sacrifices, but the heavenly things themselves with better sacrifices than these.
58:9:24/For Christ did not enter a sanctuary made with human hands that was only a copy of the true one; he entered heaven itself, now to appear for us in God's presence.
58:9:25/Nor did he enter heaven to offer himself again and again, the way the high priest enters the Most Holy Place every year with blood that is not his own.
58:9:26/Otherwise, Christ would have had to suffer many times since the creation of the world. But now he has appeared once for all at the culmination of the ages to do away with sin by the sacrifice of himself.
58:9:27/Just as people are destined to die once, and after that to face judgment,
58:9:28/So Christ was sacrificed once to take away the sins of many; and he will appear a second time, not to bear sin, but to bring salvation to those who are waiting for him.
58:10:1/The law, being a shadow of the good things to come and not the actual form of those realities, can never make those who approach perfect through the same sacrifices they continually offer year after year.
58:10:2/Otherwise, wouldn't they have stopped being offered, since the worshippers, once cleansed, would no longer have any consciousness of sins?
58:10:3/But in those sacrifices, there is a yearly reminder of sins.
58:10:4/It's impossible for the blood of bulls and goats to take away sins.
58:10:5/Therefore, when he comes into the world, he says, "You did not desire sacrifice and offering, but you have prepared a body for me;
58:10:6/You took no pleasure in burnt offerings and sin offerings."
58:10:7/Then I said, 'Here I am—it is written about me in the scroll—I have come to do your will, O God.'"
58:10:8/Previously saying, "Sacrifices and offerings, burnt offerings, and offerings for sin you did not desire, nor were you pleased with them" (which are offered according to the law),
58:10:9/then he added, "Here I am, I have come to do your will." He sets aside the first to establish the second.
58:10:10/And by that will, we have been made holy through the sacrifice of the body of Jesus Christ once for all.
58:10:11/Every priest stands daily at his service, offering repeatedly the same sacrifices, which can never take away sins.
58:10:12/But this man, after offering one sacrifice for sins forever, sat down at the right hand of God,
58:10:13/waiting from that time until his enemies should be made a footstool for his feet.
58:10:14/For by a single offering he has perfected for all time those who are being made holy.
58:10:15/The Holy Spirit also testifies to us about this. First he says:
58:10:16/"This is the covenant I will make with them after those days, declares the Lord: I will put my laws in their hearts, and I will write them on their minds,"
58:10:17/then he adds, "Their sins and lawless acts I will remember no more."
58:10:18/And where these have been forgiven, there is no longer any sacrifice for sin.
58:10:19/Therefore, brothers and sisters, since we have confidence to enter the Most Holy Place by the blood of Jesus,
58:10:20/by a new and living way opened for us through the curtain, that is, his body,
58:10:21/and since we have a great priest over the house of God,
58:10:22/let us draw near with a sincere heart and with the full assurance that faith brings, having our hearts sprinkled to cleanse us from a guilty conscience and having our bodies washed with pure water.
58:10:23/Let us hold unswervingly to the hope we profess, for he who promised is faithful.
58:10:24/And let us consider how we may spur one another on toward love and good deeds,
58:10:25/not giving up meeting together, as some are in the habit of doing, but encouraging one another—and all the more as you see the Day approaching.
58:10:26/For if we deliberately keep on sinning after we have received the knowledge of the truth, no sacrifice for sins is left,
58:10:27/but only a fearful expectation of judgment and of raging fire that will consume the enemies of God.
58:10:28/Anyone who rejected the law of Moses died without mercy on the testimony of two or three witnesses.
58:10:29/How much more severely do you think someone deserves to be punished who has trampled the Son of God underfoot, who has treated as an unholy thing the blood of the covenant that sanctified them, and who has insulted the Spirit of grace?
58:10:30/For we know the one who said, "It is mine to avenge; I will repay," and again, "The Lord will judge his people."
58:10:31/It is a dreadful thing to fall into the hands of the living God.
58:10:32/Remember those earlier days after you had received the light, when you endured a great conflict full of suffering;
58:10:33/sometimes you were publicly exposed to insult and persecution; at other times you stood side by side with those who were so treated.
58:10:34/You sympathized with those in prison and joyfully accepted the confiscation of your property, because you knew that you yourselves had better and lasting possessions.
58:10:35/So do not throw away your confidence; it will be richly rewarded.
58:10:36/You need to persevere so that when you have done the will of God, you will receive what he has promised.
58:10:37/For, "In just a little while, he who is coming will come and will not delay."
58:10:38/But my righteous one will live by faith. And if he shrinks back, I will not be pleased with him.
58:10:39/But we do not belong to those who shrink back and are destroyed, but to those who have faith and are saved.
58:11:1/Faith is the assurance of things hoped for, the conviction of things not seen.
58:11:2/Through faith, the elders were commended.
58:11:3/By faith, we understand that the universe was formed at God's command, so that what is seen was not made out of visible materials.
58:11:4/Through faith, Abel offered God a better sacrifice than Cain did. Through this, he was acknowledged as righteous, with God affirming his offerings. And through his faith, though he is dead, he still speaks.
58:11:5/Because of his faith, Enoch was taken away so that he did not experience death; he could not be found because God had taken him away. For before he was taken, he was commended as one who pleased God.
58:11:6/But without faith, it is impossible to please God, because anyone who comes to him must believe that he exists and that he rewards those who earnestly seek him.
58:11:7/By faith, Noah, when warned about things not yet seen, in holy fear built an ark to save his family. By his faith, he condemned the world and became heir of the righteousness that comes by faith.
58:11:8/By faith, Abraham obeyed when he was called to go to a place he would later receive as his inheritance, and he went, even though he did not know where he was going.
58:11:9/By faith, he made his home in the promised land like a stranger in a foreign country; he lived in tents, as did Isaac and Jacob, who were heirs with him of the same promise.
58:11:10/For he was looking forward to the city with foundations, whose architect and builder is God.
58:11:11/By faith, Sarah herself received power to conceive, even when she was past the age, since she considered him faithful who had promised.
58:11:12/And so from this one man, and he as good as dead, came descendants as numerous as the stars in the sky and as countless as the sand on the seashore.
58:11:13/All these people died still believing what God had promised them. They did not receive what was promised, but saw it all from a distance and welcomed it. They agreed that they were foreigners and nomads here on earth.
58:11:14/People who say such things show that they are looking for a country of their own.
58:11:15/If they had been thinking of the country they had left, they would have had opportunity to return.
58:11:16/Instead, they were longing for a better country—a heavenly one. Therefore, God is not ashamed to be called their God, for he has prepared a city for them.
58:11:17/By faith, Abraham, when tested, offered up Isaac—he who had received the promises was about to sacrifice his only son,
58:11:18/Of whom it was said, "Through Isaac your offspring will be reckoned."
58:11:19/Abraham reasoned that God could even raise the dead, and so in a manner of speaking, he did receive Isaac back from death.
58:11:20/By faith, Isaac blessed Jacob and Esau in regard to their future.
58:11:21/By faith, Jacob, when he was dying, blessed each of Joseph's sons, and worshiped as he leaned on the top of his staff.
58:11:22/By faith, Joseph, when his end was near, spoke about the exodus of the Israelites from Egypt and gave instructions concerning his bones.
58:11:23/By faith, Moses' parents hid him for three months after he was born, because they saw he was no ordinary child, and they were not afraid of the king's edict.
58:11:24/By faith, Moses, when he had grown up, refused to be known as the son of Pharaoh's daughter.
58:11:25/He chose to be mistreated along with the people of God rather than to enjoy the fleeting pleasures of sin.
58:11:26/He regarded disgrace for the sake of Christ as of greater value than the treasures of Egypt, because he was looking ahead to his reward.
58:11:27/By faith, he left Egypt, not fearing the king's anger; he persevered because he saw him who is invisible.
58:11:28/By faith, he kept the Passover and the application of blood, so that the destroyer of the firstborn would not touch the firstborn of Israel.
58:11:29/By faith, the people passed through the Red Sea as on dry land; but when the Egyptians tried to do so, they were drowned.
58:11:30/By faith, the walls of Jericho fell, after the army had marched around them for seven days.
58:11:31/By faith, the prostitute Rahab, because she welcomed the spies, was not killed with those who were disobedient.
58:11:32/And what more shall I say? I do not have time to tell about Gideon, Barak, Samson, Jephthah, David, Samuel, and the prophets,
58:11:33/Who through faith conquered kingdoms, administered justice, and gained what was promised; who shut the mouths of lions,
58:11:34/Quenched the fury of the flames, and escaped the edge of the sword; whose weakness was turned to strength; and who became powerful in battle and routed foreign armies.
58:11:35/Women received back their dead, raised to life again. There were others who were tortured, refusing to be released so that they might gain an even better resurrection.
58:11:36/Some faced jeers and flogging, and even chains and imprisonment.
58:11:37/They were put to death by stoning; they were sawed in two; they were killed by the sword. They went about in sheepskins and goatskins, destitute, persecuted and mistreated—
58:11:38/The world was not worthy of them. They wandered in deserts and mountains, living in caves and in holes in the ground.
58:11:39/And all these, though commended for their faith, did not receive what was promised,
58:11:40/Since God had planned something better for us so that only together with us would they be made perfect.
58:12:1/Therefore, since we are surrounded by such a huge crowd of witnesses, let's throw off every burden and the sin that so easily trips us up, and let's run with endurance the race that lies before us,
58:12:2/Focusing on Jesus, the pioneer and perfecter of our faith. For the joy awaiting him, he endured the cross, disregarding its shame, and has taken his seat at the right hand of God's throne.
58:12:3/Think about him who endured such opposition from sinners, so that you won't grow tired and give up.
58:12:4/You haven't yet resisted to the point of shedding your blood in your struggle against sin.
58:12:5/And you have forgotten the encouragement that addresses you as children: "My child, do not take lightly the Lord's discipline, and do not lose heart when he rebukes you,
58:12:6/For the Lord disciplines the one he loves, and he chastises every child he accepts."
58:12:7/If you endure discipline, God treats you as children. For what child is not disciplined by their father?
58:12:8/But if you are not disciplined—which everyone undergoes—then you are illegitimate, not true children.
58:12:9/Besides this, we have had earthly fathers who disciplined us and we respected them. Shouldn't we much more submit to the Father of spirits and live?
58:12:10/They disciplined us for a short time as they thought best; but God disciplines us for our good, that we may share in his holiness.
58:12:11/No discipline seems pleasant at the time, but painful. Later on, however, it produces a harvest of righteousness and peace for those who have been trained by it.
58:12:12/So, strengthen your drooping hands and weak knees.
58:12:13/Make straight paths for your feet, so that what is lame may not be dislocated but rather healed.
58:12:14/Strive for peace with everyone, and for the holiness without which no one will see the Lord.
58:12:15/Be careful that no one falls short of the grace of God; that no root of bitterness springs up and causes trouble, and by it many become defiled;
58:12:16/Make sure that no one is sexually immoral or godless like Esau, who for a single meal sold his inheritance rights as the oldest son.
58:12:17/Afterward, as you know, when he wanted to inherit this blessing, he was rejected. Even though he sought the blessing with tears, he could not change what he had done.
58:12:18/You have not come to a mountain that can be touched and that is burning with fire; to darkness, gloom and storm;
58:12:19/To the sound of a trumpet and a voice whose words made the hearers beg that no further word be spoken to them.
58:12:20/For they could not bear what was commanded: "If even an animal touches the mountain, it must be stoned to death."
58:12:21/The sight was so terrifying that Moses said, "I am trembling with fear."
58:12:22/But you have come to Mount Zion, to the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem, and to countless angels in joyful assembly,
58:12:23/To the church of the firstborn, whose names are written in heaven. You have come to God, the Judge of all, to the spirits of the righteous made perfect,
58:12:24/To Jesus the mediator of a new covenant, and to the sprinkled blood that speaks a better word than the blood of Abel.
58:12:25/Make sure you do not refuse the One who is speaking. For if those did not escape when they refused the one who warned them on earth, much less will we escape if we turn away from the One who warns from heaven.
58:12:26/His voice then shook the earth, but now he has promised, "Once more I will shake not only the earth but also the heavens."
58:12:27/This phrase, "Once more," indicates the removal of things that are shaken—that is, created things—so that what cannot be shaken may remain.
58:12:28/Therefore, since we are receiving a kingdom that cannot be shaken, let us be thankful, and so worship God acceptably with reverence and awe,
58:12:29/For our God is a consuming fire.
58:13:1/Keep showing love to each other as brothers and sisters.
58:13:2/Don't forget to welcome strangers, because by doing so, some have unknowingly welcomed angels.
58:13:3/Remember those who are imprisoned as if you were imprisoned with them, and those who are mistreated, since you are also in the body.
58:13:4/Marriage should be respected by all, and the marriage bed kept pure; for God will judge the sexually immoral and adulterers.
58:13:5/Keep your life free from the love of money, and be satisfied with what you have; for God has said, "I will never leave you nor forsake you."
58:13:6/So we can confidently say, "The Lord is my helper; I will not be afraid. What can anyone do to me?"
58:13:7/Remember your leaders, who spoke the word of God to you. Consider the outcome of their way of life and imitate their faith.
58:13:8/Jesus Christ is the same yesterday, today, and forever.
58:13:9/Don't be led away by various and strange teachings. It's good for the heart to be strengthened by grace, not by dietary rules, which haven't benefited those who follow them.
58:13:10/We have an altar from which those who serve the tent have no right to eat.
58:13:11/The bodies of those animals, whose blood is brought into the sanctuary by the high priest as a sacrifice for sin, are burned outside the camp.
58:13:12/Therefore, Jesus also suffered outside the city gate to make the people holy through his own blood.
58:13:13/Let's then go out to him outside the camp, bearing the disgrace he bore.
58:13:14/For here we do not have an enduring city, but we are looking for the city that is to come.
58:13:15/Through him, let us continually offer to God a sacrifice of praise—the fruit of lips that openly profess his name.
58:13:16/And don't forget to do good and to share with others, for with such sacrifices God is pleased.
58:13:17/Obey your leaders and submit to their authority. They keep watch over you as those who must give an account. Do this so that their work will be a joy, not a burden, for that would be of no benefit to you.
58:13:18/Pray for us; we are convinced that we have a clear conscience and desire to live honorably in every way.
58:13:19/I especially urge you to do this so that I may be restored to you sooner.
58:13:20/May the God of peace, who brought back from the dead our Lord Jesus, the great Shepherd of the sheep, through the blood of the eternal covenant,
58:13:21/equip you with everything good for doing his will, and may he work in us what is pleasing to him, through Jesus Christ, to whom be glory forever and ever. Amen.
58:13:22/I urge you, brothers and sisters, to bear with my word of exhortation, for I have written to you briefly.
58:13:23/Be aware that our brother Timothy has been released. If he arrives soon, I will come with him to see you.
58:13:24/Greet all your leaders and all the saints. Those from Italy send you their greetings.
58:13:25/May grace be with you all. Amen.
59:1:1/James, a servant of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ, sends greetings to the twelve tribes scattered around the world.
59:1:2/My brothers and sisters, consider it pure joy whenever you face various trials;
59:1:3/Knowing that the testing of your faith produces perseverance.
59:1:4/But let perseverance finish its work so that you may be mature and complete, not lacking anything.
59:1:5/If any of you lacks wisdom, you should ask God, who gives generously to all without finding fault, and it will be given to you.
59:1:6/But when you ask, you must believe and not doubt, because the one who doubts is like a wave of the sea, blown and tossed by the wind.
59:1:7/That person should not expect to receive anything from the Lord.
59:1:8/A person with divided loyalty is unsettled in all their ways.
59:1:9/Let the lowly brother or sister take pride in their high position;
59:1:10/But the rich should take pride in their humiliation—since they will pass away like a wildflower.
59:1:11/For the sun rises with scorching heat and withers the plant; its blossom falls, and its beauty is destroyed. In the same way, the rich will fade away even while they go about their business.
59:1:12/Blessed is the one who perseveres under trial because, having stood the test, that person will receive the crown of life that the Lord has promised to those who love him.
59:1:13/No one should say, "God is tempting me." For God cannot be tempted by evil, nor does he tempt anyone;
59:1:14/But each person is tempted when they are dragged away by their own evil desire and enticed.
59:1:15/Then, after desire has conceived, it gives birth to sin; and sin, when it is full-grown, gives birth to death.
59:1:16/Don't be deceived, my dear brothers and sisters.
59:1:17/Every good and perfect gift is from above, coming down from the Father of the heavenly lights, who does not change like shifting shadows.
59:1:18/He chose to give us birth through the word of truth, that we might be a kind of firstfruits of all he created.
59:1:19/So then, my beloved brothers and sisters, let everyone be quick to listen, slow to speak, and slow to become angry,
59:1:20/For human anger does not produce the righteousness that God desires.
59:1:21/Therefore, get rid of all moral filth and the excess of wickedness, and humbly accept the word planted in you, which can save your souls.
59:1:22/But don't just listen to the word, and so deceive yourselves. Do what it says.
59:1:23/Anyone who listens to the word but does not do what it says is like someone who looks at their face in a mirror
59:1:24/And, after looking at themselves, goes away and immediately forgets what they look like.
59:1:25/But whoever looks intently into the perfect law that gives freedom, and continues in it—not forgetting what they have heard, but doing it—they will be blessed in what they do.
59:1:26/If anyone considers themselves religious and yet does not keep a tight rein on their tongue, they deceive themselves, and their religion is worthless.
59:1:27/Religion that God our Father accepts as pure and faultless is this: to look after orphans and widows in their distress and to keep oneself from being polluted by the world.
59:2:1/My friends, don't hold the faith of our Lord Jesus Christ, the glorious Lord, with favoritism.
59:2:2/For if a man wearing a gold ring and fine clothes comes into your meeting, and a poor man in shabby clothes also comes in;
59:2:3/And you pay special attention to the one wearing the fine clothes and say, "Sit here in a good spot," but say to the poor man, "Stand over there" or "Sit at my feet";
59:2:4/Aren't you then discriminating among yourselves and become judges with evil thoughts?
59:2:5/Listen, my dear friends, hasn't God chosen those who are poor in the eyes of the world to be rich in faith and to inherit the kingdom he promised those who love him?
59:2:6/But you have dishonored the poor. Isn't it the rich who exploit you and drag you into court?
59:2:7/Aren't they the ones who slander the noble name by which you were called?
59:2:8/If you really keep the royal law found in Scripture, "Love your neighbor as yourself," you are doing right.
59:2:9/But if you show favoritism, you sin and are convicted by the law as lawbreakers.
59:2:10/For whoever keeps the whole law but fails in one point has become guilty of all of it.
59:2:11/For the one who said, "Do not commit adultery," also said, "Do not murder." If you do not commit adultery but do murder, you have become a lawbreaker.
59:2:12/So speak and act as those who are going to be judged by the law that gives freedom.
59:2:13/Because judgment without mercy will be shown to anyone who has not been merciful. Mercy triumphs over judgment.
59:2:14/What good is it, my friends, if someone claims to have faith but has no deeds? Can such faith save them?
59:2:15/If a brother or sister is without clothes and daily food,
59:2:16/And one of you says to them, "Go in peace; keep warm and well fed," but does nothing about their physical needs, what good is it?
59:2:17/In the same way, faith by itself, if it is not accompanied by action, is dead.
59:2:18/But someone will say, "You have faith; I have deeds." Show me your faith without deeds, and I will show you my faith by my deeds.
59:2:19/You believe that there is one God. Good! Even the demons believe that—and shudder.
59:2:20/But do you want to know, you foolish person, that faith without deeds is useless?
59:2:21/Wasn't Abraham our father justified by works when he offered his son Isaac on the altar?
59:2:22/Do you see that faith was working together with his works, and by works, faith was made complete?
59:2:23/And the Scripture was fulfilled that says, "Abraham believed God, and it was credited to him as righteousness," and he was called God's friend.
59:2:24/You see that a person is justified by works and not by faith alone.
59:2:25/In the same way, wasn't Rahab the prostitute justified by works when she received the messengers and sent them out by another way?
59:2:26/For just as the body without the spirit is dead, so also faith without deeds is dead.
59:3:1/My friends, don't rush to become leaders, knowing that we will face stricter judgment.
59:3:2/We all make many mistakes. If anyone can speak without fault, they're perfect and can control their entire body.
59:3:3/Consider how we put bits into horses' mouths so they obey us, and we can guide their whole body.
59:3:4/Likewise, huge ships, though pushed by strong winds, are steered by a tiny rudder wherever the pilot wants to go.
59:3:5/In the same way, the tongue is a small part of the body but it boasts of great exploits. See how a small spark can set a great forest on fire!
59:3:6/And the tongue is a fire, a world of wrongdoing. It contaminates the whole body and sets the course of life on fire, and is itself set on fire by hell.
59:3:7/Every kind of animal, bird, reptile, and sea creature can be tamed and has been tamed by humanity,
59:3:8/But no one can tame the tongue; it is a restless evil, full of deadly poison.
59:3:9/With it we praise our Lord and Father, and with it we curse people, who are made in God's likeness.
59:3:10/From the same mouth come both blessing and cursing. My friends, this should not be.
59:3:11/Can a spring pour forth both fresh and salt water from the same opening?
59:3:12/Can a fig tree, my friends, produce olives, or a grapevine produce figs? Neither can a salt spring produce fresh water.
59:3:13/Who is wise and understanding among you? Let them show it by their good life, by deeds done in the humility that comes from wisdom.
59:3:14/But if you harbor bitter envy and selfish ambition in your hearts, do not boast about it or deny the truth.
59:3:15/This kind of wisdom does not come down from heaven but is earthly, unspiritual, demonic.
59:3:16/For where you have envy and selfish ambition, there you find disorder and every evil practice.
59:3:17/But the wisdom that comes from heaven is first of all pure; then peace-loving, considerate, submissive, full of mercy and good fruit, impartial and sincere.
59:3:18/And peacemakers who sow in peace reap a harvest of righteousness.
59:4:1/Where do conflicts and quarrels among you come from? Don't they arise from your desires that battle within you?
59:4:2/You desire but do not have, so you kill. You covet but cannot get what you want, so you quarrel and fight. You do not have because you do not ask.
59:4:3/When you ask, you do not receive, because you ask with wrong motives, so that you may spend what you get on your pleasures.
59:4:4/You adulterous people, don't you know that friendship with the world means hostility against God? Therefore, anyone who chooses to be a friend of the world becomes an enemy of God.
59:4:5/Do you think Scripture says without reason that the spirit he caused to live in us envies intensely?
59:4:6/But he gives us more grace. That's why Scripture says: God opposes the proud but shows favor to the humble.
59:4:7/Therefore, submit yourselves to God. Resist the devil, and he will flee from you.
59:4:8/Come close to God, and he will come close to you. Wash your hands, you sinners, and purify your hearts, you double-minded.
59:4:9/Grieve, mourn, and weep. Turn your laughter into mourning and your joy into despair.
59:4:10/Humble yourselves before the Lord, and he will lift you up.
59:4:11/Do not speak evil against each other, brothers and sisters. Whoever speaks against a brother or sister or judges them speaks against the law and judges it. When you judge the law, you are not keeping it, but sitting in judgment on it.
59:4:12/There is only one Lawgiver and Judge, the one who can save and destroy. But you—who are you to judge your neighbor?
59:4:13/Now listen, you who say, "Today or tomorrow we will go to this or that city, spend a year there, carry on business, and make money."
59:4:14/You do not even know what will happen tomorrow. What is your life? You are a mist that appears for a little while and then vanishes.
59:4:15/Instead, you ought to say, "If it is the Lord's will, we will live and do this or that."
59:4:16/But now you boast in your arrogant schemes. All such boasting is evil.
59:4:17/So then, if you know the good you ought to do and don't do it, you sin.
59:5:1/Listen up, you rich people, cry and wail because of the misery that's coming your way.
59:5:2/Your wealth has rotted away, and your clothes are moth-eaten.
59:5:3/Your gold and silver have tarnished, and their rust will testify against you and consume your flesh like fire. You've hoarded wealth in these last days.
59:5:4/Look, the wages you failed to pay the workers who mowed your fields are crying out against you. The cries of the harvesters have reached the ears of the Lord Almighty.
59:5:5/You've lived in luxury and self-indulgence on the earth. You've fattened yourselves for the day of slaughter.
59:5:6/You've condemned and murdered the righteous, who did not resist you.
59:5:7/So be patient, brothers and sisters, until the Lord's coming. See how the farmer waits for the land to yield its valuable crop, patiently waiting for the autumn and spring rains.
59:5:8/You too, be patient and stand firm, because the Lord's coming is near.
59:5:9/Don't grumble against one another, brothers and sisters, or you will be judged. The Judge is standing at the door!
59:5:10/Brothers and sisters, take the prophets who spoke in the Lord's name as an example of patience in the face of suffering.
59:5:11/As you know, we consider blessed those who have persevered. You have heard of Job's perseverance and have seen what the Lord finally brought about. The Lord is full of compassion and mercy.
59:5:12/Above all, my brothers and sisters, do not swear—not by heaven or by earth or by anything else. Let your "yes" be yes, and your "no," no, or you will be condemned.
59:5:13/Is anyone among you in trouble? Let them pray. Is anyone happy? Let them sing songs of praise.
59:5:14/Is anyone among you sick? Let them call the elders of the church to pray over them and anoint them with oil in the name of the Lord.
59:5:15/And the prayer offered in faith will make the sick person well; the Lord will raise them up. If they have sinned, they will be forgiven.
59:5:16/Confess your sins to each other and pray for each other so that you may be healed. The prayer of a righteous person is powerful and effective.
59:5:17/Elijah was a human being, even as we are. He prayed earnestly that it would not rain, and it did not rain on the land for three and a half years.
59:5:18/Then he prayed again, and the heavens gave rain, and the earth produced its crops.
59:5:19/Brothers and sisters, if one of you should wander from the truth and someone should bring that person back,
59:5:20/remember this: Whoever turns a sinner from the error of their way will save them from death and cover over a multitude of sins.
60:1:1/Peter, an apostle of Jesus Christ, to those who are living as foreigners scattered throughout Pontus, Galatia, Cappadocia, Asia, and Bithynia,
60:1:2/Chosen according to God the Father's foreknowledge, through the sanctifying work of the Spirit, for obedience and for the sprinkling with Jesus Christ's blood: May grace and peace be abundantly yours.
60:1:3/Praise be to the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who in his great mercy has given us a new birth into a living hope through the resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead,
60:1:4/To an inheritance that is imperishable, undefiled, and unfading, kept in heaven for you,
60:1:5/Who are protected by God's power through faith for a salvation ready to be revealed in the last time.
60:1:6/In this you greatly rejoice, though now for a little while you may have had to suffer grief in all kinds of trials.
60:1:7/So that the genuineness of your faith, more precious than gold that perishes even though refined by fire, may result in praise, glory, and honor at the revelation of Jesus Christ.
60:1:8/Though you have not seen him, you love him; and even though you do not see him now, you believe in him and are filled with an inexpressible and glorious joy,
60:1:9/For you are receiving the outcome of your faith, the salvation of your souls.
60:1:10/Concerning this salvation, the prophets, who spoke of the grace that was to come to you, searched intently and with great care,
60:1:11/Trying to find out the time and circumstances to which the Spirit of Christ in them was pointing when he predicted the sufferings of Christ and the glories that would follow.
60:1:12/It was revealed to them that they were not serving themselves but you, when they spoke of the things that have now been told you by those who have preached the gospel to you by the Holy Spirit sent from heaven. Even angels long to look into these things.
60:1:13/Therefore, prepare your minds for action; be self-controlled; set your hope fully on the grace to be given you when Jesus Christ is revealed.
60:1:14/As obedient children, do not conform to the evil desires you had when you lived in ignorance.
60:1:15/But just as he who called you is holy, so be holy in all you do;
60:1:16/For it is written: "Be holy, because I am holy."
60:1:17/And if you call on the Father, who judges each person's work impartially, live out your time as foreigners here in reverent fear.
60:1:18/For you know that it was not with perishable things such as silver or gold that you were redeemed from the empty way of life handed down to you from your ancestors,
60:1:19/But with the precious blood of Christ, a lamb without blemish or defect.
60:1:20/He was chosen before the creation of the world, but was revealed in these last times for your sake.
60:1:21/Through him you believe in God, who raised him from the dead and glorified him, and so your faith and hope are in God.
60:1:22/Now that you have purified yourselves by obeying the truth so that you have sincere love for each other, love one another deeply, from the heart.
60:1:23/For you have been born again, not of perishable seed, but of imperishable, through the living and enduring word of God.
60:1:24/For all people are like grass, and all their glory is like the flowers of the field; the grass withers and the flowers fall,
60:1:25/But the word of the Lord endures forever. And this is the word that was preached to you.
60:2:1/So, put away all malice, deceit, hypocrisy, envy, and all forms of slander.
60:2:2/Like newborn infants, long for the pure spiritual milk, so that by it you may grow up into salvation—
60:2:3/if indeed you have tasted that the Lord is good.
60:2:4/As you come to him, a living stone rejected by humans but chosen by God and precious to him,
60:2:5/you also, like living stones, are being built into a spiritual house to be a holy priesthood, offering spiritual sacrifices acceptable to God through Jesus Christ.
60:2:6/For it stands in Scripture: "Look, I am laying in Zion a chosen, precious cornerstone; and whoever believes in him will not be put to shame."
60:2:7/So then, for you who believe, he is precious; but for those who do not believe, "The stone that the builders rejected has become the cornerstone,"
60:2:8/and "a stone of stumbling, and a rock of offense." They stumble because they disobey the word, as they were destined to do.
60:2:9/But you are a chosen race, a royal priesthood, a holy nation, a people for his own possession, that you may proclaim the excellencies of him who called you out of darkness into his marvelous light.
60:2:10/Once you were not a people, but now you are God's people; once you had not received mercy, but now you have received mercy.
60:2:11/Beloved, I urge you as sojourners and exiles to abstain from the passions of the flesh, which wage war against your soul.
60:2:12/Keep your conduct among the Gentiles honorable, so that when they speak against you as evildoers, they may see your good deeds and glorify God on the day of visitation.
60:2:13/Be subject for the Lord's sake to every human institution, whether it be to the emperor as supreme,
60:2:14/or to governors as sent by him to punish those who do evil and to praise those who do good.
60:2:15/For this is the will of God, that by doing good you should put to silence the ignorance of foolish people.
60:2:16/Live as people who are free, not using your freedom as a cover-up for evil, but living as servants of God.
60:2:17/Respect everyone, love the brotherhood, fear God, honor the emperor.
60:2:18/Servants, be subject to your masters with all respect, not only to the good and gentle but also to the unjust.
60:2:19/For this is a gracious thing, when, mindful of God, one endures sorrows while suffering unjustly.
60:2:20/For what credit is it if, when you sin and are beaten for it, you endure? But if when you do good and suffer for it you endure, this is a grace before God.
60:2:21/For to this you have been called, because Christ also suffered for you, leaving you an example, so that you might follow in his steps.
60:2:22/He committed no sin, neither was deceit found in his mouth.
60:2:23/When he was insulted, he did not retaliate; when he suffered, he did not threaten, but continued entrusting himself to the one who judges justly.
60:2:24/He himself bore our sins in his body on the cross, so that we might die to sins and live for righteousness; by his wounds you have been healed.
60:2:25/For you were straying like sheep, but have now returned to the Shepherd and Overseer of your souls.
60:3:1/Similarly, wives, be supportive of your own husbands; so that even if some do not believe the word, they may be won over without words by the behavior of their wives,
60:3:2/When they see your pure and respectful behavior.
60:3:3/Do not let your beauty come from outward adornment, such as elaborate hairstyles and the wearing of gold jewelry or fine clothes.
60:3:4/Rather, it should be that of your inner self, the unfading beauty of a gentle and quiet spirit, which is of great worth in God’s sight.
60:3:5/For this is how the holy women of the past who put their hope in God used to adorn themselves. They submitted themselves to their own husbands,
60:3:6/Like Sarah, who obeyed Abraham and called him her lord. You are her daughters if you do what is right and do not give way to fear.
60:3:7/Likewise, husbands, live with your wives in an understanding way, showing honor to the woman as the weaker partner, since they are heirs with you of the gracious gift of life, so that nothing will hinder your prayers.
60:3:8/Finally, all of you, be like-minded, be sympathetic, love one another, be compassionate and humble.
60:3:9/Do not repay evil with evil or insult with insult. On the contrary, repay evil with blessing, because to this you were called so that you may inherit a blessing.
60:3:10/For whoever desires to love life and see good days, let him keep his tongue from evil and his lips from speaking deceit.
60:3:11/Let him turn away from evil and do good; let him seek peace and pursue it.
60:3:12/For the eyes of the Lord are on the righteous, and his ears are attentive to their prayer, but the face of the Lord is against those who do evil.
60:3:13/Who is going to harm you if you are eager to do good?
60:3:14/But even if you should suffer for what is right, you are blessed. Do not fear their threats; do not be frightened.
60:3:15/But in your hearts revere Christ as Lord. Always be prepared to give an answer to everyone who asks you to give the reason for the hope that you have. But do this with gentleness and respect,
60:3:16/Keeping a clear conscience, so that those who speak maliciously against your good behavior in Christ may be ashamed of their slander.
60:3:17/For it is better, if it is God’s will, to suffer for doing good than for doing evil.
60:3:18/For Christ also suffered once for sins, the righteous for the unrighteous, to bring you to God. He was put to death in the body but made alive in the Spirit,
60:3:19/Through whom also he went and preached to the spirits in prison,
60:3:20/Who were disobedient long ago when God waited patiently in the days of Noah while the ark was being built. In it only a few people, eight in all, were saved through water,
60:3:21/And this water symbolizes baptism that now saves you also—not the removal of dirt from the body but the pledge of a clear conscience toward God. It saves you by the resurrection of Jesus Christ,
60:3:22/Who has gone into heaven and is at God’s right hand—with angels, authorities, and powers in submission to him.
60:4:1/Since Christ suffered in the flesh for us, you should also prepare yourself with the same mindset: because someone who has suffered in the flesh is done with sin;
60:4:2/So that they no longer spend their remaining life chasing human desires, but doing the will of God.
60:4:3/The time we've already spent living like non-believers should be enough, when we indulged in sexual immorality, lusts, excessive drinking, wild parties, feasting, and detestable idol worship;
60:4:4/They find it odd that you don't join them in their reckless, wild living and they badmouth you for it;
60:4:5/They will have to explain themselves to the one who is ready to judge the living and the dead.
60:4:6/This is why the Good News was also preached to those who are now dead, so that although they were judged in the flesh like everyone else, they might live in the spirit according to God's will.
60:4:7/But the end of all things is near: so be self-controlled and alert for prayer.
60:4:8/Most importantly, love each other deeply, because love covers over a multitude of sins.
60:4:9/Be hospitable to one another without complaining.
60:4:10/Just as each one has received a gift, use it to serve others, as good managers of God's varied grace.
60:4:11/If anyone speaks, they should do so as one conveying the words of God. If anyone serves, they should do so with the strength God provides, so that in all things God may be praised through Jesus Christ. To him belong glory and power forever and ever. Amen.
60:4:12/Dear friends, don't be surprised at the fiery ordeal that has come to test you, as though something strange were happening to you.
60:4:13/But rejoice insofar as you share Christ's sufferings, so that you may also rejoice and be glad when his glory is revealed.
60:4:14/If you are insulted because of the name of Christ, you are blessed, for the Spirit of glory and of God rests on you. They may slander him, but you glorify him.
60:4:15/Make sure none of you suffers as a murderer, thief, criminal, or as a meddler in other people's affairs.
60:4:16/However, if anyone suffers as a Christian, they should not be ashamed, but should glorify God because of it.
60:4:17/For it's time for judgment to begin with God's household; and if it starts with us, what will the outcome be for those who do not obey the gospel of God?
60:4:18/And if it is hard for the righteous to be saved, what will become of the ungodly and the sinner?
60:4:19/So then, those who suffer according to God's will should commit themselves to their faithful Creator and continue to do good.
60:5:1/I urge the elders among you, as a fellow elder and witness of Christ's sufferings, and one who will share in the glory to come:
60:5:2/Take care of God's flock that is under your care, watching over them not because you must, but because you are willing, as God wants you to be; not pursuing dishonest gain, but eager to serve;
60:5:3/Not lording it over those entrusted to you, but being examples to the flock.
60:5:4/And when the Chief Shepherd appears, you will receive the crown of glory that will never fade away.
60:5:5/In the same way, you who are younger, submit yourselves to your elders. All of you, clothe yourselves with humility toward one another, because God opposes the proud but shows favor to the humble.
60:5:6/So humble yourselves under God's mighty hand, that he may lift you up in due time.
60:5:7/Cast all your anxiety on him because he cares for you.
60:5:8/Stay alert and of sober mind. Your enemy the devil prowls around like a roaring lion looking for someone to devour.
60:5:9/Resist him, standing firm in the faith, because you know that the family of believers throughout the world is undergoing the same kind of sufferings.
60:5:10/And after you have suffered a little while, the God of all grace, who has called you to his eternal glory in Christ, will himself restore you and make you strong, firm and steadfast.
60:5:11/To him be the power for ever and ever. Amen.
60:5:12/Through Silvanus, whom I consider a faithful brother, I have written to you briefly, encouraging you and testifying that this is the true grace of God. Stand fast in it.
60:5:13/The church in Babylon, chosen together with you, sends you greetings, and so does my son Mark.
60:5:14/Greet each other with a kiss of love. Peace to all of you who are in Christ.
61:1:1/Simon Peter, a servant and an apostle of Jesus Christ, to those who have received a faith as precious as ours through the righteousness of God and our Savior Jesus Christ:
61:1:2/May grace and peace be abundantly increased to you through the knowledge of God, and of Jesus our Lord,
61:1:3/As His divine power has granted us everything necessary for life and godliness, through the knowledge of Him who called us by His own glory and goodness.
61:1:4/Through these, He has given us his very great and precious promises, so that through them you may participate in the divine nature, having escaped the corruption in the world caused by evil desires.
61:1:5/For this very reason, make every effort to supplement your faith with virtue; and virtue with knowledge;
61:1:6/And knowledge with self-control; and self-control with endurance; and endurance with godliness;
61:1:7/And godliness with brotherly affection; and brotherly affection with love.
61:1:8/For if you possess these qualities in increasing measure, they will keep you from being ineffective or unproductive in your knowledge of our Lord Jesus Christ.
61:1:9/But anyone who does not have them is nearsighted and blind, forgetting that they have been cleansed from their past sins.
61:1:10/Therefore, my brothers and sisters, make every effort to confirm your calling and election. For if you do these things, you will never stumble,
61:1:11/And you will receive a rich welcome into the eternal kingdom of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ.
61:1:12/So I will always remind you of these things, even though you know them and are firmly established in the truth you now have.
61:1:13/I think it is right to refresh your memory as long as I live in the tent of this body,
61:1:14/Knowing that I will soon put it aside, as our Lord Jesus Christ has made clear to me.
61:1:15/And I will make every effort to ensure that after my departure you will always be able to remember these things.
61:1:16/For we did not follow cleverly invented stories when we told you about the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ in power, but we were eyewitnesses of his majesty.
61:1:17/For he received honor and glory from God the Father when the voice came to him from the Majestic Glory, saying, "This is my Son, whom I love; with him I am well pleased."
61:1:18/We ourselves heard this voice that came from heaven when we were with him on the sacred mountain.
61:1:19/We also have the prophetic message as something completely reliable, and you will do well to pay attention to it, as to a light shining in a dark place, until the day dawns and the morning star rises in your hearts.
61:1:20/Above all, you must understand that no prophecy of Scripture came about by the prophet's own interpretation of things.
61:1:21/For prophecy never had its origin in the human will, but prophets, though human, spoke from God as they were carried along by the Holy Spirit.
61:2:1/But there were false prophets among the people, just as there will be false teachers among you. They will secretly introduce destructive heresies, even denying the Lord who redeemed them, bringing swift destruction upon themselves.
61:2:2/And many will follow their destructive ways, because of which the way of truth will be maligned.
61:2:3/Driven by greed, they will exploit you with fabricated stories. Their condemnation has long been hanging over them, and their destruction is not asleep.
61:2:4/For if God did not spare the angels who sinned, but cast them into hell, delivering them to chains of darkness to be held for judgment;
61:2:5/And did not spare the ancient world, but preserved Noah, a herald of righteousness, with seven others when he brought a flood upon the world of the ungodly;
61:2:6/And if he condemned the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah to destruction by reducing them to ashes, making them an example of what is going to happen to the ungodly;
61:2:7/And rescued righteous Lot, distressed by the depraved conduct of the lawless
61:2:8/(For that righteous man, living among them day after day, was tormented in his righteous soul by the lawless deeds he saw and heard);
61:2:9/The Lord knows how to rescue the godly from trials and to keep the unrighteous under punishment for the day of judgment,
61:2:10/Especially those who follow the corrupt desire of the flesh and despise authority. Bold and arrogant, they are not afraid to heap abuse on celestial beings.
61:2:11/Even angels, although they are stronger and more powerful, do not heap abuse on such beings when bringing judgment before the Lord.
61:2:12/But these people, like irrational animals, creatures of instinct born to be caught and destroyed, slander what they do not understand, and will perish in their own corruption,
61:2:13/They will be paid back with harm for the harm they have done. Their idea of pleasure is to carouse in broad daylight. They are blots and blemishes, reveling in their pleasures while they feast with you.
61:2:14/With eyes full of adultery, they never stop sinning; they seduce the unstable; they are experts in greed—an accursed brood!
61:2:15/They have left the straight way and wandered off to follow the way of Balaam son of Beor, who loved the wages of wickedness.
61:2:16/But he was rebuked for his wrongdoing by a donkey—an animal without speech—who spoke with a human voice and restrained the prophet's madness.
61:2:17/These people are springs without water and mists driven by a storm. Blackest darkness is reserved for them.
61:2:18/For they mouth empty, boastful words and, by appealing to the lustful desires of the flesh, they entice people who have just escaped from those who live in error.
61:2:19/They promise them freedom, while they themselves are slaves of depravity—for people are slaves to whatever has mastered them.
61:2:20/If they have escaped the corruption of the world by knowing our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ and are again entangled in it and overcome, the final state is worse for them than the first.
61:2:21/It would have been better for them not to have known the way of righteousness, than to have known it and then to turn their backs on the sacred command that was passed on to them.
61:2:22/But it has happened to them according to the true proverb: "A dog returns to its vomit," and, "A sow that is washed returns to her wallowing in the mud."
61:3:1/This second letter, dear friends, I am writing to you; in both, I aim to refresh your pure minds by reminding you:
61:3:2/So that you remember the words previously spoken by the holy prophets, and the command given by us, the apostles of the Lord and Savior:
61:3:3/Firstly, understand that in the last days, there will be mockers, driven by their own desires,
61:3:4/And they will ask, "Where is the promise of His coming? For since our ancestors died, everything has remained the same since the world was created."
61:3:5/They choose to ignore that long ago, by God's word, the heavens existed and the earth was formed out of water and by water.
61:3:6/Through which the world of that time was flooded and destroyed.
61:3:7/But by the same word, the present heavens and earth are reserved for fire, being kept for the day of judgment and destruction of godless people.
61:3:8/But, dear friends, do not forget this one thing: that with the Lord, a day is like a thousand years, and a thousand years are like a day.
61:3:9/The Lord is not slow in keeping His promise, as some understand slowness. Instead, He is patient with you, not wanting anyone to perish, but everyone to come to repentance.
61:3:10/But the day of the Lord will come like a thief. On that day, the heavens will disappear with a roar, the elements will be destroyed by fire, and the earth and everything done in it will be laid bare.
61:3:11/Since everything will be destroyed in this way, what kind of people ought you to be? You ought to live holy and godly lives,
